Pros: 1. Healthcare Benefits: Medical Insurance: Comprehensive medical coverage for employees and their dependents. Dental and Vision Insurance: Coverage for dental and vision care expenses. Mental Health Support: Access to counseling and mental health services. 2. Financial Benefits: Stock Options: Stock options or grants to allow employees to share in the company’s success. Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP): Allows employees to purchase Cisco stock at a discounted price. Financial Counseling: Financial planning and counseling services. 3. Work-Life Balance: Paid Time Off (PTO): Vacation, holidays, and paid time off benefits. Flexible Work Hours: Flexible work schedules and options for remote work. Parental Leave: Paid time off for new parents, including maternity and paternity leave. Sabbatical Leave: Opportunities for extended time off after a certain number of years of service. 4. Career Development: Training and Development: Access to training programs and resources to enhance skills and knowledge. Tuition Assistance: Financial support for employees pursuing further education or professional development. Career Counseling: Guidance for career development and advancement within the company. 5. Health and Wellness: Wellness Programs: Programs and resources to promote employee health and well-being. Fitness Benefits: Gym memberships or fitness-related reimbursements. Health Screenings: Regular health check-ups and screenings. 6. Employee Assistance Programs (EAP): Counseling Services: Confidential counseling and support services for personal and work-related issues. Legal and Financial Consultations: Access to legal and financial advice. 7. Other Perks: Employee Discounts: Discounts on Cisco products and services. Transportation Benefits: Commuter benefits, transportation subsidies, or parking discounts. Social and Recreational Activities: Company-sponsored events and activities for employees and their families.
Cons: 1. Unequal Distribution: Depending on the hierarchical structure, higher-ranking employees might have access to significantly better benefits than lower-ranking employees, leading to disparities within the workforce. 2. Global Disparities: Benefits can vary significantly between Cisco employees in different countries due to varying regulations and company policies, leading to disparities in employee experiences.

Pros: I spend close to 10 years (2012-2022) across various sales/account management roles in inside sales, PSU, SMB, etc. So I guess my 2 cents would give some value: -Sales and customer focused. -If you enjoy high pressure sales environment, a great place to be. -Org takes care of the employees/ benefits. I mean it. benefits, business travel quality, etc. -Great bonding & relationship with fellow peers. -Sales performers are rewarded and recognized. A very satisfying feeling that money cannot buy. (sales champions, chairmans club ,etc) -Great products, strong channel & partner ecosystem. -Partners, customers respect the brand. Makes the selling fun, challenging and a bit easy. -Account manager have power, authority and accountability. -Entire org will come forward to win a deal for and with you. -Fast, less bureaucratic, focus on execution and speed.
Cons:
-The experience is not uniform and will vary from team to team, manager to manager. While I was fortunate to have amazing managers, peers, I did see certain segments /managers were toxic, career derailing for a few of my friends. Situation can get political/diplomatic. -unrealistic sales number pressure. -you need a bit of luck -commit pressure is unreal at time. (you will love it or hate it) -not every product sells. For eg servers, webex, security sales is tough. So if you are getting in these product sales role - do your research. -The IT hardware is getting commoditized with transformation of SAAS, cloud. Has lots a bit of its charm in recent years. -Cloud, SAAS, Security is paying better these days. (2023). -Career movement / horizontally/ globally is limited. -work life balance very bad if you are in India. I have spend 70% of my weekends working (no one asks, but expects). Something that flows from top, especially in India. Not sure if that has changed since 2022.
-No career/skip manager discussions for professional growth. 

I left Cisco in 2022 as I didn't see any guidance on career growth, plan. I was getting bored. I went ahead for an interview outside to merely assess my market value and get some insights outside of Cisco world. I was shocked at the industry comp being offered. (mind you, i never asked for a single raise. I just believed in Cisco).  Having said, Cisco has been wonderful in so many ways for me. I'll always be grateful and Cisco will always hold a special place. There is never a dull moment and it will prepare you for your future.  I was lucky to be a Cisco.

Pros: I guess you could say 401k match is comparable to other competitors. Health care options - HMO / PPO with excellent benefits (like low co-pay, etc.) ESPP are a good benefit you should take advantage of. Work from home option is a perk. There are a lot of excellent engineers with a breadth of knowledge that you can reach out to for assistance. Most are willing to help and are friendly. People are smart here. For the most part. There are bonuses as well. Paid bi-annually. Amount is based on your grade / company performance / personal performance.
Cons: Let's list them: 1- middle managers are more or less cheerleaders. Esp people managers. They are also bogged down in a lot of busy meetings. So, you get ignored, for the most part. Not because of you. They are too busy. In busy meetings. Which are stacked. 2 - career stagnation. you will not move ANYWHERE unless you apply internally, which takes, what? 15 to 25 internal interviews? this is pointless and discouraging. 3 - constant layoffs. not always based on performance. in fact, the reason is never revealed to you. So no one knows why / how they were targeted. And its usually annually. right before X-Mas holidays. NICE. Cisco LOVES RIFs. And the funny thing is, they encourage you to apply internally. As if its that easy. See above. 4 - stock price is stagnant and not going anywhere. And hasn't gone anywhere for a lot of years. Well, maybe it trickled up by a few dollars per share. So those RSU benefits I listed above? You won't get rich, folks. 5 - Pointless numerous meetings with people managers, bi-weekly, 1:1. Expecting us to "grow, grow, grow." God forbid you don't look busy on your timesheets for your billing hours. They also expect you to know the management chain. When you are near the bottom. OKAY. Sure, I will memorize the names and roles of those 6 layers up, and talk candidly about their visions and what they are seeking. 6 - Mgmt - If you have a toxic manager, you will have a miserable experience. Because this company is stagnant. So you are stuck on the team unless you apply internally. And of course, pass those 25 interviews. Which can take a year and a half. 7 - Upper Mgmt - Don't ever reach out directly to them unless you want to get burnt. They expect you to reach out to their assistant directly. Assuming they have an assistant. They can't / won't be bothered. 8 - Internal technical training - yes they have it. And its not the best. Try 3rd party vendors which are far superior, like INE. 9 - Salary increase. Doesn't exist. And if it does, its basically nothing. Better to simply quit and come back as a different grade. Also salaries are on lower end of the spectrum in a comparable role at a competitor. Salaries depend quite a bit on your geographic region as well.

Pros: Remote work 100% in some roles/business units. Bonuses around 10-15%. Extreme flexibility with location -- my department didn't care if people wanted to relocate (to other countries even!). Decent work/life balance.
Cons: Remote culture means it's hard to build connections. Lack of leadership vision. Every quarter it was all about VP shuffling. Very hard to get promoted, very hard to get salary lift. I was there for 3 years before they offered me equity (a very paltry 5-figure amount to be paid over 4 years). Salary is nowhere near FAANG equivalent. 2x year layoffs. US health insurance was very Cali-focused, so if you're trying to use it or live outside of California, be prepared for $$$ visits and prescriptions. There isn't a lot of prestige to the Cisco name anymore (despite what they tell you internally). Cisco bungled the WebEx opportunity during the pandemic. If you are still early and energetic in your career, get what you can out of the experience in a year or two, and plan to leave. For those of you mid-late career, this could be a good place to 'rest and vest' if you can survive the layoff seasons.

Pros: Health Insurance: Most companies, including Cisco, offer health insurance benefits to their employees. This is an important benefit as it covers medical expenses and provides financial security for the employee and their family. Retirement Plans: Many companies offer retirement plans such as 401(k) or pension plans. Cisco's retirement plan may include matching contributions to the employee's savings. Life Insurance: Cisco may offer life insurance benefits that provide financial support to the employee's beneficiaries in the event of their death.
Cons: Cost: While employee benefits are designed to be a benefit to the employee, some benefits can be expensive. Employees may have to pay a portion of the cost of their benefits package, which can be a financial burden. Limited Coverage: Not all benefits packages offer comprehensive coverage. Some benefits may have exclusions or limitations that could limit the employee's access to the care they need. Inflexibility: Some benefits packages may not be flexible enough to meet the needs of all employees. This could include limitations on vacation time, inflexible work schedules, or rigid healthcare options.

Pros: High-Quality Products: Cisco's products are known for their high quality, reliability, and performance. This makes them a popular choice for businesses of all sizes. Advanced Security Features: Cisco's security appliances are some of the most advanced in the industry, with features like intrusion prevention, firewall, and VPN capabilities. Excellent Technical Support: Cisco offers excellent technical support to its customers, with a variety of resources available online, as well as phone and email support.
Cons: Limited Customization: Cisco's products can be less customizable than those of some of its competitors, which can be a drawback for businesses with specific needs. Steep Learning Curve: Cisco's products require a certain level of technical expertise to use effectively, which can be a barrier to adoption for some businesses. Competition: Cisco faces competition from other networking equipment and services providers, which can make it challenging to maintain market share and profitability over time.

Every team uses a different tool and many internal processes are lightly documented if at all. Getting a technical document with an author, date or version on it is a rarity. This seems to be taking agile software engineering to the extreme edge of chaos!

Pros: As a Systems Engineer, I can confidently say that working in this role has been a fulfilling experience. The company culture is supportive, and the team is collaborative, making it easy to work on complex projects. The management is approachable, and they provide the necessary resources to help us excel in our work. The compensation and benefits package is competitive, which makes it an attractive career option. Overall, it's a great place to work as a Systems Engineer, and I highly recommend it to anyone who is passionate about technology and looking to build a successful career.
Cons: One potential con for being a Systems Engineer is that the job can be very demanding and require long hours, especially when working on complex projects or dealing with urgent issues.

Pros: I was brought in, as most, through acquisition of my startup. • Since we were a successful startup, the people who came along were phenomenal, smart, friendly and we were all in-house... pre-covid. • My team supported product, spoke to the customer and brought those insights into the ecosystem • Nice RSU structure. • Pay was not competitive, but the bonus and RSUs were solid.
Cons: • Layoffs at Cisco occur one to two times a year. Often big. • After we were absorbed, people left and we became just an employee number. • Job position/title leveling. It happens in the first 3 months. You are moved to a more junior level. Good luck trying to find a promotion.

Pros: As a full time employee, the benefits are many, employees are pampered. Work environment is very friendly, open culture, zero micro management. Flexibility in working hours. Work from Anywhere is allowed 1:1 with reporting manager once a week Quarterly development review with reporting manager once every Quarter. Opportunities for doing stretch assignment with other teams Career development is encouraged, company invests in developing your skillset.
Cons: During Internal Transfer, It is very difficult to get the company to pay you on par with someone who is hired from external organization for the same role. Annual performance review works great if manager has a good opinion irrespective of what/how much work was done. Annual appraisal, stock options, bonus amount etc are perks reserved for manager's favorite.

Pros: Solutions continue to get better. Work, Life, Balance is for real and led by example. Pay is competitive. Benefits are top notch for those with families. Upper Management is top notch (Chuck and Fran are sincere executives who truly care about their employees. Our feedback is acted on) Best example I can give is we have 3 kids, all played competitive sports including summer travel. Today 2 of them are Collegiate Athletes in 2 different States. I have been able to attend over 90% of their events, even during Q4 and most understand what a struggle that is. (Note I do hit my annual numbers so that does make it easier I will admit)
Cons: Some customers can't get over the past (a poor experiance or poor support) no matter how much you show up. Its not personal. Comp Plan changes too much but we are evolving as a Company so it is expected, if you don't like change don't come here. Note this con can be for any job. My job has only been as good as the accounts I support and my team. Past 2 years I have had decent accounts, a great support team and great manager. Before that I was on my way out due to a poor manager and average accounts. You won't know this til you take the chance and join us. If you focus on the long game, the cons are single % and change is good.

Pros:
BFPWGP or Best Freaking Place to Work, Grow and Play!
I have been with Cisco for 11 years and I am truly excited each day because I have an opportunity to think about my current role, my opportunity to grow and most important my value to the community and believe it or not earth. 
In my role, i have learned so much about the importance of Sustainability and how WE need to sever the umbilical cord to Mother Earth. Cisco creates conscious citizens that are culturally responsible and push beyond their wildest imagination. Pros: First of all, Cisco is a really special company. There are so many supportive, talented individuals. It's just that the politics of leadership and lack of transparency in major decision making ruins it.
Cons: I work in AppD and we've just had a new leader come in from IOT. It's a disaster. He shows up to all-hands and talks a lot about mental health - but is nowhere to be seen for real, actual business decisions. It's all talk, not action. No focus on real, actionable things which would make people feel good about their work. No direction, no strategy and very limited support. It's a shame, as this is pushing great people out.

Pros: 1) Reasonable product design and delivery timelines. Has good processes that nobody follows. Good processes become bad processes if nobody follows them. 2) Company still has many great people and teams. 3) Good benefits. 4) Overall positive culture. 5) If you want to challenge yourself, you can easily do so. There are tons of hard engineering problems to crack. The company has no problem if you want to have a go at it.
Cons:
1) Sycophantic leadership chains that often care about titles and personal loyalty more than the merits of ideas or their direct reports. 2) Product management has often minimal knowledge of the industries they operate in, and often high turnover in product management. At the same time product management is given complete decision authority on features. 3) Slightly lower pay than the leading companies in Big Tech. 4) Random waves of layoffs that often impact great people, while the not-so-great people remain. Random waves of layoffs have been happening since 2014. Then they try to rehire. 5) 360 reviews are non-existent. If you have a problem with your manager, there is nobody to talk to on a regular basis. 6) Company is emotional and impulsive when it comes to 'disruptive' technologies. Instead of working internally on trying to develop products and technologies for new markets, the company prefers to acquire start-ups with great pitch books. Only to realize a couple of years later that it was too good to be true. Please perform due diligence.
7) In some JDM activities, brazen dishonesty is tolerated by the company from their counterparty. In other words, when a JDM partner substitutes its A-team for its F-team, Cisco turns a blind eye to it and does not demand accountability. As a result, Cisco ends up doing the work internally while pretending that the JDM did it.

Pros: Challenging yet flexible work environment, supportive of remote work. Good educational and social resources.
Cons: In IT, upper management is obsessed with transformation and service modernization, which is important. Teams which handle essential day-in, day-out operations support are less glamorous to management than teams which develop and promote new services. Consequentially there are poorly thought out reorganizations and layoffs every few years which lead to serious gaps in support and those depending on it being abandoned. Employees who remain can end up on teams where their roles, while still significant, are not aligned or relevant to what most of their other new team members do.

Pros: Great work culture and managers. Lot of projects (work) is available and people are available to help everywhere. The team culture in general is great across all teams. If you have to do anything with networks and networks is your long term career goal then there is absolutely no better place than Cisco. There is a LOT of training available , high end labs with tons of devices and opportunities to do so many industry level certificates and all this is free of cost.
Cons: At the end of the day it is a network support role after all. Even if you might take up a lot of automation python projects but you have to take care of your cases/.backlog. You might feel burnt out in few high severity cases as well (very similar to what software devs face when their 'feature' is about to 'go live') but that gets easier with time and experience. The nature of the job can be viewed in 2 ways : Positive : You are Sherlock Holmes who has to investigate and use your skills on multiple cases. Negative : Your work basically starts when things are going wrong. So you are almost always. dealing with a mental 'timer' as they are people waiting for you to provide solutions or answers and most of the times it is not easy. Multiple logs , timestamps, data correlation and since you are not the one who has written the code. Except few rare days mostly you will have a lot of emails to write and multiple logs to check. Salary growth can be slow ( as far as I am aware 10-18% is standard) however if your communication with management is positive and your manager assures you then it can be worth the wait. Exponential increment after a span of 2-3 years is common I have heard. This will vary a lot based on an individual's exp and work they have put in so not really a con. Lot of mandatory trainings :-P

Pros: Love all the people and focus on automation and innovation. People collaborate well and we have great tools like Webex that we all use and constantly improve. Security is a top priority and there is no doubt we'll continue to be a leader in the security space if we market it well. We do leadership training every year and are provided with industry training like agile principles, multi-cloud, troubleshooting, design thinking, customer service, and security. Sr management tries to communicate well, giving leaders a heads up, then letting everyone quickly know. We also love the inclusion of all people and how we celebrate people and customs from all parts of the world! Even our Russian employees were looked after without embracing what their country was doing. It was just amazing to watch how we cared for each other, as well as for people in Ukraine and our people helping others, especially in Poland.
Cons: Too many directives and micromanagement from above instead of letting Directors and Sr Managers lead and manage their budgets. For example, many still need SVP approval to travel. Layoffs are part of the company culture that is used even in the good times. People are brainwashed into thinking it is OK to treat people this way and they go along with it as they have no idea how it is to be in someone's shoes that were laid off. It is now even called a "Workforce Transition Options" as that sounds better than "layoff", and they really have no good options.

Pros: great coworkers, leadership team tries, good benefits
Cons: Layoffs ,“LR”s multiple times a year.. this really delays projects when you’re regularly losing a stakeholder or team member to LRs. During the beginning of the pandemic I was told repeatedly there was no guarantee my role was secure. The ceo claims he wont lay people off during the pandemic.. then 2 months later say theres going to be a massive layoff of 10-12% of the company in October. The additional stress and attempt to normalize the fear of losing your job constantly.. NO THANK YOU. Also huge RTP presence means lots of conservative, christian republicans. Lots of work needed in the D&I space. No formal review, no chance of promotion. People are treated as replaceable resources. 3 managers in 2 years. Didnt see a single team mate promoted in 3 years, even people that had been there 6+ years. Employees have Stockholm syndrome, “feel so lucky they survived the last LR”. The pay is horrrrible for the bay area and they do not give annual increases.. period. If youre lucky youll get a promotion every 5 years. If you are able to keep the same manager for more than 8 months. How this place makes it to the “best places to work” list..... they're clearly bribing someone.

Pros: - High caliber employees with high caliber results delivered - Great learning and development opportunities at all levels provided by Cisco - Great people that generally care about one another depending upon the department - Personally progressed several levels within my career, as a woman, with generally good support and coaching from leadership - Cisco tries to take care of their employees even in the hardest times such as redundancies - Work life balance could be good if you are in a supportive department allowing it
Cons: - Over the years as an acquisition of Cisco, they massively struggled with what to do with the AppD business. This had a major impact on innovation, strategy, and stable leadership of the AppD business. - Over the past year, Cisco is heavily focused on further integration of the AppD business creating fear-based dynamics of employees concerned about their job, pushiness when it comes to strategy moves, lack of care about impact to AppD functions and capacity drain on employees. - No psychological safety within the business at present - Employees that have been within the AppD business for years are expendable to Cisco; All executive leadership have exited and they are bringing in "Cisco people" to take over. - Some direction now in strategy, but who knows how long that will last as the trend as been to move in a certain direction and then it doesn't work out. As a hardware company, Cisco is struggling with what to do with AppD from a strategy perspective. - Work/life balance is a struggle in the Operations functions as Cisco tightens their purse strings but keeps dumping loads of work/expectations on an already lean team - Sales culture is very stressed due to all the extra burden being placed on them from an admin and process-oriented perspective. In addition, Enablement of Sales teams is a mess and creates confusion for Sales more than sets them up for success. - Extremely hard to get pay increases within teams for high performers. Wages are based on Cisco banding as a hardware company and Software companies in the market are offering significantly higher wages for the same roles. - Once Cisco came in to take over in the last year, they stopped listening to the advice of most tenured team members within AppD who knew the AppD business best. They made decisions without thinking of the impact for those "on the ground" doing the work. - New product launches going out without being fully operationalized. Rushed to market due to being behind and needing to catch up. Creating impact to Sales and potentially customer experience.

Pros: Very healthy salaries for the industry, and most jobs allow for fully remote work.
Cons: Cisco is slowly losing market share in most areas, and their only focus seems to be on switching customers to subscription models as opposed to actually developing anything truly groundbreaking. Almost 40 year old company, showing its age.

Pros: Work life balance and work from home

Pros:
Flexibility in how, when, and where you work is phenomenal for a company of this size.  It's a two-edged sword, but having the option to take a WebEx from home, Starbucks, airports, the beach, or in the office ... permits a level of versatility -- and fully acceptable by colleagues and management -- that would be hard to repeat elsewhere.  It's part of the culture.  The flipside is that work more easily creeps into your personal space and follows you on vacation if you're not careful.  Another consequence is that Cisco offices can feel like ghost towns.

Cisco has an immensely successful and rich portfolio and is well-positioned for the future.  But ... for the past few years, it has felt like Cisco is constantly trying to turn a corner ... and never quite making it.
Cons:
The biggest con nowadays is that Cisco is trying vigorously to grow income faster than revenue.  This translates to what seems like a never ending round of budget cuts and divestment.  Workforce reductions are becoming more common than pay raises and the value proposition to working here is becoming harder to defend.

Cisco has a severely bloated middle level of professionals.  Upward mobility is limited and the path can be vague.

Pros:
1. Great place to learn, amazing experts, who are eager to share their knowledge
2. Atmosphere of mutual respect, kindness, openness, being part of the team that has common goals
3. Atmosphere that promotes sharing knowledge, teaching, learning
4. Managers are mostly not bosses but leaders who help you grow, who are holding your back and are caring for their teams and every individual
Cons:
1. In my location salaries are reaaaaallly lagging behind competitors.
2. Rotation of workers is too fast, due to lagging salaries or organisational changes. All companies should focus on retaining employees because right now the fastest way of getting higher salary or promotion is to change your job/position. Costs and time of onboarding software engineers to complex projects is tremendous - it's not accounting or selling which everywhere is rather the same - and companies should do everything not only to get the right people but also actively encourage them to stay.
3. Too many wannabe PMs with their powerpoints, MBAs and 'groundbreaking strategies' and not enough developers.
4. Forcing 'new strategies', by PMs or other middle-management guys who want to show how important they are, which bring only chaos.
5. Inequality between wages by country - I don't believe that engineers in San Fransisco are 10 times more efficient or work 10 times harder than people in Europe, Asia etc.

Pros:
Cisco is a fun place to work, at least if you're in the sales part of the business. You can usually work from home and take flexible hours provided you're serving your customers well.

Career options are great, you can move around the business relatively easily. Opportunities to move to different countries are frequent and often encouraged.

Lots of opportunities to do side projects and define your own activities. Very little 'micro-managing'.

Rewards outside of base pay are encouraged and easy to distribute, creating a good culture with positive feedback.
Cons:
No inflationary payrises. Very difficult to get promotions without being a skilled political operative. Managers powerless to help employees in this area as they don't control any budget. Everything goes through a big HR machine. Everything and everyone is a number and cost to be reduced.

Managers are usually looking upwards focussed on their own careers, not paying attention to their employees. Can go months without a performance review or any guidance as to your own career. Promotions, payrises etc all shrouded in secrecy.

Leavers usually not replaced, or replaced slowly. Being 5 heads down is common and workload thrown to employees without any consultation or apology. This in turn affects sales commission.

Technical strategy is weak in areas due to massive in-fightning between business units. Huge egos run parts of the business. Fear is a frequently used motivational tool.

Pros: I was really proud to say that I worked at Cisco. I spend over 20 years of my life at Cisco and I really enjoyed most of it. I got to meet and work with some amazing people, most are still great friends. The early days were the best when you actually worked as part of a team. I learned a lot and enjoyed the work/life balance. The continuous training available was always top-notch. If you want to find someplace to hide and retire, there are plenty of dark holes in Cisco to do it.
Cons: Too much turnover! Senior people are put in positions they should not hold and this includes the majority of management. If you are not in your director's inner circle then you may as well pack your bags. To get into the inner circle you just have to play the game, kiss the right behinds, and squawk a lot. You don't actually have to work, you just have to be a puppet. If you dance enough little monkey, they may toss you a shilling. The "People Deal" and "Stack Rank" are horrendous and just created a cutthroat mentality, absolutely destroying teams. Lay-offs every 6 months, re-org every 2-3 years, and complete restructuring every 4-5 are exhausting!

Cons: Management is not good at all, the salaries are a total joke for the IT industry. This company is good only for students and if this is their first IT job. I have worked there for 4 years, so I am telling everyone just how it is.

Pros: Cisco is a fantastic company to work for. Managers go above and beyond to ensure employees are cared for. Monthly check ins with senior management, complete transparency on how business is doing. Mental health days built into the quarter. Genuinely a great place to work.
Cons: Cisco is a very large, global company so you have very little chance of interacting with upper management.

Pros: Great place to get experience and training on extremely expensive equipment that you may never touch otherwise. Huge environment with a lot of opportunity. Great people in a very respectful and friendly atmosphere!
Cons:
Cisco does not compensate at the level of the work that is typically performed, and the ability to be promoted is slow due to many HR obstacles. 

Cisco has also been rapidly reducing employee benefits (ultimately offloading more and more costs on employees) which is taking a major toll on morale.  

At this time of writing, management seems VERY disconnected from the individual contributors, partially due to way to much management and ever increasing bureaucracy. 

The result of these factors is that much of the top talent ends up leaving the company.

Pros: Great compensation and great benefits. You get a lot of experience under your belt here and it is a very well-respected company. If you put in your time, it can lead to big things in your future within this company, or the next if that's what you want.
Cons:
If you are in virtual sales (GVS), STAY FAR AWAY. It has gone from being the most rewarding and enjoyable job to an unhealthy call center environment. The VP decided to fix something that was not broken and make everyone work out of the RTP office instead of hiring real raw talent. The director rules by fear and walks the floor to make sure people don't leave before exactly 5pm on a Friday afternoon (this job is requires long hours and they don't allow you to put in overtime, mind you), and you have little or no support from operations. Half of my peers were either in therapy or needed it, and they were always so terrified to come in every day. 

Also, there are layoffs every single quarter. The ageism is real in this company.  You are not safe unless you're an older white male. The culture isn't the best here for women either. No one ever feels safe to report when men are inappropriate.

Pros: Best in class  solutions for customers in the industry,  Can be confident to know you have a great company behind you and value-add solutions that help our customers achieve their business goals and plan for the future.  Many resources available to help you be successful in your role.  Fantastic team environment.    Most employees are smart, hardworking, and always willing to help.  After 90 days you can typically work from home 1 day a week.  Challenging goals and high expectations from management, but a culture that emphasizes work life balance and is of the, get your work done and do what you have to do mentality.  Good flexibility and very little micro-management.  They hire good people and treat you like adults, meaning they trust you to be productive and get things done.  Great long term career opportunities and exposure to many different roles and career tracks.  Your options are endless.  Many employees at company for 10-15+ years; very unusual these days, especially in IT.  This is a testament to the wonderful culture at Cisco.
Cons: Large corporation that can be cumbersome at times.  Must be very flexible as things change regularly.  Days fill up quickly with many meetings, training, etc., not all of which are of great value.  Have to learn what is important and what you can skip.  Tools can be frustrating to work with, still use way to many Excel spreadsheets for things and underutilization of CRM capabilities.

Pros:
I like the flexibility of my job and the diversity of cisco's workforce. I have good opportunities to work on a wide range of interesting projects with people all around the globe.

I'm very grateful and proud to work at Cisco. In the current economic downturn, I believe Sr Management is working hard to avoid layoffs (by cutting contingent workforce and expenses first--who knows what the future will bring?). I also think they're being open and transparent about it and are generally doing the right things.

The hours and work locations are flexible; I am able to work from home often.
Cons:
The lack of coordination across projects is appalling. It seems like I work in a giant crowd of project managers who do nothing but run around in circles looking for projects to manage. There are waaaay too many 'boards and committees,' the function of which is mainly interfering and delaying projects. People at the middle-management layers are simply not incented to work together, despite all the talk about collaboration on the part of Sr. 

Management. As such, political skills pass for leadership and the people who have the best political skills get promoted. The political realities often ignore development realities, which leads to a scramble of ass-covering.

The collaboration technologies are over-hyped. While telepresence is good for demos and meetings where people just talk to each other and show presentations, the lack of interactive whiteboarding and 'working' collaboration technologies cripples my ability to do 'real work' with my colleagues across the globe.

Product development processes are also crippled; there's either no process at all or people use process as a tool for delay and obfuscation. This is the bureaucracy at Cisco.

Pros:
great brains to work with.
Very flexible working hours. Nobody will even care whether you are even coming to the office a day. You can use the WFH lavishly. Overall a great work culture anybody can dream of.
Cons:
Salary is not up to the market levels, its understandable for a company like cisco having a huge headcount. But the problem here is that when they decides to give increments, they  decides to give more % hike to the guys whos sitting in the upper level or whoever is earning more. Overall all the scenario is rich becomes richer. 

One more bad thing is the hardened processes. Doesn't matter whether you are doing a small silly task or not the number of processes you have to do consumes way more time than it takes for actual tasks itself. This repeated unwanted bureaucracy driven processes will make you terribly bored and give you headache and dizziness every single day.

I doubt the india team still does have a proper direction for their growth, everyone still relies on the big SJ team and folks here are somewhat getting considered as a second grade people. whenever a good work comes in to thewider  team, its gone to the SJ. And you gets bored keepon doing the same old maintenance work. Just to make your mouths shut, once in a blue moon day you get some crap new stuff. after that again you do the same thing.

Pros:
1) Flexibility is by far the biggest perk you'd get in Cisco Krakow. That, along with the great tools the company provides you, allow you to work remotely when needed.

2) Size of the site: it's a pretty big site (1600+ employees) with a quite low average age: people in Cisco Krakow are fun!
Cons:
1) Middle management in Cisco Krakow is really mediocre, and definitely not diverse. Most managers are Poles and while there's this appearance of inclusion and diversity within the company, at the end of the day you'll see locals (or Ukranians, the second biggest community) progressing in their career,  getting promotions, recognitions, and so on... while it happens way too rarely for internationals (in proportion with the number of people, of course).

2) Being a low cost center in a saturated market like Krakow, the quality of talent Cisco manages to get there is not so high.

3) No meritocracy AT ALL.

4) No metrics/KPI / good place for early retirement: you will find lots of people in who just put in a few hours of work per day, get to work at 10:00, leave at 15:000, go for groceries in the meantime... and nobody cares, because there is no way whatsoever to measure anybody's performance (beside in a very few roles). Management doesn't even notice it.

5) Other departments within Cisco, in the regions, do not have a high respect for centralized low cost centers.

Pros: This company has a big name in tech so it is a resume builder for sure regardless of your personal experience within the company.
Cons: If you are young in your career Cisco can be a nightmare. Managers have absolutely no idea what you do from day to day and seem to care little about that. You can go months without talking to your manager if you want. Managers couldn't care less about your professional development. Having sync up calls with your manager to discuss development is literally a joke because they will help you with nothing. Cisco is losing talent fast and a big reason is because they pay poor, the company is too bureaucratic  for career growth, and management is completely lousy. In my four years at Cisco I've had 5 or 6 managers and I can only say that one of them was a good/great one. Oh and I almost forgot. If you are early in your career forget about proper training. Cisco is absolutely horrendous and training new talent for the work force. This is literally a sink or swim company. You come in on your first day after a couple years out of college and your manager is looking at you to close million dollar deals with no proper product, role, or field training. They'll just say figure it out or browse the companies 70k people to find someone who can give you advice. They don't even assign you a mentor. The ability for people to work from home has turned the office to a ghost town so if you enjoy he presence of other human being you better forget about it here.

Pros: Financially stable company, very smart and hardworking people, paycheck every two weeks, good benefits, some exposure to the latest technology depending on which unit you are. Good place to build experience
Cons: No innovation or excitement, too many project managers, bean counters. Lots if infighting, political struggles. Too much drama just to do an Execution Commit. Your ideas will or will not be listened to based on what your title is, not based on what they are. There is very little advancement opportunity. Employees who started at early 90s are too cocky have the grandiosity complex. Cisco was at the right place at the right time but now times of high flying stock is over. For the last 8 years, there is no meaningful raise, bonuses are going down. Hard to attract new talent. Engineers who are doing the actual work are not respected or appreciated properly. Management thinks, R&D, oh someone will do that, if not we'll have it done in India or China, I'd rather increase my visibility under the label or cross collaboration and look out for my few trusted tech leads.  I know every department is different but I feel overall Cisco is on the fast track of becoming another big fat boring company like IBM.

Pros:
People.  Easiest way to explain it is, at Cisco people Care.  They care about the customer, they care about doing the right thing, they care about the companies vision and direction.

I have sent mails to VP's and even the President of the company and have always been treated with respect and deference.  That is very telling on what a true open door policy looks like.

I think the greatest support for Cisco statistically is that people who work here don't leave.  I'm in a high level consulting position and get constant job offers, but no other companies create as compelling and challenging of a work environment as Cisco has to offer.

Absolute great company to work for, and has my highest recommendation from a 15 year industry vet who has worked for top companies around the world including Microsoft.
Cons: Typical Company cons that can all be summed up by "slow moving".  But nothing that effects my job.  If I ever have a blocking issue I tell management and they take care of it.

Pros:
- My favourite thing is that I can work from home whenever I need to, and I don't need to tell days in advance. An email in the morning when I start working will suffice. This is very important for me as I'm not living in my country, and I travel often back to see my family and friends. 
- Management style is very positive (always trying to help you and making you improve, not nagging you or punishing you). They also try to make you grow with trainings or extra projects
- You can always express your opinion and you will be heard 
- I don't have flexible schedule as my other co-workers (This is due to working in customer support, that it's not usually the case for other roles). As we are working in shifts, my schedule is 8 to 4. This is a blessing in disguise because at 4 I can close my laptop and go home and it's totally normal and acceptable
Cons:
- As you can get some extra projects to learn new things (and change the routine of your core job), you can end up having to work in  your free time if you want to improve in your career, so you shine and have visibility within your team or worldwide. That's why you need to manage your time wisely and learn to say no.
- The workload is endless. (This is due to working in customer support, that can vary for other roles) You cannot catch up will all the work, you just have to do your best every day.
- Salary is less than average for the market in the same city (Happens worldwide)

Pros: The level of talent at Cisco is generally quite high and a cut above other companies. The compensation package is generally solid though raises have not kept up with the rest of the valley and Cisco is no longer significantly better than other companies. The sheer size of Cisco allows one to move into other areas of interest and find new opportunities if they desire to branch out.
Cons:
Hours are long and work loads high. If you make an effort to take time off management will be supportive in my experience but they will not go out of their way to encourage work life balance. The company will suck you dry if you let it. Competition for advancement is very keen, especially at the grade 11/12 level and politics will often play a very significant role since there will almost always be several qualified people. Career development is non-existent even for those who have been labeled "high potential".

The management at the Director and Sr. Director level is the weakest in the company and contains a significant number of political infighters and deadwood. This creates management paralysis and limits growth opportunities for others.

Pros: Cisco is a great place for work/life balance - I would high recommend Cisco for working moms. There is the flexibility of working from home if need be - best thing is people do not abuse that system. You have access to a wealth of informations - technical talks, seminars, classes to enhance technical knowledge. There are also leadership classes to hone leadership skills. Extensive use of IT tools and Web made all the processes online and very seamless. I personally believe the salary, compensation and benefits are at par with the valley companies. Overall, its a great place to have fun and work at the same time.
Cons: One of the biggest complaint I have against Cisco is it's career development plan & implementation for the employees. The ePM every year talks about the growth and career plan - but in reality the managment is always driven by very near term goals and not long term vision. As a result all the career development plans of individual contributors do not go anywhere - again next year the ePM comes and the story repeats. There is not much functional rotation as well - its very hard to convince Level1/2 manager why I would want to move from his/her group and go to another group to do something else - instead of encouraging the individual's passion to do something of his/her interest in another group, the manager is worried about shrinking empire if an employee is lost to another group.

Pros: i come from an acquisition that had a one of a kind culture and very smart team.
Cons: Since the layoffs started, senior leadership didn't have frequent communication with the teams. We weren't given any information or timelines. To add to that, during all hands, unfortunately they were reading a script and not showing any empathy about how this was affecting people's lives. The company prides itself that people come first, however during this difficult time it showed me the sad reality that it is not people's first company!

Pros: Highly collaborative culture with very smart people. In my role at least, have access to top executives who are very approachable. Still the premier tech name out there, at least when it comes to hardware and networking.
Cons: Very passive aggressive culture. Can be a difficult place for people who prefer directness. People rarely actually say no to anything and so you waste time doing things that never had a chance to gain full support, and you need to herd cats across multiple functions (this is the classical functional siloed company) to get anything done (this ties to the plus that it is a very collaborative culture - you have to work with others to get anything done). Support functions are awful, especially HR. Seriously, this is the worst HR function in the history of business. If you want to see what a company is like that operates on non-sensical policies, and where you can't do something logical because it is against policy, welcome to Cisco. Especially with regards to HR. WPR writes reports on how much space we're using and how much energy we've saved because we decided to get rid of the coffee machine. Seriously, why do we have people whose job includes spending time doing this??!??!?

Pros: Some things like pay for performance in certain BUs is true (the one I worked at least). Your bonus is a direct reflection of whether you go extra mile (or) stay 10-5. For a large company they have fantastic CAP(monetary appreciation or gift card) award programs for folks who go above and beyond (which I don't see with most employers) , well defined RSU structure and a much better than average 401k plan. You can work from anywhere as long as you get the work done your manager does not care if you don't show up at 9:00AM. Fantastic team mates and managers!.
Cons: Your base salary is low. Lately there has been lot of chopping and churning of work force non-stop. Some mandatory people movements across business units may or may not be liked by you but you have to live with it. Very difficult to move across to other BUs where interesting work is done, often they give huge weight to "current experience" - even for a very good performer if you don't have the exact skill match they're not ready to train you and in an effect you become stale and lazy over time because the desire to move around (which can be a big motivator to stay around) gets killed. Huge bias towards work done in by spin-ins. Some times they're deliberate they don't want your product/BU to thrive irrespective of you meeting H/W release deadlines.

Pros: I was hired by Cisco choice program, in which new hires can choose their teams based on how they like to work or who to work for. Since most teams need more people, managers squeeze their brains to attract the new hires into their team. Before the new hires choose their teams, they are exposed to most information about projects and benefits or drawbacks of each team which is tipped by managers, who pamper the new hires badly (I thought I'm the king of cisco during the period - once I chose my team, my heyday was over..). This is an example of cisco how this company tries to lay out best environment for their employees.
Cons: The largest problem in cisco is its size. It is a big guy, which means its decision making process is very slow. Officially my reporting structure is not that complicated; manager, general manager, director, and VP (there are more, but in my position, I doubt that I can see anyone of them). But there are also inofficial small team structures here as well and of course some politics. Thus in order for me to convey my idea and make it adopted by my team, do you know how many people I have to convince?

Pros: You are encouraged to collaborate and seek visibility, even externally. Some employees can even work from home or in a remote office. Managers are generally open minded and encourage asking tough questions and challenging the status quo. Industry Leader. Still a growth company.  Compensation and benefits are excellent. For instance, the medical and dental package is 2nd to none and much better than most other comparable companies.  “If you are uncomfortable with change, Cisco might not be the place for you. There are significant leadership and strategy changes as we adapt to different markets. Many projects we work on are started and stopped haphazardly by product marketing or senior leadership.
Cons:
“- Many things in the new hire process are unorganized for new employees. I particularly dislike the 2+ week overhead trying to get initial items setup.
- Expectations for corporate culture may be put on badges, but I am not feeling the type of camaraderie that I had, nor the new employee immersing expectations that occurred for my last job with "Big Chip Inc". It's starting to feel like more people are there putting in their 9 - 5 instead of being there because they enjoy their work more. Then again I am biased and so is my viewpoint of being a Software Engineer.”

Pros: You would think that at a company that owns more than 70% marketshare would be frought with ego and islands.  This might be true as you start moving up the food chain, however at the individual contributor level - there is a great deal of comraderie as everyone feels like a "little fish" in a big pond - and even the most veteran employees - still would collaborate.  There is a great sense of trust.  The culture is extremely collaborative with an idea that we are all virtually on the same team (because eventually you probably will be.)  A LOT of cross-teaming and matrix ran projects across the board.  I might be subjective because I had the fortune of working out of the bay area - I know that Cisco employees that were not close to corporate had less than nice things and feelings about it.
Cons:
The only constant is change.  In over 10 years, I had over 10 managers without really having to change teams very much.  There seems to be a lot of flexibility within the org structure that ends up with a lot of revisions to applications, tools, processes, and structure.  

Talk about frugal!!! No free sodas anymore- and the cafeteria prices are higher than some of the restaurants that are within walking distance of campus.  There are basically no more perks left at Cisco other than the chance to use a macbook air as your standard pc and that somewhere someone back in engineering has probably created an "app for that" if you can't find what you're looking for on the intranet.

Pros: Great work life balance. Work from home is a major plus (they own WebEx). Smart capable people. Amazing benefits including a full week of paid leave for charity volunteering. Love how much the company gives back to society.
Cons: Very rare to get a salary increase, so be sure you're OK with the salary you accept. Lots of churn in mid-management, I've had 13 managers in seven years. Tough to get your ideas heard, unless you're politically minded. Since the company is so large, there are a lot of slackers who coast along just under the radar, which can be de-motivating. Very engineering driven with design, and user experience, as an afterthought. There is also no clear career path for designers. Design is not handled in a traditional manner, so collaborating with fellow designers is rare- instead you're assigned a product and become silo'ed in it.

Pros:
- The people are incredibly sharp and supportive (with a few exceptions). 
- Pockets of leadership are outstanding. 
- The benefits are second to none. Good restricted stock options, 401K, ESPP.
- Teleworking option - allows for better work / life balance (sort of - see below)
Cons:
- ENDLESS meetings. Back-to-back-to-back...Think 8 solid hours starting at 6 AM. 
- It's great that so many of the employees have the flexibility to be remote. However, I noticed that it has meant many employees are dis-engaged, going thru the motions. 
- Count on the annual re-org happening -- which means annual layoffs
- I personally have worked at Cisco for more than 15 years and got let go. Cisco may say they want you to retire there, which I was convinced I would...I was so loyal to that company, then suddenly got let go. It was pretty brutal to say the least. I essentially got kicked out of the family.  
- There's "juniorization" of the workforce going on here. They are trying to bring down the average age so if you are 23, good for you. If you are 38 or above, chances are it will be difficult for you to make your case. Millennials seem to hold a lot of importance at this company. Experience is no longer prime currency
- Changes going on in leadership and the way work gets done is highly, highly distracting. 
- Employee morale is extremely low

Pros: I love working here and the support you get from all levels of management can't be beat. People think sometimes that when you work for a large company like Cisco, you'll somehow get overlooked. But I can tell you that's not the case. You get to work with the smartest people in the industry who truly believe in educating and enabling their employees. Everyday, I feel like I've made an impact, and that my value is being recognized. I advocate everyday for my friends to work here because it is absolutely the best place to be. Customer Success is taking the industry by storm right now, and there is not a better company to be working with.  Cisco has always been a thought leader, and they recognize how critical Customer Success is for our customers. I can't wait to see how this group grows and transforms within the coming months. It's one of the most rewarding careers being able to work so closely with customers to truly understand their business, and how we can help them reach their business outcomes. If you want to learn, grow and be surrounded by passionate, motivated people - this is where you'll find them!
Cons: It's a newer team, so naturally there are still some things they are trying to work out in terms of what technology we align to and other little nuances... but it doesn't take away from the value you deliver as a CSM or the overall experience of working there.  It's more of a growing pain than a con! :)

Pros: I learnt a lot in Deep Learning
Cons: Needed some more experience and should have spent more time working.

Pros:
Cisco strongly enables their employees even at the individual contributor level.  If you have good ideas and the drive to enable them, you can do well.

Of course, as with any large company, alot depends on your group and your direct manager.  However, mobility is generally encouraged from group to group and the tools are there for you to take advantage of it.  

Other reasons to work at Cisco are the ability to be involved with cutting edge technology and processes.  Cisco strives to be ahead of the curve both in terms of the products and the way we work.  

There are many great minds at work at Cisco and it energizes you to be around them each day.
Cons:
The bell curve is enforced for ratings/rankings and it does not always lead to good results for Cisco or the employee.

The ratings and rankings system can be unfair and hold people back who should be promoted.  There is not a lot of consistency from group to group and if you're stuck in a group where there are a lot of high performers, you can be unfairly penalized.  

As the company gets older, there can be a tendency to fall back on tried and true ways rather than innovating.  Management says they want to encourage new ways of working but if it impacts their bottom line or they are afraid setbacks will reflect poorly on them, that can stand in the way of change.

Pros: While Cisco is a huge and global company, you have a sense of belonging to something bigger than yourself. There’s ways to get involved to navigate the vastness, for example tuning into our company all hands meeting, also known as the Cisco Beat. This is an opportunity to hear firsthand our leadership’s top of mind and where Cisco is focused as a company. Another way to get involved is by joining an Employee Resource Organization (ERO), such as Early Career Network or Connected Women. These employee organizations are communities that help you grow personally and professionally by connecting you with others who share similar interests and come from similar backgrounds. It is a chance to experience the wonderful diversity that exists within Cisco . Lastly, the flexibility that Cisco has is unmatched. For example, just this past Thanksgiving Holiday I fell ill and not well enough to go into the office. Luckily, with our flexible working policies and my agreement with my manager, I was able to work the entire week from home – no missed meetings!
Cons: Aforementioned, Cisco is a large company where success is emphasized by maintaining one’s own personal network and development. You have your roles and responsibilities but an added layer of continuous self-improvement through development courses and scoping careers on Cisco’s career site that might fit with your skillset. In other words, any role at Cisco won’t be an 8am-5pm Monday-Friday set-schedule job – but it will be as good as you make it!

Pros:
Company Culture is amazing, And I really mean it. I planned to join cisco for a year or two max before leaving, out of college. But the Culture has made me love this place. Especially in TAC, which operates at its own level in most things.

So much to learn, the amount of knowledge is insane, the regular Technical Leaders at Cisco has would be equivalent, to Principle Engineers in most Companies. You never stop learning, every one and anyone you can ping, sync up and learn from.
Cons:
Salary, 
One of the biggest down side, I see is the inflated salaries being offered for roles similar if not, ever more basic then what we do everyday in TAC. 
Being a global company, the company is able to acquire talent and resources at anywhere and bring them up. Which has shrunk the teams in US, by what seems to be by design of Execs. To run barely breathing teams in US.

Once you are in TAC you reach a certain point in your Career, that there doesn't seem to be career paths that go up. Most rely on you leaving to different Org, and climbing up again, and or zigzagging.

Pros: Benefits are great.  Full medical/dental/vision, employee stock purchase plan and numerous arrangements with retailers for discounts.  In my role I was often able to work from home without recrimination, as were most people.  Generally really liked the people, but in a company that large there are bound to be some jerks.
Cons: To this day it boggles my mind how poorly managed the company as a whole is.  They have layoffs every year and never seem to figure out that its because they have poor talent management.  All too often highly skilled technical people are promoted into leadership positions , and they have no idea what they are doing and the team suffers.  there is also no consideration for compensation given to employees for their experience.  If you get hired this year at a set salary, it does not have a cost of living increase.  Next year an identical person could be hired who would make more than you, even though they have less experience.  This is one of the major causes of employee attrition.  I can really only speak for IT but Mid-level management (director level) is just plain bad.  By every definition of the term, just poor leadership.

Pros: Where do I begin?! Over the 13 years+ I have worked at Cisco it has only gotten better! There is a renewed focus on it's greatest asset-- the people, and it really shows in how the company fosters a team atmosphere, continual training/learning opportunities, and dozens of employee-focused activities, benefits, perks, etc etc etc.  I left Cisco for a period of time, and after experiencing several other companies, how they treat employees, the culture differences, I can honestly say that Cisco is by far the best company I have ever worked for. It is fast paced, and if you are not a "high performer" it can be a challenge, because the people here are incredibly intelligent and competitive... just dive right in and learn to swim!
Cons: The fast paced nature of the business can be overwhelming sometimes, but if you embrace it and work smart, with continual learning built into your career plan, then the sky is the limit. Life is about choices, and because of the collaborative, "always on" nature of the network, you must learn to unplug from work to keep your life in balance--- otherwise you start "living to work" instead of "working to live".  You have to manage YOUR career and calendar, otherwise the aggressive, success-driven nature of Cisco will "eat you for lunch".

Pros: I've been with Cisco for 18 years in the engineering department working on a very successful product.  The culture here is great - the company emphasizes work-life balance and giving back to the community.  In many positions one has the opportunity to work from home, which is fantastic!  We also have five days paid time off each year (in addition to our regular vacation time)  to serve our communities through the charity of our choice.  In my experience there is very little micro-management, the people are great to work with, and it is a very diverse work culture.  I've learned to appreciate many cultures and I've traveled around the world to Europe, India and Australia in the course of my job.  I've learned a great deal of technical skills through my years here and it is a fast-paced, challenging work environment.  Our new leadership under CEO Chuck Robbins is focusing on innovation and simplification of our products and the investment community loves it (stock price up 45% this year)!  The compensation package is great with excellent health insurance and 401k match. I love my job!
Cons: Sometimes its difficult to get departments within the company to work together due to the tendency toward silos.

Pros:
Good work-life balance, good benefits, very flexible work from home policy, at a lower level, opportunities abound since there are so many teams and there's so much work going on.

The good thing is that if you ever get bored with a certain role, you can always switch to a new team. That makes work always challenging, and when it's challenging, it's interesting. The downside is that most of the work going on is on proprietary technologies, (in may area atleast) so it may not be helpful when switching companies.
Cons:
It's a big company so you may get lost. I'm ambitious, and in such a big company, it's not easy to get to the top. 
It's also, frankly, boring. Not because of the work, but because of the environment. They have ancient drab grey cubicles, which is just off-putting to a lot of millennials in the tech industry who are used to interesting office spaces, creative and challenging environments, and good food.
Lastly, there need to be more promotions and rewards. It's common to see people leaving even though they like their job, simply because if they didn't they wouldn't progress in their career. There are slackers, and there are over-acheivers, and there needs to be a better mechanism to identify them.

Pros: Good Benefits, lots of flexibility in the working environment.  I worked for the company for 13 years with school age children.  The flexibility that there technology and culture provides for working remotely made being a working mother so much easier.   Interesting work, even though internally we might feel like we aren't very progressive, most of the company is way ahead of what is happening in most companies.  Great work experience.
Cons:
While the culture is improving, it still has many challenges.  Way too many people that are in leadership positions that shouldn't be. They think that bullying their employees is fine as long as they can effectively suck up to senior management.   Lots of implicit bias in the organization, and women definitely suffer from the classic double-bind:  if you are decisive you aren't likable, and it stalls your growth.   Continual churn of executives creates whiplash in employees, as a new executives come in with new plans, throw the baby out with the bath water, and then move on when they figure out there ideas aren't so great after all. 
Worklife balance is only achievable if you know how to set boundaries.

Pros: Diversity is a priority at Cisco, which is critical to providing well-rounded solutions and innovations. And innovation is another huge priority, which is great, as it keeps the creative juices flowing and  you can really see the progress we're making. My management chain is fan-freaking-tastic.  I get to work exclusively from a home office. My work schedule is really flexible and at no time do I feel like I have to sacrifice my responsibilities as a mom for my job.  All of the people in my management chain are GOOD people who want their employees to succeed and be recognized for good work.  They don't hold back kudos or compliments and have proven time and again that they always have my back.
Cons: Not all Cisco divisions are created equal in terms of positive work environments.  It's important to speak with current or recent employees connected to the hiring department to make sure you fully understand what you're getting into.   And I'm sure Cisco isn't unique in that they don't always provide enough budget to adequately fund certain expansion initiatives. The expected results are made crystal clear, but enough resources to achieve it may not be provided.  So, employees are left with the unfortunate choice of  working inhumanly long work days for weeks/months at a time or fall short.  And falling short isn't often an option.

Pros: Flex Time(but will work over 10 hour day minimum)
Cons: Unreliable - Can lose your job anytime in a instance. Company has no allegiance to Employees or their tenure/hardwork and dedication. A lot of employees have been there since year 2000. They stuck through with the company hoping that it would turn around. They weren't re-issued any of the Stocks they lost due to being "under-water" and also stopped any new issues. When the company started to turn around, the first people they got rid of are the long tenured people. Furthermore, you will probably come into Cisco, smart and cream of the crop, however, please beware that you will have zero career enhancement. Their constant budget cutbacks take away the key elements that keep your job skills intact.

Pros:
- Every single person I have met thus far, even the individuals I randomly bump into, have been great to work with people. 
- I have been treated with respect from everyone since day one.
- My department is granted great flexibility on how we develop our internal tools and applications.
- Several of the buildings have been remodeled. Each have their own theme. For example, one is an African theme while another will be a Nepal theme. Nice to see them mix things up on the interior design with different culture, furniture, and designs.
- The VTA train goes through the entire campus. Easy to commute this way.
- All kinds of exciting events and conventions to attend throughout the year. Developer conferences, bootcamps, and more.
- Food is good. Sometimes hit or miss. But in general it is quite good.
- Super diverse. You'll work with people from around the world here.
- Mature. Most people here are on the older spectrum. Good if you don't want to work with a bunch of fresh college grads.
- I enjoy the Cisco Beats. Great to see what the CEO has to say, what Cisco has been working on, and what values they strive for. Also good to see how they are always aiming to improve the culture.
Cons:
- Lower pay.
- No dinner. No snacks if your department doesn't allocate a budget for it. Can be difficult working late nights without something to eat.
- Lack of upward mobility.

Pros:
* CEO is well-respected and represents the company well
* Company vision/mission is relevant
* Corporate social responsibility is exemplary
* Communications are transparent (when possible)
* Benefits, benefits, and benefits
Cons:
* Many executives (other than CEO) appear focused on self-promotion and jargon-y initiatives rather than measurable company success
* Many managers do not seem to be held accountable for their own performance
* Many people managers appear to lack basic ability/training in people skills
* Employee pool is shrinking as talent leaves for companies that offer not only better pay but also better work environments, work-life balance, and opportunities for promotion/salary increase
* Workloads can be overwhelming as people exit as backfills are rare
* Team performance suffers as the best talent leaves

Pros:
Specific to the knoxville site: ample time-off, w/l balance, brilliant colleagues, training budgets, and research time are what you would expect from a truly great company.  Being a part of a small group makes it feel homey and easy to settle into. Being a remote office, and also an integral part of the security effort, we are shielded from the greater movements within Cisco with respect to business reorganizations, workforce reductions, etc.

It's a blank canvas, if you would like to achieve something special here, it is possible. Of course, if you would like to slowly wilt here, that is sadly also possible.

On the corporate side of things, l feel that upper management did the right thing by calling a preemptive layoff in 2013. They saw the writing on the wall and didn't hesitate, although, they could have reorged better; cutting 4000 and then immediately hiring 500 for new disruptive businesses is an incredible waste of talent and acquisition dollars.

We're a buzzword factory!
Cons:
At a remote site, small-office politics reign. 

Career advancement is almost non-existent. There are no career paths/development plans to speak of.  Cronyism runs rampant during the stagnant periods, which is to say, most of the time. Salaries are less than you would find on the east coast; not at all comparable to the left coast. Bonuses are necessary to make the compensation acceptable, but each year it's a crapshoot whether you will get them or not. Employees will advance faster by leaving the company and returning later.

Pros: Industry leader for 20+ years, Cisco manages to re-invent itself during market transitions, leaving competitors in the dust. Plenty of challenging work, you're surrounded by strong talent willing to collaborate in cross-functional projects to achieve goals. The complete compensation package & benefits seem better than industry average. Cisco manages finances as I do: Being frugal and debt free. The company has an enormous amount of cash available to survive tough times and take advantage of acquisition opportunities.
Cons: More political and more turf wars than it used to be. Still a good place compared to other companies though. No job security, more layoffs than similar companies - that's the price you pay for being a large company that must move fast through market transitions. Cisco is quick to let go of investments that aren't paying off and lay off people to cut costs when the quarter didn't go as expected.

Pros: flexibility for remotely working is a true blessing in disguise. due to high cost of living, many move further east towards the likes of dublin and pleasanton among other areas to take advantage of the solid school systems and housing costs there. there's an on-site gym; not free, but not terribly expensive either with just above basic amenities. every group within cisco is like it's own small company under the big umbrella. for the most part, it can be nice, but when it comes to budget and headcount cuts, many business units have to make very difficult decisions, despite fairly confusing strategems from above (i.e. moving into and dominating consumer space, but leaving before a clear indication of losing %s, which affects many jobs)
Cons: strategy is seemingly too volatile year to year, not long enough to seriously gestate in the case of several business markets. recognition not too common if you're not in the hip pocket of managers and other prominent folks, but it's not like it's dramatically different anywhere else. just that for a company as large as cisco is, particularly with how deep pockets to hold its sizable cash reserve, it's fairly remarkable that cisco still is befallen to layoffs.

Pros: Large employer; lots of opportunity; Cisco is a market leader and an employer of choice. The campus is huge and there are lots of jobs available. The transportation shuttle between buildings is a great gas-saver. Liked being able to telecommute and have a flexible work schedule. Enjoyed attending the all hands meetings hosted by John Chambers, he is a good speaker and the sessions were entertaining and informative. Cisco has great giveaways to new employees. Free onsite perks like free drinks and popcorn. Nice cafeteria facilities with good selections and reasonable prices. I liked that I could do my personal banking, stationery, and shipping at Cisco too.
Cons: Large employer; can get lost as a little fish in a huge ocean; lots of autonomy and self management expected. Had to find my own chair, computer, desk equipment on my first day - not a great first impression for a new employee. Moved 10 times in 2 years - don't get used to a place or "home", you'll be losing it soon. Management expectations not always clearly communicated. Feedback not always timely or direct. The only constant is change. Work not evenly distributed - some working ridiculous hours and some not hardly working at all. Perception is everything, isn't it?

Pros:
Excellent campus, at least at Cessna in Bangalore.
Excellent cafeteria, both in terms of variety and quality of food served, at least at Cessna in Bangalore.
Free subscription to SafariOnline, Lynda.com, Udemy.com, Plural-Sight.com etc
Excellent cab facility, though the charges that contractors have to pay to avail the facility is exorbitant.
Unlimited Work-From-Home options, flexibility to arrive and leave from office any time that suits you. 
Reimbursement of broadband expense, good insurance coverage including parents, spouse and children.
Absolutely no dress-code, you can wear anything you feel like including shorts.
Cons:
Major re-structuring and consequent layoffs practically every quarter in all locations and all BUs (and an annual big one around Diwali/Oct-Nov time-frame).
Exceptionally top-heavy organization where hardly any work gets done. If you are politically connected well, you will stay otherwise prepare to get fired.
Useless long-timers as managers, who keep firing people based on their likes and dislikes of people.
Dis-proportionately large numbers of Contractors as compared to FTEs (at least in Services/CX) which shows the lack of any long-term vision.
Marked discrimination between FTEs and Contractors in terms of treatment meted out (I was an FTE, so its not a disgruntled Contractor ranting).
Absolutely no touch with HRs, they only interact with you on the day of your on-boarding and thereafter only when you raise a case which will be responded soon enough. Beyond that, no interaction, to the extent that there is no Exit Interview either when you resign.
No onsite, at least none in IT.
No hikes every alternate year. And promotions are next to impossible, and even if you do get promoted do not expect any increment in package.
Conversion from Contractors to FTEs is a myth (almost never happens, at least in Services/CX).
