Pros:
- Flexibility in working arrangements 
- Health care packages
- You're working for #1 
- The name carries a lot of kudos, doesn't matter who you talk to in business, you mention Cisco and it does command a level of respect and appreciation
Cons:
- Slow progression. Essentially you're up against everyone else within your pay grade for a promo. That can potentially be a lot of people you have to our maneuver for extra dosh.
- Cultural shift in recent years towards loud and brash "sell, sell, sell" model, away from raw engineering and capability, that arguably made Cisco what it is today. 
- Almost too large now for engineers to be taken seriously unless they are architects / systems engineers or very senior and even then that's probably giving those folk too much credit. 
- Can be political but so can every work place

Pros:
I started my career in the CSAP program, coming directly from University. From the beginning I had tremendous support and felt the positive vibe in the company. You are always encouraged and empowered to find own solutions. I have always felt an incredible amount of trust - which let you simply grow. But if you ask for help - there will always someone available to help.
The culture is very supportive - not only on the professional, but also on the private life. Being a mother myself it helps to have a home office and flexible working hours to balance family and Cisco. 
Cisco deeply cares about giving back - every employee gets additional 5 days annually for local giving back activities. It is so inspirational to get this opportunity.
Cons: This culture works probably not for everybody. You have to have a sense of purpose for yourself and drive your own projects. If you prefer to have a detailed description and predefined steps what you have to do - Cisco is probably not the right company for you. In order to be successful you have to be self motivated, creative and the courage to succeed. And since you are so empowered - it can also be difficult to limit yourself to healthy work hours. You will be encouraged to care for yourself naturally - nevertheless there is no "clocking in / clocking out", hence there is always something to do - and you need to be able to set yourself healthy limits.

Pros: Cisco is a forward-looking company, but execution does sometimes get wrapped around the axle of politics. Cisco manages to stay where it is through the occasional big technology breakthrough, like Encrypted Traffic Analytics and thanks to brand, heft, and the fact that no one ever got fired for buying Cisco. The company is making good progress now in their transformation from a products company to a software/subscriptions company. This is an amazing accomplishment that should be credited to Chuck Robbins and his management team. While John Chambers grew a behemoth from a strong up-and-comer, and was a wizard at integration of acquisitions (for the most part), but he could not make this transformation, though he'd tried for years. It's a company with a bright future in cloud and security.
Cons: Too many decisions are made because of the HiPPO (Highest Paid Person's Opinion), whether or not it's the right thing to do. Look at key competitors from Zoom to Juniper to see talented folks who took their good ideas elsewhere and peeled off market share.

Pros:
Work hours seem to be 9:00am - 4:45pm (4:15pm on Fridays) so you are able to keep a work-life balance for the most part.
Nice friendly colleagues.
If you keep your head down, don't rock the boat, and don't think outside the box, you'll do fine.
Cons:
Rewards & recognition are hard to come by - you have to work the political game well to get management recognition for your work.
Upward mobility is also very hard to achieve with entrenched employees and very little movement, other than horizontal.
You are judged not on how well you do your work, but on who you know and your political clout.
A very passive-aggressive workforce who will smile in your face and agree with you, then undermine you and not help - only unless it serves them in their political gain.
Employee Monsters are easily recognizable, but are allowed to wreak havoc because management avoids all possible conflict (see: passive-aggressive)
Definitely an old-school mentality to go along with it's stereotypical "cubeville" work environment.

Pros:
- Great work-life balance, and very open culture between colleagues and various teams
- Everyone in the team is very supportive of each other, and always keen to share best practices and their own experiences
- Customer Success is a new team in Cisco, but we are seeing large support from the CEO and Sales Leaders as Cisco makes the shift to selling more recurring revenue solutions. This is definitely the fastest growing team; and possibly where there is good career growth!
Cons:
A lot of KPIs that the management is pushing for in a bid to prove the value of the Customer Success team.  Cisco is a sales organization, so there is large pressure for creation of expand opportunities. Even though there is so much push to get those KPIs fulfilled, people on the ground are limited due to the strange way in which the expand opportunities are measured.  This is especially difficult in APJ region due to resistance from internal stakeholders. 

Everyone in the team came in very excited and motivated about Customer Success, but I am seeing some level of disillusionment and exhaustion to keep up with ever-changing performance measures, tools, new offers with little to no time to adjust, and high pressure from the managers.

Also experiencing "growing pains" with large number of new members in the team.
There have been layoffs and budget cuts for a while and that means that salary raises havent been that great

Pros:
They trust you to get you job done with little supervision.  I can usually set the times I travel and develop my own pace of what I want to work on.  Usually I can set my schedule up to a month out and I will know what I'm working on.  Managers work with you to ensure that you are helping you and the bottom line of Cisco.

I also like the flexible hours and the allowance of working from my home.  Many times I will not get inspired until late at night and I will work in to the early morning.  As long as I meet my commitments for the next day, Cisco supports me working when I need to.
Cons: Little guidance on what it takes to get promoted to the next level.  Many companies have this problem where they have fuzzy guidance as to what it really takes to move up to the next level.  I think this is a problem for those that are task oriented (as that is one of the skills Cisco Hires).  If there were a specific matrix that helped guide people to where they want to be in 3-5 years and even 10 years out, then Cisco would have a world class system of retaining people as one would always know where one's career is going.

Pros: Cisco is a huge company and you can spend a career jumping from group to group every few years and never work on the same thing over again. Despite what a lot of the reviews here claim Cisco does pay what they should be paying. Some of the business units within Cisco treat their employees better than others and it would be wise to interview with more than one if you're considering a switch to Cisco.
Cons: Cisco is a huge company and you can spend a year drowning in bureaucracy and fighting for change within groups that refuse to do things any better than they ever have before. Some engineers at Cisco are incredibly smart whereas other engineers are incredibly dense. Cisco prefers quantity over quality not only in their employees but also in their products. Shipping a half-baked product on a silly schedule to meet some arbitrary marketing deadlines just seems wrong. No one at Cisco seems to care that their products have a terrible reputation and without the brand recognition no one would buy them. Cisco India (Bangalore) is definitely focused on keeping seats warm rather than building a quality engineering force.

Pros: Good benefit, completive scalars, flexible working schedules.
Cons: Has all the problems that a big company has. The company tried to change this by introducing a CDO college new hire program, and hoping the fresh blood can give more momentum to Cisco. But the result is just the opposite as what it was designed for originally. At first the screening process of the CDO program is too easy. Lots of new hire coming through this program are very high paid without a matching quality. And once they are choosen by the CDO program, they are offered to free pick any group to work for within Cisco. A lots of managers love to get them, just because the first year budge if coming from the company, not the BU. And the following years, if you got more people, you got more budgets. But very often the team can not swallow this much new college grades and sometimes the group doesn’t even have much work for them to do at all. So many of them end up sitting around, and picking up the bad culture of Cisco quickly, This further ruins the culture at Cisco, as an indirect result of it many senior and well experienced people are leaving Cisco.

Pros: I have been with Cisco for 3 years and I believe overall that this is an outstanding company to work for. This is the first company I have worked for that actually recognizes, values and *compensates* you for hard work. And if you prove to management your value and contributions to the overall company, they will absolutely take care of you when it comes to things such as relocation, education, and schedule flexibility. Since collaboration technologies are a huge part of the business model, there are a lot of remote work options (i.e. work from home, road, etc.) - but this depends on your exact role in the company.
Cons: The dreaded "work/life" balance is probably the number one complaint across Cisco employees but it is what you make of it. I know plenty of people that work at Cisco and maintain a pretty close 8-5 work schedule and are highly productive; I know others that work seemingly all hours of the day and night. It's up to you, setting the level of expectation and how efficient you are. But it is extremely easy to get very wrapped up with work and leave little time for anything else.

Pros:
- Good pay
- Good benefits
- Very socially conscious and progressive on important issues
- People are very friendly
Cons:
- Leadership is a mess and has no idea what is happening in the field and what reality is
- We build products that we think the market needs vs what they are actually asking for. So many old egos that will not let bad products fade away
- Just working through all the internal challenges within Cisco to sell is harder than even selling to the customer
- We pay executives tons of money, but cut all the quality out of TAC so it is not good anymore
- We over promise and under deliver all the time. Ask customers to spend like they are buying a Lexus, but they are buying junker
- Way too many people who want their voices and opinions heard and so good ideas turn into terrible execution
- We hire the same people over and over again that are in the same industry or have friends here, instead of finding great talent that can be taught the technology

Pros: Great benefits. Telecommuting. Education and growth potential.
Cons:
They will lay you off at the drop of a hat. I lived through several but didn't duck fast enough for the latest one.
The growth potential is also highly touted but the actual execution still fails due to politics and favoritism.

Pros: Remuneration is very strong and they don't expect you to compromise your life. In fact, they enable you to have a better work/ life balance by providing the equipment and ways of working so you can be highly effective from home. I work 4 days per week from home on average (I have the option to work fewer if I want to). Cisco offers all the benefits you'd expect including you birthday as an additional day off, a choice of high end Mac or PC, phone bill paid in full, 5 additional days off to volunteer for the organisation of your choice (this year I'm using mine to go on a long cycling trip for a charity started by one of my colleague's. You can also receive connected recognition, this is a cash reward of varying amounts you receive from colleagues who think you went above and beyond. I received one last month for £70 but the amounts can be over £100. Aside from all of this, the people are great and together we make a fun friendly culture. It's work hard, play hard and Cisco certainly rewards all those who do. A great choice of tech company whether you have technical skills or not.
Cons: The business is focused on short-term financial performance. This can be frustrating when trying to deliver longer term projects.

Pros:
- CISCO work culture is Open and inclusive.
Open: There are no barriers or inherent hierarchy that limits an employee from reaching out to peers or seniors. The culture encourages collaboration, learning and gives the employee a place to broaden their horizons in terms of theirs skills and knowledge.
Inclusive: CISCO believes in inclusive environment where everyone gets equal opportunity to grow and develop. It is not only inclusive in terms of people but also in terms of growth in recreational activities like sports and arts. It is quite difficult to find such a culture in other companies in India.
- Awesome benefits: The benefits provided by CISCO is by far the best that I have known. The benefits include Health coverage for Family (yourself, spouse, children and parents or in-laws). This is quite rare compared to other companies health benefits. Free GYM, periodic health checkups for yourself, family and parents. Extremely well maintained sports facilities for shuttle, cricket, volley ball and basketball and various others. It supports tuition fee refund for any education/course you take.
- Good Personal and Professional life balance: The work culture is flexible and allows the employee to maintain a balanced personal and professional life. Managers are very understanding and in general the management encourages the employee to ensure a good balance in work and personal life.
Cons: The hike and promotion cycle is fixed. The employee has to finish a certain period of time before being considered for a hike or promotion. This doesn't correspond to the work done by him/her.

Pros:
- Executive leadership communicates honestly and openly

 - The company promotes lateral movement and promotion to both cultivate internal talent and prevent attrition

 - Leadership has a keen sense of the organization's strengths and weaknesses 

 - Evolving product lines and strategic acquisitions outpace product commoditization

 - An emphasis is placed on the customer journey - even if employees on the ground ignore it. 

 - Most of the people I met enjoyed their job, genuinely wanted to add value, and came across as open and collaborative.

 - Clear limits are put in place to make sure that customers are fully supported when new products are introduced. I can't overstate how refreshing this was.
Cons:
- Sales teams seem to be split into warring factions.  This, coupled with a  lack of clear structure leads to a lot of redundancy, wasted resources, and ambiguous goals. The end result is a hamster wheel of day-to-day fire drills. 

 - For all of the talk about customer focus, most employees seem to be obsessed with internal politics.

Pros:
The company has great benefits and seems to truly care about their employees. There is lots of opportunities inside and the work-life balance its ok.
100% remote and flexible time.

Benefits:
-Childcare vouchers
-Annual bonus
-Pension Plan
-Stocks (discount of 15% for employees)
-Health insurance (extended to family, partner and descendents)
-Life insurance (42x base salary)
-All cisco certifications and trainings available and paid by cisco
-Training platforms (o'reilly, linkedin videos, udemy, harvard training, Pluralsight, MasterClass, Coursera,getAbstract)
-400 euros to spend on personal classes, health, medicines, etc
-Car and gas for tech leads (grade 11),
Cons:
The management is really poor.
Everyone that wants to be a manager can become one. It doesn't matter if you'll be a good manager or not, if you want you just work your way out to it. And that's how you become a bad manager and end-up ruining a whole team :)

The problem is that we have lazy and poor managers, managing senior and high performing engineers.

By micro managing, tons of bureaucratic processes and lack of transparency makes the life of engineers frustrating and pretty damn boring.

But it's a matter of luck, I had one good manager, a so-so manager, and now a terrible manager, so good luck with that.

This lack of transparency and bureaucracy is making cisco lose the best talent to other top companies and competitors, but the guys in the top probably don't see that.

Well I like the company, I like the colleagues, but don't trust the management and specially my manager, that's why I'm looking to move out :)

Pros:
Decent benefits
Looks good on resume
Was great until about 2003-4, but has slid downhill since.
Cons:
Boxborough is full of dead wood. Most of the talented people have left or are itching to.
Zero balance between work and home life. It's 24/7 stress due to an oversized workload, undersized staff, and too many people who are mediocre at their jobs.
Fair or not, there's a perception from other locations that San Jose is full of people who get paid for doing very little. It's all who you know. For sure the company is dominated by the IOS group, none of whom seem to understand software developement.
Brain-dead stress on metrics is driving the company and leading to ridiculous behaviors...example: rating managers weekly on their bug counts, while concurrently outsourcing QA to a third party in India where workers performance is based on how many bugs they find: you can guess what happened.
Morale at Boxborough extremely low. Then corporate came up with the PULSE employee satisfaction survey and tied it back-door to managers' compensation. So now the managers are mad at the rank and file for being unhappy. I know one manager that actually made his people take the survey twice with an unsubtle threat that they'd better score "happier" next time.

Pros: Great benefits, very competitive salaries, wide range of directions available in a big company.  As a well established high-tech company Cisco attracts top talent with a great benefits package.  On the whole Cisco looks after its employees and provides good facilities.
Cons: Limited opportunity to innovate, corporate politics, demoralizing business model.  Being head-quartered in the USA, Cisco has a very American approach, and it is difficult to influence company direction or progress through the corporate ladder without spending time working in San Jose.  Working in the UK often means calls and conferences well into the evening, long hours, and a heavy impact on your personal-life.  The company acquires businesses with large market-shares and then implements cost savings, this results in missed opportunities to grow markets and innovate and a feeling of not being engaged with the market or end-customer.

Pros:
-The rotational aspect of the program is great in that you can experience 4 very different roles over the course of 2 years, which is great for trying to understand a company as large as Cisco. The variety of roles is clearly a plus as you are able to preference which areas interest you as you move throughout your time in the program.
-Generally, the expectations from your teams are within reason but provide a challenge at least in my experience. Learning is encouraged and mistakes are seen as an opportunity to grow rather than a reason for criticism.
-The program itself feels like a family of sorts that you can relate with people in the same boat as yourself early in career. This makes for a great support system and provides an automatic resource for general questions.
Cons:
-Sometimes timing of role responsibilities and additional program expectations can overlap which can create a challenge; however, these are chances to exercise time management.
-Transitions can be a little tricky to manage due to turnover of roles (some new ones can be added and others) so some processes aren't as clearly defined. Generally business partners are understanding though and there's always help to get you up to speed.

Pros: WebEx is a SaaS leader - and has market leadership in web conferencing space. Lots of potential as SaaS model truly takes off. WebEx encourages rapid pace of innovation - and is somewhat gratifying to see things shape up without much of red tape. Most people are very talented. Ever since Cisco has bought WebEx, there is a marked increase in the quality of upper management - in terms of their ability to aim big and execute. Best thing about WebEx - you do not have to pay for Web meetings - and online meetings are so effective to bring together geographically distributed teams.
Cons:
Lack of respect for people and their personal life, and lack of professionalism (Especially within the product organization). 
WebEx culture can be described as somewhat chaotic. Disagreements / criticisms are discouraged - and the culture encourages people to rally around the Kool-aid of their bosses. Work-life balance is way tilted towards work, and the management takes it for granted. As an organization, WebEx tries to achieve more at the cost of quality of the product, and the quality of the life of the people who build the product. There are still remnants of fiefdoms from pre-Cisco time. Geographically dispersed teams can be challenging  - in terms of working across different time zones, cultural differences and language differences.

Pros: The ability to work remote if necessary. The extensive benefits for an employee including 401K matching and Employee Assistance Program, and onsite health and fitness center. Many of the people I worked with as peers were intelligent and fun to work with
Cons: This company has changed dramatically over the past decade. Internally it can now be a very political environment where promotions and increases were awarded  to those who bought into empire building within business units and not people doing the real work essential to the success of the company. The focus on process and metrics is only effctive when everyone either agrees or is aware of the metric targets, without that it seems like evaluations are subjective and unfair. Anyone who had been managed out due to restructure is more likely to have been targeted for being more of a thinker than the management wants.

Pros: Great pay and benefits. My bonuses were extremely generous (though I earned it working extremely hard).  A lot of really smart people doing super cool things. The company is still really innovative. I had the pleasure of working in lots of new areas - emerging markets, emerging solutions - and the conversations we had with customers were very interesting. Solving unique problems for smart cities, connected health, education, workplace, etc. For the right role, I would consider working there again. Internal competitiveness at one time created a healthy let's get it done environment. Great collaboration tools that enable you to have really effective virtual meetings. "Be the customer" mentality - always having employees adopt new productivity enhancing tools. Telepresence rules!
Cons: Really political. Terrible gossip system. There used to be a mentor-y "we're in it together' feeling. It changed to more of a make yourself look good at the expense of other people culture.  Lost sight of what matters for awhile. Too many company priorities (at one point, there were 50 top priorities!)  Victim of tech jargon. Lots of big words to sound grandiose, but it didn't make sense in the end. I respect John Chambers a lot, and I have had chill bumps from some of his keynotes, but after awhile, it just sounded empty, and the same old messages over and over.

Pros:
Good cafeterias -- with both healthy choices and not-so-much.
Some nice buildings, although the nicer buildings have smaller cubicles.
Cons:
Cisco is an engineer-centric society, much to its own detriment.

Cisco had an HR department website instead of new-employee orientation.  Despite the steady stream of complaints from employees about the user hostility of the internal HR website, Cisco persisted in forcing its employees to rely on a highly unreliable internal HR website, much to the frustration of everyone involved.

Cisco management seemed hell-bent on working its employees days, nights, and weekends -- all the while chanting the Work-Life Balance buzzwords as hypocritical propaganda.

Other companies work hard to instill and encourage and maintain mutual respect so that each and every employee, from board room to mail room engage with kindness and respect.  Not Cisco.

Horrendous coffee.

Pros: It's Cisco. Great in terms of employee benefits, professionalism, and fair policies. Very good in terms of social presence (progressive, diverse), community engagement, social welfare, etc...  Large company with options to move around, grow, and gain experience. Salary/compensation tends to fall on the upper side of range. Large product/solution footprint that covers a lot of technology. 800lb gorilla with worldwide presence. Good reputation, Hallmark technology company, lots of things to build with and sell.
Cons: Big company with the classic downsides. Internal culture and drivers have been impacted over the last decade by rapid development and shareholder/profit pressures. Most innovation is now acquired and assimilated. Not so much a knock, but where the company is in its evolutional cycle. The result is constant fluctuation in strategy, priorities, organization, and management. Unfortunately, career advancement/survival these days too often is knowing what bandwagon to jump on, when to jump off, and when to blame someone else. Lot of hardworking talented people get flushed in the process with the regular LRs. Too many managers "manage up" and not down.

Pros: Flexible/home working, benefits. Work life balance.
Cons: Depending on what part of the company you work for then your working experiences are different. This is highly sales focussed company, Services are a poor relation and often driven with cost reductions. TAC are well funded thanks to lucrative support renewals. Cisco is far too US focussed, almost ALL the new VP's and SVP's are American, with American strategies which only work in the US. Cost reduction appears to be high on the agenda and this impacts all aspects for a number of years now. Morale is poor and the People Deal they published is farcical considering the number of layoffs they constantly keep making. Promotions have not been communicated or transparent for a long, long time. No clear or defined career ladder either, this depends on what accounts and projects you get attached to tbh. Cisco appears to be trying to regenerate into a more youthful company to reduce costs but have lost a tremendous amount of industry experience and skills in doing so. Innovation is primarily hardware focussed. Very poor long term strategy or investment in Services, where the financials take precedence over quality, efficiency and innovation. Remote workers are VERY remote, hardly getting to see colleagues at all for years. I never saw my Manager face to face for three years! Get used to days and days siting on Webex calls.

Cons: TC is pretty low compare to other tech company

Pros: Lots of opportunities for growth

Pros: Good work life balance. Allow you to work remotely
Cons: I joined with a good salary 5 years ago as a new grad out of college, and I have seen only ONE increment of 5% in the last 5 years. It was not like I was not doing good. They kept doing re-orgs and rotated me under different managers. Each manager said I needed to establish myself with him. And each one promised me a promotion next year which didnt happen. I saw other people in other groups getting promoted or salary hiked much faster and here I am slogging under one manager after another, sometimes doing junk work that the technical leads themselves do not want to take. I stayed on because they gave me flexibility to work from home which I needed as I was facing some family issues. I looked outside and landed up with an offer that directly gave me a 45% hike. Happy to get out of here finally! I would not advise young people to join Cisco unless they know they are getting the right pay, the right recognition and growth in their careers. Each group is different, not every group need to be like mine. But move out as soon as you find out you are stagnating or you are not being just-fully rewarded/promoted, within 6 months.

Pros: Engaging work and the ability to get involved with a diverse set of customers. People here are fun to work with.  The culture: extremely flexible work environment, great people, minimal focus on performance management (you can be a top performer with minimal effort), and a company that cares about your overall well being.
Cons: Compensation and career growth.  Cisco is HORRIBLE at rewarding employees (even if you are constantly told you are a top performer) which is causing many talented people to leave.  Focal cycles once a year at best that are funded to a level where they can only give you a 4% raise at most.  New hires today make more than people who have been here 5+ years.  The company is doing better than ever but this only translates to executive promotions and raises.  To get a raise you have to leave for a year and then you can get rehired at 2x your prior salary.

Pros: I am a midlevel Software Engineer with 5+ years of experience working in Cisco, specifically Voice Technology group. We have some really interesting Projects. Some of the best minds in the Industry work here. Managers just care if the targets are met, and not individual work hours. I got to learn a lot from senior Engineers/Tech leads.  Best practises in software development. Scope of recognition is pretty high. If you come up with some thing really good/cool, senior management do recognize. Good Work Environment. All drinks free, but no free food though :(. Pay is 94k, but i think there are folks who earn more than me with the same experience. Bonuses depend on company wide policy and overall company's performance. Mine is 13% So, there is not much you can do if Cisco overall doesnt do well. Bonuses are dependent on grade level of the job position. Public transportation comes for free(Ecopasses from VTA) within Bay area. Paid-time-off is pretty good, you earn 1 day for every 8 days of work. Cisco pays for home internet.
Cons: Promotions, Salary increases seem to be rare. I havent seen more than 2 promotions in a year now, that too for very senior level engineers. I have seen alteast 5 people i know leave.

Pros: At Cisco you can find a great team of people to work with, people who are committed to making their products the best, people with a lot of integrity. Cisco offers some of the best benefits of any high-tech company in the world, and they encourage people to explore opportunities within the company that can help you further your career.
Cons:
At Cisco you may find your manager stretching your limits to complete tasks. Although you can find satisfaction in breaking your perceived limits to workload, you may find yourself working weekends to keep up.

In its effort to streamline operations, Cisco has made some aspects of working at Cisco very impersonal. For example, the use of Telepresence in some building lobbies means that you do not see a person in the lobby when you enter and exit the building. When you start a job at Cisco, you do not interact with anyone in Human Resources (HR) because the process is automated over the Internet. When you leave a job, you do not have any interaction with HR.

Pros:
An incredible brand.
An executive team with a deep talent bench that knows how to place its bets.
Nothing wrong with the compensation especially in the good times!
You learn to think like a winner.
Cons:
Patchy governance in theaters outside US & Canada and Europe.
Astonishingly weak HR for such a large company. Probably the worst and most inconsequential HR review process amongst its peers.
Absolutely no accountability for sales management. If times are good the rising tide lifts all boats. If times are bad well bad times are blamed.

Pros: Great, broad product family, TAC and Engineering Support is world class.  The company is customer and sales focused, so if you are on an account team, you can do what is needed to build win-win relationships with your client.  There are a ton of opportunities to move around and lots of opportunities to innovate.  Cisco is moving fast to a flexible, highly mobile work environment.  You can get your work done from any place, device or screen that has a connection to the internet.
Cons: Crazy amounts of sales forecasting and opportunity updates (3 TIMES PER WEEK FOR MOST SALES TEAMS!) If you are an account manager, you'll submit your forecast over the weekend, have some sort of large opportunity review at the beginning of the next and then do another forecast at the end of the week.  This leads many managers to micro-manage their teams.  Salary, as part of overall compensation package is below average. When you overachieve, you do well.  If you have a bad quarter or year, your checking account will suffer big time.  Company bureaucracy sometimes slows things down.

Pros: Truly a team culture where all members of the team are willing to jump in and help.  Peers and leaders at Cisco realize we are all fortunate and so there is a large effort to reach back out to our communities locally and globally to make a positive impact.  "You are your own obstacle at Cisco," is something I heard early on in my career and it proved to be true - We all drive towards the ultimate goal which is growth in revenue, but we have the freedom to get creative to get there and that's empowering.  We have the BEST mobile workforce powered by awesome technology.  Webex meetings and teams, and our personal video devices make any remote worker feel like they're one cubicle over from anyone they need help from.  Hands down, a world class company to work for!
Cons: While work life balance is of utmost importance, it is easy to feel like you always have to be available.  Although, I would say that is more typically self-imposed as most folks hold themselves accountable for individual (and shared) success.

Pros:
Always has a group of senior IT engineers and architects to ask questions to. They were always easy to approach and happy to answer questions and provide guidance (not sure if this is luck of the draw with their personalities, or if it is company/organization culture quite honestly).
Most of the managers are great people who provide guidance and try to help you determine your career path and put you on projects you would enjoy and your skills align to (there is always a "bad apple" manager, but this is the exception).
Cons: The IT side in particular seems to be following what I consider a negative trend in the industry of hiring contractors for specific projects with the skills needed, rather than training the full time employees they already have who have gotten the company to the successful state they are in. You won't get the best talent using primarily contractors and they will leave eventually. Then the company will lose their experience and knowledge after the project ends, when they could provide guidance towards a future project.

Pros: The People, The Culture and The Work
Cons: Disconnect from Sr Leadership Lack of vision for Webex/Collaboration

Pros:
Pretty good IT system now I work in another IT company in Silicon Valley. 
Lots of on-line and in-person learning opportunities, the internal e-learning system make learning on technical and on-technical topics very easy. 
Also relatively easy moving from one group to the other, with no upside. 
I like John Chambers will meet with employees every month whose birthday falls into the month. Also he meet with new hires very regularly. 
Cisco shows consciousness on getting green and help the community. They have an extensive outreach program in which lots of volunteer opportunities are posted, encouraged and participated. Good job in there.
Cons:
Only lateral movement moving from one group to the other, absolutely ridiculous policy. 
there should be really an incentive for people to move from one position to the other. 
I did an prestigious MBA program, then when I finish, there is absolutely no upside to move within Cisco. The HR did not find an easy way for me to find a new and exciting opportunity. So I left. 

Also, the salary review process. It really depends on your manager. If your manager likes you, you can get lots of money. If you are not the favorite, then you are out of luck.

Pros: The salary and compensation package are good. The company has an incredibly good reputation on the market (although once you are in the company and if it's not your first job, and you have known better companies, you wonder from where this reputation is coming). So it looks good on your CV.
Cons:
No work-private life balance. You are supposed to be connected 24/7, also during your holidays, weekends, sickness leaves, evenings, etc... I have worked in other companies previously (international large companies as well within the ICT sector) so I can compare.
Also, there is no "work hard and have fun" spirit. No parties organized for the employees (OK now it's economic crisis but I understood Cisco was not that fun place to work before the crisis either). Nobody having a chat in the coffee corner - so hard everyone is occupied. The workload is huge. Everyone is doing a job that is meant easily for 2 people. At lunch everyone is talking excelusively about work.
I also feel that I learn nothing new compared to my previous jobs and that is not a positive sign.
The maddeness of the forecast: you have to do it sunday, wednesday and friday !

Pros:
Cisco is one of the best places that I've ever worked.  Even among other IT companies such as SAS and Google, I think Cisco stands out as one of the best.  (Okay, Google was really good too, and possibly cooler, but I still say Cisco is better.)

Why?  I can sum it up in one word: culture.  The people here are amazing, and always willing to help you out and help you grow in your career.  I've never loved the place and people I work with more.  It's also a very good place to build a career, with a lot of lateral movement within the company.  And if you're willing to work at it there is a lot of opportunity for advancement as well.  Just be prepared to work harder than anyone else if you want it.
Cons: The work/life balance is a little skewed towards the work side.  But they have seminars on just this topic.  It's not as crazy as Google, but I do spend more than 40 hours a week at work fairly often.  Luckily Cisco allows you to work from home, so you're not stuck in the office the entire time.

Pros: The amount of information available internally to facilitate personal growth as a network engineer is amazing.  Cisco will foot the bill , provide resources internally for training, and recognition for for CCIE certification.  Additionally, you'll have the advantage of being able to work with some of the best engineers in networking within the entire industry and you'll be challenged to excel.  There aren't many opportunities in the entire country similar to working here.
Cons: The cost cutting and process oriented overhead have perhaps gotten a little too extreme and there's a bit of confusion as to which direction the company is headed.  Small perks such as soda's in the break room and home internet connection being payed for really gave a sense that the company still had a bit of its start up flair.  I think the dismantling of those programs while adding additional time consuming processes have had a detrimental effect on Cisco culture.

Pros:
- Work life balance
- Management gives lots of trust to the employees
- Top execs are very focus and open about the company
- Very good company recognition outside of Cisco
- Everything is on a webpage for benefits or events
- Excellent place to work for self-motivated employees
- Lots of smart, friendly people at Cisco still
Cons:
- Lots of politics (at many levels)
- No RSU or stock options (only exec levels)
- No yearly inflation salary adjustment
- Reviews are based on beating out peers (so team lacks teamwork)
- Some employees cheat the work/life-balance and don't get caught
- Some execs are clueless (weak leaders) on tech in IT and engr.
- IT and Engr could be better with more if the leaders come from there.
- Many top talent and employees leaves while management doesn't care
- Hours spend chasing medical claims with UHC mistakes in reimbursements
- Mandatory Year end shutdown comes out of PTO balance
- No roadmap to promote top engr and workers (always hire outside to fill positions)

Pros: Not sure anymore, but the "Pros" are getting fewer and fewer
Cons:
Working at Cisco for 4 years now and just learning something disturbing that I didn't know before: Cisco policy mandates 15% of workers be rated as "Needing Improvement" during performance reviews. So you could do all your work successfully and excel and still labeled as "Needs Improvement". Even more disturbing is your performance review is not really 100% about your performance. It appears most weight for performance reviews is made by subjective opinions made from senior management within your group, even if you've never actually worked or interacted with this. Sound crazy that people you've never engaged with can effectively rate your performance? It is, but is acceptable within Cisco's corporate policy. What's really scary is who knows what subjective criteria is used in this opinion gathering process: Maybe you don't answer emails fast enough, maybe you have kids and others don't, maybe you're older that others, maybe you don't get the visible assignments? Who know but anything seems fair game. Worst of all, you can't challenge this..

Why is this concerning? In case you don't know, Cisco lays-off people regularly now - every year as a matter of fact. And, if you're rated as needing improvement (as mandated by corporate policy) you're guaranteed to be laid-off.

Cisco is a profitable company with ~$30B in the bank and yet forces people to be laid-off, go figure...

Pros: I like the culture and the flexibility of the work environment. I loved working from home in my slippers.
Cons:
Working from home can limit your visibility within the company. I started at lower position that I should have thinking that once I was in the company I could explore other opportunities. Everywhere else I had worked I quickly moved up the ladder.  I soon found out that I was pigeon holed in that position. I was even willing to make a lateral move but could not do that.  I felt like I was between a rock and a hard place. This is especially the case for women and minorities. It is not impossible but you need to have a sponsor to grow. 

 If I had known that it would be so difficult to move into other positions. I would have waited for the right opportunity instead of taking the first one offered.

Pros: There are a lot of things to like about working for Cisco; A fantastic, flexible, 'work-from-where-you-are' policy, great benefits and PLENTY of projects to work on.
Cons: Cisco is a company with old values, expect age discrimination and little to no training. It can be frowned upon to take time off, or take time for learning, which results in most of the workforce woefully overworked and sadly behind the times in training. The cult of positivity is also very strong at Cisco, which makes trying to change processes or culture VERY difficult, any suggestion of change is usually taken personally and can result in active obstructionism to your goal.

Pros: Some great teams and management, great people and lots of flexibility.  Parts of the company will still make positions to fit their people rather than try to fit people into rigid job roles.  Flexible working hours are great.  Good people will generally accrue responsibility and be recognised.
Cons: Restructuring/layoffs are endemic, bringing constant attrition of people (good and bad) and low-level fear and malaise.  Many great teams have been turned into poor ones, with capable, experienced, helpful and flexible old-hands replaced with incapable, inexperienced, unhelpful and inflexible teams in low-cost locations.  This is not a criticism of the people, who can always be developed, but of the managers who try to automate their teams, removing any intelligence from the jobs and putting it into the tools and processes.  The result is people who are simply told what to do and how, meaning no personal responsibility, minimal personal growth and low motivation, plus when the tools or processes break (which is frequently) there is little capability to keep the business flowing.  Finally there are still too many teams with a lot of political grandstanding in the senior management--this is at best a nuisance and at worst can lead to poor decisions being taken by defocused management.

Pros: the people are innovative, creative, energetic, compassionate. The culture promotes giving back in many forms. The breadth of product makes many future possibilities exciting. Senior management are good human being. They are intelligent, experienced and compassionate. The culture is so open that I have never even heard of employee being turned away when they requested to meet with anyone in the company. The energy in the place is incredible. You want to work hard and be creative because of the people and opportunity around you. Having to write one hundred words for this thing is ridiculous. I almost stopped writing a while back
Cons: compensation package. Lack of HR processes, systems and people. HR has not been adequately staffed since 2001. Managers have little training or support to become good people managers. International assignments are very few and far between but not having done an international assignment can be a barrier to success. When employees do go on international assignment, their pay and taxes are general screwed up for years. When it is time for them to return to their home country they are on their own to find a job and generally viewed as if they are returning from a long vacation. Chambers is a focal point with no succession plan.

Pros:
Cisco hires a company to do your relocation papers and legalization in Poland and also provides tax advisers services. Sign-on bonus is ok.
You can make good friends there and a lot of skilled and good engineers still work in TAC
Cons:
The salary is 20% lower than the market - you can get more just across the fence at AON, ABB, Motorola and many others.

Do not expect to grow as an engineer there - mostly you will deal with platform specific bugs and defects in a very, very narrow field.

Do not expect to build a carrier - to get a higher grade is extremely hard. And it's all about showing your hard work and not about actually working hard (Visibility - as it called in all big companies).  

Do not expect a salary raise. Bargain straight from the beginning.  The raise is independent from your work and expertise, but rather from the stars in the sky.

Expect to be surrounded by fresh graduates, who will bombard you with stupid questions and will lower your value as an engineer because they will do the same job as you do for less money and you will educate them for free.

Working in TAC you will be the first to be hit - angry customers with problems will shout at you, sales will shout at you, because customers shout at them, your manager won't shout but will be on their side.

Don't relocate to Krakow - smog is a huge problem there (especially if you have children) and rent market is crazy and full of scam.

Pros:
Cisco is a great company by many reasons:
-	Always a pioneer, listen to the market, anticipate, have a vision and transform the strategy to stay a leader
-	Provide all the technologies and work environment to their employees to be agile and productive. Well-being is become an important part of it.
-	We have the flexibility to work from any place and adapt our time based on our objectives, this is not so evident in another company, we have the privilege to have this opportunity and trust.
-	My BU leaders are great by well communicating our imperatives, critical objectives, campaigns linked to Cisco transformation 
-	The green aspect, Impact initiatives with all the social parts, the diversity and the HR program evolution are just so important to my values.
-	I’m really proud to work for such a company.
Cons: It’ in progress but there are still room of improvements. Managers role or  Managers behaviors are not consistent. The importance to work in a healthy environment with good pressure have a good impact to a team and to the results. This is not the case everywhere in this might affect a career, a team and even the image of the company.

Pros:
- Cisco provides incredible benefits (Vacation, 4.5% 401k match, ESPP, etc)
- Salary is competitive
-In the Leaders in Finance & Technology rotation program, you get 4 different roles in finance over 2 years. This gives you good exposure to finance leadership and provides 4 different experiences. Good relationships with your LIFT class, some leadership opportunities within the program like leading meetings etc
Cons:
All the downsides are for LIFT, not necessarily Cisco

-Short rotations of 6 months don't let you get a deep dive into some roles, the managers don't want to train you a lot if you're leaving in a couple months, so you take on trivial tasks. This makes you pretty much a glorified intern for each team you're on, not a true financial analyst.
-The manager for LIFT controls your bonuses, rotations in the program etc. and you rarely ever get contact with her. There is a big communication disconnect.
-Morale is low in the program. A lot of the people dread all the LIFT meetings and are not that excited for things.
-A lot of the roles only provide you with about 15-20 hours of real work each week. A lot of downtime in most roles.

Pros: Great Work Life Balance. There is a good bit of independence given to employees to develop their space. Most managers are not into micro-management and there is opportunity for job rotation so that people do not get stagnated doing the same thing over and over. Works through consensus building and allows grass root proposals to move for action. Moves decisively, once decisions are made but decision making is a long drawn out process. Margins are still rather high even though the revenue growth has stagnated.
Cons: The size of Cisco does not allow it to be nimble. Decision making requires many layers of socialization and corporate politics becomes a barrier to being able to be nimble. So instead of figuring out how to do the next big thing, there are many many hours wasted on agreeing on what is the next big thing. Unnecessary complexity is built into the working of the company and finding the right point of contact to get a question answered is a feat in itself. There is also a sense of people taking no accountability for the business outcomes and only for their own tasks. Lately, the organization has become a bit risk averse - so big bold moves are very difficult to make. Promotion, recognition and growth at the lower levels are based on performance but as we move into middle and upper management, it is very obvious that it is handed to people who know the movers and shakers.

Pros: Cisco is a good company from an operational perspective. Their work at home policy for many jobs are pretty good and offers max productivity for employees. Compensation is lower than others but I would say Fair.
Cons: What kills this company are the many young introverts of middle managers that Cisco hires from Ivy league schools or consulting firms and Cisco has this attitude that because they come from Ivy league Schools or consulting firms tey can become good managers. The other managers Cisco hire as middle managers are NCE's. Just because he is a good technician does not mean he is a good manager CISCO!! This is where the challenges lie. 9/10 strategies are built on ppt charts that go nowhere. Cisco is a military Institution of managers. One cannot talk to anyone beyond his grade level and this is not promoted at CISCO. This is where Cisco will fall.

Pros: Cisco has bright hard working people, good medical benefits, lots of formal and informal training, deep financial reserves for acquisitions, and the drive to be number one in all fields pursued. A good deal of  honest effort is made to maintain the good citizen public face of the company. John Chambers is an outstanding Chairman/CEO.
Cons: Cisco is a stockholder/bottom line driven company first and foremost, with focus on two disciplines: sales and engineering. In recent years Cisco has developed a culture of quarterly layoffs, so everyone runs a bit scared (i.e., not a nice feeling to live with constantly even if you are a top performer). Don't come to Cisco thinking you will "retire" from here. I have seen a good performing Director level employee on leave for cancer treatment laid off the first day he returned to work; whether a common practice or an exception I cannot say. There is very little/slow advancement potential in the mid levels, and pay increases without promotion are rare to nonexistent. Paid Time Off (PTO) is jokingly referred to as "Partial Time Off". In most business climates you may be better off and better compensated as a W-2 contractor rather than a Full Time Exempt (FTE) employee. John Chambers may elect to retire in the next year or two; choosing a successor will be interesting...

Pros:
Cisco has great benefits, the pay is pretty good, and I think at the top they're moving the company in the right direction. I see and understand the vision that Chuck and the other executives are going and think that the new direction is exactly what the company needs. In the next several years, share holders are going to be very pleased. I think there is great opportunity for growth, and am excited to see where this goes.

The work/life balance is incredible. Cisco really wants you to take care of your family because they understand if you are taken care of, you will take care of the company.
Cons: I have never seen a company so full of corporate politics. It seems like in order to succeed you have to give the perception of results rather than actually produce results. While the executive team definitely has the right vision, I don't think the lower levels of management, especially those who have been at Cisco for a while, really are excited to make the changes necessary to take this to the next level because it's not the "Cisco way".

Pros: The people are generally kind-hearted (rare in a big company) and the management tries its best to foster a positive work culture. We often hear that companies are "customer focused" - in the case of Cisco it's an obsession (to put it mildly), sometimes to its own detriment (and to the detriment of its staff). The work can be very interesting and stimulating if you are prepared to move about (through internal rotations) and if you do so, you will learn a lot from some very smart people. Pay and benefit are pretty good, if somewhat unambitious for a company of this quality.
Cons: The flip side of interesting work are the punishing hours and demands. Internal career opportunities get slimmer as you climb up the ladder and there is no transparency over internal hiring decisions. Bottom line for external candidates: negotiate your grade and salary well on the way in, because it's highly unlikely to move meaningfully unless you are early in career. The company is also going through a regressive "centralisation" phase where more and more decisions are made in SJ/RTP. If you are outside of these sites, you are merely executing strategy.

Pros: Work life balance, company culture and benefits are amazing.
Cons: Compensation could be higher but the benefits help.

Pros: You get tremendous information out there inside Cisco Systems about processes, technology and ideas. You only can get benefited because of this wealth of knowledge. The overall compensation and benefits is one of the best in the industry. Cisco is one place where there are all sorts of career opportunities on offer and they actually encourage you to move around and increase the breadth of your experience and skills. There are mechanisms in place to immediately reward employees for any kind of outstanding performance so even as a big company that keeps motivated and devoted in solving the problems at hand during crisis situation
Cons: They make the same mistake as every other large company in that they tie performance and career development feedback with the monetary benefits. So it naturally results in the performance feedback influenced by the amount of money available to any team in that year's budget. There is too much of middle level management who have gone there just because they stuck with the company and not necessarily because of leadership skills and that shows up in how they lead. Cisco has this notorious habit of not bringing middle level management from outside. They should atleast balance internal promotions with bringing fresh leadership from outside

Pros: Good benefits and access to a lot of amenities!!  Some groups have a autonomy and work great.  Others are silos and you would never know there is more out there since you can get buried with the same/day to day tasks.... Divide and conquer big sales deals/acquisitions
Cons: Not all locations have all the perks and luxuries... Some have none at all :(  Senior leadership at the director level change every 8-12 months consistently and have done so for the past few years.  Goals and direction changes just as often.  Politics play big here... Who you know can be good or bad.  Some areas of the company are the market leaders, whereas others are far behind.

Pros: - Having Cisco in your resume.
Cons:
I have been at Cisco almost 20 years and I have seen it all. 

- You get the promotion in title but not in money or the direct training.
- They used to want you to have a 65% customer facing, now it is close to 90%.
- Terrible tools to work with, and especially exposing customer to it, frustrates everyone.
- No trainings being offered. We have internal trainings available but management dont give you the time to do it since they expect you to be almost 100% customer facing.
- Bonuses are being cut off all the time.
- Benefits are being cut.
- Frequent management reorganization is distractive.
- Everyone is trying to save their job so there are not many enabler managers.
- Layoffs every 6 months and outsourcing jobs to 3rd party contractors offshore.
- Don't expect this work to be 40 hours a week. most of us put double that. That is what is expected.

Pros:
My entrance into Cisco was through the HRUP program. HRUP is the best rotational program I've come across (internally to Cisco and externally). If you are a junior in college, interested in HR, go apply for the internship now! Outside of great pay, great company brand, and awesome co-workers, you are given the opportunity to explore ANY area of HR when you come on full-time. With buy-in from our CHRO, you get to explore five different areas of HR (including the internship). I have loved my time in the HRUP program, and am now in my final rotation. I would highly recommend it. It's been the BEST foundation for my career moving forward.

I'm currently recruiting for Cisco and it is incredible. The brand name gives you such access to awesome talent. Candidates ALWAYS say "It's Cisco!" when I ask them why they are interested. It's so easy to be passionate about Cisco and sell working here because it really is incredible.
Cons: There are pockets of cynics who are annoying. "What do you expect. It's Cisco". They bug me. There is a lot of change, so, if you like structure, stand back. Sometimes I miss words amongst all the acronyms we speak. Some of the buildings still look like it's the 90s, but they are slowly getting renovated. It just always seems like my building is last.

Cons: Slow growth competitive environment And many people in the system

Pros: Compared with many other hi-tech companies, Cisco values collaboration and cross-functional group work more.  Cisco's leadership team understands the need to provide employees with work life balance and flexible hours.  For the most part, Sr. leaders respect employees and you do see a level of openess regardless of ranks or titles.  The fact that Cisco is a global leader in networking also helps attract good people for the most part. The benefits and compensation are competitive enough and due to it's location in CA and the average age of the employees, there is a level of maturity and inclusiveness and diversity inside the company.
Cons: The functional structure of the company results in some inefficiencies in the system and often times it takes a lot of time to get consensus from all key stakeholder teams before a decision can be made and by that time the market situation may have changed and customer needs may have shifted.  Ultimately it potentially makes the company less competitive.  The caliber of the employees is not very consistent.  There are lots of deadweight, folks who've been around for too long and only here for a paycheck and for what they can get from the company vs. trying to do their best to help customers and innovate

Pros:
Cisco is a great company, it empowers and give employees the freedom to deliver to their full potential. It is a company that is constantly looking for excellence.
It is a great diverse place. As Hispanic/Latino, I feel my unique values are not only welcome but even encouraged. It is a true global company. I am part of Conexión, Cisco's Hispanic/Latino ERO, We help Cisco to hire and retain the best Latino talent as well as helping the Latino Community at Cisco and in our neighborhoods. 
As a large and successful corporation, benefits are very good and employees are given the necessary resources to succeed. We work on the newest technologies, with modern processes that help Cisco (and us as employees) to stay ahead of the curve!
Cons: Change is always good, but sometimes there are collateral impacts of the way Corporate America is handled, basically with a clock that shakes every quarter. Cisco being a large corporation is no exempt from that, with constant role and leadership changes as well as more than desired limited restructurings. This might affect your career if you don't know how to deal with constant change.

Pros: Decent benefits, flexible work options (location-wise). Decently easy to move around inside the company, no limit to what you can learn if you take some initiative to advance your career. Most of the managers I've had have been good, one has been horrendous.
Cons:
Stagnant wages. No raises for several years in Operations despite record income and profits.
Low morale due to constant layoffs and reorgs. 
Full-time employees are being replaced by offshoring and H1B Visa contractors. Even in the US, you pretty much have to be Indian to get hired. 
In-office work environment is very loud due to open workspace and lack of private working areas. 
On-call pay is not worth it, yet you're forced to partake in an oncall rotation in some roles. 
Cafeteria quality and breakroom amenities are lacking. 
Too many people managers, program managers, project managers and meetings which all hurt our productivity. 
We spend a lot of time training college hires, just for them to leave within 2 years for better jobs with much better pay.
Poor work-life balance due to poor management

Pros:
Overall, colleagues were simply awesome. Everyone is super friendly but your experience completely depends on the people you work with and the vertical you are in.
If your vertical isn't a focus area, you'll probably be bored. 
If your vertical is a focus area, you will get absolutely smoked but learn a ton.
Fridays are pretty laid back. If you aren't on a deal, you should be able to work from home or SF if interested.
Relocation assistance is probably best-in-class....make sure to ask for it $10-20K. It's baked into your fully burned opex cost, so theoretically the org has planned for it. Don't be afraid to ask: get the offer and then ask HR.
Bus Shuttle from SF->SJC
Yearly off-site
Executive exposure - you sit on the same floor as C-suite and work with SVPs often.
The engineers are super nice and approachable.
Cons:
Wages stay flat YoY. No inflation adjustment for junior deal team members.
Working remotely isn't really an option outside of Friday
Unreal revolving door environment
Work/life balance can be non-existent
OG environment

Pros:
Technical growth and job satisfaction are there when the manager has technical background and good knowledge of the product.   

one gets to work on real time issues.
Cons:
If the manager is not that technical, its hard to work under them.  The manager doesnt understand the complexity of issue. And trivial customer issues are communicated to manager as critical issues and engineers are rewarded for that with promotions and cisco spark awards.  The more junk stuff one talks in meetings, the more eligible is he for promotion. Speak non sense and ask same questions in all meetings and one gets visibility for that. And with that visibility promotions are decided.  

Engineer has to go through emotional trauma when he is given bottom 10% or bottom 5% rating. 

If one isnt communicating with manager well, give him bottom 10%. An engineer from every team has to be in bottom 10% every year.  This is absolute non-sense. 

 -ve work atmosphere , where in all employees are made to find faults with others , highlight that to manage and get themselves rewarded and be in a safe zone during appraisal.

Pros:
Cisco pretty much owns soup to nuts when it comes to networking, voice, security, data center, ...etc

Lots of opportunities if you have the experience.
Cons: Cisco just used to hire great people and let them move around to share experience. Cisco just wants to buy companies and  people that have what they need. The companies they buy stay silo'd which keeps any growth from happening.

Pros: Challenging work, good pay and benefits, what's left of the matrix organisation means you still usually have the ability to make a difference.  The company is at the cutting edge of many areas of IT/Telecomms and is still highly respected as a good employer so is well regarded on your CV.
Cons: Every year the decline in our core products, switching and to a lesser extent routing, means the company has to work harder and in more areas to try to make up for the lost business and show some growth.  The company has to work harder on more and more smaller opportunities with more varied technologies/solutions and business models.  Workload and complexity are going up and the company has been cutting costs and making redundancies for >3 years so the amount of work for survivors is going up and up.  This hits some teams more than others but typically mid-level professionals and above had a bad work-life balance.

Pros: People are friendly. Working for home is a plus but need to find a way where we can collaborate as a team to better Cisco. Benefits offered to employees.
Cons: Lack of systems. For a technology company I am surprise by the lack of systems available within HR. Most of the work is done manually which impacts the data accuracy. Need automation within the organization especially in HR. If you say you are innovative, bring automation into the organization. This can be a cost saving at the end of the day but the company needs to be willing to make the investment upfront. The compensation programs need improvement so it can reach 100% of the workforce and not a small percentage. The company needs to look to fund the program on an annual basis in order to attract the talent needed to take the company to next level. Losing key talents to organizations that offer higher salaries and an annual compensation program.

Pros:
Cisco is organized like a series of small companies (Business Units, or BU's), brought together under a single umbrella.  As such, there are many different opportunities and career choices available.  Want to work on streaming video?  Think that Java is a better choice for web interfaces than C?  Have strong feelings about whether XML is really a good interface between cross-domain components?  Find the right BU that is working on the technology, and a manager or tech lead who is open to ideas, and the opportunity is there.
The engineering development methodology can be a pain, but it does insure that the project you are working on will not get cancelled after you've put in uncounted hours.
Cons:
Your job satisfaction will depend on the abilities of the managers and tech leads in your Business Unit (BU).  If the BU is led by non-visionary or agenda-driven people who are not open to change, then this will just be another job.  Recognition may be based on politics or the buddy system, instead of competence, and ineffective managers will not want to rock the boat or get rid of deadwood. 
Cisco stock isn't going anywhwere, so options aren't worth much.

Pros:
One of the most exciting companies to work for in terms of technology, future growth, and professional experience.  Every big company has its faults but Cisco is a great company to work for if you want to start your career on the right foot.  Having a reputable name like Cisco behind you will always take you places.  depending on your manager, an employee can experience autonomy and job stability.

Also another great perk is that I work from home and never come into the office because my team is global.  I have the Cisco ECT/IP phone installed in my home office and I no longer need to be at my desk.  This is a huge perk because I save in gas and carbon emissions.
Cons: The worst comment I have about Cisco is its ability to give promotions and raises.  I've been at the company for 5 years and I've never been promoted.  They give me small raises here and there but this year, they no longer give out stock options.  I do not know how Cisco keeps its employees if they do not compensate them properly.  Also for a big company you will run into bureaucracy and politics.

Pros: Good pay and benefits for the work, decent benefits, global footprint and global leader in it's space (for now)
Cons: Limited promotions or opportunities to advance. Nearly impossible to have lateral movement due to limits on req's. Constant cost cutting puts more work on all employees without de-prioritizing other area's.  Every year IC's expected to do more with less.  Upper management disconnected with the lower ranks, making a Managers job extremely difficult with limited tools to develop and motivate teams.  While rewards is said to be based on performance, in actuality it is based purely on the "short term" and what was done for execs close to the performance review period and not on overall success factors and full year performance.

Pros:
- New Hire Training in SF
- Cisco Webex in the US
- Cisco Webex Management/Leadership in the US 
- Sales Kick-Off in Vegas
Cons:
- Product: Working for Webex felt like you were part of a marketing hoax by Cisco, there is barely any integration to other business units and the revenue contributed to the overall revenue is only marginal, which leads to you not being taken seriously unless you are working on big deployments. 

- Management: There is no leadership in the UK. Fear-mongering and a passive aggressive attitude in team/individual meetings add to a strange and dampened atmosphere. (!) If the Software/Cloud Sales Lead calls himself "the Supreme Leader", then take this seriously, as its meaning is conveyed in his management style. Middle Management, many without any prior experience, is a mouthpiece of upper management. 

- Work Environment: Sadly, the environment is toxic and there is no sense of team atmosphere. There is an obvious segregation amongst team members. Multiple people have been fired in the past. 

- Compensation: Average to below average if you live in London. 

- Career Progression: No career progression (!). "Senior" positions are created for doing the same job and for little extra pay, you have no options to progress further unless you move to a different business unit, which some were able to do. 

- Location: You will be based in Feltham and you will not be allowed to work remotely (but it's Webex, right?) or in the City (unless it is an emergency or other circumstances).

Pros:
After working for several antiquated companies in the business technology space, I have found the exception to that rule 🙌🏼 Cisco is leading many tech sectors globally which  means selling their solutions is fun! 

As far as the work environment, I cannot stress it enough, everyone is genuinely helpful. I have never experienced anything like it and takes a minute to acclimate. The balance of males and females is a huge plus along with cultural diversity. Again,the previous tech companies I worked failed in all of these. The level of intelligence I am surrounded by daily at Cisco is astounding. 

Benefits are very generous. Work environment is healthy.

Very happy to represent Cisco!
Cons:
This is not a big con by any means...
Initial training program can be rushed and will not fully prepare you for the seat you will eventually end up. Work hard, ask questions and keep a positive attitude. It all works out in the end.

Pros:
1. Cutting edge Technology and loads of opportunities and challenges for learning and Growth.
2. Opportunities to work on High end system design and development with with really brilliant minds. Vast products and platforms to explore your skill set.
3. Collaboration to work with cross functional team and understand the end to end development flow.
4. Visibility and response from vendors, suppliers and customers with Cisco Brand.
5. Very good learning and development options for soft skill development.
6. Good work life balance if you well understand your role and have clear planning.
7. Wonderful campus and infrastructure and work place resources to balance your daily life.
Cons:
1. Growth may be limited compared to SW groups unless you are absolutely extraordinary. 
2. Recognition and pay is not up to the market standard for people staying for long compared to lateral. 
3. No stock options for grade 10 or below. Your hardwork and effort will help to get good stocks for your lead.
4. So much process oriented which delays the timeline and execution.
5. Responsibility of the product release lies on the hardware engineer who had to literally drive other teams to get their work done.  
6. Short product development cycle gives times pressure and impacts quality of the product.

Cons: work life balance can be challenging sometimes

Cons: There aren't a lot of cons to working here.

Cons: Product is backwards very very very

Pros: Great work culture with respect for every individual.
