Pros:
Cisco has great compensation. I second what others say about how in Cisco, there are always opportunities for you to prove yourself. There is always enough work for you if you want to try new projects and and work harder, in order to get your name out and move move upwards.

Another major plus is the lower management. They tend to hire people from within the current ranks, and therefore they hire people who have gone through the motions and know what its like to be a lower level employee.

Compensation is also good, including bonuses and monetary rewards. yeah.
Cons:
One thing that always makes me annoyed by cisco is the cubicles that are pale-puke green and sick-of-my-life grey. This seems to also be the theme with the exterior of the buildings. Also lining the walls of the interior of the buildings are really old pictures to -i guess- spice things up visually, but they are faded out now so are kind of depressing to look at. sometimes I find myself just not wanting to be inside those buildings, so work from home.

Honestly, all they have to do is every once in a blue moon add a new picture to the wall, and it would make a world of difference. I saw the other day they were painting one of the walls orange. That made a HUGE difference in that area.

Pros: While not known for high salaries, the perks if you use them are many and varied. Particularly child care, gym, transport, health care centre. A wide variety of trainings are available, and people are encouraged to take them. Flexible working hours and work from home is great. If you have a good manager and your BU is doing well, its a good place to stay. The campus is beautiful and very pleasant to work in.
Cons:
Growth path is mostly uncertain and unclear. A lot depends on the BU you are in. There is huge hierarchy and a lot of redundancy in management.  Since the last 2 years, there is yearly restructuring of BUs, yearly layoffs impact productivity. Many of lower grade employees tend to leave within a year or 2. At higher grades, people get entrenched in their roles and there is no scope for growth. Hikes have been absent for 2 years. Bonus is delayed by 6 months and not likely to paid in full this year.

Management has a tendency to take up a fad *marketing* initiative once a year before their appraisals. This is usually forgotten with no follow ups soon after the appraisals are done.

Pros:
1. Benefits are awesome: 10K tuition p/year, matching 401k packages, 1 week to volunteer for a nonprofit of your choice (fully paid and Cisco will donate $ 10 p/hour worked to the nonprofit), San Jose gym is top notch, and much more! 
2. People are great and highly collaborative. I can't speak for every single person at Cisco but I can say that almost everyone at Cisco is always willing to help a peer! 
3. Great programs to get involved--Conexion, Connected Black Professionals, Men for Inclusion, Connected Asian Affinity Network, and Pride are just some of the excellent programs and groups we have. This is a really great way to network with people all over the company!
4. Great work/life balance. Need to work from home? Work with your manager and if they're okay, then life is made easy for you! 
5. Exciting place to work in terms of the industry! Working in tech is fun and exciting!
Cons:
1. There isn't much diversity in Engineering or IT but Cisco is actively working on attracting diverse talent 
2. Cisco is HUGE and it is easy to get lost in a 73K+ employee company. The way to navigate is participate in the Employee Resource Organizations and subscribe to mailers that have events!

Pros:
-Long training period for new grads
-Good benefits package and PTO
-Many friendly people
Cons:
-Low pay for the amount and quality of work that is expected
-Long training period does not properly prepare new grads for the technical aspects of the role
-The quality of work is highly dependent on the team you are placed on (they ask for your preferences but you don't really have a choice)
-The position is not supposed to be for new grads. You are expected to provide support and advice to customers who often have many years of experience, and customers will often become frustrated when you are unable to provide them with help
-Some teams are very understaffed and it will feel like you are always catching up on your cases 
-Support role means poor work-life balance. You often have to spend extra time to catch up on cases that you were unable to work on because you spent hours on a few calls during your shift. 
-Hard to take time off. There is a limit to how many people on the team can take PTO each day, so there isn't much leeway for last minute requests.

Pros: Management makes quick decisions but they are also thoughtful
Cons: Work is not top-notch and leaders are not adequately trained

Pros: Total compensation (base, bonus and RSUs), good health insurance, onsite services (health care, gym, etc), work-life balance/flexible work schedules.
Cons: Lack of development opportunities and career paths, many old timers were hired when Cisco was growing rapidly and needed bodies.  Now they are just hiding out, collecting their big salaries and waiting for retirement, which prevents young, ambitious people from advancing.  Lack of funding for training and personal development opportunities.  Incredible bureaucracy and reliance on slide decks just to look good, rather than to get things accomplished.  Too much socialization at the Senior Level to get anything meaningful accomplished.  Far too many chiefs and not enough workers.  Workers are seen more as cost centers than as valued assets and work is continuously offshored to Bangalore.  Sr. Leadership views this more as a cost cutting methodology and don't really care about the long-term productivity losses.  Layoffs are a constant concern and while there is plenty of fat to trim, it is a de-motivator.

Pros:
- Some areas of the company are still good. Cisco is a mixed bag. Be careful.
- Compensation is Strong. No longer Outstanding or Exceptional. 
- Cisco has an exceptional Sales organization.
Cons:
- Lacks Innovation. Politics and bureaucracy at senior levels stifle innovation 
- Discrimination is rampant. Age discrimination is promoted by senior management. Pockets of reverse gender discrimination exist. 
- Poor senior leadership. Company is loosing ground in its market and tends to make poor desperate decisions. John Chambers has been a strong CEO but he has no good replacement alternatives within the company.

Pros: The can do attitude and culture of innovation is refreshing and apparent across Product Sales, Service Sales, Product BUs and Services. The pace is challenging and a great opportunity to learn a broad range of products and services for Enterprise and SP customers. Compensation is solid both annual and incentive comp.
Cons: The product quality is embarrassing and pits the Sales team against the BU, and usually has the Service teams stuck in the middle. Service led sales is a joke, there is no need for a Service Sales team as an overly. It just drives cost with limited value. There is a culture of finger pointing that has been in place for at least 10 years and usually starts with the Sales organization. The underlying cost model is ghastly and will continue to challenge the firm going forward.

Pros: John Chambers is a stand up guy and does right by the people who are part of the Cisco family.  The company is great about honoring family commitments and has a great set of core business solutions. Compensation is higher than industry average and perks are amazing.
Cons: The company is built on an old purchasing model and the industry is moving toward cloud, mobility, subscription based consumption models, etc.  Cisco is retooling it's product line and purchasing models, but it's like trying to rebuild a train while it's in motion. Pressure from SDN providers is going to impact core business.  Sales comp plans built on pushing 1 time hw/sw sales (instead of monthly recurring revenue) is counterproductive to future growth.  Always on mentality....there is SO much work to do, the only way to stay on top of the workload/mtgs/reporting expectations is to work 11-13 hours per day.  (maybe this is indicative of all silicon valley firms, but it contributes to either unhealthy work/life balance if you want to stay on top of priorities)

Pros: Great Benefits and Bonus.  People are hard workers and goal setters.  Lazy people are not kept around. ESPP is a pretty awesome program.  High Ethical Standards.  I've worked at jobs where Integrity and ethics were talked about but the company did not act accordingly.  Time and time again I am impressed with Cisco's Integrity and Ethics.
Cons: 401k matching could be a little higher.  Giving it a 4 star rating because the 401k matching is a pretty big deal to me.  Since we do not get a pension, then somewhere around 6-8% 100% match would be a lot better.  Other then that the Benefits are pretty awesome for me.  I cannot speak for those with dependents if the benefits are better or worse then other companies.

Pros:
Work is chilled out, not very challenging... Even if it was challenging/engaging at any time, i never had to move beyond my comfort zone to meet expectations.
Cab service is good.
New buildings are good (BGL17,18). Older buildings look like 10yr old govt offices
Cons:
Pay is pretty low compared to market standards. They don't seem to normalize salaries.
New campus hires are paid more than Software Engineer-II (3-4 yr exp band)
annual increments are usually around 10% and on promotion around 5-10%.

Pros:
Compensation, some management, I really did have some of the best manager's I've had in my career while at the C, they instilled trust and a winning culture above most else, see cons for the rest. 

The severance package is more than fair, I will never fault the company here they do take care of you.
Cons: Yup, former 'GVS'er' here prior to the shift in culture, that from what I hear now, sounds extremely toxic. As with most companies this unfortunately comes from the top down. That organization went through many years of growth and doing things right, yet when a leadership change came in I can't say I was upset to get caught out in a RiF. See Advice for more....

Job Title: Compensation, benefits and job analysis specialist
Pros: Cisco enables an industry leading work/life flex. Cisco's hierarchical structure feels very flat and is incredibly symbiotic. Company culture isn't harsh, but encouraging and friendly. It's all about development--focusing on the team and specifically the positive and building relationship you should have with your manager. Those who are ambitious, work hard, and genuinely network will be recognized for their efforts and will be rewarded with great work opportunities. Cisco espouses the principle that in joining this one company, you can have multiple careers. Cisco can scale talent due to their collaborative technology--enabling us to hire top talent across the globe making Cisco a very diverse and culturally enriching environment.
Cons: Business functions can be siloed from one another. Not always an apparent information share between functions. Building bridges and tearing down walls can be arduous and time consuming. There is a lot of red tape, and it's not uncommon to deal with work that, in principle, should move very quickly but is slowed down because teams can be scattered across the global with different timezones. Cisco's culture of "let's create a formal meeting" in order to get work done isn't efficient, and it's hard to be a change agent in a team that has a culture of working to solve problems by creating formal meeting after formal meeting.

Pros: Get to work on latest technologies
Cons:
-- The executive leadership say all the right things during internal all-hands meetings to make employees feel optimistic. But somehow, things don't seem to be executed to the bottom level. 
-- Directors reporting to directors and VPs reporting to VPs and some of these directors/VPs don't even have a team under them. Not sure why we need so many directors and VPs when we are not allowed to bring in skilled employees who can really contribute to the work. Excellent and and hardworking contractors eventually move out when another company is willing to bring them in as employees. And Cisco ends up losing productivity by having to search for and train another contractor. Happens over and over again
-- When the company got a huge windfall from President Trump's corporate tax cut, employees were hoping we get to share some of that. Alas, the money was used for stock buy-back. Obviously, those holding large number of Cisco stock benefited the most. And guess who are the people who hold the largest amount of stock who enjoyed that windfall? Any special, one-time bonus or salary adjustment for employees to share some of that? Zilch.

Pros:
Good work life balance.
You get salary on time.
Cons:
There are several cons. Where should I start !!

Don't go with the "Best place to work" - tag.

1. Project is not that good. Most of them using legacy technology. Lot of unnecessary process to do a simple job. Do the process related jobs, they also use legacy tools.

2. There are lot of people to do the same kind job . So no good practices are being followed. Different people followed different practices.

3. Build process takes 6-7 hrs to complete and with manual trigger. So you can think how much precious development time is being lost.

4. Not much of innovation happens here . So learning new thing as per market standard - you can forget about this.

5. Everything depends on your manager. Even the company don't provide relocation benefit if you are moving to new state for the job. Everything has to be pre approved. So please read your offer letter carefully. Where in most of the company its is part of company policy, here it depends on your manager and BU.

6. Managers are not supportive at all. Even when the company has no strict work from office policy, the manager forces you to come to office. So dont know whats going on here. In the orientation they say - We dont have any rules, but in reality its something else.

7. There is no growth opportunity.

8. Think twice before joining this company. Its better to work in small company rather than working here.

Pros: Cisco hires top quality people
Cons: None to note so far

Pros: good work culture and great benefits.
Cons: a a a a a

Cons: slow pace can have a lot more work done

Pros: Many areas to evolve Certificate preparation
Cons: Hierarchical layers Local team headcount

Pros:
Flexible Telecommuting options when necessary
Overall easy going culture (if not directly working with you and in competition)
The name.
Cons:
Leaderships at all levels very political, and only those who are good at it move up despite their skills or true leadership skills.

Very vague promotions criteria.  Differs from manager to manager, largely because there isn't one and it is basically up to your manager's personal opinion and standard and their power in the organization.  

No rocking the boat allowed.  If you see inefficiency, go along with it otherwise you'll get negative comments in your 360 review for being difficult and hard to work with.  You'll see a lot of chasing around the tails on some very straightforward questions as a result.  

Concensus driven decisions and no true leader will drag on projects for a very long time and dissolve at some point without warning.

Pay and incentive is NOT based on performance.  Bell curve is used and even with performance evaluation, most people get the same bonus.  This discourages and frustrates high performers but is a haven for those who can adapt and just cruise on mediocracy.

Pros:
- Good benefits - work from home policy widely available.
- Looks good on CV
- Excellent collaborative tools - webex, ip phones, etc.
- co-workers generally nice people - although thats changing.
Cons:
- negotiate well when you join as salary increases are rare as hen's teeth. You will often see new joiners in the same role as you start on significantly higher salary and even a higher grade!
- promotions (as above).
- co-workers are generally nice people, however, I have seen a growing passive aggressive culture taking hold, I believe this is driven by the scarcity of raises, promotions and development opportuntities....
- poor line managers, more concerned with their own advancement.
- recent re-org poorly handled, many good people either walked or were made redundant.
- over dependance on video conferencing, no travel for face to face meetings, makes teamwork challenging to say the least.
- very little social interaction. Dont even have a team get together at Christmas. There is a Cisco christmas party - but it'll cost you approx $300 per couple, merry christmas!
- lost a lot of benefits over the last few years - cell phone, internet, soft drinks, prices up & quality down in restaurants - supposedly to save jobs.....clearly this failed/was not true.
- high attrition

Pros: Nice salary, nice benefits, well supported and encouraged virtual work environment.  I have been very happy with my work life balance for the most part.  And, there has been a big push for recognition among employees at all levels.  Most managers were good, but then, of course, not all.  I love all the visibility of John Chambers, his authenticity, his charisma.  He does care about more than money.  And I know that letting people go is not his favorite activity BUT it's been done three years in a row now in the name of transformation and it's getting a bit old.
Cons: If it weren't for the lay offs I'd be giving Cisco 5 stars.  I have very much liked my years there.  They talk a good game around innovation but it seems to be primarily focused around engineering.  There is very little support for it in any other part of the company. They talk transformation and bold moves and taking risks but it appears to be all talk and no action.

Pros: Great working atmosphere. Awesome culture. Lots of freedom. You can make a long career if you want and fit the culture. Lots of learning opportunities. 8 hours (minimum) per quarter to spend in training.  You can spend 8 hours per year on volunteering.  Woking from home options. Performance based on results.
Cons: Too much freedom could demotivate people who do not fit that style. Certain organisations are rotten in bad decision making by leadership and middle management drawing employees to adapt to significant amounts of change, new "strategies" of new leadership.  Massive layoffs in the US have lead to backfilling positions in other countries by junior pepole.  Sometimes management expets the same performance. Which is good for learning and interacting at a higher level, but gets you to work harder to perfore well and get promoted. It is possible, you just need to work very hard for it. Too many people with remote managers are left out on their own.

Pros:
1. This place is huge and filled with awesome minded people. It's a myth that coding is intrinsic property of a person. I feel coding is not individual but a cohesive task and with right people you have higher chances of writing better code. Cisco is one of that place where writing bad code is really tough job because it's not you can do easily here.
2. Growth opportunity here is tremendous. From outside it is one company but from inside it is around 10 different business units and believe me they all are not easy to get inside. It is really great how you can switch between these all BU's and be in the same company. It's great for the profile build up.
3. Hell amount of innovation and technology languages. You name it, Cisco has it.
4. World class office space and world class discussions.
Cons:
1. Work from home gives you great work life balance but at the same time you end up working 24X7
2. Huge org, so it is difficult to make yourself visible. Some people generates tendency to be in shadows.
3. Little bit slow in day to day work style.

Pros: The work was technically challenging and my coworkers were a great group to work. The benefits were decent and bonus was nice. I was provided the tools needed.
Cons: There is a ridiculous amount of churn at the SVP level . Had 4 SVP leaders in 32 months. Churn just below them the same. One VP lasted 2 months. No on the same page but the big bonus's stay the same. They also contradict each other. Our SVP said to focus on quality and a group meeting. The next week the group VP said focus on time to market not quality, the exact opposite. You tend to get siloed and management does not seem able to figure out get workers access to the numerous training programs or worse this lack of access is intentional. Tell your manager to figure out how to get access to "Chuck" bucks for training. Intergroup working relationships can be difficult probably due to the Cisco HR stacked ranking mechanism. People do not want to help out when integrating different products/functionality together. Definite ageism in labor reduction practices. Buy other companies then start killing the product even when still achieving 20% growth. I'm sure the tier 1 telco's are going to be happy about that.

Pros: - Remote Work - Personal development - positive work environment and culture
Cons: - Corporate Bureaucracy can be daunting

Pros: Company provide good work life balance

Pros: Cisco is a stable, solid company, process-oriented, structured company who treats employees well.   The benefit package and long PTO days are very attractive.  Salary is above average, very reasonable for the type of software development work required.  The work environment is very nice too.   Nice campus, location, cafeteria, gym and various services on site. Cisco offers good job security and job growth, internal promotions, transfers....  Depending on the work groups, people I meet there are generally happy .  If you can find a team you like and a team that contributes to Cisco's bottom line then you chances of happiness is higher.
Cons: Dealing with globalization may not be easy.  Teams that coordinates with offshore teams often work long, strange hours.  You might be expected to attend meetings (online, at home ok) as early as 7am or as late as 10pm.   Cisco though more agile than a company of similar size is still big.  Product cycle is slow (1+yr) and very process oriented.   Things don't get done as simple and as fast as they should.  Maybe folks there are pretty set in their own ways.  Not the most innovative crowd.  Don't be stuck in a group that is not performing.  Bottom line counts a lot in Cisco.

Pros: Only name is big plus some company perks thats it.
Cons:
Every year huge layoffs which makes it very unstable while upper management able to continue and secure their jobs which is totally unjust.

Useless restructuring all the time which is just moving same teams under one manager to another while keeping same management team which is not going to improve anything.

employees buttering their managers got promotions and higher bonuses even if they are not doing anything throughout the year which is culture adopted due to higher presence of people from India where this is pretty common.

outsourcing of jobs to India which is on rise as Cisco is cutting jobs from here and hiring folks heavily in Bangalore India which is not a healthy trend and it was tried and failed in some groups in past. Some groups do not even have any USA employee presence and they are totally located in India while dev team is located here which caused latency in progress but since Indian lobby is pretty strong in Cisco they are able to save their jobs easily and rule the company. Moreover folks are laid off from here while people from India are pouring in every day in numbers.

Pros: The most fair and caring company I've ever worked for.   Legitimately care for their employees and customers.   The lengths at which they go to please customers I have never heard or seen of before..sometimes to a fault.   Have been able to navigate tricky market transitions and still stay relevant.   Its a $50B company with small company feeling as the command and control structure is well thought out and cared for.
Cons: $50B companies don't move fast enough to stave off market changes/competitive threats.  Internal politics - as you can imagine - are alive and well.   Have a challenge in front of them as market moves to cloud based IT - not only in products but in positioning/marketing.  Hard to distinguish and reward the right behavior given 'core technology' upgrades bring in more revenue then a more strategic - higher margin - business outcome sale.   Although they preach work-life balance continually - its up to the individual to maintain.

Pros: Cisco is a great company to work for.  Conditions of employment are great , lots of perks (health care, etc), and opportunities to help develop your own skills, generally pretty fair pay rates, lots of flexibility of manage your work/life balance.  Of course, the Cisco 'ask' is that you work to the best of your ability to service the customer and the company, in that order.   As a Customer Success Manager, my role is to help our customers consume the Cisco products that they have bought; though not in a 'break-fix' sense.  More so in working with the customer to aid and guide them, whilst orchestrating the services and support they may need to get the best from the platform, in the context of the customers organisation.  Its a very satisfying role.
Cons: Like any large company, Cisco is sometimes difficult to navigate, and is often driven by process, to achieve consistent outcomes.  Fortunately, there are generally provisions in-built for 'exceptions to process' in order to meet a specific customer circumstance.

Pros:
*  Pays slightly above market
*  Good work life balance
*  Generous work from home
*  People are generally pretty nice if a bit passive
Cons:
*  No upward mobility.  Absolutely zero.  You will be at the same level you hired into
*  Boredom.  You will be doing the same very narrow task again and again and again.  Or you will be waiting for decisions from levels above you.
*  Very very siloed.  Deliberately.  You will probably have limited interaction with your immediate team.  Pretty lonely
*  Annual layoffs.  The behavior and performance problems are long gone and the people now getting laid off are bad fits for their organization.  Why are they bad fits?  Usually because of a prior botched reorganization that was poorly thought out
*  You will be reorganized every 3 to 5 quarters.  Expect it

Cons: Very wide spread job requirements that make the profile very unique

Pros: Good compensation & benefits if you have an upper hand.
Cons:
Once you have accepted the offer & joined, it is quite difficult to move up or get appreciated, unless you are good at kiss a** to succeed. 

Lot of engineers with mediocre talent perhaps the budget dictates the quality of people. Bureaucracy & process bogs down everything. First skill you should need is politics and how to derail others work.

Cisco internal Pulse employee survey meant to get candid feedback about their boss / management & Cisco. But  it is one big phony trick, you will forced to give a positive feedback abt boss & senior management, if not you will have to face the same consequence on performance review, because the management will indirectly warm you that they have a mechanism to identify what the individuals response are.

We are developing a product for past 4-5 years under the excuse that the customers absolutely rely on it for their day to day network operations, but in fact there is only a handful of actual users using the system out of 1000's of projected users, and we haven't even added any net new features for more than past 2 years with 20+ team just doing bug fixes, because the code & standards are so poor. There is not much respect/value for engineering, which leads to high attrition, it is like a revolving door. I have seen more than 25 people come join & leave in my team alone...

Decided its time to move on..

Pros:
I am part of Cisco India SP group for the past 10+ years. pls note that my views apply to Cisco India workplace and is different from Cisco US. I have not worked in any better place, following are pros
1. A very well oiled machine with complete life cycle of product development is present in India.
2. Expertise available in all areas which is fantastics for career growth.
3. A very competitive work place where fairly low percentage of people can take their position for granted.
4. Cisco pays bonus in better than reasonable way, usually close or above promise. Never betrays on that.
5. Work place resources (non-software) are best in the world, yes best in the world. Ex. fantastic transport,work place environment, furnitures, gardens, cafeteria.
6. Better than average software tools but not world class. However, cisco keeps improving. This makes a life little easier.
7. Reasonable work life balance with burst of high pressure cases.
8. High focus on customer delivery.
9. reasonable rewards (360 degree)
Cons:
Here are the cons
1. Opaque performance appraisal
2. India management is still under US Management and is unable to take directions on its own, typically gets dictated by US management at the cost of Indian teams efforts. Need to be self empowered and take up Products all by itself. Many product successes and significant talent available to become self-reliant.
3. Below par salary levels, causing attrition of good talent.

Pros: Great pay, great benefits, lots of opportunities for career progression. Very collaborative environment. People are really kind, caring, and invested in one another's success.
Cons: The company is so focused on social causes that they are losing perspective on their products and overall excellence in work. There are more meetings held to showcase a specific political perspective than there are to discuss how the business is doing and how it can continue to improve and succeed. People don't have the skills/capabilities they need to actually lead in their area, to innovate, or to problem solve.

Pros: They had good Medical-Dental-Vision plan. I also had an opportunity to take courses in Stanford which helped me in my career.
Cons: They had mass layoff in 2001, they are also trimming bottom 10% for many years after 2001. If you happen to do your job and work hard and manager doesn't like you for any reason, then managers can abuse power and you end up in list for next layoff. My Engineering team was technically OK but I have seen stronger teams. The ASIC methodology was not good enough and found it difficult to fix as my manager was not open to improvement. It was little support for internal IP although useage of internal IP encouraged. I managed to reengineer and manage to do my job but found the process to be inefficient. Even junior engineers are trained to think more in terms of busineess (compare with other places which are engineering focused). Cisco is combination of startups and that's a factor in their internal politics. I also had to login and work in weekends because my manager did the same.

Pros: In general respects people, has good benefits.

Cons:
Webex - every one (locals) wants to work/connect on webex only
If teams members are sitting away you are never sure if someone is working from where.
It looks good but it is not. It affects your performance too. You will always be seeking appointment.
Cisco is confused elephant now. Unsure what it wants to do. Networking or Small Cell or Cloud or Data Center or Smart City or IoT. Many other company failed in past and re-focused on what they do best. Wants to become #1 IT company but using only networking product, yet doing all stuff.

For it employee are mere commodities. Does not have any emotional attitudes towards them. It is flexible bcos most team at world wide so you will be on call most of time and rest in lab. Indians engineers spoil their personal life and become 24*7 slave if they can not handle it smartly.

Infra looks good but once in team you will realize how hard to get good cubicles is big task. All are fitting for it, so you will end up sitting somewhere.

Pros:
They own many markets.  They have the money and size to move the industry. The individual contributors and some technical managers are top notch.
This company was a leader in culture, HR, valuing employees etc.  I used to LOVE working for this company years ago.   I had a great career here and appreciate it all but...
Cons: Lost their culture. The scale used to be "we are in the top 5-10 percent"  today top 50% seems acceptable.   Constant reorganization, too many layers of unneeded management and only an echo of the past cultural values that were once so inspiring.  The company became a financial spreadsheet driven organization sometime in the early to mid 2000's and once they started "rightsizing/downsizing/limited restructuring/reorganizing..."  they got the taste and never looked back. Offshoring is constant (some of which is fine but they throw a lot of talent away in the States that could easily be retooled.

Cons: Competitive, economic market condition dependence

Pros:
- For someone interested in networking, security, and unified communications, Cisco is one of the better large companies to apply your skills
- If you have the right position in the right BU/organization, you obviously can make a large impact, given Cisco's success in the marketplace
- Overall, Cisco seems to have generally nice people
- Certain items such as its core values (ethics, frugality) are pushed downward quite effectively
- Cisco shines in sales and channels
Cons:
- Cisco has a long way to go in terms of effective product delivery (including product management and engineering). Too often, it must acquire in order to enter new markets.
- Product cycles are too long (1-2 yrs on average from concept to FCS)
- Brain-drain (outward)
- Too bureaucratic in terms of career growth, ownership of efforts, accountability
- When one can get higher compensation, more responsibility/authority/accountability, better title at other technology companies, one has to wonder what true advantage there is to stay at Cisco
- Too many "lifers" coasting

Pros: Judged on how well you perform, not the hours you work. The total rewards package is well rounded. Stock, base pay, and vacation time are all very accomodating. People are expected to perform and not required to come in to the office unless needed. There is extreme flexibility to work from wherever. The company respects their employees and encourages everyone to develop themselves in both experiences and formal education. Customers generally have a high level of respect for the services teams which makes project that more enjoyable to manage. Senior management has always been very respecful of the worlk/personal life balance.
Cons: Accounts are silo oriented. This means that when one does well on an account, the are very often only working on one account. So, the recognition does not always leave that particular acocunt team. It is also very flexible in allowing one to work from wherever, but on the other side, one needs to be in the office to get promoted. Promotions are very hard to come by and raises are not given unless one goes through a long, grueling process. Senior management needs to do a much better job of connecting performance to monetary rewards. Most of the time, one wonders why people get promoted.

Pros:
1. Work Culture is ok. You have something called as work from home option so that you can work from any part of country
2. Great campus
3. Great food court in campus :)
4. Good facilities like online access to Safari, Wi-fi network in entrie campus ( you can work from food court also), gymnasium, tennis court, basketball court, cricket pitch, volleyball court
Cons:
1. I am with Cisco from past 3 years. Believe me there has been not even a single Indian Rupee hike. People might be talented here, but their attitude towards others is very bad especially seniors. 
2. Everyone pretends to be Champion across all platform and technologies, but most of them know nothing. Most of the people here in India are very rude.
3. Working from home is good option, but on the other hand its painful coz you are expected to work in US West Coast Timings and attend late night meetings
4. Too much work pressure for very little salary
5. Even though all the sports and gym facility is present, work pressure is so much that you never get time to visit any of these sport facility any time
6. When it comes to money, Cisco is really bad as they never give good hikes as compared to other companies.

Pros: Stable work culture, collaborative and friendly employees would be the top pros  this company has going for it. They aren't afraid to take chances were they think it can benefit the business. You get the sense that you are part of something that is bold in nature and it helps push your motivation even on those days when you maybe not 100% 'into the whole job thing anyway."
Cons: Takes a long time and endless meetings to get things done. I came here from the public sector and I expected much quicker decision making on key issues. Management in my organization does not always communicate effectively how their decisions will impact their staff down the line. Large contingent work force. While this may be fine for managing expenses during business fluctuations the contingent work force does not get the same corporate culture messaging that Cisco "Blue Badge" employee get. This creates a hired hands mentality with some in the contingent workforce and sometimes slows down the decision making process.

Pros: The work is interesting and challenging and you get to work with some really motivated and talented people. Our use of vendors to augment employees allows us to be flexible with our headcount and ratios while getting a lot of good work done.  Change is happening so there is anyways something new to drive goals and initiatives; it doesn't get stale.
Cons: Our executives are out of touch with the general employee population and if you aren't in the right circles, it is difficult to get heard or get promotional opportunities.  We talk a lot about our  People Deal and how each employee matters but it feels like it is really The Some People Deal, depending on who you know.  We do layoffs of good employees instead of managing our vendor population and don't facilitate moving impacted employees to open positions within the company.  As a manager and leader, I usually feel the good outweighs the bad and support the leadership but I'm starting to wonder.

Pros:
Benefits are top notch as a blue badge (direct full-time, not contractor) with really cheap medical-vision-dental, employee discounts through major companies like Apple and Verizon, 401k with matching, adoption services, and more
Pay is good (50-50 split with $90k average OTE for starting rep) but definitely not the best for the industry.
Company laptop and credit card
Ability to self manage your territory most of the time
Can bring your dog to work
Very mod office environment
Cons:
Upper management (directors and executives) largely seems to come from positions unrelated to what they manage so they do not understand the job.
Does little to fix the real problems preventing sales peoples success like a lack of marketing, sales reps having to do double duty as support, or a consistent way to bring in new business other than pray.
Will throw money at problems in hopes it looks like they are doing their jobs as management without actually doing a lot of help.

Pros: I love the flexible schedules and the ability to work from home.  The culture, the people, the constant learning... it's great.  In 12 years I have only ever encountered one bad manager and that person was released within 6 months.  They really listen to the people in all levels of employment.
Cons: the hours... while the schedule is flexible, when working in a sales support role, the hours are not the typical 8-5 m-f.  I have worked many late nights and many weekends.  There are some weeks where my hourly pay is minimum wage due to being on salary.  Answering the phone or responding to texts and emails outside of the 8-5 hours is required, not just expected.

Pros: This is really a GREAT company! Very flexible as well as family & pet friendly (I don't have pets but just letting you know).  Really really great benefits & bonus programs. What I love most is the diversity amongst the staff here, many people to connect with.  Great team support.  Not too many bad things I can say and I've been with the company over 10 years.
Cons: *This is from a staff point of view, not a leadership role or Engineer role view* so here it goes....if you are not working out of the headquarters (San Jose) OR the  next best office like RTP (that's North Carolina ;-) you are more than likely going to be stagnant in your position.  It takes a long time to get promoted & that was not what was told to me when I got here.  The location I work out of is the one location I would not recommend to anyone looking for a job. It does not represent the company as a whole at all-the joy & happiness & friendliness I get out of San Jose & RTP compared to this location is like night & day.

Pros:
- Good work-life balance (depending on role)
- Friendly work from home policies
- Great people
Cons:
When I started at Cisco, they were still doing the free drinks, free food, and beer parties on Friday. That went away as soon as the downturn started, and then the layoffs began shortly thereafter. The first couple of years they laid off the bad people, and then there weren't any bad people left, so they just started flailing the axe at random. Every year around late summer, it swings again, so everyone is just sitting in dread waiting to see who goes. Then, afterwards, you have to try to figure out how to get things done when important pieces of your team aren't there anymore. 

It's still an okay place to work, and the people who are left below upper management are all great. I wouldn't tell you not to take a job there, but be aware that you're going to spend every summer wondering whether you'll have a job in the fall.

Pros: Pay is good and I am bonus eligible. Work/life balance is also good.
Cons:
Work from home is a thing that is not going away. They have pushed the back to work plan every month since June. If you like working from home, Cisco is the place for you.

Everything peripheral to the business is social justice oriented. Again, if that's your thing, Cisco is the place for you. You cant buy a notepad in the company store without being hit over the head about how part of the proceeds go to a social justice initiative. I'd rather my workplace be apolitical.

Little to no training. There is very much a, "Welcome to Cisco, here is a list of names of people who you might need to know. Figure it out. But feel free to ask questions.", attitude that is being addressed, but it's still a thing.

I've been here for a year now and I haven't even had a performance review. So, if I'm doing a good job, I don't know it. If I'm not, I don't know it. And if either of those things are the case, I don't know how to keep doing well or how to do better. I'm still figuring it out.

Pros: Take care of Employee well
Cons: They keep doing continuous LR

Pros: Wonderful position and I've gained great experience
Great Benefits (pto, day for me, parental leave)
Cons: Fire drills due to exec misalignment

Pros: Great culture and management is very attentive
Cons: No flexible work hours for employees

Pros: good place to work. work life balance is there
Cons: Nothing to share as of now

Pros: Work from home. Team oriented. Great team work.
Cons: Low salary compare to the market.

Pros: Good culture - enjoyed my time
Cons: Layoffs too frequent happenings there

Pros: Great company to work for
Cons: Large company to work for

Pros: WLB is good and the teammates are supportive.
Cons: The work is mostly on legacy code.

Pros: Culture is absolutely fantastic. Managers are trained to be managers and handle people effectively. I love coding as spare activities, my manager encourages this and it has led to very creative and interesting results. We feel like part of a family and the benefits are outstanding. I just told my parents 'hey this colleage gave me $100 on a connected recognition award because I helped him outside my normal activities" and they were like 'wait, you guys send MONEY to each other just because?" and I explained, not just because, there is a way for us to recognize one another with giftcards, of course supervised and honor-based. They could NOT believe it. sometimes neither can I. Tons of benefits. would recommend 10/10.
Cons: some roles (like mine) are not fully mobile, meaning I need to visit partners every now and then, this doesn't allow me to go for example to a friend's apartment in new york and work from there, and explore NYC at night. (just an example).

Pros:
This information will be mostly applicable for graduates/interns/people for whom this is the first job in IT. Here are some facts about Graduate program, which helps you to become a network engineer with almost 0 technical background. All facts are based on personal experience of finishing such program in EMEAR: 
+ during ~6 month you get all possible trainings to be introduced to your job responsibilities
+ mentors assignment, so you are never alone with any issue/question you face
+ rotation in different teams/departments during the program 
+ did I already mention that it does not require any networking background? 
+ full-time, fully-paid (salary is above average for entry level positions)
+ access to all Cisco knowledge/learning platforms and all trainings 
+ passing certifications for free (CCNA,CCNP,CCIE, etc) 
+ international environment, cohort from all around the EMEAR
+ nice benefits: Multisport card(any gym you want and unlimited), Connected Card (money for transportation), Meal Card(for restaurants and supermarkets) 
+ relocation bonus (if applicable)
Cons:
- unequal load-balance between teams
- some backbone teams are understaffed ( this problem is getting resolved, but slowly) 
- right now is kind of post-transition period, so you may face some of challenges connected with changes 
- great variety of tools and resources, which are really useful, but not cataloged , making it sometimes hard to find

Pros: Good trainings are available to all Cisco employees. Excellent company for new young Padawan and if you join at management level
Cons: As a global company it is expected to work atleast 12-14 hours a day. No concept of work life balance. While it is good to do that when you join the company for first year but expecting that for all the years something is a miss. Opportunities of growth only available if you are in the same location and bonding with management. There is no concept of providing performance feedback of your peers to level above them anonymously.

Pros:
Flexible working culture
Cab facility
Campus Facilities
Working with the best minds
RSUs and ESPP
Leave policies are good
Decent pay
Internet reimbursement
Company-sponsored registration to most of the popular learning resources (Coursera, LinkedIn Learning, Pluralsight, Udemy, etc)
Cons:
Few Egoistic, Short-tempered managers (esp in NFGW/Firewall/Security BU) can make your life hell (This may happen in any company, but mentioning it as I have seen/experienced it here)

w.r.t above point, have seen many of team members under such managers, go through serious stress-related health issues up to the point of getting admitted to hospitals, meditation centers, or starting counseling sessions for depression.

Internal changes are possible but have to go through the lengthy process of bureaucracy.

Grade change/promotions take a very long time.

Hikes are not aggressive and if you are staying long, pay would be drastically less than compared to your peers outside.

Pros: Stable large company. Too big to fail
Cons: More concerned with winning best place to work than in growing revenue

Pros: Good Pay, Interesting, Global, Benefits, Technologies Experienced
Cons: Large Organization, Lots of Politics, nothing esle to report

Pros: Good Work Life Balance Amazing People Impactful Products
Cons: Compensation can be more competitive

Pros: It is Cisco, of course!
Cons: Management lack of experience. Unrealistic expectations. Team culture.

Pros: It had good work from home opportunities
Cons: It had Long work hours

Pros: Flexible working hours and good environment
Cons: No hikes from two years after joining.

Pros: Everything is good as per me.
Cons: Nothing which I can think of now,

Pros: Good benefits, work-life balance and opportunities to learn, travel and work with friendly people. It doesnt matter where you come from. Easy ways to move internally.
Cons: Cisco is a great place to start or end a career. Problem is at the upper level, hundreds of old-timers are clogging the promotion path by protecting each other and sticking around until all their options are vested. There are very few managers promoted to director and above as at these levels, hiring is often from outside. Budget for raise and promotions are always limited whether its good years or bad years. This is forcing management to give raise or promotion to 10% of those who deserve it. The attrition rate is low so they are not trying to identify why people are leaving, HR thinks everything they do is right and are not trying to improve things, except with they screw up like when they reduced everyon'e bonus by 5% which impacted most the junior employees who dropper from 17% to 12% while VPs went from 100% to 95%.

Pros:
- flexible work hours
- allowed to take time off as necessary to handle personal matters
Cons:
- Very limited career advancement, if you're not willing to self promote yourself year round, then you can forget promotions or salary increases. Even if you do promote yourself year round, you can still forget about a salary increase. Don't even mention stock options/rsu's, those are reserved mainly for execs.

- Any perks that we used to have mostly have been eliminated. We still get free coffee and hot tea.
- Health benefits are being cut back yearly it seems.
- US engineering jobs are being outsourced to china and india on an ongoing basis. Coupled with the lack of career advancement, this creates a huge moral problem.
- Ridiculous work hours expected. It used to be somewhat worth it to work long hours when there were stock options and salary increases. Now, I find myself and others working less and less after hours. And any overtime hours worked are mostly unrewarded. It's not uncommon to work day and night for several weeks and receive a $500 cap award if you're lucky. Sometimes, it's $0.
- middle management is horrible. Mostly a bunch of politicians only worried about protecting their kingdoms.
- end result of all of the above is that it is taking longer and longer for projects to get out the door and the product quality is terrible.

Pros:
Cisco Systems is the market leader in network switching and routing.
It has a global presence, an incredible sales force and outstanding support organization
focused on customer satisfaction. CIsco is to networking what IBM is to computing.
Cons:
CIsco has attempted to diversify into many new market segments in the last many years
but at the same time has lost focus on its core switching and routing markets, falling behind 
competition in getting new products to market. Cisco is trying to address this problem with "spin-ins" where selected engineers are promised millions of dollars in stock options to join a startup 
that develops a next generation switch that Cisco subsequently acquires. The irony is 
that Cisco could and should be developing these next generation products internally 
instead of farming the work out to people who leave the Company and then come back,
while making millions of dollars in the process. This has an extremely demoralizing effect 
on the engineers that were left behind whose projects were cancelled because the message
to them is either the Company is so disorganized that it cannot develop its next generation
products internally or that the existing engineering teams are not good enough to do it.
Either way it is hard to imagine a more negative internal message to motivate folks.

Pros:
Lots of really smart people, lots of different products and markets and generally on the cutting edge of enterprise networking.  
Decent salaries and great bonus program.
Cons:
Hard to move up because of constant acquisitions (acquisitions always include more senior talent)
Hard to innovate because of constant acquisitions (typically buys into new technology/products/markets rather than developing from within)  
Too much internal competition - there always seem to be at least 3 groups duplicating whatever you are doing - creating lots of dead ends and uncertainty - are you on the winning team or just spinning your wheels until the next re-org or the next round of layoffs?
Engineering jobs are being sent overseas - strictly based on financials.  Workforce globalization is eroding opportunities in the US.
Global teams and lack of appreciation for time zones create massive communication inefficiencies
 - Forget about work life balance as global teams and round the clock video conferencing occupy more of your early mornings and late nights.
 - Expect to have hundreds of emails waiting for you every morning
 - Simple decisions require committees, tons of email and meetings to resolve

Pros:
-innovative company 
-moves quickly despite large size
-sales driven
-management makes the right decisions to correct the course
-provides large responsibility to the individual contributor level
-excellent management
-I believe this company provides as close to equal pay as possible
- I am fortunate to work for a woman who is an executive's multiplier who lifts me up with her access to execs.
Cons:
-not as diverse as I would like it to be
-doesn't provide the opportunities for exposure at higher levels (need multiplier effect to be multiplied)
-women at the top tend to be viewed as ruthless and not helping other women succeed 
-not a lot of ODs are women - which appears to be a big differential
- without my manager's support I would be very lost in this culture.

Pros:
Diversity - people are from different backgrounds which makes the work environment rich in sense of ideas, cultures and experiences. Many interesting, talented and dedicated people from whom you can learn a lot.

Trainings - the abundance of online learning materials that every employee can leverage in order to gain more knowledge and master certain skills whether it be required or desired.

Innovative tools - one of the best things is that we get to use what we sell (especially collaboration tools) that makes our jobs more productive and engaging.

Activities within and outside the office - many volunteering and sports activities that are not only fun, but also very helpful in terms of getting to know your team mates and other people working at Cisco.

If you are a person who likes personal and professional development, open for constructive feedback from anyone inside the organisation, enojys challenges and leverages opportunities, it is the right place for you.
Cons:
- It is an enormous corporation, therefore hierarchy and bureaucracy are unavoidable as in all of the big organizations.
- The hiring process is selective and competitive which is why it takes an effort to make it through.
- If you are not open to constant challenges and changes, it is not the place for stability.

Pros: very employee friendly and good work life balance
Cons: none i can think of rn

Pros: Good pay and benefits Interesting technology
Cons: Hard to grow career Too much politics

Pros: -work-life balance -good benefits -company culture
Cons: -no stock options for new grads

Pros:
* Lot's of high-end and state-of-the-art technology. 
* Flexible work schedules and work from home status. 
* Training and staying current is held in high regard and a key focus. 
* For the most part, peers are willing to collaborate.
* Excellent work tools
* Reasonable benefits
Cons:
* You must expend large amounts of time blowing your own horn if you want to get ahead. 
* Upper Management has lost vision and focus on core technologies.
* Hard to move up or get promoted
* Far too many product lines are part of the overall sales and engineering focus
* Upper management buys and sells companies like at a flea market then tosses out what didn't work even though there was never a real marketing Strategy
* Seniority in time and expertise is not considered as beneficial
* Cisco moves at a snails pace due to excessive bureaucracy and bs politics
* Wasted corporate expenses on needless "feel good" programs
* Management takes no ownership for their failures/dumb decisions. Lack of accountability

Pros: Relaxed atmosphere. Great benefits. Pride of working with a reputable company like Cisco. Telecomuting perks are great as long as you are able to get into a remote situation. A lot of freedom in the way you organize your work day but it really depends of the group you are in.
Cons: Does not stand up to its motto: We revolutionized the way we work, live and play as working from remote locations will be discouraged! Feeling of not being able to make a difference. Very cliquish environment. Experience at Cisco can vary wildly from one group to another as each group has its own style. Very hard to get promoted beyond the middle management level. Competing groups have their own agendas which sometimes run counter-current to your responsibilities. Upper management is very quick in forming opinions about personnel and these opinions are very hard to change once formed. often hard to get things done. Also, having stock options for the last 10 years has been useless at Cisco since it has been underwater ever since.

Pros: Generally positive culture ("Cisco family").  Pays well, great benefits, considerable freedom, virtual office if you prefer it, still has a chance to go from good to great again, though it may take either a near-death experience or some other major top management change.
Cons: Serial downsizings.  Way too many SVPs and VPs.  Complacent, risk-averse layers of (esp) upper-middle mgmt operates with big status quo bias.  There is no sales process (ISP--a forecast framework--is not a sales process).  "Solutions" Marketing is a 9-figure waste annually due to virtually no connection to sales execution.  Giant "learning and development" (read: training) organization is a self-fulfilling prophecy like congressional programs.   Lacking good ideas, they and weak sales mgmt produce ever-more traditional sales training, despite the overwhelming evidence that it's futile for driving behavior change in risky contexts (e.g. selling).

Pros:
I have been with Cisco for around 10 yrs and I feel its a great place to work.
1) Its a happening environment and you feel you are up-todate with the latest innovations and technology
2) Resources are plenty, there are so many great minds, books, e-material, routers, simulators where you get to learn whatever you yearn to 
3) Around 80% of the colleagues share their learnings/knowledge with each other
Cons:
However there are some downsides which can be improved
1) Priorities keep changing especially when you are growing. Every morning, You prepare yourself for what to do that day, but top mgmt asks for some other urgent data and ur entire plan for the day is screwed up. The next morning you will not prepare for anything
2) Productive time to learn or explore something is slowly getting replaced with too many meetings/ updates. 1 hr of everyday update in one forum is far better than updating the same status in multiple forums, meetings, mails and debating over it
3) As a result of 2), our actual productivity happens during the family time which results in improper work-life balance -> sleeplessness ->frustration ->  less energy/enthusiasm to explore new things

Pros:
- Great work-life balance. No strict deadlines for almost most of the work items.
- Very flexible environment. Enormous Work from home, paid time off benefits.  
- Positive culture in general inside the team.
- Overall, fun to work at in your day to day life.
- Customer focused company. Everybody make sure Customer's ask are accomplished and served well.
Cons:
- You will find yourself struggling to receive quality work and project guidance.
- Lack of long term vision for products. Comparatively less features development efforts to make the product great while comparative new born products in market from other brands is bringing lot of features on table. 
- Most of the feature ask come from Customer/Marketing side. Less internal research and motivations to bring new features on the table. 
- Lack of collaboration between teams. Hence, often you find multiple teams ending up working on same thing. 
- Due to same Titles across Software and Test engineers, PERM process getting delayed due to work restructuring. 
- As an early in career individuals, not a great place to be for a tech skills learning and career growth.
- Lot more talking before committing any project and less of doing.

Cons: Low salary compensation for employes working

Pros: it was an ok place to work
Cons: gets very political. its about who you know

Pros:
- Flexible work arrangement allows you to maintain a balance between home and work.
- Strong separation between private life and work
- Diverse workplace includes people from around the globe
- Stable workplace.. people stay for long periods of time (5 years or more in many cases)
- Quiet work environment
- Great place to work if you have a family or otherwise have a life outside of work
Cons:
The pros are also the cons

- People are friendly, but relationships don't go much deeper than that.  Again, that's a good thing if you want a strong separation between home and work relationships.  Its a bad thing if you want to make 'real' friends.

- Cisco needs some creativity, but lack both the appeal to get them to the door and the environment to allow them to flourish

- Some employees lack of perspective due to very little or no experience outside of Cisco.  Sometimes people come here as graduates and stay forever.  That's a good thing if you want stable employment.  Its a bad thing if you want to remain competitive and maintain perspective.

Pros: There are a lot of very smart people at Cisco still.  The company has built an amazing infrastructure that allows work to be done very smoothly.  The linkages between functions is mature and well thought out, like the partnership with HR, the support from IT, etc.  Cisco still has a great business, which means it has enough money to fund efforts so that they can be done right rather than shoe-stringing things together and not getting the outcomes that are possible.
Cons: There are a lot of people at Cisco today that are managing their careers rather than their business.  The environment has become much more political after 2001 and you have to be careful of people's intent.  One of the more interesting cultural outgrowths of the increased politicization is that people are reluctant or unwilling to help others.  They are intensely focused on promoting and positioning themselves without concern for growing and building teams and peers.

Pros: For those in tech, especially project or general management, Cisco provides a great experience on how a multi-billion dollar corporation operates in the technology sector. I learned a tremendous amount at Cisco, especially "the bigger picture", like marketing and sales. I didn't have any experience in these areas prior to joining Cisco. Great benefits.
Cons: Cisco is big and the typical challenges exist - tons of process and overhead. It really can stifle innovation and agility. However, it's a business that is very much about the bottom line. The best product managers and leaders are the ones that can translate a vision into a story of revenue and market share, which is kind of the cornerstone of a business like Cisco. Given it's size and background, Cisco's culture is more rigid than most of the new Silicon Valley big boys. However, it was never a problem for me as I knew what the culture would be like before I joined. Work-life balance was also never a problem.

Pros:
I worked for almost 6 years before moving to different company.  The policies are employee friendly, good campus ( Bangalore-Cessna park), good cafeteria, company provided transportation is the best, up to $100 per month internet bill reimbursement, easy to change teams internally. 
HR team and policies are women friendly.
Cons:
# Too many Org. changes, frequent layoffs, stupid 1st line managers who have no clue how to manage senior resources. 
# Hikes are unpredictable - sometimes two consecutive cycles are missed, sometimes the numbers are really low. 
# Getting promotion is next to impossible if you are a G8/above.  You need to be a really good boot-licker to get consistent hikes/promotion. 
Annual performance review is a joke- manager rates you as he wishes (rarely based upon your performance)
# New College grads are being hired at salary higher than people working in cisco with 6-8 years of workexp. 
# Some 1st/2nd line managers behave as if they are the CEO of the company- arrogant and unprofessional attitude.
# Lack of strategic vision for future by the top management. 
# NOT a company to stay for more than a few years- you constantly have the layoff sword hanging over your head!!!

Pros:
- Excellent talent.  The people you work with are the best in the business.
- The benefits are very good.
- You are always challenged.
- There is always something to learn.
Cons:
- Salaries are low for the industry...there is a feeling that you should accept this because you work at Cisco.
- It is very hard to get promoted, or get raises.  Senior management routinely will stop all raises for years at a time, meaning that the only way to get a raise is by an "equity adjustment".
- Teamwork is poor, when you send an email or leave a voicemail, the first thing most people do is look you up in the directory to see your title, if it is not good enough, don't plan on hearing anything back from that person.

Pros: Flexibility in terms of telecommuting, good environment in the offices, generally positive coworkers, some very smart and knowledgeable people.  Until recently, the chance to train to learn new skills and broaden existing skills.
Cons: Intensely political with limited to no chance for advancement, no raises and generally downward trend in salaries.  To advance requires spending a great deal of time selling oneself and picking high visibility projects rather than just doing the job at hand and doing it well.  To advance and get a raise you either have to give 100% of your time to Cisco, polish the proper knob or hitch yourself sycophant-like to an up and comer.  Or some combination of all three.  It's not about results it's about self-marketing.

Pros:
A Technology leader. CoreLogic is not adverse to spend and try new technologies to improve their product. Employee, depending on job role, has a great potential to learn many new technologies and be current in their field.

Rewards as a recognition for job performance exists, though in small quantity and small by industry standards.

Job security is there for any employee if they are a high performer -- or as it seems as a reward for a employee who has been there long term, close to retirement and in good standing with management.

In most cases a very frugal organization. In most cases spends money wisely and does not spend money needlessly to the chagrin of many vendors.
Cons:
Top heavy!
Still a somewhat patriarchal organization. Many organizational levels to justify position and accompanying salaries. Definitely not a flat organizational structure.

Some ineffective, non-performing managers and lower level workers are kept on for no apparent reason due patriarchal nature of the organization. If you are good *Kissing-Ass* and have the gift of the gab to your manager , then you will fit in well in the organization.

Starting salaries are low and pay raises are few and far between. So my advise to prospective candidates is to negotiate the highest pay rate you would be happy with for 2-3 years.

No paid overtime.

Staff attrition rate is high. Many have left for better paying work and paid overtime

Pros:
1. provides university tuition assistance
2. flexible work hours
3. has invested in lots of software tools and infrastructure - good place to self learn quite a few new technologies
4. the top management tries to spread the gospel of fair play and fairness among the lower rungs - but the middle level management from Director down is really very mediocre
Cons:
1. A hub center of political activity
2. most engineers are of very mediocre quality - could do with better hiring process
3. very mediocre directors and managers - most have them are past retirement age and dont bring in any value
4. Its who you know that matters than what you know, when it comes to career growth 
5. typical  culture of slavery - a very concentration of a particular ethnic community within all projects - not much diversity
6. strictly not recommended as an exciting work place

Pros: Lots of resources to work on projects, comfortable working environment, and you get to work on products that are used at scale by a lot of people.
Cons: Management is a disaster, incompetence is rife, and you always know that your product is being run into the ground with executive management thinking about when, not if, they are going to cancel it. Cisco is a machine for extracting value from acquisitions: it buys companies and then strip-mines them. Good people leave to find better jobs and the people who can't find better jobs are promoted based on tenure rather than ability. Every Cisco office starts out decent and gets progressively worse. There's a running joke that if you're ever handed a brief for a new product then you should quit and start your own company to build it, because Cisco will buy your company for a lot more than they would have paid you and you'll get to take all the good people (and only the good people) with you. Don't look for career advancement here; if you don't enter the company as executive management then you are an expense to be reduced.

Pros:
I'm very passionate about security and I get to work for one of the work leaders in field. I feel like the work I do is actually making a difference in the world. I enjoy the work that I do on a daily basis.

I'm very well paid. My base salary is very competitive. The bonus percentages are very high at Cisco. I've had double digit percentage raises and double digit percentage bonuses in the last year.

I get to work from home multiple days per week.

There are a lot of smart people who can do really cool things.

My office gets free lunch, free coffee (good coffee too), free drinks (red bull) at the vending machines, all snacks at the vending machines only cost a quarter.

I could wear a t-shirt, gym shorts and sandals to work at my office and nobody would care. Almost no dress code at all.

The office is very nice, clean, etc.

Good benefits like healthcare, vision, dental, etc. They also have stock options that are good.
Cons:
Politics regarding acquisitions and merging teams can get in the way of doing actual work or event prevent projects from being able to be completed at all.

I can't bring my dog to work anymore.

That's about it for complaints.

Pros:
Cisco's People Deal is real and is pervasive in all of the moments that matter in your career. From your recruitment through retirement/moving on, Cisco aims to make sure they make each "Moment that Matters" special.

The HR Leadership Program (HRLP) has given me multiple rotations through various HR specialties, giving me a good base knowledge of HR and has helped me identify where my strengths and passion will allow me to contribute at a high level.

In HR you are treated like a true professional. As long as you're performing at an acceptable level, no one pays attention to or cares where, when, and how you get your work done.  This is great for work flexibility. I have worked from several locations for extended periods of time only needing to take part of that time as Paid Time Off, and not missed a beat.

The technology plays a large role in the work flexibility as in any given day I can be talking with people from any part of the world, face-to-face over WebEx or Telepresence video.
Cons: As the technology can allow for great work flexibility, it can also allow work - if you don't proactively manage it - to take over your life as you CAN always be available.  Manage your schedule with your stakeholders and you'll be fine.

Pros: Great worklife balance and interesting work
Cons: Total comp is lower than FAANG

Pros: The benefits and the people
Cons: pay not as competitive as other companies

Pros: Many growing approaches and chances.
Cons: Benifits can be much better

Pros: Love it here great work
Cons: Always on your feet gets tiring

Pros: A great company for many years with a healthy work/life balance. The company pays well with great benefits and all in all great people and great environment. Your life at Cisco can be the best experience of your working career but your life at Cisco is directly related to which division you work for. I would recommend anyone coming to Cisco to stay within their established strength core competencies and stay away from Cisco's new business ventures, as Cisco tends to drop these after a few years if they do not perform as expected taking the employees with it.
Cons: Company politics rather than flawless execution can be the order of the day with people spending more time on pointless conference calls and meetings then closing or developing business.The concept of employees acquiring wealth through stock is now long gone and employees are now just large company assets with a steady paycheck.

Pros: At all levels of the organization, there is emphasis and value put on diversity in the workplace.  Many leaders understand the beauty and strength of our differences, and are not interested in creating a cookie cutter employee.  Many of the perks of being a Cisco employee highlight how much they want to take care of their employees, such as the onsite health and fitness centers, family events on campus, etc, but they go beyond these "nice to have" items and back up their words in the work.  My opinion is appreciated most when it differs from those around me and offers a fresh perspective.  We also have very strong communities to support each other and enable success of the individual.
Cons: There are very few cons when it comes to working for Cisco.  It certainly isn't like a startup environment and ideas can take longer to put into action because of the bureaucracy that comes with a company of over 70k employees, but you can learn to navigate these waters smoothly.  There is vibrancy and learning at Cisco that you won't find elsewhere.

Pros:
A good place for political player and talkers.
Because you talk and present and don't need to write any code or design or architect anything.
Very good pay for Principal Engineer, director level pay and don't need to do much.
A balance of life and work.
Cons:
Not enough coder. The quality of the products is severely impacted.
The pay is not attractive unless you are level 12 or above. like Principal Engineer.
Every year, there is always an annual layout.
The layoff is not based on performance but connection.
Don't expect you can get a green card soon or one because every layoff, the green card process is stopped.
RSU goes to the management, engineers won't get much or any.
Firefighting on the lousy product all the time. No clear future road map.
Promotion is based on connection, not performance. Cisco constantly promotes senior manager (not very technical people) to Principal Engineer. That is why it keeps losing its technical leadership. Losing market share to its competitors.

Pros: Despite my initial reservations and shynesss I have grown more confident as a gay employee at Cisco as Cisco’s leadership and its policies towards the LGBT community have grown to be more progressive. It took one call to HR and zero paperwork to add my partner to benefits. When I reached our  HR to say I had come out and wanted to know if there was an employee group, their first words were “congratulations.” Our resell partners sponsor an LGBT social at our annual sales conference (we have the best resell partners on the planet). And we have executive sponsors who honestly care about our welfare. They matched my donations to Orlando, PRIDE, and supported us in the San Francisco parade. They are sensitive to the situations other employees face in other countries.
Cons: They are not leaders; rather, fast followers in LGBT advocacy. In North Carolina. In Texas. In Washington. At the San Fran parade. Room to grow. Not a place to expect leadership. But a place to expect acceptance, decency and support.

Pros: The people 100%. Everyone is so helpful, positive, and extremely smart so they make me want to improve every day. The benefits and pay are awesome. The time to give and volunteer policy shows that they care about helping the world improve, some of the stories are incredible! They provide communications and trainings on the latest changes to the products and processes so we are up to date. The internal communication setup is far beyond anything I have seen, with Webex Teams we have a very intelligent setup to communicate with virtually anyone at the company and at any level of management. Lots of opportunity for growth, they encourage you to move up or around every 3 years to keep from getting complacent! I could go on and on.
Cons: It's a very big company so of course there are things that are hard to scale. We have a lot of systems and tools so that can be challenging, but the team is working on reducing those. I'd say things change a lot continually but a lot of that deals with the industry we are in.

Pros:
It's almost been 1.5 years that I started working at Cisco. I joined through Cisco Sales Associate Programme (CSAP). Here are a few highlights of my journey so far:
1. Being a fresher, I think CSAP shaped me to face challenges in everyday work and deal creatively with them as they come. A blend of classroom and On-the-Job training makes it such an enriching experience.
2. Its a place where you feel valued everyday and know that your work matters.
3. A whole ecosystem of support to help you anytime. 
4. Its an extended family. A very motivated work environment makes you want  to put your best foot forward.
5. Its an extremely collaborative environment where you work not only with locally placed teams but also with teams spread geographically! It enhances your experience all the more. 
5. Its all work and so much more fun! Regular small activities, team building events, off-sites and get togethers ensure that you don't burn out and enjoy your work equally much!
Cons: Like any other large organisation, there are constant leadership changes and internal restructuring which requires you to be an your toes and stay abreast of latest developments all the time. It grooms you in a certain way but might also cost you if you don't know how to deal with constant change.

Pros: good work culture and good team
Cons: timings and planning need to improve

Pros: Large company that is very stable
Cons: Lots of red tape to deal with
