Pros: Great benefits Flexibility at work
Cons: Not too much opportunity for mentoring

Pros: Eh nothing much but food
Cons: Crappy management and need better pay

Pros: Good benefits Good time balance
Cons: Not much to think of

Pros:
Flexible hours.   You are free to work whatever 70 to 80 hours you prefer each week.

The yearly layoff packages are fairly generous.  When you finally get laid off (and that is how most people who leave the company do so,   you have a good chance to double dip for awhile)
You learn alot about corporate politics.   

You learn how to keep your Director happy and what happens when you get a Director that doesn't like you.

You get to say you worked at Cisco and it looks good on a resume.
Cons:
Yearly layoffs.  NO ONE is ever safe.  No one.

I have seen top tier, highest rated engineers be cut.  I have seen low performers cut.  The cuts rarely have anything to do with performance,  but are based primarily on how much your Director likes you (or knows you)

Cisco has fairly low voluntarily attrition,  but very high layoff attrition (the PC term is "limited restructure".  Management fails to realize that every LR is a failure of management.

Pros: Flexible work environment (though varies significantly with the manager), good benefits. Easy to do minimal work and stay employed for many years.
Cons:
Little chance for advancement, many vicious self-promoting middle management who lead with fear. HR is useless of course, and upper mgmt is too stupid to see what's going on. Last many years have gone way over board hiring undergrads who many of which have contributed nothing after 2-3 years. I know a few who are great, but most get by on being cute and perky, while the long term employees are forced to cover. 

Annual layoffs mostly hit those who do the most work, while middle management stays fat. Reorgs are done on a regular basis just because. If the current structure was so great last year why have yet another reorg?

I've been moved 10 times between teams often even my own manager didn't know about it. No one asks if you want to move to that team, or if your skills are what is needed. We're just numbers.

Pros:
* Great company with unlimited opportunities for one to grow and excel.
* Encourages learning and personal and professional development of Engineers.
* Great culture at a company level and everyone is valued.
Cons: Having written all the pros and many more to follow, there is a con to all the pros and this is primarily because of the leadership, which believes in seeing everything started and completed on presentations and the actual execution is lost. Lot of focus on visibility aspect without actually looking at the ground level execution. Lot of opportunities are lost as the leadership level is only busy in showing accomplishments with very little to no focus on individuals growth. If you are one of those who knows how to get the limelight, you are certainly bound to grow but if you are more of doing the actual task, you are dependent upon your leaders. Growth after managerial level is non-existent.

Pros: Cisco was great because I joined a team that was highly motivated and out to build something new. I worked out of the Meraki office and really liked all of my co-workers in the building and the culture that was built there. We initially had really good dynamic, and for a period of time I really enjoyed my day to day. Over time, we had a series of leadership changes, acquisitions, and after nearly a dozen manager changes in a few short years and an exodus of talent, my team became a shell of what it formerly was. I had great experiences finding other ways to involve myself in the Cisco community that led to a lot of amazing new connections and opportunities that I will forever be grateful for. Cisco has abundant opportunities outside of your immediate org if you are motivated and ask to be involved. There were a lot of amazing upsides to Cisco, but my immediate BU was horribly mismanaged.
Cons:
Unreasonable amounts of pager duty (I was a SWE and on PD 12h a day for over 100 days of the year)
Poor upper level management of the BU caused an exodus of talent
Too many manager changes in too short of time

Pros: Chill and no work for sure
Cons: Boring and no gain for work experience

Pros: Overall Good place to work
Cons: Not that I can think of

Pros: Very good work life balance
Cons: No cons as such now

Pros: Cisco consistently upholds the standard that our days start at 8 and we take weekends and holidays. I do end up working out of hours and on holidays but by choice and not requirement. My managers have consistently supported my professional development. I had the opportunity to attend the Simmons Leadership Institute and this made a huge impact on my professional and personal life.
Cons: There is little awareness that men talk over women. I am often the only woman in the meeting and have never had a man say "wait, you just talked over her." I often have to wait until every man has finished talking before I can speak when I am running a meeting - when I am not running a meeting I often don't get to talk at all.

Pros:
Good pay, flexibility
I was in love with this company from the beginning as a college grad. I always thought I would be a lifer here. It has changed a great deal over the last 5 years as our executive leadership has shifted.
Cons:
Position in the market is slipping as Exec Leadership is more focused on social issues than driving revenue. I've seen so many peers leave the company because the technology seems to come second to "woke" initiatives. 
Cisco sent an email to all employees threatening termination in late October if you were not vaccinated or pursing an accommodation. For those that requested an accommodation, 6 months have gone by with no update. Other large tech companies have dropped this mandate but not Cisco. 
A company that focuses so heavily driving an inclusive future for all, seems to completely omit those who have medical conditions, personal beliefs, etc that derive from the narrative. 
There seems to be only one acceptable way of thinking (politically, socially) at Cisco. 
While Cisco makes headlines donating to BLM, Homelessness in San Jose, etc. the investments in Cisco Networking Academy in 3rd world companies has dried up. Very sad for our colleagues in countries like Kenya trying to make a difference.

Pros: None, lot of inherent politics
Cons: As above - a cult of self appreciating politicians

Pros:
If you are looking to learn about process and structure, Cisco is a great training ground for that type of environment. It is a well established company with decent pay and above average benefits. Here are some of the highlights of working at Cisco:

- Promote cross-functional collaboration
- Benefits: 2yr look back for ESPP
- Nice facilities, including gym and onsite medical (PPO and HMO)
- Allow for job rotation after 18 mo in current position
- flexible work schedule; work from home

This is a mature company, but the employees are still energetic and fun.
Cons: 65+ Thousand employees! Lots of politics and bureaucracy across the board (all functions). Implementation of new ideas and processes are painfully slow and difficult.....like pushing a 600 lbs boulder uphill. Promotion process it tedious and deflating, many high performing employees get stuck in roles below their capability then are "trapped" at that grade level. Good employees tend to get frustrated and rotate out of their current role or leave, which creates knowledge gaps within the group. Company does a very poor job of maintaining a best practice playbook. Loss of knowledge is common, however, there is too much recreation of existing roles do to poor documentation. Training and mentoring within Cisco has disappeared!

Pros:
Your peers are amazing
You typically get paid well
Working from home is fantastic if you can do it
Cons:
Politics are horrible here. 
Severe lack of leadership abilities at the Director and VP level.
A very caustic work environment, where the quality of what you do rarely matters, what matters is who you have sucked up to in the last year. 
Almost 90 percent of leaders are just typical MBA "yes" people. 
Lots of Directors kissing up to VP's and not telling the truth about their business. 
Power-point insanity, plus useless meetings all day everyday is typical of how your time is wasted as a leader.  
Horrible, manipulative Directors and VP's ruined the entire company after 2008.

Pros: Have worked there for 10 years.  Good pay and benefits.  Lots of good people to work with.  The best thing I have enjoyed is the flexibility, i.e. the ability to work remotely, flexible schedule.
Cons:
- You can move laterally as much as you want but upward progression can be very difficult.  Making it past Grade 11 and 12 seem to be very political.  
- Cisco relies on its bonus structure for retention.  They do not give annual pay increases.  I came in at a good rate and sat at that rate for 7 years before getting a raise.  Negotiate a good salary coming in the door because that's all you'll get for a while!
- The company still goes through an annual layoff cycle.  Good people with lots of years with the company are usually let go without the opportunity to find another position internally.  This is starting to make a lot of people anxious.  There is a big push to move US employees to their Raleigh NC (RTP) campus.

Pros:
Great people - everyone is extremely helpful, receptive to new people, shadowing for different roles is easily accomplished 
Lunch/breakfast onsite - puts the word "cafeteria" in its place as it a food oasis in a desert of boring options 
Opportunities for advancement are tremendous as well as potential to move across the USA
Cons:
Small things but from where I live and what I've experienced: 
TP location can be good or bad depending on where you live 
If you're not a fan of Las Vegas you may not enjoy being there for 3 days every august (but if you love Las Vegas then 
Organization can seem a little disjointed, coming from an organization of 200 people to one with 18k just in sales things that came easy like HR requests, websites to find information can be daunting initially, and small employee changes and what seem like mundane processes take a lot more time than seems necessary - a lot of red tape... 
Several members of the SLT team in San Jose has left recently which can be slight uneasy but overall vision has remained stable

Pros: Great company to work for
Cons: No such cons are there

Pros: culture, benefits, flexibility, pay, opportunity
Cons: big company, slow moving, corporate,

Pros: Except for good peers nothing
Cons: Salary and work life balance

Pros: good flexible challenging i like
Cons: nothing i can think of

Pros: its a great product- something to be proud of.  The people you work with treat each other with respect- its like one great big family.
Cons: upper management once Cisco took over really didn't understand or know what WebEx could do and really under estimated the people especially the CSM's that worked there.  They had to lay off over 6500 people and I don't think they really knew how to do that.  It seemed as if they kept all of the people with a 10% or lower and got rid of all of the people with a 10% or higher on their performance.  Upper management never spoke to the right people.  I believe everyone should be heard for a company to survive and not just manager or VIP's sometime the CEO has to start over to understand what the customers are looking for.

Pros: This company has a culture of consensus, which means that we can take a lot of time to make decisions, but at least there's no bully in the room dictating one way or the high way. What I enjoy the most about Cisco is that it has given me the opportunity to be truly me: I have been promoted twice in 7 years, while having a 1 year old son when I started and a baby 4 years after starting at Cisco. Whenever my kids are sick, or I had to take them to an appointment, my team always had my back. This is the main reason why I am at Cisco - this employer will make sure men and women can have exciting opportunities at work WHILE being a parent. We have 40 hours a year of volunteer time, I use it to attend my kids field trips and volunteer at school. There is true worklife balance and a lot of flexibility when it comes to working hours. As a woman, I value this tremendously.
Cons: This is a very very big company and if you don't network and get out to meet people, you'll miss out on opportunities.

Pros:
If you need a job to pay the bills it will do it. 
You have the benefit of the big name Cisco. Looks good on resume.
You can easily be hired. Most likely the people who will interview you, don't know much about software development. But careful, that can backfire. If they see you know to much they won't hire you to avoid to look inferior (old game, hire worst than you to look better). Remember the Seinfeld episode where Kramer went to do karate with little kids ? That's it ...
Cons:
Although backed up by the name Cisco, every office is different. 
This review is specifically for the orange county office, if you are looking to be hired there.
If you are a motivated software engineer, I do not recommend this office. Management is not qualified
Career advancement does not happen based on merit if not at all.
A lot of injustice, politics, wasting time in things that don't matter instead of investing on the ones that matter.
Hard to work on good projects. They will promise you exciting stuff, but than you will find yourself to fix bugs on horrible code bases written by who knows who.    
Management is ridiculous. Bunch of talks no facts.

Pros: Was once a great company when I started.  I call this Cisco 1.0.  A lot of momentum and product is very sticky.  Powerful company that owns their partner community.  Some very good people
Cons: Many of the managers think their customer is their boss.  They sell up and forget that the real Big C customer can fire them instantly unlike the managers who don't have real Big C customers.  They missed two huge transitions, cloud and virtualization.  ACI is an attempt to put the cat back into the proprietary bag similar to IBM with Micro Channel.  Customers do not want lock in and also want quicker feature delivery which means software.

Pros:
*Impactual Work
*Mid level management and lower level people are really great to work with
*Great Flexibility. You can definitely work at any time
*No fourloughs!!
Cons:
*It's not a democracy, so never ever think for a second it is. It is a command control system, so don't let them fool you by saying it is not. When the decisions come from the top, very little input comes from those on the bottom
*Cisco is somewhat too much of a fiscal conserative company. In this environment, it is a good thing, but everything has a line, and they seem to have crossed that line. They seem to overpay for acquisitions and not invest enough in the employees they currently have. They always say they want to be the leader or benchmark, but when you need funding for a project, or cuts in discretionary spending happen, they state that they are just following industry standard.. somewhat ironic. 
*Career advacement is too much determined on who you know, than what you do.

Pros: Cisco System is a great place to work because they make an attempt to balance work and life.  I suspect it differs from division to division but I think they do a decent job.  It is a stable company and a fine place to work for the long term.  If you're in the right job, you get to tackle some really interesting problems.  Before the recession, they had a plethora of training options both classroom and virtual.  Due to the cut back, some of it had to be trimmed back, but they do encourage you to develop yourself.
Cons: Given the size of the company, you feel at times that your impact is minimal and you are just another cog.  the size of the company has also increased bureaucratic and political complexity.  making lateral moves is difficult.  on the plus side, i think management realizes these problems and are taking steps to make changes.

Pros: Cisco provides to its employees a huge amount of resources to work and study.  Moreover, mobile workers that are mostly in Sales and Services are able to perform daily job in a very flexible manner.  Cisco gives an amazing opportunities for people who had just finished of finishing their studies. Incubator and New Graduate programs give a lot of benefits for future specialists
Cons: It is hard to rate Cisco globally, better to focus on one center, which is Krakow.  Cisco Krakow is barely managing in offering competitive salaries to professional hires and seniors. For a new graduate or inter this could be fine, but there is very small salary and carrier growth when a person is improving his skill-set and doing all the best to company. It is not the best strategy for this site to hire mostly people after university (with no or limited experience). Would be good if Cisco gives more credit to already hired employees at least for their fidelity and hard work.

Pros: Cisco is a very ethical and humane place to work.  The honest work ethic is exemplified by execs so that they are setting good examples for everyone.  Sr management is well organized and they have long-range plans in place for years to come.  Great opportunities to learn, employess are mostly empowered to do the jobs they need to do and in general are given the necessary resources.  Very process-oreinted company which allows them to be so efficient.
Cons: Lots of jobs of all levels and disciplines are moving to India, creating a lot of uncertainty among US-based employees.  While employees generally understand the need to have a global presence, Cisco is sacrificing quality where we stood out in the industry to save money.  In reality, the savings are not that great because there's a lot of rework required to achieve the quality we have always emphasized and worked hard to maintain.  It's very frustrating and disheartenting.

Pros: Very good and attractive salary and benefits.
Cons:
Be aware of constant limited restructuring causes continuous fears of being laid off. Every single one of the five years I've been at Cisco there has been a "silent" 7 to 10 % workforce reduction. There is a culture of hiring people "suck out" that they know and then brutally lay them off. I've seen this happening so many times here at Cisco that I come to the conclusion there is a pattern behind that..
Middle management is real hell and they are afraid of their own shadows.
Impossible to be promoted, unless you drop everything your doing and appease your director by chasing the shiny ball. You don't get rewarded for excelling at your daily job, its more important to kiss senior managements rear end and get your "name known". It is all about marketing yourself here. It's not what you do for or with customers all the work need to be done inside. Very political organization.

Pros:
- Work Flexibility is the biggest benefit of working for Cisco. You can work from home or any location of your choice in most of the BUs. Majority of roles in Engineering are location independent. Cisco provides collaboration tools to all employees. 
- Great 401K (4.5% match) and Medical benefits
- Bi-Annual Bonuses often exceed 100%
- RSUs and discounted stocks
- Recognition awards
Cons:
- Continuous layoffs; low job security therefore low employee morale
- Massive brain drain causing company to lag in dynamic tech world. Cisco is under tremendous pressure to perform and management response to it is - layoffs
- Dominance of one particular foreign nationality therefore a lot of nepotism and politics
- Constant re-orgs and management changes. In 5 years, I have seen 6 managers and 4 Business Units with just one internal job change
- Business priorities change frequently

Pros:
Good Management (Mid-level line managers are great).
Adequate recognition and rewards.
Vast peer resources (Subject experts all around)
Honest and accountable corporate culture.
Resources for Cisco Certifications.
Great health and gym benefits.

Cisco is a great place to work if you're willing to reach out to the experts and take charge of your own initiatives. There are many resources along the way to help you out. I say, and continue to say, this is a great place for college grads for the first 5 to 10 years of their career.
Cons:
Cost cutting in talent recruitment (i.e. no more college new hires in San Jose CA HW Campus).
Lots of lifers just hanging around doing average work.
Bureaucracy a major hinder.

Those criticisms are with any large company.

Pros:
In some aspects, Cisco is a great company and a stable paycheck.  Kind of like IBM of the 70's and 80's. .
SOME great people who really do care.
Great products and technology that customers want to buy.
Solid market leadership in key areas and markets.
Great vision and OK execution.
Cons:
Some sales commit calls can be like a scene straight out of Glengarry, Glen Ross.
Work, Work, Work 24/7/365.  I was on the phone with my boss on Christmas morning dealing with a customer issue.   It never ends, and the overly complicated processes that the company has in place slows productivity down incredibly, especially on the Services side.
Career advancement is practically non-existent.  If you're content with being a cog in the machine,  you'll do fine.  If yo'd like to advance your career, expect to make  lateral moves annually but any true advancement usually comes at 8-10 years of service if you're lucky.

Pros: You have the flexibility of working from home and flexible hours.  You will learn a lot about new business practices in a short period of time but do not expect direction nor a clear definition of your job role.  You can define your job role/responsibilities but it might not be tied to meaningful/valued activities.   Cisco is a great brand name company to work for and opens up doors for your next career move.
Cons: Cisco utilizes a large population of contract employees which results in a large turnover and lack of continuity in business operations.  There is a lot of overlap of roles and responsibilities within and between departments.  Projects are not thoroughly thought through and oftentimes in execution mode before the planning phase has taken place.  This results in a lot of knee jerk reactions and a moving target in terms of project objectives and process flow.   Oftentimes management doesn't know what they want but they want it implemented as soon as possible without knowing all that goes into the effort.  There is a huge disconnect between identifying problems and developing a solutions.

Pros:
- For the most part, the people are smart, expert, motivated, and fun
- Excellent work-life flexibility, including WFH, shifted hours, etc.
- Some nice on-campus perks: great cafeterias, gym, etc.
- Discounts on products and services
- Solid benefits packages
Cons:
- In recent months, upper management has been on a sharp downhill slide. The lunatics are running the asylum. 
- The loudest managers set policy and direction -- regardless of whether they have a plan or a clue.
- A backstabbing culture is on the rise, driven directly by current management.
- Accomplishment is rarely praised or recognized; morale is low and getting worse.
- A lot of silo'd groups and a lack of cohesive (and timely) communication; staff often gets blindsided with changes in approach or policy.
- Opportunities for advancement seem blocked for those not in favor with management, despite track records of success.
- Talented internal assets, especially creatives, are often marginalized and underutilized in favor or a "consultant culture" that offers more respect to vendors and agencies

Pros:
- Excellent remuneration package: comfortably above the industry average in the country, Cigna medical & dental coverage, car allowance/company car, fuel and more
- Working the some of the best people in the industry, inspiring and motivating to be in such a team
- Broad portfolio of products: every day one can learn something new, never get bored
Cons:
- No real company respect for the individual contributors, each employee is seen as just another Excel-cell
- Huge middle management, unclear actual contribution to the real business
- Huge administrative overhead; for example, one should do an official forecast on a weekly basis to the direct management, but also additional forecast to product managers, BU, services sales people, vertical people....People, just go and extract whatever you need from the official forecast! Let me do my job and SELL !
- A lot of pressure 24/7 on the job, very difficult to achieve work-life balance
- Considerable amount of internal politics; it is not the achievers who got recognized but rather the best politicians

Pros: Pay and benefits, especial ESPP and company car, which most people are eligible for. Also the spirit within the technical team and consultants are still going strong, workplace ethics are strictly enforced and looked at, there is also budget for appreciating others work as well as team activities.  Also contact to my direct managers is always great, they have an open ear for issues, may it be work or customer related, and request for time of are usually granted without problems.
Cons: The usual things when a former startup has grown very very big. Communication from upper management is mostly based on sales numbers only, making it hard to identify with if you are not working in sales. Also, the old mistake of measuring performance and customer satisfaction by surveys only, with thresholds that are mainly US based and often conflict with mentalities in other parts of the world.

Pros: Good work/life balance is possible but by no means guaranteed. There are times, sometimes months, when work can be overwhelming. There are down times when some have the freedom to pursue their professional interests without the pressure of an impending deadline. This of course very much depends on the business unit and team. There are some very bright people there.
Cons:
Communication tends to be very poor, resulting in confusion among engineers. Accountability can be very low. Many software engineers have very poor skills. Team/project managers are frequently clueless.
Antiquated software development tools and practices and a heavyweight software development process get in the way of productivity and creativity. Layers of horribly buggy, poorly documented and poorly maintained home grown tools make even basic tasks error prone and exceedingly tedious and time-consuming. A mountain of technical debt accumulated over decades of prioritizing deadlines over quality results in brittle, hard to maintain software. A low regard for the value of standards leads to software that's not portable even between consecutive versions of the same distribution of Linux.

Pros: Cisco has excellent benefits for regular employees, including all the health, vision, dental, 401k, ESPP, family bonding leave, and other benefits that are part of big company compensation in Silicon Valley.  Cisco has a good internal training and learning site that gives you access to many resources for improving your knowledge. The culture is modern and socially liberal, embracing diversity is encouraged.  And, if you are laid off, the severance package is generous.
Cons: I was part of an acquisition at Cisco.  And while it was handled well, and the transition went pretty smoothly, after a few years Cisco gutted our business in one of it's perennial layoffs. It was a disappointment, since we were making money and doing well compared to other acquisitions.  You cannot allow yourself to forget that Cisco is a big company, and if you are not working on something that's making a great deal of money there, Cisco is not likely to understand your business well enough to grow it.

Pros: As far as giant mega- multi-national corporations go, Cisco is the most benign.  On good days, I actually believe that Cisco is doing things to make the world a better place.  Even on bad days, I don't think we're doing anything to make it worse (not on purpose anyway).  Cisco is a company that you can feel proud to work for.
Cons: The same can probably be said for most companies, but direct line management can be extremely weak.  There are inconsistencies (in marketing anyway) in the ways that people are treated, whether it's moving up, down, or out of the career ladder.  HR has been incompetent for years, but it is actually getting better with management change in the last year or so.  Then there is the issue of some senior management personnel who demonstrate outright disregard for the company in the sole interest of furthering their careers.  Again, I'm sure it happens everywhere, but it's more disappointing at Cisco where the CEO and most employees have such high standards and expectations.

Pros: Cisco has no technology religion.  We thirst for innovation and continue to adopt new technologies and development process.  We learn from the very best in the industry, and we are willing to change.  You will find disruptive patterns everywhere while working at Cisco, whether in technical areas or process related areas.  You will not get bored because everything is continuously on the go.  Those who are resistant to changes or are uncomfortable with trying new things should not apply.
Cons: There is a lot of pressure on individual contributors to get "visible" because of the annual ranking process.  The process has a limited quota for top performers, so every year, management fights with each other to promote their own team, and individual contributors step on each other to get ahead.  Ironically, Cisco greatly promotes teamwork and collaboration.  However, with this limited quota ranking system, teamwork is just a slogan.  Only the naive will believe and practice it.

Pros:
Generally, the people are friendly and smart.  It's been that way since I started over a decade ago.  The pay is good, benefits are good, and in many areas of the company, you can arrange your working time around your life/kids.

The Hispanic/Latino group - Conexion - tries to create a sense of community, encouragement and support among the Latino employee base.
Cons:
There are a lot of sub-cultures within Cisco, making it very difficult to work cross-functionally.  Some groups are punctual, data driven, their word is their bond.  Others are undisciplined, political, unreliable.  

When John Chambers was CEO, we used to talk about the Cisco family, and our mission: changing the way the world lives, works, plays, and learns.  More recently, it doesn't seem we talk about that anymore.  There's less talk about the family, and we lay hundreds of people off every 6 months.

Pros:
The working environment is pretty relax and easy in the legacy and matured product BU.
You don't need to work more than 6 hours a day because most of the work are pretty routine.
Allow work remotely from home and flexible working hours.
Training and connection in women in tech helps you to move up fast.
A great place for female and Indian. You feel like home.
A lot of loyal customers and doesn't matter how far we are behind the competitors.
Cons:
Layoff happens across BU and take place every year.
Big layoff every 4 years.
Company hierarchy is crazy. My report chain is me -> manager -> director -> VP -> VP -> VP -> SVP -> EVP -> CEO. It doesn't make sense to have so many VPs.
Many new products are not generating revenue.
Cloud do impact the hardware business which is Cisco bread and butter.
There are too many similar products in the company and fighting with each other .
Collaboration between different BU are not working well due to politics.

Pros: Accumulated stock awards are attractive if you are at the Principal Engineer/Director level
Cons:
Two years on from my departure and I still struggle to identify anything remotely positive about Cisco beyond staying for share options. Continual, stealth headcount reductions after each quarter's results have gradually removed those with the energy and creativity that Cisco desperately needs to reinvent itself. For those early-in-career, I'm not convinced that having Cisco on the resume/CV helps. My experience is it can hinder you when applying to new roles as you are tarred with having worked in a slow-moving, behemoth company rather than a fast-moving agile start-up.

Let's face it - this is a company that should have owned the whole videoconference market in the wake of COVID-19 via WebEx yet it is Zoom that has stolen both the zeitgeist and the market. That should be enough for the Board to call for Chuck to step down and for them to bring in a visionary technology leader rather than yet another senior salesperson with a strategy that only looks 2 quarters out in a vain attempt to keep Wall St happy...

Pros:
Good benefits.
Interesting people.
Smart people.
Interesting products.
Working for a company that is an industry leader.
Some people who are passionate about making the world better hrough technology.
I really can't think of much more to say. The people are interesting and smart, the environment is electrifying, and it is a company that has made a tremendous impact in the way people live, work, and play! There are some really good pockets to work in within the company, and you really have to seek those out. And I think that's about it  It has been quite an experience, and one I shall never forget!
Cons:
Ageism with no recourse.
Impotent human resources managers who don't want to deal with problematic senior managers.
Senior level people hiring their friends for critical positions, and the friends are incompetent.
Excessive politics.
Burdensome bureaucracy leading to a lack of agility--inability to get done what could be done.
TAP (talent assessment process) in which competent employees are rated poorly for political reasons--I can't tell you how many times I have seen the competent employee let go in the quarterly purge, while the mediocre, non-threatening employee remains in place and is rewarded.
An Asian VP who promoted every Asian on our large team before moving on to a new position.
Reorganizations to cover up failures.

Pros: Excellent benefits and caring (if something catastrophic happens) that are worth staying for - to a point. Smart people doing some excellent work. Need to drive your own career - important to change roles every few years to keep your resume fresh. Good for earlier career folks - 5-7 years experience. Staying too long in one group/role is dangerous to your future prospects outside Cisco. Hopeful that Chuck coming on as CEO will breathe new life into the organization.
Cons: Due to the bloating of the organization, groups are forced to narrowly define what they do - leading to many groups have reduced scope and decision making/visibility is kept at the very top. Growth has not kept up and top people need to move on for others to have an opportunity to move up, but even then many times the succession plan is already laid. Leaders are often politically motivated to do what's best for them/their group vs. the company. Lots of group-think, not willing to speak plainly about issues.

Pros: Pro's They're well made, reliable, and tend to function for a very long time without going down. Well supported--it's very easy to find documentation on how to do something, or a company/person who can do whatever it is you want done for you. Very large feature set. Cisco offers numerous open standard and proprietary protocols and options in their code that other vendors lack parity with. Stable code and quick bug fixes. Bugs that cause major operational or security problems have been extremely rare, in my experience. Most products have a CLI that is easy to use and understand.
Cons: Con's Price. Sometimes I think Cisco should be spelled Ci$co. Complex licensing. One could invest as much time learning their licensing schemes as you would studying for a CCIE. Inconsistencies between products. Cisco has acquired numerous companies and incorporated their products into Cisco's portfolio while retaining much of the code base--this leads to many quirks when working in the CLI's on multiple products. Most GUI software is written in Java and can do a lot of dumb things--specifically the ADSM software used to configure ASA's. Occasional interoperability issues when connecting to products from other vendors. Software releases can be a bit confusing, as figuring out which features you're getting is not always clear.

Pros:
good brand name
can while away time doing nothing as lot of people do
if inquisitive enough can learn a lot about markets, products , technical architecture in general
Cons:
Too much politics. 
Appreciation by mouth isnt good enough and thats what you get from higher up
. Need to play politics and keep whining or threatening about leaving, you might get something then. Being new to work full time didnt play my cards well and kept to myself.

Lot of guys know nothing but talk and eventually they take the pie and you are left with crumbs.

As a new hire fresh off the school and under choice it is fun. Fast forward a year, you see you havent done anything to be proud of. It strikes to you , you knew much more when you were in school than now. You were much more marketable before than now!!
Advice: learn as much as you can , once you see its slowing down , get out before you become totally unemployable!!

Pros:
- Good resources available for the curious
- Challenging environment and growth* opportunities
- Transparency to technical information 
- Benefits (Car Lease, Healthcare Insurance, Medical check-ups etc)
- Other department exposure
- Good workplace environment
- Work from home 
- Great food
Cons:
At Company level

- Big variation in salaries for same grade
- No transparent appraisal/promotion process
- No proper feedback loop from engineers to skip-level managers
- HR department is a joke
- Pay less than market median
- Frequent Layoff/Workforce reduction, Engineers pay for the miscalculation of VPs and Directors
- G8 and G10 are eligible for RSU component in their pay, but rarely get it.

At Personal level

- Career growth *entirely* depends on the manager you report to.
- All concern/feedback stop with your reporting manager. No clear path for escalation
- How we get raise in salary or job grade is opaque and often just the opinion of our manager 
- HR redirects all queries back to manager
- Politics and growth is controlled/supported by directors/mangers
- People within the team often gang-up and create silos to keep their product and job safe.

Pros:
One of the best things about working at Cisco is the friendships you make along the way. I had the opportunity to be part of a Cisco Sales Associate Program when I first joined Cisco. This program was a yearlong, worked alongside 50 other CSAPers from different countries and had 3 months intensive training followed by 9 months on-the-job training, working remotely with virtual teams.

The wealth of experience I gathered on the job is extensive. Asides from being knee-deep in the technology and sales of that technology, I worked in the regional hub with teams of people from varying background and cultural experiences; this broadened my perspective to career and life.

This experience I must say kick off my career. I am definitely a better employee because of this. If you are ever considering joining the CSAP program, my advice is jump right in. The initial days will be tough, stressful, annoying, but it is definitely worth it.
Cons: Expect that the kind of culture you get from your cohort/ CSAP hub will change, depending on the country/hub you move to after the end of the program. Some of the fantastic culture you are you used to looses panache; this is common when you move from a larger hub to a much smaller one.

Pros: Large company, good benefit, good environment, people are extremely nice to each other.  A very nice view of Great America and Silicon Valley from the building.  A very diverse company.
Cons: This is for WebEx, a company Cisco bought about a year ago.  This has nothing to do with Cisco, but WebEx alone.  Basically, whoever speaks the loudest will get recognized, not the person who gets the most done.   So hard work and talents usually do not get rewarded with recognition or compensation.  Many valuable talents have left the company because of beauracracy and politics. There are too many mid-level managers that worry about their job security too much, and discourage employee growth.   It is a stable place to be in terms of job security, but if you are young and want to learn and advance, this is not a good place for you.

Pros: Large company, diverse product line, focus on growth and attacking new market opportunities.  Strong corporate focus on growing worldwide markets and new greendfield opportunities, which should keep overall company growth on an upward track in the future.
Cons: Excessively political environment, where information is often controlled, withheld and used as a weapon for personal and political advantage.  Finding a good group is the KEY issue for you having a good assignment, and job/salary growth and career advancement.  Internal visibility - often over actual performance - is becoming a necessary element for job survival, never mind advancement.

Pros: Friendly employees, great culture, lots of good benefits and new products coming out.  The San Jose campus is massive, with just over 50 buildings, and there is always work going on somewhere.  The work environment is also good, and the labs are generally well organized.  They also have free soda/tea/coffee, and you can occasionally find free food by going to various presentations.  There are also two gyms and a daycare center, and provide great benefits to full-time employees.  I accumulated the equivalent of 3.5 weeks PTO per year as a co-op/intern, the same as any regular employee.
Cons: There are too many managers and executives, and endless business/technical meetings which do not contribute much (in fact the most useful meetings are the meet&greet because they encourage teamwork, even though they have nothing to do with your job).  Also, the work can be slow and boring at times, and you will not be immune to "burnout" at Cisco.  As a co-op, I received no benefits other than PTO and hourly pay.

Pros: Cisco remains a challenging environment, driven for excellence. For those able to keep up, you're rewarded well, and surrounded by expert peers, managers, and senior managers committed to your success. Training, lab equipment, peer support are readily available for any assignment or task. The mutual respect and support make Cisco a wonderful place to work. The good pay and excellent benefits add icing to the cake. Working from home is a huge plus! The customers are also very easy to work with because they recognize and respect the level of expertise Cisco engineers bring to the conversation. I love my customers!
Cons: The demand for your expertise is constant. You have to know how to delegate responsibility to other teams, and learn how to use your resources, the sales team, and partners to get the job done. Otherwise, you'll end up working 12 hour days constantly. (My colleagues who don't delegate are probably accusing me of only working half a day!)

Pros:
Flexible work time and place. Good work life balance (... of course it depends on the group you work for).
Pay is not the best but still very competitive
Big company (though on the flip side, it could be a Cons), plenty of resources
Good to get some experience in a big corp (but don't stay there too long)
Cons:
Company is too focus on the balance sheet to please the Wall Street. Lack of the vision to be a true technology company. No innovation, no big bets anymore vs the good old days
Smart people left and the current senior management can't provide a vision or direction for the employee, other than constant cost cutting. Regular layoff discourages the people.
Just like any other big corp, some people are not doing there job but stay there while smart people is not rewarded and left with disappointment.
Market is changing faster than it thoughts, big risk to maintain its market shares.
Salary hike is almost none. Hard to get any promotion unless you're very junior.

Pros:
Evolving company with a culture of change, not afraid to make tough changes
Newly revived spirit of innovation and boldness
Great people with a fairly strong desire to collaborate and help out
A lot of lateral career opportunity, which can lead to upward career opportunity
Executive team has great vision and works well as a team
Cons:
Culture change has been hard...moving from box selling, to systems, solutions...now to subscription based software solutions.  Vision is good, but the hard part is retooling the sales machine.  Restructuring has been the tool of choice, which has increased employee stress levels and is beginning to dampen the long standing teaming culture
Rapid change and dramatic evolution have come at expense of support solutions With an ever growing/evolving solutions portfolio, with a significant part of that coming through acquisitions, merging and managing the support data/meta data to a standard architecture and set of tools has been a never ending challenge

Pros:
CEO Chuck Robbins has clear vision for future
Intelligent acquisitions to accelerate into Cloud / XaaS space
Focus on Customer / Customer Experience is sincere and gaining foothold (vs product / engineering led)
Culture - you're part of something and teams support each other
Cons:
Layoffs, called "Limited Restructuring" occur like clock work every 6 - 9 months, usually in September/October and February/March. These have happened consistently in the 6 years I've worked at Cisco. It's demoralizing, erodes the strong culture and instills a sense of inevitability for employees
Limited advancement opportunities to Director, VP and above levels - and, annual layoffs at these levels, not tied to performance, but for "organizational health" (ie balancing the senior positions to early in career and junior employees).

Pros:
- There is always something new to learn and keep things interesting
- There are plenty of opportunities to move within the company
- Truly care about the individual especially during difficult personal times. And I've seen time and again Senior Execs step in and help.
- Great benefits especially Medical for my and my families needs
- full week of community service beyond your PTO and everyone is encouraged to find someway to give back
- strong Senior Exec leadership especially during tough times
Cons:
- During annual 'Limited Restructures', it's not about being a rock star or not, it's your position that is eliminated including whole teams
- Tight weekly commits can cause stress within teams depending on management
- Marketing has continued to overpromise or oversell, Cisco didn't use to sell on roadmaps
- dilution of culture. when I first started you could call anyone from John Chambers down and you would get a response. Now, it's not uncommon for someone to not respond unless you cc: their manager and yours.

Pros:
Salaries catching up to the rest of high tech though they expect you to work two jobs at once
company results getting better gives us hope that they will get out of the frantic mode.
Cons: continuous crunch time for the  past 5 years is wearing  people thin. you are expected to work evenings, early mornings, sunday night. You are motivated to do this for crunch time once in a while but this is one continuous crunch time. The company is distressed and with the recent good results they are patting themselves on the back and asking for more. People are voting with their feet and walking out to new jobs. Req for open jobs go unfilled. There is an air of tyranny in the atmosphere and employees that can walk are fed up. And what makes it worse is an air of condescending attitude towards anyone that has not been with the company from the golden days with the old hands full of the not invented here syndrome and taking care of their buddies regardless of performance or ability. It is a Babel of cultures and sometimes very hard to make a change and do the right thing.

Pros:
- Many possibilities, different teams, different positions, working for Cisco allows you to explore different types of roles and team cultures without needing to leave the company
- Flexible working, from home, from another country, from wherever you are. Cisco fully encourages the "work from wherever, whenever" as long as you get your stuff done. Good setup at home including video units, secured routers, etc
Cons:
- The annual re-org seems to have become a trend. Most people you speak to don't expect to still be there by the time retirement age hits
- Working in a more expensive European country means you'll face fierce competition for your job coming from cheaper countries.
- Working for one team vs another can have a huge impact on your softer benefits like education or bonus. A lot depends on your teams' management. Where one manager will tell you "NO" on something you ask for, working for another manager might very well result in a "YES" to the very same thing. As a result, employee equality is often compromised.

Pros: Worked there for over 10 years. They have a great flexible working schedule in most job roles. Lots of learning opportunities. Global company with a global presence. Great place to start a career right out of college.
Cons: The company values management. Individual contributors who do most of the work are not valued, are given no equity, and promotions are few and far between. They'll tell you there is no money for raises for hard working individual contributor, then a month later several vice presidents will be promoted to senior vice president. This happened over and over when Chambers was CEO. Layoffs are constant (called limited restructurings). In their IT department, where I spent part of my time, they push out anyone who tries to innovate or disrupt. The entire IT organization is run by the same people who've been there since 2000. The broken reward system made it impossible for me to keep my best workers.

Pros:
Decent Pay
Good 401k match at 4.5%, vests 100% upon match
Some of the best products for collaboration, data center
Flex time and telecommuting is the norm
Cons:
Cisco continues to cut jobs through massive layoffs (5500 direct) and (another 8500 through early retirement). Some were double CCIE's and many were CCIE's. This does not show value in employee skills 
No strategy for IoT
Executive Management does a poor job communicating strategy
Internal transfers are difficult
Services margins are too high to build an IoT line of business
Sync-ups has replaced a poor personnel performance ranking system, but few managers follow,the policy on conducting the sync ups.

Pros: Innovative company that trusts their employees and gives them space to shine.  You get from Cisco what you put in. You will find great opportunities but they would be just handed to you, you need to build your network and go looking for it. If you do, there's a lot to gain! Cisco allows you to work from home or from any office you like (except for very few office-based positions), it  offers great compensation and benefits, discounts, peer-to-peer reward scheme, amazing offices with good restaurants and lots of perks like massage chairs and nap pods, gym, allows time off for volunteering, good pension contribution. For the ladies, there's also a lot of investment from the company to bring more women into technology and to develop the next generation of female leaders.  There's also a good maternity leave and there is even a nursery at the headquarters
Cons: Flexible working has its pros and cons. Because people come and go from the office at any day or time they like and can work remotely, you may feel a bit isolated at times.

Pros:
CULTURE
-------------
Strong and evolving, focused on engineering quality and outcomes

TECH
--------
On-premise codebases suffer due to legacy, but command a massive customer base and hence continuously refactored and churned with new features. High focus on engineering practices, quality and automation. Solid architectures.

Cloud services and components are new, employ relatively latest paradigms, but lack any significant customer base.

LEADERSHIP
-----------------
Passionate senior management that puts the interests of the org and people above all else. Encourages feedback, ideas and initiatives. Ready to experiment with people, processes and perspectives.

ORG STRUCTURE
------------------------
Relatively flat and transparent, dynamic structures that rapidly evolve to solve problems.

ENGINEERS
----------------
Rock-solid technical leaders, a good percentage of expertise among engineers makes this a good place to work and learn. 

INNOVATION
------------------
General impetus and encouragement to any innovation at all levels. Hacking is highly encouraged.

FUN + BENEFITS
----------------------
Engineers get to use best in hardware, equipments and infrastructure
Relaxed, fun and alive work atmosphere while also being super-intense and engaging
Amazing, huge campus here in Bangalore
Cons: Lack of vision at product management - On one hand, the on-premise portfolio is struggling to re-invent and be competitive among newly emerging competition. On the other hand, the cloud strategy and services have turned out to be unimpressive, at least until now. Product Management at all levels is unable to figure this out yet.

Pros: For a big, long established tech firm Cisco have done a great job at keeping in front of technology trends meaning is always new technology to work on and a good vibe around the company that has done very well by most measures across 20 years which is a pretty impressive achievement.
Cons:
Promotion can be slow. This is largely because churn is low, its common to see senior team members with 15 - 20 years service.  That shows its a great place to work but means new opportunities at the top rarely open up and are hotly contested when they do. 

Regular redundancies and re-org's run through the company. Is pretty well 100% of the time either adjusting to a re-org or learning about the ever more complicated org structure about to be deployed.

Pros: Flexible working hours, work life balance, lots of badly managed contra & opex used for employee perks, a lot of folk get paid for doing very little
Cons:
A sales led company where the leaders lack redbrick / ivy league education and the culture is chavvy / redneck. Educated people don't succeed here, aggressive big mouths do.

Plummers of the internet largely selling overpriced and commoditized kit, it's a hardware company desperately trying to fool Wall Street it has a recurring business. Foolishly missed the Cloud transition, and laughably did not capitalize on Web Conferencing (WebEx) during the pandemic, letting Zoom and Microsoft take the market. Little growth over the last few years, no innovation, and mostly failed acquisitions. The stock price is driven by repurchasing stock and cash repatriation.

The salesman CEO and his team make big claims about racial discrimination, whilst at grassroots nothing is done to tackle the problem, even when it is clearly apparent and raised, promoting a few diverse people doesn't solve the problem.

Winning best places to work is largely a marketing activity which is paid for, Cisco actively partaking in this charade summarises its culture.

Pros: Collaborative work environment. Everyone loves what they do and as a result, they work as a cohesive unit. Great leadership, not too much of a heirarchy. If you have a good idea, then you can take it to the top. Very responsible socially too. A lot of community service opportunities and they definitely care about others. This is not any other greedy corporation. It's a wonderful place where you can grow and develop rapport with fellow employees. I loved my time there and I hope that you will consider it to be one of your top choices as well. Good luck!
Cons: I really don't think there's anything wrong with Cisco. I'd say the only probably is that it is so large, that it is hard to find your way around the company. But that's the case with any other company of this size as well. I would suggest that they strengthen their internal communications, otherwise things will get lost in translation. They're also placing a great emphasis on the future, but if these projections turn out to be remarkably inaccurate, this could be very detrimental to the company and your long term future. So theres' a risk involved, as is the case with most tech companies

Pros: Cisco is innovative and profitable. It continues to grow through acquisitions and is continually expanding its "footprint" of products and services. It is considered by some to be one of the best places to work. It offers an exceedingly diverse workforce population in terms of nationalities (primarily Asian and Indian); the compensation and benefits are competitive; there are learning and development opportunities.
Cons: Although the company talks about work/life balance, there is an expectation of 24/7 availability,  Not surprisingly, there is an extremely heavy emphasis on the use of techology for all purposes (meetings, communication, getting the job done) such that there is limited support offered by people. Each employee is expected to be self-supporting in all areas, including administrative. There is an inordinate number of meetings during which much is discussed but often with little definitive outcome. Participants like to discuss past accomplishments. Finally, as one would expect, the size and decentralized aspect of the company make it difficult to identify and navigate among departments and people. Thus, it takes longer than necessary to accomplish relatively small tasks and can be very frustrating.

Pros: They have a lot of money, and that gets them through a lot of bad management. Record profit translates into laying off 5,000 people. Get some skills here and then go work for a company where your talent will mean something.
Cons: Cisco is a big monopoly and it is managed badly, but it does not matter because they leverage their monopoly to make money. The internet would be better if the company was broken up into 12 companies based on their monopolies in so many areas. They are a classic example of a place that at one time was great to work for and each year it goes down hill like IBM and Microsoft. I had two alcoholic middle managers that did not care about my group or understand business. You will be a just a number at this company. Cisco's vision is to maintain there existing monopolies and buy start ups that challenge them.

Pros: Depending on your team and your customer(s), you will have very different experiences. I've been lucky enough to come in through their new hire program (CSAP - Cisco Sales Associates Program) and consistently be part of very young, energetic teams. I love the aggressiveness and go-getter mentality prevalent within my team, and my organization as a whole. It matches very well with the energy we experience working with our customers in Silicon Valley. I've also had great luck with managers -- they are caring and involved, notice the work you as an individual contributor are putting in, and really show their appreciation.
Cons: Cisco is of course a very large company, and with it comes the extensive red tape that makes significant change difficult. So, although you get incredible stability and perks working with such a well established organization, it is also very hard to instigate change. Trying to change how a particular product platform works or add significant feature improvements across multiple platforms will take a very long time.

Job Title: Low level engineer doing the work
Pros:
Good pay and benefits. 
Can be interesting work in the write department. 
Top level and bottom level workers are good at what they do.
If you have good social skills and want to climb up the ladder then there are good opportunities if your face fits.
Cons:
Lower management is a joke and more like a boys club. 
Priorities are themselves, then the project then if there is any time/energy left their staff.
They lack of knowledge on how to handle exceptional engineers/people, the ones who come with side effects, so good is the best they will get/keep.
The top people at the bottom (i.e. the engineers doing the work) often do not have great social skills and management can't handle them no matter how good they are at their job of for the project..
You have to spend more time looking after your career than doing the job if you want to climb, it's not a place to survive at the bottom level for long. If you want to stay hand's on then Cisco isn't for you no matter how good you are.

Pros:
You get  to work on the good software stack and with smart people.
Cisco encourages to take up training on courses/technologies of your interest.
You can have a good learning curve.
Cons:
The things you hear about the company is not the same inside.
The culture is deteriorating, poor work life balance, you are even asked to work on weekends and no comp offs given if the decision doesn't come from upper management.
Too high work pressure , there is no action being taken to increase the resource pool to meet the demand.
Less rewards or appreciation even when you put extra effort. It is taken for granted that you were bound to work long hours. 
Due to high demanding work load , Managers fail to set goals or proper road map for your career development.
Most of your colleague  are busy and it become difficult to approach them when you are struck and  documentation is also poor and literally no ramp up strategy.
When you join in, you sure gonna feel frustrated and start feeling probably you are in wrong place.

Pros: Pay is decent but not as high as other tech companies around the area. 401k matching, fairly good health benefits, WFH and working remotely are available to most employees, but it depends on your team and manager. Its a great place to start your career but most early in career people leave to other tech companies after 2-3 years. Cisco doesn't do a good job of retaining some of their top talent. This is a perfect company for those with a family and like a lot flexibility. Most departments are pretty relaxed and hardly ever hit 40 hours of work a week
Cons:
Overall there aren't too many cons. The two biggest issues I see is a lack of merit increase each year. Some people can stay at their same salary for 5 years. Promotions are fairly hard to get if you don't play politics. Saw a lot great talent leave when they didn't get recognized. 

The only other major con is upper management. There are too many directors and senior leaders that care more about their bonus and don't focus on the bigger picture of doing whats best for the company.

Pros:
Locally, it is one of the highest paid company.  It is really the only game in town.  Hours are flexible with a lot rich company amenities like free soft drinks and bottled water. Still paying a bonus --- for now.
This is a very good place for out of college people - lots of security and compensation for Jr. level people.
Cons:
Cisco is a very SJ centric company.  All major decisions are made out of SJ.  RTP is a staff augmentation to SJ with most people are reporting to managers/directors in SJ.
Visibility is one of the biggest factor for promotion and not performance.
Reward the dive and catch more than sound and steady management.
Lack a good portfolio management process causing too many projects/initiatives with questionable values and results.
Artificial time bounded project

Pros: There are some wonderful employees at Cisco, and generally a very strong work ethic.  Most people are genuinely trying to do their best for the company.  There is a good opportunity to work globally and certainly to experience interaction with people from around the world, using virtual collaboration tools.
Cons: Weak HR means that managers deal with an antiquated performance management process (based on a 15 year old GE model); lots of unhealthy politics at the SVP level and too many Directors sitting pretty due to tenure; recent RIFs have taken a slice out of the workforce, but not out of the much more expensive layers of the organisation.

Pros:
Cisco has the perfect balance of innovation, from a technical perspective, and established business practices with a strong customer base. A primary benefit to employees is a reasonable pace. It's possible to do excellent work without sacrificing one's personal goals and the work environment is definitely more collaborative than competitive. An additional benefit is the ability to move about the company to work on different products and projects. 
The employee population is remarkably diverse and both the executive leadership and HR underscore the value of inclusion and collaboration (diversity) in both it's composition and everything it says and does. Cisco takes diversity very, very seriously.
Deep support for working remotely is absolutely outstanding! We're able to draw  talent from all over the world instead of limiting ourselves to only those people who are willing to live in or near Silicon Valley.
Cons: The overall culture isn't quite as tech intensive as the culture I've experienced at major software  and services companies such as Microsoft.  At other companies for example, demos of products in development were a critical component of any meeting. At Cisco we tend to focus on the bigger business picture.

Pros: Good salary, good benefits, a great place to work remotely
Cons: Ridiculous levels of overhead--pre-pre approval for even simple expenses like a mouse.  Absolutely no approvals for travel of any kind.  Ditto there is absolutely no budget for training at all, even if the courses are internally offered.  You may grow distant from the company/fellow employees etc over time since you'll never actually see any of them.  Managers are promoted past their level of competence.   Simple things like submitting a fix for a bug have masses of overhead.  They change management tools constantly so you'll probably have to update information in multiple places about the same thing.  Lots of the help on the web is archaic and simply results in 404's.  IT support is generally pretty bad too.  The meetings that are held are mostly focused on sales and pitching the information appropriate to sales staff.  Customer support relies on direct connection with engineers who as a result have to be available long hours/weekends with some frequency.

Pros:
Cisco has great resources for working from anywhere - the technology and tools are extremely supportive with real BYOD on campus and great virtual meeting tools, all from the Company's own portfolio of course

You will also be working among some of the best professionals anywhere and will learn many best practices that you can take anywhere.
Cons:
The top leaders have floundered with their strategy and as such have lost any momentum for growth - do not expect to make big money with stock growth, as this is a mature company (despite being in "high tech").

Managers are generally inept - the entire organization is very "political" and requires you to spend more time managing upward and sideways than actually getting things done for the business. Be prepared to be coached on opportunities to be "visible"

If you are lucky enough to grab a big, visible project and if you spend a lot of time managing up, you might get one of the very rare promotions allocated for your organization. A good strategy for new hires is to negotiate for the biggest salary and title you can.

Pros: Challenging work, freedom to solve problems, good benefits, and pay is very competitive.
Cons: Constant cycle of lay-offs.  New hiring is heavily focused on college grads, while lay-offs tend to focus on higher salary experienced workers.  Cisco uses a lot of somewhat unskilled contractors to fill the voids left by lay-offs, leaving some business units in near chaos.  Cisco is top-heavy in management.  There seems to be a line drawn between first line managers and the management team above, where the folks in the trenches making things happen don't really know what that upper layer of management is doing.  Then there's a slew of Program Managers that seem to have no other responsibility other than to feed information to upper management.  Employees in the trenches question the value being provided by upper management.

Pros: Interesting technology and intelligent colleagues make unpleasant working conditions *almost* tolerable (though not quite).
Cons:
Congested, noisy work areas
Little to no support for writers working remotely. Overcrowded freeways  guarantee a 1.5 to 2 hour round trip commute from my home (10 miles from the Milpitas campus where I worked). Factor in the after-hours conference calls and last-minute deliveries, Cisco gets approximately 10-20 hours free in addition to the 40-hour weekly salary the company pays exempt employees.

Pros:
- Cisco Bangalore campus has world level best amenities and facilities.
- Work life balance is good.
- You are open to take training on any new technologies coming in.
Cons:
There are many.. let me share few of them:
- If you are joining Cisco Service Provider India, do not expect hike/raise for at least next couple of years. People do not get hike for years(3-4 years).. Promotion is too hard to get.. you need to perform like best in team for 3-4 years continuously to get it..
- There are very less teams where you gain a good domain knowledge while working.. else everywhere just sustenance work.
- Most of managers do not care of your learning/development, their main concern is just to get the bugs fixed on time. So most of them follow the push mechanism to get the work done.
- You wont find any motivation to work. No one talks about new technologies and year by year you will loose confidence in yourself.. as you will work hard even then you wont get any appraisal..
- Most important thing, engineers are treated as slaves. Till the time they need you, you will be treated well and when they don't need you they will find a better slave and dump you..

Pros:
If you love people and technology - Cisco is an excellent place to start, grow and extend into a role. 
CSAP (Cisco Sales Associate Program) - is a global accelerated program designed for you to learn and propel your career at Cisco. You are given the opportunity to gain professional certifications, travel and create worldwide friendship. This year long program was the perfect way for to start my career at Cisco. 
Cisco will allow you to move to find a role to suit you and managers are supportive for you progressing in your career path.
There is a reason why #lovewhereyouwork and #wearecisco go hand in hand, flexible working is encouraged to help you work how and when suits you, Fun fund is what happens every few months to bond and have fun with your team mates.
If people culture is something you are looking for in your career, Cisco is where you will be made to feel at home with a new Cisco Family.
Cons: As with any big company; restructuring, politics and change can majorly impact careers but this is not unique to Cisco. Change in technology, change in workplaces will happen in any field this is not something to fear.

Pros: One of the main reasons I love working at Cisco are the people and the environment we are surrounded with. It is a place full of diversity, which is a vital factor in getting to know different cultures and collaborating together. Having a high-trust organization such as Cisco helps us avoid micro management and employees are getting most of their potential. Apart from work, we love to have fun and rest our minds from business thoughts. In one of our Global Team meetings we had Chris Martin from Coldplay join us and play a few songs. How cool is that? As a big successful corporation we have a lot of job benefits, newest technology and always moving forward!
Cons: Being a part of such big organization means that change is constant and it is something that we need to adapt as the world and priorities are constantly changing too. Nothing that worries me too much as we know this is the only way to stay ahead of the competition.

Pros: Flexible timings, many intelligent people around. Good food and infrastructure.
Cons:
1) nothing much to learn . There is no clear roadmap for why to evaluate new ideas. Its just that cisco has money so they invest and if it doesnt work then just throw the people out.
2) mass layoffs frequently.
3) constant state of comparison rather motivating for getting things done .
4) people who knows how to sustain in cisco they can but people who are intelligent but dont have the survival skills in cisco wont make it. 
5) 100 of propietory frameworks by cisco ,because of which you will be lost and you wont be able to learn anything new and its very difficult to understand the existing framework completely.
6) 100% revocation of vote for Chuck robbins as CEO.
7) never refer any colleague to join CISCO. Bad place to work.
8) work environment is serious all the time ,no vibrant environment to keep energising people. People here work like robots .such a pity( cisco was once my dream company , and sometimes dream doeant comeout as you think).
9) negligible to no hikes.

Pros:
Pays well and has amazing benefits. The benefits differ from country to country but they are great overall.
Support Team- Generally you have access to all the technical assistance in country and out of your county available to help you with your business.
Stable and Reputable Company- Solid company to have in your CV, during Covid Cisco is still making a fair amount of revenue.
Challenging Job- No day is ever the same and challenges make the job exciting.
Great sales tools available to you
Excellent at on-going training
Cons:
Very numbers driven.
Massive targets provided to low grade employees.
Targets are unreasonably high which impact your ability to make money.
No growth in African locations unless white and male ( RSA specifically).
Not a very people centric culture although that is what they sell.
Not many females and black people in local management and not many people of colour in global management.
No real presence of the LGBTQI+ community in South Africa which speaks to conscious or unconscious bias in the organization.

Pros: It's a very pretty campus, easy commute from Durham, little traffic, can park next to building, friendly people, great food, its catered and many menu options change daily.
Cons: As an internship, I expected the ability to nurture and grow my career and education.  Instead I'm stuck in a box, doing stuff a monkey could do.  I have three managers, one is a day to day manager, the other is his supervisor, and the third is my manager/mentor in California.  None of them realy give me the time of day.  My day to day manager is a super nice guy and I have no problems with him whatesoever.  I'm just so discouraged that the opportunities here are so limited.  As a contractor, I have no benefits, I can't use 95% of the features that regular Cisco employees can.  There is very limited career development here, and what there is, I can't touch, not a regular employee (and what there is is just productivity training and the like, not technical training that I actually need).

Pros: Learn a lot in a very little time. If you want to know about data communications business, this is the place. If you can survive the grind in the first year, you tend to do well anywhere in the long run. Other than P&G this is the place to learn about marketing and sales. The only place in fact in high tech. I learn't more at work than at business school.
Cons: In a large company and particularly in large business units it is inevitable to have  mediocre politicians, who sullify an otherwise excellent atmosphere. Your competency may not always count. Sometimes the mid level leaders can be absolute idiots as well, so you have to watch your back even if you are competent and doing everything right. In other words do your stuff well, but learn basics of being a politician and always watch out for mediocre idiots, they could potentially damage your career at CSCO.

Pros:
The work culture driven by mid- and lower management is extremely good & healthy. They are very supportive of employees' career growth, work-life balance and project timelines. There are silos which work in an extremely aggressive start-up mode (with their own benefits), but this is more an exception than the norm. The flexibility given to employees in terms of telecommuting and work-from-home are very encouraging - cab services, VPN on laptops, home broadband reimbursement etc. 

The Cisco India campus has blossomed over time into a nice cocoon of sorts. It has multiple food cafeterias, a big health centre, a state-of-the-art medical centre and several games / sports facilities (basketball, badminton, cricket, table-tennis, carrom, Foosball, gaming arcades, massage chairs)!! The company has a great healthcare plan for employees and their families, including free annual health checkups.
Cons:
Even though the management harps about Innovation from India, some groups / teams are working on maintenance-only projects. 

If you're a programmer who loves to work on bleeding-edge technologies and likes (re-)designing entire new products, this may seem a boring place. Lots of Cisco's products work on legacy technologies and it is impossible to re-write them when they earn billions of dollars for the company.

Pros: Cisco emphasizes work/life balance and this is honored in all roles I've held with the exception of sales. Medical benefits are very good, 401K options are comparable to other companies.  Other perks like tuition reimbursement are above average. Cisco IT is very good about maintaining the latest technologies and tools to do you job. (ie: BYOD for mobile devices and virtual office setups to support remote workers.)
Cons: I've witnessed 3 major layoffs since joining the company in 2004 and at least half a dozen re-orgs within Sales Operations.  Salaries are competitive when you first join the company, but it's difficult to advance due to HR policies and bureaucracy.  In my case, it has been a lack of job role hierarchy and descriptions on the part of HR that has prevented me from continuing to advance.  Cisco struggles to attract millennials and the workforce is aging.

Pros: Salaries are competitive with industry.  Company provides a work from home option.  Benefits are competitive.
Cons: Week management at the lower levels.  Managers are often expected to be billable instead of being full time managers, leaving little time to truly invest in their people.  Direct reports often work more closely with managers in other groups.  Due to an employee manager's focus on being billable, they are often very unaware of their employees efforts, contributions and successes, yet these same managers are responsible for providing direct reports their annual reviews.  Expect annual layoffs no matter how well the company is performing.  No clear or consistent method for targeting employees for layoff other than nepotism.

Pros: Cisco is a huge company, as such there are lots and lots of different initiatives and opportunities for employees, from volunteering to training courses, employees are really encouraged to take the lead and shape their career.
Cons:
