So Add a 20 hour commute, (I live in the East Bay) to the 60 hour work week gives extreme exhaustion.  If you have to work from home you need approval from Senior management even for rare occasions.  Also managers talk to you if you repeatedly work from home

Pros: The Cisco Benefits are unmatched.  However, beyond the benefits, 4.5% match in the 401(k), the extra time off, is the overall culture of the company and those that ensure that the culture of inclusion and diversity endures.  As a Veteran of the Marine Corps with 29-years of service, I was concerned that a civilian company would not share the same values or have a level of camaraderie even close to that of a military organization.  I was very wrong.  I have found that and more here at Cisco.
Cons: Open working areas can be more collaborative but not appropriate for all practice areas, such as areas that may require sensitive HR or Legal type discussions.  Although there are Privacy Rooms available, having to search one out due to an impromptu meeting or call is counter productive.

Pros:
- Competitive pay
- Name recognition
- Established company so it's expected it will be around awhile
- Room for climbing the corporate ladder
Cons:
- Layoffs are always looming over everyone's heads, so morale is low
- No loyalty to their long time employees, they will lay off better workers and keep the ones that everyone wonders why/how they still have a job there. Seemingly arbitrary.
- Company is way too big, you'll always feel like a number
- Sketchy leadership in some divisions
- They buy companies doing great things and then lay off the teams that made them that way and water down the product.

I know it sounds like I am a scorned employee who was laid off, but I wasn't, I was just appalled at how others fared in these quarterly chopping blocks. I left of my own accord for a better work environment and it was one of the better decisions I've ever made.

Pros:
Great benefits, lots of opportunities if you are prepared to move around (often at your cost). Great peer network. Great name to have on your CV.

A company that on the whole champions diversify with many employee led communities within the business

Internal movement and mentoring is encouraged
Cons:
Salaries are not as competitive as they used to be. 

Beware of reorganizations - there seems to be zero thought about the impact on the individual that are impacted.

Politics is rife no matter what you hear.

There can be a disconnect between the culture the executive leadership want and the culture some leaders find acceptable

The business is struggling to evolve into a solutions led “as a service” business - its not easy, think trying to turn an oil tanker. That being said there are some islands of excellence such as Meraki.

Pros:
-Work from home
-Good training available if you can find the time to take it
-Good support of job transitions/rotations
-Complex environment where you can learn a lot
Cons:
-Pay is not that great, especially when bonuses aren't paid out
-Promotions take way too long to get
-Long work hours, schedule can be unpredictable, and hours can be odd as you are usually working with a global team

Pros: Work/life balance, excellent people and plentiful talent, still a good culture and values about fair play and caring for people
Cons: An interesting mix of strong hatred of clear goals with accountability, thick red-tape bureaucracy, self-serving senior leadership that has been brought in externally mixed with the wrong sort in power internally

Pros: Still a stable profitable company with some exciting technology. Market leader in routing and switching and now compute with UCS. The company retains some quality leaders and thinkers even through tough times.
Cons: The "Tiffany" pricing on everything will eventually be eroded away as utility computing grows. Political maneuvering in management has diluted the company's culture over the past decade or so. Hopeless marketing of non-core products: Flip, Cius, etc.... The stock has been essentially flat for a decade.

Pros:
Salary
Ability to work from home
Healthcare benefits
401K match
Volunteer hours
Cons: It is a shark tank.  Whole departments are at war with each other.  The Collaboration Group is highly risk-averse and re-organization happens quarterly to serve sr leadership's concerns.  Employees are disoriented and stressed out, expected to produce miracles without any support.  Managers talk at their teams, giving directions that come straight from marketing brochures, and then scurry off to their endless closed door meetings.  Their arrogance is breath-taking.

Pros: Cisco is a fantastic company in terms of benefits - I've never worked for a company that offered more.  Salaries and bonuses are good, but there's much more - all kinds of insurance and health-related programs that help both the employee and the community.  Always something interesting going on.  Always a chance to get involved and do new things, both inside and outside of work.
Cons:
It is painfully hard to get things done.  Every department and every project and every process seems to be in flux all the time.  Too many hands in every pot.  Processes are too cumbersome.  Too many meetings, too much confusion.  It's a big, big company, with all the usual big-company problems.

Note: this perspective is from a person who joined on as a result of her smaller, privately-held company getting acquired by Cisco.

Pros: Cisco is great, period.  You will work with the best engineers and managers the world has to offer.  Cisco brings several classes to their campuses, which gives employees great opportunity to develop breadth and depth of their skills.  As an engineer, they provided free python training at three different levels!  The work is tough, but rewarding;  you will create thought-leading products that will be used worldwide.  Cisco is a prestigious company, and you will continue to improve yourself during your tenure.  Drink the kool aid and you will go far!  You can achieve decent salary and bonus increases without making lateral transitions.  I do recommend switching business units every few years.
Cons: Tough but not impossible work life balance.  As an engineer you need to stay agile and at the top of your rank to avoid layoffs. However, good work will get you far!

Pros:
Cisco as a whole does an incredible job in empowering its employees. Regardless of job role, title, team, etc. you receive industry leading benefits and are truly treated with respect and appreciation. Outside of tangible benefits, Cisco is a tech leader that cares about making a difference in the world through the power of its technologies and connections. It’s so great to see a CEO and upper management put so much time, energy, and attention on global issues and ways that we as employees can make a difference by being at Cisco.

I have been empowered to come in and do my very best at work each and every day. Opportunities for career exploration, volunteering, trainings, etc. are plentiful and you truly are encouraged to take advantage of those opportunities. #LoveWhereYouWork
Cons: Cisco is a HUGE company, so at times your work does feel like a small drop in the bucket. But the learning opportunity is huge!

Pros: It seemed like there were lots of benefits, to the point of it being difficult to be aware of or manage them all.
Cons: Cisco is a large company, and old for the tech industry, and I feel like both of those showed in the negatives.  Lots of policies, lots of old corporate systems and processes that we were theoretically supposed to know how to use, and a feeling of detachment, of being several levels down in a 70,000+ node tree.  Some things hadn't changed in years or decades, but there were also (from my perspective) unnecessary and disruptive changes while I was there; big changes in both health and retirement benefits providers within one year.  The experience of being an employee at Cisco seemed to involve a lot of complexity that had more to do with the company's size and age than with my work or what I wanted from a job, and I would have preferred a simpler employee experience where I could focus on getting actual work done.

Pros: I am only speaking to Sales, other orgs could be different. Great people among Individual Contributors, Manager/Senior Manager levels. I am very proud of the values modeled by Chuck and his ELT and their commitment towards a fair and equitable workplace, though that's one aspect of the job.
Cons: Sales promotions often determined by cliques, which in turn determined by political ideologies. I left voluntarily after a long tenure even though I wasn't eligible for the package, because I did not see a promotion path in am environment where advancement decisions are determined by nepotism/favoritism/buddy culture/race. Values modeled by Chuck and ELT do not percolate down the ranks. Culture is very inwardly focused in middle layers. Managers are not open to new ideas, have stopped listening to customers and the market, and are only focused on empire building. Employees spend so much time in "alignment meetings" there is no time left to do real work. The good news is that some of the leaders who created this culture in the org where I worked took the package last year, and I am optimistic that new management is bringing a different approach.

Pros: Flexibility in work schedules, well managed financially.
Cons: The company is comprised of acquired business units which can have very different policies in the way they treat engineers. The Engineering staff has become overwhelmingly staffed by Non-US citizens. The lower levels of management included.  Manager / Employee relationship increasingly reflects the values of the managements culture of origin.

Pros:
-overall compensation package 
-depending on your direct manager, little micro managing
-work from home / flexibility
-domestic partnership benefits at minimal cost
-diversity of workforce -- employee resource groups strongly supported
Cons:
-individual promotions are extremely hard to come by: I've been up for promotion for nearly 5yrs with exemplary yearly reviews, only to see senior management receive promotions, not individual contributors
-you pretty much work 24/7 depending on your role and which world-wide regions you support
-top-down approach rarely feels like the best approach when it's the worker-bee's who have to do the work

Pros: It was a clean and open environment, following Cisco's policy for an employee friendly company. I appreciated an independence to manage my projects and the pay was excellent going through a recruiting agency.
Cons:
Many within management are absorbed with politics and arrogance, this was a drain in time and resources. 
Promised in my hiring interview was a strategic role as a program manager leading large teams and working within an Agile environment. In reality I was the sole project manager leading tiny projects in a waterfall life cycle. The products my teams were supporting had thousands of users/paying customers, however were of low interest for management in terms of acquiring a budget or 3, 4 resources to complete the project. 
I'd found my director a bit of a nag and micro-manager which unnecessarily raised my frustration level and caused confusion with others involved in the projects.
The job was far below my skill-set and expectations. I was surprised how very different WebEx was from the rest of Cisco, a disappointment.

Pros: Cisco pays well, it's not in the top 10%, but it pays those employees well that it wants to keep. It does give out RSUs and the ESPP has paid well over the past few years. There are four levels of health care benefits, that make it easy to tailor your benefits. Work/like balance is dependent on your individual manager; most are very good. Lots of opportunities to move around. Patent and yearly bonuses are good.
Cons: Depending on the business unit/work group, middle management can place unrealistic demands upon individual contributors. Working outside of San Jose can be a challenge if you want to rise through the ranks; visibility is key. Sick and vacation time is combined into one pool of Paid Time Off (PTO), and the company has a policy of forcing employees to use 3 or 4 days during the year-end "holiday shutdown". Amount of earned PTO does not increase with seniority, but amount one can accumulate and save, does.

Pros: Good pay and Benefits package
Cons: Company taken over by bean counters who bend over to pick up nickles letting dollars bill fly over their heads.Cisco culture has been replaced through the addition of employees from other large companies, while losing long term employees who are leaving both voluntarily and involuntarily in droves. The result is a dilution of culture and a race towards big company mediocrity.

Pros: Overall benefits package is decent; telecommuting is great; SME's abound.
Cons: "Family culture" where folks take care of each other is almost non-existent these days. Too many managers moving around every year, making it hard for others to actually benchmark their career success. Constant ranking/rating employees hurts moral when folks are already burned out and doing their best. HR doesn't support employees any longer and is hyper-focused on protecting the company. Managers can't give a clear path of how to achieve promotions or move within the company. Easy to burn out if you don't know how to actually balance work-life. Rewards are pretty pathetic now

Pros: At Cisco I find myself surrounded by smart and motivated individuals who constantly challenge me to be innovative and to improve.  This is especially true of the amazing women I work with who  inspire me to challenge the status quo while at the same time continuing to evaluate and evolve my own perspective and actions.  Additionally, the ability for me to define where, when and how I work is truly what enables me to be successful both at work and in managing the rest of my life.  And the technology we use on a daily basis to do that is truly AMAZING!
Cons: As in any big company - patience, persistence and perseverance are key character traits you must rely on daily.

Pros:
- Career opportunities are available internally if you are proactive
- Great company culture if you enjoy interacting, collaborating, connecting with people since it is relationship oriented 
- Health benefits are great and there is a health center in the main headquarters
- People are great since I am still friends with many of them in Silicon Valley
- Learning opportunities are available 
- Surprisingly,  I was with the company for 9 years full-time and 1 year as an intern and it was due to the focus on continuous learning, growth, and challenge. People was also key to the culture.
Cons:
- Microcultures within the larger company. Overall, Cisco has a whole is a good company but I've experienced a few negative and disgruntled employees who are disconnected with the company since they do not make an effort to learn about the larger picture which is why I left due to negative vibes in my organization 
- Passive aggressive in some technology groups

Pros: the company is huge with many different independent business so its hard to find a specific con/pro because it really depends on the business. Security is doing fine, collaboration is ok, enterprise is struggling and service provider is shrinking every quarter. the healthy businesses are well run, good people, good compensation package overall even though the stock is stagnant. work can be interesting if you land in the right place
Cons: Russian roulette : the company is not growing and for every startup they acquire (and they acquire a lot) they fire internal people. Not a stable place at all. As stated in the "pro" section the healthy businesses can be great, for the struggling ones can be a risky place. Hard to be loyal when you feel expendable.

Pros: None really at this stage.
Cons:
Dealing with too many 'technically below par" engineers and even worse the Managers who are technically incompetent. Hence your learning will be limited. If you stick long enough, you will never come out of this mess because you won't get any outside jobs with your primitive skills you end up learning here at Cisco.
 I deal with great many business units and groups within Cisco. There are lot of unproductive people who does not have enough work to do. Like the product managers. Most of these product managers will not have their job plates full for a good portion of an year.
 This is also true for lots of engineering managers and directors. Essentially they are misusing the public investment with poor money management.

Pros:
Good salary
Great people
Woking with a well-known and hghly respected organzation
Working witrh an orgranzation that is global
Cons:
Very political, it's not if you do a good job, it's how others think that you are doing.  Getting ahead isn't really about doing the job but by doing pet projects that aren't related to you job but show that you think "outside of the box" and take initative..
Almost impossible to get a promotion, easiest way is to be in direct sales.  As long as your team is making quota (on the direct sales side) they give them out like candy.  But if you are in any tupe of support role they are very hard to come by.  I was with the company 5+ years and never promoted even though got good ratings.  If you have a team of ten or fifteen you better be ranked #1 or #2 in your group to get the promotion, which is hard to do b/c there's always a superstar.

Pros: Challenging and ever changing business environment. Strong work force with lots of support and excellence all around. Very goal oriented environment. Somewhat of a meritocracy, particularly in field sales where it's all about achieving goal. Narrowed focus down to 5 key priorities is helping a lot. Getting resources put back to where they need to be. Getting out of consumer markets and reducing distillation of focus.
Cons: Far too focused on wall street market reaction. trying to make long term decisions in a short term market environment leads to getting caught in the middle. Need to stop focusing on macro issues quite so much and get back to everyday business of being the best in focused markets. in fact some of this has started to happen with core 5 priorities which has reduced the wandering and strategy-shifts quite a bit.

Pros:
Cisco is a very well organized company.
It leads the world towards new kind of networking by providing many smart solutions.
It looks towards entering new markets and will always be taking very effective and intelligent decisions.
The technologies that are being developed and worked on are very advanced. It will be definitely very interesting to know that a lot is going on in the networking field.
The work and life balance is very good and heard the same from many colleagues with different ages of experience.
Cons:
The compensation is not in par with other networking companies although it has additional benefits.
There is very little scope for work for new college hires (mostly bug fixes), which is mostly the same for many product based companies.
Although an engineer gets to see and learn a lot, he has to wait for a very long time to be one of the contributors for the field.

Pros:
Cisco has excellent customer focus and interaction, and it shows in the way the products are received by customers. You feel a sense of accomplishment as you realize that the products you helped to build are helping the customers. 
Cisco has always taken care of its employees, with good benefits, excellent work-life balance and one of the best severance packages.
Cons: Cisco is trying to transition to a software company and doing it wrong. Sad to see it lose a lot of great engineers just because the new management (VPs...) have no idea on how to leverage the current engineers to build software products. The approach seems to be to replace them with their own followers (from wherever they come from). Many good engineers have been laid off, or left on their own. Sad to see a great company going down.

Pros: The company in general treats people well. The benefits are comprehensive, the bonuses are generous, and the gym is nice.  If you are in a good group, you can be mostly isolated from politics and bureaucracy.
Cons: The company has had a round of layoffs in 4 out of the last 6 years, IIRC.  That said, they are saying that they don't want this to be the norm, and appear intent on reducing the frequency of layoffs.  My location doesn't have the variety of opportunities for web development that there are in the San Jose headquarters.  I have heard stories of some groups having mandatory overtime, but thankfully my management really protects work/life balance.  In the past there has been an issue with commitment to Agile, but that seems to be changing.

Pros: There's an interest in unit testing and automation and in agile development. Benefits are pretty good, with 4 weeks of PTO.  In a company this size, policies are well-developed, if a bit hard to know where to find them.
Cons: Unrealistic deadlines result in faster and faster accumulation of technical debt. The tools available for developers are extremely clumsy. The bug tracker is awful (hard to use, can't have multiple tabs open to different bugs, has filtering but no real search). The version control system is Perforce, and my division dreads having it rolled out to us. At least on the command line, usability is not taken into account, making it difficult for developers to use the products we're meant to be developing and leaving us wondering how customers can stand it.

Pros: great company with mart people!  new leadership has big shoes to fill, that said - Mr Robbins knows exactly what he's dealing with and has a strong vision and support front he Board about what Cisco needs to do differently going forward, and lastly, i was the proudest employee when I worked for this company - in touch with the community and the humans that make Cisco strong, and Cisco takes and time and enables good things for its employees and the communities its in.
Cons: its a big company with some big company problems - and yes there are politics and BS that goes on - no different than most places.  in my opinion, its an authentic place with a culture that has allowed people to have a POV and speak up about it without a problem if done productively.  there have been lots of people changes since mr Robbins stepped in as CEO, good newws and some not so much.

Pros:
1. Opportunity to Work on world class products which are very complex and challenging to produce. 
2. Open space (no cubes) and good collaboration
3. Helpful associates
4. Lot of team socials, outings to keep the mind fresh and entertained and informed.
Cons:
1. Management does Poor planning on work and lot of fire fighting customer issues.
2. Very little focus on talent development, its left upto the individual to find own way in the ocean, no guidance is provided.
3. Extremely inefficient meetings. Huge amount of time wasted in digressions from the main agenda. Infact some times the agenda is not even communicated before the meeting.
4. Complete lack of focus on individual contributor skill development and training. Individual is left to fend for him/herself.

Pros: It has been exciting to join a team where you have opportunities to shape the team culture, participate in process improvement initiatives, and be immersed in innovative technology solutions.  There are plenty of opportunities to learn and grow at Cisco. Our executives within Customer Success are open minded and engaged with us to continue to improve and identify how best to serve and help us succeed in our roles. Good benefits
Cons: Despite Cisco being a large company, you should expect and be comfortable with change. Processes are continuing to evolve and adapt as Cisco aligns its efforts with its strategic vision. It can be a fun challenge to contribute to and be a part of that change but it also requires patience along the way. The tools and resources provided to us to do our jobs can at times feel numerous and complicated trying to piece it all together but great effort is being put into tying it all together

Pros: For a 70,000 person, global company, there are so many things to be PROUD of in working for Cisco. As an LGBT leader at Cisco, I am happy to be myself, and encourage others to do the same. There is tremendous executive support for our LGBT brothers and sisters at Cisco, across the globe. Cisco's continued 'foot on the gas pedal' delivering on Inclusion & Diversity aren't just words, rather, actions that continue to grow. #CiscoPRIDE is alive and well.
Cons: The only 'Con' I can muster up is the opportunity to find new opportunities within Cisco for many people. Cisco is not a high growth company, so not adding 100s of jobs/week, like some others. That said, there is tremendous opportunity for cross teaming, working on stretch assignments, and raising your hand to do 'other' things.

Pros: Average salary and good benefits
Cons: Cisco is an organisation which is devoid of any genuine ethical or moral credibility. Despite the efforts they go to with their PR activity. Cisco's culture causes mental illness far too regularly. Cisco discriminate against people who have mental health issues. They are actively covering up and misrepresenting the scale of the harm their sales teams are being subjected to by wilfully discriminating both financially and through their actions, against anyone who suffers mental ill health due to the stresses of the role. Also, not enough support to avoid burnout - Always connected culture leads to burnout - likely to be harassed by sales leadership quite often including evenings and weekends. Cisco DO NOT CARE ABOUT ANY EMPLOYEE - THEY BRAINWASH THEIR WORKFORCE INTO BELIEVING THEIR SPIN.

Pros:
- A lot of great people that are open, willing to help and brilliant.
- Work from home (even before covid)
Cons:
I always wanted to work for Cisco, but over the past several years I've seen a decline in culture and quality. 

- Complicated products! Look at how complicated SDA is, look at how complex our "multi-domain" strategy is. 
- Awful product quality. It's sad that we have to vet out our products for our customers in order to avoid trainwrecks (e.g. When FTD was released, SDA right now, ISA before 2.0)
- Silo'd. We talk about how we offer an end-to-end solution, but when it comes to sales, deployment, and even post-sales support everything is extremely silo'd. Have a multi-architectures solution? Good luck! 
- No career growth opportunities unless you move. Extremely difficult to get a grade bump or raise.
- Pay is no longer competitive compared to other big vendors. 
- YEARLY layoffs! Sometimes twice a year.

Pros: Cisco Systems, as a whole, have relative good performance over its life time.
Cons: One need find a good business unit within Cisco Systems.  If not, the "Cisco" life will not going to be good.

Pros: Competitive salaries with the market. A significant number of talented people to work with and learn from. A diverse culture within every department. Great benefits for health and finance.
Cons: Uses the GE philosophies on employee reviews using a bell curve to evaluate and a mandatory number of employees must be in the top range to be promoted and the bottom in a high pressure situation to quit or be fired. The average or core personnel are given the carrot of still getting a bonus, but no promotion or raise. The environment leads to a lot of back stabbing and almost no collaboration between peers who fear giving someone an advantage over them during reviews. One of the most dysfunctional places  I have ever worked.

Pros: One of Cisco's greatest pros is work/life balance the company provides to its employees; there is great flexibility when taking time off, and/or working remotely (ie. from home). In addition, Cisco provides its employees with excellent collaboration tools that allow for flexibility in work schedules, and an improved interface between employees in locations around the world. Cisco is an incredibly diverse company, and fosters an environment that is truly global. Lastly, I would cite that Cisco is a very generous company when it comes to benefits and caring for its employees.
Cons: Career development and Recognition have been cited by employees as areas Cisco needs to improve in. At least in my business segment, promotions are rare, and as someone who is rather low in the corporate ladder, there is very little room for growth. In addition, there are very few (if any) mentors among senior staff members that can help younger employees grow in their careers.

Pros: Instant brand name recognition and respect in technology sector. As an engineer, you get access to a wealth of knowledge and product materials. Flexibility around telecommuting. Colleagues have become among my best friends. Brand name attracts bright minds. Abundant resources and strong business intelligence make for some interesting products.
Cons: Death by process! Everything is so procedural, you spend significant time going through administrative steps to get  small, simple tasks done. Cisco is a lumbering elephant and has trouble focusing on a single sector or line of business. Overall company values are strong, but not nor applicable to certain business units. This is where some products or initiatives can fail. Middle management is an dense line of ego maniacs. Employees cannot thrive under that structure.

Pros: Very flexible work environment. People are generally very smart, open, and helpful. Very large campus allows for a lot of networking, and people are often encouraged to move around in different roles within a function.
Cons: Cisco has put a lot of red-tape in the way of an agile and quick work environment.  You can get lost easily in this large company if you don't proactively manage your career.  A number of high-performing employees either new to the company or new to their role were given an average performance rating because "they were new"... This is indicative of a seniority based company, not a performance based company.

Pros:
- Interesting and challenging work
- They treat their people with respect
- They are constantly trying to improve how they do business
Cons: -  Constant reorganization -  On the plus side though they do this to best align their resources with market needs, so other than the angst it creates for the people affected, this is not such a bad thing.  They invest in areas that appear to have the best growth/margin opportunities, while cutting back in slower growth or lower margin business areas.  The reorgs are not not company wide, and are focused in specific areas of the business, which varies with time, so this should not be misconstrued as poor management.  It's exactly the opposite. I believe we have excellent senior management.  They are constantly evaluating how to change and adapt, which allows the company to stay relevant with customers, and to grow their overall business.  Ultimately, that is good for both the company and employees.

Pros:
No company has ever treated me as well as Cisco did.  
Stellar benefits.
Constant training and incentive to grow.
Regular promotion from within.
Managers were some of the finest I've ever worked for. 
Basically, I had to work at a bunch of other companies before I realized just how good I had it at Cisco.
Cons:
Pay slightly lower than the industry average.
Stock is flat, so options don't mean what they did.
From a customer's perspective the company has lost their soul and forgotten that the customers put them where they are today. Too many companies now buying ABC - Anybody But Cisco because Smartnet is expensive and of dubious benefit when engineers just send you links so you can Read The Fine Manual.
All bugs public is a lie. 
Company hasn't figured out they aren't still a startup, so the workload is crushing.

Pros:
In my chain of leadership there was a lot of collaboration. I was often on calls or in meetings where we would discuss a client issue and the directors, VPs, managers all worked together to solve the issues. Everyone had a voice and opinions were respected. I never felt that I couldn't give an opposing view.

Relaxed culture. What you would expect of a silicon valley but Cisco is big I expected they would have been more up tight. Was not the case no matter what office I visited (east, east, north or south)  

Had a lot of freedom to handle clients and make my own decisions. Very good leadership support - they backed me when I took hard positions or had to say no.

Worked from home when not traveling.
Cons: Lots of travel, long hours, overloaded with work at times because we didn't have the staff. Had to handle a lot of things myself - would have been nice to have more admin support.

Pros: Loyal customers if you do your job right as an AM. Flexible work environment as the majority of us in my area work remotely to maximize time and productivity. Good OTE but it's weighted less on the base salary. Vast portfolio and always something to talk to your customers about. Great sales engineers which are the key to success.
Cons: Cisco has a weekly commit culture which comes with a grind and a narrow focus versus a big picture mentality which is a must for Enterprise and Large clients. When front line mgmt is only concerned about the weekly number, focus is lost on the big picture and doing all the intangibles to overachieve your number. This is my perspective only based on my situation and may not be the case elsewhere.

Pros: Nice pay, work life balance is ok (at the moment)
Cons: This applies mostly to Singapore.   increasing number of Indian engineers, which would have been fine if there were a corresponding increase in engineers from other nationalities.     slowly and increasingly biased against work life balance, due to engineers overpromising and underdelivering, I blame this on the Indian inability to say no to the customer.    Engineers should be trusted advisers but are now increasingly becoming YES men to customers, approving bad designs etc.    This leads to further escalations and incidents due to this bad design.

Pros: Cisco has made a huge investment in bringing a strengths-based approach to our culture and is backing it up in a myriad of ways - from processes that help leaders give the right kind of attention to their employees to investing in self-led learning for employees so every individual can continue to develop and grow in areas that are energizing for them.  It is in the midst of a very exciting transformation with reinventing the Network, enabling a multi-cloud world, unlocking the power of data to inform AI, and deploying security everywhere. All this and amazing sustainability and giving back programs.  The culture is amazing.
Cons: Like many organizations of this size there can be challenges with finding the right opportunities and being able to move with agility through the changes we are making.

Pros:
I have been around a lot of large companies and I can't say I've ever seen anything close to this good. I had always been curious about working here, and I had read a LOT of negative stuff about the company. When i came here (red badge/contractor then converted to blue/FTE) i kept an open mind and tried to reserve judgement. my experience has been GREAT. It's not perfect, sure, but WHAT IS?!

Great benefits
great work/life
payscale is good, but not top of the line for everyone.
Great technology 
Great team members/work culture

Don’t believe all the absurd doom and gloom blogs about this company.  Yes, it’s part of their corporate culture to restructure and RIF, accept it and move forward.  That can happen ANYWHERE!
Cons: WFH can be a double edged sword, and be isolating. Customers can be a pain and the Sales culture at Cisco can breed some real Sh*! heads, but that's not exclusive to Cisco either.

Pros:
-Great training (second to none for early in career)
-Great for making key contacts in early career development
-Corporate culture is very forward looking and emphasises more humanitarian principles than most large corporate companies
-Perks are very good, wages paid 75% to the highest average in the field
Cons:
Still a large corporate, as such you'll still encounter people playing the corporate game, even in the early in career programs.
Unfortunately, expect a lot out of you, especially if you are working in the Asia Pacific region. Burnout and overwork is common among colleagues.

Pros:
Open communication style
Management is easy to approach and competent
Company is extremely well run
Cutting edge technology (eg Telepresence)
Possibilities to work from home and have a flexible agenda
People are in general nice and easy to work with
Cons:
Extremely poor benefits package (company provides the bare minimum)
Salaries are seldom adjusted for inflation so employees in the company for a a long timeare paid substantially below market
Stock options used as an excuse to not adjust salaries for the majority of the employees while it's been a number of years they only benefit to senior executives
Aggressive sales culture leading to a very pressurized work environment
Little respect for work / life balance: on paper, the company says it's important but in reality you are expected to be on duty 24/7 and they provide you the technology to make sure you are

Pros: Cisco does pay a bit higher than the rest of their peers.  It is a large company so being able to move around is quite easy especially if you know people in the targeted area of your choice.  John Chambers is an excellent CEO and a strong leader.
Cons: Promotions, especially when it comes to Director level and above are difficult to come by and is more a matter of who you know versus your accomplishments.  Cisco does seem a bit top-heavy in management and that also prevents one from moving up more quickly.  With any large company, there seems to be "fiefdoms" of organizations that have questionable reasons for existence.  In other words, sometimes you're not so sure what function that organization was created to do and what value do they bring to Cisco in the big scheme of things.  It becomes less and less clear on how one's day-to-day work applies to Cisco's Top Business Priorities so at times you might feel that you're not really making much of a difference.

Pros: Pay is very decent but I will not say it is outstanding.  I don't feel bad but I wish I could feel better. Management training seems to be good.  The company vision is agressive and expanding which I like.
Cons: Too many people live their life in Cisco.  Sorry I don't want to work on Cisco software when I go home.  John Chambers a little too preachy and new age.  They seem to be playing the "be good enough" compensation wise.  I prefer pension and 401k mix.  I prefer less nickle and diming on health care.  I prefer Salary with raises not frozen-salary and hope for ever greater bonuses.

Pros: Cisco is stable, a fun place to work, and you can make of it what you will. I have been with the company for 10+ years and it's still a place I (usually) enjoy going every morning. When I wanted more responsibility, I just did it. In my experience you don't need to ask, just do it. Cisco encourages risk-taking, but if you're not a risk-taker, you'll do fine. Just do your job well. Free soda, popcorn, 4 wks vacation, generous compensation, and a company that is growing are all reasons Cisco is a great place to work.
Cons: Cisco's history of decentralization makes it hard to get the entire company to move in one direction. It can be hard to get cross-functional jobs done and it's not uncommon to discover other groups are doing a similar thing as you!

Pros:
I would say one of the best reasons to work for Cisco Systems, 
-Smart People a lot of resources and technology to tap from. 
-Good experience depending on your role and group.
- Global company with name recognition which could look great on your resume.
- I like the idea of rotations but now not sure how that will work.
---- ---- --- --- -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Cons: I would say the biggest downside, the size and opportunity for career movement/promotions and transparency into that area. Too many meetings and not enough time to get work done. Tied down with the work which makes it hard to actually take the time to figure out what is going on outside your department.

Pros: Great career ladder. Opportunity to work with the best technical people in the branch
Cons:
work long hours, lack life balance and career perspective. 
Advanced services organization is supposed to be a consulting organization. The advanced services engineers are there to provide customer with the highest level of technical consulting in the network Industry. Advanced services engineer main duty is not to pull up a show at quarterly review nor to sell products. Although product sale would be a by-product if consulting is done probably.
The middle management team lacks the knowledge of this job since they have never done the job and do not want to learn.

Pros: Huge company with dominant market share. Good pay. Opportunity to have good work-life balance (though it depends on the position - avoid Technical Support or Field Delivery if this is important for you). Great benefits (car allowance, Employee Stock Purchase Program).
Cons: Very political company (at least in México). HUGE number of Management positions (at least 30 EVPs worldwide). Difficult to find the opportunity to explore different positions, although if you can find the position and if you are the chosen candidate, you do not need approval from anyone to move. Management needs to open their eyes and realize there is a lot of people doing NOTHING to contribute to the success of the company. The company needs to get rid of this lazy people.

Pros: The section I work at in Knoxville has a free Friday policy where every other Friday you get to do your own research.  The projects change on a regular basis so at least twice a year you change up what you are working on.  The other employees and managers in my section are really great, intelligent cool people with only one exception.
Cons: My group at Cisco in Knoxville is very separate from corporate Cisco in San Jose, and that can make some communications seem forced and ludicrous.  Also there is that one manager in my group at Cisco who has favorites and prefers ideas from one person over another.  There is not much possibility of advancement at least from within my section at Cisco without leaving Cisco.  As well as Cisco has the regular lay offs which are bad for moral and scary.

Pros: Robust and expansive opportunities.  Exposure with upper level management.  Amazing training curriculum available.  Friendly and upbeat work environment.  Co-workers are all very supportive, and willing to help you succeed.  Although there is a ton of "older" generations at Cisco, more often than not they are willing to lend a helping hand and provide guidance.
Cons: Such a large company that you can often feel lost in the shuffle.  Currently Cisco is hitting a rough patch in the networking/routing/IT space.  Needs to be more pro-active in being at the forefront of the industry, and truly strive to be that #1 IT company.

Pros: I am in IT so cannot speak on behalf of engineering or sales teams. On IT side, Cisco does appear to be  good at allowing employees to maintain work life balance.
Cons:
If you are someone who likes to believe that never ending meeting is the idea of a job, this is the place. There are people and processes to support another set of redundant people and processes. Just too slow for a technology company. Too much office politics. Most of the middle level management is focussed on saving his/her job than adding real value back to company. Story telling is important but here it seems to be the only thing you see around. 

Biggest con i feel is the lack of quality people joining Cisco. Unlike some of the leading technology giants, somewhere Cisco recruitment process has lost it badly.

Pros: Great environment, beautiful campus, friendly people, huge cubicle space, smooth and easy communication via Jabber and WebEx, not too stressful, up-to date tools/software that makes work so much easier. There is at least one huge event every year (Cisco Rocks!) and many fun social gatherings biweekly near the site I worked at (site 5).
Cons: Slow paced work in the sense that you can't get your work done until someone is finished with their work. On a daily basis, I am mostly waiting 2-3 hours for someone to finish their work so I can work on my part of the project. It was great at first, but after a while I found it rather annoying and I didn't find myself as productive as I wanted to be.

Pros: Compensation, flexible work schedule, and travel.
Cons: Aspiring marketing professionals in college, do NOT make the mistake of starting off your career in Cisco. I was lured by the great salary, tales of a terrific culture, and the promise that Cisco would help me continue learning and growing as a marketer. The salary was great, but everything else was a lie. It is important to remember that Cisco, especially the marketing department, largely consists of middle-aged to older people who are already settled in their lives (kids, marriage, finances, etc). As a young, unattached professional, you are at a career advantage where you have the time to 1)Go physically into work and develop real one-on-one relationships with colleagues. 2)Devote time after work to networking with other tech marketing individuals. 3) Work with other young people who are more willing to take the financial risk and devote time to develop a start up. Cisco culture assists those who want a "work-life" balance which is great for those who are more settled in life. For those who still want to do something crazy and change the paradigm, Cisco is not the place to do it.

Pros: Large, robust company with a huge information infrastructure. Clean facilities. Great industry to be in in the information age. They've started adding small 'game rooms' to buildings with foosball tables, wall-sized scrabble, xboxes, etc.
Cons: You can't get anything done quickly because there is always a process for everything, or because there's an expense associated and everybody's budget is tight. Because of legal issues, contractors aren't eligible to be recommended for awards or to give input on the performance of full-time employees (for or against). Whether you have any fun at work is highly dependent upon the attitude of your management.

Pros:
Coming from university and straight to this as my first job I couldn't be happier, I work under a recruitment company and situated here at Cisco Systems.  The lifestyle and environment has surpassed my expectations of what the standard should be for a globally recognized company, compared to friends and family work environments and my previous experiences I can without a doubt say I am fortunate enough to be working at this professional establishment.

Everyone here is very friendly, there are lots of community events and it is very employee focused in the sense they put us first and make sure we are happy, not too stressed and make it fun to work here. He has good services too, on site carwash, dry cleaning, large choice of food in the canteen with special weekly dishes and much more. 

I can happily say this is one of the best companies to work at, and I would not leave unless I really had to in order to pursue my career.
Cons: Nothing I can think of.

Job Title: Sales, channel sales, pre-sales technical and business development
Pros: Having a long tenure at Cisco I enjoyed many roles and worked in multiple theatres. Cisco culture was printed and updated on the badge, but ultimately it was the people Cisco attracted. It meant working with the best of the best and many are still close friends.
Cons: Work-life balance was hard at times, but often this was self-inflicted because Cisco has such a strong culture to do what it takes and not let anybody down. There is always too much to do and so much opportunity to do more, so Cisco requires one to be a master at anticipating and prioritising. You must Network, collaborate and delegate to strike the right balance.

Pros:
Great people, who are knowledgeable, open-minded, friendly, family oriented.
Company is superbly organized in "everything", from processes, to documentation, learning portals, support and training systems, just every possible thing you can imagine.
Good benefits and pay.
Status symbol. This actually goes a long way, since people you do business with will treat you better, and seem more open to suggestions and listen to you well
Cons:
None during my 3 year contract there. Although while working at the Korean office, some people had bad work place manners (had a meeting room scheduled for an important client webex, and the lady overstayed by more than 30 minutes and just WOULD NOT leave the meeting room. But then again, I guess that's the "Korean" work culture/manners, since that seems to be accepted as "normal" behaviour.
Not much career opportunities if you're based overseas.

Pros: In some ways, Cisco still operates like a nimble start-up constantly reinventing itself. They are quick to adapt new technologies and innovations as long as that is where the market is heading. Change is the only thing that's constant, and they have no qualms to sacrifice long beholden programs or projects - in other words, no sacred cows. All this said, these are what I believe keeps Cisco successful, plus you gotta love their new slogan, "To be the best company in the world, and the best company for the world".
Cons: It is a big company, and you will feel invariably feel the beauracracies largely attributed to big companies. To get promoted you really have to invest considerable amount of time doing all the extra other things. Time that you would normally like to spend with your family. However, if you are satisfied with your current level then the workload is comparable to silicon valley standards.

Pros:
I'd like to think that I understood the corporate strategy for areas of technological expansion.

Some good centralised initiatives for creating a better engineering organisation with encouraging videos from different parts of the organisation.
Cons:
The message isn't getting through to lower level managers who appear to be much more concerned with arbitrary customer deadlines than improving their ability to deliver software reliably.

Many have noted the onerous demands of the centralised bureaucracy on individuals and teams, particularly the Open Source legal compliance processes.

Pros: You get to work with smart, talented people who genuinely want to see you succeed. You have the flexibility to work from home if needed and you get to work with a diverse group of people who really seem to enjoy their job.
Cons: You start off with good pay and compensation, but it takes a very long time to increase pay and get promoted. Sometimes it takes forever for something to be approved by upper management -this is one of the setbacks working at a large company. Also major re-organization in the company - not a good thing - people have reduced titles, went from FT to PT and some positions have been outsourced. Also - you don't always have the luxury to address issues to upper management - usually have to schedule a meeting to talk to them. Not as collaborative as I would like.

Pros: Work Life balance. Opportunity to interact with big names in industry (if you take the initiative), you get to learn a lot from such experiences. Fairly open management. People are helpful. I loved working with the people here.
Cons: Opportunities to grow are few. Cisco is a sluggish mover. People tend to be on cruise-mode. Lack of innovative initiatives from within the company, to be fair, there are platforms created, but, somehow the products/ideas which come out of them die (again, a lot of times, because of the bureaucratic, sluggish nature of the process to productize it.)

Pros:
What I really appreciate at Cisco is flexibility. I decide how I manage my work and personal commitments, whether I work from office or home. I need to deliver on my tasks in time agreed. There is great trust put into employees. If I have to take care of a personal situation, I can do it when needed. 
Other positives include good benefits package (Time2Give - extra time off for volunteering; meal card, connect card, pension scheme, birthday day off, and many more). I enjoy the culture of the company - I truly feel empowered to engage into activities related to inclusion, diversity or giving back, on top of my regular work responsibilities. Cisco also offers lateral moves, so one has good opportunities to build a diverse career here.
Cons: The workload can be overwhelming, and management is not always on top of the things; yet all of this can be worked on.

Pros:
Cisco is an amazing Company!  I always feel empowered to go above and beyond my given role. Here at Cisco you have many opportunities to network and get involved. You can become a Mentor, join an ERO such as Conexion attend amazing conferences such as Women of Impact.
I love that Cisco is a Global Company and I’m able to work across all regions in my day to day role! I feel that Cisco does a great job in creating a Culture of Inclusion.
Cons: For some, Cisco may be a bit intimidating based on the vastness of the Company.  However, once you begin to network and get involved you will quickly realize that it isn’t that intimidating, and people are very willing to connect with you.  Either to share best practices, join a shadow program or perhaps sign up to do a stretch assignment.

Pros:
Ability to work from near enough anywhere
Work with some of the latest technologies and products
Stable and debt free company
Cons:
If you currently have a social life and want to keep it, don't work for Cisco - work/social life balance is pathetic.
Salary does not match work load - Expectation to give too much personal time without reward.
Too much micro empire building in management.
It used to be a great place to work, a fun place to work, now it's just a place to work to pay the bills
Too much focus on ePM - a lot of expense, back end systems, staff supporting a system/process that is totally time consuming and meaningless.

Pros:
Great vision from CEO - Chambers turned internet "plumbing" company into software/application/unified communications/collaboration/video/data center & server company in the last 5-10 years.
Great sales execution
Great product line - It almost sells itself
Good pay & commission checks (because of reason above)
Ability to work remotely
Empowerment - WebEx conferencing, softclient IP phone allows above
Flexibility - Allows personal choices for work devices such as Macbook Pros (at company's expense!) & iPhones
Cons:
Slow career advancement
Unclear on how to get promotions
Company is severely cutting costs - no more free beverage, home internet, etc.
Perceived poor leadership from development organization - most of our technology & new product lines are gained through acquisitions
Salary increases are very little - expect none to 3-5% a year
Pace of work (at least in sales) is FAST. Must control own work life balance.

Pros:
The flexibility to work from home. 
Worked with some really talented people.
Lots of training/education
Good pay for contractors
Cons: As a contractor - I observed a lot of office politics!  Communications group puts way to many senseless ppt presentations together and redundant forms of communication.  Not even sure if people are listening or awake during large webex meetings - dead silence during Q&A's.  I was never een sure what exec management team actually did. For those that have worked there a long time, which seemed like alot of people, they are stuck in a rut and aren't open to anything new and do it they way it's always been done.  The virtuall office (McCarthy Ranch)  can't really be utilized by contractors - squatters take over the spaces that are supposed to be open to all.

Pros: Cisco is a world-class organization with extraordinary people and opportunities.  There is no shortage of challenge and opportunities can follow demonstrated performance -- particularly if located in San Jose, CA
Cons: Despite its global foot-print, Cisco remains a San Jose centric company from a leadership standpoint and --despite best-in-class collaboration technologies in its product portfolio -- opportunity standpoint.  The company is trying to re-establish geographic proximity of colleagues to align with MIT viewpoint on Agile PLM framework.  This is beyond silly on a campus where over 40 buildings and back-to-back meetings have employees calling in and WEBEX'ing into meetings where folks are in the same area.

Pros:
+ Well known name in the telecommunications/Networking Industry.
+ Flexible working hours
+ Generous with employee's career developments (training & tuition reimbursements, allowing Engineers to pursue MBA, etc.)
Cons:
- Becoming too large, i.e. too bureaucratic, too many layers (of middle managements)
- turf/territorial fighting for control-span in the middle management which becomes a game of "who do you know, not what do you know or how harder/smarter one works " for one's career.
- The top level management, ie. CEO & his staff lost touch with the employees especially at the individual contributors, hence not knowing exactly what's going within the organizations (the cause of the turf fighting within the middle management).
- Lack of true leadership.

Pros: Great people to work with.  Benefits are top notch, including tuition reimbursement for degree seekers.  Provides for continuous learning by providing company sponsored Pluralsight/CodeSchool and Safari accounts.  Internal training opportunities (Cisco on Cisco if you will) are also available.
Cons:
Budget, Budget, Budget.  While all of the above opportunities exist,  having budget to take an internal class or getting management to approve the time (and possible travel) to attend the class is difficult.  Getting equipment takes some planning and justification out the *ss, a quarter or more in advance. (note that the Pluralsight & Safari accounts are almost automatically approved. I believe there is a significant corporate/quantity discount).
Getting  promoted beyond "the middle" can take a long time.
Products are developed, in my experience, in a vacuum devoid of customer input.

Pros: Amongst the amazing and almost endless versatile environments opportunities to work in Cisco Systems has become a game changer when reaching out to veterans from all branches of our military communities. With programs for both the technical experienced and those who are not, Cisco has been able to create, modify and continue multiple programs that help bring great and talented men and women who are eager to make a great career change as they seperate from military service. Being a member of a leading team is almost every service members feeling day in and day out. You're sure to get the same, if not more, experiences here at Cisco Systems as well.
Cons:
Only two I can think of is:
Defined career path/outlook per job title/description
*Comparable salaries to other competing companies

Pros: Great Benefits, tons of vacation from the start
Cons: Not equal opportunity employment. if you don't get your money coming in, you won't get it. it's impossible to get a raise or a promotion to the appropriate grade level that your peers are at. I've been here 5 years, no raise, no promotion, i'm one grade level under where my peers are which make it impossible for me to move within Cisco  unless i want to go sideways or backwards. It's terrible.

Pros:
Great benefits - best in class!

Above average sales compensation (if you’re goaled fairly) 

Cisco offers excellent professional development and training opportunities. Take advantage of this valuable resource!

Working from home is a huge perk.

Talented, tenacious teammates
Cons:
Sales goals are highly subjective and based on corporate goals, shareholder pressure and most importantly- leadership favoritism. (Hope your leader negotiated their goal well!). Highly leveraged sales plans can help or hurt you. Must be risk tolerant to thrive in sales at Cisco. Six figure compensation swings can occur from year to year...

Layoffs. Every year. More than once a year. It can be unnerving if you depend on the income. 

Expect to work long hours, often across multiple time zones. It’s easy to burn out, overwork and/or negatively impact your health (that’s where the medical benefits come in handy).

Cisco is rapidly replacing senior professionals with millennials. Shareholders love saving money - diversity is improving - but the lack of experience shows. Out with the old, literally, in with the new...

Pros: Reasonable pay, comfortable, stable, somewhat flexible work times, good benefits, later work time start, standard 20 days PTO.
Cons:
Few top down directives, teams instead are largely independent, leads to teams fighting internally to achieve their own objectives rather than for benefit of Cisco. 
Heavily political.
(pre pandemic) Officially: working from home is allowed, Unofficially: working from home generally frowned upon, need to be in office unless sick or have important errand.
Officially: switching jobs within the company is allowed and encouraged. Unofficially managers get really petty when this happens and usually drops your bonus to minimum.
Technology and tools is generally behind the curve, huge legacy issues prevent investment in reworking.
Advancement/pay raises usually very limited, however not for lack of desire by direct managers.
Company culture is pretty bland, team cultures vary.
No dedicated sick time

Pros: Salary and benefits. In the past they empowered the employee to do great things, now not at all. The technology and availability of "state of the art" equipment is awesome. The labs and expertise of co-workers is also great.
Cons: It WAS the best employer to work for in the 90's but now is far too focused on profit and micro-management. Too many layers of managers managing time and metrics. Everything is far too focused on managing peoples efficiencies so most people are stifled and the atmosphere isn't like it was in the 90's. I'm not saying that they can go back, I'm just saying that the focus WAS on technology, coolness and $$. Now is is squarly just focused on maximizing profit. I left after 9 years of employment to another smaller "start up" type company.

Pros: If you are going to be in IT Hardware Sales having the "Cisco Stamp" on your resume is a door opener if you can make 3 years over target.
Cons:
It is an extremely political environment where promotions and opportunity are based upon who you know.  Middle management is focussed on one thing only, getting their next promotion.  To be successful in the field sales organization it is not enough to crush your number, you must spend more than half your time beating your chest about how great your methodology is... 

There is zero work / life balance.  You are expected to be connected 24/7.  The compensation is continually being driven down.  The days of "big money" at Cisco are over.

Pros: Good pay, time off, and benefits.  Depending on the group, they do have reasonable work-life management.  The nice thing is that employees seem to have the ability to move on to different groups (lateral moves) if they are tired of their projects.  Cisco does have a new group (Emerging Technologies)  that's trying to be more like a start-up environment by looking into new business areas.
Cons:
Large company:  Lots of processes, meetings galore.

Political:  It's more about who you know rather than your skill set.  Cisco does have some really good people and groups though.

Glass ceilings:  Promotions are limited and you really need your manager to fight for you.  If you are in a passive group, it's tough to move up.

Pros: My team has some of the most talented and amazing people I've ever worked with.
Cons:
Cisco is bleeding talent. Our best resources are running for the exit in numbers that are simply staggering. What's left behind are mainly those unwilling or unable to look for another job in the current economy. 
With rare exception, management is woefully ignorant of what it takes to be competitive in the current market and seems completely disconnected from reality. It's a miracle if a project get's out the door at all rather than being defunded/descoped mid-stream. What a tragedy that such a once great company is now drowning under the weight of bad decisions from bloated bureaucracy.

Pros: Cisco has made it a corporate policy to pay at the 75% level for their industry, meaning that they will pay more than 75% of their peers. That means you get a good salary and lots of bonus opportunities (stock units, spot bonuses, etc.). This makes it hard to leave even if you are unhappy with the company itself.
Cons: The company is slow and stodgy with a culture that is very risk averse. It takes at least 1 year to release anything significant and you should expect that many products or features will never actually be launched no matter how important they are. There are lots of hoops to jump through, review cycles, and red tape. Creating anything truly ground-breaking is nearly impossible due to the politics involved and the multiple layers of management. As a result, many of the people who are at the company are "lifers" -- people who have decided that they get paid well enough to stay where they are but who aren't interested in really pushing the boundaries.

Pros:
- The best place to dive deep into  and get your hands dirty working on technology, for those who like it.
- Employees are mostly well looked after, though there have been gradual cost cuttings in the last 5 years.
- Management is very chaotic but the employees are very professional and maintain a good environment.
- Work life balance can be awesome or horrible based on your manager.
Cons:
- Management level changes are so frequent that it instils a lack of confidence in your career in the org.
- Politics is everywhere. Sometimes very evident, sometimes subtle.
- Vision is very high level and implementation is very chaotic. Low level employees rarely have a say in any decision.
- Work life balance can be awesome or horrible based on your manager.

Pros:
Management are very good in general; technical, but with appropriate soft skills. Demands are reasonable, time off, flextime, and telecommuting are all accepted easily. 
In general, your personal time is valued greatly, and although I tend to work 45-55 hours a week, I can always count on being able to schedule some time for myself if the need arises.
Cons: Tenured employees can sometimes stifle innovation, tend to not understand agile and continuous delivery, and also don't appreciate how flat team structures work.

Pros: Amazing People, Great Products and the juggernaut of the Internet.  Lots to be learned, and 30 years of experience in high tech.
Cons: It's not the company it used to be.  A massive revolving door these days, and a focus on lower-cost of doing business.  Growth potential is probably very limited, and more likely, this is a company that will be shrinking a lot over the next 5 to 10 years.

Pros: You get an extra day PTO for your birthday - that's about it!!
Cons:
Not the great company it once was...

Moral is at an all time low, with large numbers of people at Cisco currently looking at leaving or waiting in the hope they are made redundant, many have already jumped ship and are now working for better companies with much, much better packages...

Lack of innovation and strategy across nearly their entire product set is a big concern, and management seem to have no idea how to fix things..

Cisco are rapidly falling through the ranks of Best Places to Work too - 8th place in 2015, and just two years later now down at 26th place (which doesn't surprise anyone based on what's been happening there over the last two years) 

Don't take my word for it though, search 'Cisco' on layoff dotcom and see what others are saying, many of which are still there hoping things will change!!

Just my personal opinion - but I reckon if you have worked for a decent company before, you will only have regret if you join Cisco in it's current state.

Pros:
Cisco is a old tech company with, leading the networking space, but a great market recognition. 

The Cisco partner community will do the sales job and Account Executives just control the forecast, create internal reporting and have regular lunch with customers.

Cisco provides great social benefits and excellent compensations schemes. Also is a great company for remote working and family care
Cons:
This is one of the most arrogant companies in the market, with partners, customers and employees. 

They discriminate partners based in personal interest, specially the Operations Directors. 

Customers feels Cisco should be replaced but the can´t have the risk. In Public Sector, they don´t give the same discount to each partner, breaking public law.

Employees don´t get promoted. What can you expect in Spain with the same senior management in the last 10 years?

Employees get fired based on political reasons and favours, not meritocratic actions.

Pros: Great benefits, great people, usually empowered to work independently, lots of opportunities to lead, choose your stretch assignments and get cross functional experience. Also several employee resource orgs for Inclusion and Diversity.
Cons: Annual layoffs, high stress, inequity

Pros: Cisco is still a network equipment branch names from the outsider's view.  The company continues to make the customers to believe in their leadership in the router/switches market.
Cons: In building the core software, Cisco gives priorities to politics and release deadlines instead of delivering quality software in a model approach.  Middle management staff are mostly from a group ethnic group.  They are more interested in their personal success than the success of the company.

Pros:
+ There are many opportunities to grow a career here. I've participated in stretch assignments, rotational positions, and been on several communications teams at Cisco. 
+ People here are genuinely helpful. This is especially important for new hires, b/c Cisco is a big company, but everyone helps you navigate. 
+ I have had 4 great managers at Cisco in 9 years. Cisco invests in management and leadership skills, so I shouldn't be so surprised at the high quality managers I've reported into. 
+ Cisco takes development seriously. The amount of learning offerings here is incredible! I've taken advantage of on campus Toast Masters, remote and in person speaking workshops, mindfulness training, and more. 
+ Depending on the role and team, Cisco is a pretty remote-worker-friendly company. I love where I live, and I don't have to compromise that to give Cisco 100% and they get that.
Cons: - It's a big company, so expect a process for everything. This is often actually helpful, but it's not for everyone.

Pros: Good Benefits.  First line management very good
Cons: Don't trust upper management (Director level or above).  You can't believe anything upper management says past 6 months.  It will change.  If you are a developer, do not think you can build anything new internally.  You can NOT.  Cisco is very good at acquiring companies for new development.  If you have more of an entrepreneurial spirit and you have been acquired by Cisco, my advice is do your contractual time and get out to start another new business.

Pros: Flexible work culture, good work-life balance, interesting projects. It can be great if you have a manager who supports and goes out of their way for you.
Cons:
Top heavy company with limited talent cultivation. The way up is by leaving and being re-hired - says a lot about their self-assessment that they value people outside their company vs inside. 

There is no documentation of success, talent reviews, etc so when re-orgs happen, you have zero track record and no say in what happens to you role-wise. You are a new hire when you get re-orged with the same timeline reset before your career can progress.

Unless you are a manager, you can go 5+ years without even a COLA. Heavily political environment where sponsorship is required, so there is a strong need to play the game and cultivate strong relationships from the get go.

Pros:
The managers over here are constantly trained to maintain balance btween all the employees in a team.
There is no micro management at all.
Your weekdays are yours, your holidays are yours
Best work life balance.
Free AC Gym provided in Bangalore main campus.
Yearly Complete health checkup is done at free of cost.
Company provided 50K (before tax) as bonus for each employee in india amidst covid crisis.
You can move from one team to another with "internal movement" which will help you get rid of managers ( if yu don't like them) or the tech stack.
- Of course, you need to stay on the same role for an year (untill you move for another one)

Identity - where you travel in the world, people will recognize the company name.
Cons:
- Salaries are not upto market standards.
- All managers are not the same.
- Some managers won't handle there team's well and it results of employees leaving.
- Food is not for free 🙂
- Onsite travel is not up to that much.

Pros:
Good Job Security - Good place to build experience. Great first job, with lots of benefits. 

I work in support, and Cisco has a good system to ensure that I do not bring my work home. Also, for the support field, I am surprised how well Cisco Support Engineers are paid. Salary is definite plus. 

Additionally, pursing a Cisco Certification within Cisco is easy and inexpensive. There are many experts on hand to help the learning process.
Cons:
Bureaucracy. Stifling young talent. Too narrow a scope of expertise, not enough interdisciplinary education or work.

I wish sometimes Cisco Management will quick recognize who is a top performer and the motivated and talented folks are. Then promote them or encourage them to keep their development. Currently we only do performance reviews once every year and it seems the distribution of incentives is poor.

Pros:
You can work in the office or  at home
Most people  care about what they are doing
Quality products
Great Benefits
Looks great on a resume
You get to make a lot of contacts in a short time
Cons:
To many ASR’s in the company who have a sense of entitlement
Mid management often doesn’t get it
Too many politics involved to get promoted
Most ODs are just trying to climb the ladder and don’t  do a good job in leading teams
AMs have gotten lazy and forgotten how to cold call
People who should be fired continue to make lateral moves and are never let go
Cisco needs to clean out the bottom 5% every year and they have gotten away from that practice.
Too many outside consultants
The whole review process  is a joke
Too many internal meetings when you should be out with clients
You have to leave to get promoted to higher spot at times

Pros: If you want a company with a good brand, market share and status, Cisco is a good one. Good opportunities for working remote. Good to have 1-2 years of Cisco experience on your resume, then look for a firm that you'd want to work at.
Cons: Cisco has either bought or driven most competitors into the ground resulting in no urgency around providing quality products. No transparency into the promotion process, it works as a good old boy network. Aside from a few token women VPs, there are no career advancement opportunites for women. Management does not listen to employees - their egos are so large, they either know it all already or they are too busy fighting internal territorial battles. If you want a company exploding with arrogance, this is the right one.

Pros:
Being a big company, one's experience can vary significantly from person to person. So providing only my experience. And this may be contradicting to others.

If you are working hard, company or leadership team provides whatever you want. This is my personal experience. Agreed lot of politics, but if you are A category employee, leadership team always values you. Promotions again on ratings and vary from team to team. Cisco pays best among network companies. 

work life balance==> always the best and on par with some of the best companies in bay area.
Cons:
perm for foreign nationals. Its difficult to start perm process as cisco is constantly doing restructuring. Though restructuring is good for company, foreign nationals suffers because of that. I see this is the only reason to move to different company.
recruitment should be improved. Quality is comparatively low during mass recruitment events.
I think leadership team needs a shuffle. Need to innovate more rather than trying to imitate. I think this is true for most of the networking companies.

Pros: Smart people to work with, ability to work remotely in many cases, good salary and benefits. Used to get great bonuses but not sure if that's going to be true going forward.
Cons: Constant churn, spending tons of money on consultants to supply answers that people already know. Especially if it's bad news, then the bad news comes from the consultant. Layoffs becoming yearly autumn event. I have no idea how anybody can still concentrate knowing that another layoff is bound to be around the corner. Felt like people were really covering their butts instead of collaborating. Got to the point where you didn't know who you could trust anymore.

Pros: Still finding the pros from past 2.5 years
Cons:
At the time of offer letter, HR told that the work type will be Development but its totally Sustenance(Bug Fixing).

Cisco is not doing good it doesn't have enough money to give hikes to their at least 80% of their employee. Even many of the employees are in CISCO Bangalore who doesn't get the hike for past 2.5 years.

 If employee asked their managers or higher management they try to scare it by saying that they will fire you and put the bad remarks in your relieving letter.
As every year, there is a culture in Cisco to fire the employees. So manager take benefits of it and as there are few networking companies so they are always try to harassing the employees.

If anyone joined, managers directly told them that you will not get the hike even if you performed well because you switched the company so you get good amount of hike in comparison to the previous employer.

Dirty politics in Cisco.

No career growth.

Pros: Cisco is an international powerhouse that has significant presence in almost every country in the world. They strive to stay on the cutting edge of technology as they compete against all comers in the international network technology space.
Cons:
Cisco is a "tale of two cities" having a smaller full-time employee force of around 25,000 full-time employees worldwide that is complemented by a much larger outside contractor workforce that they turn over very quickly based upon a contractor's length of contract. 

As an outside contractor, it is very apparent that you are treated as a second class worker that is thrown into a large pool of  other outside contractors. 

Consequently, contractor morale is very bad and as such Cisco's work environment is quite toxic.

Pros: A number of initiatives directed at female employees, most of them under the umbrella of Connected Women network - all this provide the opportunities to grow as a professional woman in IT company.
