The company empowers employees to initiate actions that are helpful in career building. Haven't experienced any discrimination. Got a lot of support when changing the role from operations to technical field. Friendly atmosphere - colleagues eager to share their knowledge and experience. Flexible working schedule.
Cons: Very few female in high managerial positions (>Manager, so like Senior Mgr, Directors etc. - I believe there is only 1 Senior Manager) in our location, and it is one of the 3 biggest sites in EMEAR.  Hear stories that females are being hired only to fulfill the diversity statistics (poor communications?).

Pros: Salary and opportunities for training good. Flexible working policies very good
Cons: Cisco bought out our successful company and have ruined it in around 5 years. It's too big, what makes sense as a direction at the top, loses its way in translation down the layers and becomes farcical.  Constant redundancies and reorganisations just to try and make the bean counters happy, with no real thought as to whether they make sense.  Good people can be cut from important/successful projects because some line manager in the States has been told to cull x people and conversely some  people can be left with a job title and a good salary, but no constructive work to do - soul destroying and I'm so happy I got out.

Pros: Benefits are great, the salary is great, but what separates Cisco is the people. I work alongside some of the smartest, driven, and fun people I've ever met. As someone who is early-in-career for my position I need support from my peers to be successful and I've been given that tenfold. I was part of the CSAP program and it is hands down one of the best ways to accelerate your career.  You get paid to learn, get certifications, and exposure to managers, directors, and even VPs on a weekly basis. In fact, the CEO Chuck Robbins came in to talk to my cohort one day. You may get something similar at another company, but nothing that's on the level of CSAP.
Cons: Like any corporate company, there are a lot of employees and sometimes tough decisions need to be made in regard to restructuring. However, from my experience if you work hard and focus  to be the best version of yourself, it's not something you have to worry about.

Pros: Nice place to work, but so are a lot of other places. The compensation is amazing. The initial job offers are almost impossible to turn down. Most employees are highly motivated about delivering new, top quality products to the customers. If you have the fortune to get on the right product team you really care about, your drive and commitment will help shape the solution from day one. You can focus on your job with minimum administrative distractions. Huge bonus in being able to spend the majority of your day writing quality code, less the distractions of administrative paperwork, irrelevant meetings etc.
Cons: Mobility in the company seems slow to average. Long hours in return for little merit and recognition. Probably due to a glut of middle management in the food chain perhaps? May result in a lot of managerial red tape in project approval process. Team creativity can sometimes stagnate as result.

Pros: Cisco has lot of great people and there are always opportunities to learn about different products and technologies given the breath of the company's portfolio.  The company does a great job looking after it's core employees (middle 50%) and has a great benefits package.
Cons: Because the company does a great job of looking after it's core employees, it has a tendency to reward mediocracy as opposed to driving for/promoting excellence.  The company has not done a good job at staying young over the past 5 years and there is a little too much bureaucracy in the organization to be nimble and effective.

Pros: I am currently a summer intern at Cisco, and in terms of summer internships, I can really say that they have given me real hands on experience with real responsibility.  I came in barely knowing what a network/router was, and I feel that I have been able to learn a lot from my co-workers who are always more than willing to help me whenever I have a problem.  My pay is very good compared to what most of my friends are making, and if I were to work overtime, they would give me time and a half.  It also looks good on a resume
Cons: Looking around, it seems that people (especially with pending deadlines) put in A LOT of overtime and complain that they aren't properly compensated for it.  It's also tough because there are some crazy people who will work 80 hours a week and then that will put the pressure on everyone else to step it up.

Pros: Stability - no one is going to buy Cisco any time soon (though there is still attrition).  Incredible wealth of resources available.  Lots of super-smart people running around.  Lots of market share in every virtually every product line, and the cachet that comes with the Cisco name.
Cons: Huge company.  Too many competitors with better technology.  Cisco can't be expected to turn on a dime, but the products need to ramp faster.  The whole "end to end" argument is getting stale with a lot of customers - we need to innovate in areas other than revenue and market share or both will ultimately suffer.

Pros: These days mostly just the ability to work from wherever I want to. In theory I like being able to lead the industry with good software and new ideas, but these days cisco doesn't lead much (unless you call acquisitions leading). I wonder: did we EVER lead?
Cons: Middle and upper management seems very oblivious. There's no risk-taking or anyone wanting to support good ideas (whether they pan out or not; that's part of the risk, guys!). As mentioned in other reviews, trying to get anything done from the bottom up is a fool's errand. Actually, I'm not sure there IS a way to get anything done, unless via spin-in or acquisition.

Pros: Cisco treats interns well and makes sure they're taken care of with good pay, interesting activities and some free swag.  You get to work in an area of the company that interests you, so you're not just thrown anywhere at random.  How you enjoy the experience will definitely rely on your manager, mentor and team.
Cons: Most of the engineers at Cisco seemed like your stereotypical engineer: working in front of a computer all day without any ability to communicate with normal people.  Definitely a lack of work/life balance, with some engineers working crazy hours without any diversity in their lives.  Not to say that Cisco doesn't have good engineers, but its hard to find one you'd want to sit down and have a beer with.

Pros:
Easy laid out life.
Can finish your 40 hour job in 10-25 hours.
You can climb the ladder of carrer growth by becoming a yes sir employee.
Cons:
a)Highly beuraucratic.
b)I have seen time and again the absolutely idiotic people going ahead of the deserving ones
c) It has become a managment playground.
d) Compensation is very low.
e) I have been in the top 10% consistently but still there are no signs of carrer growth.
f) You are expected to work your ass off, but if you ask for a hike you are given the same managmenet funda.
g) The moment you come into your managers hitlist you are as close to gone as possible.
h) Layoffs have become a game now, it is like an yearly activity and the CEO will shamelessly admit it.
g) It has the lost the charm it once used to have. Now, it just moves like a huge elephant.

Pros: It gives quality rate assistance with promoting unity. With its growth in diversity, Cisco is and will ever be knowledgeable in networking with people and enhancing its promotion with its massive international market base in different 165 countries. Cisco has the flexibility, great benefits, competitive salary, and positive work environment that I am definitely glad to be a part of a long standing leader in networking industry.
Cons: The company needs to pay more attention to its pay benefits and improve upon pay raises in North Carolina. The night life of employees are also important because the human resource manager needs to have more 1 on 1 conversations with its employees. That should be the corporate responsibility of the managers at Cisco and  the new direction of the HR sector.

Pros: Excellent benefits, flexible working from home using WebEx, and transitioning into a more competitive relevant company. It's also easy to find new opportunities and grow within the company. There are many folks, especially more middle-aged folks who've been with the company for multiple years and who maintain and excellent work/life balance.
Cons: Cisco is massive and there'll be lots of big corporate headaches with communication. You'll find dozens of teams working on similar things, but no centralized approach. This is getting better with reorgs and aligning to the industry, but still a big issue.

Pros: The work life balance at Cisco is incredibly unique. All you need is your laptop and wifi and you can work wherever you'd like (in most cases, some functions do not have complete flexibility). I live thousands of miles from my family & friends, but Cisco encourages me to go home and visit whenever I'd like, without having to take any time off. I can only imagine how wonderful this flexibility will be when I'm a mother some day. I've had numerous coworkers stay home with a sick child or take some time out of the day to go pick up their kids from school. Cisco supports it all. It would be extremely difficult to leave and lose all this flexibility. I plan to stay here as long as possible.
Cons: Nothing sticks out that is any different than working at any other company. Typical downsides of being in a business environment.

Pros: Cisco offers a place for people of such diverse backgrounds. I joined later in my career; i hadn't previously worked in IT or for a global corporation but to my surprise, I fitted in. If you are prepared to work hard and are confident enough to come up with ideas, then you are given the opportunity to grow. In recent years I have developed a visual impairment and my Cisco managers have been fantastic at getting me the support I need.
Cons: Over my 10 years at Cisco there has been a lot of reorganisation bringing changes to my role, team, managers. However, the rationale and objectives of the changes are always made clear. We do have to live and work wondering what is coming next.

Pros: Clean, uncluttered office with great views, intelligent use of collaboration technology, choose between an X1 Carbon ThinkPad or Macbook Pro as your primary laptop, good mobile/VPN access on tablets/smartphones so you can literally work anywhere on any device, diverse and inclusive culture, regular social events in the office (with wine sometimes), company-supported participation in mass events like SGX Bull Run, JP Morgan corporate challenge, up to 5 days of "Time to Give" which employees can use to perform volunteer work, company matches up to US$10K per employee for every hour of volunteer work performed, CSR activity included on every team offsite event, trustworthy and professional colleagues, regular communication from senior leadership, great internal platforms for learning, including access to LinkedIn Learning and other external learning platforms
Cons: Sometimes complex internal processes, few opportunities for promotion (people tend to stay unless made redundant), very challenging business environment despite strong leadership in most market segments and solid product/solution portfolio

Pros:
- Good work-life balance, meaning most of the times no one expects you to work weekends and after hours (may vary by BU or department, but most business functions are this way)
- Lots of flexibility; personally had a lot of freedom to work remotely (there are a lot of people who work from home everyday)
- Most people are pleasant to work with
- Benefits are good
Cons:
- No formal performance reviews, hence no clear path to promotions or pay raises (it's very unclear what your bonus is based on as well and your salary will not be adjusted for inflation every year, maybe every couple of years)
- Not a lot of growth opportunities; if you're lower grade-level you don't get a lot of autonomy or responsibilities let alone chances to voice your opinions
- Layoffs happen about twice a year and no one is "safe" (have seen people who have been here less than a year get laid off, so being new doesn't give you an exemption)

Pros: Cisco has a very big market cap and plenty of cash on hand.  They should be able to weather economic downturns very well.  Cisco provides free drinks, enables telecommuting and is very flexible on employee scheduling.
Cons: They are removing the free drinks and paid home ISP.  Cisco has lost its great culture that it had in the late 1990's, where all management and employees would do what was right for the customer, eschewing ulterior motives.  Their upper management is now so diluted with recent newcomers that old company bad behavior has crept in and trickled down.  Directors and VPs are not very trusted by the individual contributors and first line managers.

Pros: Interesting and exciting work.  The culture is unusual in Silicon Valley in that senior management takes input from anyone who wishes to share it, and then makes the decisions.  Everyone is expected to line up behind a decision once it's made.  This is a good thing, as there is no passive-aggressive behavior so common at other companies.  It's a great place to work if you are hard-charging and are willing to take risks.  Management backs you up when you do!  Also, Chambers is an outstanding CEO, who understands his employees and customers.  He is very highly respected within the company.
Cons: Comp is below market by design.  Management's view is that it's a privilege to work at Cisco, so employees should willingly take below-market comp.  Too many promotions go to cronies, without enough consideration to others.

Pros: Cisco has a good culture that promotes personal and professional growth.  There are plenty of opportunities to participate in professional development courses.  In addition, one can seek internal opportunities for a lateral move or even career advancement opportunities.
Cons: You will be working with many "type A" personalities.  It is very competitive.  There are only so many E+ and X performer ratings that can be handed out.  As a result, the manager is forced into an unfortunate position of designating bottom 10% even if the person is not truly an underperformer.  Also, be wary of internal corporate politics...  People who receive raises and promotions do not always merit those awards due to performance alone.

Pros:
Flexible work location/telecommuting (depending on boss or department - there is no entitlement - so discuss before joining)
Use of latest technologies.
Famous name  - good for cv.
Steady job.
Cons:
Compensation below average - make sure you negotiate a good salary on starting as you may not see a raise in years
Promotions rare. They tend to recruit from outside (either department or outside cisco) - can be very demoralising. Take any promises when you are offered the job with a pinch of salt - get commitments in writing.
Slow pace - highly matrixed organisation.
Annual review process pointless and impact on annual bonus laughably small. 
Thousands of VPs, directors - doing what? No one I have asked knows. 
SanJose centric. So beware if not based there - the hard to get raises, promos and visibility just got a whole lot harder/impossible!
No sign of HR at all, so good luck if you need their help or advice.

Pros:
- Fun loving employees who provide great comradery
- Ambitious vision for technology and the company
- Communities of knowledge that empower employees
Cons: - Arrogant senior managers in select Cisco organizations disempower their employees and stymie innovation

Pros:
* Great compensation and benefits 
* Smart, fast moving people, tech savvy 
* Great tech tools 
*  Decent work/life balance- big plus is many people can work remote. Perks like day care, nice cafes, gym
Cons:
* High turnover- many senior managers departing; annual layoffs that keep people on edge, revolving door culture.
* Lip service given to "great place to work" and caring for employees vs the reality of annual layoffs...people moved in and out and treated like pawns
*  Large pc of company is now contractor based,allowing it to skimp on benefit costs and reduce workforces with ease
*  Senior mgn led by the long- time CEO trying desperately to move Cisco in new directions, beyond routers and switches, with mixed results (example: video technology)

Pros: Cisco developed the internet. They're now at the centre of revolutionizing software defined networks. Cisco offers a trust-based work environment. You can work from anywhere on earth (many work from home) as long as you have internet access. Exciting, international project opportunities. I work in at least two different countries per month. I worked in the UK, Germany and USA during the last three weeks and am frequently provided with opportunities to facilitate workshops with senior leadership. We also give back to the community both financially and through community projects for those in need. Cisco staff are "family" and we live, work, give back and play together. Yes, there were redundancies but that happens in many companies. This really is a great place to work!
Cons: Slow to promote those who've earned it. People stay because it is a great place to work... But most successful employees know they'd have a higher position elsewhere.

Pros: Great people to work with.  At times work is challenging. Not so hard to move around between groups. Relentless focus on execution, however, sometime ready, fire, aim. Biggest plus is Flexible work - just get your work done, people don't care where you are (That said, some groups do)
Cons:
Very big - tiny cog in big machine - hard to make a difference
Constant focus on you adjusting to change - just not changing any of the pre-year 2000 systems.
Lots of talk about digitization, but operationally really falling behind - unable to support new business models
Promotions are very hard. Raises and high bonuses are only really given to top performers

Pros: Most everything is project-based so when, where & how you do it is largely up to you.  Level of worker trust and autonomy is first rate
Cons: No clear, efficient process to move talent around the company as inevitably some products are hits while others fail. Cisco over rotated on performance reviews. Went from onerous do it yourself yearly dissertations that direct managers "graded" to informal sync-ups that largely get blown off or skipped because they are too unstructured. Cisco needs to rethink performance reviews so they get better performance.

Pros:
Amazing company with a strong reputation along customers, partners and competitors. Working at Cisco you make a statement in your career path by having joined one of the biggest IT companies around the globe and dealing with highly sophisticated technologies.

There is to mention especially the CSAP program, an industry-leading traineeship which applies to both, engineering and business graduates. The CSAP program provides you with a unique opportunity to dive into the world of advanced technologies and how to position them, as well as you will be confronted with real life cases and projects, making you a highly relevant employee for the company´s future plans.

Cisco also stands out with many different benefits, a great work-life balance and over-average salary in the IT industry.
Cons: Being a global player there are issues due to the company´s enormous size. Processes could be optimized, some tools lack usability and visibility could be increased.

Pros:
The benefits are outrageously good.
The compensation is outrageously good.
If you are a survivor you will do well here.
If you are a high performer, you will do financially well here.
If you slack, you may actually do better than the high performers as management keeps the slackers around to cut them every 6 months when LRs are mandated.
When you are impacted by an LR and you will be, you earn a great exit package (I earned one year of base pay for 4 years of work...)
The DCP is pretty cool for 13/89s, but on reflection, if I knew Cisco was such an unstable company, I'd not had invested in the DCP program as now all my DCP is paid in one big chunk in one year instead of spread over several years as I had planned.  Live and learn :)
Cons:
Cisco's definition of culture in my brief 4-year stint was "everything is about money".   That is good and bad - good because you can make some serious dough here, bad because there is no sense of community in the workforce.

Cisco has limited restructurings in spring and fall.  The lifers refer to avoiding a layoff as "being safe" which is in my mind an oxymoron.  There is no such thing as safety at Cisco.  If you come here, be prepared to move on when you hit the wrong set of cost lists.  High performance is no guarantee of "safety" either; I earned 1.3x-1.5x multipliers on my bonuses every year for 4 years - still impacted by an LR.  Most restructuring affects older (highly compensated) workers.  There is no other logical conclusion to the restructurings than they are meant to cut already well-trained long-term growth employees and replace them with a younger untrained workforce.  These LRs create intense stop energy in the company nearly all the time as everyone is in a state of panic.  This "Fog of War" is difficult for innovators to execute in making Cisco pivot like an Exxon Valdez rather than an Eagle.

Cisco completely doesn't understand open source and evidenced by the latest round of LRs in 2018 that impacted nearly every engineer doing any sort of open source work.  The engineering workforce is far too compliant resulting in high degrees of passive-aggressive behavior rather than assertiveness.

Pros:
Cisco Sales Associate Program is a great chance for new graduates/young professionals to start strong career path. I was a part of it as a Sales Representative. During the year Cisco was massively investing in my learning and development, both sales and technical. We had professionals and coaches working with us from all over the world, best in class. The most important thing is to stay active and absorb this year as much as possible.
Moreover I was having several mentors from my country and from the hub, whom I could always ask for help and additional explanations.
Not to forget one of the most fun part of the year - is that I met a lot of knew people with whom we spent most of the time traveling, hanging out. Some of those people became very good friends of mine.
Cons: Moving to another country or even continent for the whole year was difficult for someone. But it truly depends on the person and his/her attitude.

Pros:
The environment and people in the office are very friendly, always trying to help you, and because most of them are very knowledgeable technically, you have a lot to learn from your peers. 
You have a loooot of resources to learn from. The company is giving you few free paid weeks to learn for CCIE exam, and if you pass it, you get a bonus.
Cons:
The job is very stressful, and the amount of work is tremendous. You can literally work 24/7 and you will still not finish the work. 
The salary is not the best on the market. Salary increase is done based on performance, but cannot keep up with the market. The only way you might be able to get a decent salary increase, is to tell your manager you are leaving, and at that moment is anyway too late.
Career growth is also latent. If you want to get a promotion, you need basically to work 2-3-4 years at the next level, and MAYBE you will get promoted.

Pros: The company culture is good and the Exec/Board always try to do the right think for society. Under the CEO the company is successfully transitioning to a new recurring revenue model, and while there are areas of the business like WebEX that have lost the race (with Zoom in this case), Meraki and others are driving the next phase for the company.
Cons: Within the Corporate Real Estate Team there are zero career prospects for males. Females are employed or promoted with little or no experience in corporate real estate, especially within the leadership team. Many males are dissatisfied or even leaving the company for this reason.

Pros: There are so many opportunities for learning and advancement within Cicso. It's a fantastic place to continue to hone your technical skills, and what better place to do it then at the company that made the router ubiquitous. Some may say that Cisco has become slow or unresponsive as it's gotten bigger, but I never worked in a company with so many people willing to go above and beyond for you and/or the customer. You won't get as many stock options as you would at a start-up, but Cisco stock is actually worth money.
Cons: It really depends on what your position is in Cisco. In pre-sales where I am, the main downside is the difficulty of getting features that I need inserted into the code so my customer will buy Cisco. Other then that, there really aren't any downsides as long as you work hard.

Pros: I have worked for several companies now and Cisco truly is a nice company to work for.  The benefits are good, the free soda is great
Cons: Opportunities for career advancement are far too limited.  I have been with the company for going on 8 years and have had one raise.  I see tons of people with the title "Technical Leader" with a BIG fat paycheck that got where they are as a result of joining Cisco in the growth days.  While there is nothing wrong with rolling the dice with a company and growing with them, problems arise when the growth ceases.  It is irritating to see, as the years go on, to see my contributions exceeding those of many of the 'Technical Leaders' yet I know it is hopeless to ever advance to that level in this company.

Pros:
Cisco ,the old brand name adds some value to job profile.
Learn new technologies by chance of any new acquisitions since most new technologies and good selling prodcuts are acquired by cisco.
Learn how to make things more complex.
Having fun around compromising your work experience
Cons:
Ridiculous manangement that  have a philososphy of  working to add an entry  in performance review  and not for the necessity.
All happens in the name of process and no wonder if it doesnt happen at all :-D
You can think about promotions in dream,oppurtunities in words.
Full politics and no recognition for deserving candidates.
Almost worst outsourced services like HR ,Work place resources, etc  for employees.
All happens in the name of process and no wonder if it doesnt happen at all :-D
To say it simple,you can be  recognised as a fool if you stay long.
If more than that if you wish to take a chance then its your fate!

Pros: Great technology, excellent business models, diversified products and geographies, huge profit margins, customers love us, really smart people work here, thought leaders everywhere...
Cons: totaly lost site of the value of our employees, pitiful planning when it comes to compensation and employee rewards. year after year the company leaders have chosen to grow the employee base (hire) and not give regular increases to employees. some employees got 2% (!) increases this year - what an insult. little to no promo opportunities....slow decision making, bureaucracy and politics are, sadly, here to stay. senior leadership dead set on this "collaboration", but no one else bough into it - it's become an inside joke / wink-wink.

Pros:
advanced services is an amazing organization.  lots of skill and great opportunity.  encouraging management and good direction.  low overhead.
overall, cisco encourages public transport, vacation, live/work separation, good work ethic.
outside the US, things are much more fun, competitive, and rewarding overall.
Cons:
cisco can be too big, bloated processes, large middle management and people barrier between meaningful accomplishments and progress.  
management is not very strong or supportive across the board.  recognition is often next to nothing. namely/especially within technical/customer support.
high-level and older techs can be very rigid in their opinions and steam roll others, especially customers surprising.  men...
HR and workplace management are really cutting costs and getting rid of employee perks.  coffee and building quality are awful in US, however things like that are amazing in australia, for instance.
product development and management teams are not very equivalent either.  some just plain suck.
company lost focus and direction with consumer and non-networking related products/services.  they are starting to get back on track though.

Pros:
- Flexible work hours and work from home as needed
- Great work environment (facilities & equipment)
- Great benefits & pay
Cons:
- Perks were cut back in 2008/2009
- Politics.  Poor managers can succeed by managing upwards and making life miserable for the people under them.
- Performance reviews:  Team members are ranked, so even a team with all good staff someone gets a poor review and no bonus.

Pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Cisco are the respect and opportunities available. I've worked with some of the most inspiring people ever at this company. They make me want to work harder. Also, the work we do is very interesting and I rarely encounter anything dull or boring.
Cons:
While not many, there are a few downsides to working here. The facilities are a bit sad, despite the facility workers being great people. You can tell this used to be a really happening place and people would really enjoy the environment, however with cost cutting we don't even have a cafeteria anymore, which is a big loss for me.

Also, sometimes you do encounter people that make you wonder how they got this job. Some of the interviewing seems inconsistent and you encounter people who take much more than they contribute. Luckily this doesn't happen very often.

Pros:
800 pound gorilla in the networking industry.
Involved in almost every aspect of communications.
Opportunities to be involved in full product development life cycle involving almost any imaginable communications technology.
Top performers compensated well above normal market rates.
Cons:
Hasn't had competent top level engineering management since 2007.
Complete chaos in engineering across all product lines.
Fierce internal executive rivalries and frequent engineering executive shuffling make it very difficult to successfully complement projects.
Company completes only a small number of the numerous of engineering projects it starts.
Business units are littered with un-dead zombie projects that have undergone multiple direction changes and leadership changes.
Cisco's new product development life cycle now generally exceeds technology life cycles.  It takes so long to develop products that the product technology is obsolete when the product ships.
Everything aspect of engineering possible is being out-sourced without out regard to the impact on quality, efficiency, and ROI.
Cisco treats its engineers like farm animals.

Pros: Cisco has the resources, tools, assets, people, and money to take on any topic and lead it with ease.  However, you are letting the good people go who can help build a cohesive organization aligned with outcomes and results.
Cons: Plays other peoples games versus their own.  Focus on playing others games like SDN versus coming into the games with all of the significant Cisco solution and capabilities and eliminating SDN relevancy.     Has the resources and people to focus on significant development of new solutions.  yet failed to make the investments to achieve dominance in areas like SDN.

Pros: Good company with solid benefits and great ability to work at home or at the office.  They strive for flexibility and provide the tools to make it happen.
Cons: Company is going through a lot of realignment and change and is choosing to accomplish this through consistent layoffs each August after the fiscal year closes.  Instead of retraining they fire and bring in new younger blood.  The lament that not enough people leave the company each year as their attrition rate is 3% and John Chambers would like to see it at 10%.  They lose a lot of good people with this approach.

Pros: Most employees have the ability to work from home. I personally work from home about 3 days per week. As long as I get my work done, my manager doesn't pressure me. The compensation isn't as high as some of the hotter tech companies in the bay area but you're definitely comfortable (assuming you don't buy a home out here). I constantly have opportunities for learning and self-growth. I also enjoy the ability to switch roles/teams should I want to in the future. At such a large company, moving around/getting promoted is easier because there are usually positions available.
Cons: Cisco could push its employees to work harder. The working environment is almost too relaxed at times. Sometimes upper management can be slow to come up with ideas on their own.

Pros:
1. Good and big campus
2. Better facilities like Gym, Quite rooms, Open area seatings, Cafe, Massage chairs etc
3. Flexible work timings
Cons:
My review is specific to Service Provider BU, Bangalore, India

1. Top to bottom approach. The engineers are not given much attention and importance. The deadlines are decided from the top and just informed to the engineers.
2. There is no teamwork. All are individual contributors and hence there is no bonding within the team. 
3. Managers are there only to convince you and not to understand your needs.
4. Most of the good work (infact the development work) is done at US. Only sustenance work is done here. The management will give lame excuses if we ask for it
5. The managers wont trust you and the senior team members too.
6. There are no fun activities.
7. They dont value the people. Not even as a resource. They are used and thrown out.

Pros: (bangalore site) if your dream in life is to play politics, do less work, report to managers who have never coded any feature and just count bugs, learn nothing new, get 5% hike in 18 months, avail unlimited WFH to run some side business, work on twenty years old dead codebases in sustaining mode and want  a 11am-4pm workday, this is the perfect job.
Cons:
(bangalore site)
- almost no internal investment in new products, they keep buying software companies hoping to "transform" from a hardware centric box company
- tons and tons of buggy twenty year old codebases that none can maintain properly now because the original architects are retired, or maybe passed away by now
- demoralized engineering ranks , no learning, no career progression
- lot of nepotism by managers and directors , no fair treatment for those not playing politics to showcase themselves falsely
- the 360' review system has been scrapped since 2014. a opaque gestapo panel of managers now gossips about you to give a fake rating.

Pros:
- very good salary and bonus package
- a lot of soft skills trainings
- good management
- handling the Covid situation very good
- modern offices in Krakow
Cons:
- the ways to develop from my position are very limited
- different parts of the company treat them selves as competitors which impacts the cooperation in a bad way, specially when you have to work with Cisco's contractors.
- lack of product trainings and a clear development path way. And if it is there, it is very good hidden in a very complicated development process. 
- changes are very important, but not if they are a goal of itself. The process changes in Cisco are ridiculous. Every quarter you have something new: a new tool a new process added on top of your responsibilities which only causes confusion and frustration.

Pros:
Ability to learn and grow. Compensation is very good with a combination of base salary and commission. There is a great opportunity to get stock options too.
There is a tremendous amount of web based internal training in every technology.
Also, Cisco has a saying "East your own dog food" meaning they provide you with the tools like cell phone, VPN access from home including a router, Cisco IP phone and video camera.
Cons:
Crazy work schedule. Lots of pressure to perform, sell and drive revenue. Also there is a lot of pressure to do a lot of not core job work like business development, presentations to inernal teams, lots of reports and systems to keep updateded with forecasting, ect...
There is a lack of coordination between hardware sales and services sales.
Often, there is limited time to respond to custmer request albeit SOWs, RFP...

Pros: A great name on you're resume, PTO per year is generous. I kick ass at vlookups now.
Cons: The internal tools dont work well and the process' to get stuff done are long winded and broken. We spend more time fixing errors and wading through BS because things dont work as advertised then actually doing the job itself.  If you spend more time in the beginning doing it right, the whole process gets better, faster, leaner etc... My job could be done with one eye open if tools worked as they should and communication was better.

Pros: So many reasons. Very innovative and expanding into new technologies. Strong focus on collaboration and also making a difference in the world. The culture for the most part reflects this collaborative style but differs a little from group to group. The Executives communicate what is going on within the organization. No layoffs even in a tough economy! Company is very open to people rotating between functional areas and business units although it is on the onus of the individual employee to network and reach out for that next opportunity. Less Bureacracy than I think most other large organizations. Free soda!
Cons: Well, it is a large company so therefore there is some bureacracy. It sometimes takes some time to make decisions in order to go through proper channels. We were forced to take 4 vacation days for the week after Christmas this year whether we wanted to or not (or had work to do or not). However, still no layoffs!

Pros: Good compensation (both salary and benefits), exposure to new technologies (everything continuously changes) opportunity to move to different roles (given the breadth of products and number of organizations, there are continuous opportunities for change).  Depending on your manager - and out of 7 managers, I've only had 1 bad manager - you are given a goal and allowed to achieve that goal.
Cons: It has become a big company with a lot of overhead and process.  Some process is good, but as it grows and evolves the process gets in the way of getting the job done.  At corporate there is too much politics.  When I started at Cisco, there was a feeling we were a conglomerate of start-ups.  That feeling is gone.  I've only had one manager who severely over committed the available resources making my life miserable.

Pros: challenging work, get to interact with international teams, good benefits,  many opportunities to move around and try new things, managers happy to work with you on career development if you start the conversation, smart people - I'm always learning something new, bleeding edge technology, good use of technology as standard tools at work.
Cons: long hours, hard to have work-life balance unless YOU make it a priority and set boundaries.  working with international teams is interesting and fun, but sometimes taking conference calls at 10pm is not.  salary could be better - have heard that internal equity within teams can be an issue.

Pros:
- Supportive of career advancement. Allow and encourage employees to learn about new technologies, attend conferences.
- Depending on the group you will have an opportunity to work with some of the experts in the industry.
- Good benefits/Bonuses/RSUs.
- Free Shuttle services to Caltrain/Bart Stations, San Francisco, Fremont.
- Overall the work culture and environment is nice, some groups may have shorter release cycles than others, which means faster pace. 
- Encourage work from home.
- Lots of internal tools for day to day activities that includes IT support and others.
Cons:
- You may notice some political issues in bigger groups.
- Newer projects will have too many deviations  and lack of focus by management sometimes.
- If there is a cutting edge new project, there are some senior people who would want to associate with it just to get some visibility. 
- Reorgs are frequent.
- Some groups can be resistant in using the latest cutting edge technologies.
- Cross team collaboration is often political and unpleasant.

Pros: It's great to work for a company that is #1 or close to number in so many technologies.  I'm proud to work at  Cisco, and would (and have) recommended Cisco to friends an family.
Cons: A lot of process which is required at times but not always.  Cisco is a very slow moving machine.  Employees that are not in San Jose (the mothership) often feel disconnected from the company and feel they have limited opportunity.  There is no reward that I've seen for innovation beyond what is required in your job.

Pros: Has to be the ability to work from home, and just get on with the work.
Cons:
- Sales culture: sales is very powerful and gets its way a lot of the time. As a result you're prevented from doing your job properly. For example, project managers can't exercise change control, because it'll upset the customer, and therefore potential future sales!

- pay: if you're a worker you don't get pay increases or promotions. It's the managers who get the promotions.

- job security: routers and switches had their heyday in the 90s, so now Cisco has to reduce its cost base, which means layoffs.

- Poor management: most managers are routing and switch guys, so that's the work they go after. They can't do the managed services like Ericsson, Nokia and IBM, etc. Net result is the type of projects are poor.

Pros:
As a Product manager you truly get great empowerment to explore and execure new business initiatives. In terms of company culture Cisco truly provides fantastic flexibility to the new age professional to work-from-anywhere, balance personal-work priorities. 
Cisco also has some of the brightest talent in the industry giving you the ability to take on complex technical challenges for the customer.

Cisco teaches you to be customer focused at the expense of everything else.
Cons: Company works in multiple silos, so if you are stuck in a business group which is not doing well, you will be affected in all ways - salary, promotion, hikes etc ... So it is important to be in a growth segment of the company.

Pros: Reasonably good to work at if you have other responsibilities (like a family). Reasonably diverse (at least as compared to other SV companies), but still a long way to go, particularly with respect to women in senior management, Hispanics and African Americans.
Cons: Offshoring and shrinking like crazy at every opportunity. Terrible hiring practices ensures mediocre talent pool - stunningly poor in some cases. Substitutes "going through the motions" for "getting results" as primary goals - lots of meetings, emails, powerpoints, committees and so on. Hero worship at all levels of the org ensures groupthink prevails (which could be a positive if they had any heroes worth listening too, which they don't).

Pros:
Great people across the company. Chuck Robbins is a breath of fresh air.

Dominant industry presence, but customers either love Cisco or hate them...not much in between. 

Great package of benefits.
Cons:
Being remote from SJC or RTP can make you invisible. Compensation growth is very limited. 

Sales reporting sucks, making commissions tracking very difficult, and if there's a mistake, good luck getting it corrected. When 'unknown' is the top selling partner in a region, you tend to question all the reporting. 

Politics, politics, politics! If you aren't a suck-up, you'll never advance. 

Intense focus on hitting Wall Street expectations for EPS has led to ridiculous T&E budgets. No way to do your job if you are grounded from being front of customers or partners.

Pros: Great company to work at a fast pace, learn from a top-notch team of seasoned professionals in many diverse areas (business, technology, etc), get to know a lot of different companies and industries, network inside and outside and being at the bleeding edge of technology. Cisco really cares about its employees and does not save efforts to make people learn and apply the acquired knowledge to their everyday duties. The company takes very seriously the work and life balance, allowing its employees to work remotely and with flexible hours.
Cons: Pace can be a bit stressful if you´re not used to work under pressure. Change can be a bit slow. Old ways take time to evolve and adapt to the current business and industry needs.

Pros: I love selling Cisco's technology.  I am always learning something new. It's fast paced, exciting, and I love my customers.  I am part of Conexion, Cisco's Latinx Employee Resource Organization (ERO) and I  appreciate that Cisco has so many ERO's to chose from. Incredible benefits.  Flexible schedules.  Feel like I can make a difference. Very ethical company.  #Love where youwork
Cons: If you aren't colocated in the same city as a business unit, there's less opportunities for upward movement. Cisco should also query the sales team more regarding ideas for solutions for our clients. Also market more to potential employees.  We are an incredible company, stop making such a secret.

Pros: You Can "Follow Your Nose" at Cisco, and find an area of interest that fits what you want to do.  AS a broad based technology company, you can migrate to an area where you are passionate, and make significant contributions to industry direction.
Cons:
You can work as much as you want.  As a remote employee, I work more hours now than I ever did at any previous job.  

The office politics have seemed to increase over the last few years, and this is a barrier to the creative and innovative spirit of many Cisco employees.

Pros:
- If you are lucky, will get a industry leading feature/product development work
- Flexible work. Your manager will not ask your day to day or even weekly progress. Its up to you how to manage time. You just need to meet the final time lines
Cons:
- Though it is an MNC, HR Resourcing work is outsourced to local HR companies. They try every trick to take you with less pay.
- Fixes the grade and pay based on the present pay. So, if you were working in a same company for say 10 years, you will stand loose here. Job hoppers salary would be more at this point and seems  Cisco welcomes them with good pay :(

Pros: I joined Cisco on a two week contract, and 8 years later am still a happy employee. I advanced my career at Cisco by moving to more senior positions and eventually management. Cisco sponsored me to obtain my MBA. The compensation and benefits package is generous.  I have learned a lot and appreciate the opportunities afforded me to develop myself and contribute in new ways.
Cons: As a large company, it can sometimes feel hard to get things done, but there is a focus to change that in the last 6-12 months and into the future.  At senior levels, there isn't a lot of room for advancement, and moving between teams, although encourage and even expected, seems to rest solely on the individual.  Lastly, yearly reorganizations seem to waste time and resources, will yearly layoffs drag on the culture.

Pros: Great company with a lot of name recognition with customers. Incredible people in parts of the company. Great compensation, benefits and flexibility. Had a great time in the departments prior to my last. Not sure if the people or Cisco changes but they've lost site of the people side of the culture.
Cons: Very political. Advancement and recognition became more about playing games and saying the right things rather than performance. They've missed several product cycles in their datacenter products and are beginning to lean heavily on reputation and fear, uncertainty, doubt instead of strong technology conversations. They have reached an over-saturation of product offerings and they aren't able to discuss in valuable detail the value of any one solution.

Pros: Well established company to work for, a good place to professorially grow and work toward cisco certifications if anyone is interested to do CCIE/CCAr. Lots of internal opportunities in different area of interests. supportive toward your professional and personal goals. people are treated with respect and dignity.
Cons: Periodical frequent changes without understanding the direction toward company's vision, exploring, elaborating and most importantly communicating that vision to stake holders and valuable employees.

Pros:
1. Remote work is the norm 
2. Even contractors are empowered to make big decisions
Cons:
1. Unannounced layoffs are the new normal at Cisco ... literally every month there are big layoffs 
2. a large number of jobs at Cisco are going off-shore so be prepared to repeatedly prove that your skills cannot be outsourced without a serious loss to the product/team/bottom line
3. highly political organization & lots of disinformation ... assume you really do NOTknow what is going on even if you are being given information 
4. contractors are treated very poorly, even if they provide a big value add to the organization 
5. Cisco is in crisis ... there are re-orgs with alarmingly high frequency; this is to be expected with the massive changes brought in by Chuck.

Pros: Despite working in a city of more conservative views, which I do not share, Cisco allows me to work in a very equal environment. I do not feel I have same right and my opinions and expertise has equal weight to those of my male colleagues. I feel I can further my career in a same way as my colleagues. flexibility and availability to work from home allows for more balanced work-life schedule and even though I work many hours I do enjoy it and I feel this is m,y choice and not something that has been impose on me. Cisco also encourages women to take technical and managerial positions and we are being rewarded for it.
Cons: So far I have not found any.

Pros: Cisco truly embraces a diverse workforce in terms of gender, ethnicity, generation, experience, and more.  As a female senior leader, I can look around and see plenty of people who look like me and plenty who don't, all working collaboratively and with great respect and trust.  At Cisco, everyone has a voice and we look out for each other.
Cons: Cisco is a large and rapidly growing company and like all large corporations, you have to have a strong network to be the most effective.  That can take time to build but once you make a few connections, it expands rapidly.

Pros:
Generally being a TAC engineer is pretty flexible. You work 9 to 5. If a customer needs anything outside those hours you can have another engineer on shift handle the customer's needs.
You get access to a lab with all the newest equipment to test on.
If you need to make a little more money, you can work weekend shifts.
A lot of managers offer flexibility with the ability to work remotely once a week, however this position is not a remote job.
The organization does their best to recognize hard working individuals
Cons:
Low pay compared with other customer facing roles at Cisco
High Stress - the account teams and customers expect you to be the one with the answers
You can get pigeon holed into one particular technology, especially if your technology is not 'hot'
Have to work weekends

Pros:
- Good career opportunities
- Work/Life balance is okay
- Good for new joiners and college freshers
- Learning is good
Cons:
- Very bad compensation for existing employee 
- Once you are in, you will take years to grow in terms of salary (Senior management takes all the budget for them)
- After 2 years if you are lucky, you may get 2 to 8% hike. Next hike will come again after 2 years and that too will be the same percentage. 
- New joiners (or even college freshers) will get almost 50% to 60% higher salary than 6 to 7 years experienced person who is performing well and getting good appreciation. 
- HR making so many rules for compensation or salary normalization but there will be always no budget to implement it.

Pros:
Although a  massive company with lots of moving parts, I've had opportunities and experiences that I can't imagine having at too many other companies between global travel, leading cutting edge initiatives, and paving the way for business that has never been done before because Cisco invented it.   

Futhermore, I love the culture.  It supports people first rather than the job role.  Cisco has a "people deal" that puts that culture into policy.  I've always had management that has supported my individual growth and cared for me as a person more than what I produce.  I appreciate that.
Cons:
It is a big machine, so as agile as Cisco tries to be, it just isn't possible in a company this size with more than 60k employees.   

Promotion is hard to come by without jumping to another role one grade level up.  That said, there are tons of opportunities to move roles... even change careers within Cisco.

Pros: My input is valued by my peers and my manager. I get challenged to stretch myself and grow daily. It is a true global company. Cisco is a global company and has tremendous resources. I am part of Conexión, Cisco's Hispanic/Latino ERO, We help Cisco to hire and retain the best Latino talent as well as helping the Latino Community at Cisco and in our neighborhoods.  I also love the fact that I have a great work-family integration and balance. I use Cisco collaboration tools to execute my role from piratically anywhere.
Cons: Change is always good but it seems like we are always changing at Cisco. Organizational changes happen almost yearly. We are going through a cultural change at Cisco and at times one can sense the "political" games happening behind the scenes.

Pros: In professional IT, there are very few companies who will see you worked at Cisco and wouldn't pay attention to it.  A steady company with well-defined processes, with a clear vision and huge impact on the world. In sales or BU you will see clear results of what you are doing on the market. There is a sense of satisfaction when you enter your bank branch or hospital or hotel or stadium and see Cisco phone on the table or AP on the ceiling :) Corporate events are fun and frequent. Great collaboration products let you connect and stay in touch with your remote team around the globe and have a quite dynamic balance of where you work from: home, office or on the go.
Cons: In transformation and future few years will define if the company will exist on the market or not. The road can be bumpy.

Pros:
Cisco is big on diversity. As they hire, they focus on bringing in diverse candidate pools, and 

Occasionally they will give "Day for Me" which is a free day off for the entire company.
Cons:
VERY long hours. Expect to start work early, and be forced to work late with offshore teams. This isn't a once in a while thing, but has become expected with everyone working remotely.

Culture has taken a VERY negative downturn in the past 3 months. Lots of new management changes that highlight how little they care about their employees. There is no support for others. Everything is through the lens of how "I" look to my leaders. 

I would not recommend anyone become a people manager. This role comes with all the blame and none of the reward. You will be expected to constantly push your team for results, work harder with fewer resources, and try to keep spirits up in a team that isn't rewarded for their work.

Pros:
-Flexible Work Schedule 
-Good , well-rounded benefits package
-Smart People with a lot of support
-Results-focused culture
-Financial stability of company
Cons:
-Avg promotion time is 6-7 yrs  - to get a promotion you need to pound on your chest and perhaps step over others
-Long hours are expected - you have a flexible work schedule but expected to work all the time
-No more stock options or RSU's
-Moving jobs to low cost regions of the world
-New leaders coming into the company are disconnected from the employee base - new leaders just hire "Their guy", and start all over
-In just the past year: Finance layoff, forced rotations, No more free soda's, No more paying for cell phone and home internet, and movement of finance jobs outside of US or to lower cost non-SJ locations - what's next?

Pros: Great company, if you have passion for technology, this is the place to wok. Lot of teams work in startup mode . Internal job changes lot easier compared to other companies that allows you to work on the latest products . Very flexible work culture, lot of tools available to help you to work remote. Absolutely no expectation from the management to be at office unless you manage a team. IC roles are give full freedom and empowerment to reach out sr execs to share your concerns or ideas.
Cons: Internal politics, this could be team specific. Salaries are not great, correction doesn't happen frequently. At a times your base for that grade will be less than the median base of your previous grade. Nobody cares to look at it or correct until you put your papers or tell them you are going out of the team

Pros: Your experience will vary significantly based on which department you work in. For most supply chain management roles, the work & life balance is exceptional and hard to give up.
Cons: The downside is that although the company's goal is to be the number one IT company in the world, there is little to none creativity encouraged, your coworkers will have been in their same role for 15+ years, and your day to day activities will not be challenging/ exciting/ motivating. I found it hard to stay fulfilled at Cisco. But depending on what you are trying to get out of your career, this might as well be listed as a pro.

Pros:
Great perks
Above average compensation
Work from home (WFH)
Good technical exposure
Cons:
The work gets hectic sometimes. Most of the time you will end up working 10-12 hours a day.Your life becomes Cisco if are not careful.

Slow growth specially when you join in grade 8.This is crowded grade and you will have to wait till eternity to get promoted.

Yes sir culture. If you challenge the decision of your manager, you are screwed and your growth will be hampered.

Overall perks used be great but not anymore. They are taking way benefits one by one. May be in future it will not have as many perks as used to be.

Pros: Competitive salary. The business is large enough that if you look long enough, you'll find a group you're going to be really happy with -- provided a random re-org doesn't throw you into a new position or new group.
Cons: The management team is comprised of intelligent individuals who are incompetent in a group of three or more but believe themselves to be the most effective management team in the history of the planet. Nothing will make you want to vomit more than self-important managers celebrating themselves at all hands meetings, where they think they are celebrities and operate under the delusion that the majority of audience respects them.

Pros:
Good Technology.

Loads to learn.

Challenging work.

Good natured helping folks.

Constant focus on latest technology.

Very well developed eco-system of end-to-end product design.

Strong focus on product quality.

Good Yearly performance bonus.
Cons:
No Work life balance.

No correlation between performance and promotion.

No correlation between performance and salary hikes.

Overall, very very slow growth in Org.

Strong focus on SW than HW.

HW Team is overworked and underpaid.

Loads of senior guys in every team and thus too much of politics, ego, mutual distrust and competition.

Poor Project Managers and no preemptive project management in Program.

Managers are not involved in technical management and yet have more importance in HW Team in giving technical sign-offs

Management is promoted in proper time and not the HW Engg.

Management is given most importance than Engg.

Pros: International environment, lot of project where to gain experience, nice benefits and nice people.
Cons: Workload became insane. Somebody already wrote, but since you can get reply 24/7 there is the unwritten expectation to be connected and almost reactive. Overtime is paid, but nobody asks you if you are AVAILABLE to do it. It's just (unwritten) expected, because otherwise it would be considered as business delivery not completed. Doesn't matter if the business delivery is a job for 2 or 3 people. If you are not careful, you might end in a sort of hell where your life is 100% connected with your work. This causes burnout. Another problem is that workers get promoted only when there is no other option and are basically always 1 grade below where you should be. Causing frustration as consequence

Pros: If you are looking for a stable, comfortable job that offers an excellent work/life balance, then you should strongly consider working at Ciso.  The benefits are also excellent.  It's a great place to work at while you focus on raising your family or completing an advanced degree.
Cons: You may get bored with the repetitive, highly specialized tasks and start to feel like a cog in a wheel over time.  You will definitely not be paid as much as peers at other companies...there is a cost to all those wonderful benefits.  At the middle management level, there are lots of office politics that can really be a drag to endure. The pace of change is also ridiculously slow.

Pros: Motivated work force, great compensation, strong tools and support to get your job done.   Some of the sharpest folks I've worked with.  Strong customer focus and senior management that does a great job of anticipating market and technology changes all while driving that same market.   Fantastic front line sales engineering staff.   Very good compensation against it's competitors.
Cons:
24x7 work culture and competitive work environment.   Huge product set to keep track of.  Great team environment but with the combination of ambitious lower/mid level management that can take a toll on front line sales teams.   Expectation of double-digit growth levels despite market conditions, product weaknesses, etc.  

Also...Sales Manager's needing to show 'effort' can mean unnecessary busy work on campaigns that realistically have a slim chance to work.  Sales managers have a very stressful job at Cisco

Pros:
-Good pay as a contractor
-If you have a good manager, potential to work on various types of projects
Cons:
-No recognition from the company, you will be considered a second class citizen
-Readily expendable - there are no longer term commitments.  They will only renew your contract one quarter at a time.  Contract extension doesn't matter though.  They will let you do anytime they need to.
-Self preservation is the top priority here.  People only care about protecting their jobs and getting themselves recognized.
-The cross functional dependencies make it very difficult to get anything done quickly.  There are processes on top of processes and then some more processes on how to manage those processes.  It's not easy...

Pros: There are lots of opportunities within the company so you aren't necessarily stuck in one position. Very open culture that allows any employee to approach senior level management easily. And flexible work environments allows many employees to work from home on a regular basis.
Cons: Management is not very good at planning projects and there seems to be a shortage of resources in spite of the large number of employees. In many cases, engineers become managers without learning without improving their people skills. Compensation and rewards are not the best for employees that stay at the company. It seems like the best way to grow your salary is to leave.

Pros: Telecommuting, training and educational opportunities, benefits
Cons: Excessive management, horrible stack rating - meaning you don't get raises or promotions unless you are someone's favorite in upper management, excessive work hours and work load, praise on how well you play the system instead of how good your work is. Politics in this company get worse with each layer of management. No one wants to hear that something won't work even when it won't, they just want to hear you say yes as they take credit for your work. Too many contract workers that have worked in the same position for 5+ years. Positions are made for friends without posting requisitions. It's not what you know, but who you know.

Pros: There is a great deal of autonomy and ability to work virtually.  There is a fair amount of investing in employees trying to create an environment where one is encouraged and continues learning.
Cons:
Highly charge political environment with too many layers of unnecessary management that adds little value. This in turn creates additional conference calls to help these lower level managers feel important and empowered.  

While the company touts being transparent with employees, they have a long way to go in departments that should be leading by example first and foremost.

Promotions in many cases are less the result of performance and leadership and more often a result of the internal office politics.

Pros: Great people and great technologies with lots of energetic team oriented selling.  Lots of great solutions to work with to solve many customer problems, especially over a long term relationship.
Cons: Sales is always full of pressure but there was far too much emphasis on getting the dollars now vs. building a long term relationship with the customers.  You don't call the customer every three hours on month end or quarter end day asking where my PO is?  After a while, customers knew that Cisco only cared about their pockets and only as long as the customer had money to spend.

Pros:
-Everyone is very helpful, especially to new employees
-Generally surrounded by positive, intelligent people
-Great  benefits and pay
-Work/Life balance
-Flexibility with working hours and ability to work from home
-Gym and health center onsite
Cons:
-Similar to other corporations for business roles, there is no "set path" for you to take. No promotions or raises scheduled. However this is also a positive. You are totally in charge of your own career. This is great for self-starters who are willing to be proactive and take control of their career, but if you are wanting to do the bare minimum and become promoted due to tenure, this isn't the place for you.

-Sometimes the first few months of a new role can be slow moving

Pros: Everyone at Cisco is hardworking and extremely loyal to the company and it's success.  The salaries and benefits are excellent that the company as a whole is world class.
Cons: Business has always been based on numbers and revenue; however since the new regime has taken over, there seems to be an increased focus on numbers and much less focus on the people who have helped create the company.  The sense of loyalty that the employee feels towards the employer does not seem to be reciprocated.  Senior Executives, seem to be further disconnected to  staff.  There is an undercurrent of insecurity, no one knows when they will be next on the layoff list.  The warmth and family feeling is long gone, clearly it can't be sustained forever, but outside of a few groups the company is being run by accountants.  Each organization is fighting for it's overhead and there is no feeling of we are One Company.

Pros: Cisco is very well respected brand in the IT industry.  Not only do you get to work alongside great minds and industry thought leaders.  You get to do it in the service of  public and private organizations.  We get to be on the very leading edge, helping organizations of all kinds  reimagine and reinvent themselves employing digital technology to adopt new business and operational  models.  Cisco will give you the training and experiences that will give you multidimensional career growth while at the same time encouraging balance with your personal life.
Cons: Prepare to be disrupted.  Cisco is a company built on employing disruptive technology to help organizations reinvent themselves.  The culture here at Cisco is to disrupt and reinvent ourselves; both as an organization and as individuals.   If you are not comfortable working outside your comfort zone, Cisco may not be the place for you.

Pros: Flexibility: there is no strict starting hour, with exception to those working on duty; benefits: huge selection of different benefits like medical care, health insurance, food cards, petrol cards; possibility to do extra curriculum activities: if you want to be involved in women initiatives, lgbta, helping shelters etc, you have possibility to do that here; remote work with basically no restrictions; modern office; trainings: variety of trainings available.
Cons: Salary: you get what you negotiated at the beginning and you will have it for long time, there are no overall pay-rises. Global teams: there is a possibility that you will have your whole team based in a different country, which can also mean late calls,

Pros:
Been at Cisco for 5 months and it's been great. The onboarding orientation I went through really helped to showcase all the amazing benefits of the company. Cisco is so large and finding things is never easy but they try to minimize the difficulties.

Team is amazing. We're allowed to work from home. There is an amazing culture of trust so long as work gets done. I'm sure this is a team by team basis.

Company doesn't try too hard to be 'cool' They recognize that they're competing against the big name consumer brands and try to differentiate by being themselves. And that's a wonderful thing.
Cons:
Too many systems and tools can get confusing. Since I've been here, we've switched between two intranets and two messaging systems. There are constant updates to Cisco owned software and it can be a bit frustrating.

In all, these are cons but they are cons that every company goes through. Cisco in my opinion, does it best.

Pros: Cisco has tremendous resources as a global company. Excellent work-life balance. Using collaboration tools, i am able to work from anywhere in the world to accomplish my role. I am also a member of Conexión, Cisco's Hispanic/Latino ERO. We help Cisco to hire and retain the best Latino talent as well as helping the Latino community at Cisco and our own neighborhoods.  I am challenged daily to grow and stretch myself. My manager and peers value my input.
Cons: Dealing with change in the corporate world is nothing new and Cisco is no exception. Some tough decisions have to be made in order to compete. With leadership and role changes being very fluid, you need to be aware and know how to cope with this.

Pros:
Cisco is a fast paced tech company that lets you work independently without micro management. If you have a good idea you are empowered to go with it. 

It’s also very international and you get to work with people from around the world which really makes working far more interesting. The people are great at Cisco for the most part and you have a lot of good energy. 

Benefits are excellent, and Cisco was doing remote/flexible working before COVID made it more popular so the setup is working very well.
Cons: Cisco can be too much US centric at times although they are a global company which is ok but it can wear on you.

Pros:
- Friendly environment 
- People help each other with knowledge, some great minds in the BU
- Lots of fun activities
- Chilled environment, no push for deadlines and easy work.
Cons:
- Favoritism in the group. People are given performance rating based on their relationship with manager, not on performance. 
- No acknowledgement for hardwork, no recognition. No Hikes, no timely Bonus and promotion. 
- lots of Politics in the group. You can survive only if your manager likes you. 
- No professional behavior in some team. People including manager dominate their language in the team and they like employees who speak their native language. Diversity in the group is not respected.
- They hire managers from service level company and they bring the atmosphere of a low grade service company. It doesnt feel like we are working for a product company. No innovation, no support for talent.

Pros: Stable job, especially if your grade is below a Director. Technology exposure is generally focused on networking - so if you don't have networking on resume then it is a great place.
Cons:
- Technology exposure is very uni-dimensional unless you are working in one of the emerging products
- Very little "real" work for Directors and above, it is mostly powerpoints, politics and posturing.
- Decision making is tied to hundreds of layers of management
- SVP and VP promos are random and makes you wonder if merit was any consideration

Pros:
- Good location (San Jose)
- Potential to work on some neat high-end and high-reliability systems (though you might just work on some lame internal tool that shouldn't exist in the first place)
- Good, cheap food at cafes
- Free coffee and soda (though I heard this changed?)
Cons:
- Company isn't very efficient. There seemed to be many groups working on the same exact thing. Or, there were groups working on some internal tool which really shouldn't exist since there was an existing solution (e.g., open source product).
- Many employees aren't very nice. The small things - not saying hi, for example - add up.
- Lots of needless bureaucracy. There are so many levels of managers and then so many different groups that change all the time.
- Over reliance on contractors.
- Not very diverse.. almost discriminatory in some ways: Everyone in CDO was so very similar.
- Not very innovative

Pros: People are acceptable new comer, so close communication with worldwide but be careful each country time zone. Employee could learn not only own job area but also worldwide culture. I'm in this company more than 12 yr,i happen to know that there are variety people,customer, that is most worth thing for me.  IT team offering great service with limited resources when you work everywhere every time every issues under simple contact.
Cons: Be aware, when you sleep, other country is morning. job does not stop. No managements care about. you can earn many but don't lost own health,family. Cisco was referenced company, has great empowerment. Today, political world, bunch of managers,VPs who are looking inner side.

Pros: A great place to start a career.  Strong learning, education environment for someone who is beginning in their career. Cisco is continuously trying to innovate and will let people / teams strike out to try something new.
Cons: As with any large company, Cisco is increasingly re-organizing and changing directions to try and re-capture the innovative, technological leadership position they once enjoyed. It has become a frustrating place to work, with many competing internal business objectives - product teams, services, and sales organizations are bloated, seeking new revenue and growth and the overlap is counterproductive.  Customers are left hanging with bad products, ever changing contacts as Cisco shuffles people, and ultimately a poor overall experience.

Pros: Executive Management is fantastic.  The people are awesome and the company cares about their customers and employees.  Excellent products with #1 or #2 Market Share and Gartner Quadrant.
Cons: Sales processes are debilitating.  Forecast touch points 3+ times a week and tracking every $5K deal feels very junior.  God forbid if one of your customers experience a major outage.  You won't be able to sell for a month while you take care of the situation.  Having no inside rep is very challenging.

Pros: Pay is on par with large companies. Office location is convenient. Benefits options allow flexibility on what to choose, but overall, you have to pay for everything, gym, childcare, onsite health care, etc.
Cons: Very conservative, old school way to run a company. Very political backstabbing environment. Limited growth potential.  Benefits sound good, but in reality are not all that great...rather disappointing in fact. The entirety of free food offered is Coffee, Tea, filtered tap water, and popcorn. Overall, I'm sorry I chose to come to Cisco.

Pros: Employees themselves work hard to do the right thing IN SPITE OF the lack of leadership at director and VP levels.
Cons: Regular layoffs specifically targeting over 50 long-term employees who's salaries are "high."   Pathetic senior management.  "People Deal" is truly a joke and incredibly disingenuous -- you'll get a free PTO day off on your birthday, but we'll stack rank you and NOT tell you how you fared or why or what your "rating" is.  Long-time employees (10 years+) laid-off with a moment's notice and a "generous" 3-month severance package.  3 months after 10+ years?  Targeting over 50 year old employees??  People Deal???   Staggeringly hypocritical management.

Pros:
Cisco is very good employer - great workplace, great team, great learning opportunities, great compensation packet.  One of the best employers I ever worked for.

My salary increased more than 2 times during 10 years.  I worked in customer support organization (Cisco TAC).  

Work options are flexible, it is possible to work from home when necessary.  Also there is some flexibility in choosing work locations (depends on position), or working from other company offices worldwide temporarily.

Medical benefits cover the whole family for full-time regular employees (but not for contractors).  Higher grades benefits also include either car allowance, or corporate car.  

Multi-national and multi-cultural environment at work.  All vacations and PTO are respected very carefully, people are not called on vacations.

In case of staff reduction, compensation packet (salary for a few month) is paid.
Cons:
Getting a promotion (grade increase) in Cisco is very difficult and very slow.  You need some outstanding achievements beyond your normal work responsibilities to get it.  I got mine after 4 years there.  Not many people got it event after many years of employment.

In customer support organization (TAC), you will have pretty narrow and specific area of expertise, knowing only the thing you support and nothing else.  This would cause real difficulties when you want move anywhere from the support (even within the company).  Narrow scope of expertise is not demanded in modern world, and you will need to take your own efforts to make it wider, if you want to get another job.

When Cisco thinks it needs staff reduction, it takes it easy.  If specific persons or team are no longer matching current business needs of the company, they are dismissed quickly.

Pros: Resources available to do great things. Breadth of technology solutions and constant evolution present great learning opportunities. Involved in many high growth areas including SDN, IoT, Cloud, virtualized data centre, SaaS, Paas etc. Money in the bank and depth of resources provide the basis for future success.
Cons: Constant org changes have shifted focus away from customer. Internal moral is challenged, and the Confidence/winning attitude of the past has been lost. New projects started and disbanded before they have a chance to be successful in the market, while other legacy programs and products are supported well past their best before date.
