Focus seems to be on short term financial performance at the expense of long term strategic positioning in key emerging technologies/markets.

Pros: Everyone in my area is very passionate about the product and I enjoy my immediate peers and folks I work with.  I am able to take pride in the immediate work I do. It is a good company starting out from college as they allow very gradual ramp-ups for their new hires.
Cons: The benefits are ok, but the pay is definitely no where near comparable to the rest of the Bay area. Cisco prides themselves on their work life balance, but since joining I've always had a minimum of 3 nights per week where I'm pulled into night meetings. The Upper management is horrible and doesn't seem to care about their employees at all - they all seem incredibly out of touch with everything.

Pros: Internal use of technology is to die for. 1, 2 or even more work from home days in not an issue. Company stands behind you in case of any kind of personal or family emergency.  Some really good talent in engineering and elsewhere. Switching job roles is relatively easy - a good way to get a well rounded experience.
Cons: Poor execution is a norm. Too much money is wasted on consultants as most employees just like to manage at higher level.  Mid level management is ineffective and 'siloed'. Big and small layoffs are a norm. I see a lot of seasoned talent leaving.

Pros: Tremendous work/life balance.  They truly care about you as an individual, want to help you to succeed and generally want you to be happy.  You can work your way up, if you play the corporate political game, however, there is a ceiling.
Cons:
Layoffs every year.  
Seems like the most expensive people, which are usually the oldest are the ones that they push out.  Ageism exists here folks.
You won't get raises or any annual increases.   If you want more money, you'll have to get promoted, or take a lateral move.
Don't require annual performance reviews, so you never quite know where you stand outside your first level manager.

Pros: Great work/life balance; chill, fun, supportive work culture; clear that the company cares about its employees; excellent gym/spa services; encouraged to move horizontally and learn more about different areas; lots of fun social events and outings; embracing change and the challenges that come with IT industry; even as a new hire from college I immediately felt valued and respected . Overall, it's clear people don't just like working here, they really love it.
Cons: Hard to increase annual salary once set (could take a few years at most); difficult to move up; lots of new processes on top of old processes and that creates a lot of redundancy/confusion.

Pros:
Telecommuting and time off flexibility.
Kudos in company name, for the moment.
Fantastic people to work with.
Some managers are truely excellent, but they're fewer and farther between.
Cons:
Major politics, with too much empire building and protectionism.
Lack of clear focus, with random brain farts of management converted to policy.
Cut back in employee training and peer network development (ie trade show attendence) is extremely short-sighted.
Innovation is stunted by need to keep management happy.
Middle management are just out to keep their slice of pie, and not rock the boat.

Pros: Great company to gain experience from. Very stable if you are not interested in upper mobility. Basically you can trust that your salary will be paid, while your responsibilities will increase every year (but not your pay)
Cons: In the last 8 years the company has become a political minefield, where powerpoint presentations and endless meetings are killing creativity. With frozen salaries, no stock options and limited bonuses, it has becomed a me too company.

Pros:
Health benefits
vacation and flex time is good
Nice cafeteria and office buildings
Gym on-site with trainers and nice equipment
Nice campus for walking
Cons: Working beyond reason - nights, weekends, etc so basically your pay isn't that great when spread out over all the hours.  Better off to take a fun job and work nights somewhere.  This is a very stressful and aggressive work environment.  Politics reign supreme and it is not a fun place to work.  Too much stress and management unable to respond appropriately.  Pigeonholing and promotions based more on friendships/nationality then qualifications.  A dead end opportunity for the vase majority.  The company has changed so much - not the same Cisco it use to be.

Pros:
- Smart, experienced, and engaged employees with a good balance of long tenured and newer employees
- At the center of many of the key technology trends for broad exposure
- Proactively evolving and transforming for business relevancy and impact
- Great work life balance that leverages Cisco collaboration technology to provide work location flexibility
- Lots of opportunities to work in new roles / areas
Cons:
- Large matrix organization, requires a learning curve and relationship development to successfully navigate
- Ongoing change is not for everyone, can be challenge for some folks who like a steady state
- Limited leadership development / rotational programs, requires proactive self-solutioning

Pros: Great company vision accompanied by a broad portfolio of solutions. The CEO is a charismatic salesman who positions the company and its offerings well with industry trends and customers needs.
Cons:
Excellent at selling but extremely scattered and poor at execution. The company lost its innovative culture and commitment to its workforce in developing new technological advancements. Instead buys companies to make up its portfolio and for the past five years laid off thousands of its workforce annually to support this approach. The lay offs are not performance based meaning you could be a top performer and still have your position eliminated. Out with the old, in with the new - same time next year.

Because of this, the work environment is unhealthy wherein people are focused more on running faster than their teammate in hopes of keeping their job and doing the popular thing rather the right thing. Work conditions are political and cliquish.

Pros: Great Benefits. Nice working environment. Excellent training programs. HR supports moving around to other jobs inside the company. Great Bonus programs-all employees. Tuition reimbursement. Room to grow if you're in the right group.
Cons:
Women in lower level jobs are not treated fairly. 

Most employees are doing two to three jobs at a time due to yearly layoffs.

Yearly layoffs are nerve racking.

Processes are implemented from the top down without vetting changes with lower levels--causing mass confusion for months on end.

Pros: If you are in a good group, you'll never find better people to work with.  The contacts I've made at Cisco are some of the best people out there.  The company is always one of the leaders in every technology it takes on - you always have a stellar brand and reputation backing you.  The company provides many perks, good salaries, and encourages remote working which helps balance your work/life/family needs.
Cons: It is a big company, so there is quite a bit of empire building and politics. Just hope that you fall on the right side of the technology decisions.  Right now they have to make a huge transition from purely hardware to annuity-based xaaS and software, so they are shedding amazing talent in hopes that cheaper millenials will save them.

Pros:
It is a at the forefront of SaaS evolution. All other vendors know what it is and how important it is but Cisco has it very well defined on how to its done.

Everyone from the individual contributor to the senior executives is involved and part of the evolution.

Perfect job for anyone who wants to feel his/her contribution makes an impact no matter what the role or job function is.
Cons: It is a constant evolving and growing pain. Some may like more predictability and certainty but since this is an ever evolving and growing field, they may find the changes too  overwhelming.

Pros:
Clearly moved on from just a router supplier and now a real network company far beyond hardware, really investing heavily in the software and capabilities part of the business.  The Executive are also well aware of moving to a software licensing business and making sure there's no Cisco Shelfware. 
The Executive appear to be investing heavily in customer success in it's own capability but also with the partners that's encouraging.
Cons:
It building up the capability from a small start, so a lot of things are new to everybody,  but that does give the opportunity for the company to be open minded about new idea, which so far it seems to be.  
Whilst the majority of the company take on board the new mission there are a few NIMBI's, but then that would happen anywhere.

Pros:
- Great work life balance and flexibility
- Some really awesome people and good bosses
- Great benefits
Cons:
- Lots of politics, especially Org I was involved in.   
- Absolutely no growth!!  Very few managers who really care about the people under them but way too many re-orgs all the time thus you end up rolling under another manager (not by choice), have to work on proving yourself yet again and most managers are way too busy to care about the people under them and only concerned about their own growth and fitting into the political circle.
- Been here 10 years, lots of great feedback received but that goes nowhere
- Limited Restructuring "new word for layoffs!" and they  happen EVERY year!  Very demotivating.  I would not recommend this company because of this!! I have known people who left really good secure jobs to join Cisco, only to be affected a few months later by their "restructuring".

Pros: One gets a great work-life balance. Good place for women employees.
Cons:
The senior management has trusted few lieutenants, mostly old timers that they always pull them when new development work comes. They are once who tend to be critical and are rewarded the most in terms of salaries and Stock options etc. On every product launch, the seed team will be deployed to deliver. 

No matter the amount of hardwork, for lateral hire getting to these elite few is not possible at least in an ethical manner.   Thus the majority of lateral hires end up doing minor enhancements and bug fixes. Their career growth thus limited.  Most of them will end up cleaning up the mess created by these so-called lieutenants 

HR is totally non-functional, 90% of the team doesn't even know who the HR is. They do nothing to prevent such practices.  they are confined to framing policies of leaves etc.

Pros:
1) Would get ample time.
2) It might be better for experienced people with work exp > 6 years if you play good office politics and are NOT concerned with quality work.
3) Great Cafeteria. Lot of food options.
4) HR, any document you want from them, they are quick to respond.
Cons:
1) Bad company to work for freshers. Have seen some freshers, folks from good colleges hired as Software Engineer, doing support jobs.
2) Managers in India are Narcissist, who has fall behind to upgrade themselves with software engineering and technology.
3) Hard work or innovation is not appreciated by managers if the work doesn't give them visibility.
4) Mostly Team Leads are in pockets of managers in hope of better appraisal.
No matter how good or hardworking you are, your appraisal will not be good. It has been so in my past two teams. Everything is overlooked and nepotism prevails in the end.
5) Its a glorified service company. Company survives by buying out other companies rather than innovating.

Pros:
industry leader and brand recognition
business innovaters
products truly do change the way people effectively work, live, play, and learn
nicely compensated
access to insurmountable resources
among the best and brightest in the world
trend setting
good benefits
john chambers is a very smart man who is in tune to technology and change
we keep our competitors on their toes
heavily invested in research and development
customer satisfaction driven -- we become successful when our customers become successful mentality
Cons:
not as diverse as you think
uneven playing field
subjective environment
managers make, break, or ensure your success, when your work/accomplishments should
the sales field can be racist, biased, and subjective
did not have a good experience while in the sales associate program
my bad experience has greatly affected my outlook on the company as a whole

Pros:
- The salaries and bonuses are acceptable.
- You get to work with latest technology
- Very smart and talented co-workers
Cons:
- Every year, approximately from July to Sept, Cisco targets internal organizations for reduction in head count.  Your job is at risk every year.
- Salary increases are rare
- Once technology becomes stable, Cisco moves development to India and leaves US employees to search for new position or leave Cisco.  So, if you do a good job, you are rewarded by losing your job.
- Cisco is always trying to get rid of the bottom 5%.  After a while, this reaches the good workers.
- You work long hours, weekends, all-nighters, etc
- very limited job opportunities outside HQ
- no professional development.  
- no training dollars.

Pros: Cisco still has benefits a lot of other companies do not offer. The Flexible worktime where you can plan your day yourself. Nice company cars and a good pension plan.
Cons:
All Benefits besides that (pros) have been completely cut. No more Trainings. No more travel whatsoever. No more meetings with colleagues. No more Global events. No more Fruits and Beverages. No more promotions. No more Awards. No more Stock Options. And many more...

Pretty much anything that has been a differenciator from the competition has been cut. With no future to be reintroduced. Also the communication about this was really unprofessional and badly done. The demotivational factor was and is very high.

Pros: Great job. Great support from direct management. Cisco has a great vision and really executes on their vision. I highly recommend working at Cisco unless you get stuck with supporting Tennessee.
Cons: If you get on the wrong side of an RM or SEM you support, you are screwed as an overlay sales rep forever. My experience is that you could never make them happy once they had a particular opinion of you. No matter how much success you had in other regions, they never missed a chance to poison your reputation to your management, their management and their reps.

Pros:
* Open communication
* Strong Brand
* Trust: as long as you achieve results you can decide what your day will look like 
*Being is cisco is really like being in a family 
* Very good benefits
Cons:
* Difficult to make a career
* Wage is only ok and it doesn't grow much over the years, even after continued good results
* Sn Mgm often asks to complete useless tasks which is time consuming and forces to work weekend and/or late at night
* Culture slowly fading away and transforming the company to a much less exceptional company
* In the last couple of yrs hypocrisy is becoming the top quality required (speaking one thing in company meeting and acting in a totally different way) in senior management

Pros:
Pretty flexible about working from home (they own Webex)
People are smart and overall employees are fun to work with
Meetings are kept to a tolerable minimum
Cons:
Slow to promote or increase salary so you are forced to leave the company if you really want an increases in money and responsibilities.
Like most large corporations, they do not have a mechanism that employees trust to provide feedback about Sr. Managers that will be taken seriously.

Pros: Excellent pay (includes bonus), good benefits, flexible hours, lots of different things going on in the company if you want to switch.  Company is the leader in the core of the internet, which is a huge plus as the world revolves ever more around the internet.
Cons: Cisco's upper management has grandiose hopes to lead the world in anything related to the internet, and frankly we don't have the expertise in things like tablets, social networking, etc.  That is stretching the company thin and putting undo pressure on developers.  Job security has not been good over the past decade, with layoffs every couple of years.  Morale is currently very bad.  Stock is at trading at 1998 levels.

Pros: Great sales force, great technology, high visibility within the industry and ability to drive technology and innovation. Lots of customers. If you build a good product, they sell it!.
Cons: Lots of politics. To move up the ladder, need to manage up vs manage down. Passive aggressive culture. Senior management spends lot more time managing up, unaware of the business. Throws money around indiscriminately looking for success. Senior management unaware of what is going on. John Chambers is not connected with reality on the ground. Keeps talking about how great everything is and there are layoffs across the board.

Pros: Tremendous opportunities to learn everything about networks, hardware & software.
Cons: Constant emphasized budgets & the corporate watchword of Frugality cheapens all aspects of the culture. They have acquired so many startups & other internet companies, some that don't even compete with them, in robber baron style that they've become the poster boys for job killers vs. job creators with a top-heavy elite upper management who reap a huge disproportionate amount of the profits in bloated bonuses. They are failing to integrate all their acquisitions into Cisaco, & most acquired companies evaporate with huge layoffs.

Pros:
- very good work/life balance
- flexible work - can do work from home
- Good PTO benefits
- Many folks know technically very well, very good place to learn new things
- emphasis given to training if needed
- Once Cisco is on your resume, you can easily hop jobs and come back to Cisco again later.
Cons:
- Frequent layoffs, tough for green card applicants with so much of back log.
- Compensation is less compared to market rate. Once, a salary is set, very difficult to get a hike unless promoted.
- Performance is based on ratings given by the manager which can lead to differences within the team.

Pros:
* Lot of new things to learn.
* Scale is huge, big customers.
* Great courses are offered to keep skill up to date.
* Good benefits - Health Insurance, 401K match, PTOs (1 on your birthday).
* Few great minds around to leverage the knowledge.
Cons:
* Dirty politics, VP changes then he brings all his people and let go great minds.
* Lay Offs and Lay Offs, bad hiring policy.
* Average Compensation.
* Really bad managers who are not technically sound, how can this happen in a product company.

Pros:
First and foremost: the people! The amount of training and support is phenomenal.
Going into the CSAP program I had high expectations. 3 months in, every single one of them was exceeded: some of the best instructors, IT tech courses that are geared toward the practical and relevant for the job, lab always open for "getting the hands dirty", sales training made fun. Did I mention the people? Everyone form my CSAP co-workers to experienced systems engineers to management (at all levels) is really supportive and approachable. Also, I had the chance to interact with people outside of my local office and they did not seem far at all. 
The pay is great, there is relocation support, I am happy with the insurance provided.
Cons: The training program is very engaging and intense. If not careful, maintaining a work-life balance becomes a struggle.

Pros:
Excellent benefits (bonus structure, ESPP, PTO, 
Good work-life balance but it is up to you to set it and stick to it
Great telecommuting options
For the most part, good people at the individual level who just want to do good work in a positive manner
Promotions and raises do come to those who fight for themselves
Was able to grow career substantially but it needs to be under the right leaders. A poor manager stifles this
Cons:
Disconnect between what the senior management (VP level) perceives and what is actually occurring within their org
Frequent re-orgs means cutting great talent
Changing directions and priorities make it a challenge to stick to one strategy for a sustaining period
401k match is good but could be better (currently at 4.5%)
Cisco is a low/no growth company which means managing expenses to the tenth degree. This means budget cuts, lack of travel for customer engagements, no backfilling lost talent, etc.

Pros: Pretty good pay, bonus and benefits. Innovation is encouraged and supported at high levels, but not necessarily at lower levels. There is strong enterprise support for most internal needs, and flexibility when specific requirements come along.
Cons:
It's difficult to run a company so large and varied.
Acquisition is the norm instead of internal innovation in many business units.
Management is focused on the investors before employees.
Company frequently pushes the same practices and expectations on different business units inappropriately.
Internal quality suffers as management struggles to meet goals with limited resources and mediocre engineering practices are accepted as the norm, in some business units.
The company standardizes on one-size-fits-all solutions internally, but every solution seems to have an 18-month lifespan.
Benefits are comprehensive and good, but the employee is charged for most options.

Pros:
I have over 25 years experience with many years as a consultant, which has afforded me the opportunity to have exposure to many companies.  Throughout my career I worked with Cisco employees and I was always impressed with their abilities.  When given the opportunity to come and work here I came with high expectations of myself and Cisco.  Cisco has not disappointed!    
Cisco provides an amazing work environment with the perfect work-life balance.  the opportunity to learn is off the charts.  You can push yourself in any direction you choose, be it technical, project based or managerial.  If you are willing to put in the time, the training is made available to you for self development.
Cons: As it is a large company at times internal divisions can make it difficult to align resources but once you find your way around people are always willing to engage

Pros: Depending on team, flexible work options especially remote work. Decent benefits but health benefits keep getting chipped away more and more every year. You can become a real pro at giving PowerPoint presentations. If "fun" and "culture" is learning how to play politics and reduce your conscience to,the level of betraying your mother without blinking in the name of corporate ladder climbing, then welcome to Cisco!
Cons: Favoritism, nepotism, cronyism is rampant. The People Deal employee review system is arbitrary, vague and not defined and it opens the door for management to play favorites. Survival of the fittest political player is the name of the game. No real innovation, just acquiring smaller companies now and not successfully integrating them.

Pros: Great salary and benefits. Very smart people.
Cons: Work load was just way too heavy. W-a-y too much politics all the time. People were scared to make mistakes. Management took all the glory. Women were not promoted.

Pros: Good salary for "blue badge" direct employees. Good conditions, autonomy in your work.
Cons: Lot of hot air about diversity and the SJW agenda, and rah-rah cult-like atmosphere growing out of control. Diversity of opinions are not welcomed. Lay-off culture; continous rounds of large layoffs each time the business dips, which is about every two years, as a standard operating procedure.

Pros: Opportunity to grow and work on new technologies. Results-based bonus compensation.
Cons: Travel was insane - expected to hop on a flight at a moment's notice even to international destinations. This was very disruptive to the family. Also, when it came time to layoff 7,000+ employees, Cisco cancelled unvested stock, which was a significant amount of equity unfairly taken back. Stock bonuses were awarded based on past performance and vested as an incentive to keep the employee at Cisco. When Cisco changed course under new management, they should have let us keep our stock that we earned. Canceling our equity awards was an unethical move in my opinion. The company changed for the worse after John Chambers retired.

Pros: Plenty of opportunity for improvement inside.
Cons:
Deep seated issues in Business and IT Operations and as a people company, didnt  see many being 'super motivated' individuals. All work for a salary, and too tied up with processes and hiding behind it to avoid work. Dont be surprised if you find an average employe too "busy" with meetings from morn - 6PM. 

Extensive use of contractors and consultants to "educate" the management who have the budget control and others pretty much left on their own.

Generally no electricity in the environment to get things done, except for rhetoric from Sr. Management.

Pros:
Don't get me wrong: I didn't hit my 7 figure net worth via stock options but rather the generous compensation from Cisco (and being thrift personally helped as well). Cisco does make you work for your money but it is well worth it because of all the vast networking knowledge you'll acquire while working for them (especially in the IP domain). I've worked at various companies before Cisco and I really have to say that this is THE best company so far that I've work in.

Of course, YMMV.
Cons:
Some projects, in the end, really are money losing projects which Cisco still maintain because it wants to have a footprint on those particular networking technologies. However, Cisco does recognize this and will make sure not to spend any more $$$ than it already has.

Some acquisitions, quite frankly, were too pricy IMHO and I'm not sure whether they'll see a return on investment with those acquisitions.

Pros: Good salaries and bonuses, good environment to work, managers will let you be independent and create new projects to help out the team, which sometimes results in a good innovation spread among the whole business unit or maybe even the company. Good resources to learn about the technologies employed there and they always have people to lend a helping hand and events to share knowledge about what's happening inside the walls of Cisco and around the Networking world.
Cons: Slow innovation cycle due to the huge nature of the company which means that sometimes you can't change work processes or culture already in place. Too much corporate culture and seems like independent business units are always competing too much and not in a good way. Small teams could be smaller sometimes and get more ownership of components to feel they are changing things from the inside in a way that creates more impact.

Pros: Management is fair and generally trained well. The managers I've worked under are always rational, logical, and always made decision that is always best for customer and Cisco. The benefits, perks, employee discounts are pretty nice. Don't think smaller companies can afford these kind of benefits. Cisco is always growing to new fields and markets, so there are always chances to transfer to do different work if so desired.
Cons: Cisco is a big company so decision making and project progress can be slowed. This is especially true when a project involves 2 or more business units and priorities between the two business units are not always aligned to the same schedule.  Sometimes resources are not allocated because of these differences in priorities.

Pros: Smart people, good technology, good benefits; you will be challenged intellectually in working on customer solutions, and cisco has a great pool of experts you can tap into
Cons: Horrible management with no idea how to promote strong employees and no idea how to train and maintain a strong group of employees, leaving the work of training up to each individual. Plus, Cisco has limited market growth and is too big for it's own good; whether it's in cloud, SDN, or Unified Communications, Cisco is the gorilla in the room that leverages its vast install base to get sales vs its product-set. Considering it is such a big company, it's very difficult to move up in the organization, leading to a culture where everyone struggling to exceed last year's $50B revenue mark and only the luckiest sales teams reap the rewards.

Pros: The salary and benefits were above average for the industry, with employees encouraged to work from home. Work/Life balance was okay, though policies were spottily applied and changed in their application from manager to manager.
Cons: The quality of your job experience will depend on your manager - there are large sections of middle managers and sales people who have no performance criteria other than to show up. There is little management by objectives if you have been with the organization for a long period or have political connections. This encourages the worst forms of intrigue and game playing. Frequent reorganizations and redundancies are a part of "American Style" culture.

Pros: good work life balance, telecommuting options.  Opportunities for growth and movement limited if not located in the bay area. I worked in a very smart group of experienced talented engineers. Good place to be if you want to witness firsthand the inefficiencies of a giant engineering organization.
Cons: Opportunities for growth and movement limited if not located in the bay area. A game of musical chairs  at the VP/SVP level, new leader comes in every 12 - 18 months with big ambitions for the team, then eventually succumbs to the bureaucracy or the inter-BU politics. Did I mention the periodic layoffs ?

Pros:
- telecommute, freedom to work anywhere
- fairly good compensation
- strong brand, big company with lots of technologies and departments for you to move around
- well regarded if Cisco on resume
Cons:
- a company that keeps retrenching and restructuring just to please shareholders
- change every year for change sake.. many of the changes are just for show
- losing its shine to be good employer as it removes staff everywhere, only to rehire 6-12 months later.. waste time, waste resources to retrain, lose employee's general morale.. increasingly employees don't feel loyal unlike the Year 2000-2007 where employees would love to stay and not leave...now employees only work for position, pay and glory politics..
- slower growth due to hardware focus even though it is trying to move more to software and services..

Pros: I had been there for 20+ years, and survived several 're-organizations' until this year. When it happened to me (and 5500 other people that month) they gave me a good package with several months of paid healthcare. I went back to management and asked for additional paid healthcare, and they gave that to me too.
Cons: Cisco is a company that takes care of their employees - even when they lay them off. Getting laid off is no fun, but Cisco seems to handle it very well. To much practice??????

Pros:
Graduate program gives you a solid foundation, though still some management and curriculum issues still need addressing.
Best in class technology to work with.
Reputation of the company makes entry-level Sales less daunting.
Approachable senior leaders.
Early In Career Network community.
Annual sales conference.
Cons:
Development during graduate on-the-job experience will really depend on who you are aligned to.
Lack of communication from management regarding future career prospects.
Back-end systems are a mess, causing Sales employees to waste a lot of time on admin and non-rewarding activities.
Unrealistic targets that end up demotivating.
Lack of diversity in Sales when compared to Engineers.

Pros:
- good compensation (salary, bonus, ESPP, RSU, "connected recognitions", donation matching)
- 25 vacation days a year + birthday
- respecting employees
- great compensations at lay offs
- (for few people) varied career opportunity
Cons:
- The company lacks technological focus/agenda/roadmap. It is being managed only by Sales and Finance people.
- very frequent lay offs (LR - Limited Restructuring)
- no room for techinological innovations, because the company expects very quick ROI, rather than long term growth
- Cisco is very focused on its core business (Network equipment) and doesn't care a lot about other stuff, as it is hard to compete with the income of its core buisness
- poor HR and IT support - everything is self-serve, and long waits for overseas teams

Pros: Intelligent, hard working people.  Flexible work environment . Great work site/facilities and technology.
Cons: In the HR organization there is limited opportunity and focus on career growth.  Compensation strategy is lacking - no regular merit increases,   strong performance is not rewarded in significant ways.     Limited to no stock options in most positions.   Fear of constant lay offs impacts morale... its discouraging to watch long time hard working employees who have given 10+ years to the company be laid off by new managers.  More work needs to be done on the "moments that matter" -  acknowledgement is inconsistent across teams and not creating a positive experience for everyone.

Pros: Good products across a wide range of technology.
Cons: Lost it's Cisco family values as they will layoff entire organizations off for not reason, and worse just weeks after saying that there is nothing to worry about and that everyone would have a spot as they recreated them.  That was not the case for most of the employees as they purposely stalled the job postings until after the layoffs were completed.

Pros:
The CIE group has a lot to offer including lunch 3 times a week and a well stocked fridge. More importantly, the office culture is excellent and everybody works together to get things done.

At higher (technical) levels, you can become very much a master of your own destiny. Working hours can be flexible and working from home is pretty much unrestricted (in non-Covid times).
Cons: Compliance, red tape and bureaucracy are destroying the organization. As a highly experienced tech, I get to spend less and less time on technical issues each day at the expense of attending meetings and arguing the effectiveness of mandates being imposed on our group from above. Between 2015 when Cisco bought OpenDNS and now (2020), the burden of conformance has become too heavy to shoulder... velocity, imagination and ingenuity are all casualties of this huge organization.

Pros: The Leaders in Finance and Technology (LIFT) Program is a 2-year rotational program for recent college grads. Not only does Cisco provide several networking, volunteering, diversity & inclusion, and career development opportunities within the program, but after the program as well. There are plenty of job swap opportunities throughout your entire career at Cisco. Typically, employees try to rotate to grow their skillsets about every 2-4 years. Also, because Cisco is such a large company, no role is the same. You have plenty of opportunities to learn something new and develop in new areas both personally and professionally.
Cons: Definitely depends on the specific team you are on, but work-life balance isn't always the best for roles that are more demanding. Personally, out of the 4 teams I have worked with, 2 of them have required long hours outside of your normal 9am-5pm. Cisco as a company promotes time off, it's just that certain teams are busier than others.

Pros: Emplyee friendly,  flexible working hours and telecommutiing support.  Cisco's  broad product and technology portfolio provide  employees with  divercified operchunitees based on each individual's interest level.  Cisco's overall compensation package maches with industry  standards.
Cons: In Cisco If you are  a hardworker  and dodn't know how to say "NO"  you could  end up doing  all others  works.  Medical benifits are    not    upto the  mark .

Pros: Fast aggressive workplace. Too much focus on operational issues and not much on learning and skill development.
Cons: Will be hard to learn new skills and change jobs. Anytime you change you are placed at the back of the promotion queue. So easy to get pigenholed. I changed mutliple roles and found that each time I was placed in the back of the queue. After few years, I was ridiculously lower grade, while they brought fresh people with unproven skills at much higher levels. Also my manager gave me a high speech about innovation and doing things differently to grow while people were coming in at a lot higher grade without doing any of these things. That is the biggest issue.

Pros:
Best in breed product
Good facility perks (cafe, running trails, gym)
Cons: 0 work-life balance - There was an article on our company's intranet site today stating that 85% of Cisco employees enjoy some flexible work from options however this is outright discouraged and prevented within WebEx sales.  This is completely hypocritical since we are selling web-conferencing products which allow customers to conduct business "Any where, Any time, On Any Device" - Yes that is the company's cute tag line - just don't expect it to apply to WebEx sales professionals - not even when there is a severe snow storm.  Their approach is to send an email reminding us to leave our house earlier so we can make it in on time... (Yeah don't even think about working from home on those occasions)

Pros: Cisco offers a flexible work environment based on what I view as three tenets - integrity, trust, and excellence.  The focus on the customer's success leads to Cisco's success.  Cisco has the resources to meet the needs of extremely large programs and projects which small companies can't even fathom.
Cons: Cisco develops a lot of different technologies and they are organized in a manner to facilitate leadership in each of those domains; however, collaboration between those technical domains can be a challenge.  Cisco is not and can't be as nimble as a startup; however, there are pockets of technical leadership where latitude is given to perform research, experimentation, and rapid development.  Find the right team.

Pros:
1) Good Atmosphere
2) Flexible timings
3) There is no micromanagement
4) There are ways one can express his views (if any) most of the times and it is respected although it might not work but most likely there is no grudge for that.
Cons:
1) A lot of processes for a simple thing and which makes it difficult to work.
2) You may not get deserved benefits unless you like to show off
3) Different people with varied years of experience are treated the same. Like a 4 year experienced and a 6 year experienced are treated the same with the tasks given whereas the salary differs a lot.

Pros: Health benefits, on site daycare and healthcare.
Cons: Poor Leadership, continuous cost cutting and culture erosion over time. Projects kick off but are rarely completed. Tons of outsourcing and laying off of people to rehire the same job in low cost areas. Way too much Power Point and too little leadership. People are promoted for managing up vs. enabling their teams and doing the right thing for Cisco and the customer. It is incredibly political and you don't know when or if you will be laid off if your not in with the right people. I finally quit after working there for over a decade.

Pros: At a big company like Cisco, you get a number of opportunities to network with other people by taking part in the several events that various organizations host. The size of the company also opens the doors to several different opportunities in tech, as each team and each department works in different areas and with different technologies, and employees are given opportunities to learn about what is going on outside of their team and perhaps delve into other areas of work.
Cons: A big organization also comes with its fair share of problems. There does not seem to be a universal direction, as every team and department works so differently, and propagating a proposed transition throughout the entire organization is a difficult thing to do. As a result, every group does things their own way, and one is bound to end up in a team where the processes do not follow what many other teams may supposedly be doing.

Pros:
Good people to work with (can only speak of my team)

Good work life balance

Good benefits
Cons:
Too many layoffs is demoralizing

Pay is not that great especially at junior level

Slow work environment. Email heavy culture slows things down. Impossible to get things done quickly even if you want to do so as it is generally hard to meet people face to face.
 
A lot of people work from home too often

Lack of transparency about what is happening at the higher levels

Managers don't interact with employees as often and even members of the same team don't interact with each other as often leading to a lack of team spirit.

A lot of people are not passionate about their work. Many are working just for the sake of it.

Pros:
Flexible hours, including the ability to work from home
Amazing, intelligent, creative people
Cisco is trying to do good things in the world
Cons:
Cisco's first priority is its financial commitment to its shareholders. If a project / business unit is not profitable... they fire people ("limited restructuring" or "LR"). They don't VALUE each person and try to find new projects for talented, hard-working, dedicated employees. They just fire them. So consequently we don't feel appreciated.

So we are all walking around waiting for the next LR, wondering who will be next... it's stressful and unmotivating. The only reason people stick around is to get the "package" when they are LRed.

Pros: Good work life balance, nice people layered across the motivation.
Cons: Hardly no motivation to improve.  Company culture heavily focused on layoffs.  Rigid "promo freezes" create weird culture where managers open "new reqs" to promote people instead of simply rewarding top contributors.  Loosen up the OpEx and you will likely retain top talent, thereby driving revenue growth.

Pros: Cisco is a large, successful tech company with its hands in many different technologies. This is a benefit for ensuring you get exposed to new technologies and projects. The culture in Ottawa is as similar to a start-up as you can get with a large company - there is great camaraderie amongst employees and inter-team collaboration. Compensation in Ottawa is very good compared to other large companies in the area. Vacation, benefits and perks are excellent.
Cons: Cisco shares the same downfalls as any large company with bureaucracy and silos that create scenarios where different teams may duplicate work or have breakdowns in communication. Working at Cisco in Canada you will suffer 'satellite office syndrome'. Fewer promotions, raises and less interesting work may come by.

Pros:
Leadership's Vision clearly taking this company into the next decade
The coolest products
Social responsibility is always a factor in key decisions under this leadership
So many opportunities to advance
Outstanding opportunity to invest in this company and reap the in rewards of its success
Cons:
Too focused on quarter-to-quarter results
The annual layoffs every August (look out!)
So focused on the investor and not always on its own employees

Pros: Great vision, Company goals and strategy at the CEO & ELT level
Cons:
Team leads (TL) lack leadership and self absorbed and stressed to salvage their own jobs not believing in the company goals.at the expense of not following ELT expectations
No process to evaluate TL performance and their bias, subjective choices and effectively lead and support their teams. 
Surveys results are not effective since no change in TL's behaviors for 15 plus years at Cisco Capital just because they are good at Operations and tasks with no previous management experience. Lack of skip level interactions to see through these missed opportunities.

Pros: -Vast learning opportunities -Nice people and culture -Great place to start your career. Being a new grad, Cisco will hold your hand and provide a massive support (trainings, certifications support, rotations etc.) to make you a fully operable engineer -Internal movement support. It's pretty common seeing people changing teams to try themselves in a different tech/field/position -Work from home policy and no mandate on office hours. Depends on the team, but usually you are good working remotely 100%. -Interesting tasks/cases/projects
Cons: -Might not be the best salary on the market -Unclear pomotion criterias. May find you are teaching a guy who is being paid same -Sometimes you may end up without promotions for years -Some roles, TAC especially, pretty packed with work and hard to keep work/life balance

Pros:
tele commute opportunities.
stable company
opportunities for job rotation.
Cons:
no career growth
highly political.
top management very comfortable with pathetic growth.
risk averse
compensation sucks for most employees unless you are above grade 12.
They request employees to be frugal but senior management spends millions and doesn't walk the talk.
360 degree feedback is done to show they care but no action is taken based on the feedback.
They like to believe they are share holder friendly but share holders have been getting such a bad deal investing in Cisco in a decade.

Pros: Very stable company that is poised for the long haul.  Cisco is at the forefront of many foundational technologies that will enable the next age of computing and communication.
Cons: Very corporate.  Easy to get lost in the shuffle and as with all big companies, the tendency then becomes for the worker bees to jockey for position amongst each other.  There is a perception (which is many parts reality) that the folks who move their way in to manage are not necessarily the most qualified.  Polticking often gets in the way of execution here.

Pros: Cisco Systems is a stable company with lot of resources.  It is a large company, so work experiment widely vary base on which group you work with and where you work.  Since Cisco uses variable pay method, if you work for the “right” group, you will make very good living.  It is also a very good place for young people to learn and grow.
Cons: Cisco is a very bureaucratic organization with layer of management.  Most of the works are done by a small group of people and the rests just show up to collect pay checks.  Most managers only care about growing head count and justify their existence.  And if you are not in San Jose, you are pretty missing out on most of benefit of working at Cisco.

Pros: Very dynamic environment, some groups working on cutting edge technology, benefits are pretty good, flexible working hours, telecommuting encouraged (in some groups), a lot of very good, smart, motivated people to work with. If you're working on a hot project, you have virtually unlimited resources to draw from.
Cons: company doesn't value it's employees as much as it used to, work environment and amenities have changed (or been eliminated) for the worse, work/life balance is talked about but isn't supported by management. Internal silos and politics make it hard to have successful cross-functional projects, management is rewarded for getting product out the door without respect for quality.

Pros:
The company is filled with innovative, intelligent and creative people. I enjoyed working for a company that is not limited by brick and mortar.  

Leadership understands the power of  connection and provides the tools and environment to support collaboration and the ability to "work smart". 

 It is fantastic to work in a distributed virtual environment. The model allows people from different countries to participate, and provide valuable contributions to the initiative, project or discussion.
Cons:
The constant change across the organization can be a challenge.

Executive Leadership and mid management can be disconnected.  This misalignment leads to inconsistent messaging and actions inconsistent with communication.

Pros: Culture of decency, intelligence - a place where most of the employee base is collaborative, well-wishing, open and focused on mutual success.
Cons: Transformation today pressures most departments to execute while still figuring out what they should execute, and even as transparency in diminishing relative to past times. Coordinated strategy-building is difficult with this amount of change, and without more open communication about in-the-moment navigation.

Pros: This internship was such an amazing opportunity!  In one summer full of fun & learning, with new experiences each and every day, Cisco Systems and employees taught me more than I ever imagined.  I had access to industry professionals, the work was meaningful (I never was the coffee runner), the pay was VERY COMPETITIVE, built upon skills and gained new skills I could use on any job, and the whole summer was full of networking and personal and career building tasks.  I would recommend this internship to anyone who is willing to have a team of managers and personal mentor who will see their flaws and help you build upon them, also someone who is hardworking and never gives up!
Cons: They gave us Mac laptops, I didnt know how to use it in the beginning but I caught on fast and LOVED IT!

Pros: Flexibility with family, work from home culture - empowered by great technology, autonomous team, no micromanaging. As a contractor I was given new areas to explore for company which allowed a lot of creative thinking and ability to take risks, which may be easier for a contractor to do versus a long-term employee who is worried about taking risk.
Cons: In the five years I was there layoffs become commonplace for the first time in company history, this created a culture of people being more out for themselves and getting through the next reorg which kills productivity for months a time. Company is getting too big where people can hide as non-performers, which really kills a team when others are pulling weight.

Pros: Cisco has great package of benefits and good combination of work/life balance. There is great diversity of cultures in Cisco and opportunity to work with many people across the globe. CEO and Executive Leadership Team are seriously pushing the People Deal and seem to care about employees. There is "Freedom of Speech" and open friendly work environment.
Cons: Salaries are on the lower side compared to competition. Lots of meetings and time zones across the teams, which makes it difficult to manage your normal working day. Lots of tools and abbreviations. Your experience will most likely depend on the team you land in. It can be both highly positive and negative. There is no clarity on how your performance is measured and what to expect in the next year or so.

Pros:
- Flexible work schedule/location (unless a manager requires otherwise)
- No one on my teams cares whether or not I'm lesbian, and I have never been uncomfortable bringing my wife to a company event. 
- I have never felt as though anything other than my work played a part in my employment or my project/program assignments.
Cons:
- Our Talent teams do not actively participate in GLBT+ specific conferences (like Lesbians Who Tech for example) like we do for other conferences (like Grace Hopper Women in Computing for example)
- Wish we were more visible in the GLBT+ communities everywhere we have a Cisco site. There should be employee programs and outreach at every site and we should actively participate in community events much more than we do!!

Pros: Good benefits. Access to a lot of knowledge.
Cons: Moving up is fairly difficult if you are in a needed position. They will try to keep you labeled Tier 1 while having you do design work, deep troubleshooting, etc. They also over promise things for the team sizes. Whole systems with 12+ hour coverage and only 2-3 people to support it (thus requiring extra work hours/ weekend work for many).

Pros: Opportunities to manage large teams and complex problems. This company does very interesting engineering work.
Cons:
Female engineering leaders are consistently discriminated against in this company. I know several woman engineering managers who complain of being over-loaded, under-leveled, and under-paid as compared to their male counterparts in the same org, doing exactly the same work, and sometimes even having a larger team. I know several anecdotes of male senior managers engaging in gender-discriminatory behavior & comments when it comes to compensation, growth, acknowledging achievements, and providing actionable feedback.
Instead of supporting women in leadership and encouraging growth, Cisco is consistently burning woman leaders out. Go ahead and count the number of women who are at least one-level skip managers in an engineering team in Cisco. Hint - you may be able to count them on your fingertips.

Pros:
I am part of the Cloud Security team within the overall Security Business unit at Cisco. 

The big pros (from the perspective of my team):
- An awesome startup-like culture where everyone is encouraged to take initiatives 
- No strict hierarchies followed - Hierarchies exist in designations, but in practice, any engineer can freely go and talk to a senior manager or director. 
- Hackathons twice a year - where everyone works on an innovation of their choice for 2 days. This is taken seriously by top management, and the most innovative ideas are recognized and rewarded. Even if you are not part of a winning team, its an amazing experience.
Cons: Cisco is lagging competitors in some areas, which means there is tremendous pressure to catch up, and so a lot of work especially in recent times.

Pros:
Great work tools.
Smart teams.
Completely embrace remote work.
Cons:
I applied for an internal job (in the same business unit) in Decemberr, 2021. It was a role that I have actually had with other companies, and was very well qualifiied to hit the ground running. I reached out to the hiring manager, who I knew from professional interactions, who said he would like to get to know me better after the holidays. 

Three months have gone by. No interaction with the hiring manager, and just got a rejection notice. I realize that often these internal roles can involve politics, but to not really even give me the chance to interview was insulting. I don't care how many perks a company gives, or what they tout about their values and culture. When this happens it cancels everything else. No wonder there's 30%+ attrition in the company.

Pros:
Extremely competent and driven management team.  Excellent communication top down from the CEO through the leadership teams to the general teams.  
Good salary structure and general (non-salary) rewards & recognition.  
John Chambers genuinely cares what employees are thinking and feeling.
People are truly empowered to make a difference, and encouraged to do so.
Great flexibility in terms of schedules.
Cons:
Incredible hours and extremely high expectations.  Expect to multi-task to the nth degree.
No cost of living adjustments and the vast majority of compensation benefits (increases, etc) seem to go to a limited set of top performers.  If & when you are in the top percentages you are treated very well.

As a large company it can be very hard to negotiate, and it can be political.

Pros: In this market, having a product that saves companies money makes it easier sell. Also they are open to ideas from junior folks as well as senior. Being now under Cisco means its like working for a smaller company at Webex but with the great benefits of a bigger company like Cisco. I like how they are customer first and Cisco takes care of their folks and community.
Cons: I'd like to telcommute a day a week and that seems discouraged which is funny as we work for WebEx. They are struggling a little with Cisco alignment with territories but glad to see they are discussing it and making changes where necessary.

Pros:
1. Provides a broad view of the technology sector.
2. Great place when beginning your career.
3. Process-driven operations develop a sense of discipline in you.
4. Open, frequent communications, especially from the top.
Cons:
1. Growth path for individual contributors gets limited beyond 10-15 years of work experience.
2. Maneuvering skills needed to get promoted, certainly to Senior Manager/Director/VP levels.
3. Too much emphasis on acquiring companies or recruiting outside talent. Grooming within, risk-taking to develop internal candidates is rarely done.

Pros:
Great place to work in terms of opportunities available - every organization is a company on its own yet the common thread tying these organizations is the fabulous Cisco culture which runs all the way from top leadership to individual contributors across departments.

Great flexibility, work load is on the higher side, great benefits.
Cons: An average to slightly above average paymaster.  Sometimes duplication of activities across departments and the highly cross-functional nature of work/dependencies gets frustrating

Pros:
Good compensation package
Stable large company with steady revenue
Flexible work hours/location
Great work-life balance, esp for those who have kids
Cons:
Too many reorgs: experienced 3 reorgs within less than a year. This company is so schizophrenic and disfunctional it's not even funny.
No growth: you have to be super in charge of your career in order to get something out of your job.
Duplicating work: you see two teams working on the same thing all the time.  They need to lay off a lot of people to clean up this place.
Layers: way too many layers of management. Mind boggling that there are so many VPs with 0 direct reports.
Working remotely: you can work from home for months and talk to people on the phone without knowing what they look like. way to boost morale.
Work environment: old grey cubes, empty most of the time because of their working remote policy. 
Age of employees: very hard to find young people there.  You always see lots of people in their 40-50 stuck at the individual contributor level too.

Pros:
4 week of vacations
matured products means less stressful schedule
Flexible working hours (family friendly)
Around 12.5 % or more bonus to employee
Very nice program (known as CHOiCE) for fresh graduate, they can join any group they want
Early retirement package for 50 year old of engineers or above (you will get 1 year salary + 2 year health insurance package)
Cons:
No more free drink
No more stock options or restricted stock to engineers (only top 10% engineers and all managers or above will get restricted stock)
No annual fancy christmas party (except for sales department)
Most of the new interesting projects  will finally doom fail (like cius tablet, flip video).
A lot of fighting among the vice presidents of different BU
Expect company-wise layoff once a while (last layoff history is 2011, 2009).
The senior executives are not as sharp as the old day and CEO wants nobody to challenge his position.

Pros:
- A large technology company with a large breadth of technology areas and market coverage should provide varied opportunities for growth
- Great place for people with outstanding technical backgrounds who are looking to be challenged
- Surprising amount of room for growth even though it is currently a large company
Cons:
- Challenges exist for people who join and do not have detailed technical skills.  Cisco struggles with how to use and take full advantage of non-technical resources such as Program Management
- HR processes (career and professional development) not well managed

Pros: Cisco is indeed the power player for switches, routers, and networking.  There are usually opportunities for WFH, the helath club is great, medical facility/optometrist/dry cleaner all onsite, and a healthy work/life balance is encouraged.
Cons: The company is so big that almost nothing said about it can be applied across the board, from its internal culture to management style, as most of the organizations within the company operate under different levels of Exec VPs, Senior VPs, or regular VPs...  The only company-wide criteria applicable to the whole company is probably HR and IT, which are totally self-serve.  If you are working at Cisco, there will not be an admin to do your busy work or a number you can call to have someone "take care of that."

Pros: Cisco is big in networking market and has lot of products in routers, switches, data center products, voice products, security firewalls etc.The employee can make internal move and get to know about different products and protocols. Salary is good if we negotiate for higher grade and money while joining the company. Cisco have 4.5 % of base salary as 401k match, bonus [ higher the grade more the bonus percentage 8 % to 35% ], 20 days of PTO, tuition reimbusment,  support for CCIE lab exams . If you like to switch over from technical to non-technical roles like program manager, project manager there are plenty opportunities internally and you don't need  mandatory  MBA. The work life balance is better compare to many of the start-ups.
Cons: Frequent layoffs,  bad acquisitions , high management politics and if people are not negotiating while joining the company salaries/grade levels  are low.

Pros: Great benefits.  Fitness Center on campus.  Lots of education available, both online and in class.  Access to Safari Online subscription (if you ask for it).  Telecommuting is acceptable, and tools are provided.  Hours are flexible.  Time off can be taken when needed (and is encouraged).
Cons: Most of my issues were with the leadership of my group.  They weren't real big on planning, strategy, or forward thinking in general.  Development pushed for new technology when current tech was not yet stable.  Nepotism was a problem, along with a severe lack of guidance for the rest of us.  I was there for three years and never received any hint of a promotion or a raise, or guidance on how to get there.

Pros: good exposure into various clients. Flexible work hours, no one cares where you work from as long as you are doing your work to the satisfaction of your managers, field engineers and clients. compensation was good, and so were other benefits. Very employee friendly. certifications and continued learning.
Cons: Some of the teams in India were more back end. Even with client relationships, you would be doing work that the Field engineers were not interested in doing. It was cost effective for you to be doing the work. Not easy to shift teams. If you get stuck in some of the teams from which you wanted to shift, it would take a long time. There is no internal mechanism to rotate or provide opportunity for people to explore other roles within the company.

Pros: Great Pay, Industry leader, great benefits, great autonomy and world class people...you are working with the key people in the industry....you are a leader...you are driven and love it....plenty of off sites, volunteer events....you will learn more and drive major initiatives...a truly great job..
Cons: Be careful of believing in your own propaganda.  they boast of the business unit and then lay off 40%....there are great leaders...and there are weak ones...and the weak ones will do anything to stay on...and they will ask for your thoughts...but really do not want them...agree with them or leave.  This company will reorg and layoff every quarter...and then hire on new grads to replace the seniors....a great experience comes with severe issues.  I saw the best mangers...and the worst at one company--and there is a bit of a loyalty issues from those managers.

Pros: Amazing opportunities to learn different things, technologies, industries. If you enjoy twisting and turning your way through the day and jumping through hoops to make things happen, you'll enjoy Cisco. If you appreciate different challenges and continuous change, you'll enjoy Cisco. If you like consistency and a slower pace, you'll struggle to keep up. If you value leadership and the idea of learning from others as an early in career employee is important to you (over pay) then you'll enjoy Cisco.
Cons: You won't make a million dollars in your first 10 years ... it might take 20. Pay, and promotional velocity aren't amazing, but you'll never have to worry about getting the things you need.

Pros:
I work in Cisco Security services,  and the last 2 years have been horrible.    This used to be a great company and great culture.  The last 2 years over,  great caring and capable managers have been replaced with newbies who operate without a care for employees and in lockstep with the new senior management.

Sadly,  much of the senior management is now from places like Pepsi and sourcefire.  These senior folks are dishonest, calculating and manipulative.   They also have super fragile egos and fire people for simply knowing more than they do.
Cons: Having Cisco on your resume used to be a huge strength.  But nowadays it's becoming a liability in the job market.   That combined with the annual summer picnic and layoff,  it's become a truly bad place to work.

Pros:
Overall, Cisco is a pretty great place to work!
-Great benefits like stock options, cheap health insurance, volunteering time off and donation matching, remote work options, the list goes on.
-Endless learning and job opportunities. Ability for stretch assignments to try other job roles or locations. Emphasis on self training and certifications to help further your career.
-Work with some of the smartest people in the industry. Great mentorship programs to learn from the best and get career advice.
-Leadership and executives that are receptive to change, new ideas and transparency.
Cons:
-Big company. A bit overwhelming at times. Can be hard to find resources or people necessary to perform your job.
-Annual layoffs without an emphasis on retraining current talent.

Pros: Nobody tells you where to draw the line or what not to do, as long as you get the job done. You will have sufficient time to explore any relevant technology and get your hands dirty. Cisco Bangalore has state of the art lab facilities, ample and regular in house training options. From hardware design standpoint, we are given opportunities on par with what happens at San Jose, maybe with a 1-2Q delay but good work does eventually reach our shores.  The management is transparent top down and recognitions are promptly awarded where due. Pay is on merit and merit is greatly valued with limited scope for internal politics and cronyism. Overall, a great place to be in.
Cons: Sometimes you will doubt hardware's relevance in Cisco's long term 'No.1 IT company' strategy.  Market dynamics change pretty fast, especially in the Service Provider world.

Pros: Cisco has a great work culture. Employees are very helpful and care about each other. If you need help you can ask anyone. Very happy to have these colleagues, since a lot of my questions can be quickly answered due to the experience some others already have. Besides working hard, Cisco also makes sure that the work/life balance is good. They do this by organizing regularly drinks, parties and family events such as Sinterklaas and a summer BBQ.  Besides that we have a yearly sales event in Vegas, this truly shows that the management want to invest in us to keep up our knowledge and get excited for the new fiscal year.
Cons: At the end of the quarter it can be very busy with regards to reaching your and your team's target.

Pros: Great culture, promoting work/life balance and flexibility; great benefits; great talent and people; the good managers I had were excellent
Cons: The company restructures every 6-12 months, so job security can be limited. I transitioned into a new role in a time when things were settling from a restructure, in a team with a new, very politically motivated leader, and the people involved in my hiring jumped ship and found new roles internally and externally. I really felt like the company let me down, as I kind of got lost in the shuffle, despite my efforts to speak up. If I had stayed in my original role, or if the timing had been better, I think I'd likely still be employed there. BUT they do provide excellent support to those whose jobs are cut, through a strong severance and support services for looking both internally and externally to find a new job.

Pros: flexibility in work schedule, an actual career path and planning ensures growth, as an employee you can take advantage of all the programs, interest groups, organizations whose operations range from the larger corporate culture to a very personal level of your team -- given the opportunity to hone your development experience within a well managed process.  no matter what stage you are at in your career, you will always find yourself learning from someone - or you'll find bright, freshness, and motivation of youth that could use the mentoring of an experienced professional.  you can really live the 9-5 life and be fine, or if your bursting with that 'start-up' spirit, management will not hesitate to compensate and recognize your efforts.
Cons: pay - known and admittedly so that top dollar isn't paid to it's employees.

Pros: Access to the best technical resources and people to do your job and learn. You get the opportunity to work hard and be rewarded for your efforts but there isn't so much pressure that you can't enjoy your family life. There is so much information and training on the internal cisco web that the thought of losing access once I leave cisco is quite upsetting. Anyone interested in computer networking much aim to work for cisco system.
Cons: The HR department is a bit of a monster. I sometimes wonder if the marketing team is pitching something that is a bit fluffy and touchy feely to be appreciated by the people who actually buy and use our equipment.

Pros: The environment is respectful of people. Information is openly shared among teams. Management is accessible for conversations even cross-functionally.  Benefits are good, and internal tech support is very helpful.
Cons: There are significant re-organizations every 3 months for the past 2 years.  With all the upheaval and change in players, projects are delayed and canceled.  No decisions are made.  Everything requires so much cross-functional alignment and agreement that nothing is ever decided and implemented.  Many projects in my division have been ongoing for several years without real progress...simply re-organizing and re-naming initiative something new without business results.  Funding is constantly reduced.  Employees are disillusioned with the lack of traction and completion, and leadership has lost its sense of the competitive marketplace.

Pros: Can live your own life without being bothered too much... Availability of internal training which would otherwise be very expensive. Very good medical benefits.
Cons:
Cisco is just too big. Most of the people are career hungry, but there's little opportunity to grow for 99% of the people that are there. It's a mostly Indian company (in my team of 20, there were 18 indians) and they just work differently from most of the other American companies.

They try to put a lot of pressure on engineers; I thought a company like cisco would go for the "correct" solution rather than the quick hack. False.

In Cisco, staying at the office 10 hours is better (i.e. gives you more visibility) than staying at the office 8 hours and be REALLY productive. It's all about "cover your ass". Not my ideal job.

Pros: Collaborative, smart, fun people. Work/life balance is respected and encouraged. Changing jobs internally is encouraged and necessary to prevent stagnation. World class benefits. Outstanding high level leadership, middle management less so.
Cons: Too often there are simply too many people on projects and in meetings which hinders ownership, accountability, and progress. While pay is in line with industry and geographic location advancement and compensation increases are very hard to come by which is the nature of such a large organization. You can move around to different roles across the company fairly easily but that doesn't really translate to pay increases or promotions. Global nature of teams and work means meetings will cut into personal time. Company is highly San Jose centric - partly understandable but no less frustrating at times for those in remote locations.

Pros:
good comapny to work
to the success of our customers, bringing a passion for invention that has fueled our 60-year history: We created digital TV, delivered the first wireless broadband gateway and are pioneering the standards and pathways for tomorrow's personalized, Ultra HD, multiscreen, and cloud services. We are dedicated to meeting today's challenges and preparing for the tasks the future holds. Collaborating with our customers, ARRIS will continue to solve the most pressing challenges of 21st century communications.
Cons:
hell lot of work
to the success of our customers, bringing a passion for invention that has fueled our 60-year history: We created digital TV, delivered the first wireless broadband gateway and are pioneering the standards and pathways for tomorrow's personalized, Ultra HD, multiscreen, and cloud services. We are dedicated to meeting today's challenges and preparing for the tasks the future holds. Collaborating with our customers, ARRIS will continue to solve the most pressing challenges of 21st century communications.

Pros: A solid company that overall treats its employees well.  Good benefits, with ability to work from home every now and then.  A lot of smart and talented people, both in Development and in Supply Chain organizations.  Lots of challenging and interesting projects.  Employee recognition methods are changing for the better.
Cons: For a new product that has not yet "proven" itself in the market, resources are often minimal, so people get spread pretty thin.  The hours can get long for long stretches of time.  The top management can sporadically change direction, and years' worth of work can go down the drain.  Cost-cutting has led to a lot of churn with contractors and off-shoring.

Pros: Amazing people and partners.  Good compensation and benefits.  Work from home allows good work life balance.  Although work is on 24/7
Cons: No one is safe.  Annual and sometimes semi annual layoffs with no way to predict if your on the chopping block other than being over 40 and at the mid-top of your pay grade.  There is no loyalty anymore to its employees.  People put in 10-15-20 years and get a 30 min call with their manager and they are let go.  Gone are the days that John Chambers used to say that he wanted people to retire from Cisco... tell their kids and grandkids how they loved working at Cisco.  Now its all about the shareholders.

Pros: Specific teams have great people, I'm sure this is true of any company. Really good work-life balance since virtual culture was embraced long ago. Hiring from outside brings fresh perspectives.
Cons: Lack of diversity, and a diversity office/leaders that has little idea of what it does but catch phrases that make it appear as if it's doing something. Should be entirely revamped with people who truly care about diverse workforces and perform. Ongoing policy of laying off an older workforce. It's sad to see great partners being let go over the past 4-5 years. Migrating internal technologies get launched too often, right when we get a grip on the one that was just launched.

Pros:
- Good benefits that are constantly being updated to be best in the industry
- Compensation practices that encourage fair pay
- Autonomy in job
Cons:
- Cisco says their leaders are transparent and "have your back," but leaders do not give feedback and won't help their employees progress in their careers.  
- All the acquisitions make Cisco a very segmented and unfair place.  Different treatment for many of our big acquisitions still exist and their is no timeline to create a 1 Cisco mentality.
- Management doesn't like the HR processes, systems, and tools created to make a transparent, listening, fair, and engaging environment so employees suffer.

Pros: -	Work from home options.  401K match, ESPP and top of the industry pay (unless you were acquired).
Cons:
-	Career progression is somewhat ambiguous.  
-	Big company with bureaucracy and a lot of red tape – It’s tough to get anything done with any type of speed.  
-	Sr. Management is more consumed with inter-office politics and hidden agendas than getting the job done, and doing it right.  
-	Outdated technologies to run the business effectively and efficiently.  
-	Impossible to innovate and be a thought leader

Pros: Flexible work hours and great ability for work/life balance. Excellent benefits and good salary across the board. Generally very good people to work with and good culture that gives back to the community.
Cons: Constant change and lots of politics. Frequent changes to upper management who have little to no regard to those on the team w/deep experience. Many egos and difficult people brought in to lead some groups - and then they lead by bringing in their people and playing favs. Also, you'll find Execs w/little Marketing experience w/big titles. Continued changes to Marketing team w/lots and lots of process. Multiple changes on-going and about every 3 years the entire model gets shaken up.  Disappointing that Chuck lets this all go on.

Pros: Great environment to work in with both peer and management support. Heavy emphasis on digitization with cloud-based applications taking case of much of the rudimentary tasks.
Cons: Cisco is the process of re-establishing itself in the new global climate that strongly favors a 'XaaS' business model and, a company the size of Cisco takes time to reset its course although its well underway in the transition and has done admirably well. However, until transition the complete, there are bound to be re-prioritization of initiatives & re-alignment of resources.

Pros:
I really loved working here.
Tech stack is totally dependant on team, but I got to work on hot technologies like Kafka, Cassandra etc.
Teammates were amazing and supportive. Work life balance was great. There were many team lunches, team outings and other activities. This depends on how enthusiastic your team is, but overall Cisco is a chill place.
Campus is amazing. You can sit and work even from the chai point. 
Overall it's a great place to work
Cons:
Pay is on the lower side, and increments are not that great.
It can get a bit lethargic, so might not be the best place to start your career.
However, it's also a bit risky later in your career, too, as you can get laid off without any warning. Entire teams are laid off. Now, the lay off is very fair ( extremely good compensation is given), but can be a bit stressful if you are high up in the ladder.

Pros:
new technology adoption
like the new work location, bldg 14, Mccarthy Ranch
Cons:
worst planning and work ethics
worst project execution
need to be 24/7 support
I've been supporting all nights (atleast till 1 pm) and many weekends but no appreciation
bottom and middle managers are highly corrupted
after several complaints to HR and ethics there is no progress
too many outside contractors
too many offshore - india activities with very less quality of service
totally it is in disaster
Managers are focussed only on their performance rather company's
I see the cisco is following nortal, motorola,3com 
in near future this company might bankrupt or loose it charm (today they might be cash rich but the company is going into a bad direction)
