And right behind them are the people just waiting to take credit for things they had nothing to do with.

Pros: Good benefits, cares about sustainability, cares about security and often has training on new technologies.
Cons: Only the top 5% of employees get to move onto hot products.  When Cisco needs revenue, they buy a hot startup product. When the product is growing, staff will be added in India. If your product is not growing fast, work is moved to India. USA staff will be cut every quarter until the USA team is gone and the remaining India team is cut until the product is killed. Rinse repeat for every startup bought. Cisco is circling the same whole as Computer Associates, Wang, Stratus...

Pros: Interesting work, great colleagues and a fantastic approach to flexible working. I've found the company are happy to  support any combination of office location,  (or multi-locations in my case), home working and flexible hours to make your life work. Basically, as long as you're professional about getting the work done and being responsive for your collegues, you can be very flexible about configuring  your work day and location(s). Presumably there are some roles where Cisco can't be so flexible, but my experience in technical work is that there are few limitations.
Cons: Some admin processes are cumbersome, although they've improved recently.

Pros:
Work life balace, 11am-5pm is common.
After tax 401k with roth in plan conversion 
Easy to exceed expectations.
If you are of same culture as a BU’s upper management, you’ll be treated like royalty.
Cons:
Unless you are joining as grade 13+,  don’t come here.

Their titles are washed down and randomly thrown around.  The execution is crap from top down, they present a grand vision but sits around with no action items.

If you are starting out your career in engineering, stay away.  Other function are great; sales, marketting, finance, product, etc.

If you are ending your career or seek work life balance, this is your dream job.

Pros: Cisco is an awesome company to start (and grow!) your career. The culture supports and encourages internal movement, so whether you join in your dream role and stay, or decide you want to switch to a different team and learn a new part of the business, you'll find your home at Cisco. Another benefit is the opportunity to work with peers around the world using Cisco's own collaboration technology and build a diverse, global network.
Cons: Not all companies are perfect. Cisco could do better when it comes to standardizing on-boarding for new employees and explaining pieces of the business, especially to people just starting their careers. But the Early Career Network is a great global resource for those who are new to Cisco to build a cross-functional network and start to feel engaged and involved with the company.

Pros:
high degree of flexibility (home/remote-office whenever you like, as long as you get the job done)
competent salary (basic salary + bonus)
a young, and dynamic team of competent internationals
huge variety of further trainings possible (internal & external)
receiving state-of-the-art technology (smartphone and notebook is a minimum)
open workplace
open-minded environment
pragmatic approach during projects
Cons:
due to the constant changes (senior management) also the direction of the business unit constantly changes, which gives a slight feeling of uncertainty
even though it is one of the biggest IT companies worldwide, the company empowers their salespeople more than their hard-working engineers (often a feeling of not giving engineers the same respect as their sales-reps)
constantly moving many high-competent positions to countries in which the salaries are lower (Poland, India) in order to save money

Pros:
I've been with Cisco 12 years,  I had the opportunity to come through the CSAP/ ASE training program.  There is no other program in the industry that can match the resources they provide you to take new talent and ensure they are successful, for the good of the individual and the company. 

Opportunity exist every way you look, whether that is training to stay, evolve, and enjoy your current role or transition to another. 

The company truly feels like family. I think they do have your best interest in mind with the majority of the decisions they make.

Great benefits, outweigh 20% pay increases I've evaluated at other jobs.
Cons:
Mid Level management sometimes isn't great.

It seems they are unable to fire individuals that  aren't pulling their weight, often these individuals exist for years before they are terminated.

Pros: I've been at Cisco a little over a year and I love it more every day! My coworkers are amazing and the culture of the company is phenomenal! I can't say enough about this company! I've never worked at a place where I am happy to go to work every day.
Cons: That I didn't start working here sooner because a lot of the people that I work with have been here for at least 5 years some 20 - YUP it's that awesome!

Pros: Having a job there led to a much better role at a better company…
Cons:
I worked at Cisco leading one of the AR teams, and I have to say that this was THE worst culture I have been part of. I had nightmares about the role after quitting for about six months, and every time I had to speak with my toxic director manager, I would have heart palpations starting the night before because she was absolutely awful. There is a micro culture of submission on the Comms team because anyone who disagreed with anything was pushed out. I wouldn’t recommend Cisco to anyone.

Plus they lowballed me in the leader role I was given by offering me exactly what I made in the position I left for Cisco, but they finally “relented” and offered me 1k more to lead a team. Pffft

Pros:
- Good Benefits
- Work schedule flexibility
- Good compensation
- Good technology
Cons:
- Has gotten too political over the past couple of years
- Lost its way.. Too much focus on being a “Great Place to work” and not enough on project strategy.
- Always playing catch-up to competitors and not enough trail blazing innovation.
- Identity crisis.. Wants to be a Software company but still focused on hardware

Pros: The environment within the sales dept is very collaborative and almost everyone is willing to offer advice when asked. Promotions are about who you know but good work performance is still recognized and called out. If you don't work and only do the bare minimum then it will take alot longer to get promoted and recognized amongst such a large company.
Cons: The beaurocracy and red tape makes it extremely difficult to voice an opinion about an oncoming change. Management listens but makes very little change unless its complaints from a large majority. Very metric based company. Company seems to constantly be undergoing some sort of small or large reorg but from what I've seen, very little downsizing has happened.

Pros:
Product Managemen in Cisco is a good place to learn what makes it achieve market leadership in the sectors where it is number 1 or 2. And also learn why it is not able to achieve leadership in other sectors and smaller competitors are able to.

Cisco provides a good benefits package especially the health care plans.
Cons: Several of the markets Cisco is in have reached saturation point so earning more revenues is difficult. Also being a big company it is designed more for process efficiency to crank out products at lowest cost and highest margin. That structure makes it difficult at times to introduce new products.

Pros: Great empowerment and responsibility provides opportunity and exposure.  Superb culture.   Good compensation allows Cisco to attract top talent.  On-going competitive advantage, customer benefit and innovation.  Very good reasons why this is a top place to work and all employees are well-regarded.
Cons: Overall growth is gone.  There are still growth areas of the business if you are looking for more opportunity for advancement.  Go-go years are gone and good execution is now the needed.

Pros:
work life balance.
if you want to do CCIE  you get 3 attempts free here.
if you are frequent traveler you can do wfh when you are at home.
Cons:
promotions are not based on performance, its given to  people who know to talk unnecessarily in meetings
My performance rate is E+ (which means im in top 25%) there ha.s been no hike for the last 3 
years inspite of the fact that the company is doing well in the market. lot of employees are angry on this issue.

Pros: Some great people still work here, but many are leaving
Cons: Once you reach a level of experienced individual contributor there is nowhere else to go.  Focus is on bringing in outside folks to dazzle the business but really its just smoke and mirrors.  There are some great people aching to be recognized and getting a bit fed up with the corporate musical chairs.  Having been here almost 10 years I have never had a manager with more experience than me in our subject matter area - I don't even want to think about how many people I've trained to go on to bigger roles while I sit here as a SR. SME

Pros: Great benefits, can't complain about pay and progression. Always treated well and rewarded adequately for good work.
Cons: Large fiefdoms in the company, with high-mid/upper management always focusing on improving careers. Have to leave company and work at start-ups to do any real innovation that requires risk.

Pros: If you are agressive in nature, have a slightly pushy personality, you are more than able to advance your career and influence your peers and management.
Cons: You have to be willing to take a more individual path versus having your team contribution/influence equal individual win. Succeed at the cost of others -

Pros: They pay level is on the higher side of the range.
Cons: There was a lot of terrible managers. People who had been promoted into management that should never of been a manager. There seem to be a lot of the "good ole boy" treatment also. too many managers not enough workers. How does a company purchase a camera company in these times when all phones have a camera built in? That was a loss from the start.

Pros: Work-life balance.  For me, working from home is one of the best things I've ever done.  Work more than I probably did when in the office, but it's balanced.  Most people truly are interested doing the right thing (if they're not, I don't think they last).  You have access to anyone and everyone.  Make sure you value and respect their time, but they'll give you time if you prove your worth. Most people truly seem to care about you as a person.
Cons:
Move so quickly that strategy seems to change continuously.  Don't get to used to something, because it may change next month.

They're HUGE on acquisitions.  And large acquisitions can go EXTREMELY poorly.

Pros: As the IT industry giant, Cisco hold very complete product line, also has a relatively high market share. For young people, is a good place to display their talent, learning foreign culture. The company is relatively stable,  providing salary and benefits in the medium level in the industry.
Cons: The scale of the company expanded too fast, especially in recent years, the number of employees is growing too fast. Similar with those giant companies, the company has the inevitable emergence of internal bureaucratic, slow response to market changes and competition. More and more policies and procedures within the company, account team need to waste a lot of time dealing with internal affairs. Wages have also gradually became less competitive.

Pros: You get to work on cool technology but it comes at a huge price.  Despite the 20-word minimum, it is extremely difficult to come up with 20 positive words to describe this hellhole.
Cons: There is no work/life balance.  Cisco is like the Borg.  You are assimilated into a culture of work at a sweatshop pace.  Those who do their 40 and met all job expectations are "managed out of the business."  First level managers are promoted based on who they know.  Supervisors lack management experience and management philosophy changes every time the wind blows.  Lots of back-stabbing SE managers who only look out for #1.  Constant morale improvement efforts (mandatory fun).  Morale is low.

Pros: At the time I worked here, there were standard guidelines and processes. The people I worked with were always team players and willing to help and do their part.  The company has strong ethical code of conduct.
Cons: Workload is very high and sometimes people are put into mgt roles when they are not qualified and not given any training.  Several years ago, an employee was put through management training before coming eligible to be promoted to a first line manager. Because of the restructuring and layoffs, people are pushed into mgt positions before they are qualified and there is no mentoring. The staff reporting under these managers also suffer.  Employees are asked to move into a manager roles without the title and pay increase.

Pros: Cisco is high technology so there are constant learning opportunities.  Cisco is well respected in the industry.  Cisco has high integrity so you can count on Cisco to do the right and fair thing.  Employees are given good benefits and are well paid.  Cisco offers flexible work hours.  Cisco generally promotes from within.
Cons: The engineering organization is very product focused creating internal politics, internal competition, and overlapping solutions.  The approach leads to snowflake solutions that are too often not easier to integrate together than a bunch of disparate vendors.

Pros:
Cisco is a nice place to work for the most part. It really depends on the group that you are.
Some BU's people work like crazy and products have huge revenue. "you want to be in one of these BU's". If the BU you are working has little or low growth forget about any career advancements or innovations.  
Compensation is fairly OK
Cons:
If you are in a stable BU, not much happens and if you are not careful you will end up doing the same tasks everyday.
After 5 years working for Cisco everyone outside of this company will be reluctant to wire you.
Compensation is almost direct of how many years you are in Cisco.

Pros: Great product and balance sheet.  Senior management turnover is out of control. Good employee benefits.
Cons: 30% contract workforce is not saving as much money as management thinks it is.  How does a company retain SME knowledge with that type of structure?  It doesn't.  And it is chaotic and expensive.  HR is the worst I have experienced of any large company I have worked for.  Middle management are largely incompetent, many reaping the benefits of significant hiring 15 years ago and are now operating by the Peter Principle.  Employee morale is not very good amongst those who built this company during it's first 15-20 years.  Many are leaving with their knowledge.

Pros: Smart, considerate co-workers.  Open and honest environment.  A CEO who cares about people more than anything else. Huge investments in diversity and work/life balance.  Trust and integrity valued above all.
Cons: You have to be resilient and flexible, the company is moving fast and you need the agility to keep ahead of the changes even though they are the right ones.  Team achievements valued above individual performance, if you are a solo artist you would be better off elsewhere.

Pros:
-Still some amazing people to work with and endless learning opportunities
-If you are early in career, this is currently the place to be
-Very flexible work schedule in most positions with a lot of latitude to work remotely
Cons:
-If you are middle aged white male demographic, you have a better chance of becoming the morning weather girl than to advance
-Bloated corporate structure -- lot of unwritten rules about moving into new positions (did you do this job and this job first, etc.)
-Lack of excitement and lot of turnover right now...lot of long time pros are leaving the company which could be pro or con depending on your perspective.

Pros: Good place to work, nice atmosphere with great training center. A person can learn more good things in this organization.
Cons:
I faced the consequences that without informing that the BU will close. an immediate action was taken from the management that entire Bangalore R&D of Tandberg Cisco was removed from the Cisco Management. 

In global market Tandberg was ruling entire market. Cisco acquired @ good rate later Tandberg NTT was washed and closed the entire R&D department in Bangalore. Cisco is being doing from years Acquire company by shares & remove the employees.

Pros: Overall Compensation, Benefits.  Great place to develop and learn.  Used to be filled with diverse, talented workforce, but things have changed over the years.
Cons:
Lack of ethnic diversity in Engineering.  If you're not part of the friends and family program, you will quickly get discouraged by the unethical work environment, favoritism, hiring practices, and promotions. 

Work life balance:   Heard of groups demanding engineers to come work on Sundays while preaching to have fun.    

Over the years through numerous restructuring and reorgs, they've lost key talent to maintain and keep quality of core software

Pros: Many good talented and dedicated people.  If they can get a consistent vision and strategy it is not too late.
Cons: What was once a company of the best and brightest in the industry is being replaced with entry level or outsourced resources in an effort to keep costs down.  Regular quarterly reductions in force have everyone looking over their shoulder and fearing the next cut.  Employee Innovation and inspiration has been replaced with fear and top down direction.  No one wants to rock this unstable boat.  Those left behind are looking for careers outside of a Cisco before they are hit next layoff.

Pros: many awesome elements of the company
Cons: Cisco HR wants to "help" managers by hard coding tools so that managers are "in empowered" to reward employees as they sit fit.  For example, once a manager wants to promote an employee there is a guideline on how much pay would accompany that promotion. However Cisco HR takes it too far; the pay HAS to be a certain amount, can't exceed a certain and must come out of a budget deemed promo budget. A leader who is managing within their budget is completely crippled by the rules HR sets around how to manage the team & rewards.  Its ridiculous and completely contradictory to "The People Deal".

Pros:
Salary/Pay is good at hiring
Good Work Culture
Flexible timings 
Good PTO policy
Best Campus & Infrastructure
Health & Medical benefits good, best in industry
Insurance policy also good
Nice bonuses for top performers
Transfer to other BU
Nice Labs
Good Facilities
Career growth good
No timesheet
Work from home unlimited
Good place to learn
good ESPP plan
Best office  cafeteria in Bangalore
Cons:
too many re-orgs
too many seat change
High attrition
stability in job can be little risky
too much BU dependent (some good , some bad)
Hike is less , communication gap w.r.t. hike
Hike every year may not be there; irregular hike and very less percentage
No transparent Promotion policy
Partiality, favoritism
BU/Mgmnt may not be favourable
Little BU politics
No Fair treatment for Men, women get favors
lack of project stability
lack of new tech work
no or very few stocks up to G-8
no hiring bonus

Pros: The benefits are great.  Not many companies in this area can compete.  Love the ability to work remote when needed.
Cons: Pay increases and promotions are hard to come by.  The managers tend to favor the same people.  The only way to get anywhere is to quit and come back a year later at higher pay and higher level.  Have to do a weekly report to managers about what you are working on.  Silky if your manager is 50 feet away.  If my manager doesn’t know what I am working on and needs me to send them a report, I think the manager is out of touch with employees and needs to so their job.

Pros: Good salary, employee benefits, campus
Cons: The manager was the worst I ever had in my carrier, he didnt have any clue about what was happening or what needs to be done and would just suck up to the higher management, who would support him even though the entire team has escalated about him. He would talk bad behind the backs of his subordinates and call them names with subordinates peers. There was too much politics in the upper management with everyone trying to make their peers look bad in front of their boss'. There was also too much politics between Bangalore and San Jose counterparts, with San Jose clearly having an upper hand. Old timers have their own way of staying in the company and literally can get away with anything and everything (experienced first hand). Very late night (IST) meetings. HR is highly ineffective.

Pros: Work/life balance, flexible working conditions, endless training. Monetary perks available. Pre-covid, ability to travel and meet customers as needed.
Cons: Bureaucratic, layers upons layers of management. But this is a typical large tech company, so not surprising. You may just be another cog in the larger machine, and its easy to get lost in the fray amongst your peers or organization. Their culture mimics the company's growth rate - slow and steady. If you're looking for a fast-paced, exciting environment where you can tangibly experience the fruits of your labor, this is not it.

Pros:
1. Work culture is amazing although it may depend on individual team.
2. Smart work and innovation will be recognised. 
3. Everyone is pretty cool (again depends on your team culture).
4. Learning opportunities is pretty much endless. Lot of support from managers given your goals align with the organisation as a whole.
Cons:
1. Salary growth YOY might be slow but that is expected given the large size of the company and other benefits it provides. Again if you are exceptional candidate then it will still grow at very good pace. 

2. Like most US companies, I feel there is significant stress between India-based teams and US /SYD based teams. Completely different dynamics.

Pros: Given full autonomy to manage your customer and projects in the way that you see fit, never the smartest person in the room so always learning. Great support from teammates and organization.
Cons: Not paid enough, mediocracy is tolerated and generally the norm, for a technical position in services, access to labs is hard to achieve, constantly put in a position where you are "the expert" even though you are barely trained or have one project under your belt. Constantly over worked and management is obsessed with farming out work to "cost centers" aka lower paid employees.

Pros: Cisco cares about the employee and the environment as well as the shareholders.  Cisco is an influential company with a large stake in the development and health of the global economy.  People listen to you more carefully when you have a Cisco logo on your card.  No other company has the ability to take risks and execute strategy the way that Cisco does.  Leadership at Cisco means just that - it's a company that really values the ability of creative people to inspire greatness in others.  Fair compensation and good benefits.
Cons: It's a large company and process can sometimes become cumbersome.

Pros: Lots of Autonomy; Hands off yet highly supportive managers; I get to run my team as an entrepeneuer; interesting, critical, varied work; surrounded by really smart people; great benefits, including dental and 401k matching - the best I've seen; Management transparency, frequent communications, dynamic leaders; reasonable perks; excellent training and development programs; stellar sales team
Cons: salaries do not track the industry or cost of living; some VPs are incompetent; things are starting to move too slowly with new bureaucracy; tools and systems may be somewhat cumbersome

Pros:
1) Good salary compared to others in same domain
2) Amazing talent around [people writing RSUs and ITU docs are here]
3) Highly aggressive co  when it comes to technology and innovations
4) good work culture
5) stock options
Cons:
1) pressure sometimes gets on the higher side. . Its not evenly distributed.
2) Promotions are not so frequent but then exceptions are made for exceptional talent
3) very few travel opportunities [it matters to middle class ppl in india]
4) Too many ppl. You might go unnoticed
5) Recruitment  drives are getting aggressive and level of new hires falling

Pros: Large, mature company - good overall benefits, esp. SJ campus - Onsite Daycare, Onsite Gym, Good number of cafetarias. Eventhough predominantly routing and switching, It now has branched out to more technologies. Global company - opportunities for people with constraints to find something internal if needed to relocate. Helps community. Chambers at the helm. #1 in market share in primary businesses and within the top few in new ventures.
Cons: Work environment depends where you end up within Cisco. Experience can range from very good to extremely poor. Has become a mature company - if you are young and hungry, no longer the right place to be at (except in pockets within Cisco). Given mature, no longer work and/or attract top talent.

Pros:
Cisco is still a good company, good starting salary and weekend shift loading, it gave equal opportunity for engineer to make the same amount regardless their grade.

the bonus is ok, better than those promises-but-never-see company.

Training and material is great, you will find lots of stuff to learn and grow you technical skills.
Cons:
the rewarding scheme is poor, engineers are working long hours and extra miles to reach the MBO, but not getting rewarded.

the pay raise is non-existent.

very hard to get promotion.

Pros: Cisco has great people and a strong culture with its pros and cons.  Most of the time messages and information from senior management are direct and honest.  It will likely continue to be a very strong player in networking unless there are major management blunders.
Cons: Cisco has grown considerably in the past years and has those growth pains.  The culture has changed more for the negative than positively.  The level of bureaucracy has grown and can make obtaining funds in an organization extremely painful.  A large percentage of people don't feel they are recognized and rewarded fairly.

Pros:
Big company with decent benefits and opportunities to work from home.
Good talent with lots of software experience.
Cons:
Little training allowed during the job (not enough time or department money for classes).
Manager turn over is very high (I've had more managers than years worked there).
Hard to see direct connection to customer with products you are working on (too many layers of people in between).
Yearly layoffs with little concern for talented people affected has created a bad morale situation.

Pros:
- Generally treats people well, but it all depends on what group you work in.
- Again depending on where you work, flexible telecommuting and life-balance policy/philosophy
- If in San Jose, many opportunities in working on different products and job roles. Less so at other campuses.
Cons:
- Inconsistent culture. In some areas, very progressive with an emphasis on engineering. In other areas, the culture is stale, losing focus on innovation and "the people".
- Company as a whole struggles to cultivate innovation. When push comes to shove, company acquires innovations
- Most opportunities are in San Jose. Much less at branch campuses.
- Need to flatten org, especially at the senior management level. Senior management/execs seem to focus on "their next job", often impacting long-term viability of product/group
- Compensation has become less competitive.

Pros: Cutting edge new technologies, great people, lots of flexibility that allows to balance your life with work especially if you have children. Great opportunities for learning/keeping your education up-to-date.  The dream company to work for.
Cons: Greatest challenge is to be prepared to get laid off at any time disregards of being a top performer/greatest innovator/young talent. However, Cisco takes good care of those who was let go, helping to find a new job.

Pros: Compensation is still good. Dominant market share.
Cons: No such thing as job security.   Top performers routinely hit with LRs.  The yearly Layoffs are jokingly referred to internally as the Hunger Games.  What appears to be a focused effort to actively "move people out" of the company that are "more experienced." that probably crosses the line into age discrimination.   I've gone from being one of the company's biggest supporters to someone that would/will jump ship as soon as I find another job.

Pros: The onsite medical facility, medical benefits, and the gym were excellent. Probably the only good thing about the place
Cons: Contributions only acknowledged if you are part of the right clique AND have been at the company for a million years. Not many subject matter experts and lots of things done in a very primitive fashion because management will not spend money to get things done. Executives seem to spend lavishly on themselves and seem overly compensated as individual contributors don't get so much as a cost of living raise and it is not uncommon for people to be at the same salary/grade level for years and years.

Pros: Cisco has some very difficult problems to solve and is a good place to find enterprise-level design issues in nearly all IT functions. Compensation is decent, more so if you are a remote contributor. Remote contribution is not only possible but the norm in many sub-groups within IT functions where that is possible. (i.e. web work)
Cons: If working through a vendor you may be required to fund your own travel to your department site and this may vary from occasional to often depending on function; this must be considered. Working with offshore teams is expected in many groups and this may result in some odd working hours. Culture can be poor to non-existent, especially for remote workers, be prepared to bring your own.

Pros: Cisco is a great place for a working mother.  The people you are surrounded by are smart, energetic and fun.  You have tremendous resources to help you be successful.   You will work hard but you are also paid well.
Cons: The culture is changing.  The senior management team is still trying to make their mark and find their way.  It is going to take some time and some pain to get through this transition.  Cisco needs to figure out how to stop the yearly "limited restructuring" and get the morale back on track.  It is not a happy place to be right now.

Pros:
1. Nice work environment.
2. The campus looks and feels great. probably one of the coolest offices I've ever seen. with tons of awesome facilities and perks.
3. Some fine people to work with.
4. Working in bleeding edge technologies.
5. Work from home facility.
6. A lot of short international business tours.
7. Good pay.
Cons:
1. Some of the managers are really bad. They don't have an ounce of contribution towards project or the company, but will always be there for some reason.
2. There's very little chance to go and work abroad for a long time.
3. There are a lot of sleepless nights for work pressure.

Pros:
If you find a great manager, you'll find a great place to work, supportive team, flexible conditions, remote working/telecommuting opportunities, ability to move around the organisation developing different experience and skills.
Compensation is fair, decent recognition and reward program.
Cons: Tighter budget and high compliance controls can leave a sour taste, teams are increasingly required to do more with less budget, many teams are over-worked. We no longer hire the top 10% of talent, no longer have the strong employer brand and culture we used to have.

Pros: Really interesting work. Good work life balance, depending on your current project and how much you worry about securing a system in the time you're given. Surprised at the group we've been able to hire and *mostly* keep. Smart, hard working co-workers you will always be learning from.
Cons:
Cisco doesn't give our group enough budget for promotions or raises to retain people. Talks a lot about how awesome we are, how appreciated our work is, fails to prove that.

Trusted to take on more and more responsibility but not good enough for promotion. Less and less time to look at more and more complex projects, while being expected to offer more help to the groups we work with and do more secondary tasks.

Pros: Work life balance is among the best in the bay area. The projects and skills engineers develop are second to none. Mentorship and career development are taken seriously here. For some reason, Cisco took a lot of bad rap for layoffs which a lot of other big tech companies also did, but nobody noticed. 1 year is Cisco is equal to many years in other big tech companies.
Cons: While compensation is not the greatest, Cisco pays better than many other tech companies. Also, Cisco is going through a transformation, which will take time to complete. So while pockets are working on cutting edge technology, there are still many teams working on hardware.

Pros:
Company overall does amazing things for communities around them, the environment and social justice. Also provide employees the ability to engage and contribute here.
Good opportunity for internal movement, advancement not as much.
There are A LOT of great people here, and learning new things on a daily basis is constant and rewarding.
Cons: Recent leadership changes have affected culture. There are many areas of the business where driving outcomes is done at expense of the people/team members. Decision making is becoming much less transparent. Favorites are protected and enabled.

Pros:
- Stress-free environment
- Best team you will meet
- Lots of social activities
- Lots of activities for your Kids
- Best medical insurance cover in town LUXMED VIP Package
- You have a voice and so respected 
- Great benefits as you cover all for you 
- One of the best companies for self developments and changing career path if you want 
- You can move internally very smoothly with support of your manager as its company culture
Cons:
- Most of the team work in USA California zone, so most of the meetings are late. of course they ask you to not join and watch the recordings on the next day but still sometimes it is an issue 
- Cisco is not paying the highest salaries in the market, therefore you might receive better offer from another company

Pros:
Great People to work with who are very knowledgable about technology, business processes and back office systems.

Cisco is supportive of it's employees learning new things, and in some instances will even pay a portion of the fees associated in obtaining an advanced degree.

Cisco provides more flexibility in working from home or in the office than any other company I know of.
Cons:
Promotions are few and opportunities for advancement are limited.  

Compensation doesn't keep pace with promotions, I know of people promoted to director who received fairly limited pay increases.

Additionally I recently hired someone and was apalled by the level of compensation they receive compared to peers.

Pros: It's a huge company now so you have good stability and they have a great severance package even if you do get laid off.  There are so many different product lines to sell at Cisco, that you never get bored and are always learning new things.
Cons: There is NO work life balance.  If you're in sales, you have weekly commits that are not good for the customers or the sales people.  A lot of political BS....give it another 5 years and it will be just like IBM.  The fist and second level management is, for the most part, quite weak.

Pros:
Great Work-Life balance. Very collaborative work environment. Plenty of opportunities for internal job transfers. Opportunities to learn many COTS and in house developed applications and processes. Great encouragement to the employees from the management for learning courses that contribute to career development, professional and personal growth. 
Employees in general take pride in working for Cisco and show belongingness to the company. Brand name is easily recognized through out the globe.
Cons: Too big a company, with many processes. Formal knowledge transition and standardised onboarding processes almost non existent or differ greatly across various organizations.  More than one person/team working on the same task without each other's knowledge.

Pros: The culture  - Cisco treats employees as adults.  In my experience, when there is a layoff, Cisco allows the person to continue to work to find a new job within Cisco.  They trust the staff to do no harm, and leave all access intact  often for two months.
Cons: Cisco will sometimes consolidate the workforce towards the main campuses.  Cisco also acquires many companies.  So if you work at a company that is acquired in an area far from San Jose, RTP, Boxbourgh or Richardson at some time you may have to move.

Pros:
Good use of technology. Co-workers are nice (depends on the group of course).
Fairly stable employment: People who were laid off were given decent severance packages.
Some interesting technology: options to move around since the company has diverse technology groups. 
Executive management (particularly Chambers) seems competent,.
Cons:
Compensation is an issue: people who join new are paid  more than existing employees, leading to dissatisfaction. Raises and promotions are hard to come by:  so if you don;t start off with a decent salary, you're mostly screwed.
Performance review seems completely arbitrary: your rating depends on who you are buddies with rather than your competence.
No stock options, selected few get RSUs

Pros:
-The people,made some great colleagues over the years and will miss them all.
-The offices, all are nice, modern and well appointed
-Benefits package, although the salaries aren't market-leading the overall benefits package is second to none...pensions,healthcare,insurance,stock purchase,options are all great
-The brand...did anyone ever get fired for buying Cisco ?
Cons:
-Middle management decisions often poor and made without insight or employee feedback
-Duplicitous and highly suspicious redundancy process, possibly legally challengable.
-Constant removal of small benefits eg.sodas, fresh fruit, specialty coffee, home broadband etc.. all to help "save" jobs...didn't work
-Too much reliance on "collaborative" technologies, not enough allowance for face to face customer time.

Pros: Cisco has a good overall package and the rewards scheme such as bonuses is above the industry standard.  Being a high-tech company there are a lot of big toys to play with and someone interested in systems would love the work we have.
Cons: However the company is very sales driven.  There is a lot of process and communication in place but often it hinder the technological implementation.  A lot of emphasis is put on delivery but this means quality suffers and some key elements in process improvement are overlooked as they don't derive immediate cost benefit even though long term they are proven to be key money savers.

Pros:
* A true implementor of work life balance
* Above market average pay
* Excellent technology
* excellent work conditions, 
* lots of benefits that a lot of employees do not use all of them!
* empowered AM to deliver
Cons: If a non-performing or anti-performing mid-management exists is difficult for higher management to identify and get rid off. Usually mid management put barriers for individual contributors to talk to VP+.  Recent lay offs from the last 4 years deflated people and disoriented them

Pros:
Still, at is heart, it is a company who cares for its employees.   Unfortunately, this cultural attribute is inconsistent across the company.
New CEO is appearing to want to make big change - simplify, simplify, simplify!
Cons: I long for the days that bureaucracy and politics didn't get in the way of making innovation happen.   The last 5 years at Cisco have been tough.    Poor mid-management has created a mess when it comes to strategy and communications.   Attempts to innovate and evolve happen expediently in some orgs and at a snail's pace in others.

Pros: Flexible working good health benefits and salary. Not micro managed. Great brand and solutions to sell. Some great people you get to work with. Can be fun environment. Good opportunity to travel with job. Most people been their long time over four years so culture is a place where people happy with working for Cisco
Cons: Middle Management Boys Club hard to move anywhere everyone only cares about their own career. Promote people in the boys club. Currently employing early in careers to save money happy to cut back on sales people whilst middle management seem to grow. Lost in the crowd of people's own agendas

Pros: One of the best ''schools'' in the world for new technologies. It was like a river of knowledge that just kept on flowing and flowing, and would never run dry.
Cons: Some people feel frustrated when they see you succeed and get better results than them. So they will do all they can do make your life miserable, including bullying you and say all sorts of lies to get others to dislike you as well. It takes a lot of strength of character to handle that and come away with your Dignity intact, but it's possible, because I did it.

Pros: Flexible.  Employees take one month or more of vacation and it's always approved.  Can work from home occasionally.
Cons: Moving up the ladder has nothing to do with your work and more to do with who likes you.  It has always been the culture at this company.  Often hard working employees are ignored because they are not loud enough to speak up and they are quiet and most of the time, management or another person takes credit for the work that someone else did.

Pros: Gym and health facility, large campus with 3 cafeterias and one specialty coffee shop, casual dress code, large parking lots with plenty of parking, new managers who care to succeed and improve, you are able to bring your laptop home and work from home if needed.
Cons: Layoffs every year create very low morale especially during year end which is in July.  When people do get laid off, those jobs go to people who are already working a full time job. You end up with people who are doing the job of 4 people which is unsustainable. It creates a bad reputation for that person and causes poor customer service because it is too much work for one person.

Pros:
The people are fantastic, personally and professionally.

Very good benefits.

Some of the projects are very interesting.

Perfect work life balance. I almost never take my work home with me.
Cons:
Being such a large company, your satisfaction will entirely depend on your current team and project.

Some of the projects are very boring.

There's lots of bad upper management.

Product managers don't know what they're doing.

Not much room for growth unless you have a manager that advocates for you.

There are many layoffs per year after Chuck took over, most of which come as a surprise.

Pros:
-I would recommend this job but for rapid learning and then leave to other company, this is what TAC is known for as well
-a lot of learning opportunities (certificates being paid)
-fast grow (this is somehow must though..)
-good compensation package
-office space
Cons:
-a lots of graduates in this "top" technical team  - Cisco TAC, answering most difficult customer questions
-Escalation teams/developers mostly based in Asia (not local), hired from outside with no experience,  very few engineers with experience
-senior people usually leave or migrate to less stressful teams (solutions supports, teams with much less load)
-nature of the job (stressful),  tons of cases, headcount doesn't reflect the number of cases, Management's hands tied up due to budget.
-smiling faces on Team lead, tech leads only who don't take cases
-life-work balance can be impossible if you want to "grow"
-life-span of TAC engineer is very short (50% of teams less than 2 years)
-TAC job becomes more and more difficult with "release-as-soon-as-possible" to catch the innovation wave, new products must be very unstable

Pros:
I started at Cisco through the award-winning Cisco Sales Associates Program (CSAP) and the amount of investment that Cisco put in to transform us into Cisco-grade engineers was unbelievable. There is always help around the corner only if you remember to ask!

As an Associate Systems Engineer, I was trained on Cisco's vast portfolio including Enterprise, Security, Data Center and Collaboration tools. We were encouraged to complete CCNA and CCNP certifications.

The work-life balance is probably the best thing about Cisco, next only to it's multi-cultural workforce. 

Shout-out again to CSAP that makes Cisco one of the best places to start your career at.
Cons: Leadership changes mean changes in the goals we're trying to achieve but in a dynamic industry like ours, I believe that's a necessity.

Pros: Cisco and it`s culture is giving the opportunity to work on the career path to each one of us. We have full data base of trainings and knowledge materials. Also must be mentioned the moment that in Cisco work the best engineers in the market. Together we are growing and thinking for the future, for making the world better place, as we acknowledge and love the diversity and forcing our self to think out of the box, never to felt bored and fall asleep in the comfort zone. The software defined technology is the future, and we are following that path.
Cons: Working  here is giving me the weight always to give more then i can, because i love and i enjoy being part of Cisco Family.

Pros: Flextime, and ability to move about to different groups and job roles while staying in the same company.  People are also very smart and talented.
Cons: Cisco has gotten too big and has lost control over its many organizations as a result each group operates more like a fiefdom regarding its basic employee policies, then an umbrella organization.  Also it would be nice if telecommuting was allowed across the board, rather at whim of manager.  Finally it would be nice if compensation model was more clear and applied across the board - somehow things got lost between CXO messaging and its application to each employee.

Pros:
You will gain much experience in a very short time because the expectation is always so high since day one.
During your career you need to develop your knowledge and skills and its a must, you will have a plan for your manager on what courses you will be taken during the year.
So far, the environment at cisco is multicultural and open in term of communication with upper management or any other departments.
Cons: You can never guarantee anything regarding your career, Cisco is a great place to work for, but never think about it as a life time job, and even if you could do so, be sure you have lost your life.

Pros:
Good Benefits
great vacation time
for the most part there are a lot of very intelligent people that work for Cisco
Cons: Middle Management has issues guiding, building and connecting a team

Pros: Reasonable salary, good benefits, 401(k) matching, Employee Stock Purchase Plan, RSUs, still the leading company for network equipment, company will be around a long time.
Cons: Unfortunately, Cisco is just not a really fun place to work.  It's almost impossible to start new projects or fund new product offerings.  There is a ton of process and the development pace is very slow.  The company is run by finance and upper management mismanages the company pretty badly which is why there has been a continual stream of layoffs and high attrition rates in many business units.

Pros:
Fantastic technology, great products and the ability to work with the very leading edge.  Excellent leadership at the top that always gave employees the impression that they really knew where they were taking the company and that they had a reason for doing so.  High gross margins on products mean that they were able to dedicate significant resources toward R and D and doing product development right.  The most ethical company I have been associated with.
Also pay was good.
Cons: As it turned into a larger company it has suffered from large company disease; specifically lots of bureaucracy and hundreds of little fiefdoms competing with each other, not always to the benefit of the company.

Pros: Cisco is a workplace filled with thoughtful, intelligent co-workers. The corporate culture emphasizes integrity, productivity, and collaboration. People are rewarded based on individual, team, and organizational effectiveness and, ultimately, results. Despite the mammoth size of Cisco, people are encouraged to experiment and innovate.
Cons: The sheer size of Cisco sometimes results in tricky cross-functional dynamics.  The management team has tried to address that with a variety of approaches, most famously with the management "counsels." There have been times when this uncertain environment has led to the company being influenced to take unexpected product diversions.

Pros: Cisco has not given up yet. There are enough experienced people to know how to get through tough times. Cisco has a solid run rate that could last them 20 years, key will be to keep the long view, like they had in the 90s
Cons: There is no top down leadership any longer. There has been a culture of consensus that anyone can say no but no one is able to make a decision. There is little to no upward mobility due to the hanger-on-ers that believe that selling boxes is the only way. The engineering is right Cisco foundation has been lost.

Pros:
Good work/life balance
Good salary and advantages for high-ranking employees
Attractive voluntary departure plan (PSE)
Cons:
Cisco's business is declining and Cisco is focusing a lot on external growth (company acquisition) to the detriment of its employee
My company was acquired 3 years ago bu Cisco failed to provide a clear direction. A lot was invested on projects which were then discarded.
The collaboration between all the R&D sites is not effective and there is lots of competition to the detriment of the products.
Management desision are often not understood.
Bonuses attribution is carried out in an opaque manner and depends a lot on ranking (higher ranked employees are favored).

Pros: Flexibility in schedule, company culture of inclusiveness, transparency, and willingness to help one's peers are all reasons I enjoy working for this company.  I have had many managers, and each one has created a positive team environment over the years... this is driven from the top down.
Cons: Like any company of its size, it can take a long time and involve a large number of people, to steer the ship.  I would love for Cisco to bring to market solutions more quickly than they sometimes do.

Pros:
Good for work life balance. I never had too much work. * to 4 job, sometimes had to attend interviews at night. 
Awesome campus.
AC innova cabs for transport.
Loads of events to win goodies.
Training sessions at company's cost.
Cons:
Everything is in manager's hand. If you are in good terms with manager, you get good work, otherwise end up with junk work always. 
Very tough to get promotions.
Salary hike is almost never. If you are joining, negotiate a very good package, joining bonus etc while joining itself. 
If you take sabbatical leave, you need to find a team on your own and need to go through 6+ rounds of tough interview again, though you are still an employee.

Pros: The people and benefits at Cisco are generally good.  The company is highly focused on areas of strategic importance and growth.  You want to work in one of these areas of the business.
Cons:
Not unique to Cisco, a high percentage of managers and above are only interested in promoting themselves.  Managers truly interested in developing members of their teams are rare.  If you are in an area of the business that is stable or declining you need to watch your back.
Limited Restructuring has become the norm for cutting headcount (costs) on a regular basis.  With few exceptions, senior management exempts themselves from such accountability resulting in productive people being cut.  Very little opportunity for advancement.

Pros:
Great resources; company tries to provide great benefits and tools to employees (it's just up to you to find them); excellent new executive leadership has vision and a plan.
Nice bonus structure and plenty of 'surprise' bonus opportunities
Supports a remote workforce, which made us all happier and more productive.
Cons: HUGE, matrixed and therefore, political company. Lots of 'territories.' Base pay is a little low. If your job requires international travel, they send you economy class! In my short time there (14 months), there were 3 large layoffs, and I think that's not unusual.

Pros: Cisco is a rapidly evolving, ambitious and forward thinking company at the cutting edge of the sector. Being part of the newly formed Customer Success function within the business is giving me an opportunity to help drive, shape and participate in one of the newest, most innovative roles in the business. As a large organisation, there are also a plethora of opportunities to branch off into other areas as my career with Cisco evolves.
Cons: As this is a relatively new role and function within Cisco, the processes and reporting are still quite new and would benefit from some refinement.

Pros: Team, products, ability to build strong customer relationships. Most Managers are transparent and have your back. Work Life Balance is real, not just talk. We work 60+ hrs a week but it works.
Cons: Business decisions made without field feedback at times, Managers are tried not to be as transparent as they say they are. Its big business.

Pros:
Stability - business throws off cash 
willingness to react in face of market disruptions - WebEx acquisition shows company understands that it needs to take risks to grow
Great senior leadership - Seasoned veterans who know what is going on in the space and can make decisions
Cons:
Bureaucratic - Move to matrix structure has made decision making very difficult and time consuming, also the council structure is confusing
Business Development, Engineering & sales  drive the business everyone else is along for the ride
Need to focus more on the end user as the company looks for growth in the consumer and small business market, stripping down enterprise solutions doesn't work

Pros:
1. my employer is very open about work life.  My schedule is pretty flexible, it fits my family and personal activities.
2. I the pay compensation is pretty competitive, I am fairly sastified with my compensation.  
3. I like the team members in my immediate group.
Cons:
1.  The annual review process is convoluted.  It takes up too much time and pretty irrevelant to what you going to get.  I think your annual review is already decided before you even start writting your review.
2.  I still don't understand the promotion process at cisco systems.  It seems like when an employee works beyond his or her responsibilities, the promotion should be award.  But that's not the case, there is a process that managers need to follow.

Pros: Stable, In the Bay Area, Lots of People to interact with. It's relatively easy going culture with many chill employees.
Cons: Large, Bureaucratic, lots of H1-B's. Just like any other huge large tech corporation, this is what you'll find at Cisco. These are not huge issues but something that gets to you over time. Not only that, the compensation, while not bad takes a much longer time to develop into something more substantial. But in this economy, the pay is still very good.  Cisco tends to have alot of meetings every week, which also turns to be a nuisance, since you have meetings constantly in the morning so you stay late to do the actual work.

Pros: If you're raising a family, and are looking for a stable employer with decent pay, good benefits and flexible working arrangements (in at least some parts of the company), Cisco is a good place to work. While there is a lot of big-company bureaucracy, much of it can be safely ignored by engineers.
Cons: Cisco is very slow to adopt new technology, and its development strategy, when there is one, is plodding at best. Product direction is more political than strategic, and much of the development effort is to play catch-up with what is already on the market. In many cases, internal wrangling prevents us from delivering the best product, even if we've already developed it. If you're looking to blaze new technology trails, Cisco has limited opportunities. You're better off working for a startup and angling to be bought by Cisco.

Pros:
You work with amazing people everyday.  How in tune you are with the organization's vision and the effort you put forth to contribute to that vision could reap benefits that go beyond recognition. 

You are encouraged to participate in job rotations every 2 years or so to expand knowledge and exposure.  You are expected to attend 40 hours of training yearly.  Part of that training could be giving the training.
Cons: Some team leads and managers manage remotely.  This is a relatively new model but the change is good.  It can be somewhat of a challenge to be visible but it stretches the individual's resourcefulness to make it possible.

Pros: This is my first 'real' job out of college - and I can say that the role I was hired into provides the right amount of challenge, as well as the room for growth that anyone could hope for. Working with a team where your opinions/contributions are valued, and expectations set within a reachable limit has helped me grow my own personal career, while pushing the limits of my job description, to the next level.
Cons: Sometimes that speed of work could be a bit slower than I would like - but I think that is due to the company being as large as it is. Lots of 'hurry up and wait' with the amount of collaboration my role utilizes.

Pros: [Engineering] Being a large company, Cisco needs all types of employees: slow and steady, ambitious, super talented and smart, to day-in day-out button mashers.  This is great if your're self-paced, because you'll be able to find your fit somewhere.  This is the flexibility I've mentioned, they accept all types of work ethics and styles.
Cons: If you're super ambitious, it may bother you that not everyone around you works as hard as you do or are as committedt.  They do exist, but as mentioned, Cisco employs all types.

Pros:
Compensation at the exec ranks (VP+) is very strong.
Work-life balance is reasonable.
Some elements of technological excellence, but not broad enough especially in software.
Cons:
Bloated management ranks
Overly finance driven company that is unwilling to place big bets on strategic areas of technology, except when it can buy companies.  No appetite to fund internal innovation at scale.
A strategy and incentive structure and go to market model that is still all about the past (selling big iron to big companies).
Very little understanding of or appreciation for great software talent.
IT organization is massively overwrought with little appetite for innovation or velocity.

Pros: Great Culture - everyone is driven to succeed and is very customer focused.  There are plenty of resources to help when you need them.  Lots of opportunity for career changes and advancement - if you you are at the right place at the right time.  Great Benefits.
Cons: Quota increases every year regardless of reality.  Makes multiple successful years impossible.  Recognition is a joke - expect a good steady paycheck but the years of blowing it out are only for those blessed with very low expectations.   Mediocrity is rewarded more than achievement.  Micromanaging is becoming suffocating.

Pros:
Worked for Cisco Video Technologies India Private Limited(CVTIPL, formerly called NDS) for three years. After the acquisition by Cisco, the whole thinks started to change. Many good projects closed for no reason. Managers, even directors have no answer  for this cisco's top management Behavior.  For the last three months no work and people started leaving the company. The whole CVTPL , has shrunk by 30%.

Pros:

Good Food, free food only for CVTIPL
Nap room
good compensation if you have the skill to bargain
Very good work life balance(Work ko, goli maaro, Chutiya banahoo..!)
Cons: confused management and no clear leadership. everyone back is on fire(Literally Fire). The ship already started sinking and the Captain thinks that the ship will fly. LOL

Pros: Quality of work life.  Autonomy and flexibility.  Empowerment and egalitarianism.  Liberal telecommuting policy.  Compensation.
Cons:
Somewhat bloated managerial structure.  IMHO, many in upper levels of management perceive a need to inject complexity in order to maintain job security.  

Siloed and disconnected policy making.  Central functions are continually at odds with individual business unit practices.  Cisco is a great-great company that treats its employees with respect and appreciation, but leadership has difficulty executing to a clear vision, which can be frustrating and potentially demotivating.  There are some very good executives and some not-so-goods (again, IMHO).

Pros:
- Management works hard to share their message & vision with employees
- Everyone is behind giving back 
- Can be an exciting fun place to work if your working on the hot initiative or product
Cons:
- Management challenged to keep growing value for shareholders in a mature company so the employees can be seen as expendable
- In their words the business moves so fast that they aren't good at planning ahead with regards to Headcount and have no qualms cutting HC as a way to move funding to other parts of the company
- Culture and ability to grow sales and income feel "desperate" thus easy to justify not making employees first priority

Pros: Great culture and technology.  Cisco is a very driven but also caring culture.  I loved the time I spent there and it was very hard to leave.
Cons: As an account manager, it is very hard to build a long term business because you have a limited number of accounts and are given a growth goal every year on the same set of accounts.  After a couple of years, it becomes impossible to meet the number with the same set of customers.    Even though Cisco has a large portfolio of solutions, not all of these drive large sales volume.   This comp structure model drives folks to change territories or roles about every 2 years or so which makes it difficult to build long-lasting customer relationships.

Pros:
Flexible working hours with great work-life balance
Work from home option is one of the biggest facility this company provides and there is hardly any micro management
Cons:
Hard to manage work life balance
Very big company with constant changes

Pros: Relentless sales machine with a no lose attitude.
Cons: No where near the same company I started with 16 years ago and not moving nearly quick enough to keep up with the competition. Limited Restructuring (fancy name for layoffs) now a quarterly event. Many of us who brought in millions for the company have left or been forced out when a theater goes through a down cycle.  BU's are not consistently held accountable for failure to deliver on commitments and staying competitive.

Pros:
* Okay work life balance
* Transparency
* Some great managers
* Agile. Not perfect, but they acknowledge the issues and try to come up with an action plan. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.
* Closely knit BU except some teams.
* Good position in market for now.
* Great leadership for the most part.
Cons:
* Uncertainty about future. Lackluster communication from leadership.
* Some teams have legacy baggage
* Some managers are not so great
* Lack of fresh talent. Some entrenched people with good attitude but not-so-good skills.
* Layoffs
* Lack of R&D work in some teams.
* Work can really DRY up at certain times and gets boring.

Pros:
the name of company conjures up ideas of luxury, comfort, and quality
You are free to do as you please.
There is no commute.
You can work in shorts and a T-shirt.
No one looks over your shoulder.
You can write off a small portion of your home office expenses on your taxes.
Your employer usually compensates you for incidental expenses.
Cons:
You must be entirely self-motivated.
You miss out on the camaraderie that stems from working with others day after day.
There are no coworkers to go to lunch with.
You can never escape the office and go home, because you are already there.
Working from home can be messy and can take up an entire spare room in your home.
You don't get face time with your coworkers, so it is more difficult to find out about new projects you might be interested in.

Pros: Solid benefits, stable company, market leading products
Cons: Nepotism is rampant with a policy called "directive hire",  limited ability to provide real feedback, annual layoffs, mandates that may or may not be in line with your direct work

Pros: Flexibility to work from home, benefits
Cons: I find my experience in Finance does not match other employees in other functions. Finance has little to no new hire training for such a large company, constantly backfilling at lower salary grades for the same if not higher amount of work, outdated tools with no investment - throwing oursourced solutions at the problem instead of truly investing in tools that would resolve the issues and give employees more time back instead of almost every process being a manual task . Be careful to manage your calendar wisely, 24/7 always on culture will take all of your after work hours if you let it!

Pros:
1. Has still got the brand name. That helps other top employers in the tech industry show interest in you. For some reason tech industry still has some respect for Cisco.
2. There are some smart people still in the company.
3. Good work life balance.
Cons:
1. Really bad low and mid level managers. Some of them can't even talk or understand English ( And I am talking about very basic English skill). They get to be managers, because they have been around for too long & not for their management skills or people skills.
2. Lot of old grumpy employees, who clearly had their prime time long back. Now they have just become obstacles in product delivery & other's growth.

Pros:
Interesting and big projects
Work-life balance
Flexible working options
Various options for education and self-development
Responsive team members
Cons:
Actual cons really depend on the project and team you are working with and in.

Even though there are many development options and paths for career, there is no clear and defined way of getting a grade promotion or established ways of switching roles. Some people with good performance, initiatives and skills stay for years in certain grades with no significant improvements in salaries, but at the same time certain people get promoted to higher roles and grades within a shorter time frame with way less achievements. Not only Cisco has such issues; however, some companies have managed to build a good structure and defined career paths, which motivates people to stay longer and grow.

Pros: Best work place, Best recognition, Best Teams to work with, Multinational Company, employee empowerment. Cisco is the company where th eemployee feels , secured career, appreciation for his efforts, pride to be associated with a team of winners. Cisco grooms you and prepares you to the best of your potential to get ready for more challenging positions where you can work and prove your worth. The management is always supportive at your back, gives you confidence to just go and make wins for the organization. Every employee is treated with respect and high values. this not only elevates your morale but also gives you a reason to proove your exact worth by showing results.
Cons: there are no down sides

Pros:
For the most part, people at Cisco seem dedicated and are willing to go the extra mile to get things done in a timely fashion for customers.

The community spirit is alive and well and there are many volunteer opportunities to give back.
Cons: Unfortunately, there are definitely some who don't hesitate to attempt throwing others under the bus for their own mistakes.  Processes for getting some things done are fairly light weight but for others, like new product introduction, have goten big and bloated.  Hopefully current focus on streamlining people and processes will return Cisco to a more competitive position.

Pros: You can literally do nothing and keep your 60K job
Cons: Apparently there used to be good perks about Cisco - they are literally all gone now, the benefits is cheap and pretty good that's about all you'll get. The work-life balance is pretty good because you'll be bored as hell and with that comes no promotions ever. Cisco does not give annual raises for inflation - it's pathetic. Bonuses are pretty poor as well.

Pros: Good overall benefits, flexible work from home policy (a necessity given one of the cons below), a great name for your resume
Cons: Feels like an old company trying unsuccessfully to change to a younger feel. Lots of politics, especially around headcount, which leads to continuous employee moves making it hard to move up. Constant change that leads to yearly layoffs.  Limited visibility from management on the changes and moves that makes it difficult to effectively do your job.  Open office space with no assigned space makes going into the office almost pointless and unproductive, since there's not enough rooms for you to make the calls you'll be on all day.  Pay inequality, in certain situations, that's impossible to get fixed without leaving and coming back.

Pros:
Great Benefits
Great Work environment
Really Smart people
Good Visibility
Cons:
Not much except that the company is going trough a transition right now to evolve to where it needs to be in the Software driven world, but still maintaining its dominance in Infrastructure. It will take time, but it will get there.
Some managers sometimes do not share  whats going on better. Mentor ship in my case was minimal, and not conducive to success. But I know that this is an exception.

Pros: Leaders truly care about employees and the whole employee experience at work. Cisco's cutting edge collaboration tools make meetings a breeze and enable employees to work from just about anywhere. The flexibility to get things done from wherever you are is a perk bar none!
Cons: As a company and as individuals, the amount of giving back Cisco does is HUGE, but not publicized well enough to engender collective employee pride or talent attraction. The many ways Cisco uses its technology to change the world, provide disaster relief globally, and truly make a difference often happens in stealth mode.  It goes unnoticed. A big miss. Need to redouble PR efforts in this front!

Pros: From the start, I have felt welcomed, supported, and accepted without question. Cisco has an excellent LGBT employee resource organization (ERO). I recently joined a sub-group within the greater Finance org. I'm very impressed by the caliber of thought and care given to making Cisco a safe place to work.
Cons: In our discussions about the rights of LGBT employees, we are well aware of the differences in experience country to country. We have a long way to go; we encourage our LGBT colleagues to join us in the conversation of making Cisco more globally tolerant.

Pros: The pay here is competitive to other surrounding companies, and we have hold overs in our area from Sourcefire which was a startup purchased by Cisco a few years back. We get benefits like lunch 3 days per week, quarterly fun-fund and PLI bonuses every 6 months
Cons: Corporate office environment, and less soul than when I started 2 years ago. Some people have left because of this. Also, seemingly random layoffs have happened to good people, not sure why their numbers got picked.

Pros: Caring employer with a culture of valuing people; the impact of our technology on society, and the positive brand recognition from our customers; pace of change and innovation; limitless career opportunities in various roles, functions and countries; competitive pay and benefits... list goes on. I meet people every day who bounced around jobs before landing and staying at Cisco. And also people who leave for greener grass on the other side, and come right back
Cons: Big company with associated complexities and messy back-end data sets; not a consumer brand so not recognized by students and prospective candidates - makes it harder than it should to hire top talent.

Pros:
- Great training that is interactive and fun
- Amazing people that want to help you learn and grow your career
- Cisco itself is a great brand in most IT shops regardless of segment, so having doors open are much easier than with a lesser-known/valued company
- Great pay!
Cons:
- All large companies can sometimes give you the feeling of being just a number, and during commit calls that is a feeling. (If you actively build your network it isnt too bad)
- Typical stress of a sales job. Make sure you know your business and add pipeline!
- If you want upward mobility Cisco has it, but you will most likely need to be open to moving locations or segments if you want to continue going up the management chain

Pros: Very competitive based + bonus + benefits package and great work and life balance. Flexibility to work from home. Tons of trainings to develop you career and great opportunities to move to different cities/countries.
Cons: It can be hard to get promotions. Too many bureaucracy and politics because the management is not very flat/lineal.

Pros:
Cisco is a company that is leading the way for the next generation of communications.  They have an excellent executive team that communicates a consistent vision down the reporting chain.  During the current struggles, they are adapting -- finding ways to reduce expenses without layoffs.   While there is some job loss at Cisco, I feel it is not as great as other companies.

Cisco also believes in a comprehensive compensation package, constantly checking the industry to ensure fair compensation.
Cons: During the downturn, decisions about letting folks go is not always based on performance, but geography.  If at a remote CONUS site, I feel you are more exposed than if you worked in SJC.

Pros:
Good balance between family life and work
Lots of smart folks, but management inertia makes them loose their enthusiastic and innovative traits.
If you do good work that gives visibility to your management, you do get recognition, but dont expect raise or promotions
Good place to be if you want to cruise by with no promotions and raises.
Cons: Growth is very slow, unless you are under a manager you understands your potential and can utilize your career goals to BU goals and leverage to grow himself.

Pros: Cisco provides a high level of fluidity for employees.  Employees are asked to stay with a group for 12 months, however, employees are then free to transfer to other groups and try new things.  This is done frequently and provides great opportunities for career growth.
Cons: The issue with Cisco is that if you don't work at headquarters in San Jose, CA, you are treated as a remote worker, even if you work at another major Cisco campus.  The issue here is getting appropriate facetime and leadership support.

Pros: Some of the new engineers (new graduates) put it this way. Their salary may be the lowest among their classmates but their hourly rate at Cisco is definitely the highest!
Cons: Chambers deploys an outdated management trick by letting go the so called "bottom performers" every year (sometimes it is 5%, 10%, or 20% depending on the economy). So you may receive persecution from your manager for no obvious reasons only because she/he has to please Chambers who has shown little accountability himself.

Pros:
- good benefits
- lots of great technical people
- If you are self-motivator, you can learn a lot here
Cons:
- Business Units far from HQ are treated as insignificant
- tons of politics in the middle management level that could stop opportunities from being distributed equally
- promotion is not based on work results or other effort put in, but thing so-called "certification"
- salary is below average and no market adjustment
- new hire with lower level of knowledge gets paid more money, existing and experienced staff don't get the same pay not even considered for promotion

Pros:
Smart and dedicated people.
Great products.
Amazing sales machine.
Cons:
Very very political -- didn't used to be that way!
Since the company began having lay-offs, employees are no longer as willing to share their ideas, especially if they are not in lock-step with managers, for fear of ending up on the lay-off list.  It's too bad! 
No longer open/honest communication culture that is touted. 
Unfortunate review process requires that even if all team members are high performing, someone has to be on the bottom of the list
Very high number of contractors -- so loss of native/historical knowledge when budgets are reduced

Pros: One gets to work with the latest bleeding edge technology.  If you like technology and a challenge you will have all you can handle and more at Cisco.  Also, you get to work the brightest engineers in the industry and for the most part everyone is hardworking and works well together.  The company management does a pretty good job on steering the massive organization.
Cons: Internal promotions are hard to come by depending on where you are in the company.  This has forced good employees to look outside the company for greater opportunity.

Pros: There is opportunity to build working relationships with people globally.  Working from home is convenient and may be a wonderful option for young families.
Cons: Internal politics and constant restructuring is the worse part of Cisco.  It can be very frustrating to constantly change direction.  There are long periods of no leadership during those upheavals. Management can be political and not act in the best interest of their employees.  People who are looking for a truly collaborative, trusting, and kind environment may want to look elsewhere.

Pros: Good Salary, great bonus (if you are Tech Lead or higher), benefits are okay.
Cons: Employees and management are very risk adverse and innovation is not commonplace.

Pros: Cisco was a great company for a long period of time. Great people, culture, benefits and flexibility. I enjoyed much of my time there, but the company has changed.
Cons: Overly political, especially in engineering. It's about who you know, not what qualities you can bring to the job and the overall environment. Annual layoffs have really impacted morale. The HR organization has continuously been in turmoil which adds to the dysfunction.

Pros: Amazing facility. Employee benefits are excellent. Flexible working hours. Option to work from home.
Cons: Not exciting work for atleast Java. Not a true Agile shop. When tried to escalate issues in project to onsite scrum master, the offshore manager and leads were not happy. Feedbacks are neither encouraged nor considered. Managers come up with inefficient, complicated, very artificial, not so practical or friendly process for team building. They hardly understand that it does not add any value to the member / team / company. Too many incompetent contractors continue because of Manager preferences.
