Pros: Been a while since I looked around but the salary and benefits seem competitive and the company embraces flexible working hours and locations.  Being a huge company, the market listens to Cisco giving opportunity to work with a variety of customers all over the world.
Cons: Software projects are distributed over too many global sites leading to inefficiency and frustration in taking and acting upon basic decisions.  Proliferation of management layers leads to disconnect between those setting strategy and the rest of the organisation.  Continual restructuring and an inability to redeploy workers appropriately leads to regular bouts of talented workers being let go (with corresponding impact on morale).

Pros: Huge company means plenty of resources to set up meetings and conferences, and so on. Suppliers return your call every time. Corporate resources library on the intranet is unbelievably huge. Smaller divisions like cable BU do some interesting technical work.
Cons: The size of the company is so big that you rarely feel a sense of empowerment. In the grand scheme of things, your work hardly matters. Or so it feels like. Somewhere, 6 levels above you, some EVP makes decisions and sends you an email, mostly congratulating himself on what a wonderful email he has written. The new centralized organization chart makes things even worse than before.

Pros: Great company with a sold reputation and loads of opportunity.  Cisco encourages moves between roles and functions, which means you can really grow your career here.  The company is also actively working to make the employee experience even better and these efforts seem to be taking hold.
Cons: Cisco is going through a tremendous transition right now, and with a new CEO and constant market shifts, changes are likely to be ongoing. This can sometimes make it challenging to move forward big initiatives, and it often leaves employees feeling insecure.  That said, it does provide opportunities for new paths and growth.

Pros: Fast paced.  Challenging.  Most finance people are very intelligent, knowledgeable and highly professional.  Teams typically are very collaborative and work to help all succeed.
Cons:
You never know when Cisco will outsource your job, downsize or exit your business.  So all constantly worry when their last day will be.

Very little investment in training finance people.  Internal job rotation program is not actively managed well so movement is slow as people are afraid to change jobs for fear to lose their job.

Finance teams are a reporting function to enable management by numbers.  Finance organization needs to really and truly be value add to their business partners rather than managing their business partners like Monday morning quarterbacks.

Pros:
- Well recognized name
- They are (or to be precise used to be) at the edge of technology
Cons:
- A lot of favoritism and cultural silos inside
- Your chances of hire, career advancements, raises, etc are much higher if you are a south east Indian or Chinese.
- You will have to ally yourself with either the Indian mob or the Chinese mob, otherwise, you won't last long in there.

Pros: Great place to work, very talented people, lots of trainings and opportunities to learn.
Cons: difficult to get promotions and salary increases, although a big company with lots of opportunities it's surprisingly hard to switch teams  and with some managers communication seems to flow only in one direction

Pros: Since the new CEO decided to change the company we can see a better strategy and finally an idea of where we want to go. If you are early in career this is a great place to start as you will have plenty of options and the chance to work in very different projects
Cons:
Completely lack of execution. Every quarter less and less engineering resources. 

All the Business Entities work still in silos and is difficult to get proper end-to-end solutions.

If you are senior or over grade 12 then get ready to be in a redundancy process at any time.

Pros:
Cisco are really going places with their portfolio of hardware, software, and services. 
We are really looked after with our people deal that includes great premium healthcare, pension and other perks which makes one want to stay with the company. 
The people culture is also great thing. Colleagues like to embrace new ideas and concepts, and will support new initiatives.
Cons: As a large corporate, it does take a while to understand where colleagues sit within the organisation, geography and function. With any IT Telecoms vendor, there is no such thing as a normal 9 to 5 job, and one can find working longer than an average working day, however the reward for doing so far out ways this small sacrifice.

Pros: Cisco has long been the standard for great technology companies to work for and I've loved my jobs at Cisco for quite some time. Competitive compensation, benefits, and semiannual bonus potential as well as good mobility and career path opportunities. The management and leadership culture puts priority on their people and in my experience at least, is very supportive.
Cons:
1. Not as many fun company events as there used to be, but it's all part of evolving priorities of a large company feeling the need to be socially responsible.
2. Like with any large publicly traded company, there are periodic restructurings (layoffs) as the whims of Wallstreet impact the business.

Pros:
Great early in career kickstart for bachelor and master graduate students.
Four industry wide recognized certificates (CCNA, DevNet Associate, CCNP, Devnet Professional). 
Possibility to network with executive leaders within the company as well as building your own network with the other CSAPers.
It is definitely possible to join without prior experience in IT/Networking. Technical and sales bootcamp to learn everything about Cisco's portfolio, sales techniques and more.
The Cisco Culture is great, very welcoming to associates. You are highly encouraged to get to know people, ask questions and find your strengths.
Cons:
Management and the curriculum do expect a lot from the associates, extra hours are expected and not compensated.
The Work From Home format does work quite well, but makes it harder to draw clear boundaries between leisure time and working hours.

Pros: Company values, diversity (age, ethnicity, gender, orientation, etc), inclusion, remarkable talent, great people to work with, opportunities to learn and grow in knowledge and experience (especially in our group b/c we're short-handed), best manager ever, great benefits, great pay, reimbursement for WFH expenses, and more. Almost 2 years, and still love, love, love this org!!
Cons: They encourage a work-life balance; I just don't know when to stop for the day. There's always just this one more thing that I want to finish. :-) Career Opps are limited everywhere. If you work for it, though, you'll have them. Lots of internal training opportunities. Be a great worker, continue to educate and keep up with technology and trends. Is it too good to last?

Pros: Knowledge sharing is key.  Everyone is open to help out.  It is great in this industry to have access to the origin of new technologies and get your hands on anything you need.
Cons: As the company grows, cisco culture is being lost.  I am happy here though, the grass isn't always greener on the other side.

Pros: Great Vision for the future, great CEO, communications for the general employee populace, flexibility to work from home or remotely, great people to meet and add to your network and sense of pride to work for the company.  Passionately focused on the customer.  Good tools and willing to try new things
Cons: too many "Vest in peace" upper/middle management folks that need to be let go, promotions impossible unless you are thought of as the top person in a group, no formal mentoring program,

Pros: good place to work, lot of opportunities.A positive company that makes sure that their employees are apprecitated in an apporpriate way. Driving goals from top down to make sure all employees know what direction they are headed in. Cisco is a leader across many different sub-industries within IT: routing, switching, storage, VoIP, wireless, optical, application acceleration, etc. which allows sales engineers to gain a wide breadth of knowledge and exposure across many different technologies and products. Working with Cisco is very fast paced and you get to play with cutting edge technology that has not been released to the mainstream public yet. Cisco sales managers do no micromanage; they give their employees all the freedom and resources needed to get their job done.
Cons: nothing other then the fact that it is a hugeg company.

Pros:
- Technology is not only produced but embraced and utilized.
- State of the art health center - complete with gym, doctors, pharmacy - everything is electronic
- Total Compensation is very good
- Lots of work and challenges
- Ethical and Fair company
Cons:
- VSE down to the lower layers is not there
- Collaboration with SVP's might be good at 1st glance (however, it has not made it down to the lower levels).  How can this be solved?
- See a lack of trust between SVPs and VPs and down

Pros: Good for your career; Excellent knowledge base; Very good compensation at hiring time but gets a bit less so over time; Good transfer policy within the company.
Cons: Most managers are great but it also tolerates some of the worst once; Unfair performance review process based on relative performance within your group. Really hard to succeed at higher grade levels. Some projects require daily intercation between USA and India at odd hours.

Pros: Makes you very focused and objective driven. You learn to mange stakeholders and if you are iron willed are steeled into managing internal conflicts and or rivalries to help achieve your objectives.
Cons: There is a lack of recognition of your efforts at present. Management also needs to improve it's system of reallocating and or restructuring for even good performers and team players.

Pros:
- Lots of forums for information sharing (technical/non-technical)
- Flexible work option
- Not a bad place to work, provided some issues mentioned in Cons are corrected
Cons:
A manager can make or break a team. I see that  hiring policy in India does not seem to care while hiring first level managers from outside. Whats wrong people ? Don't you know the relevance of a manager's role ? Why are you hiring people with "resource-manger" kind of mentality ? You should be hiring a "mentor/guide" sort of manager (along with the usual role of a resource manager) . 

I have seen pathetic management happening  , sort of cheap politics being played, which is very shameful.

Pros: (1) schedule very flexible. (2) most people are capable and smart. (3) employees are empowered to make decision.
Cons: (1) compensation are not necessarily tied to contribution. A person joined Cisco in recent years can have higher grade level and higher salary than people who have been in the same position for years. (2) Constant org change. Some people say Cisco is a company with ADD, it's not exaggerating. Constant org change resulted in constant people movement which can put lots of stress on employees.

Pros: Cisco was a great place to work.  They have a strong sense of culture and really understood how to treat their people.  They realized that the valley was a small world and what they did would affect them.  I worked with an incredible amount of highly intelligent people who really understood their focus area.
Cons: After some time, the company had become a little too political, but less than other places I have worked.  People began to own smaller and more focused pieces of the pie, causing some layer of overlap and some contention for ownership of that work.

Pros:
- The products are great and continue to be very competetive
- Great Silicon valley location (San Jose, CA) and other key centers in US -  RTP (NC), Richardson (TX), Lawrenceville (GA) and Boxborough (MA)
- True global player with big R&D investments in India
Cons:
- Not a healthy change in culture.  People are becoming commodities
- Low motivation among rank and file.  Noth a healthy work/life balance
- Recent layoffs (2011 and 2012) has hurt the morale.  Everyone seems to be watching their back and not easily collaborate for the common good

Pros:
gr8 work life balance, can work on all possible technology. end to end.
very flexible. good place to settle after some 8+ exp.. very good initial pay package.  and you'll get more only if your get promoted. no or less intermediate Hikes.
Cons:
No salary hikes, very very rare travel chance, No chance of saving money if you travel.
sometimes only bug fixing, and less coding. and Doc works.
very independent work culture. most people are disconnected or spread across. Most of the real R&D happen in US and other countries.some product team have only small customization or porting of code on new hardware only.

Pros: Large stable company, not struggling to get funded or get product name recognition.  Everyone in the networking world knows the name Cisco.  It's a great resume entry.
Cons: Not all groups are well funded, and promotion opportunities are more limited from within.  There is a bit of an internal joke that says if you are looking for a promotion, leave the company and get it there.. then come back at your new level.

Pros: Was once a market leader with great innovation pipeline and wonderful , competitive and team oriented culture.
Cons: Missed the transition to Cloud and is desperately trying to shift it's application suite to Cloud.  Cisco was unwilling to compete with itself or it's overbuilt channel and b/c of that it will need to make some significant headcount reductions and transitions.  For all of the resellers out there this will mean Cisco will compete with it's channel in the long run.  It has to in order to delver cloud capabilities.

Pros:
Work life balance is too good. You have ample time to improvise yourself.
Technical growth for an individual is satisfactory.
Good salary package for entry level employees though hiring is freezed now.
Variety of Networking & Packet Core solutions available which can satisfy even all the top tier service providers.
Cons:
Long wait for compensation/promotion & bonus is frustrating.
Decisions taken by top level management are not futuristic.
Frequent layoffs make this an unsafe place to work at.
Too much of company process to be followed while working.

Pros:
People are generally nice, good teamwork
Flexibility to work from home some of the time
Good work life balance if you work for a good manager
Rotations between departments are supported
Cons: Promotions / recognition / rewards have little to do with how you perform, but have much do with your relationship with your manager. If the manager is bad, there is really no way to make his or her issues known and followed up on, all you can do is leave the department or the company altogether. Finance positions in San Jose are few and far between, most requisitions are opened in Raleigh, North Carolina

Pros: Great Future vision - good current products and strong customer focus.  Senior personnel are treated as professionals and compensated as such.
Cons: Seems to take forever to get to the future - and when you get there it wasn't quite what was advertised.

Pros:
Great place to work. The BU where i worked, the incoming projects were constant.  All projects go through sufficient discussions  and reviews- so that's great!  Good managers mostly - so work related aspirations are met. 
Very good campus/ facilities.
No hierarchy - culture is pretty open.
Cons:
Salaries and hikes are not according to market.  Had too many re-orgs and management changes which ends up in having to prove yourself from scratch to any new management. Also, there is a lot of favoritism/bias by middle and top management towards ppl they have worked with for a longer time vs teams which newly join them.  
Focus and priority given to process and process torchbearers rather than technology agility.

Pros:
Depending on where in the company you are:  tremendous flexibility in taking the role where you want to.  Again, depending on your particular technology area, you can be working on the bleeding edge.
The must-haves such as getting paid, expenses, 401K, ESPP, health care, etc. all 'just work' without hassle.  Good backup resources to help through life's bumps if needed.
Cons:
Large company inertia.  Finding the right <whatever thing / person> at the right time can be problematic.  Depending on where in the company you find yourself, you can easily be a doesn't matter what size fish in a very large pond.  
Constant uncertainty around re-orgs and layoffs.  Just consider it a fact of life.

Pros:
-breadth of project and program work
-have grown my responsibilities tremendously. Company gives you opportunity to grow
-competitive compensation and benefits
-the work from home perk is bar none.  i make my own schedule around work.
Cons:
-so vast and process laden, really difficult to get things done swiftly
-super slow release cycles
-the offices are really crappy looking and dated (except for 1-2 buildings in SJ)
-all that work from home makes you feel like a shut in
-all that work from home drives an email culture which is slow and less collaborative
-alot of waste, inefficiency, and lack of basic tech proficiency
-insane amounts of managing up

Pros: Great company to work for, well meaning executive management. Great employee friendly policies. Good mobility between groups.
Cons: Toxic first line management, no empathy, slave drivers and makes me wonder how & why they promote these clowns.

Pros:
- Flexible working environment
- Great corporate benefits
- Refreshed executive leadership 
- Range of solutions and customer offerings
- Team collaboration
- Travel (if you enjoy this)
- Good compensation
Cons:
- Large company which can be tricky to navigate for some
- Some stale leaders and employees that have been at Cisco too long and need outside experience
- Long hours for those in regional roles trying to engage with HQ and represent APAC
- Lots of internal meetings due to size and matrix teams 
- Limited pay raise opportunities

Pros:
Market Leader is various technologies. Some really good technology and products. 
Used to be a great place to work...pre 2010.
Cons:
Some really poor people in management positions and appears to be getting worse every year. Living proof of the Dilbert principle.
Typical large company...The more an exec talks about 'family', 'our people are our best asset' the less likely it is they believe it.
Employee reviews are meaningless. 
Salary increases are almost unheard of.

Pros:
Biggest networking company around.
Facilities/Infrastructure cannot be better. 
Endless opportunities.
Collaboration with and exposure to great minds.
Opportunities to travel in some roles.
Competitive pay.
Cons:
Frequently changing direction of management can make life slightly difficult. Although some may even see this as an opportunity to learn more.

Extremely competitive environment. The amount of time that needs to be invested for substantial recognition is immense. Work life balance may get hampered in the process.

Although initial pay is competitive, appraisals are tough to come by. Given the competitive environment, not everyone gets fairly evaluated.

Being a large organisation, there is over emphasis on showcasing performance. As competition grows, the content that is showcased loses importance and individuals lose track of the actual goal they wanted to achieve and instead choosing to complete a task that might help bring in recognition.

Pros:
Working from home possible
Good benefits
Company-paid training possible if you can take the time for it
Cons:
Too much churn and reorg
Management is unwilling to spend enough resources on tech debt
Management wants world class workers but won't pay for it, so open reqs go unfilled and are lost completely after a month or two.
When someone does get hired, they are either too junior and are terminated, or they realize they are able to get more job satisfaction elsewhere, for better pay, and they leave 
Staff that doesn't leave is forced to train a stream of new hires, which takes away time from their tasks. Extremely customized environment takes months to master.
Cisco layoffs across the board almost yearly - forces loss of IP.

Pros: Some of the best opportunities to work on enterprise-level projects, lots of training on different subject available, stock plan, great gym and year-round sports.
Cons: Slow career development and growth, specially mid to senior level. The constant reorgs do not help either. Even though a technology company, it's heavy on the sales focus and most of engineering is pure grind. The 'fun' and exploratory groups are separated into business units (BUs). Also, innovation is typically acquired vs investing in in-house R&D, leaving the impression that the grass is always greener on the other side.

Pros: Lots of smart, hard working employees that still believe in the company brand / vision. Flexible working schedule = can work from anywhere at any time. Challenging assignments with access to a wide variety of markets / verticals.
Cons: Difficult time transitioning to a software / as a service company. Being left behind by big 5 (Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Google, Microsoft) in terms of setting the Cloud / Networking direction of the future. Revolving door of executives focused more on their own politically driven advancement than setting up the company for long term success.Employees are burned out from the yearly purge of employees at the end of the fiscal year

Pros:
- No clocking in hours
- Flexible WFH options
- Bursts of high pressure work and low pressure work
Cons:
- No push for innovative ideas
- Irregular hike/promotion cycles
- Streamlined towards a single technology
- Lack of preemptive career advices towards meeting expectations: Tells you that they expected more after the hike/promo cycles are finalized and not tell anything regarding the performance prior to that.

Pros: The variety of work, and projects to be involved in is staggering, there are endless opportunities.  Yes you'll have to work hard, but you get to do that as yourself which is so much easier than trying to mute yourself.  It's about the customers and getting the work done, not looking, sounding and working like a machine
Cons: Repeat after me - change is good!  The company and therefore the work is constantly evolving and innovating, so if you like routine and repetition you're going to be uncomfortable.  Also be prepared for diversity of people but also locations, you're not likely to be part of a team all in one place.  That's going to be tough when you start, but once you've been here for a bit, it's great!

Pros: At Cisco, you are working with the best of the best in networking and security.  These are people who wrote many of the standards and protocols upon which the internet we use daily is based.  I’m the Security Business Unit, they are absolutely making the right strategic moves to be the best overall in network security.  When Chuck took over for John a few years back, a fresh infusion of focus and ideas came forward.  I absolutely loved my team and loved my management chain.  Personal and technical growth was always encouraged and highly valued.
Cons: Being a global team, cohesion was a challenge.

Pros: If anyone wants to accelerate their career, you need not look elsewhere. CSAP is one of the most rewarding experiences I've ever had. It's tough because they expect a lot from you, but if you do your job and work hard you will be just fine. CSAP was like college all over again for me! You meet so many young professionals and hop in to those same sales/technology classes based on your track (engineer or sales representative). I went through the engineer track and got put into customer role plays, shadowing opportunities with field teams, passing required exams, and half a year of classes. I've learned so much from all my mentors and peers, and these learned traits will stick with me for the rest of my life!
Cons: None! Be ready to study!

Pros:
Cisco is a very good company to work for and in general supportive of its employees
They challenge the status quo and have a culture of having fun whilst you are working hard. Which I always enjoyed very much.
Innovation and doing what's right is as well one of its core focus areas
Cons:
It tends to have lay-off rounds on a yearly basis which I don't believe is a healthy approach to its employees and in the long run the business as there is then a tendency to keep on letting go of expertise and then hiring expertise again etc etc
Continuous learning is very internally oriented...people should really learn as well from the outside Cisco world, particularly in areas of specialization. It was possible but not easy to agree.....every course tends to be made the Cisco way...

Pros: You will have the true global workplace experience and the flexibility. Plus inclusion and diversity. Remote working option for up 70% of the time (if your line manager is OK with it) unless you are working for a sales function. You will have the advantage of running your own schedule. Let’s say if you have a training starting at 8pm because of the timezone difference you get to start working again around mid-day without needing any permission. Set Out of Office message and rest. Also vice versa. If you have team mates in different continents get used to being an super early bird, or late bird on regular basis.
Cons: Cisco do lay-offs almost every year. Terminations are never based on performance. It’s purely budgetary or employees being at the wrong location/ working site.

Pros: Strong community feeling with global sales teams all around the world, relatively good set of accounts handled as mid size, dedicated systems engineers and sales specialist teams' assigned
Cons: No car allowance, high quota carrying while earning a lot less than field sales teams, managers not much invest in team's personal development and career advancements goals

Pros: Cisco is a great place to work with amazing opportunities. Cisco is a company that cares about their employees and strives to make significant impacts to the community. In the LIFT Program, I am able to develop my career in a wide range of areas with rotations within finance and accounting. There are lots of opportunities to build relationships and gain career insights. The best thing about Cisco is the people that I work with, as I feel that they genuinely care about me.
Cons: Some roles are better than others. It can be difficult at times as you don't always have a say in your rotation within the LIFT Program, but even the roles that I have been less interested in, I have been able to learn a lot.

Pros:
Cisco has the most inspiring and ethical ELT I have ever seen at a company, with many women in leadership positions. It is truly progressive and has a warm and fuzzy feel, despite being such a large company. There are many different types of products, so depending on what you're looking for, you could find a global role or a more of a startup feel depending on the business unit.
Like any big company, the red tape can be frustrating, but I don't think the politics are that bad and it's not a cutthroat atmosphere at all.
Cons: Unfortunately Cisco doesn't pay well and it's hard to get a decent raise. Some of the products do very well and others struggle to keep up with single product/pure play competitors who have more dedicated resources.

Pros: Highly dynamic, collaborative company. Depending upon which org and leadership one is under there are great opportunities to have your voice heard and help shape direction. Lots of opportunity and resources to evolve skills.
Cons: With being agile and dynamic there's often questions about direction and how to measure success. Many layers of specialists due to complexity of portfolio.

Pros: I haven't seen any so far. I joined cisco during the pandemic. They give time off one in a while but it doesn't account for anything. No meeting day isn't really meeting free. US managers don't really follow this, why even have it then?
Cons:
1. Number of PTO per year are very less.
2. Unnecessary mandatory shutdown. This year India have to take 7 days out of the 18 PTOs. Leaves us with very limited option for rest of the year. 
3. If you work for a US team, there won't be any year end gifts. Other teams get quite a lot of gifts. 
4. Limited budget for getting work from home setup done.
5. There are no programs. There is no employee engagement activity. Team i work with doesnt do it. Cisco on the whole doesn't conduct any events. 

It has been work work and all day work ever since i joined cisco.

Pros: Good place to start a career within IT. The company exist of very diverced mix of young people. Although the company is now part of Cisco Systems it still remains with an own identity. It´s also a positive to have the name of Cisco in the brand as more people take you serious.
Cons:
As the product allows companies to collaborate online from any place and any os system they are not that flexible to their own employees allowing them working from home that much.
Another downside is that the EMEA-HQ mainly got US managers which is a disadvantage. It would be better if the management existed of european managers who understands the european diversity and complexity with regards to the different countries.

Pros: Basically this is a good place and good company to work in. You have great and cheerful engineers as colleagues. The atmosphere between workmates are easy and comfort. Here you can learn much technical things from workmates. And you also have the chance to research new and tough technologies.
Cons:
A too large company. So the opportunity for new comers is not much. The chance of promotion usually fall down to these guys with good achedamic background (PhD., gratuated from famours university, etc.) or have good personal relationship with management teams.
As a normal engineer, if you can not find the chance to show your self to the high level management, then may be your chance of promotion is also few.

Pros:
Cisco is great about letting people work where they want and allowing remote work.  It is great that we practice what we preach.  

Since Cisco is a large company there are many opportunities to try out different job areas to find something you enjoy.
Cons:
As with all large companies the politics are a little heavy for my taste.  Most of your advancement is due to connections and not necessarily your competence with the job. 

The internal movement process seems flawed to me.  In order to apply for other positions your management has to be notified at the very beginning.  This can put you in a bad position if you are not selected and bonus time is around the corner.

Pros: Good technology area, comfortable work-life balance and reasonable pay are some of the areas in which Cisco excels. There are pockets of great innovation and politics free environment that you might actually enjoy - if you are lucky to land in those.
Cons: Cisco lost lots of good talent over past few years and what is remaining is a lots of stagnant baggage. It is hard to execute with that. Next, while you come to expect some amount in any large organization, here the politics is horrendous. IMO it is again that stagnant baggage which without any zeal for some smarts / innovation to grow their careers instead use politics to grow.

Pros: The benefits are good, the ability to work from home (considering much of work is accomplished in conference calls / WebEx sessions) is a nice plus, some of the newer offices are nice. Compensation is good. Work/life balance is pretty decent (work from home, using devices to connect). Gym and medical center at the San Jose campus is very nice and is a great perk for local employees.
Cons: Hyper-competitive environment encourages bad business behavior and investment choices. Insular and nepotistic management at senior levels. Cult-like 'love' of the CEO. Cafes are pretty good, but prices are high. Free snacks / drinks eliminated in cost-cutting back in 2009 (could save more cost by not rewarding the underperforming senior management :-).

Pros: Great company and full of talented people.  Great compensation and benefits.  Everyone loves John Chambers and Gary Moore and SVP management is solid.  Hard working but well rewarding.
Cons: It's getting to be a large company so politics are pretty much a part of the business.  Starting to lose the difference between perception of and getting actual work done.  Repeated layoffs have demoralized the employees.  The company is going through the biggest transformation and it will be interesting to see if they succeed.

Pros: Benifits, perks, salary, innovation, training, structure.  They also offer great internal education opportunities. Fantastic leadership programs.  if you want to learn and grow you can, it's up to employee. The opportunities are all over the place with Cisco.
Cons: A lot of waste, some areas get a way with paying suppliers/vendors way too much..  They shoudl negotiate vendors/suppliers down more.

Pros: There are a lot of great people working at Cisco.  There are many great opportunities to learn and grow your skill sets.  Access to training and educational tools is the best I have ever encountered in my career and I have worked for several very large companies.  The benefits are great.
Cons: Salary increases can be very challenging.  Better to negotiate a good salary up front instead of thinking you will get increases and promotions based on your own merit.  They are trying to consolidate finance positions in key cities throughout the world.  If you do not happen to live in one of these locations, you might be able to keep your position if you are willing to relocate yourself.

Pros: Thee is plenty of quality leadership development training and a willingness to invest. Most  are empowered to act within their own sphere so practice is readily available.
Cons: Multiple groups compete with one another on the same exact product/solution. The most connected team wins but the battles can take years. Different teams that are working on the exact same product have differing priorities so do not help one another. There is a reorg every 6 months making it tough to get traction in new ideas given a constant stream of new leadership.

Pros: Good people and talent. A lot of old timers, but also trying hard to attract younger talent. Open to a lot of acquisitions because internal R&D is non-existent which makes sense in today's economy, I suppose. Good at automating and making over-engineered products.
Cons: Avoid business units that don't directly make money. Some of the business units that play a supporting role in selling hardware or for making product that are not directly showing revenue tend to have less bonuses and continued layoffs. The low level management in these BUs are out of touch with the market and don't encourage growth in employees.

Pros:
Please keep in mind that these observations are in regards to the Cisco Canada Sales organization. I had previously worked at IBM and Lenovo so my observations are in comparison to those companies.

- Great work culture: Excellent mix of young and old talent. Male to female ratio is 50/50. Culturally diverse workforce. Sales culture is the opposite of toxic - people genuinely celebrate in your successes and pick you up when you are having a rough quarter. The virtual sales team feels like a family and spends time together outside of working hours. The virtual sales team is also inclusive and no one is treated like an outsider (no "clique's")

- Great work/ life balance: 4 weeks paid vacation. Everyone packs up and leaves at 5pm. Work from home one day per week. A great culture of doing meaningful work, rather than trying to look busy and stressed. Paid volunteer days. The entire company shuts down for a week in August and goes to Vegas (this is in addition to your vacation days). The company also shuts down from Dec 23rd - 31st (in addition to your vacation days). 

- Opportunities for career growth: In the sales organization there is a very clear and defined path for career growth. Management has the career path conversation very early to set expectations. Every 6 months a batch of people are promoted from virtual (inside) sales to field sales. Average tenure is 2.5 years in virtual sales before being promoted to field sales. Cisco also has these amazing programs:
     - Ignite: Program that recruits young-in-career sales professionals from other industries and teaches them technology infrastructure sales from the ground up. These people come from industries that are completely different from technology infrastructure. 
     - Are you ready?: This program takes people from other Cisco business units (mainly operations), and puts them in a sales role. People who would traditionally not be able to break into sales are given the chance to try it out
     - CSAP: Cisco Sales Associate Program - This is a prestigious 3 year rotational program that recruits the top university graduates. Right out of school they spend the 1st year as an Associate Sales Rep (cold calling and learning sales). The 2nd year is spent as a Virtual Sales Account Manager (inside sales). And the 3rd year is spent as a Territory Account Manager (field sales). 

- Excellent tools and processes: ALL OF THE TOOLS AND PROCESSES WORK. Not only do they work, but a lot of the tools talk to each other. All of the processes are well thought out and clearly defined. There is never any guess-work on how to do something complex. Cisco has mastered the art of simplifying complex processes and executing quickly. I say this because at IBM it used to take weeks to get a simple task done. At Cisco it takes minutes. MINUTES.

- Best products in the industry: Cisco engineers amazing stuff. When I was at IBM, Cisco INVENTED a new datacenter product that massacred IBM's marketshare. IBM ended up selling their server business unit to Lenovo. Cisco has this same caliber of engineering in ALL of their architectures (switching, routing, wireless, datacenters, telephony, etc).

- Perks: FREE PARKING. Their office is at Bay and Queens Quay and they offer free parking for every employee. I don't think I have ever heard of a company downtown that does this!  Catered lunches 2-3 days a week. Annual education stipend to take courses outside of work. Awesome prizes and spiffs. They take over your personal cell phone plan so you pay $0 and get unlimited everything (data included). Amazing high-tech office with 360 degree panoramic views of downtown Toronto and lake Ontario. All expenses paid annual trip to Vegas for EVERY sales rep across the globe.

- Compensation: They are the highest paying vendor in the tech infrastructure industry. IBM paid well and when I came over to Cisco my new salary was a 63% increase from what IBM paid. I was so shocked by this that I started researching what the other vendors paid by asking around in my network. Cisco overshoots every other vendor by miles. Their sales quota's are attainable and the accelerators are bonkers when you over-achieve your quota.

- Good leadership: Management regularly asks the front line reps what is working and what is not working. They take this feedback and then execute changes to the overall strategy right away. It's almost scary how quick they execute and maneuver. Management doesn't play games with front line reps either, they communicate exactly what is going on and level set our expectations regularly. Another thing I like about them is that they actually know how to get things done. A lot of managers will say "let me know how I can help", but reps will rarely go to them because they might screw up a complex deal by jumping into it. Not at Cisco. These managers are veteran sales people themselves and know everything about the company. If you run into obstacles they WILL cut through red tape and help you close the deal.
Cons: Honestly, there are none. Everyday I feel lucky to work here.

Pros: If you are self driven and can work autonomously without any guidance this place is a Nirvana. You can test every skill you thought you had and become an exceptional Product Manager
Cons: There are lot of bad Product Mangers here. So if you are just starting off as a PM then get a good mentor and its very hard to find one.

Pros: Big solid company, good compensation if you want to work to earn it.  Lots of opportunities available if desired, or just sit back and punch the clock.
Cons: Large bureaucratic organization, slow to move and adapt; too many people just parked in their jobs and punching the clock.  Decision making is very slow at the top causing it to continue to trail in technology and adapting to today's tech business needs.  Only the big mature business units are able to succeed.  There is a great lack of accountability and responsibility due to politics.

Pros:
I feel that I am the Sammy Sosa of Cisco.  What does that mean?  Sammy Sosa used to say when he played baseball for the Chicago Cubs that baseball had been very, very good to him.  I feel that Cisco has been very, very good to me!  

Flexible, open environment with challenging work that pushes me outside of my comfort zone.  As a female at Cisco, I have had a good working environment working for both men and women.
Cons: Political issues do get in the way.  The yearly LRs are tiresome and sad to see good people go.

Pros:
-Flexible work hours and location. I can work remote on days I need to
-Visibility to upper-level employees. Frequent events for early in career to learn from the best wisdom at Cisco
-Meaningful tasks. I already feel like a value-adding employee after 2 months.
-Amazing teaching and learning opportunities. Entire online database of internal education that we are encouraged to learn from
-Amazing family. Cisco teammates are excited to help me grow, I do not feel like the environment is negative and competitive. Other young Cisconians willingly have helped me adjust to Cisco
Cons: Make sure you are excited about the technology industry and the future that connection can bring the world. Otherwise, you won't like working here.

Pros: Great company to work for if you're motivated and passionate about technology. Pay and benefits are outstanding. Well run company that has weathered storms, recognized market shifts, and made changes when necessary. Lots of opportunities for promotion and trying on different hats if you're willing to make it happen.
Cons:
Penny pinching to a fault at times. Bottom line is everything, often cutting into training and travel opportunities, or getting necessary resources.
Management is varied. Not all opportunities are equal, but with such a large company expect that. You need to make your own opportunities. Sometimes by working outside your job.

Pros:
- top notch technology, brilliant people 
- somewhere in between chaotic startup and old fashioned corporation, luckily for us cisco is gathering positives from both worlds
- modern leadership strategy, focus on teams not "stars", regular check-ins, agile mindset
- flexible work arrangements
- ridiculous number of perks, build on trust towards employees (e.g. emergency time off - if you have private problems you can get up to 4 weeks additional, paid time off), good compensation
Cons: - collaboration, consensus focused culture - good most of the time but sometimes all those consultations are troublesome and time consuming

Pros:
1) work life balance
2) sometimes challenging work
3) Company for retirement plan
4) Good facilities(food, sports,WFH)
Cons:
1) So many proprietary Tools used for coding,
2) So many level of hierarchy makes it difficult to gain visibility
3) No appraisals for first 2 years and then if you are excellent you might get upto 10% appraisal from 3rd year onwards
4) Variable pay is a myth, it all depends on if they have offered you high package then they will for sure pay you only 50% of your variable pay and make nonsense excuses. If they have given you less package then they will give you atleast 100% variable pay.
5) As per ,cisco,it has spent 2 billion dollars in LABs but I have always found shortage of equipment for completion of my development activities.

Job Title: Financial analyst in the lift program
Pros: Cisco is a great company to work for. The company provides numerous opportunities to learn and grow. I have thoroughly enjoyed my time in the LiFT (Leaders In Finance and Tech) Program as well. This program pushes me to reach my full potential,has introduced me to a variety of people, and has provided me the opportunity to have rotations in both finance and accounting. I can't imagine working for another company other than Cisco.
Cons: Honestly, I can't think of any major cons of the company or the program. Granted, I have had to work with some difficult people in the past, but that is the case with all companies, and if anything, has taught me how to work with a variety of people.

Pros: Some good HR policies, Great products and engineering teams
Cons:
Corruption leaders, entire bands of leaders in Supply Chain lack vision. A LOT of infighting, politics, backstabbing making life horrendous for performers. Promotions are only based on who you know. Not an environment for professionals at all. 

There are gangsters that run GMO and they go hand-in-hand with counterparts in IT. Senior leaders in Supply Chain are routinely fired for corruption. one was recently arrested for 9.3 mil corruption. This culture is widely prevalent. AND SCO is supposedly the best run organization across Cisco (imagine that). A lot of job (role) duplication at work, diluting ownership. Whoever shouts louder wins (usually). They talk a lot about collaboration culture but it is passive aggressive and lot of command and control.

Pros:
Flexible working
Good team mates
Cons:
Work life balance. Because of the tech you can work from anywhere anytime. Which means people work long hours which leads to stress and burn out.
Too many stakeholders on projects - takes forever to implement activities and
Great tech stack but over complicated, systems don't talk to each other and you have multiple tools doing similar jobs eg reporting
Conflict amongst senior management means decisions made due to politics rather than what's right for the business
Too many restructures. Living in constant uncertainty.
Lack of career progression. Senior team have been at the company so long there is little chance they'll leave and make space for others to progress.

Pros:
Flexible work options
Women in Technology groups
Cons:
Women folk,

Please research your manager before you join any team, see how women have been treated, see who left, when, were they given challenging projects, were they given promotions, these things are very important.

In Cisco manager is everything, be careful else you might just be going to a deadend in your career.

Pros: Offered good experience in SaaS software.
Cons: Top and next level management at WebEx are clueless.  They bounce back and forth like a ping-pong ball.  They are unable to develop and execute cohesive product roadmaps, yet they fool themselves into believing they can.  Employees are discouraged from bringing up "sensitive issues" to management.  Employees are encouraged to "not rock the boat."  Marketing department is unable to commit to project deadlines, yet blame this on others all the time.  Take responsibility for making things happen?  That's not a Cisco WebEx strongpoint.

Pros: Decent benefits, good work flexibility, some smart folks
Cons:
Huge pay gap between VPs and any other level.  Company swung to far in cost cutting, gotten from the understandable to the ridiculous for a company with such large profit margins, and such a huge cash pile.  The company is run by Frank Calderoni, not by John Chambers.
Too many "priorities", so there are none.

Pros: I had a fantastic time working at Cisco this summer. They told us at orientation to take in as much experience as we could, and really provided the resources to support that goal. My mentor was excellent--supportive and enthusiastic, and a wealth of great advice.
Cons: Not a downside for me, but you have to be comfortable with a little ambiguity, and put in the work to solve problems on your own a bit. To full time folks, this might be obvious, but interns who are less experienced with teamwork found it a bit more difficult.

Pros: The breadth and depth of the business allows for near endless opportunity for the identification of improvement.  An operations manager or analyst can uncover potential efficiency gains under every rock.
Cons: The breadth and depth of the business has evolved quicker than the capacity to create efficient processes and policies that can be globally adopted.  This allows for near endless and hidden opportunity for improvement.  An operations manager or analyst can get lost in the red tape without clear focus on specific targets and a roadmap of how to navigate the political landscape.

Pros: Good benefits and salary as well as mobility
Cons: Cisco is operationally a very disorganized company so it requires long hours to get anything done.  Cisco IT does not support any of their internal systems properly so it requires about 10x the amount of time and 100 Excel spreadsheets to get anything done.  Why Cisco continues to invest millions of dollars in antiquated custom software amazes me.

Pros:
Great technical specialists. 
Lots of people with tons of experience.
In general people are willing to help/work together.
Good/Great technology that moves in more or less right direction.
Flexible work option.
Brand name.
Cons:
Mid-management is getting increasingly politicized (at least in sales). No one really knows what they do. 
Visibility is valued over capability, in other words you need to beat your drum relentlessly to advance. 
As a result, a lot of good people leaving for a change.
Company is getting old, not enough young people.
More and more people that sort of hide in the shades. 
For a network industry leader is pretty bad with product/solution demonstration resources.

Pros: Ability to work remotely enables a lot of flexibility.  Company prides itself on flexible work arrangements to ensure work life balance can be fostered.  training opportunities are awesome.  If there is an interest to develop one self, company has many certifications and programs to be trained on internally.
Cons: VERY difficult to move around.  Company prefer to fill open requisitions with external talent versus considering internals so extremely competitive when interviewing for positions here.  It's really about who you know when trying to find another role within the company.

Pros: A very storied and rich silicon valley company. To me, its all about your team and you manager. If you can have good folks in both regards - its an awesome place. Cutting edge on technology. Well respected. The leader. Good pedigree. Some opportunities to make money.
Cons: Too big. Should be three different companies (UC/Security/Enterprise Networking). Middle management still needs to be cleaned up - lots of ash and trash. Last manager was more in to managing up versus looking out for me or my teammates. Lots of lip service to careers and the ability to do different jobs. Managers usually earn their job by interviewing well and lining up connections to promote their advancement. Manager purposely did not support my efforts to earn CCIE.

Pros:
Allow employees to work from home.
Very loose direct management styles allow a lot of creativity in our jobs.
Cons: High level management has no idea what their teams actually do.  Severe disconnect between reality and working process.  High stress levels at times and constant concern about job security.  Long hours.  Very little thought to work / life balance.  If you don't work 100 hours a week, they will find someone less qualified who has no qualms about the hours.

Pros: Helping Culture, Flexible and collaborative communication tools. Empowerment to achieve best customer experience. Changing physical environment to promote morale.
Cons: Took away our stock options, felt like abandoning us from feeling ownership in the company. For the veterans that have been there since year 2000, many feel that our underwater stock options should have been replaced with new ones, since we stuck it through supporting the company in the ups and downs. Lack of salary adjustments for veterans who have been in the company 15+ yrs

Pros: The people are in general great. It's nice to say you work for Cisco.
Cons: Layoffs again and again and again, and they do it so poorly! You'd think after 6 or 7 years straight they'd have the process figured out by now, which is endemic and illustrative of so many failures within the company. Renewed focus on laying off more senior employees to replace them with cheaper less seasoned college hires. No stock. No real growth.

Pros:
- Flexible working hours and work from at home
- You decide how and where you work; what counts for Cisco are the results
- Great investment in people (benefits, company car, ongoing trainings)
- Ability to change jobs/roles within the company 
- Strong Global Player in

I have two kids at home and can still pursue my job as a marketing manager. With the full flexibility and freedom of choice on when and from where (home/office) you want to work this is a very valuable benefit.
Cons:
- Ongoing waves of headcount reductions have resulted in good people leaving the company and  impacted mood of people at some times
- Complexity, a lot of administration and tools

Pros: Nice gym, cafe is nice , benefits are in par with other companies, still pockets of excellent people. Leader is networking.
Cons: Cisco + Summer = layoffs its been going on for 7 + years. The leadership team was 80% excellent and now only 20% . My VP was worthless and is still there with no direct reports. But she laid off good people. The channel leadership is at a all time low. With ego maniac Hill running around acting like king Joffrey. Glad I dont have to deal with people like that. Cisco was great because of the people but the people in charge now only care about themselves.

Pros: Great experience to work for a company that is a leader not only in the industry, but on a global level. Awesome culture. Seems like there is room for growth especially within Customer Success since it is a newer department. Great pay in comparison to competition.
Cons: Because it is such a large company process and change doesn't happen fast. Seems like your input and suggestions are heard, but not much management can do about it. Customer Success is still in start up mode so the process is overwhelming for now, however, it is being refined currently to solve that problem.

Pros: Employee can get complacent with work. The management doesn't push you to do more. Not all work profiles are challenging. Salary hikes are very meager. Technical knowledge of the employee is not always recognized by the management.
Cons: Employee friendly management. Employee can get exposure from different teams and work profiles. Good work culture. Good work from home policy. Good perks.  Good facilities for employees.

Pros:
- excellent work-life balance; I rarely had to work evenings or weekends
- good benefits
- interesting work (at least in my case)
- if you don't like your work, you could apply internally for other Cisco jobs. I foolishly did not try this, and left the company instead
Cons:
- office environments can be dreary
- you are a tiny cog in a gargantuan machine; you will get buzzword-laden and apparently irrelevant mass emails from people 6-7 rungs further up in the hierarchy
- Fall layoffs are a bummer, even if you don't get laid off
- management may not be competent, depending on the project you are on; if so, their inability to connect software needs and abilities with business needs will frustrate you

Pros: I've been here 10 years and leadership has really worked hard to improve  things like leadership transparency, diversity at the top, employee benefits,  etc. I'm grateful to  be working for a company that always strives to be better!
Cons: We have so many products and I dont think we do a good job at helping employees who aren't involved in products directly to really know what products we have and what exact impact they have  (Cisco Kinetics, Connected Health, Cisco Remote Expert, Tetration, Firepower just to name a few....)

Pros: I have been working for Cisco for a little over a year and thoroughly enjoy coming to work every day; my teammates and colleagues are a major part of that. Not only are the people great but the work environment has been set-up to accommodate all the needs of the employees. Great benefits and compensation. As part of the Global Virtual Sales organization, they fly us out to global sales training (has been most often held in Las Vegas, NV) not only to learn but also to meet the rest of our teammates based outside of our own locations; Cisco really focuses on career-pathing and opening their employees up to options within the company.
Cons: Cisco doesn't offer a travel reimbursement for highway-tolls, etc., but all-in-all that's the worst thing I can say.

Pros: Cisco was a great place to work. Too many perks to list. Leadership generally lived by the core principles of the Cisco "People Deal", an initiative to retain talent by putting the needs of employees first. One example - I was supported through a very difficult and extended personal leave. Cisco retained my job and welcomed me back once the crisis was past.
Cons: Engineering-driven company with scattered UX practice and greatly varying levels of success. There are pockets of great design in various BUs, but unfortunately I was not in one of them. 8 bosses in 5 years, and the only excellent and fully competent one I had was fired because she rubbed some old-timers the wrong way.

Pros: a good place to start a career, learn a lot in a short time. Company well managed with the pandemic. Mandatory working from home.
Cons:
High rotation between engineers, managers, PMs, plus lay-offs every 6months then re-hiring... Difficult to change internally position. Need to know with whom to be a friend in order to get a promotion. Everything depends on visibility how popular you are. Lack of transparency. Heard plenty of internal issues with managers: emotional distress, inequality. Employees afraid of talking about it loudly. Officially we were told to care of ourselves but due to the lack of a workforce, everyone is overloaded. Some managers don't allow to register overtime. So, you might land working 50h per week. 
Foreigners do not stay long, due to cultaral maching with Polish work culture.

Pros: Nothing, water, pop corn, foos table
Cons: Management, Managers, Story tellers, Do nothing types

Pros:
Flexibility to work from home
The perks, some of which are being eliminated...i.e. the fitness centers, the on-site cafes, home wireless service covered (no more), cell phone coverage (no more), etc.
Cons: The seems to be a culture where expediency and politics are valued over efficiency, effectiveness and empowerment.  Furthemore, while the working remotely option is valuable, it is also abusive as it tends to also be an abuse of all-access to the employee and the expectation that they will work around the clock.  Last but not least, I hear the rhetoric of work-life balance and diversity but it is not apparent when you do basic observation of the day-to-day business environment and work culture.

Pros: Flexible time, even with tons of work.  The job is more project oriented than time oriented, and most of your coworkers "get it."  This is not the type of place where a few people do a majority of the work, it's very competitive to stand out, I like that.
Cons: Typical big company issues, lots of processes.  But they try at least to do something about it.  Worst part is the slow erosion of things that made it special 10 years ago, cut for the sake of squeezing every penny out of the bottom line.

Pros:
- Encouraging of your initiative to learn and external education opportunities. 
- Typically relaxed work environment where your workload is self-determined. 
- Has access to large code-bases from which you can learn a wide variety of software techniques. 
- Relatively stable company.
Cons:
- Can be a conservative and procedural-strict company. 
- You need to be in one of the smaller and more advanced-tech group to enjoy many of the pros. 
- More sales and hardware oriented, software groups don't seem as valued in terms of funding and attention.

Pros: Some great people and really cool tech. Fun work trips interstate and international. Some opportunity to expand professional experiences. Looks great on the CV. Very strong customer awareness and penetration. Can make okay money as long as you are selling well. Pretty good corporate perks - hotels, medical, etc...
Cons: Highly politicized. Constant backstabbing and bickering. Significant gap between exec leadership messaging and regional/localized management implementation. Tribalism and nepotism are rife at the coal face. Spineless managers who would rather bury their heads in the sand than advocate for their staff.

Pros: Salary, benefits, technology, work from home, minimal travel if you have the right customer/job
Cons: Management, too many leaders, too little resources assigned to customers at the beginning of any new technology. Squeaky Wheels get all the grease. Customers should complain immediately when they see they are not getting what they paid for, as management only assigns where there are new sales opportunities, regardless of service contracts. CEO "Office" has way too many executives that provide no value but are kept on at high salaries.

Pros:
work life balance is great
Benefits are amazing
Training is hit or miss. Some depts LOVE you to get training others won't spend $1 to train. I've spent time in both of those.
Cons:
Promotions/pay raises are non-existent
Forced ranking- which means managers have to make the tough choice of putting someone as a low performer.....even if they don't have one. 
People come in making more than you with less experience doing the same job( i.e. longevity isn't rewarded)
The sky is always falling! We'll have awesome quarters ALL the time, yet management consistently says OMG we suck!

Pros: If you want to learn, be challenged, do the job of 2+ people, have no life balance, if you like constantly shifting environment and a "wild West" environment, Cisco is the company for you.
Cons: It is difficult to contribute in a meaningful way, when the vision keeps alluding you, the strategies keep changing on you, the organizations keep reorganizing with no clear articulation as to why. The organization is very hierarchical, and each higher grade cost more! So it's very difficult to move up in the organization. You end up stagnating at the grade you are for many years and if you are good you are rewarded with more work.

Pros: I joined Cisco in 1995 and left in 2014.  The company I joined was not the company I left.  The culture of family existed in the 1990's and early 2000's.  The products, technologies, and people were fantastic and still are very good.
Cons: Cisco now does what large companies do, which is annual layoffs.  Sometimes these layoffs are actually ongoing just aren't reported as they are below 3% of the total employee population.  This systemic issue leads to a culture of CYA and backstabbing, especially at executive levels.

Pros: Culture feels like a large family, highly collaborative, people who generally want to do the right thing for the company. Lots of talent at all levels. Great compensation, benefits, and work/life.
Cons: Not product-oriented (too customer driven...easy to build new products with little strategy, hard to kill products that have no market viability). Too many people resting and vesting in certain functions.  Too many rounds of layoffs. Starting to feel like Sun Microsystems of old.

Pros:
You get to work with greatly talented people. 
Flexible work arrangements are good.
Cons: The leadership team in IT is corrupt starting with the CIO. People are promoted for the most vague reasons. The claim they act with integrity till you find family relatives of the CIO working in her reporting chain. She actually continued to manage family members, who benefitted financially from outsourcing deals even after moving to her role as COO under new CEO. The new CIO is one of her watchdogs, who also is known to promote people based on racial agenda. He has no achievements and just a talking head. It is still Jacoby in the house with G keeping the status quo. They witch hunted many good people managers who were forced to leave.

Pros: Smart people, decent pay and benefits.
Cons: Very siloed positions, most people are under-employed since very talented people are hired into job silos that limit the full expression or development of their skills.  There are constant layoffs, accompanied by all of the unhealthy cultural by-products that come with layoffs: paranoia, lack of motivation, managers pitching smoke-and-mirror programs since you will never be held accountable to deliver based on the constant reorganizations and priority shifts, lack of trust.  Very talented senior leaders who have the confidence to speak the truth, name the dysfunction for what it is, and try to be agents for change are always the ones to announce they are 'pursuing other opportunities' (aka, forced out), leaving the sub-par leaders to run the ship.

Pros:
1) Flexibility: Have work from home options and work hours that can be balanced between home and office. This allows me to spend time for self-care and family, apart from focusing on my career.
2) Beautiful campus and added facilities
3) Management is always ready to listen 
4) Compensation and other benefits such as, leave of absence, etc
Cons: The recent layoffs have triggered a fear of insecurity with the job. However, Cisco takes utmost care to ensure that the employees who are impacted are taken good care in terms of the benefits.  This cannot be compared with the other organizations. Although these decisions are difficult for Cisco, it tries its level best to compensate in the best manner possible.

Pros:
Checking all the boxes related to social justice and D & I
Chuck is a great face for the company
Cons:
NO clear strategy that is executed with any priority/investment commitment 
Multiple layoffs due to lack of portfolio and wfp
Little career/promo opportunity if you aren't part of the 'deck' that continues to get shuffled at the top
EXTREMELY slow

Pros: Cisco has been rated as the best employer anywhere in the world several times in recent years. The focus on culture quickly made me realize that I had been working in toxic workplace cultures for years without really realizing it.   Cisco attracts a huge depth and breath of talent, so are likely to working with some of the best minds in the industry.
Cons: As an engineering program manager joining Cisco, I was initially expecting a more process driven culture. Cisco has many product groups, some based on acquisitions. Every group seems to use a different set of tools, templates and documentation standards. This means there is a little bit more overhead in managing technical teams if programs bring together engineers from around the organization.

Pros: The attitude of "customer success" is very prevalent within the company, so if you run up against a roadblock, using that magic phrase opens many doors.
Cons: In Customer Advocacy, there were no real opportunities for advancement unless you were willing to relocate to San Jose.  Benefit costs increased substantially every year, but there were no raises to be had.  Reorganization happened every 6 months, so I never had the same boss for one full review cycle.  Management was constantly trying to justify the existence of our group by adding supplemental job tasks to the job description, but failing to recognize and evangelize the inherent value of our core deliverables.

Pros: You are working with talented and driven peers in a  highly collaborative environment. The management team is very supportive of employee training and development, allowing employees to learn and grow with the company.  Cisco has a culture of employee empowerment, giving employees the freedom to make important decisions.
Cons: Long hours and job strain can take toll on personal life. Need to find better work-life balance for employees.  Though the company expects its employees to perform in the industry's top 10% but its compensation plans for the systems engineers is only above average.

Pros: I can generally work from home.
Cons:
Limited promotional opportunities so it's important to play politics well if you want to succeed.

Few women in leadership positions. Lots of lip service on diversity but no real data is shared.

With limited raises and underperforming stock, it's not a good place to retire from unless you are in a senior management position.

Managers and above refer to themselves as "your leadership team" (ironic) and post their pictures on every email. And, of course, they are all wearing suits and ties. Individual advertisement and selling is a big time waster at Cisco. 

Innovation is not emphasized or rewarded. Instead, you have to learn to play the game well and know who to buddy up with.

Pros:
Brand is highly regarded
Install Base typically leads to long term customer relationships
Always able to get audience with customer executives.
Cons:
What John Chamber's preaches is not reality in the trenches.  Sales Management are spreadsheet jockeys who are manic and frankly, emotionally frazzled by their fear of upper management.  I likened my experience in sales to the attributes of 3rd generation child abuse.  You manager was abused by his manager, so he abuses you because it is the "way I was raised".  A total lack of management ethics when the heat is on to hit a sales commit at the end of a month or a quarter.

My advice is to not be seduced by the "Human Network" but stay away from Cisco for your "Human Sanity"

Pros: Many different technology projects to work on, options to move around - laterally - in the company.   Some good, smart people still work there.
Cons: Upper management has lost their pulse on the business.  They don't meet with the customer anymore and have lost respect for the individual contributors who own the relationship with the customer.

Pros:
Work form home supported
Still some great people left in the company
Cons:
Promotions and compensation decisions are based on politics and not performance
Execs could care less about employee morale or development
Recognition is non existent
Managers only care about their ego and their upward movement

Pros:
Interesting group of people, working on good technology.

Good sense of long-term vision by the execs.

General culture of being willing to take risks on new technology.
Cons:
Bureaucracy for anyone trying to hire people, buy captial equipment, or add a vendor to the approved vendors list is horrible.

Inter-team petty politics, particularly by some Support managers, is a pain.

Strategy seems to change too frequently to be able to implement effectively.

Too many people in different customer advocacy roles just trying to justify their own jobs.

Pros: Competitive pay, good benefits and the advantages of contributing in a world-class, world-leading institution. Most management is flexible and focused on results. Definite benefit to working in California but the good news is that the mentality is slowly changing and telecommuting is more and more accepted. A case of "eating your own dog food" since Cisco sells the technologies that allow for remote work. Had I not have a family illness I needed to tend to I'd still be there.
Cons: Has lost some of the agility as it has grown. There are some people who still cling to the past rather than work at making today and tomorrow better. When I was there they were moving to the open concept work space

Pros: Cisco has a bunch of perks; Flexibility, Growth, Exposure, Work/Life Balance, Great Atmosphere, Work Family. Overall Cisco cares about their employees and what makes them happy.
Cons: Cisco only has a couple of negatives in my opinion. Performance reviews are slightly unfair but don't really harm you(meaning you are more likely to get average but that means good). Visiting HQ depends upon the team you work for and some teams never send people some limits visibility face to face (WebEx makes up for that a little but still would like to shake a hand from time to time.)

Pros: Like the company's management by objective (MBO) culture, assuming everyone's MBOs align. Do love the company's acceptance of a distributed (work anywhere) culture. Do support the company's latest "Internet of Everything" market-texture.
Cons: Cisco has become more and more about who you know and who likes you, in lieu of what you have delivered or your value-add to the company, shareholders and/or customers. Politics now dominate the landscape and the embedded bureaucracy is only for the strongest of heart.

Pros: They are supportive about flex time and telecommuting. Paychecks arrive as scheduled.
Cons:
There is no on-boarding. If you need to know about something, (f.e.; auto-deposit payroll vs. commission checks) you're expected to find it on the poorly-indexed corporate website(s). For somethings you can call HR in California. The phone staff was always friendly & the on-hold times were ok. However, even at ok, altogether it'll make for very long first days.

There is no relocation assistance, so bargain hard for that signing bonus! 

I can only speak from my experiences, but in my opinion - Do not work for this company. Not unless you enjoy being bludgeoned out of your career by small-minded micro-managers. If you have another option, take it. I had options. And I chose Cisco! Dammit.

Forewarned is forearmed.

Pros: Great culture, great security, very smart people. It's a high integrity company with high integrity people. Very people-friendly place to work.
Cons: Never-ending reorganizations make it extremely difficult to get anything done. Lots of decisions seem to be made based on politics and personal favors, and those decisions don't last. The result is lack of trust w/ the most executive leadership.

Pros:
*Best part is the flexibility to work. Flexible timings, work from home.
*One of the best infrastructure, good gym.
*Cab facility
*Enough scope to learn
Cons:
*You may not get hikes for couple of years in a row
*Very senior people are still waiting for their promo. 
*Depends but chances are you have to take calls sometimes even at late night
*If you are more into customer issues you will be stressed.

Pros: Good salary and benefits - very flexible work environment.
Cons: Annual laying offs  have become a regular and unpleasant part of the job.  3 years running I have laid off employees not based on achievement - simply based on hitting a HC number.  My employees are running scared - never believing their job is secure - no matter how hard they work or how well they achieve.

Pros:
At the core of the digital revolution
Amazing product portfolio
Unmatched partner network
Very strong balance sheet
Highly skilled workforce
Open, flexible work environment
Limited hierarchy and politics
Cons:
Struggles to depart from product-centric culture
Jumps from vision straight to execution, lacks clarity of strategy with sufficient detail and focus to guide employees
Incentives are still old-world
Company transformation is hampered by Wall Street expectations and company search for short-term returns

Pros:
(1)  Flexible work environment.  Can work from home
(2)  Salary and benefits are good
(3)  Still has a few good executives and leaders
Cons:
(1)  Cisco has been in a state of constant restructuring for the last 4 years.  Roles and responsibilities can change overnight
(2)  Morale of employees is at an all time low.  And most of the management does not seem to care
(3)  Cisco has lost its innovation edge.  Its a company that is slowly going out of business
(4)  Zero career growth opportunities

Pros: Work from home and flexibility in work hours are the biggest Pros why people want to stick to with the company.
Cons: Network Consulting Engineer job is a thankless job at cisco with no great pay compared to other job roles. No one values this job role as much as they do if you were in Sales. Software Development and/or Hardware Development. Very hard to grow up if you are sincere, hard working and self starter, probably you will end up working more and nothing else. Other big companies give benefits to their employees and so does cisco, so nothing different and great in it.

Pros: Great people with deep experience.  Bench strength was phenomenal -- deep subject matter expertise in a broad array of capabilities.   Mature org that meant it was rare to see a mandate without the resource plan to make it happen -- far different than many tech companies in that regard.
Cons: Going through a major re-org throughout most of my time there.  I had three bosses and four roles in less than 18 months.  Profesionally, that was invigorating but it didn't yeild as high a contribution  that a bit more stability would have afforded.

Pros:
Great culture, everyone happy to collaborate and help each other. 
Management hierarchy is relatively flat and most managers are very open to conversations and getting stuck in at all levels of the business. 
Packages are competitive, and the commission get's exciting when you star to overachieve.. 
Cisco of course carries a big brand into a lot of accounts so getting in front of customers is never a challenge...
Cons: Still a hardware vendor first, massively needs to look at becoming more software driven, and refining the cloud proposition - and fast. Work needs to be done on Cisco's business relevance to IoT, digitization and the move towards applications and software.

Pros: Cisco is a company that believes treating its employees well and invests heavily to maintain that culture. The even have things like on site day care, a really nice gym, and on site doctors with a pharmacy. As far as the business is concerned it is still a monster generating a lot of cash but it still primarily comes from Routing and Switching - a market that is being disrupted.
Cons: Lots of red tape and politics. In recent years the company has had little growth and with a lower turnover rate due to a good work environment it creates challenges for people to move up even when they are more than ready.

Pros: Work-life balance, work from home perks, good benefits -- full gym, health center on campus, job stability, free shuttle from SF, growth opportunities
Cons:
- A LOT of corporate politics which creates a negative work environment where teams within the same organization are fighting against each other instead of working together 
- Still working in a waterfall/semi-agile
- Not a "tech start-up" feel (limited free snacks, subsidized lunch, gym cost comes from pay check, not very many millenials)
- lack of clear roles and responsibilities

Pros:
1) Joined Cisco through one of the industry's best  early-in career program called CSAP (Cisco Sales Associate Program). This extensive  1 year training program includes a 6 month on-the-job experience & prepares us for field role.
