This program infact accelerates our career & gets us at par with a 5-8 year experienced Systems Engineer role.

2) The culture of the company itself is to nurture each-other & grow together. So all the colleagues ,  mentors & managers are extremely supportive , guiding us to climb the ladder of our career

3) As a part of technical pre-sales, I get the exposure to both crucial technical design discussions & the business side of the company.
Cons: None. Cisco is one of the best companies you can work for.

Pros: 4 weeks PTO at all levels plus holidays and one week volunteer time. Longstanding flexibility with WFH and remote work.
Cons: Depending on the team there may be crunch at times, but it isn't usually prolonged. Regular layoff cycles. Pay is middling. DevOps, tooling, and procedures are decades old. Innovation is welcomed, but hard to actually execute or get time or budget for.

Pros: People benefits were amazing. Cisco really does commit to their people and their benefits proved it. A major medical issue meant I had to take time away and it was a none issue. Complete support from my boss and the company as a whole.
Cons:
So many... Process and policies that don't align with reality. A lot of politics, particularly in upper management. Tons of churn in middle management that leads to constantly changing priorities.

Speaks a lot about DEI and does try to take some steps towards it, but trying to get recruiters to focus on diverse hiring is a nightmare. Additionally actually bringing in talent that isn't white male or Indian is hard since there isn't a great supportive culture to point to, so the problem perpetuates.

Pros: The best Cisco offers is flexibility in working hours.  Lots of options in when and where to work from.  Home and different locations.  Other benefits aren't the best but are acceptable.
Cons: Downside is the flexibility in working hours can sometime end up causing you to work extra long hours especially when under a time crunch.  Cisco has a fully outsourced manufacturing.  As such, many of the manufacturing operation has long since moved to lower cost regions.  This resulted in the need to work odd hours considering that time zone differences.  This can at times be a strain when new products are being launched.

Pros: An ambitious company with its heart in the right place. Capable of producing incredible technology. Pay and conditions are excellent and you get the sense that you work for a company that is not out to screw its employees. Company has a very high reputation that is, in my opinion, well deserved.
Cons: Despite working for a networking company, communication between functions can leave a lot to be desired. Company is known for being inflexible towards its customers. The overall strategy and direction can sometimes come across as being a little vague.

Pros: Great pay for an internship, great experience if you end up in the right group.  San Jose's a nice area to live for the summer, and the other interns there are good people.
Cons:
The learning curve when you join makes most of a three month internship dedicated to figuring out what's going on in the company, although I'm sure this is pretty common across companies this size.

The intern experience can vary greatly depending on what group you end up in, and there's no way to know this before hand.  Some groups will have you doing real work while others won't.

Pros:
Job stability, I can't think of another place in this industry where better stability is offered.
Most of benefits and bonus are definitely on par with others in the same industry.
As the company is hugh in size, there is always some job that can interst you.
Cons: Middle managers - as with many companies, there are just too many mediocre middle managers that are not contributing to anything. Some managers that are on the same building takes 2-3 hours working out/jobbing in the middle of the day! Yes, that might be good for him or even amazing for his age, but that's not going to bring out a lot of confidence from others who are just trying to meet the deadlines.

Pros: Challenging work. Very smart colleagues. Huge market opportunities, if operational issues can be addressed. Leadership is commitment to open dialogue with employees. Stock upside.
Cons: It's a pretty hierarchical place, with not as much empowerment as needed for middle tier management. Heavy sr. exec politicking interferes with rapid, smart decision-making. There is little positive feedback, so you need to be ready for that.

Pros: A market leader in many technologies, continued investment in innovation, and strong breadth of product. An industry leader that has oercome many growth challenges over the years and positioned itself well vs competitors
Cons: Lower and middle management are filed with underqualified aspiring leaders who lack the background and experience to effectively lead. Through 2 recent early retirements and layoffs, many competant folks have left the company leaving many dolts to rule the roost. Politics and self interest define the motivation of lower management at the expense of great employees.

Pros: Challenging work which contributes to a lot of learning and growing as an employee and as a person.  Working there twenty years ago when the business was booming, was a fantastic, one time life experience.  There are a lot of smart people at Cisco, which was a great environment to work in.
Cons: They lost focus of the most important asset, people.  It is a very top and bottom organization/company.  The executive compensation gap compared to 55% of the company, is HUGE.  There should have been more key leadership changes at the very top, much much much sooner and often.

Pros: Benefits are good. Cisco works very hard to put excellent people in their roles that collaborate together. In the time that I have been here I have found all my coworkers very helpful; we all work together to make sure we are all successful.
Cons:
The money is good but could be better. 
Each year there are management changes which are good and bad. You never know if you will be working for the same manager for more than one year. If you really love your manager you may not have him the next year. 
Fortunately most managers are great people and also try and make you successful at what you do. 
Big challenge with expense control. Sometimes it's limiting to doing your job.

Pros: In my experience bonus + salary is pretty tough to match at competitors.  Great work/family balance, working remotely is generally allowed (but I never tried to abuse it).  In general the work is interesting and furthers my career as a software engineer.
Cons: Sometimes I feel as if my work assignments are not as "meaty" as I would like.  At other companies I've had a lot broader scope and responsibility.  It's not always the case; I think it varies from group to group and even manager to manager.  Promotions can be tough to come by (at least for grade 10 and above) and is largely dictated by your level of visibility and playing politics.

Pros: Strong brand with great earnings potential for sales people as Cisco basically can offer customers a solution across a much the wider spectrum compared to other network vendors
Cons: Strong focus on sales numbers, so it kind of consumes your life leaving little space for other matters of life. Cisco is 40+ B$ company, but it's share price battles to compete with likes of a 1 B$ ntwk company like Ciena's share price - something is wrong up there?

Pros:
-If you are a loud speaker and enjoy talking for hours and doesn't matter if you are talking sense or not, you can climb to the top and do quite well (Director level) with this company.
-Without college degree?  No problem, I've seem people get their foot in the door as a contractor and then kiss their way up.  

-Good medical benefits
Cons:
- No more perks like free water, soda, juice, commuter's check ,etc.  
- Free lunch for monthly staff meetings became pot luck.
- Worked 14-16 hours per day.  No overtime pay.
-Too many meetings, and very little time to do any work.

Pros: Brand, Financial stability, people on the ground level, breadth of technology, does acquisitions better than most, global, ease of working globally, flexibility in work location, benefits in the upper quartile
Cons: too many directors and VPs spend too much time managing up for their own careers and not leading their teams; bloated in the middle, that is, too many VPs and directors, too many layoffs, promotion of the wrong people

Pros:
Good place for younger people and recent college grads to get a start in Networking.
Competitive benefits.
Cons:
Cisco has done a reset over the last 4 years, moving their compensation and benefits ranges down to match
new younger employees.  Not a  lot of growth opportunities. Rampant racism and infighting between corporate and India operations.  Lack of senior leadership, vision, direction.  If you just want to get some experience on your resume, work hard and keep your head down, then you'll do ok.  If you want a long term career, go somewhere else.

Pros: Cisco is a great company that will provide you ample opportunity, provided you're able to "get out."  Some groups invest in their people more than others.  If you're in the "right" one, it will be awesome.
Cons: It's hard to get out of some positions that have a negative stigma attached.  Bonuses are not structured fairly.  Cisco is moving away from telecommunting so it's hard to find advancement if you're not in the right city.

Pros: I love working in the Technical Services organization at Cisco in RTP, NC.  There is a competitive, yet laid-back atmosphere that I really enjoy.  There are many opportunities for development and coworkers and managers are very supportive and are typically quick to recognize individuals for their good work.  The salary is decent but coupled with all the great benefits the overall compensation package is certainly competitive.
Cons: Skilled engineers can make a better base salary at smaller companies in the area although job stability and the benefits are likely the trade-off.  Otherwise I can't think of many cons to working at Cisco.

Pros:
Transparent leadership decision making
The best technology in the world
Fantastic work experience, from offices to how they equip you remotely
Focus on YOU as an employee, not what you do in a current role
High ability to move around, try new things and grow new skills
Every employee has a voice, and it is listened to
Working with the smartest, talented team in the world, around the world
Cons: some times the work from anywhere, anytime does encroach on personal life, especially if your team is global.  That said, the expectation is you are responsible for this -  and take time back for yourself another occasion.

Pros: World class company.  Many Type A employees.  $50B in revenue which makes it tough to grow significantly.  Top compensation packages and benefits.  Many interesting projects on routing and switching, cloud and IoT.
Cons: Frequent reorganizations and layoffs.  Most of the business is stilled tied to routing and switching which are slow growing businesses.  Disorganized and Constant budget pressure and the need to do more with less resources.  Lots of hidden headcount with contractors which account for 70K heads.

Pros:
* The pay is above the average comparing with other R&D center of similar size foreign companies in China. 
* Unlike most other Chinese companies, overtime work is not common.
* It is a pleasure to work with professional colleagues.
* Managers are supportive.
Cons:
* Strict with travel cost. Used collaboration tools heavily to avoid traveling.
* No travel allowance if travel abroad. Just cover all the actual cost of accommodation, dinner and transportation.
* Career opportunity for software QA engineers is not as good as software engineers.

Pros: Overall, good opportunities (if you know where to look), ability to impact the industry, solid benefits, great life/work balance and reasonable salaries.  There is a reason Cisco consistently makes "best place to work" lists.  The leadership change has been a huge positive.
Cons: The closer you are to the core businesses, the more politics you end up having to deal with--it can be a huge productivity tax. The market is evolving and some leaders are in denial about this, which can be equal parts frustrating and entertaining.  The thing is, Cisco is so big, you cannot make a blanket statement, it really ends up depending on your manager and management chain.

Pros:
Exposure to latest technologies.
Excellent work from home option.
Half yearly bonus.
Recognition in terms of RSU, gift vouchers and much more.
Salary on 25th of every month or last weekday before 25th.
quarterly team outing or lunch.
stock purchase option.
fun activities. Sponsored training.
Medical insurance covers parents as well.
Company transport at a very subsidised rate.
Manager feedback etc
Cons:
Be ready to be fired any time. Quarterly results play a vital role.
Cisco is well renowned for networking and firing
Annual appraisal depends on your business unit.
You will get used to hearing headcount reduction, business unit sale or some acquisitions quite often.
Appraisal only single digit.
Performance doesn't matter when it comes to firing.
I feel sad for my fellow Colleagues losing jobs

Pros: I have been working in this company for 10+ years in India Site. I have found that this company adopts best industry standards when it comes to software development process or employee care. It provides you the choice on how you want to contribute yourself. I have seen colleagues who been rightly rewarded with promotions and higher grades when they give exemplary contributions. It pays as you perform without any hindrance. You can choose to grow slow and steady while giving enough time to your family. In other words company allows you to grow as you desire. One another good things is that this company provides good transport service for its employees.
Cons: On some areas I feel India site is not having R&D opportunity in latest technologies.

Pros:
- Flexible work hours
- Relaxed environment, challenging work
- Awarded for hard work and results
- Great exposure to different technologies
Cons:
- Due to company size, lots of free loaders
- Sometimes number of years trumps newer innovative thinking from junior/inexperienced folks
- 80/20 rule applies, company seems to run on 20% of the folks doing a lot more than the 80% who are doing what is expected, nothing more.

Pros:
The best part about Cisco Systems is the diverse portfolio of the company would provide you with immense opportunities to grow. You can be certain of finding a job you like. 

Other Pros include

1. Great Management who provide space to grow.
2. Flexible timings and Work from Home.
3. Work and Play. Time is devoted to both work and enjoyment involving outings and field trips.
4. The company is a market leader in is technology. Once you master it, you become a domain expert.
Cons:
1. Some areas need growth in terms of research expenditure.
2. Layoffs is a concern in both senior level and fresher positions.

Pros: Seemingly large company, lots of products
Cons:
Since it's an exceedingly large company, (up to 8 layers of management from bottom to CEO), there's no true care for employees.
- Lots of HR propaganda about give-and-take, pretending to care about homelessness, mental healths, etc. but  when it comes down to it, they will fire you and not blink an eye.  hypocrites!
- internal job site is a joke - unless you want to take a huge pay cut and move to San Jose
- lots of internal politics, brown-nosing
- VPs not even responding to emails
- no employee loyalty

Cisco will be eaten by  more agile competitors - either US-based or elsewhere.

Pros:
1. Excellent Benefits & 401K match
2. Flexibility
3. The CEO has been leading a great transition towards Software & subscription revenues and the stock price reflects it.
Cons:
* The individual performance only matters to a minimal extent as we keep hearing from our managers and directors over and over again that the BU did not get enough budget for promotions or hikes. So even if you are a high performer and are not in one of those GREAT BUs, the hikes are not really hikes. You can get stuck way below the market range for your grade.

* Not sure if the company / HR has disclosed about gender pay gap.

Pros: Decent pay and benefits. The work can be challenging and rewarding but career growth come from you with little company support.
Cons: Ageism is real there. Excellent courses for career development but they do not tell management how their employees can access them, So it is just window dressing. If your business unit is not at 20% growth, find a new job. Senior managers have different goals. The priorities of our Business Unit SVP were not aligned with our Product VP.

Pros:
Work culture and company policies are very good.
Good work life balance and WFH facility.
Good work and opportunity to work with best engineers in the domain.
Bonus pay is good and most often it is more than the 100% of the target bonus
Cons:
Growth and getting up the ladder in the company is very slow. 
Overall compensation is less when compared to its peers because of which attrition is increasing. 
Even though lot of opportunities available, internal rotation is difficult.

Pros:
The perks are good but thats about it. There is a the all famed claim that "Cisco is a big company" but that is all that happens.

From the day you join till end you hear the same dialogue again and again.Everything is an aquired project and no one has a clue about bringing it to ship shape quality.

The cafeteria is even outsourced so to speak and it was the worst caterers ive ever seen in my life. The people raise complains all the time but its of no use.

Occasionally theres a fire drill for which we need to run downstairs , thats one thing i learnt from there
Cons:
sick management
lack of vision
no proper management or visionary views
no guidance or mentoring in moulding new employees into anything

Pros: Good for anyone who lives networking, C, Java, and web applications. Pays well and benefits are ok. Work from home is especially good.
Cons:
It is a software engineering job and can be very boring and tedious at times. Java is non-algorithmic coding and the only thing you learn is more Java. You don't really research any novel ideas and implement them, just maintain and update old products with new features. Features developed sometimes makes you think if anyone will use it, even internally. If you are not interested in software, this is not your heaven. 

Performance is based on how many customer found defects you resolve and quality of your code.

Pros:
-flexible work hours (@home etc)
-good management (really depends on the BU/group, but this one was top notch). they stick up for their employees.
-impetus is on the employee to make career advancement, but if you take initiative and play cards right, you'll be rewarded -- depending on your preferences or personality, this could be a good or bad thing.
-good brand name for future careers elsewhere
Cons:
-highly silo'd organization 
-unclear priorities or tasks at times -- might be mgmt related
-need to know who to ask to get things done (politics). 
--to qualify this, seems like this would be pretty universal to any workplace, but many have stated it's more prevalent at cisco

Pros:
1. Open communication.
2. Fair chance of growth.
3. Nurturing of talent.
4. Development of carrier
5. Workplace and work environment is very good, respect of individuals.
Its really a Human Network.
Cons:
At times, seniority is given apriori above all, even if you have valid concerns.
They will not tell you what you have to do for your growth, you have to find your ways, basically
you have to be innovative by doing things differently. There is major room for improvement in bringing the top management plans/ideas/execution to the individuals. Upward Vertical communication is good, but not the otherway.

Pros: If you want to lead a peaceful life with no tensions then cisco is the place for you. I think cisco is a great place for married people as married people need to stike a balance between their married and professional lives.
Cons: The downsides are unlimited. Cisco's talent retention policy is pathetic and they dont give adequate recognition to the talent they have. infact in one of the interviews i've heard chambers say that they dont like to hire the best. Cisco is a place for a mediocres. Cisco is the number 1 networking company in the world but from the salaries perspective they are at the 60th percentile.

Pros: It has a very open culture and takes care of it's employees well. Most of the time work ethics and responsibility taken by employees are good
Cons: Off late, open culture is going away, by virtue of cisco allowing it's acquired companies to giving a complete free hand and that has destroyed some of the good DNA of Cisco. Most of the time, the head of these acquired companies and it's VPs manipulate things just under the nose of Cisco's heads just for their personal growth and destroy the team and later run away to other companies.

Pros: Cisco is truly  caring about employees and when John Chambers calls us the Cisco Family, he really means it. Cisco's  compensation and benefit packages are excellent compared to other industry peers. Cisco has an excellent senior leadership team at the top.
Cons: In some areas, Cisco has too many layers of management. Also, the work culture can be quite inconsistent across teams. Some teams would be working many hours and tight deadlines and other groups taking it easy.

Pros: Great exposure to technology and corporate culture. Good work/life balance. Decent compensation and great benefits.
Cons: If you stay in one role for more than a few years you could end up stuck there. Not to mention things become repetitive very fast so move around in order to stay relevant and continuing to learn. Management is not in sync across the bored so you can be a super star on one team, but a complete failure based on the criteria of another team. This is harmful to those who want to move around in the company.

Pros: Cisco is very good in being accommodating and treats its employees with respect, respects their personal time and tries its best to be flexible.
Cons: Hierarchies are quite closed, there is little to no chance to get promoted and there seems to be a never ending number of management levels tripping over each other. Difficult to see accountability. Also since they introduced webex, people don't see eachother anymore and teams don't meet face to face anymore - a loss of humanity in my opinion.

Pros: Great learning, Market leader, in-depth customer perspective shaping products
Cons:
Employees who stay at Cisco are not rewarded..Case in point I got a 40-50% jump in salary when I switched to another competitor. Takes too long to get a promotion. 
Company is very bureaucratic and even small projects having a demonstrable but small impact (in the 10-50 Mln $ range) take a long time to get approval. Company is built around getting massive transitions correctly.

Pros: The are some strong really talented executives still around.. .Technical Services and Cloud Sales. Maybe others. .I don't know.
Cons:
More layoffs.  Annual event. Same dribble. (This year a denial that it is to cut costs.  Ha! )  The executives ( 98% white male over 50) want a younger cheaper work force so salary increases will be metered out only in low cost geographies (India and China) and to those under 35.
The way to make money from cisco is as a contractor.  Can't do without them and pay through the nose.  Not saying don't accept an offer. Just saying .."free agent" aplies even if you are an employee.

Pros: Established tech company with some good people.  We often say we suck less than the competition, and there is a lot of truth to that statement.  There are competitors that have solid point products, but customers have to cobble together a solution from many different vendors.  Our products run a broad gamut and do work, but aren't always the best.
Cons: Large, slow, and lots of "overhead" wasting lots of time trying to justify their existence.  Many little fiefdoms that exist for the soul purpose of hiding useless overhead.

Pros: This is a "smart company" and the by product of an innovative culture that has grown well sense its inception. It appears that the CEO and the very top brass have a true desire to maintaining a culture were ideas can flourish and people are treated with respect.
Cons: Unfortunately, corporate sludge has stuck to the bottom of the organization. I have noticed some of this "sludge" has gone rogue and created their own culture (about them only), and make decisions that are not in the best interest of the company, rather, it keeps them feeling powerful and employed

Pros: Cisco has a great technology portfolio albeit huge, the people are great to work with and have a winning culture, thought leadership is inspiring - although it can sometimes be so far in the future it is difficult to execute effectively with channel partners, work-life balance is excellent,
Cons: Constant change - as in regional management reshuffle, strategy and structural changes follow the frequency of management change and the constant downsizing every year means a paranoid and political survival culture is developing and with the organisation announcing 4 months before it actually happens full sales productivity in the year is reduced to only about 6 months

Pros:
- Really good work-life balance
- You are given time to finish your projects and to experiment , there is no real pressure or stress
- Nice team of people to work with
Cons:
- There is a red tape and hierarchy here which makes it difficult to get your projects approved 
- Projects get cancelled and layoffs are high even when customers are excited about your product
- There is a bias during Performance review so you will never get top 10% even if you are superstar and your Director does not think so 
- No innovation (or) thought process around user experience

Pros: Flexibility - people can work remote somewhat, depending on your manager.  However, if people don't see you in the office, people may not know who you are.  When the next localized or global layoff (which is very frequent) comes, you may have the high chance to be on the list.
Cons: There are groups at Cisco which are plainly fat.  There primary existences are to justify their own existences by spinning initiatives to make them look good even though there are no meets in those initiatives.

Pros:
- Market leading technology, lots of acquisitions too, which make approaching customers with new propositions much easier.
- Great team culture around collaboration, and working together as one unit
-  Work life balance and flexibility to work from home is brilliant and is aided by Cisco's technology.
- Company trying to evolve and capture market transitions - Software, IoT, Cloud which makes for an existing future.
Cons:
- Pace of change and execution is awfully slow
- Despite claims of being a software company, sales team is still heavily product orientated. 
- Stale middle management have become "stuck in their ways" and lack new innovative ideas to drive real change.

Pros:
Can work from home. 

Management leaves you to do your job for the most part.  

There is a strict unwritten rule not to lose it (aka, yelling at employees, writing rude emails and etc...) no matter how hot the subject .  It will not happen right away but, they will isolate and layoff those people.  A very good culture requirement.
Cons:
On call 24/7.  

Things that are normal for a big company aka watching management change direction randomly, people sending pointless emails to the entire company.

You just ignore requirements and endless demands take mandatory training.  

At the end of the day they realize that you are very valuable in the customer's eyes and that is all that matters.

Pros:
Diverse opportunities -supports career moves across functional silos
Competitive compensation and benefits
Good people - little to no tolerance for empire builders and leadership by fear
Collaboration culture - supports flexible working, virtual collaboration, etc
Cons:
Big company - takes a while for anyone to connect all the dots.  You will likely find people in different organizations trying to achieve the same goal not knowing about each other
Work hours - global company means working across time zones, partly compensated by flexible working, but if you need a 9-5 job this may not be for you.

Pros: Good package, Good work life balance, good start for fresher's I'm terms of package.
Cons: No job security. Employees live in fear of layoffs everyday. No real RnD going. Cisco wants to be huge, but there is no concrete vision. It's more of a bank. Lot of buying and selling. Staying at Cisco for long, could end your career due to lack of challenge. They don't have uniform policies across countries. Biased policies, Indian employees are taken for granted.

Pros:
Incredible ongoing focus on people and experiences
Opportunities to help determine direction just keep coming
Executives really want to hear from everyone, not a yes culture
Employees feel more heard and a part of decisions around what's next
Easy to rotate or move into other parts of the business to round out your skills and knowledge
Recognizes the need to evolve constantly and tries to do so
Cons:
Sometimes we focus too much on making a change instead of is it the right one to make.  
We don't always backpedal fast when we realize we took the wrong course.  
Experiences are not consistent across the company.

Pros: There are many reasons to love Cisco. I would highlight the three main ones about this company. Firstly, in Cisco you are surrounded by truly talented, knowledgeable, and kind people and you are a part of a big (global) diverse family.  Secondly, each member of this family has great opportunities to grow and develop themselves personally, intellectually, and professionally. And thirdly, Cisco is indeed about honesty, integrity, and transparency, which is very important for me personally and many of us.
Cons: This is not really a downside, but a more challenging thing when working in Cisco. It is constant changes that the company goes through because of the constant and rapid changes in the market and industries. This requires you to be agile and adaptive.

Pros:
My role typically requires me to be on site a couple days a week because it is customer facing. When Covid hit my team was so great at transitioning into the virtual world. Everyone is so understanding of each individuals situation and management encourages us to take care of ourselves and our family first. 
I love the check ins from the ELT that occur bi-weekly. They are super transparent and are not shy about talking about various topics ranging from Social Justice to Mental Health. If you are looking for a great place to work that cares about it's employees Cisco is for you.
Cons: None I can think of

Pros:
- Excellent health insurance (choice of plans, low out-of-pocket maximums, easy to deal with)
- Most technical writers are salary non-exempt which has the advantage of overtime pay but it's degrading to have to enter time every 2 weeks
- Flexible WFH even before Covid
- Excellent departmental management (very empathetic, encourage you to work on your strengths, doesn't punish you for not being naturally good at something)
- VPs and up are completely disconnected from reality
Cons:
- Miserly PTO (3 weeks, not negotiable, no accounting for seniority)
- Pitiful tools you have to use every day (except for Oxygen Author)

Pros: Great people are attracted to Cisco. They do care about their employees and show that with ample benefits packages, good pay, and superior products. The core of Cisco is still one of the best companies to work with
Cons: They force their corporate politics at every opportunity. The current view of putting politics before profits, customer service, or their existing employment base is driving very negative culture and results. Morale is as low as I ever experienced and getting worse as the social appeasement ramps up even faster.

Pros: Flexible working hours, challenging work if you are lucky to be in a good project. Also being a big company, there are distinct advantages in getting answers to any questions that you have (technical or non-technical). Makes the most effective use of on-line resources. Has a very good social community.
Cons: Salaries are not great. Lots of middle management and program managers. Its very hierarchical, so dont expect to be recognized or rewarded for any good work. Stock never rises, so dont expect to make any money from stock options.

Pros:
Executives do a good job of fiscally managing company
Nice Campus with on-site gym, cafeterias, and coffee shop
Free drinks for employees
Relaxed dress code
Flexible work schedule
If you look hard enough you can find some interesting projects to work on.
Cons:
No salary increases in the last several years. Entire sites were skipped over even as other sites did get raises.
Overuse of the words "collaboration" and "innovation" by management. Just because the words are spoken, that alone doesn't make it happen.
Large corporate environment, lots of politics, process, and lack of communication.
Lots of jobs heading to India and China.

Pros: Overall a great company. Employees genuinely like their job. There is lots of flexability in terms of when and when you work. With a 60,000 person company, there is also lots of opportunity to move around and try different things. The management also practives what they preach (the Vp's all have small offices and fly coach). They encourage continued education and there is a great selection of classes at 'Cisco University' that you can take to enhance your skill set.
Cons: 1% raise pool each year. This does not exactly motivate everyone to excel. The company is also pretty frucal when it comes to travel and stock options.

Pros: extremely flexible work lifestyle.  Most staff work from home - they encourage staff to work from home to cut costs.
Cons:
0 pay increment.  I heard the longest is 5 yrs without pay increase.
low career growth for individual contributors.  You have to have direct reports in order to get promoted.
Fringe benefits shrunk as a result of massive cost cutting measures.
A few very senior and experienced professionals were repatriated in order to cut costs. This is a great demotivator.  It shows the company do not recognise and value your contribution.

Pros:
- Very innovative company always coming out with new products and services
- Wide community and people really willing to help out
- Compensation is amazing
- Lots of benefits, like free internet at home, free drinks at offices
- Flexibility, ability to work from home
Cons:
- lack of career growth and advancement, you often get stuck with the job position and salary that you started with
- harder to transition into new and more challenging roles
- too sales focused

Pros:
relaxing place to work
friendly working hours
nice offices
Cons:
no transparency from high management
no opportunities to develop
low level of trainings for new commers
temporary contracts 
frequent tools issues
not too much consideration from high management for employees

Pros:
-Committed workforce that believes in the mission of "changing the way the world works, lives, learns and plays.
-Uses its own technology to enable work and life balance (effectively).
-CEO leads with a heart and that is cascaded through the organization.
-Big, complex organization that provides wide breadth of opportunities for growth and contribution.
Cons:
-Transitioning between innovative start-up mindset to more mature company, which can create some organizational confusion as to what kind of company Cisco actually is.
-Recent changes and organization changes/reduction has eroded employee morale.
-Some decisions can be made quicker in pace with market speed.

Pros: Fun work environment, flexible work hours and spaces, great customers to work with.  For a long time Cisco had a great strategy and moved into innovative areas, but the economy crashed and Cisco had to refocus.
Cons: We ran out of products and our BUs bacame too political and lost their mojo.  They lost all the good people and have been left with subpar PMs and others.   Cisco's had a series of layoffs and has demoralized the company.  Cisco has exited a number of businesses and is more of an R&S company as opposed to a true communications company.

Pros: Collaborative, supportive culture. Management typically supports telecommuting and PTO for family emergencies. The company is very responsive to larger enterprise customers.
Cons: Execution in this big company can often get confused. Frequently, obvious issues fall through the cracks and result in disappointed customers. Aiming high for innovation is that much more challenging, and the company is still not software-oriented in multiple ways.

Pros: Opportunity to work with really smart people and see the impact of your work. Always new projects and work on new approaches. Cisco may not always be first but they are never shy about admitting they need to accelerate efforts to catch-up. For a large company they are quiet nimble.
Cons: Large company with very distributed decision making that is hard to make stick. To make big impact there are a lot of internal politics to work through and deal with. The company in general wants to do the right thing but frequently trips over its own feet.

Pros: The hours are great. A lot of flexibility. The salaries are decent, but with the flexibility added in, they become much better than the rest of their competitors.
Cons: Slow to act. I had a terrible manager who was around for 5 years too long however, senior leadership would not let him go until layoffs took place. The extra time he spent sticking around led to relationship break downs with stakeholders and talent moving onto other teams due to his poor leadership style. I feel that senior leadership does too little for their employees while they walk away with large salaries and bonuses.

Pros: Employees are genreally nice and friendly, great place to start out and learn about the IT industry, decent reputation
Cons: Stupid acronyms, over-inflated egos, Managers are AMATEURS, Contractors are treated like third class citizens, tons of bureaucracy.  Values Profits over Employees all day/everyday.

Pros: Cisco operates at a scale and influence that exceeds any other place I've ever worked. You command a lot of respect from customers and partners, and the sales channel is amazing in its efficiency.
Cons: There are a lot of silos, making it hard to collaborate across parts of the business. (I had another product group refuse mine access to source code for a product they were discontinuing.) And a lot of deadweight - middle managers and engineers who had been at Cisco their entire careers and didn't have a perspective on the rest of the market. And the company's been seeking a new overall strategy for what seems like a decade now - with a stock price that reflects that.

Pros: Cisco is a great company to work for, I was fortunate enough to spend 15 great years with them.  They provided me with a good severance package and great support when I was laid off.
Cons: I missed the "Start Up" feel and mentality that Cisco had when I first started there.  While everyone talks about cross functional work and flexibility the work and hierarchy is still very siloed.

Pros: Good pay, good benefits.  Free coffee.
Cons:
Whatever you do avoid the projects that manage large numbers of servers.  Poor engineering of products.   Documentation is lacking.  In my job the debug / edit / compile cycle was approximately 1 hour (versus a few minutes at most other companies).   This is due to bad choices made in engineering, and the cost on current employees is very high.   

Cisco does not "eat its own dogfood."  So the complex task of managing hundreds of servers is not deployed at Cisco.  Furthermore, the company isn't willing to invest much in hardware.  You'll be forced to use "simulators" to debug things, being that there is no big set of hardware to use.

Also, if you are not Asian you may not "fit in".  Don't expect the other employees to be very friendly or helpful.

Pros:
Great big company. Cisco culture is still on a personal level and that is a great quality!
Living far from the office, managements advice is to work from home. How good is that!
The vision Cisco has is  very exciting to be part of.
Cons:
Strict promotion process what can make talent to leave. 
In the transition the company is in, there is a culture gap of traditional Cisco and the new Cisco.

Pros:
I was a small company girl, last year my company was acquired by Cisco, in candor I was very concerned about working at such a large organization. I was pleasantly surprised by how inclusive and supportive the culture was. I have never felt that I had as many opportunities as I do at Cisco.

Of course it is also great to work for a company with as strong a brand as Cisco!

The other thing worth mentioning is that at Cisco our team is so strong that when I went on vacation this summer, I didn't have to work! Being in Sales that is a first for me.
Cons: Cisco is huge! That means sometimes the you have to deal with information overload.

Pros: OK work-life balance, remote Work, some really cool people
Cons:
Arrogant management, big focus on OPEX , the way company progres is by  running layoffs marathon every 3 months. There is no appreciation , people get fired if they have opinion different than manager and HR covers up all those cases. The leadership has no clue about the products they are asking engineers to build, things  getting build and scrapped and rebuild and to cover the failure its being presented as a learning curve (learning when everyone already knew it?)
The career opportunities do not exist. Pay is rather low compare to the market
Average benefits, few of them being taken away :(
There is few great people but the culture coming from the upper management is disgusting, saying you either with us or you should live ... not nery motivating on  convincing.

Pros: Smart, hardworking peers. In general most employees are team players and looking to do the right thing.
Cons: The company is quite agile, which is how it has thrived for 30+years in high tech. Unfortunately this causes a lot of internal churn as departments and projects are spun up and spun down. Often  good people can get caught in a re-org. Company could do a better job of educating employees where talent will be needed so job transitions could be made without relying on  traumatic re-orgs.

Pros:
Feel like home because most of the leadership are Indian.
If you are Indian and on the right food-chain, you will move up faster because we have strong alley here.
Good balance of work and life.
We have extremely loyal customers.
Friendly environment to H1-visa holders.
Presentation and Talk is more important than building things because we buy instead of build.
Cons:
Overall compensation is not as good as top tier companies like Google, FB.
However, hourly rate is better than Google, FB because on average you work less than 6 hours because most of the products are extremely mature.
Take around 6+ years to get a green card.
Annual layoff.
Luckily, most of time they don't cut H1-visa holder.
Too many reorg, sometimes it takes longer to move up.

Pros:
Enough technical challenges
Good opportunities to learn new things
Friendly co workers
Beautiful campus though no time to enjoy
Cons:
Work pressure is certainly more
Job uncertainty as layoffs LR are frequent
Development process overhead
Political senior mgmt level
Growth in terms of compensation or role is stagnant or very slow

Pros: Overall Good culture. Household name. Focus on Diversity and Inclusion.
Cons: Poor acquisition strategy/execution. Failure to unify on-prem / cloud managed Enterprise Networking Portfolio. Major product quality issues across the portfolio. Major emphasis and oversubscription on CX/Renewals- Fix the product quality issues before you ask a customer to renew a service/subscription that doesn't work as advertised.

Pros:
World renowned company, everyone knows the name.
Many extremely intelligent, knowledgeable employees.
Numerous training courses available to further career options both within and outside of Cisco
Brilliant IT infrastructure: Great support, technical resources second to none
Certain benefits: Free drinks, good medical plans, good retirement funding plans
Cons:
Salary below industry standards, grading and salary increases are awarded in a staggered manner (promoted first, then payed more "at some stage")
Growing trend towards extreme frugality is becoming bothersome: Benefits are slowly being taken away in various theatres across the globe (Asia Pacific reducing bottle waste - no more juices or bottled water)

Pros: It has an up and coming internship program that seems focused on attracting new hires.  If you are able to take part in the Cisco choice program you are given a decent level of flexibility in choosing which group you would like to work for.
Cons: It is a large company and it seems like it would be hard to advance positions.  I think this is a characteristic of most tech companies though.  I have been told the best way to get a raise or advance is to get a job at another company.

Pros: There are very good people at Cisco and comitted to customer success.  The senior management is smart and understands the business.  Benefits are good and overall compensation is on par with the industry.  There are different opportunities to learn and grow in different technologies.  Cisco is the leader in shaping the way the world communicates.  It will be a great company for a long time.
Cons: Promotion opportunities are limited.  You either have to have been here over 10+ years or have come in at the level you feel you are working at.  Once inside, unless you have a guardian, performance with a combination of ability will not you get you very far.

Pros:
Flexible work schedule depending on your immediate manager -- but if you are expected to work 20 hours -- does it really matter?
It might be possible to use your time spent at Cisco in lieu of course work towards Political Science degrees.
Cons:
Not a technology-oriented company.
Not many US educated employees, nor many people with advanced engineering degrees.
Employees are usually Indian with a typical background (Indian education from unknown universities); get on the boat using India Consultancy Inc.; jump ship to Cisco and hang around there for a long time to become part of management -- continue hiring new people off the boat -- build empires and bask in the glory of sycophants.

Pros: You'll enjoy workplace flexibility, team work, competitiveness, good salaries, travel, diversity and a great high tech learning environment.  Besides you'll make a lot of good friends. Cisco people are one of the best I used to love the culture which is based on the "Human Network" human communication and cooperation, at least in my team :)
Cons: You'll have less time for your personal life. Workers become workaholics. We used to work extra hours and during weekends. It gets stressful around month ends and year ends, we used to stay up until 12 am to closed deals working from home, but I used to like the competitiveness spirit during these times.

Pros: Exposure to multiple dimensions of Networks. Chance to work and interact with the best in the industry. Definitely a haven for those intrigued by Operating Systems, Computer Networks, and Distributed Systems(the company owns more than 85% of the network deployed in the World).
Cons: Doesn't provide competitive salary in the subcontinent region. Moreover, the rate of progress is not very competitive for someone who just works hard and doesn't ask for returns. Overall, you have to make them know about you hard work all the time.

Pros:
- Wide and diverse technologies and sales methodologies to learn
- Best operations and employee tools
- Space to grow in the organization
Cons:
- Moderate salaries compared to other smaller companies but better than most giant companies
- low chances to overachieve as the bar became too high
- Away from Software industry

Pros:
- Open door policy (accessibility) of senior management
- Encourage rotation - managers very supportive
- Opportunity to do variety of things and develop breadth of knowledge
- Smart and congenial people to work with - snobbish attitude is a no-no
- Managers do not micro-manage
- Flexibility to work remotely from home
- Good benefits
Cons:
- Promotion process sometimes seems like popularity contest
- Frequent restructurings of late affecting employee morale
- Being a big company, sometimes 2-3 teams are working on similar project without knowledge

Pros: lots of great people at Cisco.   for the experienced professional Cisco offers a competitive salary and benefit package. On-site gym and medical facility are hard to beat.   Don't forget to get your free light rail pass in you take a HQ job
Cons: budget cuts force employees to always keep their heads up for positioning of new projects that will continue to get funding.   At times this type of rapid change drives inefficiency as teams don't get their heads down to do work like they could if they trusted their mgmt had their backs.   the tough part is even mid level mgmt gets surprised by budget cuts, so it can make it a tougher place to work these days.

Pros: The Product design and development was so clear as i[senior developer] was literally involved with many stakeholders like Program management, Customer Facing Engineers, Product Test teams etc. Further my duration of stay[4 years] helped me understand in-and-out of the PowerKey Solution. Thus i was able to handle all customer issues as well. Travelled to OCN Shanghai, China and Den,Delhi on Cisco business trips.
Cons: Actually the overall time that you spend in Cisco Systems adds to your professional portfolio and increases the experience of how big multinationals work and deliver solutions to client. Thus sometimes, the project management does not give clear roadmaps on the product.

Pros: The very best technology in the market today. Progressive thinking in positioning for a dynamic and ever changing market place. Seamless way of working from outside the office using the device of your choice. Fantastic work-life balance policies. Good work rotation opportunities. Mentoring of employees a plus.
Cons: Compensation lags behind major players in the industry. Decisions can take a long time to make. IT systems not optimised nor integrated in many areas. Operational deficiencies make it difficult to make things work. Career opportunities not present once you get to middle management.

Pros:
Chance to work with some very experienced, professionals who have kept Cisco at the forefront.
Good severance packages.
If you can network, then there are plenty of opportunities in other parts of Cisco. Indeed there may be other parts doing very similar work!
Cons:
Culture can become toxic with managers seeking personal fame through driving employees; e.g. working from home was banned, sessions in which we had to declare our weaknesses to our colleagues, and reviews became highly personal.
Once the manager has you in his sights there is little you can do. Forget HR.

Pros: The compensation package and work style is the best part of the job. About 3 weeks off per year and the ability to work from home is great. Seemingly stable job with good benefits  and relaxed work environment
Cons: Depending where you get placed, the work may or may not match with your skill set or be of the most interest to you. Changing this can be difficult and must be fought for. Management changes can be frequent (3 in about 16 months) and political which can lead to a feeling of misdirection. Hard work can go unnoticed and so can slacking off

Pros: Decent benefits, Amenities in office like espresso bar, snacks etc.
Cons: Benefits not at par with other leading employers like Google etc. Poor management, clueless managers who just follow directions coming from there superiors but have no big picture in mind. Nepotism, polarization with Indians hiring/promoting only Indians, Asians only Asians etc. Projects get moved to India but nothing gets done and there is no accountability so the projects have to be brought back again to Stateside to do firefighting. Rumors are rampant that some of these execs/managers get kickbacks for sending work overseas but no one has any proofs.

Pros: I am a long-time employee and have had a great career at Cisco.  Generous company - you give your all and the company gives it right back.  Able to move around within the company, develop new skill and experience different opportunities.  Great benefits.  Good people.
Cons: The company is changing, some good, some not so much.  The new leadership team seems obsessed w/ redoing/rebranding everything from the Chambers era, including some things that were actually pretty good.  Not sold on the new leadership yet, but then Chambers is a hard act to follow.  Cloud strategy is poor.

Pros:
people are supportive .
Compensation is good for new hires.
Cons:
Work is not good at all
People talk big things but there is no execution of things at all
Especially in cisco IT , 70-80% of employees are from TCS,infosys and other IT services . They didnt even know the basic complexity analysis . You have to work with them and contractors consider superior in cisco IT . 
Its very shocking , Contractors manages cisco employee here . This is not a product development org at all.
Cisco employee dont have value here.

Pros: Amazing, talented people with a passion and mission for changing the world. Culture that supports growth, reinvention, innovative ideas. A strong vision that places listening, partnerships and advocacy for the customer at the heart of everything we do.
Cons: Yes- we're big but anyone who can connect/collaborate will thrive. Yes- we have too much process in places but anyone who is curious, respectfully disrupts and seeks constant improvement will be valued. Yes- change is constant here but leading companies transform with a purpose. And that's how we roll.

Pros: Working in Cisco is one of the best experiences that someone can have in his career path.  Really pleasant working environment full of intelligent people from all around the world. As Customer Success Managers we deal with many different functions of the company and we are working closely with the customers in order to help them accelerate their business outcomes using Cisco technologies. The opportunities to grow in this company are plenty.  Nice benefits and highly skilled people ready to assist you at any time.
Cons: As it is a dynamic environment it needs careful consideration for someone who doesn't like changes. Sometimes the training material and process can be too much in order to be up to speed as fast as possible.

Pros: Good culture overall but can depend on location.  Good benefits and other amenities.
Cons: Disconnect between upper management and the grunts on the ground (front line support specifically).  There is career advancement but it's only one or two steps, and if you're technical you have to go to sales or management.  Support perspective, horrible work/life balance; they tack on a lot of extras in addition to the 10 -12 hour work day that suddenly become required.

Pros:
- LIFT's rotational aspect gives you an opportunity to try 4 different roles within finance for 6 months each
- The people at Cisco are AMAZING. LIFT provides a great community of active LIFTers, LIFT alumni, and LIFT managers 
- LIFT has many great opportunities to grow your career and build your network outside of just your role, including mentor circles, networking events, additional training academies, social events, leadership series, and learning series
Cons: You are making a commitment to be held to higher standards, be engaged, and fufill various program requirements if you join this program. I don't consider that a con because that is something I wanted, but if that's not something you're willing to do, this may not be the best option for you

Pros:
-You are going to be working in an environment where you are forced to learn and acquire new skills everyday at a very fast pace.
-You are required to know switches and protocols inside out so you will able to acquire in-depth networking knowledge, skills and experience one cannot gain anywhere else outside Cisco. 
-You will be able to acquire exceptionally high problem solving skill which definitely will help you in your career in the long run.
Cons:
-It's a customer support role so sometimes you have be on call for long hours and get stressed from that.
-Sometimes, escalation team or developers are not helpful or got the impression that they are not preparing battlefront worker like us with sufficient information and troubleshooting skill sets.

Pros:
1. Seamless processes - Employees get to focus on their work alone and the processes take care of the rest.
2. Cross-functional opportunities - Cisco has its own job market and employees can choose who/what they want to become.
3. Transparency - Folks in leadership positions are accessible. Hardly any senior leader would refuse to talk to an employee by simply putting time on their calendar.
Cons:
1. Internal movements aren't lucrative. HR makes it a personal mission to ensure employees move into new roles underpaid.
2. Growth is sluggish - Although there are plenty of roles on offer, at times growth can feel a bit sluggish.
3. Size of the company and established processes may at times bog you down in terms of the time needed to take action.

Pros: Flexibility, industry leader, empowering, focused on continuing education and employee resource development. You get out of the experience what you put into it from what I've seen. There is room for growth and advancement but you must work for it. Training opportunities are nearly limitless - company provided distance learning, publications, classroom based training, you name it.
Cons: Visibility, disconnection, isolation. Working with so many great people in such a disconnected environment (remote/travelling/telecommuting) presents challenges to gaining visibility. The distributed nature of the job lends to a feeling of disconnection to the chain of command occasionally.

Pros: employee empowerment. work areas, and employee benefits. Very open minded in hiring practicies, laid back approach to corporate polices, no dress codes, free sodas, jucie, tea, coffee and popcorn. working with cutting edge technology, and the opertunity to work with some of the sharpest people in the industry.
Cons: Long work hours needed to compete with peers. Tough policy of maintaining the top 10%, their is constant pressure to manage out the bottom 5% performers, as there will always be a bottom 5%, there is constant pressure to stay on top of your game. Cisco sells the company ownership package to argue lower salaries.

Pros:
I can talk about engineering. Stable job, top heavy,don't need to show revenues to preserve jobs :),  If you are prudent in business unit selection then you can also work less and get paid more. Do not have to be good technically, just need to keep your "people" skills good. 

Best way to join Cisco is do a startup that complements Cisco's Technology or when you are in your career where stability is important.
Cons: Mostly dependent on the group. Not for politically challenged individuals.  Lack of accountability (could be good or bad depending on what you your objectives are). Fairness.

Pros: Of course the pay is acceptable, they are a billion dollar company after all. But that can also be a chain to keep employees from being able to leave. Senior management make much, much more than your average engineer. That is ridiculous. Benefits are also quite complete, but should be standard at any company anyway.
Cons: Too many departments heads who don't seem to do anything but manage numbers. The ratio of overseas employees or recent immigrants is substantial. I'm for creating opportunities equally, but it's obvious that foreign workers will usually sacrifice for the job, where locals will lean toward their personal lives. This creates an uncomfortable work environment, unfortunate when working in America.

Pros: Stable company - could spend your life and retire at peace. But it has lost all its charm of the good old 90's
Cons:
Not enough employee development opportunities
Not a fair promotion process  
Employees are not rewarded for good work
Long standing loyal employees are starved for promotion while those that come in with acquisition get a jump
Overall low employee moral!

Pros: Technology for routers and switches are still the best, John Chambers is a great salesman and a good leader in terms of taking care of the customers.  The growth for the early years was great.
Cons: Cisco bought quite a few consumer lines that did not really bring in considerable revenues.  There are way too many VPs,  directors, and managers in the company and their contribution should be cross examined and evaluated.

Pros: Energetic, Caring, Understanding management. One of the best places in the world to work for.  Love the environment and people. Very helpful work environment, team oriented, Vast suppositories of knowledge available for all.
Cons: kind of a weird schedule depending on which one you are assigned to at the time. No rest for the weak at heart.

Pros: Pay and benefits.  Flexible work options. Most of the folk want to have a team environment, but the polarization of management and a select few seem to limit a climb in moral.
Cons: Disconnect between management and non management employments.  The politics in the company is disturbing and fosters a feeling of being treated beneath others.

Pros: 401K contribution, daycare pre-tax reimbursement, health pre-tax reimbursement, company contribution to education/ training and even grad school. Peers are always happy to help out one another despite their busy schedule. Many folks have the mantra of working hard and efficiently for the greater good of the company.
Cons: silo'd division of business units challenge the ability to create a consistent marketing message. Over the years, lost the benefits of free drinks, yearly company events, family days, and even the tchotchkes. Regular pay increase not consistent across management.

Pros:
As mentioned, great flexi time.
Work from home.
Salary is good, good bonus.
Cons:
Plenty of red tape.
Big company a lot of in house competition.
The usual workplace politics.
There is a lot of process involved in the development side.
Complete micro management of tasks using the agile process.
Hard to move up the ranks, a lot of competition and not as many promotions available.
Benefits have been cut this year.
The bonus is not guaranteed.
Managers need to listen to the tech leads/architects more.

Pros:
-World-Class Campus here @ Cessna Park with many lots of amenities.  
-Plethora of opportunities-If you dont like: Development, you literally have many windows open for you. DevTest, TAC, TME, Technology Change (SP-->DC-->Wireless) etc. 
-Free Internet reimbursement
-Reachability to Technical Champs across the globe- Fellows, DEs & PEs.
-Mentoring sessions are awesome.
-Flexible work hour Options, WFH
Cons:
can be better to meet Other Tech Companies:
-No CAPs/hikes/Promotions from the past Year
-Salary is: ~30% Less compared to SFT, Amazon.
-Too Many BU Transitions

Pros: Benefits are great. The sIze of the company encourages & enables role changes. Remote work, working from home are supported.
Cons: Several years of heavy layoffs (10K the first year I was converted from red to blue badge, then 3000 the next, and finally 5000 last year). Employees are being overworked for less pay - this negates the work-life balance theory they "support." Excellence is no longer expected. Talent is no longer exceptional - the team I worked on had about 40 employees. At least 20 of them I know/told me they hated both the team and their roles.

Pros:
My director was an inspirational leader, someone who strongly advocated for his team.  Our team was a family, a wonderful - too rare - collaborative family.

Strong compensation including great benefits and campus perks.
Cons: I never knew which way the sand would shift underneath me.  The company's senior leadership would point the "ship" in one direction and just when I was getting good progress toward the goal...they would change course significantly and I had just lost 6-9 months of work (60+ hour weeks, etc.)

Pros: Good time to be selling SaaS anywhere but certainly helps to have the brand recognition of Cisco. Fast growing team so there is a lot of upward mobility available. Great dog-friendly office with free food everyday. Plenty of opportunity to make solid $$ if you're good at sales.
Cons: Similar to the Pros, fast growing team also means there is constant change so be willing to work in a "start up" environment. Sales floor can get pretty loud which is sometimes frustrating when on the phone with a client or prospect.

Pros:
Work flexibility is good...but beware being isolated if working from home too much
Overall package and fringe benefits
Cons: Can be very hit or miss on the quality of manager and lack of consistent performance management  system (no ratings shared) means you are at mercy of line manager's whims when they don;t actively take any interest in your performance or development.  All employees are essentially stacked ranked when it comes to the annual cull.  (ironically the annual performance appraisal system seems to be replaced by annual redundancy system...)

Pros:
Decent Salary
Interesting projects
Great to work with a wide selection of engineering talent from around the globe
Stable work environment
Cons:
Non transparent management
Very strong empire building centric management style
Coded buzzwords such as accountability thrown about in what in practise appears to be more a case of shielding the management from accountability
An increasing lack of ethnic diversity quite readily apparent in the hiring and firing decisions leading to a starkly visible employee representation imbalance, especially within the engineering space

Pros: I feel comfortable being female engineer here overall. There's Lean in circle, events to empower women in Tech and events to engage girls at schools and universities to choose Tech industry and continue work in the field after graduation, accordingly.
Cons: For now few female managers and leaders (at my organization), and few female engineers. But I know company is aiming to accept more, diversity (overall, not gender-wise) is priority here

Pros:
Good compensation.
many different opportunities.
You will find atleast one office in most of the states.
Cons:
Very frequent LR
No clarity on roadmap. Business strategy keeps changing 
No protection to new hires. you may loose job in few months even if your performance is excellent.

Pros: One of the best training programs out there! You come straight out of college and have a one year long training program where you learn sales and technical skills.  All of your colleagues are your age and you will end up forming a very tight bond over the year.  You will also become a Cisco Certified Network Professional by the end of the training which is equivalent to a masters in networking.  The benefits and bonuses are very competitive!  Best year of my life and I can actually say I enjoy going into work everyday! :)
Cons: Wish they had free food like a lot of the other startups in Silicon Valley.  Politics sometimes get in the way of big decisions.

Pros: The benefits are really amazing. Work From Home policy is very lenient, even for non-managers/Early in Career folks. The people are also very understanding and caring. You can tell from the way they are handling the lay-off's during the COVID19 pandemic that they truly care (extending their employement period, etc.)
Cons:
Leadership changes have been frequent lately, but the actual change isn't really felt at the line-level
Growth is slow for Early in Career folks (first 6 to 12 months would be painfully slow for someone who doesn't ask for work)

Pros: For graduates and early in career nice place to earn experience. "Have worked at Cisco" can still be a brand-like attracting point in your resume.
Cons: You will be underpaid. You will work extremely hard. You will be just a resource, a line in Excel file. From Senior Manager level and above leaders are focused on their career only, nothing beyond that (you will observe people who sold their souls).

Pros: The actual work and the technology you work with is amazing , your colleagues are smart and usually fantastic people.
Cons: Middle management does not care about you , it will always be "yes" if you are the one doing the job , and "no" if you propose it and/or they have to move a finger . Scope of work is well defined , but managers overlook that and are happy to have you do anything and everything other roles exist for without room for conversation , forget about scopes

Pros: Cisco is such a great place to work--the senior management emphasizes integrity and productivity.  For a company of its size, politics are not such a big issue.  Cisco is a great place to work remotely too.  Benefits and career opportunities are good and compensation is roughly in the mid to high range compared to other comparable companies.
Cons: It's hard to ramp up at first--because it's such a large place and there are a lot of internal systems and lingo to learn.  Unless you're a director and manage at least 4-6 people, you are in a cube.  Sometimes it's hard to know who to reach out to for information on various topics.

Pros: Cisco is a fun place to work and gives the right level of challenge to constantly keep me interested. Lots of smart people and most of whom get along well. Opportunities are vast if you are in a position with exposure and visibility. Broad product portfolio in many different technology areas.
Cons: Getting to big, lots of dead weight, could fire 5000 people and wouldnt skip a beat. Too many people making a career at Cisco out of making a career at Cisco. Too many products that overlap and internal competition between different product groups is very counter productive and does not benefit Cisco or the customer.

Pros: Great people to work with. Everyone is very friendly, collaborative and professional. Minimal political nonsense. Most people seem to work from home at least one day a week, so there is a good work/life balance as well. Many people who work here stay for years, and I can see why.
Cons: A lot of stakeholders involved in projects. This can delay and overcomplicate projects that could be more efficiently handled. Need fewer decision makers on some projects to eliminate unnecessary complexity. Additionally, this is the sort of company where it takes a few years at minimum to move up the ladder.

Pros:
Good benefit package
Challenging sales work at field
Shining brand
Some shining technologies
Cons:
Amazingly a large portion of useless, impotent, lazy people in middle management and so-called support\enable\virtual\tiger\special\functional\segments teams
Smoking Sn.Management from VP and higher - has not much clue what is the reality
Poor experience and information exchange
Poor personnel developments programs and complete disaster with career planning
Awful sales operations automation - sales people may spend days fighting india Customer Service troops
Awful internal IT

Pros:
Like any large company, if you land in the right team (of which there are a few in Cisco India, so ask around before you join the team) you get to work on challenging projects with good visibility and appreciation.
Very friendly managers who are very open to ideas and criticism alike.
Cons:
Senior management (based in the US) does not understand ground realities of the Indian employees ("You want hike? employees in the US have not had a hike for 2 years! you had yours last year")
The US employees of your team (who in most cases do almost the same if not less work) than you can seem to have more name recognition and appreciation.

Pros:
* Positive work environment
* Family friendly workplace
* Flexible work timings
* Good benefits
* Movements possible within the company
Cons:
* Poor Mid-level, senior level management & leadership
* Promotions typically a visibility contest
* Most managers lack team building qualities
* Bureaucratic work culture
* Too many consultants, employees lack the edge
* Too many meetings, slow decision making
* Globalization in the wrong form, work distributed ineffectively, where there is no way to do things without working for at least a couple of hours out of normal work time.

Pros: Great flexibility with good benefits and vacation. Opportunities to use many tools and develop skills to move on to other places.
Cons: Constant change in policy and management makes it hard to accomplish goals. If you were not a true Cisco employee meaning you came by way of acquisition moving up and around can be hard and you may be first to go when its time to cut. Depending on where you worked the pay was low and if you were not a "classic" Cisco employee meaning hired by Cisco not an acquisiton you were probably paid less and ranked lower on your team.

Pros: It was nice to telecommute so many days out of the week.
Cons: It probably sounds like sour grapes, but anyone considering reviews should be aware of the issues too and decide for themselves what to do.  There are some people in charge of other people in the Service organization that are abusive and unreasonable.  I was cautioned by a recruiter about their reputations (in writing), but it was even worse than he admitted.  They have no idea what they are doing.  Seriously.  There is no way working under them that you can be successful.  It was an unfortunate experience and tops the list of bad news.  In a large company bad apples can hide for a long time and cause a lot of damage, all around.

Pros: Work/life balance; collaborative environment; awesome colleages
Cons: I was a red badge contractor doing a great job (being considered for a permanent blue badge if a position came available), but did not have my contract renewed due to the global restructuring in September 2013.  Disappointed to be caught in that mess, as it only impacted the red badges who were up for renewal right when that happened.  Other PMs on my team that had contracts come up only a short time later were renewed.

Pros:
People - Cisco employees one of the brightest in the world, so get to work with the smartest
Culture - Cisco is one the best place in the world to work for if you are looking for work/life balance. 
Salary - Its competitive with good benefits including bonus
Technology  - Cisco has diversified into various technology play, so you are always work on cutting edge stuff
Cons:
Too much fat in the upper mgmt. Company has been recently trying to cut the fat and become more lean and thin
Making decisions takes a long time and this slows down overall projects/programs
Too many layers causes growth to slow down i

Pros: Challenging and interesting work; I have never gotten bored and the company does not suffer complacency.
Cons: Managing a work/life balance is challenging.  There is always more to do, more to learn, etc.  It is your job to manage your time and the expectations of your manager, co-workers, and customers.

Pros:
Company culture is good, engineer and non engineers respect each other and can have fun together.
Company events and healthcare adequate.
There is 401K match.
My pay was at market.  But others i heard from Engineers claim they are lower than market.
Cons:
Many reorg's and in my organization new management every 2 years.
New management many times never had any success in their previous product lines took credit and funds from the projects/products that are making the profit, because the new managements are in the old boys club, and who you know.
Quite some politics when new management comes in, they want their people in charge, which is understandable.

Pros:
Very good Benefits, super nice gym and sports facilites. 
People are nice, and it is really hard to find a bad manager.
Great work/life balance, you work as much as you want. 
Very long career oriented, they have a lot of different positions you can move to/from.
Cons:
Big and old corporation. 
Old technologies. 
Too many boring steps to build features/products, that is why they acquire other companies. 
A lot of the products are in maintenance state, so you end up working on bugs most of the time.
They promote once every 3-4 years but they only increase salary by 3%.

Pros: Huge company - a lot going on and a wide variety of opportunities to learn and work in different areas.  Some smart, capable people and interesting work.
Cons: Highly political environment in some areas.  Can feel like living and working in an episode of Game of Thrones.  Not unexpected for a company this size, but the level and degree of scheming and backstabbing is disappointing.

Pros:
Wonderful people: smart, capable, caring, and fun to be around.  The Cisco employees I worked with are friends as well as as work-mates.  
Cool products: Cisco usually has products at the front edge of technology and they have the money and influence to make things happen.
Cons: Lack of clarity about the mission, incoherent execution.  Probably because of it's R&D-by-acquisition approach Cisco has internal silos and no coherent, cross-functional, operations capability so it is inefficient and has difficulty focusing on a clearly defined objective.

Pros: I had enjoyed working with Cisco and the teams. It was rewarding journey from learning and career perspective. I liked the company in many aspects: great culture, transparent communications from executives, ethical, collaborative and inclusive working environment and superb talents community.  If you show good potential, are passionate to take bigger responsibility and take initiative to advance career, I have found management is always willing to provide mentoring and coaching and development opportunities. I also felt proud about the fact that the company put lots of efforts in social responsibility.
Cons: I generally worked long hours and sometimes stayed up late to get connected with team from other countries. Headquarter centric, there were moments that regional team needed to fight for decision making.

Pros: Big company, a lot to learn. Complex business processes, good place to polish your business and management skills. Prepare yourself to be worked to death since everything is around California time which makes it very tough for employees outside the US to take on calls, TPs, etc at normal hours since they will have to adapt to Pacific time.
Cons: Too political. Corporate is not fully aware of what happens in the regions, same people have been running the regions for years and have formed silos and closed environments that make it impossible for other people to move up.

Pros: Ample training opportunities;  Access to a lot of resources, both hardware and software.  Access to some very smart people.  Good treatment of minorities.
Cons: Went from having a bad rating system to having no rating system at all.  Performance makes no difference, compensation growth is well below inflation.

Pros:
