great virtual work policy....work where you please
great tools for collaborating, especially Jabber (IM) and WebEx
exciting to work for a major company that helps shape the tech industry
Good severance if you are let go in the layoff, ahem, limited restructuring
Cons:
Horrendously unstable
Bad communications with employees
So much lost time and effort wiped out each time layoffs; teams spend years developing great process and tools and then its all wiped out in a few weeks
Employee paranoia -- when's the next cut coming

Pros: Top notch compensation.  Excellent work life balance.  Excellent training programs particularly for new sales engineers and senior leaders.
Cons: Cisco is changing for the worse.  While compensation is top notch, the (at least annual) layoffs and re-org/strategy changes do take a toll on personal psyche as well as your organization's ability to deliver.  Senior leadership now seem to be "consultant MBA types"  or mediocre engineering program managers rather than people who want to build products that customers want to buy.  Accountability is completely lacking at middle levels of the organization

Pros: I am a professional woman who has worked at Cisco for 6 years and have loved the company culture since Day #1!  Cisco values and respects its employees and I enjoy working in a diverse environment of mutual respect where all ideas and points of view are welcome.  I also enjoy the flexible work environment and Cisco's commitment to work-life balance.  I also love Cisco's commitment to giving back to the Community.  Cisco's Corporate Social Responsibility is strong and that is important to me!
Cons: Change is constant at Cisco and, in order to be successful at Cisco, employees must be agile and be able to adjust to change and sometimes work and push forward amidst ambiguity.

Pros: I have been at Cisco for almost 20 years and yes, I never thought I would be at any company so long! However, Cisco has provided me with the professional opportunities I was looking for throughout my entire journey. I have been in several functions across the company - Sales, HR, IT, Operations and was part time for over 8 years while raising my children. I have lived in Sydney and Paris with Cisco and been able to travel and see the world. The people are smart and challenging and there are always problems to solve each day.
Cons: Like any company over 20K people, there is a need for consensus at times across several functions and that can slow progress down and be frustrating.

Pros: They have a great work from home policy which I really appreciate. Work life balance is also fairly good.
Cons:
Ancient tools, slowing moving giant. They love to talk about the buzzwords in technology but have no clue how to proceed. Management is filled with layers and layers of yes-men who are caught up in a cycle of incrementally modernizing their bloated products. 

To "innovate", they purchase other companies - often started by Cisco employees themselves frustrated at the rate of change within Cisco. Then they layoffs start, and people are told they don't have the skills Cisco is looking for, when in reality it's the management which doesn't have the skills to lead.

Pros: Flexible, Role Exploration, Supportive, Inclusive,Forward-Thinking, Progressive,Opportunties to Lead, Talent Recruitment, ESPP, EROs, Career Advisory Programs
Cons: Seperation by FT/Contract (contractors seen as irrelevant at times), Not a lot of traveling

Pros:
- Work life balance. You are not expected to work 60+ hours a week in most groups like other tech companies. You can work from home and at any time you want as long as you get your work done. You are treated like an adult.
- Culture of giving back
- Great benefits. 401k, ESPP, up to 10k+ for grad school
- You are encouraged and empowered to rotate to any other role or organization at Cisco
- Smart people
- Learn new technologies at a global scale
- Lots of fun activities like soccer leagues, barbecues, and team outings 
- Nice offices with massage chairs, game rooms, and coffee machines
Cons:
- Not as highly paid at base salary
- Very high contractor to full time employee ratio in IT

Pros:
1. People are talented and great to work with
2. Work/Life Balance
3. Benefits
Cons:
1. MEETINGS
2. Bureaucracy causes many teams to move slow, but that may be expected of a company of this size.
3. Engineers in IT are underpaid when compared to the industry standard.
4. Engineering work can be really dull in IT. It's common for engineers to get stuck doing 3rd party integrations as much of the engineering work in IT is outsourced to cut costs.
5. Engineering culture is not strong in IT. Agile development is a relatively new thing in the organization, and its questionable how many teams execute the methodology.
6. Office perks are nonexistent besides popcorn in most buildings.

Pros: Cisco "appears" as an industry giant ready to change the world; this is not the case.
Cons: Cisco lacks creativity and simply acquires technology to maintain market share. In the end, they cannibalize product lines and kill the momentum of their acquisitions by trying to pigeon hole their success into the Cisco model.  Additionally, compensation is below industry average and based on feedback, management feels their brand offsets the poor comp plans.  As for people management, Cisco is more concerned with maintaining ratings then they are with doing the right thing.

Pros: Cisco as a company provides a lot of incentives for employees - be it from the flexibility of WFH (even pre COVID times) to bonuses/ appraisals. Cisco management allows you to be flexible with your work - they don't encourage a strict clock in time, thereby gives you a good work-life balance.
Cons: Might not be the most exciting work for young designers and Cisco products that are developed in India are not really given enough investments or opportunities to do innovations. The designer to engineer ratio is extremely low compared to other companies. Also, the pay may not really on-par with other B2B companies and definitely lesser than what B2C companies pay.

Pros: Good benefits , Salary is okay , Process driven, good learning opportunity, nice company to work for ,
Cons: If you have remote indian managers - forget about company USA good culture , these Indian managers/directors bring nasty politics to Australia as well, not recommend to work under Indian Manager/ Directors , Try to work in Sales managed by local Australian people.

Pros: The Associate Sales Representative program is a training program that ultimately feeds into Cisco System's sales force.  You are trained thoroughly for about 8 month.  Subjects of training include everything from how to be a more confident public speaker, to cold calling, to the obvious training on all of Cisco System's hardware and proprietary software.  You are divided into 'teams' within the ASR program and you do most everything during the work day with them.  You have a manager that is your 'team leader' and you have a tech manager who is responsible for teaching you the material on Cisco hardware as well as pointing out the relative strengths and weaknesses similar competitive products have.  The ideal end result of this program is to take a sales oriented person and tech him or her enough technical information so that this person could sit down in a meeting with a client and speak to a CEO, CFO, CTO and answer all of their questions with the caveat that really technical things will be covered by an Associate Sales Engineer (ASE) who is your more technically savvy counterpart.  Cisco's aim is to have ASRs and ASEs work as a team together.  This doesnt exactly work out because the ASR to ASE ration is conservatively skewed at 2 to 1 respectively.
Cons:
I was a part of the Associate Sales Representative program, we are referred to as ASRs within Cisco Systems.  The problem working at Cisco is not the upper management or the training; I was very satisfied with those aspects of the job.  Your co-workers will make this a miserable experience.  The dynamics of the training program were worse than high-school.  We were provided with subsidized housing through Cisco and college graduates could not act appropriately.  Some were even kicked out of their leases.  

There were people skinny dipping in the apartment complex's pools, people egging other people's vehicles.  It is the farthest thing from a professional behavior you can imagine.

The sales staff of Cisco Systems is notoriously cocky and if you speak to anyone on the outside who deals with them on any sort of regular basis, they can confirm this.  The program is also set up like indentured servitude.  By which I mean, once you have completed the training program you are bound to work for them at a location of their choosing (ultimately it depends on your desirability as a Sales Representative and suitability to the area) for no less than 2 years.  If you quit before this period, you are required in your contract to pay them back a subsidized portion of your training.

Pros: Cisco offers competitive starting salaries and great benefits.  The company provides free coffee, drinks and popcorn.  Management is very flexible with the work schedule.  Most engineers get in the office between 9-10am and work from home about once a week.  Vacation time is generous and requests are rarely denied.
Cons: Because projects are always getting cancel, it is very hard to get a salary increase or promotion since you keep reporting to different managers.  Most companies give a 3-5% salary increase if you meet expectation, but I have been working for Cisco for over 2 years and my salary remains the same.

Pros: Great product lines and intelligent people to work with.  The company treats employees well and provide good medical plans.
Cons: Recent years Cisco hasn't been giving annual merit increases. This month it has cut back on many things such as free drinks, home internet access and etc. It's understandable in this economy.  However, I think the company should stop paying a huge premium for companies with no customers or no profit. Instead they should use that money to do internal R&D and use part of that money as incentives to current employees to come up with innovative ideas and products.

Pros:
1. If you are working in the right division on the right job you are good.
2. Good benefits such as Vacation time, Insurance and if you have a good manager good work-life balance as well.
3. Brand Name
Cons:
1. Your growth is directly proportional to the number of people you know inside Cisco.
2. Most managers are very technical and resolve your technical issues if you are stuck but that stops there, people skills are negligible to Zero with most.
3. Size of the company is a problem, you are just another employee in the 70k folks inside, some employee services such as Immigration take your service request for granted.

Pros: A great place to develop and learn to operate under pressure; backed with a strong brand.
Cons: Internal politics is on the rise, leaving a negative vibe in the organisation. The focus on numbers only through negative reinforcement has driven the company away form its core values of being one of the best places to work at while still achieving commitments. Some of the current management needs a LOT of management skills trainings to lead and manage by example and stop losing the experienced people that made the company succeed.

Pros: HD Video collaboration tools at your finger tips, rich online libraries to help you get your work done.  Everyone is excellent and has good energy.
Cons: Career path mobility is near impossible since the best of the best are hired here.  As such, the salaries are not nearly as competitive as some of their smaller competitors (that will always be trying to lure you.)  I worked at Cisco for almost 15 years and never made it past first line management where most other companies would have seen me at Sr. leadership roles by then.

Pros: Should be great place to work over the next few years. Company now makes each employee take all their vacation time.   Most cisco managers are so busy you are not micro managed. Great rewards for top performers. There is no glass ceiling for women.
Cons: Few employees receive stock grants. Company has regular reduction of employees. There is risk of top line revenue as many companies are moving toward cloud implementation.

Pros: Salary, sales commission program + benefits. Brand and name has an excellent reputation, great talent working for the company worldwide. Opportunities to grow for ambitious people.
Cons: Staff moves around a lot, very political inside large companies. Lots of internal selling to make with different levels of people to move things forward. Too slow at launching new products or technologies, smoke and mirror syndrome is hurting the sales team credibility (finance and legal weigh more than marketing and sales). Lay offs are inevitable (almost each year) - highly competitive culture among staff due to this pressure.

Pros: Can make good friends while in the trenches together.
Cons: Asked and expected to be online all the time currently.  The IT department is very much a click based advancement program anymore.  As a new hire or young in career there is room for advancement, but if you are further along in your career, prepare to search for the proper manager who either likes you, or is an actual leader, if you are unfortunate and land with a manager who is more inclined to pay attention to his bonus or his boss than his employees expect a less than enjoyable ride.

Pros:
Cutting edge technologies
Plenty of training if you so desire
22 PTO days a year
Flexibility (teleworker)
Good Benefits 
401k Matching 
Life Insurance
Mid-year and End-of-year bonuses
Employee Stock purchase program
Indoor and Outdoor recreational facilities onsite 
Cafeteria onsite
Cons:
Quarterly lay offs. 
Lack of job security regardless of employee or group performance
All innovation comes from acquisitions.
Politics, Politics, Politics...
Solution overlap between groups/business units

Pros: I'm part of one of the most agile teams in Cisco. In my time here I've had enormous opportunity to grow professionally and personally. The culture from the top down is straight forward and honest about where the company is headed, It's easy to draw a line to what I am working on and the long term direction of Cisco. This truly is the best job I've ever had and the best place to work I've ever experienced.
Cons: Cisco will let you work as much as you want to - It's important to take time for yourself outside of work and understand that 'No' is sometimes the right answer.

Pros: Great benefits to offset most cons and job security is assured for most support folks since they'll always need more.
Cons:
- Internal company politics and inane policies prevents a lot of things from getting done. 
- After working for a few months, it's very apparent that Cisco is a sales-oriented company and would sacrifice the quality of a product in order to pump out something new and sparkly for their investors.

Pros: Top notch peers (hard working, highly intelligent subject matter experts); flexible work environment (depending on group); networking and moving into different jobs highly encouraged; opportunities for learning; global teams lead to exposure to different cultures, work styles, way of thinking; monthly broadcast by executive leadership keeps employees updated on what’s happening with the company
Cons: Work life balance non-existent like at many high tech companies (average 12+ hrs/day and weekends); cost saving measures result in employee purchasing own office supplies (e.g. batteries for mouse/keyboard, replacement equipment such as a headset); compensation not as good as other high tech companies; nearly annual RIFs are off putting and may result in having to take on more work indefinitely

Pros:
1) work flexibility (Cisco is great about your everyday life: i.e. moving meetings around pick up/drop-off times for parents, moving meetings if you are feeling sick etc..)
2) great team culture - we were ranked #1 place to work in 2019 because of how understanding the team is; they care about more than just your work
Cons:
1) raises not offered every year
2) not much upward mobility if you start there - you're better off leaving and coming back for higher salary
3) a lot of layoffs because of change of direction of company

Pros: Good incentive, Good Health insurance, Decent technology stack
Cons: Layoffs is a big issue and more importantly you might be laid off even though you are a top performer if you did something which makes your manager angry. There are no metrics, no rules that the lay offs are based upon, which is frustrating. It will happen every 6 months and thats the harsh reality at Cisco.

Pros: Very flexible, a great culture of balancing personal life and job. Great internal resources to learn (a lot of self-training). People is in genera willing to help you if you do your share of your work
Cons: Very changing on work dynamic, don't get too comfortable in your position, be prepare for change and keep learning and preparing, this can be a bit stressful but also a good opportunity to grow in knowledge and experience!

Pros: Cisco is one of the top 10 company in the world. They care about employe. The pay and hike is good. There are many benefits given to employee like you may claim upto 50 dollar for Internet expense every month.
Cons: But the worst part is that the CISCO is recently acquired IMIMobile. Here in IMImobile, the management is not good though it is coming under Cisco. Managers, Leaders, Directors are not good. They use their employee like slave. 12-15 hours hectic work. No leave. Too much pressure and politics. Very sad

Pros:
Very collaborative environment where people work across functions to get the job done.

I have been at Cisco a year and been very impressed with the caliber of employees and their thinking. 
I came to learn how other companies work, and have learned a lot about Cisco approach to business stargey form john Chambers himself at town hall meetings.  I have been very impressed with the level of involvement John has with employees of this big company -- he is one of the premier business strategists on the planet, and yet is very approachable.
Cons: Some vestiges of big company bureaucracy, but that's changing.  John Chambers has emphaiszed collaboration and has accelerated this through a series of online initiatives.

Pros: Saying you work for Cisco.  They take care of their employees, lots of perks, lots of interesting classes.  They have a lot of money to spend and it definitely shows.
Cons: Communication is sometimes difficult, as it is a very diverse group.  Interns don't always have as much leadership as I would like, and a lot of them goof around because they have nothing to do.  All the computers given out are Windows laptops, which is annoying when you're developing a Unix system.

Pros: Steady pay, good overall benefits (until they take those away), if you really don't want to work, you have a great place to hide.
Cons: Lack of promotion opportunities, completely clueless middle and upper management, short sighted - the next qtr is all management is worried about. It would be nice to have a long term plan that showed where we are going and how we are going to get there. The main R&D is buy a company that does something we want, put a logo on it and say it is part of the "human network"

Pros: If you are an engineer in the networking field, there is no better place to grow. You will gain an immense amount of knowledge in a very short time. When you work for Cisco, you are at the center of where everything happens in networking technology.
Cons: Cisco is a very large and fast moving machine. You can certainly get lost in the mix or overlooked. It can be hard to gain promotion unless you are willing to sacrifice a lot of your personal time.

Pros: Cisco pays very well, has a terrific benefits package, and provides some very nice perqs. The campus us pleasant, the cafeterias are excellent, and the facilities (gyms, etc) are top-flight.
Cons: Middle management, at least in my division, is very insecure, leading to political battles. Goals were kept intentionally nebulous by an indecisive VP, leaving the directors to fight for resources for their pet projects. Cisco top management likes to run on real metrics against measurable goals, but since goals were unclear, metrics became meaningless. Goals and metrics were fudged, so the VP could direct attention and resources to pet projects and employees.

Pros: Good people, very strong core products, generous time off and still a pretty good work environment, though less so than a few years ago
Cons: Boards and councils model means lack of accountability and it can be maddening trying to figure out who is in charge; managers are like Supreme Court justices, they only leave upon death so promotions are nearly non-existent; don't complain about my travel expenses when you've got $40B in the bank.  Do you want me to call on customers or not?

Pros:
You work with a lot of smart and motivated people.
You can influence product dev/features, marketing, and execution.
Salary and benefits are exceptional.
Access to bleeding edge technology and information.
Empowered - but less than in the past.
Cons:
Too much bureaucracy now that Cisco is a larger company.
It is a social environment - most of the time you get things done because you are friends with someone.  Accountability  is lacking at several levels above sales.
Stagnation in middle management. 
Too much middle management.
Not enough equity and promotional pools to treat top performers adequately.

Pros: I started working at Cisco TAC in Bangalore when it was just being set up. The benefits were amazing! Work from home, weekend/holiday pay, shift allowance, free cab service to and from home, energetic and young workplace, completely informal.
Cons: Lots of politics, stack ranking, not easy to advance, and MOST OF ALL, a lot of people seem to treat TAC as a temp job while they hunt for other jobs. Well, it was my first job out of college, so it may be that other jobs are also like that.

Pros: Big title company, still the leader in the industry, plenty of opportunity to interact with customers.
Cons: Constant reorg and workforce reduction/layoff have created an untrust culture within teams & colleagues. Company is known for bonus based - performance review can affect the bonus. Cisco tends to hire people as contractors first, a bit strange compared with experience i had in other companies. The promotion tends to be "organically grown" - need to be with Cisco for a long time to be able to be promoted.

Pros: Cisco is fast paced environment and a fantastic talent pool and will only enhance your career and CV. You have a freedom to shape your role as long as it yields results expected. A very personal company and will go out of their way to help you with both work and non-work related issues.
Cons: There are many employees in Cisco you need to do more than your day job to get recognised and promoted.

Pros: Lots of networking opportunities as an intern to learn about various departments and functions at Cisco.
Cons: Did a lot of paper pushing as an MBA intern. Not much growth or knowledge gained from projects that may help within product management or marketing. Bit disappointment. Perhaps it may have just been bad luck on my part getting an internship on a team that did not value giving projects to MBA interns that would be challenging.

Pros: Work life balance is the best I've seen among SV companies.  Mostly hands-off management.  Good vacation and PTO benefits.  Management is very understanding about personal commitments.
Cons: There are not enough Engineers at top positions.  Most decisions and product road maps are developed with $$ in mind.  Too many 'non-functional' managers that don't understand the details and can't go-to-bat for their groups.  We frequently talk about 'wonder what that Director does all day'

Pros:
Salary and benefits high standards.
@ center of latest networking evolutions. for people with a passion for networking, the place to be as you are always surrounded by top notch networking experts.
Cons:
too much middle management or the 'too many chiefs and not enough indians' syndrome. 
Yearly restructering round - based on the bottom five approach, problem was often that in small team with only good people, the company was 'sacrificing' good people (the one with the highest salary...) 
long working hours were becoming a show-off practice (sending out emails @ 2AM in the morning)

Pros: Flexibility, great pay, innovative and good people
Cons: No annual appraisals so managers can do what they want, most upper management has no clue about the bad moral, no promotions, no stock options, no recognition

Pros:
I have been at Cisco for more than a year now and below are the things I like here.

- Alot of opportunities to grow. We have vast variety of trainings available, one can choose his/her own career path and choose mentor and start grooming. 

- Respectful multicultural environment

- Strong Customer Focused strategy means that we put customer's interests on top. 

- Cisco makes us believe that what we are doing really matter in the industry.
Cons: No Cons, been too immersed in the awe for this company that I like everything about it

Pros: Learned some stuff and experienced different culture
Cons: It's not an equal opportunity environment.  90% of engineers are Indian.  If you are not Indian, you have no chance to get promotion.  There are a lot of backstabbing and politics from your "teammates".

Pros:
Great work/life balance and benefits
Among its peers in the Valley, its commitment to CSR really stands out
Leaders in Finance and Technology (LIFT) program is a great way to learn the ins and outs of Corporate Finance right out of undergrad
Global presence; opportunities to work abroad or away from your home campus in the US (6 month rotations in EMEAR theater and San Jose or North Carolina are possible while in LIFT program)
Cons:
Huge, sometimes unwieldy corporation (finance is smaller than sales or engineering, but it's a big place)
Global presence means sometimes attending meetings outside of "business hours"
Frequent lay-offs and restructuring, despite leadership "commitment" to minimizing these. Doesn't always feel transparent or authentic when they discuss these at company-wide meetings.

Pros: Open and frequent dialog at the top on company financial, social, and environmental impacts. Top management shows genuine care for employees and communities. Working here for 5+ years, and it always amazes and impresses me how talented my teammates and Cisco employees are.
Cons:
The frequent layoff is the biggest concern but Cisco is trying something new recently to give higher priority for job openings to people impacted by layoff due to exiting/resizing of product.
Given the pursue and application of cutting edge technologies, the schedule is always hard to predict, and hence the work life balance is always a challenge.

Pros: Large company with room to grow for the driven individual. You can transition from one role to another with manager approval. They also will help with tuition expenses up to $10k per year but I saw more in the ballpark of $2k per year for the average employee.
Cons:
Layoff culture. CEO stated no layoffs during pandemic, we don't want to contribute to the homeless problem in San Jose...then scheduled layoffs.
You are rated against your teammates so better to only collaborate with those under a different manager or director.

Pros: Cisco is a very diverse (in technologies) company and the opportunity to work across these differing technologies is amazing (though results are rare). There are many very smart people, with broad backgrounds, who can offer excellent insight into many things. The overall balance of compensation/benefits/work-life are all very good.
Cons:
Cisco's primary innovation engine is acquisition, thus there are limited internal opportunities for big thinking.
Strict P&L management of business units makes it difficult for their respective GMs to invest in the future vs cost optimization.

Pros: Great benefits, telecommuting, industry leader, opportunity to learn networking from the best, ability to move within the company.
Cons:
Depends on which organization you work for. Middle management is bloated and weak leadership makes matters worse. Re-organization in Engineering is frequent with a general lack of accountability. The new mantra of collaboration might not improve this situation. 
Recognize that you are responsible for your development and if you face the above, look out for better opportunities within the company.

Pros:
There are pleny of good opportunities for professional growth and it is a fairly good environment to work in.  
Decent salary and benefits packages.  
Good opportunity for training and certifications (but you have to want do participate - CCNA, PMP, CCIE, Stanford, Microsoft). 
Good company attitude towards telecommuting/work from home.
Cons:
Many hours, sometimes the work/life balance is a major challenge.  
Internal teams don't always play well together.  
Sales Teams tend to disappear once the sale is complete.
Processes in certain areas are in need of a tune up (documentation, maintenance) 
Employee recognition is scarce unless you are a major cheerleader

Pros: Good place to learn IP/routing technology. Open and fair process in place for information sharing. Good and knowledgeable employees.
Cons: Heavy on processes. HR and Finance put rigid rules. The company wastes volumes on unnecessary collaboration. A sales force that has no desire to sell more than its quota. The sales force waits for the channels, and resellers to make and maintain the customer contacts. It does not know how to do business directly with the end customers. It is also not well structured to reduce overlaps among the BUs.

Pros: Great employee benefits; global presence; strong eco-system and brand name
Cons: CEO has been lost around 2006-2007 (that caused CDO Charlie left the company); a lot of politics and fat;  doesn't have any succession plan;  can't retain talents (seems CEO and board don't even care);  no innovation but still think things will turn around.  It's sad to see this will become another DEC or Sun Microsystems.

Pros: Good bonuses, nice comfortable work environment, lots of learning opportunities.
Cons: Same as most engineering jobs - you hit a salary and promotion ceiling fairly soon, so it can feel stagnant after 5 - 10+ years. Used to have many more free perks in the breakroom like bottled water, juice, soda - now just coffee with plain cream (not flavored) and sugar.

Pros: Came in as part of an acquisition and it has been very encouraging to find so many other folks who have come in that way and stayed around for so long. The benefits and the pay are good. I work from home full time which allows me great flexibility and time with my children.
Cons: If you prefer a smaller environment it can be difficult to find the right niche within Cisco which provides that smaller company feel. Also travel budgets are pretty locked down which can make being a full time teleworkers difficult.

Pros: Getting to use the latest conferencing technology. Great people to work with.  Flexibility to work from home.
Cons: Don't make offers quickly enough to contractors that are exceeding expectations, recent layoffs were terrible and of great concern to people remaining.  One person doing 3 different titles, not fair for work life balance, everyone there complains they've gained weight since joining there so fitness club shouldn't be an added expense and should be a mandatory daily activity and for free.

Pros: Strong brand. Well respected leadership bench from Wall Street. Quality vision.
Cons: too big. too slow to make decisions. no Steve Jobs/Jeff Bezos like star/visionary executive to make bold moves. worry too much about what Wall Street thinks. lower-mid management disconnect with top level decisions. Terrible upward mobility and talent management.

Pros: Excellent pay and benefits. Established company with huge market share. Well run from a logistics standpoint. Heavily values giving back to the community.
Cons: Lack of vision at the top. Top 10 for layoffs every one of the last 5 years. Stagnant leadership espousing the same messaging year after year and expecting everyone to buy-in. Heavily political with entrenched leaders making difficult decisions for the wrong reasons. Process, process, process.

Pros: Work from home as needed; interesting people, great pay.
Cons:
Senior Management no longer cares about its people. Every year decisions on people's lives are made and great employees are laid off without even consulting with their immediate managers. There is fear to speak up: transparency is a myth. 
There are VPs that are only in for their own selfish reasons and will lie if needed. This is no longer a company I respect.

Pros:
Flexible work policies, leaves and unparalleled work atmosphere.
For tech geeks, sky is the only limit
Friendly HR policies, approachable staff
Cons:
Due to mass migration of people from service industries to Cisco, policies are getting changed gradually
Micro monitoring is gradually increasing in all the teams causing toxic environment
Venomous people try poisoning the minds of superiors to play their cards.
Vertical move from one grade to another is very slow due to high volume of same grade performers
Top management vision is not clear and road maps are not very clear down the line
Very frequent Limited Restructuring, causing anxiety in the minds of the people quarter on quarter.

Pros:
- Work load is relatively balanced compare to some other companies (e.g. Apple, Google...etc.)
- Salary is market standard.   
- Benefits are great.  Perks such as free shuttle, free VTA eco pass, free EV charger, frequent lunch out at fancy restaurants, and great corporate insurance...etc.
Cons:
- Politics!  Like many big corporations, Cisco is highly political.
- Slow career advancement.  Promotions are rare unless you really impress the management
- Salary is market standard (nothing spectacular about Cisco salary)
- Frequent layoff (like twice a year, ritualistically)

Pros:
IMPORTANT - Different divisions within Cisco are vastly different from one another, my advice is to make sure you know if a GlassDoor review is relevant to the job that you are applying to.

I work in the Collaboration Technology Group (CTG) which includes WebEx, TelePresence, IP Phones, Jabber and Spark (aka Project Squared).

The Pro's of CTG are:

(1)  Typically your co-workers are great people. My immediate team, for example, is one of the top group of peers I've had in my whole career. They are smart, qualified and everyone cares about each other

(2) The Collaboration Group has some really interesting products, there is a very good chance you'll work on something that is relevant and that you'll be proud to have on your resume 

(3) Cisco offers great benefits. I can almost guarantee you won't find a company that can beat what you get for being a full time employee (Medical, flexible work, 401k matching, etc)
Cons:
The con's of working within the Collaboration Group:

(1) At the VP and Director level Cisco is competitive and tumultuous, more so than any company where I've worked in 20+ years. In the last 5 years there have been 4 different Senior Vice Presidents and with each change there has been a lot of churn and changing of priorities.

(2) There is a ton of in-fighting between groups (aka BUs or business units). Basically every Director and VP is incented to compete against ever other Director and VP for budget, resources, attention from executives & the sales force, etc). While this sounds normal for a large corporation, the stakes are high. Winners build set their own agedas and losers can not control their own products and often are subject to yearly layoffs. The bottom line is almost none of the teams are rowing in the same direction, rather everyone competes against each other. 

(3) Most importantly Cisco has a yearly layoff. Every July/August for the last 6 years the company lays off a large number of people. In that time the company has laid off more than 20,000 people and yet the number of employees is larger than ever.  I've seen entire product teams get cut when other teams could sorely use the talented people that were let go. I know someone who got an Outstanding yearly review (which is only given to 6% of people at Cisco), and he was laid-off just a week later. 

Normally you think of a large company as being more stable than a small one, but Cisco is not at all stable

(4) It's very hard at all levels to move up at Cisco. If you are a manager who wants to become a director it's very difficult, the best way to be a director at Cisco is to be at a company that Cisco buys. If you are a Tech Lead who wants to become a Senior Tech Lead the competition is fierce - I know several engineers that have been trying for years to make the next step.

Pros: Had a great direct line manager and a good development team. My work was valued and appreciated as I brought a skill set that was not normally available to all groups. Was able to work remotely.
Cons: Since Cisco is a huge organization, sometimes it takes a long time to get new development through the system.  Because of their size, Cisco is not able to respond to the needs of the marketplace very quickly and they are losing market share to their competitors.

Pros: Great employees, talented and motivated to work. Great work environment and depending one department possible to work remotely. Great technology and sometime leaning opportunities (i.e. if your schedule permits)
Cons: Unstable work environment due to constant restructuring and lay offs some of which are done without consideration for the valued talent. Individual performance is not considered when your unit falls on the chopping block. It is like cut off the the arm, and the finger is not saved. Lot of internal politic.

Pros: Its becoming more software centric. Good monopoly in networking and expanding in security and data center side.
Cons: There is no people deal. Its hire on demand and fire whenever you want attitude. Internal blogs are filled with this msg. Why dont mgmt just get it. If this continues employees do not feel esteemed to work and passion oozes ..

Pros: Not many Pros in this company anymore. Most of what Cisco's management is doing to attract college hires is by spending a lot of money  on free food, snacks and weekly Pop-up Parties!
Cons: Culture is changing--bringing in college hires --for every college hire, Cisco gets rid of two senior professionals. Then over loads the college hires, essentially paying them a 1/4 of the salary.  It was a great place to work now it is just trying to hang on with less talent.

Pros: Flexibility, Hard Work in results have been rewarded for the most part, Management trusts their employees to do the right thing, no one cares when or where you work as long as the job gets done.
Cons: roughly 10 managers in 10 years constantly re-building those relationships.  Management has a tendency to over-rotate from one extreme to the other.   Lip service given to asking for honest feedback, I've seen many good people falsely branded as mal-contents.

Pros: A lot of great technology and industry knowledge to soak up.
Cons:
Not much chance for advancement. Management is highly politicized and appears to only be concerned with advancing their own careers, before help you with yours. 
Also, management used to be glass door, but not for a while.

Pros:
Still the leader in the industry. Lots of experienced people in the RS, networking, SDN etc. area. 

Good employee benefits, OK work & life balance.

Salary is OK but not great.
Cons:
Too many re-orgs. Depending on your team, but once per 6-month would not be abnormal. 
Your performance is evaluated heavily by your visibility, so the people just doing the talk and knows how to play the game of favoritism are considered having great "leadership" skills.  Hard and honest work seldom get you promoted.  Few people  would speak out when decisions from higher management clearly not making sense, where are the backbones?

Pros: DEcent pay mostly, but they will try to get you in at a low figure and trickle in the pay raise.  You have to actively go after your increases if you want them.
Cons: Layoffs are pretty much an annual occurrence.  Your time will come, especially if you have a change in management or your are too expensive to the company, you will be laid off then someone cheaper (or a friend) will be hired.  Oh and recruiters will contact you to work on the same team you just left.....till they realise it is too soon for you to come back.  lol.

Pros: Industry leader in networking, strong presence in all market segments, diverse hardware and software product line
Cons: Way too much inertia in responding to new technical trends and customer concerns, old,  hacked up, buggy code base with insufficient refactoring to address weak areas, Way too much inertia in adopting and moving on new technical trends and market directions, too much infighting, intimidating management culture, no real performance review process, antagonistic attitude toward telecommuting.

Pros: the people are intelligent and great team members
Cons: lower pay than similar firms and in constant reorganization and lay offs

Pros:
- Incredible flexibility in hours, location, role
- Senior leadership genuinely trying to create value for employees and customers
- Lots of opportunity for new challenges
Cons:
- Crazy political environment 
- Promotion at best done based on “you were good at that, let me give you something totally different,” at worst based on personal comfort level of senior management 
- I saw diverse teams — men, women, White, Black, Asian (multiple countries of recent immigration) where everyone not from a particular country was managed out and only people from a single country were promoted. It was weird and obvious.

Pros: I enjoyed the people I was able to meet with outside of my team. People were very welcoming and wanted to see me succeed and were interested in getting to know me as a person.
Cons: My team that I was assigned to did not care about me at all and the overall experience was disrespectful. My manager did not care about my personal and professional growth, I was never prioritized and he would go through my mentor to speak with me.

Pros: Great place to work low key in a supportive environment. Great work-life balance. Very results oriented and collaborative – you do better work when you network (pun intended) with other people in the company and work strategically, rather than do heads-down grunt work. Of course this all depends on who you have as a manager, but generally the bad apples find their way out of the company in due time.
Cons: Low pay compared to similar roles in similar companies. Opportunities for increased compensation are scant, and when they do happen, its small. Career growth is at a snail's pace. This is a place to chill, not grow your career or skill-set, or makes lots of money.

Pros:
* Cisco creates and leverages tons of tools that make it easy to work from anywhere in the world, such as remote access devices and software, as well as revolutionary video-conferencing software (TelePresence).
* Cisco employees are some of the best in the industry, and it's nice to work with smart people.
* Cisco compensates employees well, at least with salary and bonus.
Cons:
* Cisco's openness to working anywhere often means you will work more hours than you otherwise would in the office.
* Retirement package is not very generous.
* Cisco did away with merit pay increases many years ago, so there's no annual compensation increases.

Pros:
Cisco is the leading company in network. It shows strong leadership and mindset. The traditional competitor is more and more far away. Now Cisco drives innovation proactive in the Web 2.0 world and providing more attractive products and services like Telepresence and Webex, etc. 
Change is corporate culture. If you are not change yourself, you will be changed by others or out. :)
Cons:
Salary is not competitive and not increase quite a long time. The compensation plan is not good.
Promotion is not easy recognized and sometime you have to stay in same position over years.
Human resource dept is not value for staff.

Pros:
Cisco is relatively stable due to their success in business. Cisco pay a little higher than market average, offer good benefit and competitive high bonus. Cisco is good for those:
(1) New graduates with weak technical skills and no work experience.
(2) Immigrants who need visa & green card sponsorship based on employment
(3) Lazy engineers who do not want a progress in technology and career
(4) Ass kissers who enjoy spending 90% of their time on office politics.
Cons:
Cisco is very successful in marketing for hardware devices, but has a very bad and extremely expensive way for management.  Try to develop innovative software product here is so tough, just like a "group constipation": Many people works very hard on it, and takes very long time, and it turns out little -- s**t. They keep on deliver software product which makes little or no money and abandon it later, and no one say any thing bad inside Cisco for those garbage software products except their customers. Cisco has to use their famous strategy : keep on buying good technology from other company, to make up this shortage. 
Cisco's performance system over require so called leadership & influence no matter what your position is and how much you actually need it. This encourages people  spending too much time on virtual work, spending endless time on meeting, phone calls, writing emails and not much useful documents. The more time you spend on real solid work, the less time you may spend on increasing your "visibility" or "influence", and worse performance you will get. My whole team was acquired by Cisco from another company. In my previous company, my performance never drop below top 15% for a few years, but in Cisco, with the same boss, same team members, same kind of excellent  project I lead and accomplished, my performance drops under average. Cisco is full of mediocre engineers. The reason is not because they hire mediocre engineer but they make their engineers mediocre, they are encouraged and forced to be mediocre. If you stay long enough in Cisco, you will probably become mediocre even you are excellent before, and you will find it is hard for you to find a decent job outside again with what you learn in Cisco.  Cisco is a "traditional" big company, not Google, or Microsoft type.  Motorola, Lucent, Nortel's today will be Cisco's tomorrow.

Pros:
Flexible timings
Work from home
People oriented company
Management encourages you to take initiative and to innovate
Good Senior management
Cons:
Not much growth when you are in
negotiate hard when getting in (hikes are done at US levels 5-6% a year)
Mid level management is bad
company has more faith in vendors as compared to its employees
Work is done for short term gains and no one thinks about long term design

Pros: Good place, always on the leading edge, conducive learning environment, flexible work hours but meetings pretty much happen all the time, and if you are working with remote/offshore teams, you pretty much don't have a life as at least 3 days in a week you will have late-night calls or early morning meetings.
Cons: Working extra hours from home with remote/offshore teams is not adequately reflected in your compensation/recognition - it is almost taken for granted that you will be 24/7 on the job.

Pros: Cisco is a good working place with flexible working hours and respect for personal and family matters. One can gain a lot of valuable experiences working in Cisco.
Cons: Cisco management don't apply fair practices in promoting people. It is very hard to transition to another group and it is not encouraged. Cisco does not seem to care for individual careers. The promotions are often already selected and it is not a fair game. Often management team are very snobby.

Pros: Resources, equipment, talent, flexibility and respect are but a few of the reasons to work for Cisco.  At Cisco, self-starters and self-directed employees manage to execute on tremendous projects with minimal management interference.  It is a joy to work here.
Cons: A slow erosion of some of the company perks along with less recognition award has caused the morale of may old timers to decrease.

Pros: Very good pay.  Open Communication.
Cons: Lethargic pace.  Management is seriously lacking--they appear to have no idea at all what they're doing.  Feifdoms rule the land, with each manager looking to grow their territory.  Communication from upper management lacks any actual content.  Stock is in free fall.  Layoffs are planned, but unknown where they will take place.  Management is moving jobs overseas.

Pros:
Fantastic Opportunities to Learn and Grow - Literally, the Mecca of Networking
Overall, smart set of people as colleagues all around
Respect for individual
Recognition where its due
Cons:
Overall Monetary Rewards leave much to be desired, esp for folks outside of Sales (AM/SE's etc)
No Salary Reviews! :(
Clear discrimination between SE's and NCE's when it comes to payouts, promotional give-aways etc
Cisco still is a product sales machine - Sales folks take the cake (and the candles too) - every time, all the time. While Services Delivery is left holding the bag :(

Pros:
Work, life balance
Autonomy to do work, flexibility
Opportunity to learn many new business/partner models if you look hard
Experience to move on with other companies in your career
Cons:
Lack of upward movement and advancement
Management lack of focus on competitive pressures
Under-performers often stay.
Declining market share and margins is causing hasty decision making
If you are a remote worker, you start to feel isolated from coworker interaction
New position postings are often decided before they are posted, just a formality

Pros: Learned a lot, great coworkers, salary and benefits were more than fair. Large company allows employees to move to very different areas without leaving the company.
Cons: Lack of vision in management. In my BU the only thing looked at was cost and cost cutting. New products and product vision only happened by mistake. Forced ranking of employees is a distructive practice; kills moral and team work.

Pros:
Freedom and responsibility - I was given complete ownership of my component and I could make design and other related decision changes. Many times, with the help of my colleague, I would rework things from scratch. Of course, I was also responsible for all the bugs in this area even if I had not coded the early part.
Flexible working options – there was no fixed timings to come and go. I was given a laptop from day 1 and so I could work from home whenever needed.  Thus, I could easily attend meeting that happened late night during US times.
Cons: Pay that was below industry average.

Pros: I get to work on a large project where hard work is respected and occasionally rewarded. Code reviews are taken seriously and smart solutions are noticed. I love the unpredictably of work assignments that comes with working on a new product with agile development, but to be fair, it drives others nutty.
Cons: It is not just enough to be an amazing developer; you must also have the trust of your peers who may be spread across multiple sites and teams. If you have an uncompromising approach to software development is, then you may have trouble at Cisco.

Pros: Generally a leader in the networking industry backbone.  Pay and benefits are good to start.  Lot's of opportunity to rotate jobs. Good work/life balance and ability to work remote.
Cons: Very difficult to get raises.  Make sure you come in at a grade level that you are comfortable with for several years because it can be tough to get grade level promotions.  You may be subject to layoffs every 1-2 years that may not be tied to your performance.

Pros: Good pay, good people, good benefits
Cons:
Cisco thought they knew video better than the company they bought (Tandberg). They then proceeded to try and push the market where they wanted to go, not where customers necessarily wanted to go. The trickle of ex-Tandbergers turned into a flood, and there you have it (again), a great company ruined by the Behemoth that is Cisco.
The yearly layoffs, the overlap between Bu's (and constantly rearranging Bu's, what a mess!

Pros: Wide variety of opportunities. Switching job internally is encouraged after one year of service which is good.
Cons: Difficult to maintain work life balance. Work from home facility ensures that you take work home and also attend calls, meetings at US hours ( india unfriendly hours) thereby spoiling human clock :(

Pros: Very good place to work. They take care of the employees and tons of useful resources, courses to enhance skills, good work/life balance.
Cons: Has become far too big. You just are "one more person" there. Too much process, The technical focus has reduced considerably. The solution is to create spin-ins or acquire companies for something they could use from their own good talent pool.

Pros: Technology always evolving, changing.  Always something new to learn and offer customers (solutions).   Professional and exciting environment. Empowers employees with productivity and demonstration tools. Top-rated compensation plan. Pleasant and rewarding culture. Work-life balance.
Cons: Good old boy network still exists depending where and with whom you work, team-wise.  It's easy to become a workaholic.  Work life balance needs to be self-managed but does exist.

Pros: Flexible work environment.  Competitive pay.
Cons: Political environment.  Culture fosters mediocre performances across most. Consistently rated rated poor in recognizing & rewarding top performing employees.

Pros:
Leadership - strong and supportive
Promotions - good
Benefits - very good
Flexibility to work from home as needed (comes with the caveat that there is some disrespect to those who do that often)
Cons:
External recruits are not accepted very well (by experienced team members, non-managers) . There is a lot of resistance and it's hard to fit in. Most of the employees are previously contractors in the same group converted to full time. 
Bureaucracy - lots of teams and processes - little work gets done.

Pros: Work life balance is great. The company is very understanding of your home life and most jobs allow you with the flexibility of working from home. I was located at the RTP office and the campus is very nice.
Cons: If your expecting a high impact challenging environment this place may not be for you. While the work is stimulating it is definitely not like working at other younger tech companies. It seems like a lot of people are at their jobs for very long times so moving is not the easiest. The organization is very buercratic and it can be frustrating to see how longs some things take to get done.

Pros: telecommuting from work, flexibility (which means round-the-clock at times), friendly people all over, compensation is on-par if not better than its competitors, transparency
Cons: playing catch-up while pushing its weight on to competitors, employee morale low due to 'limited-restructuring', no one dares to challenge the status quo-some did and was sidelined, general prospects are gloomy, not a great place for young people, gen-y, millennials

Pros: Best thing about Cisco is the work culture, and the people. I joined this company as a fresher, and really enjoyed all the learning. Everyone from a teammate to the director and VP is approachable and open to suggestions and discussions. Additionally, if you are working on some of the relatively new products like UCS, it is a great opportunity for learning new technologies.
Cons: Cisco is  a huge company, and thus have all the cons associated with a mammoth company. The development cycles are long, and it takes time to fix thing because there is a development ideology being followed for a product, which might have become stale for the current requirements.

Pros: Cisco is a great place to work for the most point.  There are creative over achievers who all want what's best.  Cisco is trying to start investing in it's employee and recognize they make Cisco what it is.  The investment in technology and the IOT promises to keep Cisco on the cutting edge of the ever changing market changes.
Cons: Some of the challenges are the salaries are not inline with other technology companies.  The advantages that Cisco used to have in benefits for employees are vastly disappearing which leaves it's employees to look only at salaries when comparing to other opportunities.

Pros: Fantastic culture built around continuous learning and growth. I couldn't have asked for a better internship experience. Leadership empowers you to take control of your professional success with constant feedback and visibility into the broad array of opportunities Cisco provides.
Cons: The only drawback about the internship process was the lack of information provided about the type of work we would be tasked with during the internship. Having material before the internship starts to get a better understanding of your role would be really helpful. The summer flys by and having the ability to maximize your time is essential.

Pros: Great pat and benefits.  Great work/ life balance and flex time.  You are not part of the big Cisco culture at smaller remote sites.
Cons: Lots of meetings and work long hours to Management doesn't believe in the smaller remote sites.  for short deadlines.  They don't allow anyone to be promoted to senior level management positions.  You are not part of the big Cisco culture at smaller remote sites

Pros: Great company, good benefits, great people, dynamic place
Cons: Don't plan on making Cisco a career employer, they target employees 5 + and the sad part is, they tell you "it wasn't performance related".   "Workforce reductions" are base on how much you make an tenure.  I've seen excellent people let go, only to bring in contractors and be rehired as a contractor.

Pros: Collaborative, matrix culture where teamwork and collaboration are valued and encouraged.  Ability to usually have great work-life balance is huge positive.  High touch sales  model for large accounts helps teams establish deep trusted relationships with customers.
Cons: Very large company now so getting things done can be cumbersome at times.  Cisco is going through the transition to software and subscription based services and this pivot will be very challenging for years to come.  No clear strategy for cloud and platforms.

Pros:
- The people were passionate, smart, helpful and forward thinking
- Being part of a company that has such a huge impact across the globe 
- I personally loved the flexibility and working from home
- Networking....it seems like anywhere you go after Cisco there are tons of ex-Cisco people which instantly bonds you
- Amazing benefits!
Cons:
- Constant lay-offs make it hard to stay aligned with your goals and even know what you job is at times. Sometimes you also wonder how they make some of their decisions on who to keep and who to let go
- Because the company is so large, it can feel like the work you do is just a drop in the bucket
- Collaborative work spaces

Pros:
- Work from home policy is very flexible
- Possibility to take leaves on a very short notice 
- Option available to buy more leaves 
- Any equipment that is needed for work can be ordered without any scrutiny.
- Convenient location if driving from eastern part of county.
- Work/life balance is acceptable. There is almost never any pressure to stay beyond normal working hours.
- Great involvement in local community projects and charity organizations.
- People are genuinely very nice and fun to work with.
- Sports and Social club does a good job organising events throughout the year; there is however a membership fee to participate.
- On top of the above there is a separate fund to organize team outings every quarter which are always good fun.
- A lot of attention is given to constantly monitor and improve coffee machines.
Cons:
- Strange location for an IT company, in the middle of an industrial park, outside of town. Not a very pleasant place to go for a walk with trucks and forklifts roaming around. Oranmore village is at least 20 min walk away, which is a bit far if one wants to go out for lunch. That's also where the bus stop is, so it's something to consider if using public transport to get to work.

 - Canteen is very bad. The catering staff are trying their best, but are very limited with what they can do because the kitchen is very badly fitted out, so they can’t prepare any half decent meals.

- Cisco is ultimately a sales, not an engineering company so while good engineering practises are appreciated by some, it’s not what necessarily gets people promoted.

- Salary, promotions and opportunities are good if one knows how to play the game and gets noticed by the right people.

- A somewhat weird/cringy ‘we are an amazing company’ attitude from some people. It’s disheartening how much self-affirmation we received from winning the somewhat irrelevant ‘Great Place to Work’ survey last year while conveniently forgetting that we were competing against some small insignificant companies. We are unlikely to stand a chance if the top US software companies (i.e. companies we should really be compared with) decided to participate in a survey like that. There was a time when they decided to start giving us a free bowl of fruit every day, which is a great initiative if it wasn't sold to us as the greatest thing ever i.e. on the same level of getting a free house.

- Because we don't really having any real proper competition in Galway, the company gets settled in the virtual security offered by ‘we are good enough for Galway’ mindset that hinders any effort or initiative to continuously improve and yet wonders why it is so difficult to attract experienced people in the field to work here.

Pros:
There are a lot of growth opportunities. If you are eager and ask for help you will receive help to develop yourself as a professional, not only on your current role but in general. I've been working for more than 5 years in Cisco and had to move to another country, I was able to move within the company and this made the adaptation much easier.

It is really focused on work/life balance and if you are struggling you get a lot of offers for help.
Cons: In my experience, the monthly salary is usually lower than what you can get in other companies, specially Cisco partners. However, the benefits package like stocks, bonuses, etc usually makes Cisco a better option.

Pros: Good benefits and multiple business units to join. Teams focus on meeting goals. Management comes up from the ranks. You can learn as much as you can take in. Lots of business unit with different products that will keep your interest.
Cons: Depending on the teams, diversity is not always apparent. People tend to hire and work with same ethnic which doesn't promote diversity nor cohesiveness and somewhat of a prejudice environment if you are not the same ethnic.

Pros:
The People...wow there are some talented people here.
Industry leader...allows you into doors that others have to fight to get into.
Benefits...Pretty good considering the rising costs.
Cons:
Lower than industry average Compensation
Promotions (within Sales) are rare and hard to come by.
Repect from management is lacking, you are just considered another cog in the wheel.
Common thing to hear at Cisco, "You should be happy you still have a job here"
Senior Managment likes to promote each other...but it is hard for the average working guy to get a promotion, and raises are VERY RARE.
Very Long Hours...not uncommon to work 70+ hour weeks.

Pros: The only good part is the name.  If you can get a job with the company and leverage its name towards moving up in your career, then that's about the best reason for working at Cisco.
Cons: Directors and middle managers are mostly incompetent and unable to lead or manage resources amongst them.  Instead, they like to take the success of their subordinates and make it there's.  So when it comes to proper recognition of work, acknowledgment of contribution, and everything you'd expect to advance in your career, you can forget about.

Pros: resume building is good if you work there.  Once you leave it it will look really good to others who don't realize that it is just as backwards as lots of other companies
Cons: the pay really sucks and they work you too hard.  They always take take take tale and never really give give give give, especially at bonus time.  You need to be in the old boys club to get ahead and if you are not you get stuck and never get any raises or good bonuses

Pros:
Good breadth of technologies to work on.
Relatively easy to move around within.
Some very good techies to work with and learn from.
Good infrastructure.
Cons:
Technical skills and engineers  are not valued, except for the very top few.
Growth mostly for management side of the company though it professes equal opportunity for technical and management growth
Usually clueless senior management on the technical side of the company.
Too much bloat in middle management.
Usually incompetent junior and middle management on the engineering side.
Too much emphasis on process stifles new ideas and the ability to move fast.

Pros: Cisco empowers employees to be the best people they can be...personally and professionally.  This company believes in growth and development, rewards and recognition and pay for performance.  I am surrounded by intelligent, driven colleagues who challenge me to be my best self each day.
Cons: Cisco is a leader in telecommunications and technology.  We sometimes miss the opportunity to come together in live meetings due to the recent downturn in the economy.  However, because we specialize in some of the greatest virtual conferencing technology in the world, this downside is limited.

Pros: Empowerment, Responsibility, and both encouragement and opportunity to grow skills and knowledge.  I've worked for several high-tech companies and this one is the best run of any I've ever worked at.
Cons: Management on average isn't as technical as other companies I've worked with, which probably limits the complexity of the projects we've ended-up tackling in the past.   The company understands this and is actively working to address the issue.  I'm hopeful that the changes our BU is undergoing will address this in the not to distant future.

Pros: Strong company in growth industry.  Decent benefits and work atmosphere.
Cons: Very corporate.  Middle management layer is not very good.  Employee recognition and development programs are not very well articulated or executed for such a mature company.  Employees are not recognized on ability to excel at their job, but more on ability to self promote.

Pros: Lots of chances for internal moves to diversify your portfolio and for those who don't like to stay in the comfort zone.   Employees do not hesitate to share information and help others when needed.
Cons:
Some compensation and benefits have been eliminated from the first level employees who do the grunt work but still exist for the management.

Management is inexperienced and in some cases uses brute force approach to get work delivered and this translates into no life/work balance for extended periods in some cases.

Pros: Flexible work environment, Good bonus program at mid- to senior levels, really smart people.  Some products very strong.  Great lab infrastructure for engineers to play and get certifications.
Cons: Strategy drifting a bit, promos based on relationships vs. competence, acquisition process, competitive response (including SDN).  Solutions approach confusing.  Too many re-orgs.  San Jose buildings getting very old and need a major refresh.

Pros: Great company that works hard to keep employees satisfied.  Driven culture with smart and passionate coworkers.
Cons: Can be difficult to pursue career opportunities due to internal politics and silos of the business trying to retain talent in their group instead of encouraging employee personal growth plans and ambitions.

Pros: Flexible work schedule. Decent PTO, average benefits
Cons: The Security and Government part of Cisco (can't call it a division because they don't like that word) is completely leaderless. Sure, they have people who fill those positions but they provide absolutely zero leadership. The senior management is aloof and does not directly communicate with or engage the work-force.

Pros: Good pay and bonus Coworkers are typically pretty good people, although they tend to be on the more conservative side. Culture has taken a turn for the worse.
Cons: Horrible leadership, tons of politics, terrible HR, basically you should treat yourself as a mercenary and look out for yourself. Also, since they put in water less toilets, you get the honor of smelling your coworkers urine. Great motivation to stop drinking water during the day which saves the company valuable revenue.

Pros:
The company is better than most, does well by employees, focused on customer needs and market transitions.  It has survived for decades in an ever-changing technology environment where competitor after competitor has come and gone.  Uncharacteristic of a tech company, CEO John Chambers likes to think that employees might make a career at Cisco.

Plenty of opportunities for learning and development and for finding new opportunities within the company.
Cons:
It is a big company and it can be really hard at times to make sense of corporate strategy.  Internal communication is a challenge at which Cisco could be doing better.

You don't get quite the same perks as other local tech companies.

Pros: Cisco did not tear up the start-up I worked for when it acquired it, and we managed to retain some of the character that we had before.
Cons: Very difficult to get noticed in such a large organization, and no clear direction. I expected that a large company such as Cisco will be less "Quarterly profit" driven.  The many layers of management - boards, committees and what not - make product decisions very difficult to drive in a timely manner

Pros:
Biggest reason : Work-Life Balance
Training & Development opportunities improved after I reported to an American manager. While I reported to an Indian Manager, minimal personal development opportunities. Guess, it is a regional bias but Indian Managers try to show more savings everywhere.
Cons: Lay-offs for past 4 years, discrimination to some extent. In my function, Indians are not heard much. Decisions are all made in USA and we have to adhere to them.

Pros:
Great team.
Top talent.
Cutting-edge, ever changing and evolving.
Pays well.
Great benefits package, including matching 401K and stock options.
Cisco Health services, with monetary reward for participating.
Able to work from home. Great for work-life balance.
Cons:
Too many cooks in the kitchen on any given product or project.
Upper management doesn't really understand what individual contributors do.
All profit driven, very little room for creativity.
Persistent reorganization and layoffs creates an environment of dog-eat-dog and fear.

Pros: Good benefits.  Flexible workplace is fantastic.  Depending on the team, great colleagues.
Cons: Lots of talk, little want to actually change.  Toxic managers who are managers, not leaders and don't want others to succeed, only make their team look good.  Promotion of the best looking and non-team playing members.  Not really free to take risks, fail and learn.  Lots of bureaucracy, red tape, and processes slowing down decisions, etc. Lot more, "Tried and true, vs. innovate and new".

Pros: Workplace flexibility, hands-off management, company culture, volunteering opportunities, complex & challenging opportunities.
Cons: Lay-off culture, too many reorgs, Business Units creating overlapping/competing solutions under the same domain, Work life balance, promotions are based on social ladder instead of contribution ladder

Pros:
The company, overall, cares about its workers. You can see that throughout the COVID19 pandemic.

Employees are encouraged to give back. Each gets 10 days to volunteer.
Cons:
Being such a big company, too many red tapes to get little things done. Requests sometimes takes weeks to resolve.

Sometimes money is more important than people. Employees who bring in $ are promoted even though they are terrible managers. Some employees with issues are also kept on/promoted instead of being let go.

HR - treatment differ between upper management and lower employees: the previous get salary increase with promotion and increase scope of work but not the latter.

Reports to Ethics teams are supposed to be investigation but are ignored.

Pros:
- Great support for new hires out of college
- Excellent leadership team that really cares about employees and their wellbeing
- Internal mobility is highlighted and personal development is supported by your team
- Great work/life balance (has been especially apparent during Covid WFH)
- Great company culture (you can see why they are often voted one of the best companies to work for)
- Awesome company benefits (PTO, insurance) and perks (company discounts, free swag)!
Cons: - The only con right now is that they are reorganizing some of the business units, which can make it a little difficult to understand reporting structures, but they are handling this and should have it figured out when the new structure settles

Pros: Good benefits, co-workers are generally nice, gym at the time was great for $20 a month that included group classes and towel service
Cons: I was hired as part of a new grad cohort straight out of university. My title was Software Engineer. Unfortunately it took a few months before I realized that although my title was SE, I was part of a QA group. It was odd that there was no differentiation of QA engineers and SE in the job title. Communication is slow and teams are all around the world. Getting someone to help you oftentimes involves staying up late to wait for someone to wake up on the other side of the world.

Pros: Strategic member of account team. If you can achieve and exceed quota it pays well. When you can close a deal customers appreciate the expertise.
Cons: Always competing with partners for professional services business. Always the most expensive service solution. Comp plans keep changing and are not aligned with what management wants to see in the forecast. Product sales team will avoid engaging to get sales done. No longer compensated for any technical service renewal business limiting the services available to sell.

Pros: The benefits are amazing. You really can't beat them. 4% match to 401k, deferred salary at Director and above, health care benefits are pretty unmatched. Usually working with great people.
Cons: Cisco can't get out of its own way. Upper leadership has such wide mandates they have no idea what's going on but try to shove different things together because they think it fits into their view of what Cisco should be. I saw projects that should have happened, get killed when leadership changes, only to have it later brought up as "oh we should do that" and everyone pats themselves on the back for being so smart, but the people that can do the work have left at that point.

Pros: Stable company.Look at optimizing product groups with clearer decision-making and better integration of product management and engineering. At the end of the day, product groups (incl marketing and engineering) are still 20-70 people, very manageable units. You don't have to concede product development to competitors. Too much compromise
Cons:
compensation and career advancement. Only lateral movement moving from one group to the other, absolutely ridiculous policy. 
there should be really an incentive for people to move from one position to the other. 
I did an prestigious MBA program, then when I finish, there is absolutely no upside to move within Cisco. The HR did not find an easy way for me to find a new and exciting opportunity. So I left.

Pros: Such a big company that you can re-invent yourself every few years if you choose.  Internal transfers are encouraged and learning on the job is highly encouraged.  Most VP's support education and Cisco paid for my MBA.  Cisco has diversified away from core routing and switching, ensuring that we are not at the mercy of the cyclical health of individual market segments.
Cons: We have grown so large that promotions have become extremely hard to get.  What used to be an 18-24 month promotion cycle is now about 36-48 months, at best.

Pros: Great company, good leadership, very good benefits, people take pride in their work and actually help each other succeed.  Little pettiness, very professional organziation and community--coworkers are actually friends.  Salaries are very good.
Cons: Very little downsides.  High expectations, as this is a very high performing organziation.  But that is to be expected.  There is nowhere to "hide" at Cisco.  If that's what you want or you don't have a good work ethic, look elsewhere.

Pros: Cisco is a decent company that cares about its employees and is a very relaxed enviroment. A good portion of the people get to work after 10 and leave around 4 with a long lunch break and are able to do to the work efficiently.
Cons: The experience seems to vary greatly between teams. Avoid the Java folks and you'll be fine ;) They are trying a little to hard to make sure "the sun never sets on Cisco software development" and it creates communication problems for many of the teams. A lot of the employees just slip by but its like that everywhere.

Pros: Cisco really supports work-life balance and has many programs for new hires to integrate into the company and socialize with coworkers.  Groups are generally small yielding good sized teams, effective in getting stuff done.  Benefits package is great as well.  Management communicates to employees well (but doesn't necessarily receive employee feedback very well)
Cons: A lot of bureaucracy so its hard to get stuff done, especially with technology that functions across multiple platforms.  Sometimes have to work long hours especially close to deadlines.  The company is huge so you really only work with and get to know a small group of people.

Pros: Good benefits (though those will diminish with each downturn)
Cons:
Inability to innovate.  
Teams spread all over the place; takes twice as long to get stuff done because you have to ping pong protos/equipment/information.
Lack of recognition or promotion opportunities.
Lack of top level product leadership, lack of discipline (product roadmaps change with the wind).
Wasted resources on projects that are there for political reasons, but end up failing as expected.

Pros: Financially stable company.  For the most part work environment is flexible.  CEO is dynamic.  4 weeks vacation is great.  Well run company.
Cons: Too much bureaucracy.   Very top heavy.  Decisions made a lower levels are too mind boggling.  Very disjointed.  Not easy to transfer jobs.  Internal jobs are posted even though hiring decisions are already made.

Pros:
