1) Big company resources: on-site training, commuter checks, free VTA, shuttles
2) Big budgets: to buy necessary things to get the job done, to give bonuses when due
3) Big name: everybody knows Cisco
Cons:
1) Big structure: matrix structure isolates you into your business unit and role
2) Establish procedures: no room to wiggle for some things
3) No more free drinks?! (or so I hear)

Pros:
- Brand name
- Well matured cisco internal tools
- Transfer with in organization
Cons:
The below are about Chennai Cisco based on my experience

- Its not cisco, this division was previously known as Scientific Atlanta and they still follow the old work culture. If you expect Cisco work culture and join here, you will be highly disappointed. I joined here because of brand name. But later disappointed. Work culture is similar to service company, you will never feel you are working for CISCO.
- No work from home, No laptop(No laptop for engineers, but admin and finance have). Some team provide both. But not all.
- No recognition, during the appraisal they only concentrate on old employees. Lots of politics
- If you from a good company this place will not suite you, People from small company might like this place

Pros: Looks good on a resume, everyone knows them
Cons: When I left a well respected hardware company to come to Cisco, everyone tried to talk me out of it, a manager told me (who worked there several years prior to coming to the company where we both worked) told me "at Cisco people don't tend to stab you in the back, they'll come right up to you and stab you in the face!" - a few weeks later I found out how truthful that was

Pros: product, ecosystem, build personal network, brand gets you in to the right level.  good engagement at the field level with with resources to solve customernissues, management are hit and miss.
Cons: company still thinks its 1999 and their stock is 500.  mgmt have created a boys club and the only reason why they are able to keep their overpayed jobs is they can be trusted to keep the club going. chambers started the culture and it lives on. many managers rose through the channel ranks and have no customer skills

Pros: Was a great company with attentive/customer-focused managers that promoted according to merit.  Products are good.  Benefits are great.  Pay is competitive.  Work/Life balance is adequate.
Cons: The sales organization is choked with administrative tasks that each new manager creates because they think that a "new" way to collect/collate the same information will yield different results.  The true definition of insanity.  The overlay salesforce has no other capability than to troll those same tools for reasons to ask the same inane questions.  The organization is so choked with useless mid to low level management/overlay organizations that spend more time managing internal expectations rather than customer attentiveness.

Pros:
Great people who are smart and hardworking
Company allows maximum flexibility for work/life balance
Great benefits
Chance for great bonuses
Cons:
Pays lower than industry standard
Management structure is not conducive to work processes
Slow moving company that sucks at change
Always seems to be a step behind in the industry trends

Pros: Excellent benefits; truly global scale; flexible working options; very broad exposure to technologies; high level of operational effectiveness; extremely mature for a tech company.
Cons: Frequent layoffs; too many levels of management; large amounts of corporate inertia; very slow advancement in mid levels; no ability to retain products with less than 60% gross margins; ageist cycling of experienced employees with tech start up acquisitions and college hires.

Pros: Ability to work remote was great.  Access to training, tools & technology are there for you to develop your skills.  There are a lot of very talented people for you to work with and learn from.  When you work with the best it will push you to be better.
Cons: Working remotely can be a double edged sword.  It does not give you the face to face interaction that is key for building strong relationships.

Pros:
Good work life balance
Scale and resources available to do impactful work across industries
Competitive compensation 
Lots of smart top-notch employees
Cons:
Highly political, top-down culture
Lots of bureaucracy in certain areas
Old school command & control management 
Lack of workplace fringe benefits like free drinks, snacks, good coffee etc.
Good amount of non-productive harmful employees who survive only due to cut-throat political prowess

Pros:
The old days when stock options could make you rich are gone forever, but total package is still good, in the top 50% percentile of similar ICT companies. You can get RSU (restricted stock units) as a bonus each year.
Networking is not as "hot" as it used to be 20 years ago, but it  is still an interesting area for working, in terms of innovation and market opportunities.
Work environment is OK, similar to other large ICT companies, not heaven and not hell, but still  way better than a steel factory, although not as exciting as a startup or high tech software company.
Cons:
Morale not great  after many rounds of layoffs.  The company needs a major shift to survive long term, which might be a threat or a great opportunity, depending on where you end up.  Cisco was the Google of the 90s, now it looks more like IBM in the 90s. It is not an innovation leader anymore and market dominance is at risk.
Many senior leaders are focused on politics and protecting their back, so the work environment is not as friendly and relaxed as it used to be. Some of the executives lack the vision, depth and personality. They can manage the "blah blah" in videos, but they fall short when it comes to real market understanding, technology vision  and execution.

Pros: Work from Home, Good company for trainings, and learning
Cons:
High level politics, routine lay-off, no criteria for lay-off, now days more US centric, promotions only in you are in a political group. Not any more good company to work for... it is a ice berg...
no scope for growth if you are hard working....political pressure to share your work with some favourable workers...

Pros:
1. Lots of different technologies and areas you could chose to work on
2. Some great talent when it comes to networking industry
3. Great work life balance and facilities
4. Lot of autonomy to engineers
Cons:
1. Management needs focus and reduce internal politics
2. Growth is slow even if you are a great performer
3. Dilution of work over time and bad hires

Pros: Great place to work with some great benefits. Work life balance is good. Company being large provides ample opportunities to switch in case one is not happy. Stock has languished for a while but that is had to understand.
Cons: Process overhead sometime is quite a bit. Also very conservative in terms of technology stack that it uses. Overall planning leaves less time for development and bunch of work is completed during actual QA cycles. Need to go agile with smaller release cycles.

Pros:
- good team work and people who want to create great products
- management is supportive
- good work-life balance
Cons:
- company is shifting to cloud based and away from making products.
- mechanical teams are part of hardware organization.
- senior managers seem like they don't know what is going on.
- few skip level meetings. 
- little long term planning or development of engineering team

Pros: For a public giant, Cisco makes a noble effort to stay current with industry standards and best practices with its team org and culture. Mature company with a healthy drive among its senior-level leadership to run with the kids.
Cons: Changes can still be a bit slow within the massive machine. Lots of established processes and playbooks, so coloring outside lines can be at own risk ( not to say you can't, just do so with aware caution ).

Pros: Cisco is a well-established company. It has a solid stock value. The company has a strong footprint in all six continents. Its brand is well-known internationally.
Cons: Cisco  portfolio is not focused and is all over the map. They try to compete in niche markets that are not well-suited for the company core business. They do not have much potential for growth.

Pros: Some of the most incredible people i've worked with in my career.  Genuinely very high standard of employee.  Truly global company.
Cons: Cisco is a coin-operated machine...if you are not in sales, then you don't really matter.  Current headcount reduction is removing all strategic/business capability from the company and replacing them with sales 'bodies' to hit the numbers this quarter.  This only delays the problem which Cisco will face.

Pros: Work live balance - lots of good individuals - benefits package - flexibility to do the right thing for the customer - remote working is facilitated
Cons: Too many new managers who just don't understand the business and how customers actually work - too many initiatives that go nowhere - Emperor's New Clothes... Latest round of layoffs has removed lots of good experienced people; cost cutting exercise on the surface but this has increased the workload on the people left and has created at atmosphere where employees are worried about their future

Pros: Great place to work!  By drinking their own champaign, Cisco is able to support remote workers using their collaboration offerings.  Cisco always "does the right thing" for its employees.  Even my experience with their limited restructuring was well handled.
Cons: Cisco is going to continue to be a market leader for many years, but then will need to figure out how to transition out of the proprietary hardware business into software and services to last more than 5-10 years.  I expect the stock to continue to trade sideways for the foreseeable future, so don't count on stock options.

Pros:
The side in Krakow is full of young talented people that are eager to jump-start their careers. Thus it offers many opportunities for new recruits.
Site is amazing and very work-friendly.
Possibility to work from home.
Cons:
Unfortunately, many people decide to leave after 2-3 years as there are not enough promotions and salary increases. These is an obvious stagnation for the more experienced employees. 
It seems that the management is more eager to bring new talent than to keep the current one.

Pros: Flexibility, Access to technical resources, good benefits, work-life balance is good. Change to become software oriented is a good move and hopefully, Cisco can make similar business decisions.
Cons: Not competent salary. A lot of internal politics. Recognition is poor. Cafes are overpriced and not subsidized. Bonuses are not paid according to business unit's performance rather the whole company's performance. The problem here is that there is always a BU which performs poorly and the profit-making BUs take a hit because of this.

Pros:
At Cisco, we recognize the value veterans bring to
the workplace—including a unique set of skills that are
innate in those who have served. Mission-focused.
Leadership. Collaboration. The possibilities for veterans
in technology careers are greater than ever before.
And Cisco is in a unique position to help veterans find
a rewarding career in technology by providing access
to both learning opportunities as well as connections to
our partner ecosystem.
Cons: Sometimes promotions can be hard to come by if you stay in one job. But if you are willing to take on new challenges and maybe even relocate, the the opportunities are there.

Pros: Empowered to make decisions. Global company. You can travel to anywhere in Cisco and the culture is the same, one family. The technology in the company allows you to be flexible where you work. Diverse team where bullying and discrimination is not tolerated. A message from the CEO. I have seen people asked to leave the company for unacceptable behavior.  Share prices going up. Company strategy is very futurist. Vision. Cisco changing the way we work, live play and learn. It has always been this for the last 13 years of my employment.
Cons: Its not a 9-5 job because it is a global company. But work time is flexible.

Pros:
Amazing leadership, culture, and my team operates in a fairly fast paced environment for a big enterprise.  Lots of opportunities for growth and understanding the business - especially in a cross functional role like Product Management. They have an amazing commitment to sustainability and philanthropy and amazing resources/development plans for their employees

Overall would highly recommend working at Cisco to anyone. Oh and amazing work life balance
Cons: Always some politics to deal with and things can be slower than you like.  But good culture definitely depends on your leadership and the organization you're in - lay offs do happen frequently at Cisco

Pros: Good people, good culture, good package, great CEO. If you fit in you can happily work here for a very long time and have a solid career as long as you dont get caught up in very frequent reorg cross fires.
Cons: In recent years as a consequence of new management cost cutting and reorgs are a frequent thing now in an attempt to stop the bleeding on the revenue side . Many jobs gone or migrating to cheap labor locations around the globe and seem to impact in particular the more experienced demographic in Europe. Site strategy changes can mess up long standing careers easily. Dont expect loyalty based on your seniority with or contributions to the company.

Pros: Very well establish company, financially stable with long history, training programs, flexibility in work situation. Went the extra mile to accommodate employees during the pandemic.
Cons: The team I worked for was in TAC customer support where we take cases from customers and it was stressful. We had a new manager with limited experience and we had a a very demanding customer and the team was lacking in organization and that created friction between team members. Changes happened very often.

Pros: There is good work/life balance at Cisco. Most groups provide flexible work options. It is a very well run company for a company that's so large. One can get very interesting and technically challenging work.
Cons: One can easily become invisible at Cisco. One's work does not always do the talking. It is imperative that you blow your horn to get noticed. A true engineer will feel dissatisfied here because he or she may not get noticed easily.

Pros:
Great team, good pay, nice managers (at least in the BU I work for).
Plenty of new technologies to learn, with Gurus around you.
Tons of cutting edge equipments to work on.
1 month of PTO for fresh, plus virtually unlimited choice of WFH via company paid broadband service.
Top school districts around the campus.
Cons:
Too many low level managers from a south Asia country and they are mean, mean, mean!
Where goes the stock options?
Not as well paid as Yahoo! and Google... especially by stock bonus.
Relatively long working hours, although it's normal in the industry.
No free lunch, like Google, and no free dinner, like Juniper.

Pros: Cisco pays well and is a very recognizable name in the tech sector that looks good on resumes.  The San Jose area is also pretty rockin.  Also lots of different areas of expertise to choose from; hardware, software, low level and high level programming opportunities are offered.  Plus you get to choose your own team in the Cisco Choice program.
Cons: San Jose is a very expensive place to live and even though they pay well it seems like it is not enough sometimes.  It is a big corporation, so it can be difficult to earn personal recognition or advance the ladder.

Pros:
Good Technology
Interesting work
Great Engineers
Cons:
Cisco management is now treating its employees like commodities
Opportunities for growth are very limited in Cisco
Cisco's mantra for the last 5 years has move everything to India (which failed since most projects sent there came back)
Corruption in management is a concern. I have heard of managers  who bring in contractors through their own companies so that they can get a  piece of the action. 
Senior management is rumored to only open doors to vendors in whom they are allowed to hold stakes

Pros: Great work experience for students getting into the networking field.  Sure the work is very basic but it really lets you get to know the inner workings of all Cisco has to offer in its products.  I learned so much while working there.
Cons: Unless you take a year off to work for Cisco it is very difficult to get more indepth into the learning process.  You start out with the basics but you get what you put into it.

Pros:
flexible time and could work from home, get personal thing done during office hour
learn technical and train for certification
Cons:
no raise
dont know how to get promoted even if you are qualified, 4 years on the same job and performance rating is good. they say it is about a budget that is shared and there is a list, you have to be on number 1 list before getting promoted. what if you were transferred to a new boss? it will get reset

Pros: The combined salary+bonus makes for a pretty good compensation package.  Base salaries are a bit low, but when you add in the annual bonus it brings the compensation level up to par.  It's a pretty family-friendly environment.  Working from home is allowed.
Cons:
Promotions are difficult to get and depend largely on how popular you are with management.  

Cisco is really 20 companies under one umbrella.  Each business unit has its own culture, so make sure you understand the culture/attitude/behavior of whatever group you choose to join.  

Someone's opinion from business unit X has absolutely no bearing if you are joining business unit Y!

Pros: Cisco has historically been a great place to work. Management does care about the employees and their personal well being. The work is challenging and can be satisfying and rewarding. More recently with the troubles in Cisco's business the company is changing for the worse. There has been massive attrition of key engineers and engineering leaders and Cisco doesn't seem to be able to stop this trend. While the company is certainly not a disaster and the problems it faces are recoverable it needs to move quickly and decisively which is something it has not been able to do for the past 3+ years since it implemented the boards and councils management structure a mistake John Chambers is directly responsible for. Since then most of this structure has been removed and now its about getting the right leaders in place. Compensation is relatively fair especially if you have a good manager who recognizes who the contributors are. Benefits are really good to...
Cons: Attrition is a major issue right now and Cisco needs to stop the bleeding quickly and figure out not only how its going to retain the top talent but attract new talent which is especially difficult in Silicon Valley where there are many startups wooing the top talent as well as employees leaving to join the red hot social networking companies. You need talented engineers to build the best products and solutions in the market and while this won't effect the company in the next 12 - 18 months you will see the impact outside of that. The executive team is a group of extremely bright and talented business people but that is also the biggest problem is that there are no true Engineers at the top of the company and this is a technology company who needs great executive technology leadership!

Pros: The are a very ethical and respectable company, with a very flexible work policy.  They continually solicit feedback from employees on internal policies and meeting effectiveness.  They offer many different challenging job roles within the networking field, and large campuses to keep internal moves from affecting your commute.
Cons: The hours are long, they have a forced ranking system, and there is lots of internal competition over engineering projects and resources.  Execution is all-important and quality suffers.  They are overly-frugal... employee families are never invited to company events.

Pros: We can work from home part of the time. The company's corporate social responsibility (CSR) programs are impressive. I like it that our volunteering generates matching funds to nonprofits.
Cons: The politics have become challenging during the last year or so. It saddens me that some talented, wonderful people have left for this reason.

Pros: The big advantage with Cisco is that they hire smart people. You can always find helpful and intelligent people to get help from. Compensation is not stellar but ok.
Cons: It is sort of like North Korea. The leader is always right and you must applaud at the the right time. A little sectish at times... There is never any difference on how hard you should work: We're below budget - work harder! We're on budget - work harder! We're way above budget - work harder!

Pros: Great people. Good community. Great use of own technology to enable collaboration and anywhere, anytime, any device connectivity. Home office setup was great!
Cons: A little too big and too redundant in some areas, causing duplicate efforts or unnecessary waiting for resolution of conflicts. Working to resolve, at least on operations side.

Pros:
During my time at Cisco I worked with several people across different projects and teams. What I found(astoundingly) common them were that the people were so open and always ready to help (whatever it takes to get work done). It is always great to work at a place where work is not technically "work". 
Also internal movement is highly encouraged and very common. If you get tired of what you are doing or want to learn something new, there are plenty of new things to try out.

In summary, very talented people, great work-life balance and a lot of fun to work here!
Cons: As is commonly known, the remuneration is not great (when compared to companies of similar reputation).

Pros: Lots of people with families and CEO John Chambers fosters a family-atmosphere. While you can put in lots of hours, stress levels are kept pretty low. We get the job done, but we don't' run over people to do it. Great benefits including the company medical facility in San Jose and employee Gym. Very smart people here and it's bay area. Traditionally a strong rotation culture but see cons list on this one. Generous bonuses. You also get a front-row seat on some pretty awesome technology and vision for the future.
Cons:
Cisco does a terrible job identifying talent and promoting them, as a result of this and the recent layoffs and market challenges, I think Cisco is seeing a bit of a brain drain. I know and hear of plenty of notable talent heading for the doors. one reason they're leaving is this company prefers outside talent to fill open positions which clogs the top and greatly limits upward mobility. While traditionally a rotation company, which is great, open reqs have been almost all shut down coupled with the new focus of hiring in RTP North Carolina complicates and limits available rotations in San Jose. 
There's also very limited equity adjustments and a weak mechanism for distribution. After several years I learned new hires at my same level were being offered salaries higher than my own. That tells me Cisco values my time here less than brand new people and is the completely wrong message. Another gentle push out the door.

Pros:
A group of friendly talented people. There are some really capable technical people inside the company.
The culture is very much all about sharing information everyone is passionate about the company.
Working remotely is something that Cisco does really well and using the technology to make this a better experience.
Culture of sharing goes beyond Cisco focus and allows for giving back regularly to charities, schools etc.
Cons: Career progression means changing roles often and moving department, the career development does not favour people staying in the same team in the same role.

Pros: Great name recognition for your resume.  Decent benefits.
Cons: It's a popularity contest through and through.  An employee is graded on how well he/she kisses up to management and not performance or productivity.  A person can be the most productive and the most technical member of the group and still end up at the bottom 5% for frivolous reasons.  Managers only cares about trimming the workforce.  Annual layoffs are detrimental to productivity.  They will do everything possible to break and humiliate you on your way out.

Pros: Still a good place to be. Morale took some dings over the last few years, with annual layoffs and the institution of a horrible, ill-conceived "stack ranking" system that effectively incented employees to claw and scratch their way above others, while undermining your colleagues instead of collaborating for results. Thankfully, the horrible stack ranking system is finally on its way out. There are some exciting things happening in product development, and a buzz of energy I haven't felt for a while.
Cons: As with any big company, it's sometimes difficult to be nimble. Leadership needs to do a better job at setting priorities, and sticking to them, and communicating effectively.

Pros: Cisco Systems has the ability to quickly produce and market the state of the art in technology.  Cisco provides their employees the opportunity to gain certification in these technologies increasing a persons future job prospects and making them a sought after resource at many companies.
Cons: Cisco needs a little more focus on investing long term in their software strategy.  Because the technology for cloud is now coming from open source, grassroots communities Cisco has not yet decided on the best path to follow.

Pros:
- Work-Life Balance
- You'll get to interact with hardware and see how your software runs apart from just writing it
- New opportunities in the areas of Cloud Computing, SDN ant IoT
Cons:
- Depending on the team, after few months, everything gets slacky and you'll hit the career saturation point
- Lots of old people; old ways of doing thing
- Layoffs/re-org almost always trickles down to engineers; managers/directors/VPs hardly gets laid off even thought they are DUMB and lack the vision
- Bureaucracy
- Too many fools running the show

Pros: the brand name - know that you are employed with one of the well known IT Giants
Cons: No respect for employees - especially when they want to cut resources - hard work, sincerity have no role to play - biggest worry : no job security.... you can get the marching orders anytime without rhyme or reason ! Highly political !

Pros: Generally speaking the work environment is very flexible, as long as you're producing quality work.  The compensation was reasonable, but it varies widely based on what group you're in and what projects you're working on.  The newer projects obviously get priority when it comes to budget, as well as the workload.
Cons:
As said in another review of Cisco that I read, it is very easy to slowly get sucked-in and end up working 14 hour days.  Generally speaking, you will be rewarded based on what you put into it.  So if you choose to put up boundaries and stick to a 40-hour week, you'll be comfy and cozy.  If you choose to put in 60-80 hour weeks, you're likely to be elevated in the long term (provided you're not in a group that's approaching "sustaining-mode" where there is very little new development).
If you're lucky enough to get into the "in-crowd" and you're a hard worker that puts out quality product, you're set for life.  Cisco has a very elite group of people that jump ship every few years, create a new start-up (i.e. ensime, nuovo, andiamo), work their tails' off, get purchased by Cisco making tons of money, and repeat.  But getting into that group is extremely difficult even if you're good at what you do.  There's a bit of class-ism in the Cisco HW department.

Pros: If you have a good manager, it's a fantastic experience.  Overall the benefits are really good.  You have a lot of leeway to be able to work on various projects or programs.
Cons: If you get a bad manager, it can be very challenging.  There have been a lot of re-orgs, some that have made sense and some that have not.  When they prolong the org changes, it really lowers morale as with each of these there are small lay-offs.

Pros: Negative overall experience. But will give credit where it's due. Pay is somewhat competitive and benefits are good if you're new to tech or bay area. But not comparable to "established" younger and newer tech companies. However, best benefit is WFH or working remotely. You might have to work out details with your team or they might not care - but you can pretty much work where-ever you want, which is a pretty sweet perk to have and makes traveling much more flexible (and affordable).
Cons: With that said, there were WAY MORE cons than pros. It's an older company and people are stuck in the past. They're trying to change and adopt younger viewpoints, but if you're young, good luck. Yes, you'll hear people put down younger peers b/c they're more "junior" or "less knowledgable" - and apparently that's okay (why?). Culture's cut-throat, very political and everyone's trying to one-up everyone else. Saving face is more important than being honest - which ironically is the only way to improve and actually impact the bottom line. This is not the place to be if you seek, speak and spit out the truth. You WILL be seen as "difficult" and your career WILL be negatively impacted. Also business moves at glacial pace and everyone spends more time talking about what they will do than actually doing it. Also zero accountability - if you're managing a project and need to see it through, you WILL be working with people who don't care and you WILL have to pick up their slack. Again, if you're young, career advancement is limited - unless you're with a good manager who "gets it". More rare than common. WFH is also great at first but gets real old, fast. You'll miss the in person time and communicating with remote co-workers will require 2x the work. Best advice? Get in, get the experience you need and then move on. Don't get stuck in the cycle.

Pros: A great company to work for. The benefits are fantastic and the people are top notch.
Cons: Beware every year there is an expectation of transition. Transition to Cisco means that there will be an organization that gets changed and reorganized resulting in Layoffs. This means that as soon as you get hired network and look for your follow on job immediately. Cisco's definition of diversity currently focuses on white women. On the surface Cisco is very friendly to minorities but hiring retention trends on the manager through the VP ranks until you get to the CEO board suggests otherwise.

Pros: Excellent benefits (4% 401k match, ESPP options, $50,000 Lifetime Fertility coverage, paid volunteer hours, paid time off) and work from home whenever needed
Cons: Meetings. Meetings. Meetings. With no agendas. No accountability. Work falls on the base level employees. Tons of middle management bloat - expect 6-7 layers of management above you if you are a worker bee. Communication is not direct - expect every announcement to be lengthy, full of fancy words that run around the point.

Pros:
Amazing benefits
Flexible hours (work in your pajamas as long as you have a reliable data connection to the team/project)
Total pay easily exceeds industry
Very smart people (higher up you go, more vicious they get!)
Cons:
Lot of backstabbing and ruthless competitiveness
Flexible hours (Expect to get 5 am WebEx invites that you are EXPECTED to accept)
Networking products are not the most in-demand and Cisco is yet to define the new growth strategy

Pros: Excellent compensation/benefits for Silicon Valley employees; possibility to obtain exposure to a broad range of technologies and product development. Career development resources are available.
Cons: Company has been going through a transitional period for the past 18 months.  This is something that has been very disruptive, with a reduction in workforce occurring approximately every 3-5 months.  Additionally, for the past 10 years, the Company has been in a mode of buying promising Companies in order to acquire new technologies or solutions, and then after about 2 or 3 years, shifting a chunk of software development resources offshore or in some cases to Canada -something that may be a concern depending on job role and department.

Pros: Good benefits, facilities and market position.  Some first rate people, particularly Systems Engineers.  Strong partner network.  Good quality equipment.
Cons: Weak management, too many conflicting business priorities and strategies, lack of domain experts in some business areas, poor morale, low investment in potentially high growth business areas.  Expensive equipment compared to others in market.  Progress and promotion is not merit based but through sucking up.

Pros:
Good work environment
Good product will billion dollar yearly revenue runrate
Good benefits especially health plan & number of PTOs
Cons:
I hated the layoff culture! Frequent layoffs affect PERM processing of H1B holders, but I guess the company is hardly bothered about it. 

The second issue I encountered was the willingness of people to learn new stuff slows down as the team dilutes. Not everyone is focussed to learn cutting edge tech, the attitude seems to be like a 9-5 job. 

Lot of bureaucracy!

Pros: On the Sales side of Cisco the culture is great. Management allows you to work independently and check in when needed. You can always get help from your peers and the company is very much about putting their customers first.
Cons: Working remotely is great, but it also brings on challenges. Getting face time with people is often difficult because most people work from home. The collaboration tools are great, but having a hallway conversation is nice once in a while

Pros: A year-long Cisco Sales Associates Program has been a life-changing international experience. The program takes all the efforts to make you a better version of your own self. It does so through assessed role plays, technical and soft skills training, which helps prepare for a career in Sales / Systems Engineering. Instructors and managers are seasoned professionals which not only make it challenging but also make it fun! It's a great way to develop yourself while building your network among the top university graduates from around the globe.
Cons: It's hard to realize things come to an end, but you have to move on, great things are waiting for you.

Pros:
- Flexibility in work schedule and remote vs in-office
- Volunteerism emphasis 
- Great benefits (amazing maternity leave, tuition reimbursement, the list goes on!)
- Constant professional development opportunities
- Encouragement to rotate jobs within the company
- Culture of driving success: it's expected that you challenge the status quo, not just do things the way they've always been done
- Endless learning potential with a company this large and complex
Cons: Not exactly a con, but the downside to the extreme flexibility in work schedule is the fact that you have to own your schedule and defend your work life balance. There's always support for the work life balance, but it doesn't always present itself.

Pros:
- Best place to learn networking technologies at a level that you won’t get anywhere else
- Depending on which team/technology you support, the skills you obtained from here can take you to the next level level position at a lucrative salary elsewhere (yes, people from TAC have moved to companies like Amazon & Google, if that’s what interests you)
- Colleagues are friendly, nice and supportive
- Free exams when attempting for any Cisco certs, including CCIE
- Many opportunities to move to a different team/technology within the TAC theatre but not so much outside TAC
Cons:
- The salary in TAC is below par. Many times I have raised this issue to my direct managers & even to the higher bosses during skip-level meetings about considering to increase the overall pay across all grades but not a single cent has ever increased! Oh, and those eNPS survey as well. Not sure if the bosses who read the surveys ever showed some sympathy to the suffering TAC engineers
- The kind of work you do in TAC is very narrow. You can be highly skilled in X technology but your knowledge in other technologies can be very poor (unless you have gained experience in these “other technologies” from your previous roles)
- Favouritism! TAC has a funny system to get a payrise or a grade promotion because managers value you merely based upon what you have showed off to them or what they saw from the metrics/stats and not so much with the depth of the technical knowledge & experience you have gained over the years + the challenging issues you have resolved on your own + the number of times you have helped your colleagues with difficult cases. These are stuff the managers have failed to notice! Whoever read this may disagree but they disagreed because they never understood and they always thought they were right. This place can be awesome for newbies/grads because if they showed off their little contributions here and there, worked hard, stayed in the office after hours to either study or work on cases, and be nice to the managers, they will surely get the cool stuff, travel to other Cisco’s offices for BU rotations etc, and get promoted to the higher grade very quick even surpassing the salary of the seasoned TAC engineers
- Politics everywhere! I have always wanted to stay in Cisco (outside TAC, of course) and I have applied for many other internal jobs before moving on. Of all those many internal positions I have applied, 95% of the time, I got NO interview invitations at all. Did my resume failed to impress the recruiter? Was there some kind of favouritism in other departments as well? Didn’t they like TAC engineers at all? Was there some kind of politics being played out? I don’t know the true answers but whatever the reasons are, it’s funny how I got an offer upon my very first external job application from one of the Big Four tech companies. Funny but this is the reality!
- Constant & very high number of employee attritions due to the above reasons
- High pressure work environment because you are basically a support engineer which means that you are there to resolve problems after problems, and for every customer, their problem is always urgent to be resolved. And because TAC always lack of engineers (due to constant resignations), it creates a constant burnout mentally & physically

Pros:
Having been at Cisco for a couple of months its apparent that Cisco has indeed nurtured a very collaborative and transparent culture. The technology we sell to customer resonates very well with the Cisco culture. As we provide top-notch networking capabilities to our customers, as a Cisco employee, I always find myself being able to be directed to the right person at the right time to get the job done.

Everyone is friendly and approachable, most importantly helpful as we work in cross functional teams.
Cons: Being a giant, some processes do need to be streamlined and therefore, Cisco is actively sifting through its processes to help us employees move things faster by simplification of processes.

Pros: Great culture and people to work with. You will like your work there. People are proud to be working there. This company positively sucks you in. Work-life balance is not just a myth here. It is encouraged and definitely possible be your daily reality. You are encouraged to be your best at work and outside of it. Social Responsibility (incl.charity) is taken very seriously and on a large scale.
Cons: In recent years constant reorganizations and changes make it difficult to always stay on top of everything. Positions, responsibilities, what is expected of you will be changing constantly which is not what everyone likes or is good at. Work can be very demanding.

Pros: Lots of opportunity for entrepreneurship and driving change as company transforms from hardware to SaaS and subscription software. The corporate culture is really good with supportive and committed leaders. Very satisfying work environment and the focus on networking, security and collaboration are all valuable, feel-good tech areas. You can feel proud to work here.
Cons: The size and complexity of the company make it difficult to drive change. Lots of buy-in and consensus required, even where there is general agreement. Important efforts can be blocked or held-up by stove-piped organizations.

Pros:
Fully remote work with the option to move closer to an office (either RTP, NC or Richardson, TX) and an allowance to help with the move.
Access to plentiful benefits as soon as day two.
A full year of training: half to study for and attain certifications, the other half to settle into the team you're placed into.
Cisco pays the bill for your first three exam attempts per cert.
Strong support from management and your peers.
Structured onboarding process and ongoing checkups from your managers.
WFH equipment included.
Yearly flexible raise to compensate for inflation.
Cons: Not a con, per se, but you *must* be determined and devoted in order to get your certs on time, especially if you have no previous networking experience.

Pros: Excellent compensation (including bonus and base salary). Many different aspects of the company, and if you are able to move around, you can work on many different cool projects. Also I think CIsco is one of the strongest companies, and will always remain a backbone of the technology sector -- as any company requires an IT infrastruture (something Cisco has a "monopoly" in)
Cons: Cisco is too big, often times you will not know whats going on in other parts of the company. From what I saw, I think its hard to move up the ladder, because people have been there for so long.

Pros:
- The best company to learn the compute network knowledge in the real world.
- You can move around easily to different areas within the company
Cons:
- You find office politics like other big companies.  The unfair promotion upset many people. But in the economic down time, can't complain too much.
- No salary increase for the past a few years. The only way to get salary increase is through promotion. 
- Not many new projects during the economic down time.
- Too many people on the same project.  Everybody gets a little bit of work.

Pros: work life balance, great benefits, for the most part great people to work with, work remotely full time
Cons: no more perks, pay for your cell even though its work related, pay for internet even though you use it to for work, promotions in IT come every 4-5 years, salary and grade levels not at market rate, huge bureaucracy and too heavily process oriented in IT makes it difficult to complete projects in a shorter time

Pros: It feels great when you leave.
Cons: Managers are sweatshopping engineers trying to compete not with the marketplace but instead with other groups doing the same exact thing.  What a huge waste.  Being forced to work late and weekends is awful, and if you do manage to get your own work done during " normal" hours you still have to come in weekends "for the team".  Apparently you dont have enough to do if you are getting your job done during the week. After all that, no raise and no bonuses for me.  So I left, got 2 offers in three days elsewhere and have never been happier.

Pros: Cisco Systems pays well, especially at lower levels.  Majority of employees participate in a bonus plan.  Casual attire is acceptable when not presenting to customers.  Team work and collaboration is encouraged.  Communication to employees is frequent.  Opportunities to interact with the CEO for all employees is possible at least annually.
Cons: Cisco Systems is a very large company.  Sometimes the processes and procedures are cumbersome for optimal business execution.  Steps are being taken to improve this.

Pros: Average salaries, benefits, bonuses; somewhat favorable organizational commitment to Inclusion and Diversity in workplace; global workplace; very smart and capable employees; many opportunities for formal structured learning
Cons: Frequent "Limited Restructurings" (Layoffs), Rare and limited opportunity for promotion, infrequent salary increases based only on "CompaRatio", not on Cost of Living; Millenials quickly move to places in which they can advance in their careers; difficulty in integrating many acquisitions; some limitations to innovation; difficult on-boarding with little support; frustrating information systems; many siloed efforts lead to duplication; workaholic culture that rebrands "work-life balance" as "work-life integration"; frugal culture - no business class travel for frequent long-haul flights

Pros: Great place to work, A large corporate with very good benefits.
Cons: Small cog in a big machine - middle management are under motivated and over payed. Thus lack the dedication required to support your personal career growth. The work life balance doesn't exsist for many, but this is compounded by the fact that others in the same teams and roles get away with doing very little, and it is never picked up by management.

Pros: Good managers abound, but politics a growing concern.  Has lost the small startup mentality long ago.  Works as a big machine with lots of re-orgs.
Cons: Uses old bellcurve system of performance management which discourages management from forming a team of Top 10%.  Little ability for employees to share in company stock outside of ESPP.

Pros: I liked being part of a company that promoted the Internet and the way it can change people's lives.  It may sound hokey, but Cisco really makes the connection between selling routers and impacting people's lives for the better.
Cons: I felt like a number.  Leadership viewed the sales team as a 'means to the end'.   This is true for many companies and so you just need to realize that and find your purpose outside of the sales leadership mantra of  'make your commit'.

Pros: bright talent anguishing at the bottom of company hierarchy
Cons: diminishing technical Job  with frequent lay-off due to outsourcing, new tac has become sweat shop culture, CEO get huge raise of 80% for cutting Jobs.  Management had mind set of Cisco being hardware co. failure to do timely acquisition in software, virtualization & NextGen technologies has put the co. dominance par behind its competitor.

Pros: It is all about delivering results in the SHORT-TERM
Cons: Requires to adapt to change VERY fast, to deliver results faster, and the culture varies by organization. If you are really interested to join Cisco, make sure to know very well NOT ONLY your direct manager, but also his manager. The organization changes very often, which makes it difficult to get continuity on what you do for mid-to-long term. So, you must reinvent yourself as valuable contributor on a yearly basis.

Pros: Great technology firm, excellent breadth of solutions so you can move horizontally. Flexible work, once you used to it, you can never leave this place. Excellent middle-top management and clear goals to measure performance. Very liberal training policy, and not so bad travel policy.
Cons: Groups based on your country, or some demographics. That's the horrible part. Many jobs, decades old IT systems, Heavy workloads, and worse of all is the information overflow. There are tons of files with old information, and many versions/revisions but you need plenty of luck to find the correct information. So indirectly you'll end up relying on people.

Pros: Good pay and benefits.  Incredible employees to work with....the over all employee talent pool is higher than I have ever experienced.
Cons: Long hours and difficult condition to accomplish work.  This is driven by the unspoken policy is that 5% of employees must be valued as low.  Even when your performance is very good it difficult to be recognized as such.  Eventually you may be push out.

Pros: There are opportunities for learning in abundance. The question is, which way do you go! Cisco does place a fair amount of trust in it's employees with intellectual property, and you are truly in charge of your own career, though, it takes time to become aware of this...
Cons: Managers are somewhat too "hands off!" Knowing where you stand with your department takes a lot of effort sometimes.  Because Cisco is always trying to improve the company bottom line via projects and processes, there is not a lot of long term security with this organization. Each year, layoffs do occur whether they are advertised or not. Not a place to feel extremely comfortable in.

Pros:
Lots of resources
Industry giant 
great balance for a large company between innovation and stability
great work life balance if you manage it right (will vary based on role and qtr of year)
lots of hands on when you want it.
Cons:
as with any large company its hard to know what resources/ppl you have available to you. comes with time.
upward mobility is easier if you are willing to move into new roles vs staying in same role. you go to promotion...

Pros: Good pay, good benefits including health insurance, car, RSU. Personal growth is possible trough great access to online training as well as in-person.
Cons: Cisco used to be a great company to work for, exciting projects, good Customers, high pumped atmosphere, but now's gone.  Seven+ year or reorganisation has completely paralysed the company, many talents left and delocalisation in low-cost labour area is terribly impacting quality delivered to Customers. Top management is constantly engaged in war to maintain position and no true career development exists. Just consider another company...

Pros: You will get to work with some good technology before it is moved to India.
Cons: As our market share falls and our profits dive, products and projects are being moved off shore to India.  Number one goal stated by senior management is to increase the amount of turnover.  96% of new hires under the age of 30 and most are hired directly out of college.

Pros: about 5 years ago, it would have all been pros: The. one thing left is good salary.
Cons: politics, nepotism, HB1 Visa overload, lay offs, culture of fear, lay offs are a popularity contest. Although I wasn't hit in the LR, lots of good people were. Being young engineers might get Cisco fresh on tech but with no business acumen with older leasers leaves Cisco with smart immature punks who cant be part of a team.

Pros:
Reputable company, doesn't hurt to have them on the resume.
Cisco tries to do something for their employees. Of course it's easier for big profitable company. Good work/life balance, good benefits and corporate perks.
Cons:
Too much politics and too many conflicting groups of interest. Many layers of management. Not all are capable. Regular layoffs to weed out the lower 5%, I guess.
Mix between Cisco veterans and more recent additions. Veterans can be lacking sense of ownership and don't really own/drive or behave like they could make a difference. Maybe that happens if one stays too long at this company.

Pros: Very easy to move around internally between, engineering, development, IT and other functions.   One can build their career and move upwards, there are a lot of resources one can leverage to seek a mentor, network internally and build relationships.
Cons: Too big and too bureacratic, sometimes gives the feeling you are working in government, takes a lot of time to convince and do the right thing.  Despite the soundbites, management only likes quick wins and their career focus.  As a result people management is often overlooked in place of technology management.

Pros:
People who work hard and are committed, is show equal commitment from the company as well.
Job satisfaction is more if you are equally invested in what you are doing.
Lateral movements is possible if you prove your worth.
Work culture/Benefits depends on the BU you are working in.
Cons: Since it is a large company, sometimes your hard work is rated from among the teams accross CISCO. Benefits also might depend on how well the company does in that quarter which is not directly influenced solely from your team's work. But having said that, it depends on the team/BU you are working.

Pros: Lots of flexibility, was able to telecommute and work part time for a couple of years.  Way back when, most everyone got stock options and felt ownership.  That's not a pro anymore.
Cons: The process people took over.  Sometimes we had to change perfectly functional code to satisfy a tool that identified a possible problem, even if we could prove it couldn't happen.  Too much focus on reducing headcount rather than retaining and motivating good performers.

Pros: great benefits, work life balance.
Cons:
Acquisitions are frequently abandoned after few years as non strategic - which raises the question on the process how due diligence was carried out during evaluation of the acquisition
Annual Layoffs in Aug-Sep time frame every year.
Executives are focussed in making wall street happy at the cost of customer and employee satisfaction
Cloud Initiative was a flop and the company has No cloud or analytics strategy while AWS and Azure continue to execute and grow.
Top Heavy - everyone is a leader or visionary while there is no one to do the actual work

Pros: Lot of freedom to pursue our passion, move internally within the organisation to a desired role. Empowerment, recognition, very energetic and fun work atmosphere. Awesome infrastructure at office - love the ambience. Amazing leaders who are very approachable. Constant learning and development. Totally love Cisco for the opportunities that i have received thus far.
Cons: Vertical growth gets stagnant at some point in the career ladder which needs to be looked at. As a millennial, I want to grow..and grow fast.

Pros:
- Great exposure to global business
- Flexible work schedule
- Decent work-life balance
Cons:
- "Limited Restructuring" in 2017 meant 16% of workforce or roughly 15 to 20 thousand people looking for new work. 
- "Limited Restructuring" always looming overhead with disregard to performance..it's all about reducing expenses to make shareholder price so if you perform well and make a decent salary, get ready to be "impacted" at some point. 
- Incredibly challenging for Cisco to make necessary changes and implement solutions quickly due to size and complexity of organization

Pros: Cisco Systems is a great place for a technologist, designers, project managers and other roles to learn. They will learn the latest methods, processes and technologies. It provides a foundation to advance within many careers.
Cons: It is constantly going through reorganizations and lay-offs. No matter how talented, innovative and hard working you are, you never know if you'll be hit next.

Pros:
Cisco leadership is passionate about the employee experience and invests time/resources in the employee resource organizations.
Ability to shape and drive initiatives that directly impact Cisco's people culture.
Developing my leadership skills.
Cons:
Large company with flexible work style makes coordinating within and across employee resource groups challenging.
No digitized employee insights tool to properly track employee experience and high potential areas of impact.

Pros:
- Great culture with:
    - flexible working 
    - friendly and respectful colleagues
    - growing trend of innovation
    - focus on personal development and training

- Good benefits including:
    - healthcare
    - childcare
    - stock purchase
Cons:
- Upper management seem to have a disconnect with the understanding and needs of their functions.

- Some unnecessarily complex systems and processes which miss the mark.

- HR department is poor.

Pros:
- flexibility of work (time, location, etc)
- collaborative, international culture
- parking on the campus in Krakow
- support in times of need
- understanding of work/life balance (even if not always possible to maintain)
Cons:
- nearly all decisions are made in US
- not attractive compensation
- global approach often does not take local conditions into considerations
- limited growth opportunities in Europe

Pros:
Good food, Flexible work hours, decent tools infrastructure.
Some good policies to keep the unruly management in check.
Cons:
-noisy open workspaces which doesnt not allow anyone to concentrate, made under the guise of collaboration. However everyone knows its to save real estate.
-(toxic/micro)management that has no intrest in growing the Business unit.
-unrealistic deadlines and compromises on quality, scapegoating of engineers when issues are seen in production.
-favouritism
-limited salary hikes
-management wastes engineers time with pointless meetings and status updates, and expects work to be completed out of office hours
-not much technical work, usually it involves firefighting with bad quality code written in the America

Pros: lots of training if your manager allows, good food though not free, transport is also good, big name in market, good campus , some people are learned and willing to share knowledge
Cons: boss n senior boss is always right although the project suffers, huge difference in Cisco India and Cisco US in work approach. you cannot have a disagreement

Pros:
Code of Business conduct includes protections based on sexual orientation and gender identity and includes vague protections for lgbtq+ people
Healthcare options include some gender affirming healthcare
Cons:
Culture is not generally accepting of LGBTQ+ people
Little effort or importance put into hiring lgbtq+ talent or ensuring their teams will be welcoming or accepting
Ineffective HR department offering lgbtq+ employees the run-around instead of adequate support; HR is also undereducated on lgbtq+ identity and issues, with no feedback loop in place for complaints against HR
Little effort by teams within the company to live out the corporate values of inclusion and collaboration
Dishonest reporting on lgbtq+ inclusion metrics by some leadership

Pros: Culture has been a big factor for Cisco over the years and they have had a huge presence in the IT sector for more than 30 years
Cons: Quality of service delivery appears to be targeted towards continually lowering cost which may have long term negative implications for employees and customers

Pros:
Flexibility to work from anywhere, most people are really great to work with.
Good communication from ELT.
Cons:
Finance tools very inefficient and outdated.

Work life balance highly dependent on the team you are in and who you work with. Since most finance teams are a "business partnering" function, the business partners you work with may dictate your work atmosphere and work life balance. 

For me, work life balance is lacking with constantly changing deliverables, unclear processes, everything being a priority all at once, and team members working 12+ hours daily.

Pros: Great culture, positive place to work, great benefits and overall compensation.  Very comprehensive employee services with attention to detail for those services (e.g. gym offers many different classes every month).
Cons: Very fast paced and if you are not up to this pace you will get lost and/or lose credibility with your peers in this organization.  Also, work life balance in my opinion continues to be a struggle as part of this hard-driving organization.  Expectations are VERY high of all contributors with those willing to sacrifice family time or other work/life balance continues to be a struggle.

Pros:
Great opportunity to move around if you were inclined
In the early days the entrepreneurial spirit was inspiring
Great people - many of whom are dedicated to doing the right thing.
Cons:
Senior management have lost the plot.  
Cisco's culture "legend" is not what it is today.
Vague corporate goals lead to duplication of effort, politics and individual interpretation of what is important for the organization to reach it's goals.
Too many directors with no one reporting to them.

Pros:
Good Life-work balance
Not stressful
Company emphasis on personal time 
Generally friendly environment 
Company is doing well financially
Great company to work if you are a recent college grad and want experience
Cons:
Very political and promotions are not always given to those that are productive
Company is not in favor of paying in the top percentile in the industry
Raises are only given to senior management and not generally given to individual contributors 
Many complain that they have not had raises in over 3 years but management has
HR is not helpful 
Management puts more effort in quality of life and not salaries

Pros:
*  Agile process, 
*  very aggressive,  good learning curve. 
*  Brand Name/Value in the CV
* Good Salary(only if you negotiate)
Cons:
* Very competitive within the team instead of being team work oriented. 
* Will be make a scapegoat if you are not up to your knees.
* No Employee Friendly benefits. (More contractor friendly i should say)
* The more you slog the more you are recognized, the more you get payed and finally end up screwing your personal life.

Pros: The first few years were fun - management was good as they provided leadership and empowerment.  Bonuses were good and perks were OK.
Cons: Too much turf-building and not for the right reasons.  Departments don't work well together.  Stock never went up and bonuses were cut by half.  No more stock options and restricted stock given only to upper management and above with very few exceptions.  Too many political games going on.

Pros:
Good health benefits
Plenty of parking
The chairs are comfortable
Good gym
Plenty of office supplies
Free bottled water
Nice tee shirts to wash the car with
Cons:
To political
Very little chance of career growth
Everyone seems to be stressed out and overworked
Long hours with little rewards
Bad management with little interest in employees
Easy to get pigeon holed in a dead end job
Bad work life balance
It's a who you know not what you know mentality 
No one seems to know how to manage at Cisco, to busy watching their own backs

Pros: Cisco offers equal opportunities to all people, it encourages personal development as well as stretching people to ensure that they achieve not only what is good for Cisco, but also good for the customers and for the individuals.
Cons: Cisco can be very top-heavy politically, there are sometimes overlapping groups that will wrangle for political control of a situation which is not ideal; as an engineer you need to steer clear of the politics and knuckle down.

Pros:
1)  Chance to work with seasoned engineers who are good at what they do.
2)  Large company, relatively stable
3)  Well structured, many support groups SI, DevTest, Diags, EDVT, Mechanical, Manufacturing, etc...
4)  Good benefits, healthcare is best benefit one now.
Cons:
1)  Meetings about meetings
2)  Management's lack of foresight in project planning
3)  Cronyism, Cisco is an amalgam of many smaller businesses, due to acquisitions.  Each group has their own culture and school of thought.  If your group is merged with another group, and your group is not on top, attrition will ensue.
4)  Innovation seems to be mostly due to acquisitions, this company is little r big D.  Do not expect to do anything beyond the mold of the immediate project, unless you are in the upper echelons of the company (DE or Fellow).
5)  A company a recent college graduate should not consider, growth is limited.  A start-up or younger company would be better.
6)  Pay is industry average.  You can do better.
7)  Senior management has mislead the CEO for years.  They indicate the market is moving in a specific direction when it is not.
8)  While age discrimination is not permitted, the management finds ways to make it happen.  Over 60 and chances of being fodder for the headcount reduction increase.
9)  The days seems to flow seamlessly by.  Each day seems more and more like the last.   Before you know it, months of time have passed into the abyss.
10)   Due to stress, people have experience heart trouble.  I have gone though 2 anxiety attacks before the age of 30.  Heart medication is likely to be required by your doctor, should you even be a first line manager.
11)  Cisco is becoming more and more like a Chinese-owned company.
12)  Management has a propensity to not tell the truth.  They have and will continue to mislead the ICs (non-management employees) about their prospects for advancement and the direction the company is going in.

Pros: Work/life balance, excellent people and plentiful talent, still a good culture and values about fair play and caring for people
Cons: An interesting mix of strong hatred of clear goals with accountability, thick red-tape bureaucracy, self-serving senior leadership that has been brought in externally mixed with the wrong sort in power internally

Pros: Lots of opportunities. Enormous customer base. Good perks and salaries. Relatively better than other companies of this size. Still works very closely with customers and therefore provides a great way to learn about actual customer issues from all parts of the organization (if one is in the right organization).
Cons: Big company. Fewer pockets of no-nonsense culture and work focus. Slow moving. Smart folks are leaving since it is no longer the company to work for (was so for about a decade). Lots of duplicated effort which hinders progress. Conflicting Business Unit goals cause misery to all around.

Pros: Smart individual contributors, great use of technology that makes jobs easier and work at home easier, people almost always willing to work with you and help you
Cons: Getting very difficult to be promoted.  Management often better individual contributors than managers.  Numerous layoffs last few years is getting tiresome, and having the executives make excuses for why they do it is even moreso.

Pros:
From a company perspective Cisco is a great company to work for.   Cisco tries to take care of its employees even during staff reductions. 

Each organization are different, some are ran really well while others poor.  Get on a good one you will love Cisco, get on a bad one and you can't wait to find something else.
Cons: Prone to frequent layoffs.   No consistency between projects.

Pros:
Work with some of the smartest individuals in the industry, the projects are challenging and give you the opportunity to lead and drive the technology direction for your customers.
Have been here less than a year, really enjoying working for the team... Hopefully can maintain this review in the years to come.
Cons:
With the latest layoff announcement, people have been put under more pressure to perform (which isn't a bad thing). More project responsibilities have fallen on most people and under the radar to deliver. 
I guess it's understandable when the company is going through drastic change. With the recent changes, the company's outlook looks stronger coming into next year.

Pros: Cisco is a huge company and you can have internal rotations within the company if you are bored of your current role or if you want something more challenging/exciting. Cisco is centrally located in the Bay Area so the commute is not bad from anywhere in the Bay Area. Cisco also offers you flexibility of work hours in most of the organizations.
Cons: Cisco is not the greatest pay-master. The Career growth is cisco is very limited as this is a big company and it takes more than just 'good-work' to go on to the next level.

Pros:
- flexible working hours
- decent benefits
- good place to retire and vest-in-peace if that's what's important
- decent bonuses when times are good.
Cons:
- limited upward mobility
- top-heavy organization, eg. 300+ directors with no direct reports.  Let's get real!
- promotions not necessarily based on merit or accomplishments
- nepotism is rather common
- heavy politics, lack of focus, more talk than walk
- frequent 'limited restructuring' affects the lower ranks first when the problem is elsewhere.
- frequent 'limited restructuring'  -- I think I said that already....never know when you're next.

Pros: Cisco is definetly a great place to grow in your career. Cisco is a very large, global company and there are so many opportunities to either become a deep expert in your area of expertise or broaden your skills and try different roles. The flexibility and remote-working is also highly valued, espcially being a mother!
Cons: Because it is a large company, some things take longer to get started and approved, and there is so much collaboration/buy-in required that it can sometimes really slow down a project.

Pros: This company would hire inexperienced, newly graduated college students, and gives them the chance to choose groups and teams to work with.
Cons: In Cisco, half of people are contributing, and half of others are blocking others from contributing to company. There are various internal wars. Some people survive there well only by complimenting other than contributing. Also, some technical leaders don't qualify for their jobs, and they twist other developers to follow their ideas to earn credits for themselves.

Pros: Cisco is a large company and it's great place to learn and grow your career.  It is a fast moving environment and allows employees to get exposed to different areas of the business.
Cons: Cisco used to be much more entrepreneurial that it is now.  The past few years the company has grown a lot and red tape has taken over.  It is nearly impossible to start new initiatives and the current environment does not support highly creative people.

Pros: Excellent products, very good senior leadership and vision.  Benefits excellent and great pay.
Cons: Some Low & Mid management leaders poorly execute or ignore senior mgmt. vision and there is significant lack of inspection of adherence to directives from the top down.  Quality of work is becoming less important than "working your manager / managing up" which is causing some very valuable team members to go elsewhere.

Pros:
- Tel-commute and flexibility with working hr
- A lot to learn from a big corporate
- Work-Life balance
Cons:
- Too many re-org 3-4 /yr
- Culture of witch hunting 
- Low Salary per market ( but thats gets compensated with the flexibility)
- Biased leadership
- In-spite of all the surveys leadership does not really understand the pulse
- Promotion hard to come by unless you have extremely aggressive and arrogant

Pros: Great team environment, open to provide support and collaboration when needed.  Projects that have to span teams are able to be completed because each group is held accountable for pulling their own weight.
Cons: Lack of transparency from peer reviews regarding promotions.  Feeling the immediate impact of your day to day work in a company this size is not easily noted.  Difficult to implement change.  Process heavy day to day work.

Pros: Great people is the biggest assets.  For an extremely large company Cisco manages to maintain itself as an amazing company dedicated to changing the world - and making a profit.  Lots of engaged people, lots of brand recognition and tons of internal opportunities.  Work flexibility is a huge plus, there is a lot of autonomy and trust within the organization (this could also be a con when abused)
Cons: Seems like the organization is getting fatter at the top, and not enough middle management or growth opportunities.  Because many people have worked there for many years, they can be set in their ways or play favorites.

Pros:
Good company to work for.
Excellent benefits and compensation.
Very flexible with corporate policies and procedures and the culture.
Cons:
As long as the Business Unit is bringing good revenue, you are good.  The moment BU revenue goes  flat or  negative YoY, the jobs will be sent to Low Cost locations.
Some bad elements always look for building empire and better stay away from such BU's and the leaders.

Pros:
Excellent insight into technology, u become master in ur space within few months because I learn via customer issues..ccie attempts etc good perks..

Part of cutting edge technology
Cons:
Work life balance sucks , never expect it to be good. As tac struggles to get equality employees from outside so teams are usually understaffed.
Usually viewed as 2nd grade citizens in Cisco as tac is not product development, so its not a very respected job within Cisco.

U may come across service managers in tac who may make life difficult..

All said pros r more than cons and would definitely recommend for someone in early stages of career..

Pros: Great company and culture. Great benefits and work environment. Most managers are pretty empowering and the culture motivates leaders to encourage innovation, great work and empower their teams. Values are still held closely and there are big changes happening to ensure the company catches up with the changes in the technology industry and with the market transitions. Big changes in the HR function as well to move towards team based leadership and coaching leaders to be effective not as individuals but as team leaders.
Cons: As it is a large organization, one can lose focus and can get lost in the mammoth organization and its dynamics. It is important to have mentors and people who look out for.

Pros: Large company with some talented people and some opportunity if you are in the right place at the right time . Cisco also highly values its corporate culture and identity, and has taken recent strides to create a newer, more modern work culture to the best of its ability.
Cons: Large company with lots of places for un-talented, lazy people to hide. You may also find yourself in the wrong place at the wrong time working for/with the wrong person or people.

Pros: Excellent compensation and benefits. Decent work environment. Generally good training opportunities (although not so great this year.) Excellent benefits, and very nice recent improvements to family leave policies.
Cons: Internal support (e.g. IT support) is a complete train wreck. For your product, expect regulation after regulation after regulation (all internal). A tendency to use low quality internal tools instead of commercial ones. Layoffs, layoffs, layoffs. Except you don't call them layoffs, you call them LRs.

Pros: Go there if you want to Retire after 50.
Cons:
If you thinking that Cisco is company that work in  niche of technology , you are wrong. Specially if you are hired in India.Cisco India is  outsource based of Cisco USA , All New developments and research are done in US and once every thing is done , its transferred to India for Maintance . Whether its Data Centre Product Nexus or Firwall or UCS..

Secondly too many processes that will hinder your producivity..No information Sharing form Seniors..Proprietarty OS wrapper , So arent markettable Outside Cisco and No Pay hike for atleast 4-5 Years ..Normal Promotion Takes 5 Years.

Pros: Excellent pay and benefits, ability to telework, interesting work
Cons: When I first came to Cisco, it was very supportive  environment for employees; not any more.  Unfortunately the new management has focused on the bottom line and forgets it's their PEOPLE that make the difference.  The company says they don't "layoff" people but they do, twice a year.  They treat their contractors terribly promising to hire them after a year or so but then they just let them go for "budget" reasons.  A routine work week is 50-60 hours.  Lots of turnover and constant "reorganizations" for efficiency.  Not a great environment for women; there are exceptional women that work there but certainly not enough opportunities.

Pros:
-Tremendous resources
-Good bonuses
-Good legacy software (IOS)
Cons:
-Very hierarchical company. Higher up you are, the more arrogant you become
-Very political. You have to associate with right group
-Despite being in Silicon Valley, Indian culture dominates the company to the extent that I wouldn't call it an American company. I was in a business unit where even SVP spoke Indian language to his Indian subordinates (VPs and Directors) to discuss official matters in presence of those who didn't understand their language.

Pros: Highly talented people, good benefits and lots of development opportunities for younger employees.
Cons: In Eastern Europe Cisco's senior management team is turning what was once a great, collaborative work environment where diverse opinions mattered into a military organisation where you're managed with a baseball bat and the managers who display the most disregard for people are the ones advancing their careers. Highly political environment (and not in a good way).

Pros: I was part of an acquisition and really came to respect and appreciate the Cisco culture.  In my experience over 5+ years in Supply Chain, the culture was great.  People were always respectful of each other and worked to collaborate and build consensus.   The pay and benefits were very good and the work environment was top-notch.  I know there are many experiences in a large company, but in my case I can say it was 99% positive!
Cons: Cisco is a big company, so the pace of change can be frustrating

Pros:
Freedom to achieve goals - comes with accountability
Real flexible and work from home culture - great for working parents with otherwise long commutes
Encourages new ideas and tries to nurture more innovation than before
Cons:
Cumbersome operations processes, some still antiquated and don't support scalability of marketing operations. 

Still lots of manual admin tasks that take away quality time from really thinking about how to grow the business.

Frequent leadership changes and restructuring - more than can be absorbed effectively

Pros:
Long history of great products and services
Lots of smart people who mostly want to help
Average compensation and Average Benefits
Fast paced and challenging work
Cons:
Takes a long time to get things done - Not what is used to be...
People are hesitant to be responsible and accountable - Not what is used to be...
Slow career path and slower compensation increases - Not what is used to be...
Bureaucracy can make if difficult to get things done - Not what is used to be...

Pros: Very liberal work from home policies. Progressive culture. Extremely easy.
Cons: Everyone pretends to work hard but nobody is fully leveraged. The corporate bloat is so extreme it’s not uncommon to find whole teams idle, doing a few hours of work a week for a year or more. Layoffs are more political than strategic and the realignments happen so much you’ll have several new managers and teams a year and it’s always in the air what team is now supporting what. Constant fear of layoffs is very real and it hurts morale badly. I also think Cisco is not competing product-wise and the stock shows it.

Pros:
- you will get to do everything. server setup, coding, write dirty code if you like because nobody understand it .
- you can test your patience while replying to technical queries which coming from egoistic people
- you will forget all your life problem because you will have only work no life :)
Cons:
- you have finish eveything early so spend day and night working
- employees are mislead about project delivery and they are made to work more than 12 hr 
- coding without learning 
- manager are not much technicle people so technicle people are harrased and wont be able to convience manager about point of view

Pros:
* Great culture to work in, coworkers are friendly and respect each other
