* Challenging and engaging work, good tech stack used (although this would also depend on the team that you are in)
* Company is very employee friendly 
* flexible work hours 
* Compensation is at par with most top companies 
* Good leadership, responsive to employee feedback and suggestions
Cons:
* Haven't found any cons as such. 

Only thing that was sub-satisfactory was that during year end Cisco shutdown , company expects you to use your privileged leave despite it being a shutdown. With only 1.5 leaves credited every month, this can be little upsetting sometimes.

Pros: Good benefits and health plan. Great place to learn and if you are proactive you can move up the ladder.
Cons: With automatic headcount reduction of 5% per quarter its hard to concentrate on the work and not worry about being cut. This makes a cut-throat environment where making others look bad so you look good is a place not to be.

Pros: strong leadership, taking care of all people awesome colleagues Strong "machines", hardly ever lose any deals to competition Superstrong portfolio The midrange of social security benefits
Cons: Salary and benefits are totally out of time, they are still as they were 10 to 15 years ago, so our competition has easy to recruit people from us. You can get like a 50% higher salary when going to any of the competitors.

Pros: It's a good job with good benefits and for a big company - relatively low BS.
Cons:
It's not as fun as a smaller company or startup.  They don't practice what they preach - work from anywhere in the world.  You can work from anywhere in the world - as long as it's San Jose.
The caliber of employee has gone steadily.
Senior management and Directors are WELL taken care of while the people who actually do the work are not.

Pros: Stable and ethical company.  Flexibility with telecommuting, good benefits. Intelligent and passionate colleagues.  Open communication.  Use of technology for communicating and collaborating.  Phenomenal Exec management team.
Cons: A lot of "managing up" and "kicking down" within Cisco at mid levels.  Overt , selfish career ambitions of middle management (Sr Mgr to VP) that drive decisions rather than true business needs. If you are not at least a Dir level you have no "status" and no one pays attention to you, calls you back, or responds to your email.  Severe lack of promotions or career advancement.  The ones who get ahead are those who are best at self promotion, positioning and politicing rather than leading or inspiring.  I am disappointed at the significant number of people who have advanced upwards who are "good at playing the game" but are not "good people".  Way too San Jose centric - remote employees are an after thought at best.  Extreme cliques and a culture of "who you know" to get things done or get ahead.  Inconsistent pay for performance and advancement criteria. Performance reviews are a joke.  Archaic travel process and policy.  Lack of sabbatical for long term employees unless they are at exec level.  Complete under utilization of indiv contributors who have years of experience.  I know at least a dozen women over 50 who were forced out because their "managers" didn't know what to do with them anymore.  Continuted lack of diversity despite years of trying/claiming otherwise. Huge waste of dollars spent on expensive, overpriced consultants and outside services.  Inconsistent workload and hours required to do job between various groups.  Some people are working 80-90 hours per week and others are working 40 hours or less a week.  History of keeping inept midlevel managers by moving them laterally.  Very talented people leave because there is little opportunity for them to succeed if they don't play the political game.

Pros:
Cisco is highly regarded within the industry and by customers so there is a certain amount of professional prestige that goes with the company.

There is a lot of opportunity for professional development, although the amount of actual TIME you are given to pursue it varies by manager. If you have a good manager and a decent territory, then the job can be satisfying, rewarding and fun. Self-starters will enjoy themselves and in some ways working for Cisco feels a lot like being self-employed (especially if you work in a remote location.)

Technical resources for engineers varies widely depending on office location and manager's personal style. If you are in San Jose, Herndon or RTP, then you will have easy access to lab equipment and gear. If you are remote, well, not so much... 

For the larger sites, Cisco offers a well-laid path for supplies, access and availabilty, although getting ahold of the latest and greatest products seems to be very sporadic. (It can be tough to sell the latest product effectively if you have never seen one in person!)
Cons:
Personal experience and job satisfaction will vary widely depending on your location and on your manager. I've worked both at a large office and as a remote employee, and large office is definitely a far better experience. 

Even though Cisco has thousands of remote employees, they are frequently treated as an after-thought.  Mid-level managers do not seem to be trained in dealing with remote employees and many times they act as though "out of sight, out of mind". As a remote worker, my manager should be my main tie to corporate, but I usually got better, faster, more accurate and more complete info from friends who worked in different parts of the company.  

Some managers will authorize time out of the office for training, some will not. Your ability to pursue professional development will depend completely on your current manager. Many managers feel that with the number of virtual courses available, then you should never have to take off for training. There is some merit to this postion, but you can't focus on a virtual course if you are not given the time away from your regular job to "attend" it. 

Every August at the beginning of the fiscal year, Cisco re-organizes. Teams change, the managers change, the focus changes, etc. July is usually a useless month because everyone is holding their collective breath waiting to see how the re-org goes and in August there is always a giant account shuffle. It is completely wasteful. During one five year period I was re-organized four times. At the end of that time, I ended up more or less where I started but my team had a slightly different name. 

The worst part about the annual shuffle is that incoming managers always want to tinker with the structure/focus of their team. As Systems Engineers, we had a technological specialty area that we were supposed to become experts on. Every year, the teams' new manager would change the area assignments. This forced us to set aside our other projects and re-qualify for our new team assignments. There were usually several tests involved and a couple of weeks worth of studying in order to pass them. The upheaval always seemed totally arbitrary and not at all productive.

Cisco does not offer a very good work/life balance. (I doubt that they have ever even heard of the term.) The only time they encourage you to take vacation is when they need to get the hours off of the books for accounting purposes.  I have had managers tell me that they want me to take vacation time, but still work on whatever project I was working on.  Also, I have seen a couple of cases where an employee was hassled by their manager for taking time off to deal with a death in the family (once for the employee's child, once for a parent.)

Nights and weekends are fair game for emails and phone calls. I have had a manager call me at 11 PM, just to "catch up on things". As a remote worker in a different time zone, I have done several conference calls between the hours of 2 AM and 4 AM . (These were not for emergency purposes, these were just for the convenience of the manager.) 

Cisco is definitely a male-oriented company and women face a unique set of challenges. There are almost NO women in management within certain divisions. I was the only woman on my team for years, and it can be a somewhat hostile work-environment. I skipped any "team-building" that took place at Hooters or at strip clubs in Vegas. On one team building event during the sales meeting in Vegas, I asked to be dropped off at my hotel rather than tag along to a Gentlemen's Club . (My manager openly ridiculed me for that in front of the rest of the team.) Going to HR is widely considered to be the kiss of death to your career, so very few complaints are lodged.  I believe this sort of behavior is not tolerated in every part of Cisco because I know women who have transferred out of the division that I worked in and they said it was a different world on the outside.

Pros: You can balance personal life very well with job. Again, it depends on the which group you are working with. You can just plan to work for eight hours a day, rest is yours. Benefits are good compared to other same level of organizations.
Cons: Management is old-school. It is hard to convince the management some times, as they can not see the value in the innovations. For the same reason, management fail to asses/promote good resources

Pros:
Cisco is great for your resume and giving you good experience at how global organizations work. It gives you exposure to a broad customer base, and how each of those work as well. There is a lot to be learned that's both technical and experiential. 

The benefits are (were) great, but now they're dwindling with every cycle. 

There are still a few managers who DO care, but you may have to dig to find one during your career. 

Salary is (was) great, but buying power is dwindling with the lack of merit/COLA increases. 

If you're customer-facing there is still a good deal of job security. If you're in IT or development, not-so-much, offshoring is the name of the game. 

For a really big company, it really is one of the better one's out there. 

Some of the serious technology plays have a good chance at being highly successful and keeping Cisco on top of the industry pack.
Cons:
Leadership team members have lost touch with reality, and are primarily drinking the Kool-Aid. They communicate the direction to Sr Management and line-management, and those managers are then forced to try and take an untenable vision/strategy and execute upon it. How well they can balance reality with fantasy determines how well you, as an individual contributor will do. 

In the ancient past, if you chose to bring up a serious weakness of a product/service you were considered to be contributing to the success of the team, now if you are outspoken you are not a team player. Empowerment is now non-exsistent. Mediocrity is becoming the norm, and those that want to excel are starting to look outside the doors of Cisco now that the Golden Handcuffs (stocks/bonus/benefits) are evaporating. 

The EPM (employee review) cycle is a joke and your reviews are strictly based on your manager and his/her ability to 'fight' for you at leadership ratings/ranking meetings. 
Have a passive manager who doesn't like a good fight or has someone else they're solely rooting for? You'll not get that strong E+ or X rating to get that promotion or salary increase. Period. 
If you have a passionate manager that cares for his/her people, then they can eventually "spread some love around" to you, but chances are it will take a few cycles. 

A note to prospective employees: Once your inside, if you plan on sticking around, shop for those managers... If you can find one that's good with people, technically sharp, and somewhat politically savvy at the same time you might be able to also get some promotions along the way as he/she rides the wave upward. You need to use your skills/merit to leverage yourself into an org that will allow you to play this game, then you can be promoted. This skill took me a long time to learn, but it's a good one to learn, since it doesn't just apply here as Cisco is just like any other big company now. 

And yes: negotiate a high starting salary - you may not see an increase for some time.

Pros: Customers that work with you respect you because you work for a power house company like cisco, and the work is usually engaging, but promotions seem achievable only if you leave the company, or leave the group.
Cons: Was recently passed up on a promotion because i don't kiss butt enough.  manager told me to get out there and meet and talk to people, but how can you when you are pigeon holed in your job and cubicle day after day

Pros: Excellent flexibility. There's a very thin line of difference between work and life. You get a chance to pursue your interest. There's no micro-management. You have full freedom. You have lot of opportunities to move internally and work with different team/technology.
Cons: Some teams/technology is really saturated. As a result if you get into such teams, you won't be really able to enjoy your work. However, if you want to be very "light" at work with minimal learning/progress, you might like it. It will be more like enjoying retired your life. You need not have to work !!

Pros: Flexible work schedule, job rotations, many areas to specialize in, job stability, smart people. Good company culture,
Cons: Corporate politics, many layers of middle management, minimal opportunities for career advancement once you reach a certain point since many people are competing to crack into management level. continually reducing head count and increasing workloads. Some people are impossible to please, and that goes through many teams and many layers of management. Appearances of doing good work, doing more work, working long hours are more respected then well thought out ideas.

Pros: Endless possibilities.  You truly create your own destiny.  Smart people with a very flexible schedule.  As long as you deliver quality results you can work remotely and maintain a very flexible schedule.
Cons: Very fast paced.  You need to be set boundaries or you will end up working around the clock.  You need to have a contract with your leadership team and be clear about what you will do and won't do.  If you can come to an agreement on that, you will have a fantastic time working at Cisco.

Pros:
Great culture. World leader, good learning opportunities, wonderful peers.
In terms of taking care of the employees, Cisco does a lot more than other employers
Cons: Size of the organization is increasing in India, which means, most of the times, the great culture and learning opportunities are negated by getting stuck in the wrong team, doing worthless work. Internal transfers are not as easy as it is talked of, still better than other employers. Yet, having a manager who looks at his own interests will ensure you dont move around easily.

Pros:
(1) Flexible working arrangements
(2) Empowerment to all levels
(3) Open and encouraging environment: Anything is possible
(4) Great collaboration and team work
Cons:
(1) As with other US MNCs, Cisco starting to hire and fire people
(2) While we see cost cutting measures eg moving office out of expensive rental and multiple rounds of restructuring being executed, there are some strange practises such as introducing additional allowances to senior executives and increase travel.
(3) Lack of appropriate support/backup during vacation/hospital leave
(4) US eccentric-Worldwide teams need to be more holistic when introducing policies and programs.

Pros: Lots of empowerment at the grass roots level. Easier to move horizontally than most companies. Traditionally able to accurately see market transitions/inflection points. Culture of "giving back." Strong brand image. Credible vision for the future of IT and the network.
Cons: Innovation in jeopardy. Frugality making people risk-averse and not invested for long term. Loss of personal touch within bureaucracy. Sea change anticipated for our business, markets, and operations.

Pros: The people who work as Cisco are very professional, proactive and fun to work with.  The health benefits are great and a great place to get as much training as one can absorb and still get work done.
Cons: The processes for getting hardware projects from concept phase to First Customer Ship (FSC) have gotten more complicated and cumbersome.  Salaries were frozen, bonus were far in between and stock options are not very valuable as stock price has not increased past $30 a share since 2000.

Pros: WORK LIFE BALANCE (Routine jobs & restricted job responsibility to high quality employee result in lot of free time)
Cons:
Systems & Processes are not aligned, Multiple systems created in silos & they dont talk to each other

Quality of Work is poor at country level, maybe good at HQ

Inflexible HR policy, Bad Gross to Net take home ratio

No ONE Finance approach

Finance treated as support function & not business partner/ advisory.. you know what i mean !

Pros: Work life balance is awesome. Most of your job is mobile, especially since the acquisition of Webex, so it allows you to create your own schedule around your customer's schedules. Awesome employees in most areas.
Cons: It is not a well-oiled machine and sometimes feels like you're working within the US gov't in trying to get issues pushed through. Not easy to move unless it's horizontal. Internal system consists of job levels and applying for something above your job grade, even if you're qualified, is almost always a no go.

Pros:
Name recognition. 
At corporate level they have tons of money to spend on little things here and there to cheer you up.
Lots of PTO days.
Cons: Despite the appearance, there are racial preferences. There are managers who outright admit to it.

Pros:
* decent salary for the region
* good benefits
* many technology areas to branch in to
Cons:
* they are off shoring many positions to India and China
* work / life balance often gets out of skew
* seem hypocritical: Mr Chambers presented a video calling for employees to remain loyal to the company, that if we stay with Cisco we can proudly tell our grandchildren that we were not Bay Area mercenaries running to the biggest salary -- and yet Cisco regularly (once every 1-2 years) lays of large numbers of employees. And they aren't the bottom 5% as often advertised.

Pros: If you like to learn and push the envelope with technology, then Cisco is the place. If you are a temp and provide good work then your chances of becoming an FTE are great. Just an overall great place.. 6 years plus in the making..
Cons: I really have no Cons, except that make sure you hit your salary target when hired. when you move internally to a new job, it is very rare to have a grade bump. MAKE SURE YOU ARE OK WITH THE SALARY FOR AT LEAST 3 Years..

Pros:
friendly environment between management and employees
flexible work option.
nice perks
Cons:
Recruitment is very strange.
Don't give importance to CCIEs, which is its own certification.
Funny thing is people with less experience and less technical knowledge are hired and paid hefty pacages, i remember one of my collegue who doesn't know simple techinical stuff like OSPF were given offers of 26+ lacs..whereas talented techies are not even given a chance to attend a interview..No wonder why cisco is not performing well recently

Pros: great benefits, work life balance, love the CEO, in a great place in the market.  whats not to love?
Cons: not many cons.  i'm in finance, so i don't see the stress of the TS employees or delivery.  the work is HARD, but engaging and a great development opportunity.

Pros: Opportunity to have work/life balance, work from home, and ability to volunteer a lot of community hours.
Cons: The upper management is not great. A few managers I know treated their subordinates like children. It's really about who your manager is. If you have a great manager try to stay with them although it's hard as managers get changed all the time. I've had 4 different managers within the last year. I had to explain my role to each one every time.

Pros: Cisco placed a great deal of value on its culture. There has been massive change at the company in recent years, and whether the company will be able to re-create that amazing culture that it had for so many years, is still TBD.
Cons:
Huge turn over in recent years. It might be a good thing for the company longer-term, but with so much change comes challenges. 

I think Cisco needs to focus on developing better people managers. That goes hand-in-hand with a great culture and that is where I think they lost their way in recent years.

Pros: Top Flexibility, okay pay (below avg)
Cons: Culture Politics Determines What You Work On. Especially if you are a minority (not Indian or White), there seem to be cultural "cliques" that play into favorability. In addition, Cisco's political neutrality generates a lack of culture, particularly for younger employees seeking companies that stand for something

Pros: Collaboration and strong team drive with opportunities to engage with customer stakeholders to drive adoption and expansion of key products and services. Cisco is in a leadership position in terms of CuSM program, tools and process. Cisco is an excellent employer who cares about employees and is very fair in terms of compensation, training, benefits and growth opportunities.
Cons: Cisco is in process of transition from a traditional HW player to a SW player, so there is a lot of change, but CuSM role is positioned well for Cisco in the future, especially in SW.

Pros:
The people and the culture! Cisco looks after employees' wellness and  work life balance.  In my role, I am able to work with very diverse, fun and smart people on a daily basis. 

Access to fantastic technology also brings the already flexible work environment to the next level. We can stay connected anywhere without feeling any real difference whichever location you are in, may it be in one of the colorful couches or rooms in the office or at the comfort of your own home.
Cons: Not really a con... Office location in some countries are not centrally located (but then again this is subjective as to where I am staying).

Pros: Cisco was a great place to work if you are into networking because of the dominant position in the market place.  Cisco also has dominated markets such as communication and collaboration.  They have grown and innovated through multiple acquisition which brought in top talent and technology.
Cons: Recently, Cisco seems to have lost its ability to bring in and retain top management talent.  In addition, management practices which emphasize top down decision making thrives at Cisco.  There is also a move to let go of older employees despite high performance.

Pros:
4 months bootcamp to deeply understand Cisco' culture, solutions and strategy.
High quality training for both soft and technical skills. Different courses given by worldclass experts through visioconference or physically at your office.
Huge community of CSAP Alumni (over 2000 currently working at Cisco) that gives you a very large network inside the company.
8 months as Account Manager in shadowing to practice what you've learnt during the bootcamp. Ideal to know your strenghs and things you have to work on. Peering with a senior account manager that will give you tips to crush your quota at the end of the CSAP year.
Cons: International travel to share experience/best practices with others CSAP Hub.

Pros:
I have been with Cisco as a campus hire for almost 2 years now. Didn't feel like the company is fit for freshers, but good and manageable if you really want to purse in networking domain. This review is a bit biased since I have only seen Networking devices business of the company and not other businesses like Collaboration, Security, Cloud etc

- Company culture is good. Not toxic or work obsessed.
- Some good work in selected teams and projects (May be 5% of total teams).
- Very employee friendly in terms for PTOs, WFHs, Maternity/Paternity leaves etc.
- Good work life balance.
- Less workload in most teams (depends on project or releases)
- Code reviews usually make you a good progammer but it depends on the attitude of the reviewers.
- Managers are mostly good and friendly.
- Healthy food in cafeterias
- Very good office environment and infrastructure.
- You will have enough time to purse your hobbies or interests outside/inside work.
- Good gyms and games facilities.

Heard good things about other businesses under Cisco but don't have first hand knowledge of it. New projects, young technologies etc might be good.
Cons:
In general, not good for people who want to grow in their career. All the points are from the eyes of a fresher.

- Work is mostly sustenance of legacy code and occasional feature addition.
- Less learning opportunities.
- Process oriented. Very difficult to get things done. Coding is only 10% of actual process to get the code or bug in.
- Most of the good work is usually done in US and is moved to India for sustenance or continuation after success.
- Pay is not competitive. They try to give the minimum possible to make employee stay.
- US or abroad folks see India as cheap labor market and have this attitude is few occasions.
- Many senior folks stay because they can't go elsewhere to get this good treatment at this stage of their career.
- Many has become used to this slow environment and don't want to change anything other than getting more money.
- Managers are bit obsessed about metrics like bug count, bug incoming, customer bug count etc but not about the product as a whole since it has grown so large for its own good.
- Difficult for a fresher to get up to speed and start contributing since there are no proper documentations for old code.
- Mentoring may not always be a feasible/effective idea since there is lot of history/legacy reasons associated with everything.
- Hike cycle has been every bad in my experience. They postpone 6 months to 1 yr to give hikes and state lame reasons. When they do give, its not up to expectations or market rates.
- They hardly give any stocks to non senior folks as rewards.
- Promotions are given for good performers but management considers experience as the biggest factor for grade change. Hence, it is nearly impossible to get promoted in 1 or 2 yr even if you perform exceptionally. 
- Company is so big, you wont get any visibility more than 2 levels in most caseses. (i am 7 or 8 levels down)
- Less breadth of work to really show your talents. You will get used to the slow moving environment and loose the enthusiasm especially when you are a fresher.

Pros:
1. Work life balance 
2. Work on latest trends in networking industry 
3. Flexible work policy
Cons:
1. Very bad insurance policy (You don't believe cisco just think now days as take it if u need like that , even small companies will give a better insurance plan for you, you just spend 3-4 hr weekly to followup if u have claims ) 
2. Not a place to learn for fresher (you will just learn people management , not the tech ) 
3. Mostly work independently and team bonding is very less

Pros: People are treated like they are family. Lots of opportunities, great work/life balance and support from co-workers and management when times are tough, or even when you just need to spend time with your family. Great salaries and benefits, discounts, savings plans, great use of leading edge technology, ability to work from home without being penalized. Amazing leadership by extremely smart people. Great opportunity to learn and be challenged.
Cons: While working remotely is mostly encouraged, there are fewer and fewer opportunities for leadership outside of the main San Jose campus.

Pros: In Cisco, Employees are well respected and treated. Cisco has an open, inclusive culture. Work and life can be well balanced. Senior managment promotes and practice an open transparent communication and employees are kept informed on company's strategy and direction. Overall, cisco is a good place to work.
Cons: It is too big, and too slow for you to move if you want a fast pace. Individual's contribution doesn't matter that much in such a giant company, which means the contribution may not be recognized properly. Cisco Systems might be a Good Place to work, but not a great company any more.

Pros:
Great salary when compared against other companies' internship programs.

If you're working at the San Jose campus, you'll find many other college students scattered across the campus, as Cisco hires students from a variety of universities across the country. As other reviews have mentioned, the new hire program offers opportunities to meet with your peers.

You will be working on pertinent projects with full-time employees, doing the same [if not similar] things they're doing. If your team is busy, you'll be busy too.

There's an "open-door" culture at work - if you have questions or concerns, you are free to bring it up to your manager or co-workers. Many of them are more than willing to help you learn and contribute while you're here.
Cons:
If you're not a local, relocating to San Jose can be confusing. Although Cisco offers relocation compensation, it'll be up to you to find a place to live for the next 3 to 6 months. "Corporate housing" is not offered for interns and co-ops. However, the Silicon Valley area has seen so many interns/temps that many neighborhoods/apartments offer short-term or month-to-month leases.

This might not seem like a "con" (especially if you're a college student), but if your team needs you to stay until midnight to get something done, expect to do so (and expect overtime pay as well).

Despite my short stay, I have definitely caught a whiff of the stagnating bureaucracy that can drive you, your project, and your co-workers nuts. But I suppose this is what happens in a "big company."

Pros: Overall great team spirit, result oriented flexible hours usually, professional environment of respect and trust, mobile working opportunities, reasonable benefits
Cons: some teams are bounded by the old working from office mindset than the coporate mobile work culture; also not too many functions and job roles available within HK office.  Also some started behaving in a more bureaucratic manner

Pros: Great work/life balance, excellent benefits, challenging opportunities.  Internal job rotation is getting better, used to be frowned upon in some groups.  Great systems and internal tools to get information.
Cons: Limited career development opportunities.  Unless you are a rising start, it's difficult to move upward.  As the company is getting larger, it's difficult to get things done - too much beaurocracy.  Managers are too busy to help, many times you will be on your own with limited support.  Not much social interaction, groups and teams are very silod.

Pros:
Nice Gym.
Nice intranet.
Nice heath center
Cons:
A lot of management layers, tons of managers, VP, senior VP, GM..
You are supposed to work on weekend, night time by paying yourself boardband. Totally lose you life. 
Ranking system makes everyone is your enemy, not going to share information and complete/trap each other. Your rank is totally based on your manager taste.
No career growth. No inflation adjustment and no raise.
Current layoff and outsource all USA jobs to India.

Pros: Cisco in the Middle East is very dynamic with a lot happening and amazing growth. We are working on many interesting projects and initiatives and we are way ahead of our competition thanks to our investment in the region and coverage.
Cons: Working in an ever changing environment can be tough due to the unknown. Pressure is extremely high within Cisco Middl East and a lot of the time this pressure is unjustified. Management are focused on growth, growth, growth.

Pros: Large company, many products, lots of opportunities and innovation. You could easily spend a lifetime at Cisco and never run out of challenges.
Cons: Product teams have a lot of leeway and don't necessarily hire designers. This can lead to an uncoordinated mass of multiple design directions, many driven by non-designers, throughout the company. More strength should be given to central design teams, and more teams should hire designers.

Pros:
Flexibility
Great benefits - very generous
Many smart people
Cons:
Cisco is it's own worst enemy ... it is a caring environment that takes feelings way too far.  People are quite gossipy and can be down right cruel in the rumors they spread. 
Buyer beware - Cisco will do "backdoor" reference checks on you!!
Be prepared to work extremely hard with little career growth ... career movement is extremely limited.  It's not the norm to be allowed to move across functions or departments.

Pros:
Access to great technologies and information on everything.
Financial stability.
High level resources in specific teams.
Benefits are very good compared to other local companies
Cons: Running business on excel spreadsheets. Thinking web pages are actual tools instead of access points. Inefficiencies are extremely high which explains why the margins need to be above 80% so that all that overhead can easily be hidden. Example: change orders take several weeks instead of minutes or hours.

Pros:
Work life balance.
Work from home is appreciated.
If you get in a good group, chances of getting nice work are lot.
No disparity between US and India teams.
Great place to work if you dont have any professional ambition left. Just come and work get a salary below par.
Cons:
Salaries are not at all at par.
HR and Management does not care about iteration.
Vision and focus is lost as most good people have left or stopped caring.
It is becoming more of a service company, innovation is loosing slowly.

Pros: Work from home options are prevalent in many teams, and are a great benefit. There is a culture of "work-life" balance, and most (but not all) managers recognize that. It's a fast-paced and sometimes fun place to work, again, in the right team and under the right manager.
Cons: Is hard to know "how" to get to the next level for promotion or pay raise. The goal you are given is to "perform at the next level so that you can be promoted there", but then, there is no definition of what that next level is.

Pros: Cisco has a special opportunity for college new hires called the Cisco Choice Program.  This program allows new hires to actually interview the business units they would like to work for, then select the one they are most interested in.  Through this experience, Cisco gives it's new hires the opportunity to match their passions and talents with a known business need which leads to maximum employee effectiveness.
Cons: You never know when there might be a corporate wide restructuring and you'll get a new manager!

Pros:
- Each can get as much work as he is willing, comfortable and capable of taking up.
- No work pressure.
- Very good work life balance.
- Very flexible (Work From Home, flexible timings of work hours, etc.)
Cons:
- Time based promotion pattern. Need to spend a fixed amount of time at a grade irrespective of how well you perform before you are eligible for a promotion.
- Slow growth.
- Most quality work is done in the HQ at San Jose.

Pros: Cutting edge technology, great teammates, involved management, and opportunities to advance in career. You can get as much out of working here as you are willing to invest into it and there are many people to connect with along the way.
Cons: The company tries to measure everything, and I mean everything that you do. Some things are not quantifiable but that does not stop Cisco from trying. Some of it brings value and insight but some of it seems futile and redundant.

Pros:
Outstanding product portfolio
Significant presence in the IT market
Client credibility
Global operational capability
Internal resource pool
Financial rewards
London office location
Calibre of most of the service delivery personnel
Cons:
Complex internal systems
Quality of management not as high as one would expect
Compared to other IT companies there is little opportunity for personal development
Legacy approach to support services is archaic
Services product portfolio and supporting tools are far to complex.  Cisco tries to fit what they have to meet the client needs rather than build exactly what the client wants.

Pros: Advanced thought leadership on technical evolution in the future, and acquiring/developing the products based on strategic directions. Strong leadership on technology gives good influence to the customer and business.
Cons: Many overlapping organizational architecture from continous acquiring of companies which makes ambiguous roles among different teams. People tends to leave responsibility to another team or people for the problematic situation, but wants to put their name on the good business deals/successful orders. Company brand name still do the work for the business, but customer technical support or business relationship mostly rely on partners.

Pros:
Work/Life Balance is good
Ability to work from home when needed or desired
Mostly good people
Funding is usually available for professional development
I've been able to travel and see some really cool places 
Great tools (computers, IP phones, software)
Cons:
Cisco still uses a forced distribution for performance ratings (bell curve).  There is more focus on increasing your "visibility" and building your "personal brand" aka behind-kissing than the value of your actual work.  I've seen people work their tails off year after year and still receive a mediocre rating (I've been an Individual Contributor AND a manager, so I've seen this from both angles).  Managers don't have the final say in an individual's performance rating anymore.  That is left up to the leadership team within their organization (they do submit a recommendation).  The final decision is made whether or not they've "heard" of this individual's work.  Seriously.  This absolutely equates to a culture of fear, distrust and non-collaboration.  I've seen this personally multiple times.  People are working for their rating vs. working for Cisco.  It's an incredible way to make your employees non-productive.  

It just feels like a sinking ship.  After nearly 10 years, I have very little confidence in the Operating Committee or senior leadership within my own organization to turn things around.  The cycle here is Q1=re-org/layoff   Q2= finally figure out what your new role/team should be doing  Q3=your team actually starts performing  Q4=great performance, but word of a new re-org rolls in, layoff rumors start, productivity goes down the toilet.  It's a cycle I've seen year after year and quite frankly, it's getting old.  Morale is in the toilet, people are just doing what they have to to get by until they find a new job.  They talk about innovation and moving the business forward, but how can you do that when you are CONSTANTLY re-orging people, roles, etc.?

Pros: I like how my colleagues are down-to-earth, in a real way. I interviewed with hot industry names and was really put-off by the arrogance of the people I've met. The work-life balance is also very good. The compensation is competitive with most of the top names in the market. Also, management is experienced and good to learn from.
Cons: It's an older culture. People are not very driven. The company isn't really innovating. The benefits are good, not amazing - the ESPP program, for example, is pretty good for a corporate.

Pros: Nice campus, facillities etc. Brand name.
Cons: political battleground; not a place for a productive software engineer who wants to work sincerely and get work done. Just a battleground for political managers and directors (dime a dozen) who want to bask in their own ego, save their own job somehow and try to act like they influence a lot of things - while the reality is that all decisions get taken from San Jose and get percolated through. It is like a big boys club at all times. Many first line and second line managers are worthless.

Pros:
I find this best company to work for, it is process based, systematic and well cultured company. Cool staff, good salary, bonus and other benefits.
Medical insurance and medical check-up every year. 
Outing quarterly, bonus twice in an year. 
Very good for learning too, you can do your work with proper planning and under guidance of some talented architects. Other than your work you can attend their training programs which are conducted almost every month on hot technologies.
Cons:
Hike is not that good, after 2 year you will find yourself on almost same salary unless you are promoted. 
other than this I don't see any cons.

Pros: The Cisco GVS organization is so far the best, most challenging and pleasant environment I've worked in over my 20 year career. Sharp, accessible leadership. Clear, concise goals and targets. Excellent talent acquisition and retention made for me leading the best sales teams I've had. Compensation and environment are exemplary. I can't recommend Cisco GVS enough.
Cons: The main con comes with being a part of such a behemoth of a company. At times, it does seem like all your efforts amount to being a small cog in a very large machine. Par for the course with a company this size.

Pros: Decent salary, decent perks & bennies, occasional fun events.
Cons: Top-down sweatshop mentality; "The beatings (or layoffs) will continue until morale improves." Sadly, the latest iteration of the  upper management regime is even further out of touch with those who do the work than the previous shot-callers. Same mixed messages as has become the norm for Cisco; previous CEO quoted as saying how much he cares about the workers the same week the company posts a record profit then turns around and lays off 6 thousand people. My amateur psychiatric diagnosis: this company is suffering from a serious personality disorder.

Pros: Technology leader; industry bellwether; sophisticated internal tools and systems for support; amazing team of people ready to cooperated and collaborate; great customer base.
Cons:
Many acquisitions facilitating confusion.
Constantly changing strategies and company goals.
Sales tactics too focused on quotas, rather than customer requirements.
Outsourcing too much to India-based partners who are good people and hard workers, but offer Cisco cheap labor using inexperienced partially qualified labor.
Advancement based on personal network, rather than performance.
Many (non-technical) employees (Program Managers, Marketing, Sales, etc.)  are decent people with good intentions, but are unqualified and lack relevant experience with technology.

Pros:
- Great challenging work and a whole load of learning opportunities. Real job satisfaction, at the end of the day. 
- Fantastic recognition program from peers and managers. 
- Open culture and a very mature Agile practice, where the team "owns" and delivers. Managers are really facilitators.
- Opportunities to present and seek feedback from end customers, as part of sprint demos. Quick feedback for work that you've just completed.
- Easy work from home option for dealing with contingencies.
- Pretty good compensation to go along with all of that. :-)
Cons: None that comes to mind.

Pros:
I have been with Cisco for almost 6 years and it is extremely hard to imagine working for a different employer.  

What I appreciate: 

- Being trusted and independent - no unnecessary control or hand-holding 
- Unparalleled flexibility - remote work, flexible hours 
- Great Culture of equality 
- Biggest Cisco strength is it's People 
- Good benefits and salary
Cons:
- Due to global working environment, you can expect some meetings with people in different time zones, which can mean either late hours, or very early hours
- You have to be proactive with searching for training offerings - no one will find them for you and sing you up

Pros:
The new head of HR, Fran, has made some positive changes which are well appreciated, including closing the gender pay gap, inclusion and diversity training, getting to take the day off on your birthday, and taking up to a week off to do charity work.

Other people say Cisco has good work life balance. I think it depends on what product you are working on. I feel like I am under a lot of stress generally and put in a lot of hours. I have been at Cisco over 10 years and there haven't been a lot of breaks. 

Many of my coworkers work from home at least a couple days a week, especially after they moved us to an open floor plan.

The people I work with are for the most part friendly, smart and professional.

I love making killer products that make billions of dollars of revenue each year.

I learn new things constantly and feel challenged.
Cons:
At least in engineering, there is not a supportive environment for women. There is lack of education among the first line managers how to promote respect and give air time to all type of people, and to promote, give opportunities, listen to and value the ideas of  women. And there is some blatant sexism. For example, when I had my baby, my manager told me the 'right' thing to do was to become a stay at home mom. And despite  making a sacrificial effort to perform well my first year with a baby, my manager said he gave me an average rating because I had a baby. His perception was colored by my being  a mother. I thought I deserved a higher rating for an exceptional year. And he asked me what are my priorities, my child or my job? He didn't ask my male coworkers this question. Even now, he 'forgets' to give me a bonus even though he gave every other report of his one (who are all male). In the previous two layoffs, the only persons he laid off were women. He asks me to plan the fun group outings, not my male colleagues. On separate occasions, my director and my VP asked me to take minutes when there were plenty of men available to also take minutes. Many of my female coworkers moved on because of the frustration of not having their opinions valued as much as our male coworkers. It's a tough problem to solve because people come to Cisco from many types of backgrounds, but I feel there is no management support from any level of the management chain except for Chuck and his direct reports. 

Open space floorplan is distracting visually and audially. The space is so tight that the moveable whiteboards are not near our desks.

Currently, morale is a little down because it is not clear how individuals will be engaged in making the future roadmap happen. People fear for their jobs. We've had repeated layoffs in my group, and there will be more to come.

Pros:
Work life Balance
Benifits like perks
Food option
Purses
Medical insurance
Cons:
No Pay hike from 2 years
company is doing good ,but profits are shared with employees
No matter how much hard work you do, management always say they donot have receive budget 

Only 34 % of employees recieved hike and that also 4 to 6 percent after 2 years.
I would highly discourage anyone to join this organization , they not at all care about there employees. All the upper management reap the profit

Pros:
Some of the smartest people I have had a chance to work with in my 30 years in the working world.  
Empower you to excel and grow both personally and professionally.
Team building runs throughout the company.
Excellent compensation and benefits programs.
To me, the biggest pro is Cisco itself - we are changing the world through technology.
Cons: Lots of reorganizations, senior leadership changes, and a few acquisition slips - but we keep moving forward, so not as much of a con as the way of the tech world working for a company that is leading the way

Pros:
* Excellent company culture - everyone is extremely (and genuinely) friendly
* Technical aptitude of coworkers is second to none - you will learn something new every single day working here.
* Benefits are great, especially for blue badges (full time employees)
* On-site gym and health center is extremely convenient
* Somewhat flexible WFH arrangements, depending on team, job role and manager permission
* It is extremely easy to find an expert or answer for any question you may have - networking with people is almost more important than the networking technology.
* Three different on-site cafes (in RTP) have amazing food and are very convenient, but a bit overpriced. Lines are extremely long at opening, and they've done nothing to reduce lines/increase capacity/better manage the flow of people.
* Campus is beautiful and well-maintained. Improvements to the buildings, indoor and out, are a refreshing change.
* Volunteer opportunities are everywhere, with 40 hours of paid volunteer time off.
* Paid certifications and training are awesome and allow you to advance your skills, but are hard to take advantage of when the teams are so small/overworked.
* Senior management doesn't feel like they are too good to talk to you, even if it's just in the break room, but they are pretty hard to get a one-on-one with.
Cons:
* Advancement is slow and dependent on arbitrary metrics that workers have no visibility into
* I've been in my position 2 years without a single formal review of my abilities.
* The politics are absurd at times - you have to worry about hurting peoples' feelings, as Cisco is very "feel-good". 
* Upper management throws around tons of buzzwords but seems to be completely disconnected from the struggles of the troops on the ground. This may be true of all large companies, though.
* Cisco is "open", but unless you've been there 10-15 years and have no fear of losing your job, most people will not raise the questions/concerns they have in open/public forums.
* "Escalations" are absurd - everyone is quick to CC the next highest manager, and everyone gets in a tizzy over incidents, but nothing changes. It's cyclical. 
* There are lots of employee-lead organizations, but unless you're in a non-technical role (sales, marketing, HR, finance), you really don't have time to join them, especially when you are expected to work after-hours and weekends.
* Cisco severely underpays its' workers, which is why turnover is so high.

Pros: For my time at Cisco, I continue to recommit to the values we hold on hight. Kindness to all being the main one. Exhibited in 1000 different ways, around every corner, message, and action. Cisco is the ultimate company not just as a place to work but as a place to advance humanity globally.
Cons: Like all companies, there is a range of experiences occurring for our people. When you lean into our principles, expectations, and live our mission, vision, and commitment you yield the ultimate experience. If you do not, then you will not be as satisfied.

Pros:
great executive leadership from a culture perspective. 
Great company to have kids (i did, and I was so happy to have done so). 
Great growth opportunities internally
Cons:
products live that shouldn't, investment strategies don't encourage building new products to solve problems - they'd rather make acquisitions and make many safe moves vs taking bold risks to innovate/solve things for customers. 
Products seem point to point, more investment is being made in this area though.

Pros: Company stock, Flexible working, Graduate friendly, Good starting company,
Cons: Likely to work 6 days a week without compensation, hard work never gets rewarded only blue eyed employees get the fruits, ruthless managers putting up fake smiles and fake characters, no one cares about the product, the company or the poor customer using Cisco products. This is one place where hard work never gets rewarded, work for 6 days a week 18 hours a day and still get abused by managers. HR doesnt do much so dont bother trying them.

Pros: The company has an overwhelming market share and influence in the network equipment market, and a stable revenue base. The company has a straightforward strategy to grow by expanding its portfolio in areas with high synergy with its network.
Cons:
Cisco's business is basically infrastructure, and although we are also focusing on Webex and Security, our sales volume is infrastructure.
Cisco's business is basically infrastructure.
If it does not grow, Sales will be forced into a very difficult situation.
If you are looking for a new job, you will need to have a good understanding of infrastructure.
I'm not sure if this is a good idea or not.

Pros:
Great worklife balance and team culture.
Lots of benefits and flexible working hours.
Best in class office infrastructure.
Cons: No decent salary hikes or reward for working hard. It doesn't matter how much you contribute to the team , in the end you will get average hike citing the reason "lack of budget" . The time you stay with the company defines how severely underpaid you are compared to other product based companies in the industry. Lot of higher level management politics with frequent reorgs along with directional changes. Average work and code quality as most of the good engineers leave as early as possible for better opportunities outside.

Pros: Allow you to work from home, great benefits package, flexible hours and locations. In particular, as a single mom working from home allows me to still spend time with my daughter and interact heavily with my nanny to ensure my daughter is being raised right. I also like the opportunities under my current management chain for growth and success.
Cons: Competitive environment, high expectations, travel, long hours. These are rare compared to the everyday benefits though.

Pros: Cisco has a great reputation in the industry and is well-respected. The company tends to treat its employees generally well, and provides them with the resources to maintain, or start career-enhancing training
Cons: The management structure is quite ossified and bureaucratic. Promotions and career progression can be quite difficult to obtain, and the process can seem arbitrary. Projects can live or die based on political reasons, and one has to be careful in understanding the political landscape when working with, and trying to extract from, cross-functional teams. Failure to do so can result in bruised egos and more serious repercussions.

Pros: Lots of opportunities to learn new things and meet people with wide range of interests, Learn about cutting edge technologies (Cisco is market leader in many of these industries), Professional growth opportunities (training, classes, conferences), Rewarded for patent ideas, People are very smart and driven, Business units have team events/socials/celebrations to boost morale, Security of a big company with many resources, Open to new ideas/work styles that are collaborative workpaces, Down-to-earth culture, Pretty good food, Great location in CA, Good relocation package, Can meet lots of interesting people as an intern
Cons: Hard to move up the ladder, Hard to know what is going on in other aspects of the business

Pros: technology, relevance to the industry. You can add cisco to your resume and become a hot commodity any where in the technology industry (assuming that you are good). I consider my time at cisco more as a career builder than as a job.
Cons: lot of waste of resources, ineffective senior management, peter principle's manifestation at its best. Your reviews are not very objective.. and then the mindset of entitlement from least productive dinosaurs!

Pros: I started working for Cisco thinking that this is the company that I wanted to retire with. It had the name and the market share to prove. The reputation of treating employees fairly and rewarding them based on performance was also high on my list.
Cons: During the bad times, the true Cisco came to light. Bad Managers were promoted. Wrong decisions were taken and good people either were let go or simply resigned, like myself.

Pros: Cisco Systems is a big brand and has an amazing culture. The flexible timings, working from home option and less work burden makes it an idle place to maintain a work-life balance. Though it doesn't have much additional benefits (perks) but the campus is amazing and I really enjoyed my stay there.
Cons: Since Cisco is a big company, the growth opportunities are very less. The review cycle is not very effective and the overall salary and other benefits are comparatively low.

Pros: Big Company/many opportunities. Very flexible work schedule. Good package.
Cons: No much diversity, too many people coming from same Country. Too many people with same (old) mindset. No much willingness in to experiment new things. Many people are laid back. Many people are not committed to their work. Many and many talents have recently left the company. Management professionality is not always high.

Pros:
Work life balance
Average people so opportunities to stand out
Stable job

For people want to have laid back job with work life balance it could be good place to be. But not a job where one could learn lots of new things unless you learn on your own.
Cons:
Pass the buck attitude with most of the employees
Not much learning as everyday work is mostly maintenance and fixing unreadable/bad old code
Low pay

Most of time will be spent on deciding who's work it is as people are good at passing buck around. Being proactive and taking up more responsibilities can fire back with more work with little or no recognition.

Pros:
-- Work Culture is great. 
-- Management is very supportive for your learning individual as well as business growth. 
-- Discussions are very often conducted for individual performance feedback and to know where we stand. 
-- no micromanagement that makes it very easy to work.
Cons:
-- Salary growth is slow. Takes around 3 to 4 years for a decent Hike in salary. 
-- Yearly increments are there called Market adjustments but not exactly increment in salary.

Pros: Been working remotely from home for 12 years so good way to keep work/life balance. Lots of very smart people to interact with.
Cons: Too many VPs and above, not a week goes by when you don't get an announcement about yet another VP created somewhere while the "working folk" can't get a promotion or even a raise. Much too siloed in many places slowing decison-making down. Chambers solicits feedback yet seems to do whatever he wants anyway resulting in a few decisions where everyone said "we knew that wouldn't work, why didn't he?"

Pros: Great place to work. Its work culture is good. There are lot of learning opportunity. Upper management is very supportive for innovation and initiatives. Cisco always takes the lead path to identify and use future technology while designing product
Cons: There is always a risk of employment for under performer but in positive sense it gives them the chance to learn, grow and do better.

Pros: From a people, technology and product perspective, Cisco is by far one of best high tech companies in the US.  I have worked a many high profile companies, and Cisco surpasses them all.
Cons: Cisco leadership encourages employees to attain an equitable work/life balance.  However, given the extreme workload demands, this is not possible.  Employees must work with their leaders to attain the proper balance.

Pros: Smart motivated "do'ers". Great benefits. Great place to learn, with excellent education benefits which you can put to good use at your next job.
Cons: Annual layoffs to pander to Wall St have not made much difference to the stock in the 5 years I've been there. Recent management additions from Symantec are proving to be clueless. Bad shift in culture away from work-life balance. Very small annual increases and very little chance for promotion.

Pros:
- some interesting projects 
- majority of people are smart, though that is changing
- flexible work hours
Cons:
- Cisco services is slowly being turned into a sweat shop
- layoffs don't make sense
- quality of projects is going down
- quality of new hires is abysmal
- managers of tech teams are non-technical especially in services.

Pros: Professional group of people who uplift each other.  The people are what makes it a great place to work.
Cons: Changing business strategy disregards worker sentiment.  Many express sadness on the changes being made by management, because it shows little regard for those remaining.

Pros: they try to promote a work-life balance although you may work long hours when it comes to certain projects. Great place for flexibility and buffer to learn new stuff. Able to work from home on most occasions. The benefits are excellent! The work culture is exceptional; everybody is willing to pitch in and help out whenever possible. And there are tons of resources to use.
Cons: there are plenty of work compensation and promotion complaints. Most importantly there have been at least 4-5 job lay-offs in the last decade...

Pros: Multinational environment, high quality jobs. Good and flexible working time, work from home.
Cons: clear distinction between Red badge and Blue. Red badges are considered as a Temp workers and mostly hired for short term jobs and to support Regular employee/manager support.  if you are  experienced  then never join as a red badge otherwise just for few bucks you will loose your dignity and don't be surprise when you have to leave the job in 2 weeks.

Pros:
Good company. You get to work on latest technologies, good HR policies.
I have worked in cisco for 6+ years, this company is NOT what it used to be. Good place for freshers to start your career.
Cons:
Management is a waste. Boot lickers get the perks, hikes, growth while hard workers get nothing. 
Too much of management hierarchy. Performance reviews are an eyewash- Manager does what he feels like. Managers practicing regionalism etc
Frequent secret layoffs ...

Pros: Cisco is one of the few companies that actually provides a true work life balance.   Heavy adoption of their collaboration technologies allows for working from home when not traveling.
Cons: Rapid shift in technology over the past few years has resulted in numerous layoffs.   Cisco is hiring but weeding out those that aren't adapting to the new world.    This should be done once vs many smaller actions.

Pros: Great health plan, office conditions ok but new office is coming in Sydney, great access to technology. Strong company, great products, name opens doors
Cons: Expect a nervous annual event as you wait to see if you a redundancy candidate, changing comp plans mean that some sellers i.e. service sales will earn less than before particularly for plan overachievement (not site what Cisco are trying to accomplish with this one), Consistently changing environment (if you don't like constant change) then this is not the company for you

Pros: Very professional and progressive. Grows you up as a corporate sector employee with great base salary, perks and quality work
Cons: Ruthless about deadlines and target. The area the company needs to focus on is laying off the employees who are not performing or are on performance improvement plans. I saw a lot of very talented and intelligent employees with proven track records get impacted by the layoffs and noticed the under performing employees are still there. They also need to spend some time focusing on the international employees as well.

Pros: some really strong colleagues existed before they were LRd. I was fortunate to work with a great number of teams. I enjoyed working on many different projects.
Cons: constant lay-offs leaves everyone grumpy and scared... you can be laid off for being 40+ no matter how good you are or if you have received commendations for good work. Don't expect to move within the company. They find it easier just to eliminate you and infill with new graduates. Their compensation levels are now much less and designed for those who lack experience.

Pros: I have worked for Cisco for a total of >12 years. The company treats its employees well and gives opportunities to learn new areas. Great incentive scheme and growth to those who constantly outperform.
Cons: Too many internal meetings, frequent reviews and too many presentations created. Too much pressure in sales and the last few years annual layoffs and organization restructuring confuses everyone. The settlement time is too long and then there is more restructuring. Too many acquisitions and strategy is not clear.

Pros: very accommodating to working from home. very good salary and benefits. lots of extra curricular activities (like employee mentor programs, stretch assignments, employee organisations, fun fund days) and opportunities to take leadership outside of official role.
Cons: slow process to go up grades (although can be manager specific). need to be someone who is okay with change and unknowns because reorganizations are common

Pros:
Excellent Flexibility. Great Pay, especially for top performers.
Trying to reinvent.
Cons: Leadership is toxic, not able to live up to right values. In turn losing a lot of good people.  Not reinventing itself fast enough.

Pros: Cisco is a great place to work. What I love about the place and will really recommend to all working mom's is that I have been able to balance my work (and do really well) and my family of growing kids and give them the attention that they or my family needs. Great policies and amazing leadership in thought and action and is a great place to learn and grow.
Cons: Progress and transformation are slow and very challenging. However, having seen the actions the leadership is taking up close I understand the right moves are being made. Having said that it's really slow.

Pros:
# Flexibility & ownership.
# Agility/focus to customer need.
# Great talent pool
Cons:
# To many re-org and changes. Changes are needed, but, it could be better planned.
# Unnecessary (necessary ??) politics impacts leaf level engineers/managers and impacts moral adversely.
# Better planning to re-educate existing work-force (rather than taking from outside always) on new/upcoming technology.
# Need smoother internal transfer process. HR has guidelines, but, it becomes VP dependent.

Pros:
Good benefits make me feel appreciated.
Healthcare facility provides high quality integrated health care.
Newly renovated engineering buildings and free snacks provide a modern feel.
Cisco veterans tend to be nice, stable people who react calmly to organization changes.
Regular all-hands meetings from CEO and VPs.
Bonuses tied to company-wide performance, which makes me feel connected to the company as a whole.
Cons:
Engineering managers tend to have 25 direct reports, which seems like a very high number, but Cisco veterans think this is normal.
Hard to get data science and machine learning projects off the ground.
Hard to understand the politics.
Went through some rough patches due to not enough management.

Pros: Great development program that holds high value within the company. Vigorous program that sets you up for success if you are willing to put in the effort. Fantastic San Jose manager who really has your back and wants you to succeed.
Cons: CSAP board is a bit removed from what is actually expected in the field from a Systems Engineer, resulting in disappointing trainings at times and confusing communication throughout the program on what is expected of ASEs.

Pros: I work from home, so I'm home when my kids get off the bus.  When one of my kids has an appointment, there's no issue with leaving my desk to take him/her.  I use my Time to Give (40 hours a year!) to volunteer at school, and to lead my daughter's Girl Scout Troop.
Cons:
Global workforce and remote working creates challenges for the team environment.  Webex video meetings help, but there is nothing like spending time with your colleagues face-to-face.
In my experience, upward mobility when working remotely is limited-- you need to work in one of the centers if you're looking for a management position.

Pros: Great team.  Former Chairman really drove business value and solutions.  Under new CEO the company has retrenched to being a hardware and technology focused company.
Cons:
Fragmented.  Multiple organizations started to focus on the same markets.  Political infighting prevented cohesive go-to-market.  No focus on non-IT customer execs, only IT.  

Now only known for routers, switches, and servers.  Not much else.  Latest reentry into industrial IoT will be another bust.  They had invested heavily in multiple organizations before.  Why do they think it will work now?  

Too little, too late, and will not work as a hardware only vendor.

Pros:
Pay is pretty good if you are well connected
High attrition means opportunity to creatively procrastinate
Crazy, intense politics that can be used to take out your inner rage
Low quality nepotism hiring benefits you if you happen to be from the right background
Astoundingly bad technical talent that allows anyone to look good with even modest effort
Chuck seems pretty good
Cons:
Pay is really bad if you've been around too long
Nepotism
Politics
More politics
Crazy backstabbing
Terrible, out of date technology
Lazy resume-oriented design as the primary paradigm outside of routing and switching
Boring
Soul-crushingly, mind-numbingly boring work
Lots of credit stealing

Pros:
I have been working at Cisco full-time for almost 3 years, started as a MBA graduated

Cisco is a great company, every day my feeling is that I am adding value, you can deliver your full potential. Is diverse and best place to work worldwide and in different countries, benefits are great  . We work to make communities evolve and we rely on the latest technology and human talent to do this.
Cons: Restructurings, change is always good, but at a large corporation strategy and leadership changes can create a lot of restructures.

Pros:
-very innovative
- feels like a small company even though being huge.
- Very good, awesome CEO, the best in the industry.
- good benefits
- customers look to Cisco for advice
- great SE’s
Cons:
- becoming to complex too sell. Too large portfolio
- quota is set on last years exit even though you overperform massively. You are expected to grow at all times every quarter every year.

Pros: Cisco truly lets you be yourself. A colleague died her hair blue and it was no big deal. They are supportive of diversity and social justice initiatives. They are also focused on the employee experience and making sure people have choices. During Covid - they have routinely provided a "day for you" to take time off and recharge/focus on you. This time does not go towards PTO. There is also a focus on volunteering and giving back to the community with a company match of time and funds.
Cons: A lot of change but that is to be expected as the company is evolving to meet changing markets.

Pros: Work flexibility, team is great and has each other’s back. Technology access is good. Good advancement potential.
Cons: Still can’t figure out the cloud transition. Not overly excited about vision. Leadership has overly pivoted to worrying more about the state of political issues than actual business it seems. There should obviously be a balance and everything should be inclusive but it seems like this is all leadership cares about. CEO is less than exciting and motivating. Really miss John Chambers excitement and bullishness.

Pros: Big name company with some interesting technology
Cons: Its a big company so it all depends on which team you are in. It can be a great company who are trying to be a great employer but it can also be painful. Many layers of management, below inflation salary increases even for high performers and difficult to get promotion unless you leave and come back. Innovation is non existent. Cisco prefer to acquire companies but then inevitably kill them trying to integrate into Cisco.

Pros:
Industry leadership; good to employees
It's an exciting time to work at Cisco.  It is  an environment that helps employees balance their work and family responsibilities while staying healthy.  Employees' personal and professional growth by offering a comprehensive range of training and development programs.  Cisco goal is to achieve a more diverse and more inclusive workforce that is capable of producing ever-higher levels of technological innovation.  The company is committed to providing a safe and healthy work environment that exceeds government requirements.
Cons: Large and bureaucratic; slow moving.  Often depends too much on consensus. More internally focused,should pay more attention externally.

Pros: Cisco is a great place to work that pays very well.  Expect the goaling to be high, the stress for achieving to be high, and the compensation is also high.  Cisco is a market leader and technology innovator that is highly respected in the technology industry.  It is very easy to get appointments with IT staff and senior management with your Cisco credentials.
Cons: Promotions and advancement limited.  Hard to balance work/family.

Pros: The company has obviously great name recognition, and it's a good place to jump start a career and move off into other companies.  Cisco has Solid management -- lots of talented people are there, although now things move a bit more slowly than at a more nimble startup environment.
Cons: It's a long way from San Francisco, where I live, and my job made it difficult to work from home.  I was on the WebEx side, and it's not completely a meritocracy -- it's often been a place where having a good relationship with higher ups mattered more than talent or impact.

Pros:
Solid benefits package

Great job to have on your resume

Front row seat to the latest and greatest technology trends in the industry
Cons:
Line managers more concerned about their own success rather than their direct reports success

Diversity policy is pure comedy gold -- most diversity hires are very limited in ability and are not strategic hires or promotions.

Promotions are purely political -- not based on ability/accomplishments

Director level (and below) management is ill-equipped to lead, but is great at parroting corporate buzzwords

Company  fits the definition of  "bloated bureaucracy" quite well

Stock options went away, and now only executive levels benefit from (excessive) stock grants

Constant reference to "Cisco family" is ironic, unless your  "family"  fosters an atmosphere of back-stabbing, brown-nosing employees

Fanatical expense reduction has sucked the life out of the workforce and has brought morale to an all-time low

Focus on political correctness has resulted in an atmosphere of  "yes men"

Committees and councils do not equal "nimble"

EPM process (annual reviews)  is laughable, and fits right in to the culture of cronyism

Entirely too many VPs (446 as of July '09), and quite a few of them are simply cashing a paycheck

Empire building prevalent even amongst lowly line managers

360 review process is a joke, as HR is not willing to listen to criticism of managers

Bad/non-productive managers and employees are often simply reassigned, instead of weeded out

The arrogance of management -- especially the line managers up to director level -- makes for an exceptionally unhappy workforce.

Pros: Trust culture, empowerment, flexibility, opportunity to try new roles, full of very talented people most of whom continually go the extra mile.
Cons: Complete lack of work/life balance, sickening references to "the Cisco family" when people are getting laid off, all of the perks have been removed, no promotions, no salary-increases....and yet the executives are rewarding themselves handsomely. Comes across as a complete lack of respect for their "family members". Big company culture has crept in and it the time to get things done is demoralizing.

Pros:
Make your own hours

Some flexibility in work location (work from home, remotely, but this is a double edged sword)

Financially sound with diverse portfolio of products and services, able to endure tough times better than many other companies
Cons:
Engineers are viewed and treated as a commodity, not as the engine of product development.

Career growth is non-existent.  There is no benefit to moving within the company because you can't get a promotion or raise even if you get hired for a position that is a higher grade level.

Your direct manager has no say in your evaluation rating, it is all rolled up to executive levels who arbitrarily rank order you.

Cisco loves to talk about hiring the top 5% of talent, then they want to compensate them at the 70th percentile (if that), and not recognize their efforts.  This causes low morale and limits the effort that people are willing to put into their work.  If everyone in the company is top 5% of talent, why do the rankings have to fit an arbitrary bell-curve distribution.  Isn't it possible that you have a high performing organization because they are all top talent?

Cisco wants their employees to work like it is a start-up, i.e. lots of hours, however, there are no start-up type benefits.  Individual contributors don't get stock (but execs get lots), there is no career advancement (see point 2).  Why should I bust my ass for no reward.  Cisco wants you to be "happy you still have a job" in the current environment and they manage by fear.  Apple employees are asked to work like it is a start-up, but they still get broad based stock grants.

Cisco talked a good game about open communication and transparency, but when an exec was asked in an all-hands how many VPs and Directors were impacted by the "limited restructuring" (i.e. lay-off) of 3-5% of the company, the response was "we're not going to talk about that"

Cisco likes to think of itself as a family, however, when members of the "family" were going to be laid-off if they couldn't find another job in the company, they didn't even get interviews for open positions that matched their skill sets.

Pros: Interesting and growing technology portfolio.  Many good people.  Reasonably good support for field sales force.
Cons: Incestuous management promote cronies.  Has become a bloated behemoth.  Too many people telling other people what to do instead of actually doing something productive.  Too much bureaucratic bs and contemplating our own navel. Boards and councils can't make decisions and no one makes the BUs stop fighting and work together.  No one is accountable when poor decisions are made.

Pros:
Long history of Network experience with huge information base in networking technologies and provide a rich source of strong network skills for learning.
Cisco is composed of several business units (departments) and each one is acting as a separate company by itself, and that provide a great opportunity for internal transfer with a great change of experience and technology.
Cons: Focus on execution-oriented performance most of the time. Not good place for Ph.D. graduates because of lack of support for research

Pros:
- Still a lot of smart people around the organization.
- Some interesting technologies to work with; still the dominant player in the networking space.
- Great benefits and all the perks of working for a big company
Cons:
- Hard to succeed, get promoted or get recognized if you aren't overtly political.
- Really poor senior management decision making; when Chambers said Cisco's strategy was sound but execution was failing, I had to ask... Flip anyone?

Pros: Flexibility, good people, fair compensation and benefits
Cons:
Top heavy, process heavy, too many people to show how to put on the bulb, few doers and less credibility for the doers.

Slow decision making

Off-shoring of IT functions has in fact increased costs (as onsite resources are required anyways), quality has suffered, and delays and failure in delivery of IT projects.

Pros: Open communication, nice vibe.. good pay
Cons:
Hard to get a promotion, rules are not really transparent. If you are a "get things done" person, you might run into quite some struggle with push back because things are moving slow at Cisco sometimes.
