A lot of "lifers" at the company, being there for 13years + and try to keep their profile low and not move too much so that they can maintain this "well paid" position until they retire.

Pros:
Opportunity to work with a lot of smart people (regretfully they are not always in leadership positions)
If you can take the numerous re-organizations, there is often opportunity to learn more and broaden your resume
Cons:
Politics reign supreme
Politics determine who gets ahead, regardless of competence or lack thereof
Insane work hours, every re-organization means more work

Pros:
*Quite good pay
*A name that opens doors at customers
*Some good technology
*Work life balance
Cons:
*To internally focused, forgotten the customer is more important than your manager
*Political
*Difficult to maneuver round the organisation
*Too many products, no one is sure which ones to sell, confused messaging to customers
*Company is currently in decline and needs changes to reinvigorate growth
*Culture has become a Webex call and a spreadsheet
*Processes are killing the company

Pros:
- Great Benefits (Health Insurance/ESPP/401K/PTO)
- Work Life Balance
- Flexibility to do what you want.
- Stability
- Number 1 in it's industry and starting to expand to other areas as well.
- Alot of projects to work on (Depends on your BU I guess)
- Tuition Reimbursement for graduate school
Cons:
- No yearly salary increases, once in a few years. (Also depends on BU)
- Slow moving and decision making company. Probably because it's an old company.
- A lot of old timers waiting for retirement.
- Bureaucratic

Pros: Interesting place to work with a relatively good corporate culture. Competitive salary, good benefits, and lots of smart people. This is a great place to start and grow your career.
Cons: Too many products with development spread around the globe, which makes communication between teams painful.

Pros:
I joined CSCO when it was a small company. It was nice to see it grow into a multimillion dollar company. I always worked at the cutting edge of technology. 
Other engineers are also pretty smart and one can learn from them.
Cons: The schedules are very accelarated and challeging. You keep very busy and don't have time for taking more classes. Also for women with small children, it can be very challenging to work for cisco and take care of home as well as children as one needs to spend lot of extra hours at work many times.

Pros: Ability to work from home, great on-site gym and doctors, PTO policy is rather generous for new hires. If you have a great manager, it can be a very positive experience.
Cons: Actions are regularly taken without accounting for the consequences and how they impact employees. Problem solving tends to be very reactionary which leads to a very imbalanced workload - one week you may have hours of free time and the next you're working until midnight.

Pros: The people that are here are fantastic if you're talking to the right people! They call it political - I think it's a lot of people realizing how quickly one feature can spin up a TON of work for support, which is why things need to be done properly!
Cons: The scale.  It's massive.  And every conversation is a battle to be the best.

Pros: Cisco pays well, and for the most part if you are under 50 and not a grade 12 without direct reports you are probably in good shape.
Cons: Horrible senior leadership. Very slow to respond to industry trends.

Pros: Cisco is a big, company that sells boring but necessary technology. This means that they have many domain experts, and you will probably be the youngest out of them.
Cons: I interned on one of their bread and butter teams and there wasn't all that much "innovation" happening within that team. Corporate admin encourages innovation with running a contest to see who can be the best "intra"-preneur, which can satisfy some people, who want the stability of working for a BigCo, but also want to think more creatively within their job.  I'm not a networks/big corporation guy, and this internship really made me realize it.

Pros:
Can work remotely if necessary.
Plenty of Paid Time Off (PTO)
Management encourages innovation and stretch projects.
Decent salary
Cons:
layoffs on a yearly basis.
They tend to reward personality rather than work performance. For example, 2 individuals with the same job title, both performing at the same level, but the 1 that likes to make chit chat and brown nose a little more...will get a promotion.
While the salary is nice, for the Bay Area it's still just scraping by, especially if you have a family.

Pros: Culture of innovation, early adoption, several groups/technologies to pick, flexible management which is employee friendly most times, good reward system (works well most times but has some flaws as well)
Cons: Management relies heavily on managers feedback. There are instances when good employees suffer due to poor managers.  And stress on innovation seems artificial many times leading to several employees pretending to be innovating by trying to file patents on someone else's ideas or simple ideas ..

Pros: Excellent vacation (20+ days), extremely flexible attitude to telecommuting. Very collaborative culture (in marketing, at least). Very strongly profitable company, and overall reasonably well-run. Good top-down communication and transparency.
Cons: Pretty chaotic at senior leader levels since new CEO Robbins was announced. A lot of layoffs, executive departures...tried and trusted people, processes thrown out without much regard for whether they were effective or not. Either good (tough) decision making, or leaders doing whatever they think they need to do to curry favor with the new CEO. Hard to know which currently.

Pros: This is a large company with great benefits.  They love to hire from within and there are lots of opportunities.
Cons: Cisco has gone to the layoff model to management.  Their people have become disposable while middle management continues to grow and protect each other.  There are too many managers with an inconsistent message.  Half of the managers appreciate their employees and work with them to help them advance in their careers.  Others want people that are going to stay in the same job forever.

Pros: Amazing company! Lot's of challenges and lots to learn. There are plenty of opportunities in the company. There is also flexibility to explore different business functions/roles. The work life balance depends on how to manage it. The on-campus facilities like health, pharmacy, gym etc are simply fantastic. The company rewards performers very well. That is, your bonus and overall compensation structure gets very good if you are top performer.
Cons: It's a very big company. With the size comes it's complexities. There is a extremely large management structure. Changes are either too slow or too fast. The inter business group dynamics are often not healthy and complex.

Pros: Flexible timings and WFH. Cutting edge routers and optical technology. You can brag about the work and product impact.Market leaders currently.
Cons: Bad management.unrealistic pressures and expectations.groupism.manager maintains a pet group under him . If u are not in the group no matter what good work you do gets unnoticed.customers are too touchy and literally blackmail openly about cancelling orders if some trivial bug is not fixed within time.This shakes up the whole management structure from director to apply pressure and get work done no matter what. It's ruthless .Software tools are open source and very difficult to debug  as debug infra is not taken seriously.No hikes at all.Promotions only if you are in the above pet group

Pros: Cisco has incredible talent across the spectrum of networking. As industry leaders in corporate and service provider networks they generate a tremendous amount of revenue and incredible profit margins
Cons:
There are two major external trends which Cisco has to embrace if they wish to be relevant in the future:
1. The advent of cloud service providers beginning to dominate the TAM
2. Increasing interest in network virtualization as opposed to dedicated routers and switches

Pros:
Possible to work from home.

Good benefits - Free health insurance.

Buy up to 5 days extra holidays.

Good work life balance.

Everyone I work with are genuine and nice people.

Get to work with modern technologies, environments and programming languages.

The products we are working on very new and so you do
get to spend a good bit of time actually coding new features vs
just bug fixing etc. 

Good hardware for work.

Very good to the wider community and are continuously raising money for good causes.
Cons:
No career progression. Very possible to get stuck in same
position / salary for years on end in this company.
Seem to have no budget for career advancement at the moment.

Very difficult to stay motivated.

Good engineering practices are not always recognized.
Management say they care about quality but only seem to reward
engineers who produce at speed but cause many bugs in our products.
Actions speak louder than words.

No team structure. You don't know what you will be working on week to week. Very varied. Can be a good thing or a bad thing depending on the person.
Not what I like in a work place environment.

Very frugal in general with employees i.e Don't help pay for Christmas Party.
We used to have release parties but since we are releasing on a continuous basis
this has all dried up. Again no recognition to the dedication of employees.

Since we develop communications applications there is a culture of always being online
and it can be common to seeing people replying to messages at 11 - 12pm at night. Can be
very difficult to switch off. Management don't directly encourage this but also
don't try to curb this behavior.

Canteen is expensive for what you get. Cisco didn't provide the catering
contractor and canteen staff with the proper facilities so they have to make do with pre made factory food and microwaves. Food seems highly processed and as such the quality isn't very good.

Vending machines have no healthy options.

Senior Management are more obsessed with image i.e Winning Great Place 
To Work instead of actually improving the work environment for employees.

I feel that management don't listen to employees concerns. 
I had many experiences of engineers on the team voicing common sense concerns about the direction of the product to management only to fall on deaf ears. 
Eventually the customer voiced the same concerns and so we ended up wasting countless engineering hours backtracking on previous work. This has happened on many
occasions.

Over the last number of years there has been annual redundancies with out fail. 
It has actually affected the Galway site a couple of times. One year a whole team was let go. 
This was without consideration to the performance of individual members of the team. So it
doesn't matter how good you are you could still be let go at anytime.

Pros: Results driven atmosphere, and a company designing technology that runs the backbone of the industry.   Very dynamic and fast paced (at least, in my role), and very customer focused.  Very easy to "rally" people due to a customer need.
Cons: Very unclear requirements in regards to career pathing, raises, and future growth.  Lateral moves are the norm, but upward movement is a mystery, and appears to be shrouded in politics.

Pros:
Lots of great people - generally super-helpful
Excellent flexibility to work mobile or from home
Top-notch communications technology (natch)
Pay & benefits are pretty good
Workspaces are pretty good (the newer ones anyway)
Strengths-based performance management system (Stand Out program)
Excellent learning & development opportunities
Cons:
Lots of politics in the sales organization
Scale - finding the right people who can help you can be challenging and the org chart isn't very useful
Salary increases only come if you get promoted - no cost-of-living adjustments
Continuous restructuring as company changes focus
Bureaucracy - getting stuff done can be difficult
Product mentality is still network-biased and breaking out of that is challenging
Work-life balance not as good as first claimed

Pros: Lots of facilities in the campus, but no time to utilize them.
Cons:
Unstructured and unplanned management.
Mgmt not capable. Just long timers in cisco passing time as managers.
Mgmt Cannot understand any of the technical problems or designs.
In the name of flexible seating arrangement, everyday i was left with no seat to sit by the time i reach office. Too pitiable condition. WHy this torture to employees without having a fixed seat???
Unmanly tasks to finish.
Office politics is too high. Indian crab story is apt for this environment.
Have this offer to join as a last resort, if you don't have other offers.

Pros: Extreme communication to employees, all employees are valued, liberal views, ability to continually develop, educational opportunities, growth opportunities, flex time, work from home/ remotely, global, Cisco campuses are modern and have great features, volunteer opportunities and paid time off to volunteer, paid birthday day off, bonuses, employees can monetarily recognize fellow employees (connected recognition)
Cons: Too many contract employees leads to less opportunities for permanent positions and instability in the knowledge and workforce in place, pay raises are not a regular yearly practice, too many "restructures" too often

Pros: nice working environment   work, and life balance
Cons:
politics, politics...

one member holds information does not share it with a teammate, no meeting invitation, no email exchange, no conversation, cannot meet that person in the office as that person always works from home, However, he can be protected by manager even manager knew the entire story.   The response from the manager is I need to keep him happy, that is my job.

Pros:
Incredible people - committed to the company and each other
Incredible managers - very caring - very supportive through challenging personal time.
Incredible - Monthly Check-ins by Management - ranging between multiple topics - and incredible support throughout the pandemic since day one. - Including being vocal on mental health, homelessness, volunteering work - and ensuring company makes an impact both in SW / HW and its People and their locals.
Cons:
Multiple Geo Coordination is challenging work / life balance - but that is true for many companies i worked at - in various positions.
At its core

Pros: Excellent salary and benefits. Flexible working. Technology to enable work efficiency. Well respected and you are generally empowered especially with the right management
Cons: Imbalance of resources between US and other theaters . At times worknoverliad occurs and work life balance becomes a struggle. Highly political. Constantly re-organising. Over complicate things and use of acronyms. Over communication.

Pros: 1) excellent work culture 2) work life balance 3) Pro employee policies
Cons: 1) as soon as covid started work culture completely destroyed and even after offices reopen same bad culture. 2) Now its no longer product company its became like service company. 3) Management became obsessive to save pennies even company is performing good. 4) finally once you joined cisco the same salary remains even after 5years 5) after i resigned they ate my bonus. yes cisco employees will get their share bonus even after he left but this time they ate it for no reason.

Pros: Hardworking, accessible experts all over the company!  Beyond the IETF leadership, patents, and certifications, I can probably count on one hand the number of times a subject matter expert has declined an opportunity to discuss their field of expertise, especially with a customer.  Individual contributors are the soul of this company, and many work after hours and on weekends to get the job done.  Some may call them perfectionists and some may call them crazy, but the level of excellence I've seen from many coworkers is truly exceptional.
Cons: Management has gotten complacent and collaboration needs to improve among product lines.

Pros: Great name to have on the resume, stability, a lot of resources to grow professionally for those who look (not on the job though in most cases), decent compensation. I like the HR department. A lot of interesting people to work with.
Cons: The promotion system does not work correctly - working harder hardly working... Too much talk too little business, but one can call it a "process". Engineering grades do not have anything to do with the individuals' competence.

Pros: Cisco's vision as communicated by John and the rest of senior leadership is one that engenders hard work and loyalty "Change the way the world works, lives, plays, and learns."  There are plenty of smart people and plenty of long hours...rewards are good, not great.  Interesting work most of the time.
Cons: Lots of smart people and long hours make the competition for jobs and promotions fierce, especially if you're gunning for Director or above.  Typical fast pace and lots of ambiguity to deal with.

Pros: The salary and benefits are good.  Fellow employees are for the most part nice and helpful.  There is some recognition for working at Cisco.
Cons: Management is slow and goals are vague or inconsistent.  Evaluations are subjective and career advancement is not great.  Not much recognition for the work you do.  Cisco culture is political.  Also, they only play Fox News on the TVs at the cafeteria.  That news broadcast is way too opinionated, political, and annoying.

Pros: Cisco as a company is trying to redefine how businesses operate.  They definitely want to try to change the world and are willing to take risks.
Cons: At the end of the day, Cisco is really fundamentally a hardware company.  Most of the innovation is happening in software and Cisco while wanting to make the transition, continues to stumble.  There is too much of a reliance on acquisitions to grow the company.

Pros: It is too diverse to summarise here. A lot depends on the business unit and your manager. I worked in two BU's under four managers. In one I found a lot of interesting work being done. In the other there was no clear direction and projects kept getting cancelled. So if you are lucky, you can find good work. Also it is easier to achieve life/work balance.
Cons: Too much politics!! In order to get promoted, you need to be good at buttering up to your manager and his manager. You will go nowhere if you or your manager gets victimised in turf grabbing.

Pros:
Decent pay, telecommunication options, benefits, etc. 
Loads and loads of IP to learn from. 
Can move between roles internally.
Cons:
I joined CIsco 3+ years ago and have been seeing the company unraveling before my very eyes.

Reason you ask ?
> Incompetent Senior Executives
> Too much office politics, even at lower levels
> Mob mentality of employees.
> Feels like working for the government

This is not a company for y-geners, for anyone actually - but definitely not the y-geners.

Pros: The company encourages employees to take risks and it allows career movement across different business units within the company. Management makes a quick correction, even though it is sometimes painful.
Cons: It is easy to be lost in an ever changing organization, going through acquisitions, restructuring, and management's experiments. There are too many redundant projects/products that ended up discontinued. Too many middle layer management, which could slow down decision making.

Pros: There are plenty of good people and a decent salary range.  There are good benefits and an innovative culture that allows flexible working to a degree though there are nice office locations too that have plenty of drop-in workspaces.   you can get a lot of autonomy which leads to good prospects to move internally or take on new projects.
Cons: higher management is slightly over-heavy though this is getting  better, a tendency for people to stay a long time so upward movement can sometimes be difficult

Pros:
If you are a workaholic with a bit of A.D.D. you have come to the right company.  Things were always changing and you had to keep up.  Fast paced and generally positive place to work. I enjoyed the global view on things and collaborating with people I would never meet in person. 
Good benefits, flexibility and PTO time.
Cons: It is a great place to work just not for the faint of heart.  You work as hard as you get to play. Hours can be long and inconvenient. In the administrative area, there was no career path if you are located in a smaller sales office.

Pros: Master of your own destiny, company is getting its act together, feel much more a part of 'One Cisco', opportunities for promotion and advancement increasing. Fantastic roadmap, good customer alignment. More of a 'can do' attitude than recent years.
Cons: Don't trust the senior leadership enough to feel secure in my job, high amount of 'mandatory' internal meetings, very high workload (due to being under-resourced). Compensation still too stock price oriented for SEs - stock options and RSU don't make up for lower base salary in this economic climate. Not attracting top talent any more. Some colleagues are of questionable ability.

Pros: Work remotely, good benefits, accommodating to family issues.
Cons: Too political, promotion by cronyism. It is not what you know that allows you to get ahead, it is who you know. The rating and ranking system does not work, a good employee can get rated with Needs Improvement just because a metric needs to be met. You are not rated on your actual value.

Pros:
A lot of opportunities to learn new technology and to be marketable.
Compenstation and Bonuses are fairly decent.
Cons:
Upper Management only seems to care about the bottom line.  I never felt that they ever cared about the products or the people which made me have no respect for upper management.

You need to give 110% every day.  This is expected.  Weekend and holidays, too. The way they handle employee ranking is the same methodology as GE which to me is pretty unfair.

Pros: Broad product and service offering. Opportunities to do multiple roles and functions within company.  Good benefits and remote worker flexibility. Opportunity to learn and develop self, but it has to be self-driven.
Cons: Diffusion of focus gets in the way of execution. Too many chief's and not enough people to do the work. Personal growth is very hands off and not structured. HR function is not engaged in people development.

Pros: Smart people, good products, strong brand.  Very innovative and geniunely intelligence people work here.  Good location, a nice gym, good back up day care service.
Cons: Not very impressive levels of ethics, and also relatively low levels of emotional intelligence.  Compared to HP, which is where I worked before.  Also, there is a wider range of intelligence levels there - some people I come across I wonder how they work there.

Pros: Large company benefits... You have a good choices for benefits, stock options. Flexibility in schedule and some really great people that work there.
Cons: Cost cutting is the primary focus. Once your in growth is hard. Was high performer year after year with no growth opportunities. Completely changed orgs, same high performance no opportunities to grow. So much cost cutting culture isn't the same as it use to be. Was a great company...

Pros: There used to be plenty of them
Cons: If given a choice between giving you a raise or a promotion, they'd prefer you just leave.

Pros: You have the ability to cease any opportunity and work through any and all area's that you are familiar with.  This may sound impossible but if you can handle your core functions, there are many other area's that like to work cross-functionally to build relationships and drive initiatives globally.
Cons: There really are not a lot of con's.  Assuming you are willing to step up and be heard, there will be opportunities for you to grow and lead.

Pros: Cisco payscales are very good.  Benefits and Bonus are great too.  If you are in senior mgmt you get good RSU's which are icing on the overall compensation package.
Cons: Cisco is not the same company it was 10 years ago.   No more the IT bell weather stock company it was a few years ago.  Still a good place to work mainly because of the compensation.  But overall, there is no clear direction of where the company is heading..

Pros: Fantastic Networking technology is Cisco company. People in Jammaz distribution  people are friendly and collaborative; grew fast in the past 10 years and got a lot of chances to switch between different roles.
Cons: Organization is too stable, turnover rate is very high. None of colleagues in my departments left over last 5 years because wages is highly paid than industry average.

Pros: Flexible working hours , chance to grow in the industry , good name on your resume
Cons:
A toxic work environment built on perceived visibility and contributions rather than recognising individuals for what they really are contributing. This promotes a culture of pretending to work rather than really working. 

Too many mid level manager , most have nothing to do and abuse corporate travel and expensess.

Pros: Cisco provides good compensation, benefits, and (with many positions) flexibility to work remotely.  The people who work at Cisco are intelligent, respectful and nice.
Cons: As an older tech company the culture can be a bit stuffy. Cisco is trying to fix this and encourage young people to come/stay but there is still work that needs to be done.

Pros:
- Exceptional customer focus
- Outstanding sales force
- Leading technologies in networking
- Brilliant channel and partner engagement for reselling and customer engagement
- State of the art labs and deployment
- First to adopt own technology
- Flexible work env
- Medical and 401K benefits good

- Old school management methods
- Several dying products still carried forward

- Undue work load to manage international teams

Pros:

- Great diversity

Pros: Flexibility, New technologies, Good engineers, Good market presence. Two stars because of flexibility in some groups and not in all groups.
Cons: Red tape, slow execution, lots of meetings and politics, too many bad managers, analysts, program managers, PMs , bad benefits to employees, promotion politics, too many people doing basically nothing, layoffs and favoritism. This applies specially to IT. Sales, Engineering, Advanced services are better groups

Pros:
May be many , specially if you want to know core basics abut networking then its surely interesting place for you.
Work life balance most of the time ( except in few projects)
Cons:
Depends on project , there are some loop holes . 
You can not expect very good increment for some time after you joined in. There are exceptions of course . But salary is kind of stagnant for some time. So those who are very enthusiastic about salary , then its not the place for you.

Pros:
Flexible work
Generous benefits including bonus 
Modern offices located everywhere around the world
Friendly
Cons: New direction of the company seems unclear and 'family' spirit with associated culture is disappearing. The conscious decision to address the issue of the company ageing with the need to attract millennials has led to substantial cuts of middle management - losing a huge amount of experience and knowledge. Cuts seem constant resulting in a very low level of motivation.

Pros: Great salary and benefits, culture of "taking care of people", training and courses encouraged, very competent leaders. They have a wonderful network of people to help you overcome any issue with your job responsibilities or assignments. Always an SME on hand.
Cons: Can be a non inclusive workspace at times, specially if your team is mostly male. It can be hard to transition to other roles. Other than that, I can´t find anything negative about working for them. It was an incredible job and a wonderful experience all around.

Pros: Free to pursue own path to creating value for the business.   Freedom to innovate is very high.  Transparent communication across the company.
Cons: Culture of layoffs every year is always a worry.  Its always stated as something that won't be constant but always it.   Promotions now heavily favor women and is unfair to men.   Good if you are a woman.  Health insurance benefits not as good as Microsoft and other tech companies.

Pros: There are excellent abilities to do stretch assignments and training in this area. Work life balance is excellent! Being a program manager in a new area has been difficult to understand the company from a different aspect. The political climate in his area holds a lot of information close and does not share relevant Information to your job ; this makes it extremely difficult to learn and grow.
Cons: Lack of clarity on goals and objectives and a disconnect from the greater mission and vision of Cisco at times.

Pros:
Great company culture, with no penny pinching, solid training and amazingly intelligent colleagues.

Opportunity to make some great money.

I support and sell a mature, industry leading product.

Full time work from home, with a reasonable travel schedule.
Cons:
Things change constantly. Every year is another guess as to wether our team stays together, or not.

Despite selling a great product, it's not getting the focus is needs to stay innovative.

Pros:
Benefits are OK, not great
Working from home is a plus
Cons:
Untrained management with little accountability
Says one thing concerning the people who work here but acts differently
For a Tech company, there are much fewer perks than most tech companies but the work is still hard
Yearly layoffs hurt morale and add work to the "survivors"
The company has gotten a bit bloated and "focused" on too many different areas to be effective in any of them
Not much ability to move into management.  Current managers are not going anywhere

Pros:
work-life balance
fair salaries
friendly environment (depends on team and manager, certainly)
interesting jobs
engaged employer
support for current employees in internal recruitments
Cons:
lack of trainings that support my personal development ("learn what you need for your current role")
slow pace of digital transformation (focus on results, results, results...)
Cisco does everything what Stock demands, no long-time planning
sometimes "old style" of employment reductions

Pros: Outstanding technical talents, especially towards the more senior ranks. Agile for a blue-chip company: things that are decided are implemented very quickly. Very flexible (family friendly) work hours. Compensation can be very competitive/generous depending on how  much Cisco wants/needs you (not unlike many companies). Constantly learning something new.
Cons: Not a problem for me, but some engineers have narrow scope for their work. There are opportunities to grow into other roles and technologies, but as in all big companies it is easy to be complacent. There are occasional layoffs, but that is not unique. Standard big-company bureaucracy with processes.

Pros:
Best company when it comes to work/life balance 
Flexible schedule
Ability to work from home
Great co-workers
Cons:
The pay is significantly lower than similar positions in the tech industry.
No perks (ie free meals, drinks, micro kitchens, etc)
No job security - layoffs are frequent and without much notice
Lots of movement, constantly merging or eliminating teams/groups/orgs
Struggle to create cohesive teams because of the layoffs, etc
Needs to modernize the company overall, feels very dated and stuck in the early 2000s

Pros: Access to a global environment.
Cons:
Very toxic culture. To get an idea, men make fun of how ladies should go cook rather than share their opinions publicly. It’s considered a “joke”, of course. And if you don’t laugh, you’re just not spiritual enough. I once witnessed a coleague on the balcony, that was wearing a gorgeous dress, being ridiculed that she should just come naked to work. 

It’s not easier for men either. It’s an office culture of bullying, where if you don’t subscribe to toxic masculinity beliefs, you are belittled as a coleague and as a man. 

To top it off, Senior Management shares far right articles on the internal chat, literally saying that white men are underpriviledged in this day and age. It would be mesmerising if it wasn’t all true.

Stay away from this office/team if you’re a ballanced individual.

Pros: Cisco Chennai - Broadsoft was really a good company to work. Especially after Cisco acquisition so it should be a excellent place for technology lovers. I remember I had a open learning environment and was able to focus on work life  balance .
Cons: Seems same site leader is continuing his role in Broadsoft chennai office really doubt if he was selected by poll ? He used to behave unfair with others and always was making lot of stupid conversations, argument,freightening employees with his power. But Dont know how he is behaving now after Cisco acquisition.  Otherwise the sites facilities can be improved

Pros: Was a contractor for 7 yrs before being converted to FTE last year.   I appreciate the flexibility to work from home and do so 60% of the time. For the most part doing work I enjoy and enjoy my team.
Cons: Cisco routinely switches adoption and/or drops of internal tools routinely.  However if you are around long enough,  "tools" resurface ;-) like MS-SharePoint which was ditched in my old group in 2013 and is now back company wide now as the "new" thing.  Sometimes I have to work with not so competent contractor team members (guess Cisco is paying very low?) - frustrating.

Pros: One of the best parts of Cisco's culture is the focus on driving results. Leadership isn't concerned with how you structure your day or where you work as long as you accomplish your goals. Strategy cascades down from leadership empowering everyone to be able to make decisions that tie back to the company goals and customer success. It's a fast moving, hard working company that rewards employees based on success.
Cons: It's a big company, you might be a high performer and have accomplished great things in the past but if you move to a new org it can be like you are starting a new job.

Pros:
Excellent work - Ability to directly impact the top line of the big company we are 

Values and Culture - People are valued for what they bring to the table - diverse views are welcome and encouraged - People are mentored to take their skills to the next level 

Servant leadership style of leadership from line management to the executives 

Mental well-being is talked about openly and people are encouraged to pay attention 

Knowledge is power - you have information about what happens in each part of the company easily available 

Collaboration across various functions, theatres, BUs happen naturally - Synergistic decisions
Cons: Nothing I can think of

Pros: Typically your peers are great! Miss my team and co-workers.

Management will sacrifice anything and anyone to save themselves. 
Even if you are a top performer, they will put you in LR list if you are over 40 and are in higher pay bands. You could get a raise one year, told you are a true team player, be top rep in that quarter and get LRd that week.

Pros: The company is full of great people, the programs are extremely employee friendly, the teams well funded, and lots to do
Cons: a lot of stagnation it feels from long time employees 10-15 years in the business, growth through acquisitions are hit or miss, and the various entities inside the company operate fiefdoms that do not necessarily work well together

Pros:
People, culture, work environment.
Cisco takes care of all its employees really great no wonder we have been voted best workplace two years in a row.

When it´s people reduction, many times it´s a Finance decision or Politics behind the choice of who will stay and who will have to leave.
Many times I have seen very good people, both with technical skills but also social skill have to leave because of this.

Pros:

-Teams respect work life balance
-Stock performance over 5 years has been good

Cons:

-You can get lost in the big company and many times your voice may not be heard
-Office politics in certain teams and groups
-Salary Increments year by year not very uplifting

Pros: Good Benefits, supportive leaders, transparency, great team members (last one depends on team)
Cons: Work-life balance: many say it is very good at Cisco but it depends on which team you are in. I work for Supply Chain. We have been struggling a lot for last few years with work-life balance. Many of colleagues mentioned that they put nearly 50 hours every single week. I personally put around 45 hours every single week. On top of that not able to retain employees and some great team members leaving, I see that work-life balance to go even worse.

Pros: Good place to learn networking technology. Good people at the lowest ranks. Not a sweat-shop.
Cons:
Incompetent senior management that is unbelievably short sighted. Promotions are only possible by being hand-picked by a VP who are the least qualified. The result is chains of incompetent management. Marketing is ridiculously superficial and self-serving. Development is cheap and poor quality.

Indeed Chambers is a great CEO. He's an excellent business manager, visionary and leader. However, Chambers is a horrible technical manager and cannot make Cisco into the world-class company we should be. As proof, see the recent departure of Alan Baratz. Great technical  VP who barely lasted 6 months. Stock has gone nowhere in 10 years and this is the cause.

Pros: The name gets you noticed anywhere, especially if you are in networking.
Cons: Career advancement, slow innovation.. comes with such a big company

Pros:
Benefits and Salary are very good.  Flexibility in hours and range of products.   Organizations vary considerably as to work environment.  

Best President a company could have--extraordinary and inspiring leader.
Cons:
No growth opportunities either laterally or providing  growth experience after a certain point.  Cisco likes to keep qualified people doing exactly the same thing so strong performers get bored and demotivated after so many years. 

Reorgs are only executed at the top level,  resulting in people, often managers doing the same thing, or confusion about responsibilities.  .

Pros: I joined Cisco right after graduating with my Master of Science degree. It is obviously one of the biggest high-tech companies and it is very stable. We have all the right infra structure so we are fully empowered to do our jobs. Also, most functions are located in the Bay Area campus so we have less issues dealing with multi site issues, although we do have occasional issues like that.
Cons: It is a huge company and sometimes there is a danger of becoming an anonymous worker amongst endless of other smart colleagues. Also managers tend to have too much power.

Pros:
Cisco is a great company to build someone's career at.  Gaining 5+ years at Cisco is not only a resume builder for a young person starting his/or her's career, but also having the knowledge in the latest technologies (DC virtualization, CORE/EDGE Routing, UC, Telepresence, etc).  I've gained wonderful experiences at Cisco  and very proud to work for a company with a great name recognition and being a part of some of the most innovative ideas with some of the brightest folks.  This is a great place to start a career if you only have 5 to maybe 8 years work experience.  Also, you benefit from its strong benefits but it might be changing due to the down economy.  The company paid for my MBA school ($60k) and supported me through any career developments I wanted to tackle.  

Furthermore, I loved working at Cisco because they are world-class in how they treat their employees during a restructuring.  Cisco typically lay-off policy is that you get 60 days to find a job within the company.  If you cannot find a job within after the 60 days, then the company gives a 4 months severance + COBRA paid for during those 4 months.  Hence, it is like a 6 months severance period.  Also, Cisco pays 4 months of services for an executive search firm (Lee Hecht Harrison) to help you polish up on your interview skills, and resume building, and how to network.  That is not bad compared to other companies.
Cons:
Though, I think Cisco is a great company, there are some downsides.  I think the number #1 downside for me that has been frustrating is expanding my career within the company.  I started at Cisco within IT and after my MBA school, I wanted to explore to the Sales Organization and try to work with the account teams.  Though I made that transition, it was very very difficult to crack into it.  I did it through tireless networking and a ton of referrals.  I will always be grateful for my manager in the sales org. to give me a shot.  But truthfully, Cisco is a typical large company that does not allow folks to move from one discipline to another.  The company would rather have you quit, gain the experience outside, then come back to the company serving the job function you would want.  Or during the most recent restructuring (6k people were impacted), the company would rather lay you off, then rehire folks who have that skill/talent.  I hate mentioning that because that is classic business-school 101.  However, I know that HR is trying to rectify that problem.  However, I doubt it will work due to the culture of the company.

Another downside is getting promotions.  Though as I mention that it is a great place to start anyone's career (which is very true), the company does not do a great job of giving you promotions to keep you.  I've been at Cisco for 5+ years and never had a promotion.  Though, I've had several raises, never received a promotion (keep in mind I went from IT to sales which is maybe the reason I did not get a promotion.  Starting in a new org. brings you back to square one on the promotion track).  It is very difficult and political to receive promotions at Cisco.  So something to think about, if you are interviewing for a position within Cisco, try to get the highest possible grade level you can, If you are a mid-level manager.  If you are someone straight out of school, then you are at the mercy of the company compensating you cheap compared to its competitors.

Pros: Cisco is great for job security and takes great measures to retain FTEs.  The ability to get your work done with flexible hours and/or the ability to work from home is also a GREAT perk.  And because of the size of the company, there are a lot of options to move internally (lateral) to see different sides of the business.
Cons: There is an excessive amount of middle management layers, which can often result in poor top-to-bottom communication and poor bottom-to-top visibility.  Cisco is also not very good at career advancement, specifically if you are an ambitious go-getter, as promotions and raises tend to have more to do with seniority and less to do with performance.  They also have an internal policy that you can not get promoted when you switch positions.  While I believe the intent was so that people do not jump from job to job simply for a pay increase, what happens in practice is top performers who move to a new opportunity for a new challenge, have to make that move laterally even when it is a job with more responsibility.  However, if you stay in the same role for years, you will eventually get promoted just because of seniority.  As a result, many top performers make a few lateral moves and then leave the company in order to get a promotion.

Pros:
- CISCO has a good name for itself, one of the best companies to work for
- Encourages on collaboration, knowledge sharing (organizes nerd lunches), good for career growth
- Tution reimbursement for courses 
- Flex hours 
- Good employee benefits
Cons:
- All the employee feedback programs are an eye wash, finally its the QUARTERLY BUDGET which decides everything
- Employee recognition, they conduct lot of surveys but there hasn't been any significant change. 
- Bad Managers. Ratings, promotions  & salaries are all decided by mid year and after that its just acting to show the decided ratings are right.

Pros:
Wonderful office - one will fell in love once they see it
work life balance.
time off when in need.
extra-curricular activities - WAN, singing, contests, technology programmes and goodies.
Very nice transportation and infrastructure.
Food is pretty nice.
Learning vision for children till 5 years of age - kind of day care and school.
Very nice people and managers in India.
A very good place to get networking and work with people from different areas. If you are in support, you get a chance to meet people in different departments and create networking.
blr-masala is spice - An exclusive Cisco community.
About work - it's good to learn new products and applications, however, when you are in support get less exposure, that means no career growth outside Cisco.
Cons:
Don't join as a contractor - most of the people are partner based in Cisco. Don't get tempted by salary. it's good to join Cisco as regular employee than contractor or Partner.
No performance reviews.
US management has taken lead over India management.
If you are in US, you have better opportunity to grow and learn, both career wise and inside the company.
Not all contractors can become regular employees of Cisco. So be aware with all the terms and conditions.
Politics -> but which company doesn't have it in India. So, it's okay in my understanding.
Less growth. If you want to become a manager in Cisco, being a Cisco-ite not possible. Join some other company become a manager and then join Cisco as manager if possible. Climbing the hierarchy is not simple in Cisco.

Pros:
Abundant opportunities to learn
Ethical
Relevent
Flexible work at home opportunities
All business resources are automated allowing for increased effectiveness and job satisfaction.
Wonderful new tools to support collaboration.
Cons: Moving to reduce expenses- most perks have stopped and salaries are capped for strong performers in order  to invest in employees whose salary is below the benchmark. Feels pretty socialistic.

Pros: Lots of interesting technology and challenging projects to work on.  Dedicated and knowledgeable individual contributors and first line managers.
Cons: Too many directors and VP's, most of whom are too concerned with agreeing with and keeping their bosses happy than with making real progress.  Too slow to make necessary changes, such as getting rid of Councils/Boards structure, eliminating redundant products, and stepping away from product areas (consumer) where they are incapable of succeeding.

Pros:
Work life flexibility, room for career growth, dynamic work environment. Employees can choose to rotate every 1.5 - 2 years and learn something new, or stick with their current role.

Like with all companies, networking is always a plus, and job visibility is very important for career advancement.
Cons: Due to the size of the company, some roles are limited in scope. However, it's relatively easy to pick the right role for you based on job descriptions and interviews.

Pros: Cisco provides competitive compensation and has some very strong talent on both the engineering and the business front. There is a strong appreciation for work-life balance and, while the company is very mature, there are still some great perks reminiscent of more nascent Silicon Valley companies: pool tables, ping pong tables, amazing gym...
Cons: As a young person who wants to be close to San Francisco, the location of Cisco's head office is very far from the city. Also, Cisco is a mature and bureaucratic organization with a corporate feel to the culture; this may take some adjustment for people who stem from firms with more lax startup feeling cultures.

Pros:
Tuition support
Work life balance
Fair salary
Promotional opportunities (long run, not short)
Cons:
Limited potential and promotional opportunities in short term (e.g. Not sure why if you get promoted its almost guaranteed a year "time off" of the promotional treadmill to make space for others). 
Salary growth
Stock price
Bureaucracy and levels of management

Pros: I enjoy the people and the collaboration at the company.  The compensation and benefits are above par and the work life balance is pretty good.
Cons: Extremely hard to change anything due to the layered politics at the company.  Unless you can make a change in the 100M range no one really bats an eye.

Pros: Flexible working hours and decent pay. They promote a health work and life balance. A good code of conduct in the work place.
Cons: Big organizations tend to lose sight of people who are very valuable. Each year perks of the job seem to be less and less (free soda, force you to use mandatory PTO, ect).

Pros: Cisco has one of the best Silicon Valley cultures I have experienced. You have an opportunity to learn more than many places in the field and the culture allows for creativity and entrepreneurship to thrive. Everyone at Cisco is friendly and helpful. There is a wide variety of roles available and opportunity for growth. Great benefits! Can't say enough good things about this place.
Cons: When you join, you will almost always be required to hit the ground running at a very fast pace. This is not necessarily a con if you are able to keep up with it (I personally welcome it). Some even need a little time to adjust.

Pros: Not sure if I'm lucky to be in this team, but I have little politics. We work great as a team and the learning experience is good. Work-Life balance is good. Work From Home/Remote facilities are good.
Cons: Politics among higher management seems to be present. Compensation is not competitive enough and does not seem to be encouraging experience people to stay in the company. Once experienced people leave, there is a natural decline the quality and there is dissatisfaction in the rest of the team. Experienced people should be compensated/encouraged enough to sty in the team to help with the dynamics of the team.

Pros:
good benefits
good campus
work is good if you are in good team or mostly its maintenance. cisco Bangalore is no research center.
Cons:
management is not transparent. 
lot of politics.
if  you are not in good books of your manager then hope to see your name in layoff list next year for sure.
be a slave to your manager and you well get by.
cisco is not the place it used to be.
layoffs at year end has become a tradition now. so beware of cisco if you are looking for a stable job. 
you will find yourself on your tows always and there will be always a sword hanging over your head.

Pros:
Work-like balance
Remote work
Management focused on new markets and technology
Cons:
Annual layoffs kill morale
Salary increases not regular

Pros: Salaries are very high vs comparables.  You can learn a LOT if you're willing to work AND can find part of the org that is growing.  There are still pockets of very cool technology.  Generally very open to remote workers.  Many jobs have very flexible time schedules.  There are some really really good managers here.
Cons: They're struggling with a strategy.  It's hard to get innovative projects committed in the mature parts of the business.  The last couple of years have seen regular layoffs that have badly hurt morale.  There are some really really bad managers here!

Pros: Always challenging, good benefits, on site medical and dental. Plenty of opportunities for cross theater collaboration. Plenty of work. Very diverse teams.
Cons: After 19 years, I have watched this company go from the cool young company to an IBM type of gold ol boys running the company. Not fun anymore. Very hard to get raises, company has major layoffs and restructuring every 2 -3 years. Management not diverse enough.

Pros:
I love everything about my job:
- smart people who are collaborative
- leadership team that is very strategic and thought leaders in the industry
- autonomy - freedom to be creative in solving the challenges we face
- work life balance
- workplace flexibility
Cons: Personally I don't see any downsides - I could not be happier with my job and the people I work with all seem very happy as well

Pros: Decent work culture, zeal for innovation and solve issues differently makes Cisco a very good place to work. Teams are equipped with multiple technical capabilities.  There is a bit of initiation on the  innovation just stared.
Cons:
Felt that Cisco needs to pay some attention on it's people.If you are a new hire, you may not complain but people stay for more than 5-6 years are not happy with what Cisco offers. 
Should push for more innovative ideas and adapt problem solving skills.

Pros:
- Strong and passionate community committed to Cisco's success
- Smart people
- Leadership honors commitment to grow people by giving rotation opportunities across the company
Cons:
- Frequent organizational adjustments can be disruptive at times. Have seen resources change direct reporting relationships four times within 2 months.
- Can be a fair amount of politics across teams, although no worse than I've seen at other companies.

Pros: Fast paced environment (for a big company); Smart people that work hard and play hard.  Genuinely committed to our customers success
Cons: Has become too bureaucratic; internal systems not built for shift to cloud/SaaS models, yearly layoffs hurt morale (we'll see if Chuck changes this); too many layers of management

Pros: I worked with leaders in the field. If you needed to talk to an expert in a given protocol or product you just picked up the phone.  Communication was very open. I have nothing but respect for those I worked with.
Cons: Eventually (after over 10 years there)I had to leave to grow my career. In Advanced Services if you don't work at it you can get pigeon-holed.

Pros: Both hard-soft skills to learn, and most colleagues are smart, nice, and tech savvy. Usually the eng daily work does not have too much load, so you don't have to be a workaholic. Work and life balance is expected. The culture part of cisco china facility can hardly meet its public image.
Cons: Some Chinese managers are not tech savvy but really good at playing politics and fooling around people, which is not a big problem in old water fall mode. But it's getting worse and obvious under Agile.

Pros:
Fantastic benefits (401K match, platinum healthcare, employee discounts on technology, gym, doc, therapists on site, 
Trusted name to have on your resume
Lots of change going on
Cons:
Chaotic culture - everyone loves a firedrill so they occur every day
A lot of passive aggressive politics in the mid level management
Not a 'fun' place to work. Culture changed as Chambers exited

Pros: Excellent company to work for, loved my job and the people I worked with. The salary and benefits are very good and the company has a great industry reputation. I would work there again if given the opportunity.
Cons: I was part of the Consumer Division of Cisco selling the Linksys home network products and Flip HD camcorder. Unfortunately, our division was not the focus of Cisco at the time due to low margin and heavy CE/Retail competition.

Pros:
Flexibility, great benefits, competitive salary, positive work environment
Have worked at another company since leaving and realized how well Cisco takes care of their employees. Current employees should be very thankful because the grass is definitely not greener on the other side.
Cons: Spend more time having meaningful 1 on 1 conversations with employees. Understand that as a business leader/manager

Pros: There are no pros. Required word count.
Cons: Doesn't care about innovation, people are resources and are disposable, efficiency doesn't matter, software engineering best practices are ignored, suggestions and feedback are ignored, internal tools suck, internal website unusable, frequent layoffs, outsourcing as much work as possible, speed over quality is their mantra, seniority is the only thing that matters not ability or being right.

Pros: visionary, innovative, taken as a reference in the market, have strong etichal values. In one word "AMAZING". Have strong processes and employees are making extensive use of the Corporate technologies to improve profitability and quality. The employees are really taken care of, from all perspectives: continuous learning, health care, benefits, career opportunities
Cons: The organization (and financial) structure is made in a way that makes doing business very difficult and fragmented. Each silo is looking at their own business objectives that are most of the time conflicting with those of the others and this in turn causes stress, latencies, frustration.

Pros:
+ Generous WFH. 1-2 days a week is normal.
+ Management trusts you to get the work done, so no micro managing (depending on which team/manager you have)
+ Opportunity to work on tough problems and work amongst the best in networking technology.
+ Work comes in cycles so the work-life balance is great during "down" time.
Cons:
- Stagnant growth if you just do the work you're assigned. You have to do better than that if you want to move forward AND be visible to upper management (very important).
- Lack of innovation - competition has caught up and Cisco's position as the market leader is declining.
- Salary is average, not great.

Pros:
1. The high level of technical expertise of the people you're working with.

2. Everyone helps each other in tough and highly escalated Service Requests.

3. Saying 'Thank you' for doing something extraordinary is not enough, you get rewarded for it.

4. The personal brand and the respect that you receive (and rightfully earned) when you work for Cisco Systems.

5. The support group within Cisco, not only with the work that we do, but also with the personal issues/stuff.
Cons: The only negative aspect of working with Cisco is that when customer opens a case, they expect you to fix/identify the issue even if the issue resides on a 3rd party product/platform.

Pros:
Solid technology in core areas
Brand reputation with customer base is still solid - if aging.
Cons:
Losing market share in EU across all product lines
As a high performer/high potential employee you will be asked to pursue projects or possibly rotate into another group to do something new.  The moment that "new" thing loses its political backing you WILL be laid off in a "Limited Restructure".  
A good Cisco employee is 60% worker and 40% politician.

Pros:
Very Good Work Culture.
Decent Perks.
Cons:
Salary is initially high, post which it hardly increases.
Cisco has never done salary correction to existing employees in last 5 years in our team.
Projects are often delayed due to lack of budget, or internal politics.
All hands at Director level are more of ritual than what they mean.
Too many re-org and restructuring and gives sense of insecurity.
Company lacks vision and many BU's future is uncertain.
Interview process filters out many talented employees due to outdated methods.
Managers aim at quantity and never emphasize of quality at grass root levels.
Too many managers who are dead weight to the ecosystem.

Pros:
You will work with some of the best and brightest. Come ready to learn - - your colleagues will be a major asset for you. Take advantage of their expertise. 

Cisco is very generous with work/life balance, offering much more flexibility than any other firm I've worked with.

Cisco doesn't cut corners, and as a result, has stellar industry-leading products. If you work in a Sales or Marketing role, as I did, the doors will be wide open to you. Cisco has partnerships with major players in almost every industry. You will have the opportunity to network widely within your field.
Cons:
The divide between  red and blue badges is wider here than at many other companies. If you get stuck in a contract role, you'll face a real uphill fight to get converted.

Decisions from leadership can  sometimes seem draconian. I've seen entire teams dismissed at the drop of a hat. Presumably these events come as the result of a compelling business reason, but that's not ever communicated clearly throughout the ranks, contributing to an overall sense of vulnerability among staff.

There are many BUs within the company that are siloed off from one another, making it difficult to streamline and share institutional knowledge. This can lead to inefficiencies and duplicated efforts. 

I can't honestly say that the executives' vision for the company is clearly communicated. It can be challenging to find after several months (or years) of working toward a target, that the target was moved by someone in the board room and your team wasn't informed.

It can be like pulling teeth to secure budget for certain projects, while leadership will rain dollars on other departments that they happen to favor. In some cases this makes sound business sense, but in some cases it seems inscrutably arbitrary.

Pros: Work-life balance, refreshed energy in the company and new leadership, and great opportunities for internal movement/growth. There is an internal jobs site that allows you to anonymously apply to various jobs within the company across all functions.
Cons: Typical large company challenges (duplication of work, managing up, etc.). Also, while I mention that there's room for growth (lateral and promotions) via internal movement, it can be a challenge to be promoted within your current role.

Pros: Military Friendly Culture empowers and gives transitioning veterans the opportunity to learn develop self to full potential. As a Military Retiree I feel there could not have been a better company to transition to than Cisco and the leadership team is very understanding and appreciative of what we bring to the table.
Cons: Some may say the constant changes, but as for a person who spent 22 years dealing with changes I think change is always good and welcome.

Pros: Great learning environment.  Ability to move laterally within the business. Good pay and benefits.  Great portfolio of products/services.  Excellent example of a company converting from pure product mentality to a service-driven culture.
Cons: Engineering teams are driven by fear and intimidation.  Leadership quality varies  greatly by organization.  Very few opportunities for vertical growth.  Too frequent RIFs and layoffs during transition.

Pros: Working from home, numerous financial benefits to compensate for substandard pay, lack of micromanagement enables you to 'create your own work'
Cons: Utterly incompetent middle management.  EXTREME politics.  Recognition has nothing to do with your work or efforts, it's entirely down to who you know.  Working from home means you're isolated and effectively a number rather than a person, which means the company considers you an asset similar to a mahcine, not a human being contributing to the business.  In short, a great place to add to your CV/Resume as long as you take advantage of the company and leave soon after joining.

Pros:
The office was nice and most teammates were helpful and collaborating
Good perks at the office
Flexible hours
Cons:
Entitled manager who thinks that he owns the company. He was always trying to scare us with the lay off to make us work much harder with no compensation, he used fear instead of support. TOXIC.
Zero regards to human life
Work was never appreciated even if we work 65 hours a week zero recognition and raises
I was treated like I was getting paid 1 million dollars annually, but my salary was even below average so I don't know why do they think they're paying their engineers well, if you calculate it based on 65 hours a week instead of 40(officially) you get minimum wage keep that in mind
I got another job with better pay thank god

Pros:
Outstanding benefits
Executive leadership talk with staff through all-hands meetings on a frequent basis
Ability to apply and change roles internally
Cons:
While Cisco is a large company, which provides opportunities to change roles/departments, being so large also is a negative (lots of processes, hard to find opportunities in the roles you are in)
The work culture depends on the team you are on, leadership are trying to create better alignment, but when people managers don't attend those meetings, it's hard to enforce the culture they promote
Frequent internal reorgs

Pros:
Fast paced and challenging work. Working at scale and at enterprise, means that there are some fun challenges to conquer.

The business respects work life balance, and we are given freedoms as a product to do what is needed.
Cons:
Bureaucracy especially when working with the larger Cisco portfolio. Sometimes a focus on selling or adding new features takes precedence over improving existing functionality, which in turn means accrual of tech debt.

Constant lack of resourcing means that we often find ourselves struggling to keep up. The commitment asks for new integrations, new features, often exceed our capacity.

Generally underpaid compared to market

Pros: If you love technology and live and breathe and learn it. This is the right place. IN general, in the earlier part of the career, this is the case.
Cons: As you grow further, promotions and salary bumps become smaller and smaller. On the other hand, you get afraid of what is out there and suffer unless you are bold enough to step out, and then you see how much more your value is. Work-life balance can be out of whack for some in CX who handle multiple accounts.

Pros: Get things right more often than not, try to care for people and empower, remuneration is good. There is no question the collaborative style of the company makes for a warmer welcoming environment, the leadership when good, is really very good indeed. Lateral movement is easy and geographic movement an option too
Cons: Layoffs .. stop the darn annual layoffs (which I think they are doing now

Pros: Market leader, lots of technology and flexible scheduling. Depending on what area of the business you are in and management, you can determine your career path. If you're in good with management and can get assigned the right projects, you can accelerate your career, otherwise you're a cog in a big machine.
Cons: Lots of politics going and jockeying for position. Talent is often times overlooked if you aren't a vocal person.

Pros: First of all, I am PROUD to work for Cisco Systems, as it is the leader in the high tech industry. Secondly, though all Cisco employees work very hard, we are all well compensated for our hard work. Cisco employees (from admins to sales) make an average of $130k per year. I am in sales, so if you are looking to run a business with the backing of a huge corporation, Cisco Systems is the place to be. The comany and management truly empowers their employees to reach success and grow with the company. At 24 years old, I make six figures and after less than 2 years in the field, I am already up for promotion. Stock options are great, beneftits are great, and the "work hard, play hard" mentality at Cisco makes it tremendously fun to work for this company!!
Cons: Though you pretty much set your own hours (nobody really breathing down your neck) the hours can tend to be long, if you are driven to succeed. Given everything is technology oriented, you can find yourself on your computer working long days into the late night and on weekends. You are required (and rightly compensated) to work whatever hours it takes to get the job done. If you can complete a task and be done by 4pm everyday...great. If you need to work until 10pm to get everything done that day, then that is what you must do. You are encouraged to take time off  away from Cisco, but that can sometimes be hard for people that are as driven as I am to succeed and exceed expectations.

Pros: The best thing about working for Cisco might just be that you if you are a competent and productive engineer, you have quite a bit of flexibility in defining your role and your contribution level. If you are really gunning for promotions, look for a good group, find a niche, take on roles that are difficult or un-wanted, and work your rear end off. If you want to coast and balance your time between work and other interests, then find a steady group, manage your time well, and you can stay safe in your job with just about 40 hours of work a week... and you might have the flexibility to telecommute or work from home.
Cons:
There is one other danger I must mention. This applies even in 'good' groups. There is a tendency at Cisco to just keep loading you with more and more responsibilities until you actually stand up and say enough. If this is an interesting job, you might find that you are spending more time on work than you had originally planned, at the expense of family, friends, etc. So decide for yourself how much you want to work and what your goals are. And then be prepared to work with your management to define the appropriate role.
No one will come and ask you what you want at Cisco. You have to decide that for yourself, and then communicate it to your management.
Also, if you do end up in a bad situation, be prepared to make an honest assessment of the situation and leave. No one likes to quit, but if you end up staying 5 or 6 years without fair rewards, you will find yourself falling well behind people who were your peers when you started... and this is really not a good experience.”

Pros:
The People and the Culture. Immediately with in the first week of starting my job, I was awestruck with the quality of people I was working with. It was like finding several needles in a hay stack. The intelligence of conversations were by far in large very intriguing. The people I worked with while in training will not only be colleagues but friends for ever. This is extremely important in helping shape your career, as in the future these will most certainly prove to be invaluable resources.

On top of this Cisco is committed to providing you endless amounts of resources to help further your career. You will be rewarded for your achievements and I am talking about the kind of reward that maters to most of the world...

The CSAP provides opportunities down several paths not just one which was important to me. Opportunities exist for you to work with in the industry that you desire. 

This was without a doubt one of the most rewarding times in my life, It is something I will look back on and feel proud to be a part of.
Cons: Well, we sure do work hard, which means working a lot. Be prepared to put in your fair share in. This may seem like a negative to some but you won't always have a manager that is telling you what to do. You have to further your learning by your self and find ways to create value. I take this as a blessing as I do not fit well into molds. Cisco will expect you to find your own right of passage but they will give you all the tools you need to feel empowered.

Pros: The caliber of people you work with.  Large company with lot's of opportunities to move and to grow professionally.  Many job types to suit all kinds of lifestyles.  Financially healthy with a respectful management provides for a harmonious work environment.
Cons: Globalization means long days, a bit of herd mentality is creeping in - be careful with better together slogan some people interpret it to mean everyone doing the same thing

Pros: It's a big company and the market leader. Great medical and health care plans and flexible work hours and places. An important tool for garnering that feedback is the Cisco pulse survey. This provides a confidential and consistent means for employees across Cisco to rate their experience with the company. I would recommend Cisco as a good place to work and would encourage people to join Cisco. Taking everything into account, I would say this is a great place to work.
Cons: It has all the downsides that all big companies tend to have.

Pros: Good pay, with some nice benefits, like a good remote access policy, free drinks, good cafeteria.
Cons: Cisco acquires all their companies. This creates "silos" where each company is still closely nit and not interacting with the rest of Cisco. This is commonplace, even among acquisitions that took play over a decade ago. It's hard, as an outsider to these groups, to get information out of them. Management needs to force their hands. Cooperation is not what it should be, even among people in the same department. Many employees have a view that if you can't do your work, it makes them look better.

Pros:
* interesting work if you choose to look for it. The base code has evolved over the last twenty+ years.
* great people
* telecommuting
* reasonable pay and benefits
* work / life balance
* both public and monetary recognition for a job well done
Cons:
The same problems one finds everywhere:
* politics politics politics
* Promotion is often based on cliques. 
* Far too many middle managers.
* no management consistency -- one manager will allow telecommuting, another will not.
* the company is no longer a startup, and new technologies are purchased, not developed in house

Pros: Strong and professional Sales leadership, overall a culture of respect, some good events and things here and there
Cons: no work-life balance, career dead end in some teams with unprofessional managers, limited internal job roles within, extremely difficult to get promotion, perks and benefits diminishing, some teams don't allow working from home with many multiple micro-management tactics, more and more political and bureaucratic, employee are getting more risk averse to take risks

Pros:
Four weeks of vacation.  You can take it all, however, it is usually interrupted with fire drills.

Good place to spend a couple of years to leverage into a better role elsewhere.
Cons: Make sure you negotiate salary before accepting a position because raises are worthless and opportunities for promotions are almost non-existent.

Pros:
1. Work Culture
2. Employer Friendliness
3. Salary
4. Various Technologies to work on
5. Career Growth
6. Various Trainings
7. Benefits and Bonus
8. Name & Recognition
Cons:
1. Need to introduce back free snacks and soda
2. Need to introduce back free internet service at home
3. Work Environment can be more friendly than what it is right now (I am not saying it bad but still it can be improved)
4. Lots of asian, put extra work hours and make mandatory sometimes for others as well though management doesn't demand this.
5. Need to introduce seek leave OR increase annual vacation days from 20 to 25.

Pros:
Good opportunities within IT to whatever technology you're interested in.
Salary and benefits fairly competitive.
Lots of opportunities within the company.
Management still has long-term focus.
Cons:
Grade promotions within IT are few and far between (it's better on the business side).
It's common to get pigeon-holed in your role/past work, and switching to a new role or getting growth often requires leaving your current organization.
Growth muted the last decade, restricting raises/promotions.
Moving around within the company can be a major effort if you don't know someone.

Pros:
Employees are smart and hardworking
Ability to work remotely based on personal preferences
Jobs are challenging
Usually very good job security
Cons:
After 6 years, salary is still 20% below bottom of pay grade, and no correction in sight
Management so swamped in their own contributions that there is no time to devote to developing their direct reports
Too much "corporate speak", bureaucracy, and self-promotion
No budgets for anything
People are increasingly frustrated and unhappy
Cisco is poor at follow-through - whether with a new product, a new program, or new plans to "re-organize" the company

Pros: Cisco is a very large company with lots of opportunity to learn. Internal transfers between teams and even business units are very easy. Can gain lots of valuable experience.
Cons: It's easy to get lost. Make sure to continue to acquire new skills, don't get complacent and happy with just doing a niche job. Unfortunately it is hard to move up the ranks. It's hard to get promoted when there are a lot of senior people in front of you.

Pros: Smart co-workers, good benefits, telecommuting options very helpful.  Lot of people cross trained in my department so it was great to have others available who could offer advice and time saving tips.
Cons: Unrealistic deadlines, extra work added at the very start of the job that wasn't originally discussed in interview process that added an additional 50% workload immediately.  Lot of team members spread across multiple time zones (9 total time zones) made it challenging to manage projects.

Pros: Great brand, monopoly position of company in business, profitable company. Great benefits. Good treatment of employees on an average except when it comes to recognition.
Cons: Huge waste, Extremely top heavy, Super deep empires by moron executives who care about nothing but their own promotions. Several product initiatives are simply exercises in fantasizing and preparing powerpoint slides for managing upwards.

Pros:
The work-life balance at Cisco is awesome.  You are given every tool and opportunity to be able to work at any time from anywhere.  Managers have always been understanding for even small things like soccer games and school assemblies.  As long as the work gets done and everyone is satisfied with your work, you are a valued member of the team.  

Cisco has an open, honest culture from top management.  There are still many perks, bonuses, and stock awards - though they are fewer in number.  Salary ranges are competitive as well.
Cons: Constantly changing priorities and management make it difficult to get velocity on a particular business initiative.  The size/weight of the company is a struggle.

Pros: Innovation Focus - Customers Matter - Results Driven and Fact based.  Cisco specializes in knowing and acting on key discontinuities - this means working on the leading edge - using with an enterprise wide architecture mental framework and truly helping Cisco customer create competitive advantage
Cons: Still challenging to get things done - admin and back-end process wise - but not as challenging as other large technology companies.  It is a large company so not as nimble perhaps as you might want - but the great things about Cisco is you can find find entrepreneurial niches in many of the business units

Pros: Flexible working options, good work environment and good pay.
Cons: Too much noise in emails and too many meetings to attend. No/minimum help for employees to succeed. No transparency in product delivery. Not sure whether your product/work will be released or put in cold storage.

Pros:
Great learning curve and everyday action packed place. Everyone get's a chance to produce and be recognized.

You work with amazing people everyday. How in tune you are with the organization's vision and the effort you put forth to contribute to that vision could reap benefits that go beyond recognition.

You are encouraged to participate in job rotations every 2 years or so to expand knowledge and exposure. You are expected to attend 40 hours of training yearly. Part of that training could be giving the training and being a Mentor or Mentee.
Cons: No downside. Action Packed place and yet learning encouraged, Work on weekday evening and weekends .. it never ends.
