Pros: One can be at the bleeding edge of networking technology at Cisco as it is a market leader in most of the segments it operates in. It also has significant engineering, sales and marketing resources which enables it to solve complex problems for the customer.
Cons: Cisco has merged and acquired teams for the past 30 years and while it has tried to keep the acquired teams together under their respective business units, it has allowed allowed the teams to develop into isolated silos. This has resulted in customers seeing inconsistencies across product lines. While Cisco is actively trying to fix this, it is an arduous process.

Pros:
Good work and life balance.
Flexible timings and Work From Home options.
Very caring and cooperative management.
Predictable bonus.
Cons:
Not many options for career growth.
Need to negotiate more before joining the company. Once if u r in , career  and packages grows very slower.
Need to be proactive to select a competitive work. Management allows u to work on an exciting project if you insist for it.
Most of employees need to follow up actively to get to know any new works are coming.
No profit sharing and no stock options.

Pros: Great infrastructure to support you in your job. Nice perks (although not as good as they used to be) and benefits. Good communication from upper management.
Cons: Rather bureaucratic. Have gotten a little cheap over the years - have eliminated free waters/sodas, reduced the lunchroom hours and raised prices, hard to get new monitors, etc. approved, almost zero travel budget for anyone but executives and salespeople, and so on. Haven't given out stock options in years, and raises are seldom.

Pros:
Great culture, fostered great friendships.
Lots of learning experiences and management can be open to providing opportunities to their team members.
Cons: Senior leadership appeared directionless at time. Numerous restructurings, shuffles and redundancies led to confused and disenchanted employees.

Pros: Benefits are awesome, comp is fair and maybe even above grade, support from the company is good
Cons: Boxborough, MA office culture for the Webex team was pretty awful. Stemming mainly from 1 Director and 1 Manager who were brothers (and allowed to report to each other - hello nepotism). They are since gone, so the culture is more friendly. Work/life balance not great within the Webex team. Not allowed to work remote. This might have changed since working there.

Pros: Still an overall good culture, lots of great people that still have a "change the world" attitude. Work-life balance varies by role but in my area it seems reasonable. Cisco name is still one to be proud of and we make a lot of great products.
Cons: With layoffs becoming a regular annual event since 2008,  a culture of fear is seeping in. Focus is becoming less on innovation and excitement, more on cost savings and following the rules. Less open-minded people are moving into senior management positions. What leaders say and what they do are not always matching up.

Pros: Stable company, very strong infrastructure & processes, challenging work, exciting projects, wonderful co-workers & team environment (may be from sharing the pain together), competitive compensation, very strong work ethic (a requirement for success here).
Cons: Confrontational environment, unrealistic expectations from engineers and teams, project success at any cost, treats vendors poorly, slow personal growth as company is stagnating.

Pros:
Great direction and strategy, the company does an excellent job of keeping up with market transitions and staying relevant 

Wonderful people

Good pay for the sales teams

The flexibility to work at home!
Cons:
Limited restructurings, layoffs and the like have become very common

Lack of job security - even if you are a top ranked performer, you can get cut if your team is impacted

Promotions are far and few

Employee rating system is awful - very demotivating!!

Pros: Diverse learning opportunities, invested in employees with training, Able to work remotely, wealth of knowledge, you could work all evening and still be left with much on your plate, access to partners in the industry
Cons: Annual layoffs the last 3-4 years, due to this would have a new manager, customers yearly, challenge to move swim lanes in career, many benefits that made Cisco special to work for the first 5-6 years eroded, acquiring companies then lack of proper development with some product lines, no clear career path or job openings after going through trainings, on/off again hiring freezes would derail opportunities

Pros: Cisco has very high quality senior management. High ethics and Fair play. Overall the Customer first  culture helps Cisco win in the market place. It is an Open work environment, with lot of flexibility at work eg. Work from home. No one looking over your shoulder. Generally a mature culture at work. Very employee friendly policies. and a winning culture.
Cons: Cisco like any large Global is an ocean with slack. People at middle ranks are beginning to loose their way. There is too much room for one to be a Cog, and too many overlay roles and functions.

Pros: you get a chance to work on advance technologies and with some great minds
Cons: Cisco keeps doing regular silent layoffs which make prevents CIsco from filling immigration petitions like Green Card. People keep waiting for years to get their PERM processed. So if you are looking for a sponsor to file GC for you then CIsco is not a place for you. Save your Big American Dream!

Pros: Great work from anywhere anytime to get stuff done depending on your organization.  Many smart people still left..
Cons: Standard benefits and pay at 50-70% industry. Yearly stack and shank the 40 and over or senior grade 10-12 is bad for business and for those effected and left to fend off the LR for another year while Director level and above do the slef preservation dance.

Pros:
- Very good work life balance throughout the company
- Company culture is excellent, everyone is willing to help out each other
- Slowly improving work environment that's comparable to other better rated companies
- A good amount of perks
Cons:
- Project can be slow pace at some times depending on team cause is a big company
- Like other big company there could be politics involved
- Random laid offs, probably due to too many work force

Pros: A good company to works for. Benefits are excellent and there is a lot of opportunity to move within the company.
Cons: Too much "Limited Restructuring" The company is going through a transformation and nobody is safe. Too much uncertainty. It has become a norm and everybody excepts the end of year layoffs which creates a very unhealthy work environment

Pros: Work on some of the most complex design and verification problems in the industry; business still generates a lot of profit (>$4B) for the company
Cons: The management team that built and grow the team are all gone now;  new managment has no idea what directions to go;  Company takes the profit and re-invests in other groups/markets that are growing.

Pros: professional atmosphere. a good mix of young in career and experienced professionals. love the fact that i have the opportunity to work flexible and when wanted form home or any other place. i'm judge for the quality of my work and not the hours i make. have been here for 10 years an developed my career in different areas.. all is possible within Cisco. Also great benefits - salary, pension, bonus, car allowance, education, health insurance, gym, mindfulness courses....
Cons: the restructuring that we need to go through. i understand the business decisions behind it but not always nice

Pros: I have been with Cisco for close to 17 years.  The company has offered me exposure, challenging work and the opportunity to make a meaningful impact.  I have been rewarded in many ways including compensation, internal and external recognition as well as special development opportunities.  I believe that Cisco Leadership values me and my work.  The company also allows for me to have a flexible work schedule which fits well into my lifestyle.
Cons: Although this is changing, Cisco has been slow to make decisions.  We need to move faster.

Pros:
Amazing workplace with a lot going on in Networking more than what you could imagine. The company always embrace innovation and pulls in new technology that comes in order to maximize their profits and provide a better service to their customer. Highly customer oriented. 
Provides flexibility in working hours to employees and provide awesome perks.
Cons: It takes time to get your hands on good quality of work. As the Networking is quite vast, be ready to learn something new almost everyday but if your work is ad-hoc and repetitive, there is no skill you would end up developing, So it really depends on which team you are in.

Pros:
First thing comes to my mind about this group : Always do the right thing to Customers which is evident in the way the backlog gets prioritised, the leadership works and the way teams interact with Customers & Partners. 

Some of the Pros I see : Emphasis on quality, freedom for teams/individuals to balance tactical tasks Vs innovation, ability to raise issues to senior management (with no fear or retribution), the 360 view of everything we do (debates leading to decision).

Overall : Great Products, Awesome Collaboration, Nice team, Amazing Passion all driven by the underlying practice!
Cons: None I see at the moment!

Pros: I was employed by the Cisco Consulting Services organization.  The was truly nothing positive about it.  I have never been a member of a more dysfunctional organization.  The only good thing I can think of is that four years have passed and perhaps corporate leadership has finally figured out how to build and operate a consulting services organization.
Cons: Everything ... poor mission ... poor leadership and management ... severe political infighting ... truly perverse managers with no understanding of how to lead and direct effort ... everyone watching out for themselves and "assassinating" others in order to advance.   I have never been a member of a more dysfunctional organization.

Pros: If you are working in India location, and have no big ambitions, life could be more or less cool.
Cons: Indian employees are treated not so well. Fun fund we are entitled to is $15 compared to $55 in US/Israel. On-call payment for Indians is $15 compared to $100 in US and $300 per week in Israel.

Pros: The culture at Cisco is really collaborative and transparent. There is constant and thoughtful communication so I can feel confident that I'm getting all of the information I need to do my job and understand the broader company. There is also a TON of talent at Cisco, and it's great to work with people who are as passionate and focused as me.
Cons: My team is spread out over the US so we don't always see each other in person, but there are several opportunities each year to meet as a group.

Pros: empowered to run with ideas; encouraged to move fast and do the right thing-  fantastic culture-  truly enjoy coming to work to engage with my team-  feel like I matter and I am an integral part of the overall success of our organization
Cons: a large company can't always move as fast as I'd like and having multiple systems with a ton of data can be overwhelming-  introduces complexity

Pros:
- Open culture.
- If you are self motivated, you have umpteen number of opportunities be it in project or competitions or trainings or travelling. Its amazing from employee policy to work culture everything
Cons: - If you are use to working on feedback based work or improvement. You may feel out of place in here. You need to have clear vision on how you want to progress and grow.

Pros: Good salary and benefits. Some teams are great, and some are horrible. It all depends on who your manager is.
Cons: In my time at Cisco, I have been discriminated against based on my gender, been bullied by senior management, and developed PTSD.

Pros:
- Employee centric -  drives a culture of really focusing on the employees and ensuring they feel empowered in their jobs every day, while also maintaining the development of the individual within the company
- Corporate Social Responsibility - Cisco does so many things to help give back to their communities by partnering with different organizations to help with certain crisis and issues all across the world with the use of their technology
- Good benefits
- People are super friendly and helpful!
- Ability to collaborate with individuals all across the global 
-Flexible work practices
Cons: There's really no con's I have to say about the company, it's truly amazing!

Pros:
it gives good opportunities to learn - udemy and another learning tools are freely accessible.
employee complaints are taken seriously
Cons:
internal movement to an other team not easy.
too dynamic situation,  they refine the team every now and then - so if one's manager doesn't appreciate your work (may be for genuine reasons..) one will lose the job.

Pros: Cisco has been awarded great place to work award two years a row for good reasons. The management team I've had the chance to work with really cares about the employees development, but also well-being. I've had the chance to work on very interesting project involving the latest technologies. The vast majority of team mates are focused on cooperation and not competition. Personal pro, the office is near the city center.
Cons: You need to be patient to get a raise or promotion. In some projects the working hours are difficult because you often get a mix of stakeholders from all over the world.

Pros: It's a great  place for career development, possibility of being in the action center. You can be part of great  projects such as Expo2020 creation in Dubai and many others. Social community is very active. There are  multiple clubs, programs. If something is missing you have possibility to initiate it!
Cons: Management has poor soft, team leadership skills.  Unable to handle more complex cases such as mobbing/bulling in the team.  It's difficult  to fight with  faulty corporation system.

Pros:
-Work life balance is mostly good, you are responsible for managing that, however, there are times when you have to step up. 
-Respectful environment, that is inclusive. 
-Cisco cares about your long term professional growth and allows job rotation
-Benefits are good. 
-I have worked in several places and this is good. 
-Cisco employees are motivated, innovative and finish what they start.
Cons:
-Sometimes people are people.
-Deadlines and changes that are fast and huge take more effort and dedication. 
-Nothing really bad to say.

Pros:
A very well established India presence with load of opportunities at work, customer exposure and skill building. Company encourages internal movement to explore various facets of work. With facilities to work remotely, BYOD etc, you can take your work everywhere. Besides core work, a number of activities on campus, partnerships with NGOs, time to give - you can take 5 days in a calendar year to contribute to any community initiatives - either via company or in a personal NGO.
Facilities on campus from a fully equipped large gym to badminton/basketball/yoga room and places to relax and unwind, Cisco has it all!
Cons: None I can think of.

Pros: I have stayed at Cisco 8 years despite many times being recruited by other large tech companies. I feel I am very fairly compensated for the work I do but mostly feel a strong loyalty to Cisco for how I've been able to achieve an amazing work/life balance through taking advantage of remote working. I've always worked for managers many states away, communicating regularly but not too often, by Cisco's HD video technology. I've never been micromanaged and always been empowered to work when, where and how I choose as long as I am performing and excelling at my deliverables. This has allowed me to very successfully transition in to my new life as a working mom where unlike most of my friends I haven't had to make the choice between career and present parenting. I can truly do both, even as a breastfeeding mother and didn't have to take a single step back. Maternity leave was ridiculously generous and long enough that I actually felt excited to come back to work (especially since I work from home near my baby and nanny). The other perks for new moms that Cisco provides are over the top generous between milk stork, $100 lactation store credit, stuffed animals and baby books mailed to my home, free lactation consultant, and more. So thankful for Cisco and the wonderful career, no, wonderful LIFE, working here has afforded me. No reason I wouldn't spend my whole career here as I believe these benefits are unique to Cisco in the tech world. Speaking of the actual work I've always been empowered and encouraged to pursue new and interesting opportunities across many departments and job titles. I've always been promoted and given raises before I even thought to ask for them. Cisco has treated me really well.
Cons: Being a huge company there is some waste and duplication of efforts which can be frustrating at times.

Pros:
A Customer Success Specialist (CSS) is a technical person, who is given the task of acting as a technical consultant for customers, in the post-sales stage. The goal is helping customer with product adoption.

The daily job is a mix of studying/practicing with the technology, on one side, and engaging with customers in meetings and workshop, on the other: so, it's a very interesting mix between technical and "soft" skills. 
It's particularly indicated for technical people who have a passion for explaining, helping, engaging with people. It's the ideal position for people with a strong technical background, who wish to move a little bit towards the business and the communications side of the IT work.

The Customer Success organization in Cisco is still very young, which gives an opportunity to stay in an enthusiastic environment and to shape the organization, because many processes still need to be finalized.
At the same time, it's a growing part of the company, because Cisco's vision is to focus more and more on recurrent revenues, and therefore on subscription renewal, and therefore on adoption.

Being a post-sales role, there is not excessive pressure, because CSSs are not measured in relation to a sales quota. This gives time to learn, and to establish a good life/work balance.
Cons:
The cons are exactly the other side of the coin, if compared to the pros.

E.g.: Since Customer Success is a young organization, things are changing very often: the management is changing ideas and adjusting the strategy very frequently. This is not ideal for people who like to stay on a solid ground, or to be constantly told what to do.

Another example: since the role is post-sales and not bound to sales quotas, as a result the compensation and the incentives won't be so high as in a sales role. But, in turn, you get lower pressure and stress.

Pros:
People are approachable and ready to help.
Projects are really good and learning curve is really good for initial 4 years
Lot of cross functional teams to deal during the phase of project as most of products require multiple department to collaborate and build one product
PTO's are good total 20
Allowing to work from home depends on your manager
Lots of social around the year and 1 team lunch quarterly.
Opportunities to take courses provided by Cisco
Cisco Exams and certifications are free
Cons:
Salary is the issue. medium - low salary compared to other big companies.
No free food except during socials.
Recognition for your work is not that great

Pros: Good Benefits at a low cost. Bonuses can be solid. Still WFH with a promise of a hybrid office in 2022. Pretty secure job as long as you show up. Generally great co-workers.
Cons:
They track PTO which is odd for a “tech” company in Silicon Valley.
Stock hasn’t moved much in years.
They pay is fair, but people have gone years without a raise of 2-3% even when the company performs well.
Few management opportunities and almost no management training.

Pros: Big Company with a lot of interesting development work to be done. Moved from working on an on-premise deployed software solution to working on their WebEx Cloud offering. Learned a ton, met many incredibly smart people, and overall had a great time.
Cons: Like any big company the processes can be a bit heavy at times and things don't always move as fast as you'd like. But having since switched jobs to a small startup I have to admit that I find myself missing much of the oil in the machinery that a big company offers.

Pros:
good benefits

good days off
Cons:
political culture, even at a team level. 

no feedback on work other than "nothing to say" or "you shouldn't be here" (then later, "nothing to say")

culture is completely dead, soulless.

basically a technological backwater at this point, ridiculous decisions made at every level. 

priorities not really aligned with making good products, company is doomed in some areas.

all the other reviews are absolutely true, the company is filled with bad management. I didn't believe it, but sure enough 

I honestly don't understand why people stay here for years, I cant imagine doing so.

Pros: Good work-life balance and online training subscriptions.
Cons: Pay is average and almost no pay hikes once you joined unless you're promoted. Leadership team biased to liberal politics and act like they are running for office with too many social  initiatives. Employees who opposed the opinions of progressive ELT team with conservative approach got fired.

Pros: Dynamic place, lots of different work alternatives for work and career if you are competent and adaptive
Cons: Some of the project work can be grueling. Some key work goes to outside consultants that are compensated at much higher rates than FTEs, which can be quite demoralizing for the teams in the long run.

Pros:
Stable employment. Cisco is trusted in networking world very well. 
No one gets fired for buying cisco.  Good employer to be with during downturn.  competitive pay and bonuses.  4 weeks of vacation. Located in beautiful san jose. 
Nice co-workers. Cisco respects employees well. Diversity is celebrated well. Senior leadership is strong.
Cons:
Too large. You are in one in thousands.  Not much innovation inside the company.
Takes a long time to make any impact.  Lot of layers of management.  Typical
disadvantages of working for a very large enterprise company. Not the best place
to be at the bleeding edge of networking industry.

Pros: Tremendous felxibility and great work/life balance with an extremely competitive compensation package. Very autonomous work atmosphere which allows the employee to be creative in their solutions while working at a pace that best suits their abilities. Great leadership guiding the company going forward and a tremendous amount of high growth opportunities on the horizon for the company.
Cons: Slow moving (as with a lot of large companies), too many inefficiencies and redundancies, lack of visibility to senior management.

Pros: Very stable employer.  I contracted here during the financial crisis, and I was allowed to stay for the entire duration of my 6 month contract.  If you want to advance here, you do need to work your butt off and understand big corporation politics, but this organization is large enough that opportunities exist in enough places.
Cons: Really hard to stand out.  Hope you get a good tech lead and/or manager for this in engineering.

Pros:
* Flexible work hours
* Management not averse to employees working from home
* Company gym is convenient
* Used to be able to attend classes, but that seems to be changing with budget cuts.
* 401K match is decent. 100% match upto 4% contribution.
Cons:
* Unbearable levels of politics.
* Unhealthy Performance Review process. Because they need to document why they are unable to promote you, management purposefully kills your self esteem. The process is very unhealthy. The purpose of the epm is no longer a tool for healthy development, but rather a tool for managers to 'keep score', put you down, and keep you 'under control' - these are actual words I have heard. It happens 3 times a year, and for this alone, avoid this place.
* Its a big company, but management is constantly ratcheted under pressure. What happens is people run very fast, work under a lot of pressure, but with the added huge overhead of a big company. And they run round and round, instead of making progress. People who say things are slow are not working in engineering groups where the pressure is immense and very unrewarding.
* Benefits are cut almost constantly. 
** The paycheck contributions for Health has been going up ever since I joined 4 years ago.
** We used to get free water bottles - that's gone. 
** We are expected to attend meetings late at night, early mornings, and work weekends but Cisco will not pay for broadband (that went a couple of years ago).  How can they expect you to work weekends? Oh, they will not say that directly. It will be more like an email late Friday evening asking you to fix a problem by 9am Monday. 
** We used to have receptionists in buildings - helpful when you have visitors, that's gone. 
** This may sound mundane, but it is a bad experience for men - they removed water flushes from all men's rooms. It's in the spirit of going green, but the toilets stink - at least they should have more janitorial service, but instead they keep cutting that as well. The janitorial service has picketed in Cisco at least two times to my knowledge.
* There is no face to Human Resources. There is a 408 number is San Jose, but you will be hard pressed to find the number on the intranet. They are making it harder and harder to open cases for anything, probably discouraging you to do so. I heard most of HR has been off-shored.
** We used to get free access to safaribooks, but now departments get charged and so you are not sure of access. This is such a simple perk with huge ROI for Cisco and even that they cut.
** I once opened a case with WPR (Work Place Resources) saying my chair was bad. Some one evaluated it and a week later I got a chair must worse that what I had! 
** When I wanted to move to another group in another building, the Secretary told me not to move because Cisco is not approving moves. I said I am in engineering and cannot work in another building while the rest of the team is in an another one. I was told that it would be better if I moved everything myself otherwise Cisco will end up rejecting the move. I couldn't believe what I was hearing!

I cannot believe Cisco keeps getting voted one of the best places to work for. Everyone I speak with seems to be unhappy. I think a lot of folks stay here because the pay is good and mainly because of family and mortgage commitments  and commute. As an engineer I felt completely unwanted from the day I joined.

Pros:
-Job security (won't get fired/laid off unless you are a complete idiot...and even then, probably not)
-Work life balance (4 weeks paid PTO...easy to take time off, reasonable work hours)
-Convenient amenities for SJ employees (health center, gym, daycare, etc)
-Decent benefits package (although healthcare costs rise every year)
Cons:
-Stagnant pay (won't get a pay increase without a promo, promos are nearly impossible to come by)
-Politics - It isn't what you do, its who you know and how well you can brown nose/take credit for others' work to get ahead
-Consensus based culture - Too many cooks in the kitchen...everyone needs to "buy off" on initiatives; creates tremendous bottlenecks to the point of not getting anything accomplished
-Turf wars amongst management - Makes it even more difficult to get ahead and get stuff accomplished
-Unqualified leaders - In the mid-late 90s, when Cisco was growing rapidly, they needed to hire bodies; many were unqualified and lacked even a college degree; now these losers are in leadership positions and have power trips; will backstab to stay ahead, since they know they can't on their abilities alone
-No training/development budget - Continuous learning is difficult when there's no budget at all for training/certifications and conferences/travel
-Generally, old stodgy work environment - Not much camaraderie when many folks are over 50, don't want to work hard and are just collecting their paychecks

Pros: Front line management is very well aware of the issues that exist at the top, however they cannot makeup for the short comings of a senior executive team that has led the company in the wrong direction.
Cons: The boards and councils structure the company conducts business under allows the use of rampant political games that are destroying the company from within.

Pros: Cisco Systems is the leader in the Networking domain. Being part of  SAVBU - the datacenter unit is very fortunate. It gives the benefits of a large company while the quality/quantity of the work remains that of a startup => you get to learn a lot of things and a lot of scope for personal development.
Cons: Since Cisco is a huge company, irrespective of how your BU performs, the hikes and the bonuses are most of the time normalized so that all the BUs are treated equally.

Pros: Great salary and benefits, flexible schedules, and interesting work.
Cons: Things have gone downhill since the big tech crash in 2002. Management seems to care more about the bottom line financially than actually providing quality products. Successful products are cut or shipped overseas to die. Jobs are outsourced. Employees are asked to do more with less and the good benefits are chipped away, little by little. It's gone from a fun place to work to fairly depressing. I'm sure it varies by department, but this my experience as a 15 year employee.

Pros: Room for growth. If you take initiative you can go far. Many ways to get involved.  Cisco has a great volunteer program that lets the employees contribute their time to good causes. Good teamwork and collaboration within Cisco.
Cons: The employee evaluations are sometimes difficult to compile. The employee needs to asses themselves, then the manager gives input.  Here is where you list your accomplishments and classes you have attended.  Unfortunately, the admins are grouped together with the teams they support, so it is hard to rank high compared with team members that do more complex jobs.

Pros: Full flexible timings, work from home, no dress code, Won't see work pressure often as it's a product company, good pay, variable pay will be more than 100% always, awesome work culture, Very good company benefits like highest medical benefit in the industry. Will become lazy due to work style and get addicted to company.
Cons: Constantly laying off employees every year worldwide but no problem for the employees who work well. Hikes and promotions mostly depends on our managers. Won't see much change in the work.

Pros: global leader, brand, compensation, technology leadership, international foot print, customer recognition, cisco is definitly one of the best place to work
Cons: work life balance some times tough, especially with young kids. Grey ceiling for mid to senior management positions exist despite recent slim down of that part of the organisation. culture has been deteriorating over the last couple of years, but remains strong especially in the sales organisation. in general, the company is looking at streamlining the mgt chain with a reduction of the people sitting in the fat belly of the organisation. Good for cisco, good for the good performers.

Pros: Bright people, good work/life balance, good medical benefits
Cons: Frequent Layoffs of great and talented people, Lack of Quality Managers

Pros: High degree of remote employment opportunities;  good level of internal experience and exposure.  Cisco typically is at the cutting edge of hardware/software platforms.
Cons: Often high pressure;  performance review process is sub-par;  has not been fair to U.S.-based employees.  Cisco's days as a U.S.-based company are LONG gone, with a preference toward many of the offshore teams;  therefore, U.S. workers are having less and less true job security.  Witness the global re-org last fall....

Pros:
Great Work-life balance! There is a lot of fexibility and posibility to work remotely. 
The cisco culture is welcoming. Many events happen ( if you can find time to participate) to relax and contribute to a positive environment. For a fresher, the pressure is less and can spend more time honing his skill set !
Cons:
There is no direct visibility.  Like in most companies, career growth depends on the project.
Personal growth is not great. No much perks apart from the intially good salary slip, and it doesn't really increase as expected with time. (Juniors who were hired were offered more than two year experienced guys.)

Pros: The company invests in it's employees with on-going training to assist you in your job role.  The training is good, it really benefits the department and employees.  The management is structured and is pretty flexible in it's ability to make changes, they are very forward thinking and demonstrate it in it's everyday management of the employee's ability to try new things and step out of the box.
Cons: The stress level is very high, the demands are high.  They give you freedom but everything lives and dies around making the numbers every month.

Pros:
Great people and products.   
John Chambers finally left.  It was time.   Company had good years under him but also company grew stale under him.
Nice buildings.
Nice cafeterias
Cons: They took away employee perks and don't even give you free drinks anymore.  I think we are lucky we get free coffee still.  They took away cafeteria subsidies.  A lot of Bad acquisitions.

Pros: Flexible employer, easy to work from home, six weeks vacation for Norwegian employees. Also, in many ways remarkably open in sharing information publicly for a company in this industry, which is sympathetic.
Cons:
Yearly layoffs euphemized as "limited restructuring" for many years in a row, with little and mostly useless information to the organization both leading up to and after the layoffs.

Lack of clear direction for many functions and products, leading to uncertainty and frustrations. In many cases horrible coordination across sites, teams, and time zones on larger projects and programs, which the org seems to struggle to admit to, pretending cross-site collaboration is a cinch.

Pros: Pays well.  Excellent benefits and lots of perks (including local gym).  High integrity.  Very flexible (work from home at times)
Cons:
Constant layoffs.  Company is going thru a transformation and several people have been laid  off over the last few years.

Managers do not work as hard, and keep their jobs.  Engineers are usually those that end up being laid off.

Pros: Good benefits.  For the most part management open to teleworking. Good technology, top in their field.  Stable Company, money in bank. Salaries competitive.
Cons: Promotions difficult to get. Will try to bring you in at a level or two below what you are worth -- don't bite. Aggressive acquisition strategy leads to yearly layoffs which they disguise as limited restructuring. Say they want you to be innovative don't believe them, they buy their innovation, and when it comes down to it not appreciative of it.  People management skill level low.

Pros:
1) Big company , has mature product lines , lot of people for a task , relatively peaceful, easy to maintain work life balance.
2) global company has office through out world , encourage across office movement for performing employees.
Cons:
1) getting a challenging work can be tough task.
2) you need to vocal about things else you may get unnoticed.
3) Since mature company , hiring up the people ladder can be daunting task.

Pros:
We work in offices surrounded by smart, passionate and very friendly people. The company itself is extremely fast paced and proactive. They are always bringing in new tools and initiatives for us to get involved in and try, providing lots of opportunities to communicate and work with people all over the world. It is a great opportunity to build a global network but does take time.

Workplace satisfaction is very important therefore we have a range of facilities to use.
Cons: Being a global company has its benefits but also processes can be timely due to its size.

Pros: You are treated like an adult. No micromanaging but I guess it depends on the manager/supervisor. Great working environment - 40 hours volunteer hours, 20 days paid vacation - first year; company shuts down for a winter break between Xmas and New Years. Work is challenging but very rewarding. Team works seamlessly with no drama or gossiping.  Flexibility to work at home as needed.  Bonuses are written into offer letter.
Cons: If you work in a small office, there may not be the advancement opportunities unless you are willing to relocate.  Have heard that raises are hard to come by.

Pros: Decent pay, good benefits, flexibility to work wherever you want.
Cons: Company is in mature to declining state creating highly political work environment, layoffs every year, stagnant wage growth, and almost no opportunity for career advancement.  Company has almost no ability to innovate and senior management that only care about making money for themselves and friends (at employee and shareholder expense).  Annual reviews are really more popularity contests than reflection of work product and achievement of objectives...

Pros: It's a large company so there is a lot of internal opportunity for those who can build relationships and always focus on the right things at the right times.
Cons: It's a large company so it is possible for high-value employees to be lost. Cisco has, over time, become a very process-driven company which, in my opinion, has contributed to an overall segmentation of roles. This means that if it ain't your job, they may not listen even if your ideas are better.

Pros: The work environment is challenging however the compensation is good. Sometimes it is difficult to strike an acceptable work / life balance. It is a multinational corporation.
Cons: Career advancement is limited. The company is in the process of evolving it's business strategy. Some leaders have been in roles too long which they are not suited for. Once an individual turns 50+ they look to move on in many cases.

Pros:
Awesome classes and certifications that just need your manager approval. 
Great flexibility for working remotely (but also needing to take meetings early morning or late nights if you were in a global role) 
Health center, massive gym and cafes on-site.
Cons: Their acquisition integration is always rough. They don't do a good job on bringing a lot of new people in without a ton of upset and drama. They always end up losing good people because of it. I think all of the "cisco" legacy people were gone not long after the Sourcefire acquisition.

Pros: Interesting work and many very bright colleagues.  If you are in the right organization, the fast-paced leading edge work can be very energizing.  Many opportunities to learn and keep skills and knowledge current.
Cons: The culture has shifted tremendously over the last 5 or 6 years and politics is rampant.  There is a systematic effort to get rid of older employees despite their qualifications.  Although there are some very good managers, there is an equal number of poor managers.  Too many shoot from the hip decisions being made.

Pros:
Strong and broad portfolio
Competitive workforce
Cash strong balance sheet
Relevant to Customers
Cons:
Too frequent changing direction and strategy 
Too many layoffs
Too short -term focused investments and decisions (handcuffed by Wall Street)
Slow innovation, reliance on acquisitions, integration with acquired companies seems poor in most cases (exception is Jasper) 
Cloud computing and utility consumptions models will kill Infra companies unless they reinvent in the right space and live it out with convictions for a while

Pros: Cisco is reinventing itself. I came in through an acquisition and it's been a fantastic experience. There's a lot of opportunity to move around Cisco if you get tired doing what you're doing after a few years.
Cons: Company needs to be more HR flexible on comp, grades, etc. As a manager, it's tough to do what we need to recruit and retain great talent. Most policies are designed for a 70,000 person company, which is fine, but there needs to be way more flexibility around exceptions for exceptional people.

Pros:
-Extremely collaborative, team centric environment
-Very easy transition from 22 year Army career 
-All of my co-workers are extremely supportive and genuinely have my back
-Cisco is more like a family than a workplace.  Work/Life balance is amazing.  (It only gets difficult when it is my own doing, I love the work I do)
-Plenty of opportunity for growth and career advancement
Cons:
-Hiring process can be somewhat drawn out and cumbersome
-The current FY19 transformation can be frustrating to navigate but overall is exciting and

Pros:
Great people to work with, very professional with a skill set that is very high. 

Amazing Team working with people across the whole world where you always can get high professional help whenever you need it. 

Management is truly inspiring and is always there if you need anything.
Amazing turnover of the whole company in the last 18 months,  on a fantastic ride in the digital transforming of the world.

Come and join us on a fantastic journey.
Cons: Could be a bit of a "silo" mode then it´s a large company with many product lines.

Pros: If you find the right team, it can be a wonderful place to work.  End up on the wrong team and it can be hell.  Work from home policy is generally up to your manager, and they tend to be flexible if you perform.
Cons: Raises and promotions can be difficult to come by, and they are middle of the pack when it comes to pay in the Silicon Valley.  You won't work here for the money.

Pros: The pros would be that you have flexibility to learn what you what. You are given the freedom to explore your talents and the managers and team encourage you to excel. You can be yourself and people respect you for that. It really is an amazing paced to work. I always feel like my team has got my back and that I can contribute to the success of the team and company.
Cons: Since the company is so large, the roles are segmented, so its hard to learn a bit of every role like you would in a start-up.

Pros: Best employee welfare and culture to look after its employees. One of the best places to work in many countries. I have worked with Cisco in 3 continents and its easily the best place to work. Many benefits like Work from home, birthday offm, 5 days of paid leave to do charity work, macbooks at work.
Cons: Execs are disconnected from the challenges of the sales force on the ground. Its become a slow company to adapt to change, however, with leaders like Gerri and Chuck - things are improving.

Pros: Great culture and senior leaders. Very people first approach that is embodied by HR's "conscious culture." You really get to work with smart people.
Cons: Decision making is slow and too bureaucratic. Because promotions are so few and far in between the it creates too much hierarchy at that top and has incidents where new promising talent needs feels like they need to overly self promote to be recognized. That has the potential to lead to toxicity and insecurity.

Pros: Chaotic mix of acquired companies. Desperate to hire people. Recently bought by Cisco, so a chance to move to a better job?
Cons: Low pay. Confusing "organic" systems. We deal with all operating systems, VM's, physical servers, EC2, Elastic, Azure, etc.. with random systems/services running on any of these. There is no up to date documentation. It is just ugly and is never going to get better.

Pros: You have the backing of a well rooted company in Cisco. Job security isn’t top of mind.
Cons: It seems Cisco is realising it make a mistake with AppDynamics. The product has stagnated, new product roll-outs are fraught with deep technical issues, the revenue generated by AppDynamics pales in comparison with other acquisition companies. As such, budget is non-existent, hiring freezes are the new norm, and attrition is only increasing Whilst Cisco figures out a path forward for this ailing acquisition. Sales culture is deeply toxic, borderline abusive in some cases. Pay is unbelievably disparate, support teams are woefully underpaid and under resourced. You will be worked into the ground, it doesn’t matter the role you are in.

Pros:
Cisco is an arms dealer - as internet technoligies and appliceations get more and more pervasive nad popular, as data and voice gets more and more critical to business and commerce - Cisco only stands to gain. 

Good company, healthy culture, great benefits, good inter transfer opportunties
Cons: Matrix organization can be difficult to work in, silos and turf wars happen often, if you are in corp then San Jose is where you need to be to get ahead. Promotion seems to happen only when you look like you will leave otherwise - not because it is deserved

Pros: The name of the company. That is the only reason I can think of. It would have been a great company if Cisco spends more time investing in US and not in India.
Cons:
Everyday passes we see our jobs and projects gets transfered to India. Most of
the first/second level managers are Indians and they like to promote with in
their "circle of friends".  Obviously they prefer the projects to go to India 
so one day they can all go back.

Pros:
Flexibility - management very open to remote workers; can take time off when needed
People - I am blessed to work with a very strong team, both in the immediate group as well as the extended team; these folks are extremely dedicated
Cons:
Career advancement - little focus on hiring internal employees for open jobs; starting to get better
Benefits - no big difference from other companies of this size
To make game-changing decisions, you have to go through too many layers of management

Pros:
Latest technologies and always expanding
Generally smart people 
Travel opportunities outside the US
Will stay in business while many other companies may not be there in future
Cons:
Very little promotional opportunity unless you are well connected and part of the clicks
Very long hours
Compensation being managed down for many years - aims to be in the middle of the industry
Stock never moves - no more options given
No job security - if you have a bad acct or bad BU you are cut irrespective of years in the company and performance

Pros: The cisco choice program is an excellent programs which gives the new grads the option of choosing the group that they want to work for. Also, being a large company, there are hundreds of internal opportunities and hence you need not look for a new job outside the company very often :-).
Cons:
Being a large company, things are slow and old fashioned for the Gen-Y. Cisco is a marketing/sales driven company rather than a engineering driven company which makes things a little slower from technology perspective. 
Promotions and professional growth is slower as most of the management is made of technical leads who do not know much about managing people.

Pros: Love working with high quality people, everyone gives it their all.  We have world class products and are slowly building a story to support them.
Cons: BUs work in siloes.  Very little money for raises.  Most people have not received raises in many years.  Sadly, the solution seems to be to leave Cisco and then come back.

Pros: I work from home 100% of the time which allows me to maximize work / life balance.  It is nice to be treated like they trust you.
Cons:
I've never had a manager that I felt "advocated" for me.  It is a very political environment which I found to be demoralizing.  

They provide the benefits that I think any company should (medical, visual, dental, 401k, etc).  I thought it was still very expensive for the employee; I've had much better at smaller companies.

Pros: With such a big organization, there are many opportunities to try new things.  Also, you get a great degree of flexibility, generally to work as much or as little as you choose and where and when you choose.
Cons: It is very difficult and slow to move up the ranks.  Also, the entrepreneurial and collaborative culture mean no one is in charge but everyone has to sign off on things before they move forward, making it slow moving.

Pros:
* Pay and benefits are very good
* Engineering talent is top notch - much to learn from your peers
* Work/life balance better than it used to be
Cons:
* HR has become too fragmented - mistakes are made and there is no single point of contact for new hires
* Way too top heavy at middle to upper management and councils. Layoffs typically impact those doing the actual work and management doesn't realize the mistake until it's too late.
* Becoming more risk averse and less innovative

Pros: The best part of working for a networking giant is that our network connects into our homes so working from home or the office can feel the same.  The benefits are not bad but have slowly degraded over the years.  And the salary seems to be tops for the Austin area.
Cons: I have not had a raise in 4 years and there is always the fear of being affected by a layoff in the future.  There are no electric car hookups at the offices in Austin.

Pros:
Work life balance, flexibility. Ability to take off time to care for young child, aging parent. 
Ability to work across multiple technologies, change groups, roles.
Cons: Late working hours with global teams, Extremely slow promotions. The company is good for someone who is not looking for growth but only needs a steady pay check. Upper management positions are mostly filled from outside or through acquisitions.

Pros:
Learned foundations of computer networking
Got very good at debugging software
Got visibility into company operations
Good coworkers
Cons:
Lots of corporate politicking in upper management
Mergers and layoffs resulted from misaligned, redundant, and competing business units

Pros: Good salary and PTO policy and opportunity to learn. CISCO encourages employees to rotate to other positions within the company. Even the multiple ongoing rounds of layoffs are handled as gracefully as such things can be, with sensitivity to those affected.
Cons: Lack of communication. There are too many oddball managers in too many departments who are technically adept but lack people management skills. The Finance organization has been struggling to find the right blend of San Jose-based, India-outsourced, and North Carolina RTP-based job mix.

Pros: Great management overall; good salary/benefits; inspiring place to work in terms of contributions to the world; for such a big company, adjusts surprisingly quickly to market issues and opportunities.
Cons: Of late, the company has had numerous re-orgs and the most recent one let go some personnel who were solid contributors which is impacting morale.  Also, it appears there's a tops down push to simply eliminate some processes.

Pros: Flexibility of working remotely.........Cisco provides CVO routers and equipment for your home office.  With WebEx and your camera you feel connected at all times
Cons:
........you feel connected at all times............my job was global so the hours can be long

'collaboration' is excessive.  A leader needs to step up an make decisions.

Pros:
- State of the art technology enabling Collaboration & working from home
- Ethical culture coming from Top Management
- Employees have a high sense of urgency (rare in large organizations)
- Top Management is high quality and clearly communicates the Cisco vision
Cons:
- Hot-desking (no individual desk) leading to no "sense of belonging"
- Excessive use of collaboration, "back-to-back webex calls" starting at 07h30am
- Overworked/Overstressed staff never available for informal discussions
- Overcompetitive career-conscious Managers stressing out their staff

Pros: A nice place to work in. Good work life balance. Telecommuting is the best thing to happen. Top leadership is good.
Cons: Work progress is centered around your manager's ability to take the team forward. A manager with a very average vision and intelligence can hamper your growth here. Nothing is done to correct or train managers in this regard. Mediocrity has already set in.

Pros: Cisco pays, they have great benefits, flexible work and excellent vacation time (paid time off and floating holiday pay) :)
Cons: If you are a woman, you will be in a boys club and you will deal with sexism every day. If you have a baby, prepare for the sexism to be amplified and for a ride on the mommy-track. Sad but true.

Pros: It is a big company with many different facets and is spread across the entire globe. You can move around and find something to your liking. When they claim end-to-end network support, they truly mean it and can deliver. The overall compensation including benefits is  good.
Cons: Engineering process is overwhelming and due to legacy+large installed base very hard to change. Depending on release schedules, work-life balance will get upset. Various groups do not work as a single entity.

Pros: Competitive compensation, particularly bonus.  Established company with dominant market share in numerous markets.  Great flexibility in the workplace - remote workers supported.
Cons: No top line growth for years.  Leadership team not setting clear direction for company to follow.  Too much time spent internally focused in meetings and not enough on customers, the market and the competition. .

Pros: Excellent autonomy - Able to define own vision within responsibility and act on it.  They are very interested in your career path, but have difficulty in execution - but improving.  Work/Life balance is generally very good, but can get skewed if you don't stop it.
Cons: Politics - your promotability, salary increases and bonuses can be subject to those within your org which you don't directly work for.  'Visibility' outside your team but within your org is critical.  Seems that their regular 'restructuring' activities is utilizing layoffs as a standard practice.

Pros: Most of the people I work with are great. Very smart and good team players. Compensation and benefits are top notch. I've been given great opportunities in the 8 years I've been there.
Cons: Wayyyyyyyy too much politics, turf wars at higher management levels (and sometimes at the lower levels) and it's absurd to me that good employees get laid off every year when the company has billions (literally) of cash in the bank. There's also pressure to make your work the number 1 priority in life.

Pros: Benefits, peers, educational development, I work from home
Cons: Lack of focus, entrenched management, failing executive leadership, low salary

Pros: Excellent commission scheme. Very good culture and working environment. Market leadership in most of the products it carries and sells in the market. Technologically advanced products widely acknowledged leader and innovator in its field. Excellent pool of top engineers and sales experts. One of the most desired IT company to work for. Most flexible working environment with best mobility and telecommuting solutions provided the employees.
Cons: Very tough sales cadence. Weekly / monthly / quarterly commit and forecast review. Health coverage can be better. Target of almost every other vendor in the industry due to its breath of products and services.

Pros: I liked the diversity of employees hired as contractors. Working conditions include flexible hours and lots of challenging opportunities.
Cons: If one is looking for permanent employment, contracting is not a stepping stone to that. Contractors do not get benefits so it can be uncomfortable to work very hard for permanent staff who have paid vacations; many contractors because they are not paid for holidays or mandatory vacation days make a lot less than their stated annual "salaries".

Job Title: Tac engineer iii video broadcast support
Pros: I am never ever bored. There are so many resources & opportunities available 24/7 - a veritas of new ideas...
Cons: TAC Engineer must maintain multiple internal responsibilities simultaneously while ensuring satisfaction in resolution of customer cases; all the while, increasing one's skill-set continuously. Multitasking is an understatement and long days are the norm.  Although I enjoy this type of environment, it is demanding and should be considered - else your team suffer's!

Pros: Great culture to work in. Overall Management is good with some pockets of "how did they get here?" Fun place to work with really good benefits.  Pay is pretty good for industry, but movement can be restrictive by HR red tape.  "We will promote you for your same current pay"  kind of stuff.
Cons: Don't get stuck in non essential roles.  Every October, they clean house at or around 10% of workforce.

Pros: My team had a very close collaboration culture.  Lots of interesting work with the ability to implement leading best practices in digital marketing.  Emphasis on aligning with other teams and making sure that activities were coordinated between groups.
Cons: Political maneuvering at the top meant lots of reorgs and layoffs.  That was hard on our team, which had cultivated deep friendships and trust over the years.  Really devastating, because cuts were made not based on skills but based on $$.

Pros:
Dynamic environment.
Lot of opportunity across company, which can be tried out without informing your manager. complete freedom to work.
Technical challenge with good reward (Money).
Compensation is good while entering to the company.
Cons:
Company have less faith in Video division.
Many layoff  happen in past
Eligible Technical People from Video division having a tough time to enter into other division of Cisco Systems.
Year on year salary increment are not that great.

Pros: Amazing people, tightly focused on delivery of best products to fit the needs of our clients.
Cons: Long hours, often weekends, with a lot of stress from the clients to achieve their goals. Often working with clients who were not fully educated with the strengths of the systems. The pressure was to "Get it now exactly like it used to be" rather then taking the time to Do what is Best. As some jobs grew more complex, the pressures increased.

Pros:
- Very good facilities for employees & lot of opportunities to learn & contribute
- Excellent talent in the org
Cons:
- Frequent leadership change makes BU's direction less.
- New leader always things old leader done was crap & wants to achieve some thing of his own agenda
- Internal movements are very very difficult
- Very rare salary revisions/promos
- More of mediocre performers who are left in the BU's, create tonnes of useless meetings
- Very frequent leadership fires or leadership exits

Pros: great compensation and opportunity for growth. You really are in control of your own success. The product is best in the business and the environment is fun and young.
Cons: Training is not organized and management shows a lot of nepotism. You have to be relentless and I have seen some questionable decision making by management. Still has a mild "good ol boy" culture as has been the case in corporate tech for years.

Pros: best environement inside the company.
Cons: Company management should treat contractors from cosnultancies also as a employees. Should make them permanent once they complete 2 years of work experience at cisco. That policy of removing contractor depending on thier flexibility is very bad. should consider them also as employees. Contractors also involved in making revenue to the company right. then why that much negligance about the contract employees life.

Pros: Cisco provides very good benefits. Good opportunity to learn about Supply Chain management /product and manufacturing areas of business Great started company.
Cons:
Salaries are stagnate; new hires are recent collage gradates that will be paid less and expected to do more than the older employees.  Original mission statement included "Work / Life Balance" that has changed. 

If you are young with a masters degree, Cisco is a great company to get your feet wet before moving to FB or Google.

Pros:
Some coworkers are excellent people and the top network engineers in the world.
It was a pleasure to learn from them.
Cons:
High school atmosphere.
"Boy's club" which included male managers.
Sexual harassment is a given if you are a woman (overt and covert).
If management doesn't like you for any reason, off you go. They have let go excellent engineers.
Impossible demands "because it's Cisco".
Toxic competition is encouraged

Pros:
* Great environment
* great people, with initiative and many good brains to learm from
* In general good technologies
* good buisness
Cons:
* Looks like Cisco does not cherish people and fires them without any count
* Cisco does not exactly know what to do with traditional NDS business
* Many good people left alone, other fired without any reason
* Try to initiate new projects in new areas not connected with NDS business, nobody knows where does it lead
* looks like a decline of a very good place

Pros:
You get the sense that cisco really cares about their employees and at the individual contributor level they will provide lots of flexibility (no strict 9-5 hours, possibility to work remote, etc) to ensure that employees feel comfortable and valued.

Cisco has been around for a while and is good place to learn and grow as a professional engineer at a large company.
Cons: It will depend on your team assignment but the overall atmosphere at cisco is geared towards older and more established professionals. As a fresh grad straight out of college it can be a bit of a culture mismatch, but everyone is still incredibly nice and easy to work with.

Pros: Very good work/life balance, and flexibility to work from home.  You are not tied to the clock as long as you show results. Lots of perks and Cisco branded freebies.  Great benefits.
Cons: Don't feel the job security that I felt when I first started.  As technology changes and evolves, teams and priorities change = lots of lay offs.

Pros: Balanced work life, flexibility in hours and working from home
Cons: Limited opportunity for promotion, still long ways for women to get considered for managerial jobs. Low rate of sponsorship vs men and getting support needed to move up.

Pros:
Smart, caring people, lots of opportunity to shine and make an impact, as well as give back to causes you care about and support the community.  

Leadership is truly compassionate  and caring and will work hard to support your career journey.
Cons: If you don't have a solid career plan, you can become stagnated and for those of us who have trouble with direction and asking for help, it's a challenge (but that would be anywhere!).

Pros: work life balance has been great, the main reason why i stay. important for women who become mothers to have that balance.
Cons:
lack of clarity around opportunities & requirements in order to obtain a promotion
very little salary increase year over year, i see a lot of colleagues going to other companies and obtaining a 20-30% salary increase. hard to want to  stay at cisco when there are other opportunites out there

Pros: Management empowers you to voice your new ideas and proposal improvements to the organization. Management will place you with meaningful work that is yours to own start to end. Culture really embraces to influence without authority from all levels which is great. I'm also a board member for one of Cisco's Employee Resource Organization's -- Early Career Network. It's an inclusive community for young professionals starting their careers to network & develop cross functional on the campus. Some of our events include happy hour events, professional development workshops-- negotiate your salary, and volunteer opportunities.
Cons: very fast-paced culture and competitive. there's never not enough work to do.

Pros: As an early in career employee at Cisco, I have been able to gain exposure to many organizations within the business and with upper management. I love that you have the autonomy to make your own schedule, which enables a great work-life balance. The company really values their employees and customers - and I love that we come first.
Cons: If you are not able to manage your own time, you might be overwhelmed with getting tasks done and managing the distractions that might arise in this environment.

Pros: Freedom to work when and where you want. Half-yearly evaluation based on performance of deliverables. It is easy to take on new projects that according to you create value for the company.
Cons: Virtual teams, lack of personal contacts. Flexibility means also working to accompany colleagues in different timezones.

Pros:
Good company to work for with Great Work Life Balance,
Talented People,
Really flexible with timings (Work from home option )
Can change jobs internally without much hassle.
Option to buy stocks via ESPP (but not included in offer)

And lastly Cisco Share is all time high , trending positively.
Cons:
If you are in a business-unit that's making generating less revenue might come under Layoffs / due to severe under-performance.

Hike Cycle might get postponed, with less/no hikes.

No RSUs.

Pros: At Cisco, we definitely change the way the world lives, works, plays, innovates, connects, creates and benefits each other. Love the people, culture, innovation and employee empowerment across the globe.
Cons: Functional silos, lack of SSOT for data, competing priorities and disconnected cross functional goals.

Pros: There are good benefits and a flexible work schedule.  There is plenty of PTO and often there are opportunities to travel internationally.
Cons: Nothing moves quickly at Cisco.  Every process they make hinders innovation .  Often the expectation is for you to just fall in line and going against the status quo can get you into trouble.

Pros:
Good work life balance.
You may get to join the company at a competitively high compensation.
You can change team within Cisco in different units of operations.
Good campus and a very good show-off environment.
Cons:
If you are in some legacy OSes of Cisco you may end up only doing maintenance and highly stressed customer issues.
The career growth and compensation growth gets stagnated if you stuck in these teams.
Some teams have very micro-management intensive managers. They make life miserable.

Pros: There's plenty of room to grow at Cisco and mobility within the company is encouraged.  There are very smart innovators and engineers who share knowledge and vast experience.
Cons: Frequent layoffs (termed "limited restructuring") is not conducive to a healthy workforce. A lot of colleagues are in a constant panic of being let go and this sadly affects momentum and satisfaction overall.

Pros: Good people below the management level.  Good corporate tools, decent perks
Cons: Abundantly clear that the company is clearing out employees who have either been there a long time (12+ years) or who are 40 and older.  Every Grade 11 and 12 get replaced with junior Grade 8's.  Also a place where rewards go to the loudest and never to the most able or deserving.

Pros: Many teams have flexible hours and locations, as long as you get the work done. When my kids are sick, I can work from home. When I want to take a longer break to visit my kids at school, I can.  Cisco has high performing, dedicated employees, but that's only possible because they take care of their own.
Cons: A pro and con of working at a global company is that you may sometimes have to take meetings at odd hours to collaborate with others around the world. At least you can do that from the comfort of your own home.

Pros: I have been at Cisco for over 11 years and I have loved every minute.  I can honestly say that what I do matters every day in the lives of children, neighbors and communities.  I help to solve some of the countries biggest challenges through the use of technology.  I live and work with purpose.
Cons: As for most top companies, Cisco sets the bar high and expects everyone to rise to the occasion.  Although we have great work/life balance options, you have to set your boundaries and that can sometimes be a challenge.

Pros:
- Really nice people
- Great leadership
- Awesome campus in Bangalore
- Good for people of 40+ age, who would like to retire after this job OR people too engrossed in their families.
- Really nice managers
Cons:
- Slow lethargic
- Lethargic approach to work
- Less compensation, ones who want to enjoy stay very long. Good ones leave soon.
- Friday WFH is understood in many teams.
- Bad HR policies, salary comparison done with Service Companies.
- Most of the software work is for internal teams.

Pros: Good benefits, compensation is competitive, opportunity to work with lots of talented people.  The pace is fast which creates new opportunities.  Middle management genuinely seems to care about their employees.
Cons: Fast pace also means you can have a lot of turnover. I personally had 8 managers in 9 years. The hours can be long but this is typical of tech sales.

Pros: Solid work/life balance, ability to work remotely, great people. Good benefits
Cons: Being a Cisco employee means you always have the threat of a layoff hanging over your head. Never enough budget or resources and corporate is obsessed with maximising margins even at the cost of market share growth. To much reliance on acquisitions as a substitute for long term strategic planning and investment. Bean counter mentality rules the day,

Pros:
Good work and life balance and well structured career development system as well as internal opportunities.
Great leadership team that shows empathy and strong leadership & a great sense of responsibility, understanding during COVID situation.
People are great and a lot of humble & genuine people to work with in such a massive corporate environment.
Cons:
Overall benefits (except insurance) is not the best of what other competitors or typical top IT companies are offering, surprisingly behind.
Adapting IT industry trends can be slower than others as it is still very hardware driven. 
Too big organization, hard to navigate people you need to connect with sometimes,

Pros:
Empower employees to do quite a bit 
Flexibility on working hours
Cons:
Generally older and old fashion management layer
Supply Chain management is middle age / old white male
0 advancement opportunities even if you are top performer
Compensation is about 20% below other tier 1 tech companies
Long working hours 
Management is more focused on playing politics than developing their people and talent --> incompetent people getting promoted

Pros:
- Cisco Genuinely cares about its people, and is voted best workplace often
- Great Benefits
- Truly Enterprise Sales
- Really great people
Cons:
- Product can lag 
- Within AppD the path forward is not clear
- You will work harder than you ever have as the market is competitive

Pros: Flexibility is probably the key benefit to working at Cisco.  We have the ability (and also the responsibility) to manage our work/life in whatever why we feel is appropriate.  We are measured on results, and not (always) on being politically visable.
Cons:
We are not as good at giving feedback as we would like to believe.  Cisco is very open in giving positive feedback, and if something goes very wrong, we are very open addressing it and improving on it.
However when things run 'ok' the organisation never really takes time to feedback and improve on it.

Pros:
the benefits and perks are good, especially work at home technology
the pay is still above average 
about half the people are great -- smart team players who do the right thing
some units are very good places to learn and advance
Cons:
too many meetings where people waste time talking about work and not doing it
some groups are petty and political, and if you are in one of those, it can be a constant struggle to stay in the loop
some executives are incompetent
often different teams are given the same job in blind competition == wasted effort

Pros: Like anywhere else, a person's opinion of a company probably has a great deal to do with their manager and the way their business unit is run.  Overall, Cisco is a very well respected company and they try to maintain that level of professionalism with respect to the way employees are treated.  The management team and Human Resources policies certainly are geared toward rewarding the individuals that offer the highest contributions to the business.
Cons: The compensation has been going down in recent years.  I say that for several reasons.  First, the salaries have not been going up in general but cost of living, of course, has.  Second, the benefits are slowly getting worse.  The primary one being stock options which have all but been terminated now except for the management and highest level technical folks.  But in addition, the various medical and dental plans offered are covering less and costing more year after year.

Pros: Excellent compensation, good health benefits, great telecommuting options for employees that live far away. The Cisco name carries weight and is a great resume builder and a good place to build your network at the beginning of your career.
Cons:
Unfortunately, after 4 years I didn't see my career transforming to something different, and many of my colleagues felt the same. I wanted to transition from Sales to Marketing, or an international role and got little management support or guidance on how to do this. There is little encouragement for trying new roles not in your direct department. I know many who have left Cisco, gotten other outside experience and then come back in a new role. That was one of the main reasons I left.
Also, there was little work life balance for me. I was handsomely compensated as an Account Manager, but in return, I worked 70-80 hour weeks sometimes, and almost never took vacation. I worked when I was sick, when my parents were ill, etc. It was great that Cisco allowed me to telecommute when I was ill and when my parents were sick, but in return I was expected to be "connected" at all times. I took two 10 day vacations during my 4 year tenure at Cisco and had to get permission to leave my cell phone/email off while traveling so I could actually enjoy it. 
Also I didn't really feel it had a "work hard, play hard" atmosphere either. I have a small handful of close friends from my Cisco days but besides that, no one in the office really wanted to interact or socialize with each other after work hours so I also left the company with few long lasting relationships, despite my best efforts. The company culture is fairly conservative and bureaucratic- I didn't find it a "fun" place to work.

Pros:
Options awarded prior to the dotcom bust can be worth millions.
Good outplacement services
Some managers have integrity
Cons:
Long hours
Good performers can be laid off for being in the wrong place at the wrong time
Layoffs focus on those with 10+ yrs experience 
Managers can write reviews that are entirely political, with no consideration of the work completed
In PDI, they laid off almost everyone in SJ, while the entire management hierachy planned their own exits - awful.

Pros:
Good comp and benefits
Good competent individual contributors
Financial strength and stability of company
Telecommuting available to some
Many types of organizations and positions
Cons:
Execution driven, poor analysis and planning ability or processes at the Company.  Where this does exist, it is not really leveraged. The focus is tactical and execution oriented.

Non-existent decision-making or accountability.  Continuing trend to use committees to make decisions, which continues to promote lack of individual decision-making and accountability by the right people.  When all goes wrong, targeted scapegoating is the result of this framework.

Middle management is not competent.  Many grew up at Cisco during boom (late 90's) and were promoted to mgt (due to low unemployment) without experience, competencies, training or solid role models. No real progress on improving this gap.

Fire, aim, ready mentality.  Lots of fire drills, false starts, rework.

Lots of posturing and heavy politics.  If you can stand to "hear no evil, see no evil and speak no evil" you will do fine, though you may not help the company.    

Bonus system promotes dishonesty.  Sr. Mgrs and above get significant bonuses.  No wonder they are possessed with everyone creating our "smoke and mirrors" deliverables.

No work/life balance.  My Director verbatim "you will never find a job at Cisco that offers work life balance, so don't bother looking.  All Cisco employees are expected to work 60+hours per week." At that rate, I can do better financially and personally working for the defunct state of CA.

HR is invisible.  When I asked, my manager would not give me the HR contact and suggested it was useless to get them involved in what would have benefited from HR consultation.  No one in our group knows who our HR rep is as we have never been told, seen or heard from anyone in HR.  There is no place to go to look it up, as far as I know.

Limited opportunity to transition to other groups.  My VP has prevented 2 attempts I have made to move to a different group, even when a job was available for me.

Pros:
1. Cisco folks are smart, experienced, diverse, culturally exposed, very professional and quite friendly. Collaboration is part of daily work and people are willing to help out. 

2. Technology is everywhere, and Cisco eats its own dog food, just not the latest release. The portfolio of products in Cisco will simply amaze people. 

3. Individual contributors are empowered to make critical decisions, access people across the company towards identified goals in a relatively flat hierarchy. 

4. Awesome work life balance, you decide how much you want to work and earn, now with mobility and great tools, where doesn't really matter. You can use Apple, PC, iPhone, BB, Android, IT is heading towards any to any device. Which is great for tech savvy folks 

5. Overall package is average with good medical coverage.
Cons:
1. Compensation package are sometimes mediocre at best, promotions and pay increments can take eons. Loyalty is rewarded by stagnation in grade level, however we welcome jumpers back with higher grade, pay and recognition. 

2. Personal growth and career can be on both ends of the spectrum, depending on your manager, which team and where ? Markets with high growth reasonably gets resources and attention. 

Along the lines of its acquisition and develop strategy, talent seems to be managed the same way. Rarely find young people in Cisco, mostly IT old timers, reliable and dependable. This makes things dull and mundane at times. 

3. Cisco finds innovative ways to complicate doing business, which in turn complicate most peoples jobs. 

4. Too many initiatives, too many programs, too many tools "everything in Cisco is online somewhere, if you can find it then great". 

5. Cisco culture is beginning to be diluted in certain places, from an awesome company its starting to be just another IT company. Yet whats most disturbing is on the surface things are ok.
