Pros: Technology you get to work on is top-end. It is not just a support site for the US office unlike many other product companies. The work culture is nurturing and allows you to grow without suffocating you with politics. The managers are understanding in your needs.
Cons: Appraisals usually do not reflect the performance although the hikes are good enough even though the ratings aren't that great. There is not much emphasis on work-life balance.

Pros: You can make a career of changing jobs and working on different projects within one company.   There's so many ways to make your mark through your successes including creating process improvements, driving higher scalability, and lowering costs along the way.   The company rewards those who make the company more *productive*.  You feel proud to be part of the internet revolution and how we now use it in our personal lives and in business.   If you enjoy immersing yourself into work, you will do well here.   The profit-sharing bonus is great!   You get to work from home liberally as the San Jose campus is so spread out and you can't be expected to drive from building to building and be on time to your meetings.    Nearly everyone now tele-conference calls into a meeting with WebEx.    With WebEx on your smartphone, the word 'work' is no longer a place you go to as it is wherever you are when you have an internet connection.
Cons:
This is a place for workaholics and folks who want to make things happen.   You're always connected to work because of the internet, email, IM, WebEx, mobile.    Work - life balance... forget about it.    To keep pace, you need to be reading your emails at night and on weekends.  Time to eat lunch during your lunch hour... SELDOM unless you own all the meetings or the meeting can wait for another 2 weeks when you have a more reasonable time that you or the others are available.   These are the hazards of working for a global company when the people you work with are in multiple timezones and don't eat lunch or sleep when you do.    If you find a good boss to work for, enjoy it while it lasts.   On average, you'll have a new boss every 1.5 years.      If you can work in a non-IT role at Cisco, you'll add more years to your life.

One other thing... when there's little given out in salary raises, promotions, big titles, big responsibilities, the politics gets tougher as there's more fighting for so little and less sharing.   Since 2002, this has been an environment with much less rewards than had been there before.   Welcome to big corporate life when you have the usual emphasis in cost cutting!

Pros:
When WebEx was purchased by Cisco, we knew there would be a culture shock (hardware meets software as a service).  Cisco was very professional and had more people wearing ties and removed the WebExcess back in 2007.  The training and exposure to the largest most integrated solutions challenged everyone and grew the most professional teams I've worked with to a new and higher levels.

Cisco has been also been another Pro as the integration and stability they have brought thru process and industry best practices in large deployments has been invaluable.
Cons:
Some of the legacy systems like Oneview (custom service portal), Bliss (custom billing system)  and fax document processing has held WebEx back for years.  Cisco WebEx needs to implement and leverage more self-servicing tools like Sprints.com customer service portal and finish delayed projects like Oracle while also maintaining it's expert communication practices.  

An additional Con is the current expectations set with customers and the major cut back.  It will be nearly impossible for Cisco WebEx remaining staff to meet the new demand for implementation and deployment.  At the end of Cisco's FY11 (July 30th 2011) there was a massive influx and transition type order to the Cisco Global Price List (typically partner oriented deals).  The executive management made cuts based on financial needs and has really put the Cisco WebEx implementation and deployment specialists (aka Client Service Manager's) in a precarious position with very limited and very new specialist.   Top partners like PGi, Intercall, Verizon, AT&T, INX and more will have to deploy, implement and service these accounts with little to no help.

Pros: Open Framework and employee empowerment limited by excess process and layers of management. Culture is under considerable pressure with layoffs and reductions. Great place for a college student but if you are over 50 they want to get you out of the company. The loss of margins in their routing and switching business will cause many years of pain.
Cons: Too many directors, VP and SVP's protecting turf and process. Chambers blew it with Wall Street but  the board gave him his job again for 3 years which is something many employees don't understand since all stock options are under water and stock options are gone. The story of being easier to do business with Cisco is complete BS at the transaction level as there are no changes in process to get deals done. If you complain at Cisco you are put on a black list by executives. They don't want to hear bad news so why complain if you want to protect your career?

Pros: Cisco provides a multitude of opportunities to expand your skills, knowledge and professional contacts.  The opportunity it there to make a difference, add value to the corporation.  The pay and benefits are exceptional.
Cons: Management slow to react to shifts in the market in demand for technology and competition.  Reward system can be based on politics more than personal performance but most large corporations are similar.

Pros: Cisco is a great place to develop technical knowledge, communicate with smart people, and advance a career. There are wonderful tools for collaboration and management is very supportive of employees.
Cons:
Cisco is very big, and feels even bigger. The organization structure is complicated and yet it must be understood in order to be an effective employee. The right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing. And different business units are in constant competition with one another, frequently for internal attention and resources, and sometimes in the external marketplace too. Senior management doesn't seem to understand technology and industry strategy, at least not well enough to make difficult decisions and provide real leadership. After a year on the job, I'm still not really sure how to make a difference and create value for the company.

On a more personal level, while I'm satisfied with the salary and bonus structure at Cisco, I'm unhappy to find that the benefits are not as good as my previous employer. The health insurance plans are expensive and don't provide any significant benefits unless they're heavily used, because of deductibles, co-pays, etc. Frankly, I'd be willing to pay higher employee contributions for a better plan, but my previous employer's plan was better and less expensive.

The vacation / PTO allowance is pretty standard, but after starting with Cisco I found out that there are "mandatory PTO" days at the end of each year. In other words, some PTO days (approx 3 per year) are not available for the employee to use as they wish, but are effectively "holiday" days. Since my previous employer gave me 5 days more than Cisco (actually 10 days more than Cisco, due to my tenure; 5 days more for new employees), I was already expecting a step backwards - the mandatory PTO just makes it worse.

Pros:
Flexible work environment; work from home
Lots of employment opportunities / chances to move around the company
Cons:
Job satisfaction really depends on who you work for, what dept you're in
The new open workspace is terrible
Zero help for commuters
Working from home means sacrificing your career
Base salaries are laughable; perks benefits and total comp dwindeling
Re-orgs are status quo
The company does not do enough to retain top talent

Pros: Cisco has provided me oppurtunity to hone my expertises and develop my skills as well as enabled me to develope my employees
Cons: Cisco has been slow to maximize employee  potential and I still see employees struggling with  management and leadership team to make best use of exployees and maximize their potential.

Pros: Lots of change.  In my 15 years, I've never been bored.  The admin community is strong, and there are plenty of opportunities to enhance your career.
Cons: Lots of change.  New technology doesn't always scale properly and there are bugs to work through, causing a lot of frustration in getting your job done.  Some processes take too many steps to complete.  Politics come and go, although I'm sure that's the same with any other company.   Hiring admins thru agencies (budget purposes) makes it challenging for FTEs to find a new position.

Pros:
-very strong brand name, market share gained for many years, most revenue just coming from loyal customers without too much sales effort
-Still can stay stable and safe for many years
Cons:
-No long term plan at all, everyone only care about  "WEEKLY" forecast, nothing more.
-No longer a cutting edge tech company, selling product like selling commodity goods, increasing revenue only by pushing customer to buy more 
-Very unfriendly culture, even hostile, don't expect any help from others
-unreasonable target

Pros: Cisco develops cutting edge products and implements them internally often making employees beta users (fun and frustrating).  Encouraging early adoption of new technologies benefits employees by making them  savvy tech users across a broad range of technologies compared to peers.  Working for Cisco commands a lot of respect from people outside the company.  You have great 24-hour global emergency support whether you're on business or travel.
Cons: There's been a steep, and documented, decline in compensation in last 10 years.  No raises unless you're promoted.  Promotions are limited to approximately 15-20% of the workforce and are a 12-18 month cycle once your manager gets you in the queue.  Couple this with the elimination of stock options for the majority of employees who are rated as meeting expectations (around 60% of the workforce) and uncertain bonuses means you lose money staying at Cisco unless you're on and stay on the promotion track.  It's no secret that Cisco has a substantial chunk of cash which it keeps off-shore to minimize US taxes.  While "good" for the bottom line this strategy also penalizes US employees because it keeps the pool of money for promos and raises small.  The hours are relentless regardless of your role. It's not unusual to receive emails from peers in your time zone at 11:00 or 11:30 pm.  There's subtle pressure to respond to emails from peers in other regions during their workday a.k.a. your evening.  Working partial days on the weekend isn't uncommon and working Sunday evenings is standard.  Training and education is under-funded. I was not approved for any professional training in the last five years of employment at Cisco.

Pros:
Being part of Cisco has, literally, been a life-changing opportunity & journey for me. I can't imagine myself anywhere else. 

Constant, sincere & authentic commitment to customers...at all levels of business, this is always and without question the top priority and decision-driver! I've worked at other companies that talked this same talk, but didn't back it up with practice or action. It's one of, if not the top,, reasons that I always feel proud to say "I work at Cisco". 
OTHER: Flex-scheduling; remote work options; autonomy; intelligent, curious, committed and passionate colleagues; organizational integrity; $10k annual education reimbursement.
Cons:
Cisco offers lots of opportunity for lateral movement across org's & functions- which is great for those of us who like to keep learning and want broader organizational knowledge. The downfall of this, however, is FREQUENT management changes. There are also major re-org's every few years, also resulting in movement and changes in team structure/management. For many of us, our managers substantially influence employ,net decisions and ultimate job satisfaction. Unfortunately, at Cisco, you can't really base decisions on this because it could change tomorrow. 

Cisco's top-heavy. Congestion in higher job grades makes upward movement slow and difficult, even if deserving, because there are already so many people in these grades that it's difficult to justify adding another. 

Underrepresentation of women in leadership roles, particularly at Mngr, Snr Mngr, & Director level. Cisco's said this is a focus area, and while there hasn't been much change at most levels, we are seeing women fill the ranks at VP & SVP.  

Cisco's huge. Ramping-up as new-hire takes long time- learning all diff efferent org's, acronyms, functions, etc. (But it's worth it.)

Lacking generational diversity. Based on my observations only... small percentage of employees under 30. I'd guess avg age Is about 40-45. 

Pressure to perform and emphasis on results, means you have to market yourself. At times, I've definitely thought to myself "I could achieve so much more if I didn't have to spend all this time communicating my 'wins'".  The culture's competitive though, and making sure others know what you contribute is how you stand out.

Pros:
* Flexible work practices - working from home and flexible timings top it all, unlike some other companies, working from home is not looked badly at.
* Good work culture but like any other big organisation  - varies with the team you work for.
* Lots of resources to learn if you are really inclined
Cons:
* The peer group quality has deteriorated over the years as a result of dilution in hiring quality
* Not the best of paymasters
* Not very agile

Pros:
Good work/life balance
Great colleagues
Good benefits
Cons:
Frequent Layoffs
Frequent change to business strategies
Cumbersome business processes

Pros: The insurance, 401K, ESPP benefits are great, and the pay is decent compared to similar companies. Cisco does a lot to get their employees excited about working there
Cons: Hard to feel like you're making an impact at the company, constant fear of layoffs, hard to get compensation issues resolved, still under the 'old boys club' mentality

Pros: Great benefits for employees, especially by giving flexibility at work. Gives the chance to meet great people,   the teamwork here is taken very seriously and is one of the things that makes it a great place to work. Whenever you reach out for help, the culture in the company is to give, no matter at what level of hierarchy.
Cons: Growth might be a limited to horizontally and not vertically. You need to be proactive in searching for help, and the company goals might not always be visible , especially to remote locations.

Pros: Cisco is brand is good to have. And some of its facilities are applicable for as well.
Cons:
Growth perspective still not sure. As after acquisition few valuable customers are lost and only two new customers are won.
As cisco believes in more profit, small customers are neglected.

Pros:
Depending on the role flexibility in hours and ability to work from home.

Large company ability to rotate and learn new things

Excellent pay - Cisco strives to pay at the 75th percentile, pretty good benefits

Great place to work and advance for women

Bonuses are usually paid out or in bad years a portion of the bonus.

If you do get laid off and are a blue badge (non-contractor employee) you will get a generous severance package - in 2011 it was a 6 month payout for most, but for long term older employees it was 1 year.  In 2013 the package was something very similar two months on the books - paid with a four month payout.

If you don't have a brand name school on impressive company your resume, people will take you more serious after doing time at Cisco.

The possibility of driving important initiatives of very significant size - the ability to impact millions of dollars of revenue or be part of a billion dollar business unit or enterprise.

A great cross cultural - world-wide and cutting edge technology experience.
Cons:
If you are a red badge (contractor) in the USA- odds are you will never become a full time employee with benefits. Back in 2011, 40% of the company was contract, today it is higher.  Many have the dreams and desires to convert from contractor to employee but your odds are almost as good as playing the lotto.  (If you are a women, your odds will be better - as you will help the desired diversity metrics).

Raises almost never happen.  They are the exception and not the rule.

Continual layoffs of higher paying positions - almost every year - cost shifting of higher paying jobs to lower paying areas outside of Bay Area/USA.  

Each job has very limited role responsibility because they are typically structured in a silo - so after two years you might get bored and will want to go through the job rotation program.

Some departments had VERY inflated job titles compared with the outside world. I have met Directors and Senior Directors that I wouldn't let them run a McDonalds (if I owned one). As they say in Texas - all hat and no cattle.  

If you are a straight white male not in engineering it's not the best place to advance - you will have difficulties in advancing because you will not meet the desired diversity quota. Because engineering is so heavily weighted toward men, the other areas of the business are being strongly encouraged to hire women. I've seen entire departments shift from 50/50 to 75/80% women. Many of the women prefer only to hire women. The women dominated departments are creating new issues which I had never seen before in any organization and in certain cases slows down progress. While I support the advancement of women, some things are hard to challenge, change or modify without coming across as a Neanderthal.  (I hope they balance things out better in the future). 

The LGBT agenda can create a hostile environment after the inclusion and diversity on the annual review implemented by a previous HR exec who is now at Twitter. The review now can be used against those that have more traditional views of the world. It creates and Orwellian world where the word inclusion means exclusion.

If you work at Cisco too long you might become immersed in the slow "collaborative" bureaucratic way of doing things where nothing gets done and perhaps lose your ability to act and think quickly.

Pros: Great Work  life balance.  They actually care about your well being.
Cons: Doesnt matter how good your are at your job it only matters if you are assigned to the "next big thing" projects if you want to move up.  Have seen many crappy managers / directors move up because they were in the right place at the right time.  Some managers (now SR Directors have had 3 promotions in 3 years.  No one else can come close to that.

Pros: Work-life balance and compensation are adequate in many departments.  More often than not you can be self-driven and independent.
Cons: Annual layoffs and heavy weight of bureaucracy stifle true innovation.  Many department segments not coordinating meaning everyone is creating the wheel in different sizes and colors.  Leadership is inconsistent and generally inept and untrained as management.

Pros: Pioneered the enabling of the internet.  Global reach.   Was a prestigious company to work for.   Was a engineer's company.  CEO is a great speaker.
Cons: Culture has changed from motivation by rewards to motivation by fear.  Fear driven sweatshop in engineering. Innovators don't stick around in this environment.   Suspicious lack of diversity in software engineering teams.   From VP of engineering down, its 98% Indian in San Jose.

Pros: Working from home, solid pay, but nothing extraordinary, and great innovative technology to sell.
Cons: Poor management generally speaking, and they are driving a great company into the ground.  The culture is now dessimated.  Soon the business will follow.  Mediocrity prevails, and to be a Manager means keeping your mouth SHUT and do not attempt to push back and improve things...  More than anything, Cisco needs a change... But no one in Management has the juice to make it happen.

Pros: Want to be the #1 IT company in the world.  They could do it.
Cons: When I started, it felt like a start up - could change on a dime.  Moved like a sleek yacht.  They have grown so large, they can't maneuver as quickly, but they think they can.  It is not more like turning a super-sized freighter in a small harbor.

Pros:
Cisco cares a lot about their employees, their big and sometimes you can get lost in the chaos but when the chips are down the management will do what they can for you.

Great benefits, ability to work from home and amazing flexibility. 

Company lives their values/culture.

A ton of free professional development opportunities, like a job and free education at the same time.
Cons:
A lot of re-orgs.

Still a lot of contention between internal groups, working on that though.

Pros:
Good salary, benefits, working from home options.
Also, the access to the knowledge shared across Cisco is amazing. There are a LOT of very very smart people at Cisco.
Cons:
Management who seem unable to learn the technical capabilities and limitations of a platform.
Even though there is lots of knowledge shared at Cisco, much of it is hidden away in niche knowledge repositories. There seems to be no serious global push to document things in a well managed repository.
There is also a new flavour of collaboration invented almost every 6 months which means that no technology in this area is allowed to mature and gain acceptance.
You can also get stuck in a rut, if you are in a high load team. Leaving you little to no time to attempt to go above and beyond your role to further your career.
Some management also seem to have little regard for a work/life balance. Heavily evident in the teams I was involved with.

Pros:
Exceptionally good work life balance! Although it mostly depends on your boss, you'll be most probably not judged for WFHs and leaves if you do your work properly.
Compensation is according to industry standards.
Very Nice office in Banaglore
Cons: Growth is not terrible but it's not too good when compared to a few others. Also it get really difficult to align to company strategy as we find a new buzz word every month and run around it.

Pros:
Top management, i.e. Chambers and his top team are inspirational, reasonable, progressive people who I believed to be in it for reasons other than money and power.

Flexible working was excellent although this can vary depending on how much of a dinosaur your manager is.

Salary/bonus/benefits were pretty good.
Cons: Some really strange appointments, as in new hires, were made within my organisation.  I can only think this a symptom of such a large company finding it difficult to filter the core values of the leadership team down to all levels.

Pros: Generally friendly and employees do not seem to have a cutthroat attitude.  People do go out of their way to help you
Cons:
In terms of documentation or training or expertise, nobody knows what anybody else is doing.  There may be three or four groups trying to accomplish nearly the same goals in providing training labs or POC environments, and none of the groups even know that any other exists.  
TOI and documentation are miserable.

Pros: Great cultural diversity, company perks in terms of dental cover and stock plans, etc.
Cons: Cisco is still built on the 'progression is based on time served, not merit' model, where the longer you've been here, the more you'll get. For young people starting out, out-performing their colleagues, not the greatest motivation to have. Also, for new fields, it's harder to define your career. Avoid if you're young.

Pros: Some groups have challenging work and professional environment where one can grow technically. The management encourage the team to innovate and come up with new product ideas. Benefits are decent.
Cons: Most of the groups have lot of middle management which is not aligned to the top management. Sometimes, the middle management is very opaque and it gives the impression to the team that there is lot of politics is at play.

Pros: Compensation is higher than normal for Greater Atlanta Area IT sector. If you're in the right group, you can be shielded from most of the upper level management shenanigans, politics and bad business decisions. If you're not in the right group - all bets are off.
Cons: Cisco has a habit of acquiring companies and then destroying them.  This is certainly the case with their acquisition of Scientific Atlanta, all traces of which will certainly cease to exist within the next two years. Upper level management is a revolving door and there is a high level of chaos as folks scramble to maintain employment - often working on projects that have very little chance of succeeding.

Job Title: Cross functional business operations manager and project manager
Pros:
Individual contributor employees are top notch and great to partner with on solutions
Opportunity to work from home is a nice opportunity
Benefits and pay are market compatible
Volunteering and giving back opportunities are very nice
Products are quality and ground breaking
Cons:
Loyalty no longer means anything, the company has become to stock value based
Experienced employees are no longer valued
Work life balance is hit or miss depending on the group 
RSU (Restricted Stock units) are given at the wrong levels and when they do make it to the individual employee they are too few
Many of the good perks are gone (drinks, food, social events)

Pros: Cisco is a large company allowing it to invest in smaller innovative companies.
Cons: Cisco moved its headquarters to India over the past several years. This has dramatically changed the make up of its workforce. Most of its strategic vision is for Global investment. This strategy comes at the cost of American resources employment opportunities.

Pros: Cisco is still a leader in the IT industry with a significant presences in most every business and government segments.   They are well respected for their keen attention to the customer and best channel program in the business.  The IOE strategy is positive and being well received in the industry.   Technology innovation and solution sales continues to be their strength and focus.
Cons:
New strategic focus on recurring revenue and software is right direction, however execution is still lacking as Cisco tries to define themselves in this space that is more focused on what happens after the initial sale then the big deal focus that has been celebrated and made them a success. Lot of talk about increasing customer usage, expanding the  relationship and retaining customers but still and afterthought and reactive vs strategic and proactive.  
On a personal note, not living in one of their major hubs like San Jose or Raleigh is the reason I believe I no longer work there after over 10 years of being with them.

Pros: Strong sales culture, focused on results.  The strength of the brand continues to make up for  portfolio and delivery shortcomings.
Cons: Advanced Services is in dire need of an extreme makeover with major issues to be dealt with in sales, pre-sales and delivery.  The company will not be able to transition away from its box-mover legacy without it.

Pros: I enjoy having the option to work from home a couple of days a week. The benefits offered are pretty nice, but not unique in Silicon Valley. I enjoy having lots of opportunities to volunteer time and donate to causes I care about.
Cons: There are constant layoffs and reorgs, and I don't fully feel that I can trust management. Conversion from contract worker to full-time is either glacially slow or impossible unless you have connections in high places. You have to play at politics too often to keep your position and be online constantly, sometimes sacrificing a healthy work/life balance.

Pros: Base pay and annual bonus are very good.
Cons: Cisco has struggled to remain relevant among the leading IT and technology companies today - do you think of Cisco the same way you think of Google, Amazon, Facebook, Tesla, etc.?  I worked in Service Provider Video for 11 years. Since the acquisition of NDS it was all downhill with routine layoffs and a gloomy work environment.  Other business units may be different, but I would not recommend SP Video to any of my friends.

Pros: Depending on the business unit, seems like a fun place to work.  Everyone else I see throughout the typical day seems to have plenty of free time to socialize.  Good benefits.
Cons: Depending on the business unit, you may be asked to save the world with d t tape and baling wire.  Running WAY too lean.  Lots of lip service about customer satisfaction but when you're capped at 50-75% of what your headcount should be based on volume, customer sat is out of your hands...

Pros:
Salaries are competitive. There are many perks such as healthcare; flexi-time; working at home; shares; the ability to gift other employees awards in the form of vouchers; pension contributions and up to 30 days holiday if salary is used to buy 5 days on top of the base 25 days.

Good infrastructure, facilities, nicely laid out buildings, a small canteen and generally good people, with a few exceptions (see 'Cons').
Cons:
The problems lie with Cisco not knowing how to run the STB side of the business; local upper management and middle management being uncommunicative, and a contracting business, with hundreds of layoffs around the globe in ex-NDS offices, many coming at the end of 2017, in preparation for what may likely be, a sell-off (Bloomberg wrote an article late last year. 'Google Bloomberg NDS'), now that it's cheaper to run.
    
    Cisco have halved the workforce in 5 years, with only one client, Sky, now paying for the s/w created. There are 4 'culls' every year, roughly every 3 months which are usually small but have increased to 20+ people in the last year. This has lead to a more negative atmosphere in the last couple of years.
    
    If you're unlucky and end up in the wrong team, you could be working with mangers and colleagues who look after number one and hide their ineptitude and bad behaviour from those above, whilst making themselves look good off the back of other people.
Complaining to HR doesn't do any good, they're still there. It doesn't help there's no local HR department, as they were 'no longer needed' over a year ago.

Pros: Flexible work hours, work from home options, bonus and employee stock plans, understands the need to transform business models and products
Cons: Career progression typically requires moving departments or leaving the company and coming back; several executives are taking away flexibility to work from home; pay raises are infrequent and not on par with new hires

Pros:
It's a very enriching experience both in a professional and personal level. 

Firstly, you can learn a lot about technology, sales and soft skills from formal learning and on-the-job experience. 

Secondly, you're surrounded by an international and diverse group of young professionals, which teaches you about dealing and understanding different cultures. Also, you build a very strong network around the world. 

Finally, you receive competitive salary and benefits while training.
Cons: The training might feel detached from the every-day reality of your first position after the program. It will eventually make sense when you earn more experience and progress in your career.

Pros: Amazing opportunities for growth and development. I've been here a while and have had the  chance to take on a wide variety of projects. Not all managers are as incredible as mine (supportive professionally and personally, encourages agility and defines fail as "first attempt in learning") but the tools are all here for employees to be the best they can be. Executive leadership is second to none.
Cons: Because many (not all) employees can work remotely, it's difficult to connect to coworkers. While it's great to have the flexibility, we have to work harder at establishing and maintaining a unified sense of commitment.

Pros: Cisco is an amazing company to work for, you really feel you are best in the world and best for the world.  Work life balance is great, and tremendous opportunity to try new things.
Cons: Innovation is sometimes hard to achieve.  Like most companies you need to be in the right circles to get support for your ideas.

Pros:
-Great training and education resources provided. 
-Competitive salary
-Great company culture

It depends a lot on the team you land, but the culture is great. We go out on team dinner very frequently. Even though the company is huge, at some moments, it feels like you are part of a startup within your team.
Cons: Because the company is based out in Silicon Valley, they have a lot of competition when it comes to employee perks. For example, we do not get daily free breakfast/lunch/dinner, but it's something you can live without.

Pros:
This is a wonderful place to boost your experience - it might be technical or non-technical. In all cases you will find something for you. When it comes to carrier boosting - it depends. Cisco is a company of "visibilities" and "egoism" - if you do the right things, you will get your promotion, otherwise you will "die" in humble circumstances and nobody will sorrow about it.

If you are a student, less than 30 years old, have no family, you have a passion for technology so strong, that you are ready to work overtime (of course for free) - this place is right for you.
Cons:
Here "good job", "fantastic results", "keep up" phrases mean nothing, at least for management. Cisco is a cruel and bloody business machine. You can rag to riches to rag in few months if you do or don't do the right things. You may work very well, receiving glorious feedbacks from Customers - all it is taken for granted.

You will not see promotion unless you make something really fabulous, thus you will be noticed by Top Management - for example you will visit CiscoLive with your own presentation. Practically it is an easy and very dainty way for Tech Leads, since they are not expected to work "on shift" all the day long. Tech Leads of course supposed to have other responsibilities being an escalation, but who cares that they don't - management adopted a laissez-faire attitude long time ago. As a result bum engineers trample over each other just to get to TechLead paradise.

All above is about Cisco TAC/HTTS and at the end of the day it is my personal opinion only.

Pros:
I would say each review mainly focuses on each BU and the overall org's upper management 
- W.R.T the BU I'm a part of, I couldn't ask for a better team to work with.
- The kind of work we get to do and the impact of the products on customers is also perfect
- The overall org review i'd say the projects are well documented and each project has its developer community we can reach out to to get the necessary help. Really developer focused upper management and extremely helpful teams.
Cons: - none as of now

Pros: The culture is great, they really let you be who you want to be. You have the guidance and support that you need but you are also given the opportunity to make the work your own. Cisco invests heavily in their employees, they support with training and development and encourage people to improve and move forwards within the organisation. I would also like to mention that Cisco have been fantastic throughout Covid-19, they have been understanding and respectful of each individuals situation. I am grateful that I am working for Cisco during this difficult time.
Cons: For me personally there are no cons.

Pros:
- Great place for less experienced people (<10) to grow and explore.
- Huge scope to explore different career options within a single company.
- Nice work place, facilities includes play areas, gyms, multiple food options.
- Best transportation facility.
- Great place to relax n retire, if you are looking out for management roles..
Cons:
- Not competitive pay masters.
- Diluted engineering expertise, atleast @ India.
- Pathetic management. Managers are struggling hard to ruin Cisco reputation. 
Technical know how of management chain getting very very thin. Was not the same few years back. Infact managers are working based on perception instead of addressing their responsibilities (most of them).

Pros:
Pros about the Security Business Group
1) A lot of opportunities to learn and improve.
2) Surrounded by knowledgeable peers.
3) Dynamic work with interesting projects because of the increased focus on Cloud technologies.
4) Opportunities to work on a wide variety of projects.
5) Get benefits of both world, stability of an MNC and the dynamic work culture of a startup.
Cons:
Nothing of significance.
In some teams, the tech stack being used is a little old, but not something that is a significant problem. The amazing culture makes up for it.
PS: There is increased migration to newer and more powerful tech stack all across the company.

Pros:
- Flexible Work options /WFH
- Good Work Culture, Good people overall
- Good CEO
Cons:
- Pay structure is not competitive as other companies & peers
- Always heavy workload, bad for work life balance

Pros: "Be you, with us" isn't just a tagline. I really can be my full, authentic self at Cisco -- and I'm valued for it. Leadership is very engaged and is constantly open to feedback directly from employees, which I believe, is why Cisco is ranked the #1 World's Best Workplace.
Cons: As with any large company, sometimes it can take a while to get to a decision or see change happen because there are multiple decision-makers involved.

Pros:
Recognition and thanks are plentiful
Individuals try their best to make an impact
Cons:
Leadership needs to shake their heads - too many changes - too fast!
No processes or protocols
Employee churn and stress are very high
Toxic environments and siloed work/leadership styles

Pros: In the early years there was interesting and innovative work to do in networking protocols. Many of those protocols have become standards. The company and its people are and have been smart and creative.
Cons: Since the transition of the world to Cloud, Cisco has fallen behind. Cisco's original routing and switching products were high quality and long lasting. Cisco sold them at a premium most of the payment around the time of purchase and no recurring cost licensing. Cisco has been moving to recurring licensing, but the move was slow and late, thus impacting revenue and growth.

Pros: Cisco fosters the perfect environment for technical innovation. Going to work doesn't involve the superficial necessities that jobs in finance require such as wearing a suit every day. The hours are extremely flexible and rewards completion of work rather than physical presence in the office. Cisco's upcoming technologies are extremely exciting.
Cons: The nature of the work tends to spawn people who are too tech-oriented and don't necessarily know how to have a good time. That is the only possible downside i could see.

Pros:
The company is extremely progressive in trying new methods of working; i.e. telecommuting, social networking, collaboration etc. They are concerned about the environment and are urging everyone to go "Green". 
The people are friendly and the managers are very supportive both professionally and personally. This company bends over backwards to ensure employee happiness and work/life balance.
Cons: I can't think of any. Maybe I've just been lucky, but I've worked under several managers here and most of them have been extremely good managers and made working at Cisco a pleasure.

Pros: Benys and flex schedule are obvious pluses. There are plenty of opportunities for career development and networking.
Cons: It's a large company. It's easy to become another number or wheel in the cog. It would have been helpful to have a peer to 'shadow' with in the beginning. I feel I was left to sink or swim.

Pros:
- Ability to balance work and personal life
- Ability to telecommute
Cons:
- lack of clear career path
- Work can be unchallenging at times
- Large companies mean overspecialization which can lead to too narrow a focus
- Management will give you more work that you want or can handle unless you put up boundaries
- Sometimes you wonder if you are making a difference since you are so removed from the final product

Pros: Nice campus, building, gyms, etc
Cons:
You're walking into a dead end job.
After 10 years of great reviews, ive had 1 small raise.
Cisco's plan is to offshore 85% of their workforce to india/china.
If youre american, they are just hoping you will leave one day without having to lay you off.

They will take all the free hours you are dumb enough to give them.
50+ hour weeks are pretty common

Pros: Your future is very much down to you, lost of opportunity to work in exciting technical areas and with clever people. Cisco leads and other follow
Cons: Your future is very much down to you :) a lot of polictics at senior level and as its a US company dont expect to make policy unless you move to San Jose. Lost of peolpe happy to jump in whne there is success but not when there are "challenges" or out and out failure

Pros: Cisco is a great company to work on and develop your carreer further. You will learn from many qualified colleagues and Senior Managment in this very competitive and fast pace company.
Cons:
The flexible working makes you fail in your work-life balance. You will end up working 70-80 hours per week without having a personal/family life.
Do not join the company as a contractor because you will be working like a fixed employee without having any benefits and neither management support or training.

Pros: If you're ready to fill your head with as much technical knowledge as you can handle, Cisco is the place for you. The phrase "Drinking from a fire hose" is frequently used to describe your first months and even years, and it's accurate.
Cons: Innovation is lacking, and the markets see it. Also, the company has had enormous growth and with size comes some growing pains.

Pros: Great to walk into any far flung office and have badge and internet connection just work.  Salaries seem competitive and maybe some middle managers are overpaid.
Cons: Cisco feels bureaucratic and slow but I'm sure that varies through different divisions.  A never ending cascade of acronyms and new initiatives all seemingly unrelated to the business of selling Cisco products and services.

Pros:
Opportunities to network with some of the brightest minds in Computer Networks
Good benefits and compensation
Flexibility to move within the organization
Cons: Becoming increasingly bureaucratic with a "my way or the highway" leadership style, Increased lack of transparency in management, Bad hiring practices, increasing mediocrity in talent, Management does not take your career development seriously, Extremely long work hours to fulfill mundane duties, Sub-par processes and lots of inefficiencies

Pros: telecommuting capabilities, flexible work schedule, great benefits, management is fairly open and honest, training benefits, many ,many great co-workers who are dedicated, professional and all around nice.
Cons: Senior management is a little ivory tower-ish and coming from a company that was acquired, it took them far too long to dislodge the old management regime.

Pros:
Interesting project and client based engagements available
Open culture to learn from some of the best in the business
Good balance of life and work opportunities
Cons:
Middle and upper management neither know how to define and execute strategy, nor optimize the "day to day" operations for the field
"Only good news" culture contributes to a lack of ownership to drive necessary changes
Internal processes slow down decision making and accountability across the company

Pros: Flexible work hours, telecommuting, intelligent people, thought leaders, cross functional & development opportunities, great mentorship, team players, open knowledge sharing, stable
Cons: Lack work/life balance - no downtime/LONG work hours, politics, lengthy processes, complicated structure, slow promotions, constant changes are counterproductive, no company wide event to boost morale & celebrate successes - too frugal (i.e. company funded local holiday parties)

Pros:
very experienced in business, sales dominant culture
competitive compensation, good benefits
Cons: Too many managers. All things follow all kinds of strict process, lacking of flexibility and can't keep top talent in some situations. Managers don't spend time on figuring out who make great contributions to the company, instead, they put most of their time on political things. People who gets promotion usually aren't a result of how much contribution he/she made, sometimes it is purely because his/her managers win in a political war...

Pros:
Very good people culture. Professional attitude, high achievers and smart people. Strong infrastructure enables you to get a lot done. Company allows/wants you to work you remotely, almost expected.

CEO says the company is like family and he means it. When bad things have to happen (reductions), Cisco does more than any company I've seen to soften the blow. Outstanding efforts in this area.
Cons: Hardware-focused company needs to make the change to more service-centric and software-centric world. Engineering drives most decisions which contributes to the company's inability to make the change.

Pros: Very good pay and benefits.  Wide and competitive product portfolio.   Cisco has strong R&D and acquisition teams.  Significant opportunity for advancement.  Cisco has many good people and is an ethical company.  Management does the right thing for the Cisco's business, customers and the workers most of the time.
Cons: Sometimes Cisco's internal processes makes it hard to get something done for our customers.  Too much "Red Tape".  This issue is being addressed by management but it can't be solved quick enough.

Pros: I enjoy being able to work from home and the tools Cisco provides to make it as easy as possible to do so. Great collaboration and teamwork are the norm in my experience. John Chambers is a great communicator, always very candid and open with employees.
Cons: Tight budgets mean that I don't get to travel to meet with my colleagues in person; upward mobility is difficult if not impossible; constant organizational and process changes are frustrating.

Pros: Main networking vendor. Good flow of information on the industry if you are interested into networking industry. Good name on resume (still).
Cons: In international branches only sales focussed with good career development possible only if you are from sales, all other employees in branch offices are not A citizens

Pros: Some teams are better than others. It's better than HP, similar to Oracle and IBM. Many teams are trying to use agile development - which doesn't adapt well to building enterprise product.
Cons: BIG company that treats employees as interchangeable. If they need you NOW, then you're OK, but as soon as you're not required they'll lay you off. And that includes senior engineers and managers.

Pros: Flexible work schedules (people work from home a lot), smart people, and good pay make it a good place to finish out your work life. Products are good, margins are solid, and the people are generally friendly.
Cons: The people who stay have died inside. You sell a part of your soul to stay, especially if you want to do anything truly interesting or innovative. It's a massive organization, so it's easy to get lost in the organization.

Pros: Technology turned into business/life-quality values.
Cons:
Weak Management made of young and inexperienced people in both sales and people management.
Vocal young-people using "informal" feedback to quickly damage people's reputation.
Continuous management changes make it impossible for employees to be fairly evaluated, from historical prospective.
Young management perceive themselves as "innovative", where in fact, playing consistently "old-Cisco" whenever possible.
Promotion of young-managers to demonstrate willingness to innovate, turning into a no-value game and proceeding to cut the older employees horizontally.
Consistent promotion of "friends", make it look more like a closed-club, rather than a "family" (as it used to be).

Pros: Flexible work options, benefits, employee recognition tool (employees can recognize and send gifts to each other), lots of technology to learn and play with, good reputation in industry, opportunities to do stretch assignments
Cons: Hard to move up (and around) and get promoted, particularly if you are in a remote location; Too many layers of management in some areas; can be very political

Pros: The company pays for your certs and gives you a small bonus after completing your CCIE lab.  Great start if your just beginning your IT career
Cons: The company is very difficult for promotions unless you have time in grade there and also does not come close to paying what others are paying for CCIE engineers

Pros: Lots of flexibility, many people work from home. Teams are distributed geographically, which is a testament to the flexibility. Good benefits, especially health care.
Cons: Similar to the pros. You might work with people for a long time and never meet them. If I was just coming out of college I don't know that I would like that -- it would be more fun to have a bunch of people around.

Pros: The department i work in has a great office culture. People are for the most part relaxed and laid back about things. It is expected that you get your work done on time but whatever path you take to get there is up to you.
Cons:
I find that the department is fairly rigid about what technologies it will allow developers to use. Cisco is a big company and as such moves slowly when it comes to adopting new things. 

Often times there seems to be a "too many cooks in the kitchen" situation when it comes to projects that I work on.

Pros:
1. Open culture
2. Scope for Innovation if we think out of box
3. Environment to learn cutting edge technologies present in IoT , networking and cloud
4. Some teams have hectic schedule
Cons:
1.  Very Slow career growth
2.  Opportunity/Chances to move up is to difficult after certain level ENGINEERIII
3.  Poor first line management, The don't know how to  distinguish b/w hard worker and time pass engineers. (restricted to few teams)
4.  No onsite opportunities for ENGINEER I and ENGINEER II though they perform outstanding.
5.  JOB rotation policy is scrap. A process is there but none of the manager leave his resource.

Pros: Great benefits, global team, open to improvement, flexibility, work-life balance, connectivity, win, win, win mindset, customer focus, a vision of making the world a better place - all these things and more contributed to a sense of real pride in being a Cisco employee, regardless of the stock price.
Cons: Departure from employee ownership mindset was a terrible loss and reduced management credibility.   Being the apparent source of many Dilbert strips regarding the over-reliance on meetings for every decision led to a great reduction in ability to delivery solutions in a timely, cogent manner.

Pros: It's a good company with exposure to some good technology. I enjoy the focus on staying at the top of most industries, although this is beginning to decline.
Cons: This company treats its employees poorly recently. I have had issues with my manager, with changes in the organization, with low pay, and with terrible company acquirements that leave us lower than where we were/

Pros: Employee and customer focused company. Great experience working with multiple highly talented teams.
Cons: Became too large and too bureaucratic with many many layers of management. Manager reports to manager reports to senior manager reports to director reports to one more director reports to ....

Pros: Flexible work schedule, stable, great benefits & change happening on a large scale currently. Groups are varied by the manager.
Cons: Regular increases are exceedingly hard to come by, even for the top performers outside of promotion cycles. Which are rarely given. Also, ease of movement, agility in process. Very political environment. Groups are varied by the manager.

Pros: The line of work is interesting, and mostly cool projects to work on. My direct team is great. Stable. Work from home option is great.
Cons: There is a definite corporate politics atmosphere, where schmoozing is important the higher up you are. I have experienced a culture of entitlement from execs who believe the world revolves around them.

Pros: Pretty casual culture, everyone was very friendly and easy to talk to for the most part. Everyone goes out to lunch together on the company dime on Friday
Cons: I don't think the CEO was interested in having a second junior developer. Code quality was definitely not a priority there. There were a lot of kludges and pretty bad separation of concerns. User tokens were exposed where they shouldn't be, and it was pretty easy to see that they cared about shipping first and anything else came after. Not a ton of support from the more senior developers there. The attitude was one of "figure it out"

Pros:
Flexible on working time and location - focus is on getting the job done rather than 'logging hours at your desk'
Great benefits in the UK
Cons: You are not really in control of your career, even though you are told you are - you are past around from one manager to the next and seldom able to define where you would like to be.  Career decisions are made and then you are told what your next move will be.

Pros: Cisco is one of the most famous network vendors, has the relaxing work atmosphere, simple  colleague relationship and the flexible work model. There are many opportunities to develop yourself as long as you want.
Cons: In our region, the salary isn't competitive, thus it would make engineers feel that they don't have much superiority and competitiveness, even if we support advanced technologies. To some degree, it cannot reflect engineer's value exactly from the perspective of revenue.

Pros: Good working environment, flexibility to work from home,  use of new Cisco technology. Ok benefits, including ESOP and 401K match.  Good place to get experience - and move on.
Cons: As Cisco tries to become a software company, more annual layoffs are likely.  Cisco continues to make BIG cuts in August - beware!  Cuts may have nothing to do with performance so network well while you're there.   Like most companies these days, don't bank on loyalty.

Pros: Great Atmosphere and work environment with minimal issues with management micro processing project.
Cons: Management style is so hard to put your finger on, but I think in general a good manager gives clear directions and actually stays pretty hands-off, but is ready and available to jump in to offer guidance, expertise, and help when needed. They did not have many of those.

Pros: Cisco is a work-life balanced culture with many friendly people 'in the middle' hanging out, collecting a check, and enjoying the ride.
Cons: Your political acumen will get you further than your ability to produce at Cisco. I'd advise another company if you are not excited by court intrigue at the top and bureaucratic indifference in the middle.

Pros: Being a women at Cisco you don't go unnoticed as they are not a lot of us, especially in sales jobs, so people easily remember you.
Cons: In a male dominant environment, there is little to no empathy in general. It depends on the team, but it gets worse when you are pregnant and once your kid is here you still have to put in the same long hours.

Pros: Fantastic benefits, flexible hours, interesting problems to solve, and fun people to solve problems with
Cons: Older parts of the company (both Cisco HQ and recently acquired startups) are reluctant to change their ways, and enjoy grand standing on seniority.   Also, some colleagues have extreme alpha male tendencies, which can make for an uncomfortable new-hire environment.

Pros: Work life balance, flexible working arrangement, very global perspective. Quite competitive starting pay when you get into the job and then it stagnants.
Cons: Appraisal and recognition process is ambiguous, not structured and not transparent. Do not expect yearly increment and your pay will be below market rate very soon if you stay there for 2-3 years or more. Some folks can be more interested to make themselves more visible to management to get the promotion than focus on doing the job - they make this a competition.

Pros: Conditions like: Flexibility, Medical Insurance, Homeworking, Company Car and so on
Cons: No career evolution : very few opportunities to move to a different role or department. For technical positions there are lot of trainings but not for sales roles where MBA or trainings like this are really appreciated

Pros:
Competitive pay and benefits
Good CEO
Smart and hard-working people
Cons:
Cisco is in a mature market where cost-cutting is essential. It's a good place for junior people with low salary requirements. Not good for senior people, esp US-based, who are constantly being laid off to create openings for lower-paid younger and offshore workers.

I worked there for 23 years. The longer you're there, the more you become a target. Don't plan to stay for more than 3-4 years.

Pros: Cisco is a great technology company and moves fast through acquisition. While that is good for business its not that great for employees, especially those who have worked there for a while. Every acquisition comes with a re-org. Plus there is constant churn at the VP/SVP level.
Cons: Un-due stress created for employees through constant re-org and resulting job cuts. Even in profitable businesses. Part of working for a company is a sense of trust that it has your back. In Cisco, its very clear to most employees that they cannot trust the company to take care of them. The next acquisition might take them out.

Pros: Over the past 5 years, I have been working with a team on the East coast.   I would start my day at 5:30 am in my remote office and be able to stop by 4 pm to start my second job as a Mom.  This is very convenient and allows me to stay very involved with my child's school.
Cons: Cisco does have a policy of limiting restructuring every 6 months.  If your department is no longer deems worthy you find whole departments cut.

Pros: Work-life balance is generally good with Cisco IT. Mainly, you can choose to hold back for one year and then next year try to rise above the current gradelevel. Depending on the team, and boss, sometimes, things change. But mostly you can reach out to the skip-level manager and get out of the issues
Cons: Cisco is a Networking company - not just the hardware, even soft skill side. They expect people to work with each other. Need to work on soft skills.

Pros:
- Positive culture
- Good campus facilities and benefits plan
- Excellent learning opportunities
 - Quality of work is a hit or miss
- Decent salary but currently with the recent MRR, growth is stagnant
Cons:
- Lack of identity of India IT team
- Ownership with HQ / US teams and order takers in India. Worklife balance takes a hit due to this.
- Offlate, excessive focus on ERO's

Pros:
- CSAP graduate program is an amazing experience and gives you a head start ahead of others for sure
-  Benefits are great and the amount of chances to develop are also very good
- High quality trainers and facilitators on hand to guide you
- State of the art products and also offices
- Great development chances
- Nice colleagues
- All in all best place to work :)
Cons:
- Fast paced and fast moving environment/industry
- Its a big company so sometimes administrative processes can waste some time (but actually less than in comparable companies)

Pros: Intra-company mobility, quality of staff, solidity of business and ethical principles, benefits. If you perform, you can do very well at Cisco and get a lot of satisfaction from roles as well as interactions with great colleagues.
Cons:
Sometimes  over-politicized, especially at mid- to senior levels. Can get in the way of swift and efficient decision making compared to some of its peers. 
Unfortunately Cisco has had to stick to its bi-annual limited restructuring exercises for the past 15 years as it is constantly trying to re-invent itself towards new business models. Creates stress amongst employee base.

Pros:
Work life balance
Flexible hours
Positive CEO
Good work culture
Great people
Cons:
Self serving managers that are obsessed with targets and metrics, who are also selective listener.
Managers are obsessed with "face time" and afraid of higher-up managers
Limited career growth opportunities within team and internally 
Too many re-orgs, lay offs and work shuffling within group
Promotion is not based on skills or job performance but by connection and/or face time

Pros:
Brand image
Benefits of gym , health , open to apply in other BU
Cons:
Old people and  immediate manager decesion always counts. 
Lot of firing and  without proper goals.
great talents leave due to limited restructuring plans 
CEO and board comitte always thinks firing is the best way for cost reduction

Pros:
Great work culture
Helpful team and manager
Awesome work life balance
Campus and facilities are world class
Cons:
Lack of regular hikes and promotion.
The decision making at the higher leadership is too slow and any changes take frustratingly long time.
Not a good place for an undergrad or fresher who is inclined to put in time and learn as much as he/she can in their early years. 
The work is very slow and the possibility of getting into comfort zone.
If the some of the team members are in US timezones, then there might be late night meeting every other day.

Pros: Very Dynamic workforce always changing and evolving. Pay is OK, Benefits are Good. Global teams and work from anywhere culture. Great Corporate programs around driving change back into communities. Get to drive projects with new products (new and shiny stuff) before our clients.
Cons: Current CIO has no clue. "Always on culture" can mean long hours. Re-Orgs every 2 years. Way too many layoffs.

Pros:
- work in teams is excellent
- good life/work balance
- remote work is well understood
- interesting work
Cons:
- work is often segmented across teams
- much of the actual decision process is no longer in the US
- focus to drive the market is lacking
- old products linger

Pros: Cisco is a great place to work. Coming out of college I was looking for an employer that would not only be financially rewarding in the short term, but also a company that would add value to me as a person and a worker. As such I was extremely pleased to be accepted into the Cisco Sales Associate Program, a year long training program that provides technical training, teaches sales skills and business acumen. The training was excellent and I feel well prepared now that I'm in a full time sales role. The pay's great, the opportunity for Cisco and it's employees is incredible, and I'm looking forward to a bright future ahead of me with Cisco. Most compelling however is the quality of people I work with. I've been thoroughly impressed with the diversity of experience and strong wills within the sales organization. All in all Cisco's a great place to start a career and I couldn't be happier.
Cons: Needless to say the great rewards are a result of great demands. This means often working long hours, particularly as a new salesman. However, I wouldn't rate it as excessive or unreasonable given the position. In addition to demands on time, they demand results. This means occasionally employees are let go for underperforming, and some people are uncomfortable with such quantitative metrics. Moreover, if you're not too interested in technology and what it can do for businesses, schools, governments, and individual's lives, then obviously Cisco's not the place to be. I would imagine as well that when Cisco was primarily a route/switch vendor it was harder to get excited about the technology, but now everyone from Jack Bauer to Michael Scott's using our stuff.

Pros: Employees are permitted to work from home at least once a week.  There is a snack table, and there are free sodas and coffees.  Even though I don’t consume any of those things, I still like the fact that they have them.
Cons: Time and effort are often wasted because there is a lack of communication between departments and within each department.  For example, 2 groups maybe working on the same thing at the same time.   Also, there are too much politics; people spend more time in fighting for power than getting more works done.

Pros:
Company reputation
Flexibility in work schedules
Cons:
- Its all about who you know not what you know
- Poor rewards and recognition process
- Employees that have been with the company for years have very low comp ratios, so they get prioritized to receive adjustments ahead of newer employees.  This doesn't seem to be a very fair process for newer employees that are doing good work.

Pros: I knew it wasn't the right place for me within three months, but I lasted three years.  It's basically a typical big company with the advantages and drawbacks you'd expect.
Cons: The isn't really a clear path up the corporate ladder beyond director.  Most of the management was somehow from another company.  It's usually ranked as a good place to work, but I always felt like they went through the motions on the criteria and didn't actually care.

Pros:
Exposure to a broad spectrum technologies and market segments.
Abundance of training
Consortium of brilliant technologists, visionaries, and distinguished engineers until their creativity is stifled, compromised,  and eventually re-packaged.
Cons:
The agenda of headquarters is not communicated effectively to the field and partner ecosystem or  field tested for validity before it is put in production with the sunset of tools, processes, and programs.  Any efficiencies and ROI's that may have been gained are lost with rework, work around processes and partner/customer damage control.

The most amusing power struggles and political positioning of SVP, AVP, Directors, etc.  There was a day at Cisco when John Chambers wanted no more than four levels of management down from CEO.  There are more VPs than a bank and just as much distrust, self-absorption, and lack of true leaders.  

Programs are funded in multiple departments to develop and deploy the same end goal resulting in overlap and confusion.  These initiatives have elaborate benchmarks, milestones, etc. in which the program teams must meet the red, yellow, or green milestone whether it has any business relevance or not.

Still huge parity in the best, most qualified individual with equitable compensation and compliance with federal diversity metrics for tax considerations.  Employee performance and goal attainment is very subjective.  If you are not identified for advancement, your compensation and success is easily manipulated towards marginal or worse non-performance.

Do not expect to be given credit for process improvement recommendations, lead generation, best practices, etc. as you are not socialized or given credit for it to executive management.  You will often see 'golden ones' given accolades for your creativity.

All internal moves are lateral even if the job has increased job responsibilities and advanced skill sets.  Salaries are not competitive with industry and increases are based partially on epm ratings.  The problem here is managers are given a certain number of X and E+ ratings for their reports.  This is a position in which even the most well meaning manager is tested with doing the right thing.

Pros:
Smart engineers who freely share knowledge and take time to collaborate.
Good benefits - matching 401K, PTO. 
Flexible hours.
Excellent facilities, including free fitness center.
Bonus
Good severance package
LOTS to learn
Cons:
60-80 hour weeks
No promotions
Too many rules and processes that change as soon as you understand and adopt them
Very complex Cisco software is requently amended by patching in code from purchased companies - with minimal cohesion
Little-to-no insight by San Jose top management on sites outside of San Jose
Development teams in three time zones are a challenge and make 'Agile" pretty sluggish and ineffective

Pros: Flexible work hours is the single most reason for me to stick to Cisco. Unlimited flexibility either to work from home or to choose a location closest to your home.
Cons: Being a large company, it is easy to get lost and to be visible you need to build your network of known people to listen to the feed back and also to bounce your ideas before making a desired impact.

Pros:
Company respect in the marketplace
Good hands-on technical experience in certain roles
Good customer wins in certain roles
Solid business with repeat customers, especially in mainstream market
Still many world class people in the company
Some remnants of the "overcome any obstacle" culture
Cons:
Cisco has become an organization where those who neither sow nor reap are now the leaders. Director after Director in non-productive infrastructure/biz process position gets created.

HR is a joke.  Outsourced and incompetent.  It can't even carry out it's main mission of indemnifying the company from legal action.
IT is a drag on the organization, not an enabler.  
AS sells cut-rate Offshore services at hyper-premium prices, and the market is not buying anymore.  Finance are nickel-and-diming employees to death, and a major impediment to doing business.
US managers are finding it incredibly hard to get jobs requisitions open, and harder to attract talent willing to overlook the shortcomings of working at Cisco in a technical role.
TAC has gone from the best reason to buy Cisco, to just another cost center that has lost its way.
CDO is lost in the fog of conflicting priorities and politicized leadership.

Technical "crown jewels" engineers/SE's/NCE's aren't sticking around.
Great sales folks are finding the market packed with better offers.
Top PS/AS/TS guys and gals are leaving for immediate 50% compensation increases.
Great line managers are utterly left without recognition.

Pros:
Challenging environment
Self motivated people can learn a lot
Some peers are the best of the best
Good experience for one's career
Finally brought back the college new hire program.
Cons:
Flagrant abuse of the H1-B program. Diverse workforce = Indian Majority

Stock has been flat for 10+ years.

CEO makes political statements that would only help him, not the rank and file.

Below market salary with mandatory (some paid, much not) overtime. (For TAC, which they then try to count as a 'benefit' and higher base salary)

Extremely flat hierarchy limits promotions to every 4-5 years for the top 10%+.  If you are not a driven workaholic you will not advance.

If you do not have/get your CCIE you will not advance. You will not be given time to study, but are expected to do so IN ADDITION to your 60+ hour work week. Internal CCIE resources are mostly mediocre or have giant waiting lists.

Salary or cost of living adjustments are mediocre to non-existent.

The best and brightest engineers tend to leave after 2 or 3 years once they figure out raises or promotions are nearly impossible and they will be paid much more elsewhere.  

Constant outsourcing continues to scrape off the bottom end.  This is fine for a short time, but after ten plus years of this, the current bottom end is the previous mid to high end.  They're scraping bone now and show no signs of stopping.

Internal IT and tools are terrible, healer heal thyself.

Pros: The learning process is deep and never ending. So many products and services to major in as a specialist once you are in the Cisco family. Some of them are subsidized by the company for individuals who wants to grow with Cisco.
Cons: Complex, they focus very much on Tier one partners and the tier two belows are at times left out when it comes to service-both pre sales and post sales.

Pros: It is great to be able to work from home and maintain a relatively flexible schedule.
Cons: The marketing organization at Cisco is one of the most political organizations I have ever worked in. There is a constant land grab going on, people crowing about work they did that is simply their day job.  Politics are commonplace, especially in large organizations, but this is ridiculous and not exactly a motivator.  Also, make sure you negotiate well in terms of your incoming salary because raises are non-existent.

Pros: Pedigree of computer networking background. Great place to advance your product management, product marketing, Ethernet networking domain expertise. There are some great people there.
Cons: Abusive languages, turf wars among business units. Your product will get de-positioned by other BUs. And you will have to de-position them too. The company is terrible at getting multiple BUs to work together and build a cohesive system. In the era of modern data center convergence, this is a deadly issue that will cost Cisco continuous market share decline in Ethernet switching.

Pros: Incredibly flexible work/life integration, cutting edge technologies, brilliant people, and interesting work. My team has a great manager and we all really enjoy what we're doing.
Cons: Death of 1,000 budget cuts - constant pressure to drive down costs year after year. Projects get stopped or features & functionality get reduced to meet cost cutting requirements, however the work still remains to be done.

Pros: good Business, Marketing, and Sales experience
Cons: crowded place (Cisco sold 8 buildings on Tasman), and moved all the people to other buildings, separation of classes between full time and contractors (over 20% of employee are actually contractors to 14 vendors). Contractors are chosen base on their acceptance of the lowest hourly rate not their experience.  Technologically the company is basically counting on buyout of other companies, and they are mostly counting on good marketing and sells strategy, instead of technological advances.

Pros: Some of the best things about working at Cisco include good career opportunities within the company, excellent benefits, lots of opportunity for self development, global presence, competitive pay.
Cons: Cisco is a very large, international company, and the sluggishness of some policies and speed of change reflect that. The company wants to be very cutting-edge, but doesn't do a great job of melding that desire w/ being a 'great place to work'.

Pros: Cisco is the market leader in most categories it operates in. It is a recognized name. Cisco is big enough that the company "could" expand into growth areas, if the management had the knowledge and foresight to choose the markets carefully.  There is enough brain trust and money still on board to create the next dozen world-changing products.
Cons: Any company can experience only so much growth before market share and sales level off. Cisco's flat growth rate was inevitable. Yet the company still tries to bow to Wall Street, at the expense of customer and employee satisfaction. Outsourcing of software and hardware development jobs is reaching a fever pitch. Product prices are on a race to the bottom, while quality follows, but internal metrics for performance measurement have not changed in a decade. Products and product strategies have not changed significantly, despite re-org after re-org. Employees are asked to follow the same processes, and perform to the same metrics which were put in place a long time ago, when profit per employee was seven figures.

Pros: It's easy to take time out for family and personal stuff. Some teams work on cutting edge stuff and are very good for learning but there are also a lot of other teams which work on sustaining old products and don't have a lot of learning opportunities.
Cons: Compensation and other perks are not that great and it's hard to get a promotion. Lots of bureaucracy to contend with. The constant lay-offs and changes in direction can also make it difficult for you to focus.

Pros: Cisco offers reasonable and competitive compensation packages with the ability to earn more via bonuses, CAP awards, and such. It's possible with a strong performance, a supportive manager, and a manager who understands the tools and processes, to award significant rewards per year to an employee.
Cons:
As an acquisition our product has floundered; the product has undergone several management changes, the product has failed in critical areas, and there appears to be no ownership or consequence for those failing. Many teams have taken defensive positions to eliminate work or ownership of product growth and development. The product is circling the drain and no one seems to care. For a period a renewals team didn't exist and customers were simply canceled, and canceled without warning. The product looks as it did 7 years ago and any efforts to introduce new features has resulted in a huge number of bugs (customers treated as beta testers), undocumented features, and usability issues.

There are a significant number of long-term Cisco managers, occupying roles for 15 years or more, managers who seem lost in a Dilbert comic. Able but unwilling to enact change, making sure to not rock the boat or do anything to actually improve the products they're part of.

Products are extremely complex, developed by engineers for engineers, with no focus on usability or the human experience. Customers complain about complex deployments and call in for guidance configuring the most simple of features. The acquisition of Meraki shows an ability to recognize a strong usable product but its yet to be seen whether Meraki will survive the Cisco touch.

Pros: Virtual office supports work/life balance, typically strong, Sr sales talent, sales discipline drives exceptional visibility, executive level support for any deal when needed, Aggressive M&A strategies to plug holes, and broaden Cisco relevance in transitioning markets (collaboration, security, etc...)
Cons: Very aggressive, and political at times as you move up (or want to change jobs).

Pros: Cisco pays well and has a variety of groups to work in if you want to switch and stay within the same company.
Cons: No job security.  Large bureaucratic and extremely hierarchical structure which stifles innovation and employee growth.

Pros:
Ability to make a lot of money
They are extremely cash positive with very little debt
Large organization with good health benefits
Cons: You are just a number.  Your job is as safe as the stock price.  They are extremely top-heavy in management and you better have an "in" with your direct supervisor or you will not move forward...a lot of favoritism not based strictly on performance.

Pros: Allowed flexible work hours and environment.  Great collaboration tools to allow workers to work remotely.
Cons:
Cisco acquire companies due to lack of innovation and/or loosing market share.  Cisco mismanages acquisitions and have a hard time integrating cultures from acquisitions.  

Layoff has became clock work.  CEO announces the layoff at fiscal year-end every August.  After the layoff, Cisco will acquire more companies to gain market share, then, layoff employees due to overlap technology and job function.

Pros:
