The company is big so there's a lot of opportunities and lots of new technology to learn.  There are training classes you can take.  There are docs to read and presentations to attend.  

Hours were very flexible, as long as you make the meetings.

Cisco leases a soccer field for daily pickup games at lunch time and also used to run a league.  It still has other leagues for other sports.
Cons: Sometimes, the work may get overwhelming.  There is alot to learn for a new employee.  The organizations structure and the many acronyms used could get confusing.

Pros: Cisco is a company with good culture, good benefits, good pay and flexible work hours.
Cons:
1. There is a great wastage of talent, skills and work. Multiple teams, multiple people work on solving same problems, using same technologies in complete isolation with each other. 

2. The way the information is shared between teams is extremely inefficient and outdated.

Pros: Flexible work environment, great benefits, good people to work with, diverse job opportunities
Cons: When Cisco decides to trim budget, long-time employee tenure, loyalty and history of good/exceptional performance may not keep you employed. While Cisco values employee loyalty and high performance, the company does not return the favor during what has become annual layoffs.

Pros:
1) Initially good compensation but then yearly hikes are pathetic 
2) Work from Home option is the one of the best privilege 
3) Freedom while doing your task but not much of learning ( you have to take initiative to learn new things)
4) Good work culture and opportunity to wok with talented people
Cons: Not Good yearly hikes

Pros: if you are in senior sales position you can make very good money and if you can work your plan into the excelerators you could blow the doors out.
Cons:
The culture is broken.  If you are in sales avoid the services sales organizations, get on the product side, they control the account and the destiney.  I would have a hard time recommending being on the Services Sales side of Cisco to anyone,  If I were to ever consider going back It would have to be on the product side like the ESO, you have control of your accounts vs the services sales organization really an overlay sales organization that is in denial of what it is.  I have heard rumors ( 2015) that they are basically moving the services sellers into the product side, so if true I would expect chaos for the next year or so.

Back to the culture being broken, they have been doing large layoffs for the past few years, I have lost track how many, and it is not just bottom 5% type layoffs, which is why it is like Game of Thrones, you have organizational leaders trying to save their high paying fiefdoms, and it paid in the blood of the field.  That is not to say there is not lots of deadwood in the company, there is, but much of that deadwood was developed by the leadership by creating a culture of scared sheep vs developing a culture of leaders.   Think about what it does to moral,(this is more impactful to the sales support staff and delivery people)  when you have a workforce that is afraid to make life decisions because they are not sure if they will need to be looking for a new job every year.

Pros: Great products, extensive offering, some very dedicated employees that want to get the word out. Would be helpful if everyone was working toward same goal.
Cons: Lack of teamwork, Mgmt celebrates the wrong behaviors, so much more would get one if employees could trust each other and the Management Team.

Pros:
Work life balance and flexible work environment
Intelligent and responsible co-workers with superb managers
Large company offers many options for lateral movement
Competitive salaries
Good values that are demonstrated through action - social responsibility, care for the employee, etc.
Cons:
People management positions hard to come by and only after 10 years experience approximately.
Larger company is typically slower to move and role scope is generally limited because of size and complexity of the company.
Culture is not one of innovation and is attempting to get younger and more nimble but has some way to go.  This is not your twitter or google!

Pros: Good company, good people to work with, good work life balance, lot of scope to explore and learn new things.
Cons: The hikes in subsequent years are not very high and need to wait for longer duration for promotion. You need to inform your manager prior and tell him that you are looking for promotion otherwise you wont get the promotion even if you are top performer for consecutive years.

Pros: Exciting new leadership - at all levels of the company - so the company feels very energizing and focused. Spending a lot of time and attention on investing in people - engagement, recognition, performance as well as salary and merit money.  Good bonus structure and benefits.
Cons: The biggest challenge is the ability to change jobs within the company. Creating or influencing change is also difficult - like moving a battleship.

Pros: Great work/life balance, beautiful campus, decent comp (not competitive to bay area tech peers though)
Cons: No set salary increase schedule, lots of written "benefits" that never come to light (e.g. spoke to manager about getting tuition assistance for courses directly related to field and was told that the program was basically eradicated even though it is still written as a benefit),

Pros:
- Big Market share and footprint in the networking industry
- Strong Channel partner ecosystem
- Big selling machine on the ground
- Large portfolio
- Large Customer base
Cons:
- Looking to short term impact for shareholder value
- Do not value employee experience and skills and customer relationship
- Company culture has changed since Chuck Robbins is on board
- The People Deal message to employees is a fake story
- Do not retain talented people to move the company to the next level

Pros: Best place to learn and grow, Always something new to learn and the managers certainly encourage you to get training whenever possible.
Cons: The potential to move upwards is limited. Managers seem more interested in getting more work out of you then trying to help you grow. At least that has been my experience in the AS GDC

Pros: The technology makes it possible to work from anywhere in the world. the flexibility is great, the compensation package is nice, the paid volunteer hours is a plus and the paid birthday is great.
Cons: Cisco is slow in helping employees with professional development. It can be almost impossible to move around within the company.

Pros:
Supports work life balance, work hours flexibility and working from home.
Provides good compensation including salary, bonuses and stocks.
Has good training programs for employees.
Cons:
A very big organization, with a lot of silos and lack of coordination between teams.
Most acquisitions fail over time. Cisco doesn't succeed with maintaining good talent. People are sent home very easily, when business needs change, rather than diverting them to new areas.
Constant organizational changes. Leaders think about their personal career and benefits before the good of the organization.

Pros: Opportunities to work on new technologies, good tech training program, good benefits.
Cons: Too many layoffs in short period of time.   Too frequent change of project directions. Lack of in house research and innovation, rely on acquisition to get into new fields, however merging these companies are often unsuccessful.  Lack of culture diversification when most employees originally come from one country.

Job Title: Sales program manager & bow tie guy
Pros:
Cisco has 70k employees and somewhere around 40k contractors/vendors (total guesstimate) that work with us full time. We do business in over 120 countries worldwide. If you are a go-getter and have a passion for learning from work experience and global coworkers, Cisco is a perfect place to gain knowledge and grow your network which will help you through the duration of your career. Also, many roles are partial or full telecommute-roles, aka, work from home roles. Helps a lot for families with small children or folks who just live too far from a Cisco campus. There is a good range of younger, fresh out of college employees to seasoned veterans who have been in the industry for 10-30 years - so it's easy to find people that you want to hang out with or learn from.
Their social media teams are very engaged and a lot of the groups make working at Cisco fun! The different work teams and affinity network groups host fun events such as sports tournaments, concerts, outdoor lunches, networking events, and many more. We are partnered with Ticketmaster/Live Nation, as well as sports leagues like the MLB and NBA, so you may run into free tickets occasionally.
Great benefits (health, dental, vision, stock purchase program, 401k, life insurance), although salary is a bit low.
Cons:
Free food is not a company standard, although many groups offer some free meals and snacks in the office.
The pay is lower than the likes of Google, LinkedIn, Facebook.
The company is so big and complex that sometimes, shy, young new hires are underutilized and underdeveloped.
Too many meetings.
Relatively low base salary, but benefits make up for it.

Pros:
Good people
Chance to hop teams for diverse challenges
Cons:
Legacy monolith
Only innovates through acquisition (funded by layoffs)
With few exceptions,  outdated work environment
Mediocre benefits for such a large company (many startups are better!)
Culture and diversity are more talk than walk

Pros: I've been at Cisco for 18years and it's the only company that I've stayed at for more than 5yrs.  Ability to move around to very different roles, support for continuous development, and support in taking risk.   But all of this, though company wide can be hindered by a few leaders in some groups.   Sr. Leadership is very open in monthly all employee meetings.
Cons: It's a big company!  Thus not agile as we once were but the Sr. Leadership is always working on that.

Pros:
In my opinion, Cisco employees enjoy a very competitive benefits package. Salaries are fair, plus there are additional financial rewards such as an annual bonus and the opportunity to be recognized with gift certificates from co-workers.

The facilities (campus, office, relax areas etc.) are world class.

There is a lot of diversity, many different nationalities in the office which creates a good vibe.

You will have opportunities to take part in many fun and/or charitable activities, and the company encourages it by giving additional time off to participate (for example preparing Christmas gifts for needy children, animal shelter visits etc.)

Many opportunities for development like training, mentorship or shadowing. However this requires initiative from you, don’t expect anyone else to handle your career development for you. Often the company can sponsor industry certifications like PMP or ITIL.

Flexible work options. In most roles you can work remotely, and in some you will have a lot of control over your work schedule.
Cons:
Not specifically a con, but your experience at Cisco will depend a lot on your manager and team, which probably applies to any company out there. If possible, use your network to find out more about the specific team you are planning to join because not all teams are the same in terms of atmosphere, work schedules etc.

You can’t really expect quick and regular salary advances and promotions. In my experience, you will need to consistently perform above your level, plus the timing and budget must be favorable. In other words, hard work plus a bit of luck are needed. Some employees are obviously performing above their level and waiting for the right recognition. Because of that I've seen valueble employees decide to leave. On the other hand, if you’re good at what you do and have the patience it’s often worth the wait.

Pros:
- Solid stable company
- Good growth opportunities (career wise and company wise)
- International corporation
- Good extended compensation (i,e, bonuses, services, stock, etc.)
- Good possibility of work life balance (based on culture, but this depends on manager)
Cons:
- Sales focused company (focus on acquisitions, margins, and OpEx expenses) as opposed to engineering focus (i.e. R&D and engineering innovation)
- Good compensation, but not as competitive as it should be
- Management is very influential (compensation/work life balance can be significantly impacted by management decisions)

Pros: Great Culture and good work life balance. Company provides all the benefits required.
Cons: Over the years I have seen the focus moving from technical excellence to cutting costs. Because of this we are losing on a lot of good talent to other companies.  Due to this gradually the focus of employees is moving from customer centric to a mundane process oriented culture.

Pros: There is an inherent trust that everyone will give their best in a flexible working culture. Being accepted for who you are and being encouraged to bring your whole self to work is another plus. Giving back is a huge priority for Cisco and everyone is encouraged to get involved in volunteering which I love!
Cons: Flexible working conditions mean sometimes it does feel like you are 'always on' but it's a small price to pay for being able to fit work into your life rather than fit your life around your work.

Pros:
Great and evolving culture where you are encouraged to bring your "whole self" to work. Especially awesome are the Employee Resource Organizations that celebrate employee diversity and inclusion.
Cisco Executive Leadership Team are taking huge strides to promote better mental health awareness programs and culture within Cisco.
Cons: Annual layoffs affect morale and have a feeling of"The Hunger Games".

Pros:
Cisco is a great company! I have worked at many different companies including start-ups and other mature companies. I will be at Cisco until I retire. Cisco does an outstanding job at giving employees the freedom to deliver to their full potential and rewards excellence. Many companies claim to encourage upward mobility but never deliver. Cisco has an incredible amount of opportunity and every leader I have encountered at Cisco actively encourages her or his team member to prepare for the next role. Additionally, There are many avenues to share your ideas and execute on them if they make sense.

Cisco celebrates diversity and has “ERO” groups to connect people of different backgrounds with each other. As an Air Force veteran, I am a member of the “Veteran ERO” and am always uplifted by the many initiatives and opportunities we have to celebrate our fellow Veterans and fallen Heroes.

Lastly, I have never been at a company that has such an incredible culture of lifting each other up!  We all need help and advice at times (in technology, probably more often than in other industries!). Most other companies have a few people you know will help you and not make you feel like a burden. At Cisco, it is RARE to find someone who is not overly eager to help, point you to someone who will help, or help you find the right resources. It is humbling to ask a question and immediately be in touch with someone who authored the book on a subject!

As a large and successful corporation, benefits are very good and employees are given the necessary resources to succeed. We work on the newest technologies, with modern processes that help Cisco (and us as employees) to stay ahead of the curve!
Cons: If you are not accustomed to change, you may have some challenge getting used to work at Cisco. Our leadership does a great job of staying relevant in the industry (our market share and market cap shows this). To do this, we are in a constant state of change. You basically have to hold on tight and enjoy the ride!

Pros: Cisco has an awesome reputation to it is definately a resume builder and you learn some valueble skills.
Cons: Crabs in a bucket culture due to the fact there are limited FTE positions everyone is mostly contractor. So when a FTE position comes along it is a volitile place. Some leadership/ Team leads are may be good at the technical but are not good at being a team lead or leading a team. That caused a lot of turmoil with in the group.

Pros: Cisco is the best place I have worked for, after several other big companies in Krakow, in overall 13 years. I have been with Cisco for 5 years now and I hope it will be at least another 5. What I value most is the flexibility of the working conditions, I can work both from home and the office, there is no micromanagement, I feel the independence and I value that the hard work is being appreciated here. I also like the diversity and multicultural environment.
Cons: Cannot think of any cons at the moment.

Pros: Starting to take innovation more seriously and make improvements to a legacy portfolio of products and services.
Cons: Sales leadership is so out of touch with modern sales techniques. They do not use the CRM effectively to mange deal cycle. It’s quite embarrassing. The entire territory allocation process is like a bad dream. Someone up to had no idea on how to build out a strategic territory GTM plan. It’s just plain bazaar. Things will continue to deteriorate under this pathetic model. Until then Zoom will continue to eat their lunch.

Pros:
* Excellent working environment with knowledgeable and dedicated teams / team members
* Plenty of oppertunities within the organisation to move around and/or train to learn new skills and keep things fresh
* Great office conditions with free snacks/drinks and bi-weekly meals provided etc.
* Great company direction and leadership
* Comprehensive private healthcare
* Decent pension contribution
* Good overall remuneration (bonus / stocks)
Cons: * Poor base salary compared to market

Pros:
I have been working for Cisco for more than 2 years now. I joined Cisco straight out of college.
I will forever be grateful to Cisco for helping me build myself from scratch. 
Even though I am here on Glassdoor looking for a job switch now, I am amused to see how high my standards have become, all because the way I am treated here at Cisco.
They might not be paying me as much as I want but they sure are treating me well.

> Best work culture ever. Saying this based on what I hear from friends working in other companies.
> You will know they actually care about you and Cisco will go out of its way to show it to you.
> Excellent leadership team, their ideas and visions flow through the entire company and keep us all on the right path.
> Got to learn a lot in the past 2 years, all thanks to the management and teammates.
> Satisfactory compensation.
Cons:
The role that I am in is customer-facing and with a support role, comes its own challenges. Everyone knows Cisco TAC and appreciates it for the work we do. At the same time, being a TAC engineer can get exhausting for the following reasons.

1. We are supposed to work 8 hours a day but the amount of work can never be wrapped up in that time. Even though we hand off after our shifts, you will always have work pending on you.
2. Escalations may exhaust you now and then.
3. In the past 2 years that I have spent here, I have only heard of cost-cutting measures taken to save the business and keep it growing. Although I understand the decisions taken from a business point of view, but they still need to make promotions more frequent and rewarding.
4. The sheer amount of talent present in Cisco makes it very hard for you to get promoted. Doing your day-to-day job well is not good enough, you have to show the extra efforts you have put in to get promoted. This kind of challenging work environment is great for growth as long as the promotion we get justifies the efforts.
6. Seen senior talent leave for the above reason.

Pros:
Inspiring CEO along with some other amazing leaders
Work life balance appears good for the team I'm on
Commitment to inclusion, diversity and social justice internally and externally
Flexible, hybrid work options
Smart and collaborative coworkers throughout company
Cons:
Cisco is transforming its business amidst a profound technology change so it can be bumpy with layoffs and reorganizations. Just be prepared and aware.
With some teams, there promotion opportunities beyond director are pretty hard so can force good people to leave if they want to grow title/career.
The compensation is not very competitive with digitally native companies initially and over the long haul.

Pros: Executive leadership, communications and some programs across the company were outstanding.
Cons: Excessive and unnecessary team politics and sub-team culture was horrible, bad behaviors allowed to occur. Pay was not competitive against peers and industry which is one of the reasons why talent has attritted tremendously. Internal movement wasn't always easy either.

Pros: Good compensation and benefits as well as company perks.
Cons: Bad executive management. Cisco represents a company stuck in the past. The leadership team clings to old strategies and is mired in politics and committee meetings. When the stock falls, the real workers in the company are the first to be laid off.

Pros: If you look at work over a 3 yr timeframe I would say Cisco is a better place to work then most. I have seen peers leave and the grass is usually greener for 1-3 yrs then they bounce a few times until they finally find a great home in 5-6 yrs after they left. Work, life, balance, culture, & opportuities are amazing. They give us the tools to succeed. Cisco truly cares about its employees and does it best. We do mess up at times but they address it over time and put in actions to improve whatever that was.
Cons:
Every 3 yrs sales reps usually have a very bad year b/c growth leads to an unrealistic goal, then you bomb that year and it comes back down to earth. Cisco needs to find a way to fix that b/c we lose good reps who know they have a year with no way to exceed goal and make little money. For those looking to work at Cisco we only make real money after we exceed goal. Only get paid 1% of revenue til then which is underpaid. For those who exceed, you can make great money. Also note 2/3's of my peers always exceed goal so most goals are realistic at least every 3 yrs.
Temp note for 2022 and 23: every rep is on a deferred payment program for 1-2 years due to supply chain (we get paid when items ship). If you don't have money in the bank to get you through the hard times, don't consider working here for a few years as 50% of our comp is hardware. FYI

Pros: Typically surrounded by people committed to the same role and the company will present a ton of “benefits” for you.
Cons: It’s all fluff. You will not be making commission because nothing ships for anywhere from 6-20 months. Sometimes more. The salary isn’t near good enough to offset that. Worked there for 4 years and made less in year 3/4 than year 2. This was while overachieving every quarter/year and getting raises… sometimes. Also don’t expect raises even with inflation rates.

Pros: Industry Leader.  Still a growth company.  There are pockets of good people and good leaders.  Broad product portfolio.  Broad coverage of markets including consumer, enterprise, SMB and mid-market, which means more growth opportunities for employees.  Location of San Jose, CA is also good as it is the mecca of high tech and attracts many great smart driven professionals.  People do seem to be collaborative, more so in some of the other companies.  Work life balance is being addressed more than other companies I've worked for and people do have the flexibility to work from home when needed and some people telecommute most of the time.
Cons: Too big.  Beauracracy.  Seniority matters more than results.  Bad for young talents.  I see innovation being stifled because it takes many councils and boards for the company to make up their mind.  Compare this with Google or other more innovative companies, the structure of councils is really slowing things down and often time doesn't necessarily foster collaboration, rather it has fostered passive agressiveness, walking thru the formality etc.  I've seen executives in disagreements in reality but always try to put on a facade of collaboration in these council meetings.  It's disgusting.  the folks in the trenches are good, but they are not empowered.

Pros: Collaboration, innovation, time off...Cisco has awesome management who want you to succeed.
Cons: Cisco is first and foremost hard to get into. Expect long interviews with winning applicant having a cheerleader push them through.

Pros:
Flexible schedule, very fair with family time off above and beyond the contractual obligations
Good opportunities if you know how to manage up, relatively straightforward to move around between groups, if you're competent
Cons:
Expect long hours, there are peaks and troughs, but it can be very long cycles. Currently working on a 3-4 year project with six monthly release cycles, and the trough is one month out of six.
IT is very disorganized, disproportionate ratio of program and projects managers, yet very little real planning happening. Lots of powerpoint slides, very little execution.
Too much time in meetings.

Pros: Compensation, Benefits, Process & Operations, Management Training. Facilities were excellent; IT support was outstanding.
Cons:
Reward and ranking systems foster an environment when there is little work/life balance. To be successful, employees know that they must always work harder and longer than their peers.

Some business units have stagnated...little opportunity for new challenges and learning. It is also metrics-driven to a fault. Acquisitions were handled badly, from a people management point of view.

Pros: Lots of projects and the pay is excellent.  Cafeteria is terrific, one of the best in Silicon Valley.  Many interesting people.
Cons: Unfortunately, some of the people I worked with had no idea what they were doing.  They thought their product was operational and were aghast when we demonstrated it didn't work.  Plus there is little communication between groups, even among support people.

Pros: Large bonuses, intellegent people, and open communication. They are completely understanding when you need time off. Not to mention they pay pretty well
Cons: It is a static company, they have 80% marketshare and they are not going anywhere soon. Yes, this means they have money, but it also means that everyone there is all too comfortable working there. This really is not the place to be if you're passionate about engineering or marketing. There is also a large age gap since they have just recently begun tapping the college graduates.

Pros:
The work-life balance in general is pretty good(of course that may vary depending upon the team and management). Engineering deadlines are not very aggressive and cisco puts enough resources so that employees do not have to sacrifice the personal commitments for projects. The growth is good especially if one joins from outside with 5+ years of experience.

Senior Leaders from across the globe frequently visit India and hold "All Hands Meets" to give market updates and the position of Cisco and its products in the market.

If one is interested in corporate social responsibilities, then cisco provides ample opportunities. There are about 20+ NGOs to which cisco India contributes.
Cons:
The salary package offered to New Hires(of even top Universities in India) are not competent compared to many other companies with same brand value. If one joins Cisco from outside, the salaries can be pretty high depending upon one's current salary.
Most of the Cisco core products(routers & switches) are stable,  there is more of maintenance work than new development. 
I will not recommend some one who intends to start career at cisco India. This is a good place to work after gaining some experience in some company working on new products which provide ample opportunities to work on new product development.

Pros:
The three things I liked best about working at Cisco were:
*The people
*The products
*The freedom to try new things
Cons: Cisco is a large company and faces the challenges that all large companies do. However, even more than most, it is a highly decentralized decision-making culture that relies heavily on collaboration and compromise to get things done. While this often pushes decision making authority down farther into the company (pro), it also necessitates a lot of meetings and constant internal negotiations which slow down many projects.

Pros: I am very pleased with the compensation package, and the flexibility in working for the Giant Networking company.  Working from home, flexible hours all help make for a good work/life balance.
Cons: There has been confusion in how leadership makes company decisions, and re-orgs are common at Cisco.  Hopefully the recent change will stick for several years to come.

Pros: A leading company for network infrastructure manufacture. Fortune 500 company in the world. The working environment is flexible. Base salary is decent in bay area.
Cons: Compensation is fixed over years comparing to other company. opportunity of promotion and salary raise is small. From VP to manager are from India. You will not find any diversity here. No free food and beverage in break room like other big companies in bay area.

Pros:
Great work/life balance - management truly wants to see you happy and productive and they know that having a good balance helps.
Ability to move up and around within company -- if you pick the right vertical, there are lots of opportunities to move around.  
Peer Group -- fantastic work ethic
Cons:
Benefits get worse every year
Company is getting "big" in the sense of HR -- too many hoops to jump through for even the smallest items
Company run by accountants

Pros:
Quality of work is good, but again depending upon the team in which you are. 
Not at all hectic. Now, that can be a positive or negative point.
Cons:
1) A lot of focus on work experience while making the hiring decision. Smartness comes second.
2) People are not enthusiastic about their work. Just want a stable source of income.
Definitely not a place for a fresh graduate.
3) Slow growth.

Pros:
- 401k matching
- Decent gym
- Stable in most business units if you're contributing
- Great if you just want to coast along in your career
- Great CEO who knows how to make money
Cons:
Cisco was probably the place to be in the 90's but not today. The work culture and environment is very hierarchical and bureaucratic; and worse no one seems to care about this. Old time employees are lackadaisical, out of touch and downright incompetent as team players. Another thing I've noticed is forming of "clans". I came from a company where despite the office politics when it came down to "getting it done" everybody worked together as a team. I am absolutely certain that this would never happen here, in fact, other teams would be glad if another team fails to deliver as this would look good in front of superiors. Managers here are extremely mediocre, which makes me wonder if they've ever had management training. The development tools for software engineers are from the Jurassic age (all command line) and the usual answer I get is "you'll get used to it". I mean, are you serious? I spend most of my time learning such archaic tools which has nothing to do with my daily job is pathetic. At least recognize that this is 2012 and people shouldn't be wasting time wrestling with command line utilities to get their job done. And don't tell me that real programmers use command line tools; there is a reason why GUI development tools exist and it is to stop wasting useless cycles jumping from one directory to another and running one script after the other doing trivial tasks.

If you're a new grad do not consider coming to Cisco, you will have no decent mentors and will be left on your own to fend for yourself. This is extremely sad since the products indeed are class leading and there is a lot to learn from senior employees but they are unwilling to share their accumulated knowledge.

Pros: Good compensation and benefits for employees
Cons: Lack commitment to the employees performing well and wanting to stay with the company

Pros:
Name recognition
Resume builder
Flexible work environment
Cons:
Who you know within company more important than contribution
Difficult to get increase on base salary
Too political
Too many directors reporting to directors
Dead weight seem to survive
Gross Uncertainty and lack of job security (second layoff in less than 6 months coming
Hard work does not pay off here unless you focus as much time on playing the game 
Subpar performance acceptable in some departments

Pros: Fast moving, peer group is collaborative,
Cons:
- strategy is directionless as reflected in stock price for last 10 years.
- Culture has deteriorated a lot. Politics play a big role than focus on solving customer problems and growing business

Pros: Flexible hours, good career opportunities for anyone that has the drive and willingness to excel. If you manage your accounts in cooperation with the AM you have all possibilities to make some fantastic deals and money :)
Cons: You need to be self driven and have a good network to be able to get good results. Workload varies from Q to Q, you need to be able to savor the slow periods so that you can cope with the crazy ones, 50-60 hours per week is an average.

Pros: Decent total compensation, flexible work benefits.
Cons: Big, bloated large corporation struggling to grow. More focused on cost-cutting than innovation and improvement. Middle management completely focused on managing up. Can't articulate objectives, strategies or success metrics to save their souls. Change direction every year. Congratulate themselves at every quarterly meeting. Refer to themselves ad nauseum as "the leadership team." Enormous focus on hiring and retaining new college grads. Reliance on large pool of contractors, many of whom have been performing the same job for years without being converted to full-time employees.

Pros: Passionate people, use of technology, sense of purpose, great benefits
Cons: Not enough resources, internal politics, frequent layoffs, no career progression, old worn out work environment (some buildings are getting a facelift)

Pros:
Wonderful place if you are looking out for work life balance.
Good Career opportunities.
No disparity between offshore and onsite teams
Cons:
Very less teams, have Product Management in India which give less exposure at design level.
With Emphasis on re-orgs, relocations CISCO is loosing Talent. Best example is the recent Business Unit move from Hyd to Blore  with no second option ,except immediate resignation,  given to the Talent, who could not move their families for their own personal reasons.

Pros: Work life balance can be OK with a good Manager.  Cisco still is a Global leader, the CEO's vision of the Internet of things was correct and he was ahead of his time.  There are some good managers and V.P.'s.  The benefits are decent. Ability to work from home and flexible work hours can be good.  Some smart people there.
Cons: Not much of a promotion path, Too much politics.  Cisco wants to be the best IT company, but they do not offer the best pay, The HR system and review system are not helpful.  The acquisitions and mergers have been anything but smooth.  IT is was to complex and bureaucratic.  The benefits, food,  and pay are not on par with many other companies.  I worked there years and watched very few people get promoted.  If you hit some big milestones and worked at Cisco long enough you where given glass balls (no joke) as a thanks for your dedication and hard work.

Pros:
Good training ground for new hires. It has many technical and non technical courses offered on campus for employees.
Since Cisco has been a leader in the industry, it has many products lines and relatively more internal opportunities if you want to take advantages of it.
Cons: Like many other big companies, it has reached the point that constant changing is happening, struggling to hold on to the market shares. many departments are being squeezed with budgets and politics plays a big role.

Pros:
New CEO coming in, might actually change the way the business is run. 
Good pay and benefits.  Test team has good access to hardware in the labs for testing.
Cons: Annual layoffs the last 4 years have killed moral and stripped teams of product knowledge.  Company is forcing teams to move to Agile even if there isn't a good reason to.

Pros:
It is an honour to work with such great people. Cisco's culture is something I strongly believe and why I work here.

Flexible working also works very well for employees, Cisco and Cisco's customers.

Another example of freedom of choice is your tool. You can select Mac or PC, choose your own phone or tablet, etc.
Cons:
Can't think of any.

It can be very busy sometimes but I guess that also depends on your time and work management skills as well.

Pros:
Cool events weekly pop up parties generous snacks and food perks. 
Huge Work-life balance, sometimes is can be a bad thing with too much time in your hands
Managers are awesome even functional non-direct reports.
Cons: ...On a higher level management side of  engineering  (I'm sure in different organizations as well) there is unethical and illegal practices being done. Why is nothing being done you ask? Well look at the diversity and you probably won't be shocked at who protects who in this organization, there is plenty of people waiting in line to take your job.

Pros: The work life balance is good, the pay is competitive, but I don't feel like I have the development opportunities. I'm wondering if the commute in silicon valley is going to get any better. Cisco is a good employer.
Cons: No development opportunities, as a new college graduate in hardware engineering, the pay is very competitive, but I don't feel like I have the mobility to change teams

Pros:
"Golden cage" benefits:

- 26 yearly vacation days (vacation days cannot be redeemed into salary)
- Most people will work 9:00-18:00, with no overtime expectations
- On premesis kitchen and dining room with gourmet lunches that are free (you just pay the tax)
- Social benefits are a touch better than anywhere else that I've seen
- There's a quarterly group fun day
- Cost for leasing a car is covered from junior employees and up (tax not covered), it doesn't reduce social benefits, and can be fully exchanged into topping your salary
- There are shuttle buses that pick you up in the mornings and take you back home in the evenings. Plus, you can order a taxi home and charge the company in case you have to stay late. The shuttles apply from Ashkelon in the south, and up to Nathanya in the north, including many locations in and around Jerusalem.
- Employees can take shuttle buses, and a leased car - no need to choose one over the other
- Employee Shares Plan is available to all employees, and some people get shares as benefit
- A very extensive and professional learning center, and learning facilities (online too)
- Some positions allow working from home (1-2 days a week)
Cons:
Cisco Israel is made of many acquired start-up companies. Most of these cannot make the leap of culture to change into being part of this great American giant. This fact especially applies to Cisco's Jerusalem based "NDS", which is the largest office of Cisco in Israel. Here's what this means:

- A terrible working atmosphere, with constant rumors of the next layoffs always going around
- No feeling of "being part of a big family", no feeling of stability, and no job security
- Salaries are below average - comparing with other companies in the same area/location
- Car leasing costs for non-managerial employees are of the highest in Israel
- Employee discount plans are more expensive than anything you can get privately
- Senior management doesn't execute, so there's no actual leadership, and no clear directions
- Projects are created and killed like disco lights, so there's no feeling of stability
- Mid and Senior management are replaced every other year, so again, no stability

Pros: Cisco is at the forefront of technology and has the power to move the market.  This situation creates a lot of interesting opportunities for workers and great access to customers.  Pay traditionally has been very good and the culture is very supportive
Cons: Cisco is facing a lot of disruption to its current business model and is experiencing a lot of executive transition.  Much of the old culture is disappearing and in some ways the company has not "found its new path yet".

Pros:
They're well made, reliable, and tend to function for a very long time without going down.
Well supported--it's very easy to find documentation on how to do something, or a company/person who can do whatever it is you want done for you
Cons:
•Price. Sometimes I think Cisco should be spelled Ci$co.
•Complex licensing. One could invest as much time learning their licensing schemes as you would studying for a CCIE.
•Inconsistencies between products. Cisco has acquired numerous companies and incorporated their products into Cisco's portfolio while retaining much of the code base--this leads to many quirks when working in the CLI's on multiple products

Pros: The logo (let's be honest, working for Cisco carries weight), Benefits 2nd to none, good work/life balance in sales, Chuck is moving this monster in the right direction (it appears)...  Cisco's size.
Cons: Quotas - Cisco is making it harder and harder to be successful  (make money) - YoY quota growth is high in an increasingly commoditized, software-driven world; Annual restructuring is distracting and unsettling.  Cisco's size.  (Yes, its strength is also its weakness.)

Pros: There's a reason why so many employees stay for 10+ years and/or come back after leaving Cisco. Great benefits, diverse workforce, excellent work/life balance, reasonable pay.  Good training and career opportunities for women right out of college.  Dedicated people. Strong executive team. Very competitive.
Cons:
1. I recommend that mid-career women joining Cisco enter at a level they can live with during the rest of their time at Cisco.  Only lateral career moves will be available to you after you join. Don't expect to see a raise or a promotion.  
2. There is a layoff EVERY year at Cisco. Work slows and morale tanks the moment the rumor of a layoff begins to circulate. Bottom line: one quarter a year is lost because everyone around you is terrified of losing their job.
3. Engineering org is predominantly male and engineering  leadership is almost universally male. It's easy to get used to men talking over you in meetings,  and promoting your ideas as their own. 
4. There is a lot of finger pointing at Cisco. People have a lot of responsibility but little accountability. 
5. Extremely hierarchical. You talk to your manager, they talk to their manager, that manager talks to their manager. Only Director level and above have any authority.  
6. Every career movement is dependent on your manager's approval. If your manager is a dud, your opportunities at Cisco shrink to zero.

Pros: The culture at Cisco is what you expect from any great IT company. The pay was very competitive for the job market. And the opportunities for career development and advancement are the best that I have experienced.
Cons: Some groups within Advanced Services do not experience the same culture and luxuries that is found in the rest of the company.

Pros: Benefit and salary are amazing
Cons: Sales and marketing teams are only teams that are treated with a high amount of respect.  I worked at Cisco for 7 years, and while the salary and benefits are great, the money doesn't go to anyone but sales and marketing teams.  The execs threatened the state of NC with the open-letter regarding HB2 talking about how much the company loves and respects folks, uses employee numbers to show how much they "care" about people then within weeks turns around lays off up to 7,000 employees world wide to slightly trim into their margins.

Pros:
Great like-minded people
Very good pay and benefits
Leadership with truly good intentions
Strong reputation and market acceptance
Cons: Pivot form HW-centric solutions to SW-centric solutions is a real struggle.  New products mean new selling motions and requires new skill development.  Not a easy ask for incumbents, and newer/younger employees are challenged with the legacy baggage that comes along with working for an older corporation.

Pros:
-- Generous salary and bonuses
-- Committed to staying a step ahead in the industry (even if not always successful in every venture)
-- Strong mutual respect among employees
-- Noteworthy commitment to integrity and high ethics
-- Support from the top for inclusion and diversity
Cons:
-- Huge size of company results at times in blundering moves.
-- Revolving door of executives is unsettling, and periodic layoffs are bad for morale.
-- The company talks a good talk about career growth and development, but you are really on your own quite a bit to make your way.

Pros:
* Diverse company 
* Lot of problems to solve
* Don't think networking is the only thing Cisco solves, there are many things to solve even if its not Cisco's expertise. 
* Friendly management and approachable leaders
Cons: Lets say, you really work hard and grow to become more smarter, it may be difficult to be challenged by co-employees which might have an impact, as you will be finding it challenging to find newer challenging problems, unless you make an effort for it.

Pros: Cisco was rated in the top 10 places to work.  It has a great work life balance.  It’s huge.  Some good people.  Chuck seems to be doing a good job turning it into a software company. If you are hired into one of the new software units that Cisco acquired, you made a great choice!  You are working with some of the best talent in the world and your growth is boundless. It will be hard work but extremely rewarding.
Cons: The startup mentality is gone!  The offices for Cisco employees are bland and do not have any employee snacks like the top companies out there.  Newly acquired companies have better cultures and work harder. Cisco employees are paid a lot less than the company employees they acquire.  Cisco is aquirimg some fantastic companies so this says a lot.  I’m in sales for appdynamics Cisco and the amount of preparation, pride and strategy that go into every deal is phenomenal.  I’ve noticed many from the Cisco sales side “show up and throw up” ... in other words they are not prepared.  On the hardware side There are many that are there for just a job and there is no ambition.

Pros: Flexible work schedule. Great benefits. Good work/life balance. "Family first" approach. Diverse workforce. Many opportunities to attend training and conferences. Worked there for 9 years and was promoted 3 times with 2 raises outside promotions.
Cons:
Engineering management varies widely between locations. My first 7 years were with a business unit where I had a great experience and was appreciated and promoted several times. Management was supportive and seemed truly invested in my career development and work/life balance. Development was team oriented with lots of collaboration and support from peers. 

Then I made an unfortunate lateral move to another business unit in another city with some major issues I did not anticipate. Engineering staff there had serious morale issues. My peers were constantly "joking" about how terrible the product we were all working on was. At first I wondered why nobody did anything to just fix the issues. After working there a while I realized it was because the engineers have practically zero ability to effect change in the product. So the senior engineers there are basically just going through the motions because the pay is pretty good, the benefits are basically second to none, and they don't want to lose that. Meanwhile the younger engineers are leaving because the environment is pretty awful. 

Having your own hard-wall office seems great at first until you realize you hardly ever collaborate with the people on your team. On my project the standard practice was to assign a single engineer to develop a feature, write tests, and perform QA in practical isolation. As you can imagine this was pretty stressful and didn't work very well, resulting in buggy products due to lack of a dedicated QA team. Asking for help on an engineering issue was usually like pulling teeth because you had to pull other engineers away from their work to collaborate. Management was not receptive of suggestions to change the status quo to alleviate these issues. My manager frequently missed our weekly one-on-one meetings, sometimes for several weeks in a row. When I attempted to reschedule these missed meetings my requests were frequently ignored. I know of at least 5 other engineers that left the org within a few months of when I did due to the increasingly toxic environment.

Pros: Cisco is an amazing organization that is really geared towards driving personal and professional success for its employees. I joined through the Cisco Sales Associate Program (CSAP) and the experience was monumental for my professional career and helped guide me from inside sales to the field.
Cons: The usual complexity that comes with working for a company as large as Cisco. If you are not proactive there is a chance to fall behind. Whether that's in product knowledge, tools, etc. Luckily there are many resources to help with this if you take the time and effort.

Pros: Decent pay and flexible options.
Cons: Too much politics, Many worthless managers who are motivated to play silly games and feel empowered to take any decision they want to take as they own the employees job since management gives complete authority to hire on wish.

Pros: Warm, Inclusive, Diverse, Excellent onboarding experiences, lots of training opportunities, development path, caring managers, visionary leaders, value their employees, get your birthday off, embrace WFH and equip employees to succeed there,
Cons: The biggest con of working anywhere is *having* to work. But since I don't have a way around that at this time, this is THE BEST PLACE to have to suffer through making a living.

Pros: Good company if you are looking to settle down and spend at least 4-5 years in the same role with great work/life balance. There are tons of resources to learn. Management is fairly hands-off and let's you run your business as long as you are delivering results.
Cons: Slow career progression with long pay increase cycles. If you are not over achieving your quota the compensation is not impressive (and even below market value).

Pros: Great benefits, not a bad bonus program, good people to work with. They try to do the right thing around inclusion and by their people.
Cons: People work from one layoff to the next (and that happens at least once, but sometimes twice a year), never knowing they could be next on the hit list. ELT is a bit disconnected from the standard rank-and-file in the company, especially when they are laying off people while they receive millions in stock grants. Certain areas of the company are very political and nepotism is everywhere.

Pros:
-Work from Home is normal here [even before pandemic]
- you can push the gas pedal based on your limit how much you want to work..
- lot of new areas and technologies to learn
Cons:
- lots of folks here working in same group for decades 
- lots of folks here are aged and at times some can't digest young bud excelling them and create roadblocks in growth... for some it is fun to deal with....
- Pay is not the best.... but decent one in bay area...

Pros:
1. Intellectually curious, driven and hard-working people (if you know where to look)

2. Everybody talks about this and this is in-part true: balancing life with professional obligations is easier than in certain sectors of the industry

3. Interesting projects in the security domain. For example, if you are interested in applying theory from high-dimensional statistics, signal processing, stochastic processes, causal inference and survival analysis there are many novel projects that you can get involved in.
Cons:
As a data scientist here are some observations:

1. Bureaucracy and red tape for accessing data and understanding data - primarily because of disjoint business groups and over-reliance on data warehousing consultants in India (Tata etc.)

2. Actual implementation of solutions that use data is exceedingly difficult. Certain business units of Cisco are on various parts of the spectrum of ML Operations and data infrastructure. Thus, these same business units are on varying spectrums for data science integrations into their services and products. Consistently, however, technical resourcing for data science teams, competent leadership with experience in deploying models and product management for data products is a deficit that impedes impact.

3. Related to (2) - cultural changes and frequent reorganizations interrupt or disrupt continuity of development of data science projects or actual production implementation of solutions.

4. Lack of investment in data infrastructure. Cisco’s engineering and data scientist teams (sans the acquisitions) are still mired in “software development” mindsets. There is little understanding or awareness be senior management and technical leaders of the challenges or workflow of data science projects and challenges with hard data science problems. 

5. All of the above is not abetted by a culture of sales and feature factories for current products - both legacy and SaaS.

Pros:
Amazing work culture with great perks. Bangalore campus is just woww.
Work life balance is really good, there is always scope for learning with lot many training’s offered throughout one’s stay.
Flexible work hours and lots of Wfh. Attrition is less at Cisco for all the above said reasons and no surprises that it tops the list for “Best place to work for”.
Cons:
LR - Even though a few BUs are lucky to be not impacted (like the one I am in), employees do have a fear waiting for their turn.
Growth - Promotions are not to easy get, although not true for everyone.

Pros: Generally a good culture, rewards and benefits are up there with the other top companies, good remote work and self management practices. Very high quality of employees - intelligent driven collaborative. Good CXO level leadership has moved the company to recurring revenue model and set it up for longer term sustainability
Cons: Had a bad habit of annual layoffs (seems to be discontinued now) - pockets of poor leadership at the VP level

Pros:
Like any big company, your job experience at Cisco will vary from group to group. The ideal situation in Cisco is to join a group which already has good mix of engineers at every level, and a strong upwardly mobile manager who trusts you and manages upwards well. If you can find this opportunity, and perform well, you will have the best career prospects. 
That said, the best thing about working for Cisco might just be that you if you are a competent and productive engineer, you have quite a bit of flexibility in defining your role and your contribution level. If you are really gunning for promotions, look for a good group, find a niche, take on roles that are difficult or un-wanted, and work your rear end off. If you want to coast and balance your time between work and other interests, then find a steady group, manage your time well, and you can stay safe in your job with just about 40 hours of work a week... and you might have the flexibility to telecommute or work from home.
Another note - Cisco is a great place for competent women. There is a strong network of women employees and a tradition of mentorship, that really helps career growth.
Cons:
The down-side of working at Cisco is that the salary is not great. And promotions & bonuses can get very competitive at the senior level. So, if end up in a group that is over-loaded with good people at your level and above, then you can get stuck in a situation where you are working hard but not getting enough rewards, bonus, or visibility.
Actually, getting stuck in the wrong group can be a pretty bad experience over the long term. Talk to people and do your research before you accept any offer. 
Your manager is also very important. There are two types of managers you want to avoid. One (relatively rare) will use you to get ahead but not give you a fair share of recognition. The other (more common) one is a  manager who is so swamped and has such little management insight / experience, that he or she is not able to help you with adequate guidance, especially when it comes to career development and growth. 
There is one other danger I must mention. This applies even in 'good' groups. There is a tendency at Cisco to just keep loading you with more and more responsibilities until you actually stand up and say enough. If this is an interesting job, you might find that you are spending more time on work than you had originally planned, at the expense of family, friends, etc. So decide for yourself how much you want to work and what your goals are. And then be prepared to work with your management to define the appropriate role. 
No one will come and ask you what you want at Cisco. You have to decide that for yourself, and then communicate it to your management.
Also, if you do end up in a bad situation, be prepared to make an honest assessment of the situation and leave. No one likes to quit, but if you end up staying 5 or 6 years without fair rewards, you will find yourself falling well behind people who were your peers when you started... and this is really not a good experience.

Pros:
As an intern, I hear a lot of things from other interns all over the company. I think we all agree that Cisco's New Hire Network does a great job of getting us settled in and offering workshops with advice on making the most of our time here. The administrative tasks during the first few weeks were very fluid for such a large company. I was very impressed.

San Jose is a great place to live. I love scenery, the traffic (or lack thereof), the very accessible and omnipresent public transportation (which Cisco pays for), and, of cours, the California weather. Most of the interns, as well as many of the full time employees, live in an apartment community located in the middle of Cisco's campus. Every morning, I walk to the nearest Cisco building and take the campus shuttle to my building. Best commute ever.

Before I got here, I was afraid that I would end up doing menial tasks like getting people coffee, even though Cisco and every other company I applied to ensured us that would not be the case. I was given a couple of small projects at first; however, I didn't feel like I was contributing enough, so I asked for something else, and my manager quickly found bigger project for me! :-) The project my particular group is working has a life cycle of about four months, so I'm really excited that I get to see most of it!

I can't say much about work/life balance for full time employees, but we interns are having the time of our lives here. We have something planned almost every night (e.g. free salsa lessons on Thursdays down in Japantown), and I've visited many of my CS friends at other companies in Silicon Valley. If anything, there's more of a life/sleep balance issue.
Cons:
I cannot believe "frugality" is so strongly emphasized. Is it really necessary?

The salary is great compared to that of other engineering internships, but college students tend to rank companies by how much they can afford to pay their interns.

Pros:
When I joined Cisco, they were able to attract "type A" personalities who were generally bright, self-motivated individuals. There was unspoken but obvious competition to be he most knowledgeable in ones chosen field and the most successful both for and with their customers and partners.
Together with the reputation that Cisco had in the industry, and the strong leadership in marketing that allows Cisco to punch way above their products weight, there was always a feeling that anything was possible.
The level of employee empowerment and IT systems were incredible, and no excuses were tolerated.
Senior leadership team was strong at the time.
Cons:
Stock options did not perform and were always intended to be a supplement to the relatively poor basic salary - these did not perform as projected.
Compensation was not comparable to those packages available on the San Jose campus.
The matrix management scheme was full of inexperienced middle managers, who had little or no people management skills.
Technical staff were offered no advancement beyond a certain level of income / staff grading. The only options to earn more money were to become an account manager, despite several senior directors having been home grown from the technical side of the business.
New recruits were given higher salaries to start and better grades, which obviously was a bitter pill to swallow for the more experienced and therefore more productive employees.(Cisco is a big company and it takes a couple of years to build the relationships necessary to deliver value)
Quality of new entrants to the organisation is somewhat lower now than when I was recruited.
Failure was rewarded with promotion, provided you could spin it the right way and kiss the right butts.
Nepotism was rife - not the place to work if you are a workaholic - it will bury you.

Pros:
The pay is good, though in the Bay Area it never seems to be enough. The benefits package, however, is great, especially if you have a family, and the new central gym/clinic/juice bar/pharmacy facility is amazing.  A dominant company with plenty of cash in the bank, it's definitely a good place to be in this economy.  
Training is encouraged and widely available and people seem to be encouraged to change roles every couple of years.  If you want to get a flavor for a lot of different aspects of the business, its possible to do.
At least in my org, there's some flexibility on hours and work location - working from home on Fridays has never been an issue.  
Its also great to work with people who have interests and concerns aside from just making money, and impressed with the amount of philanthropy and volunteerism.  Most of the people here seem genuinely smart.
Cons:
The politics.  It seems the only way that people move up is to make their sphere of influence greater, not do a good job with what they are already have.  So forget trying to get into a job and start kicking ass - its all about managing expectations and having a few wins, and then spinning the results.  Everyone takes pride in the company's innovation, but I think we're mostly riding on past reputation, and improving products we already have.  While we've done a great job promoting TelePresence, its not exactly a new idea - we just improved on it.
Part of the problem with the politics is that its difficult to move up once you get to say Sr. Manager/Manager level.  It isn't clear what the requirements are to develop your career, and people aren't always willing to develop their direct reports for fear that then they'll take over their job.
The boards and councils that drive many of the initiatives are all executive driven, and its isn't clear at all that they are productive.  Its tough to get everyone on the calendar at the same time, and it doesn't seem that they want to do any delegating to those of us further down the chain.

Pros: Learn a lot in a short amount of time.
Cons: There are a lot of employees that have been at Cisco for a long time and are set for life due to stocks.  Some (not all) of these employees now contribute nothing to the company and are just milking it.  This makes work difficult for the rest of their team members who are helpless to do anything about it.

Job Title: Web project lead (title has little to do with my real job)
Pros: I just passed my 10 year anniversary and am still proud to work at Cisco. The benefits are varied and quite good, lots of vacation earned (6.16 hrs / pay period) and caps at 280 hours. Lots of non-monetary rewards like gymnasium, child care, dry cleaning, car wash, new medical facility, free soda and water (although not for long), and telecommuting options (although this varies greatly by group and manager), the pay for my monthly home broadband too ($62/month). Lots of on-line education and the tuition reimbursement is great ($7500/year). Fortunately I work in a fairly decent group (marketing) with minimal politics except for a few highly volitle people. I have an engineering background so like the mix of business and technical. If you're a technical person, it's a pretty good gig.
Cons:
I don't know where the many people who wrote reviews here work who said there is good work/life balance because I've never seen it. I have never worked less than 55 hrs/week and often 80+ hrs.  There absolutely are duds here who are great at talking non-stop and so get recognized but they don't do anything. I get frustrated working at a high tech company and constantly get asked stupid questions about how to use Excel or PowerPoint or things they can easily look up themselves. How can someone get a job here and not know computer basics is beyond me. Just because they're busy doesn't mean they're productive (basic computer skills would be a great improvement).

I also don't like the performance review system which many others mentioned. It's an absolute joke (and not a good one). Your score has little to do with the quality of your work, but how much your manager likes you, how much work s/he is willing to do to help you get ahead, and how lazy they are. I've had managers tell me they never give an X (the highest score) no matter what you do and everyone gets the same rating because it's easier for the manager. I was fortunate to finally get a promotion last year (and two raises) but it was a horrific, butt-kissing process. I've had over 15 CAP awards over the years but none of that seems to matter. You can do the exact same work for manager A and get a E score but then move to manager B and get an X, it makes no sense and there is no oversight or standards.

Pros:
-Get a chance to work with the smart and stupid people at the same time (find this in the meeting most of the time)
-Flexible hours (you can work from anywhere, tolilets or home as long as you have a phone or wifi)
-Cross function working experience (from engineer to VP together)
-Super quick promotion/raise you could get if your boss is your buddy or friend
-Good to have a Cisco batch to show (like driving a volkswagen that is made in mexico, go figure the quality urself)
-You can choose macbook Pro but if you screw up then no IT support
Cons:
-Very vague promotion/raise policy and performance review guideline, basically the top management makes the rules here
-Extremely long hours, 8 hours a day at least you would need on just in the meeting and 4-6 hrs spending each day on emails, reports, projects, ridiculous last minutes super urgent request from boss
-Employee performance is measured mainly based on how close your relationship with the management, if you are not on their buddy list, then you gotta have a lot of projects you are working with on hand in order to negotiate the next raise or opportunity within the organization. otherwise you don't expect to get anything excited from the management even you stay and work hard on your full time responsibility for 100+ years, nothing will change.
-Lack of direction and attention from the management, since the managers also busy working to make their bosses happy so don't expect they can take good care of the individual contributors like the engineers
-Must have the super silky smooth talkative skills like Obama in order to shine your boss's shoes and make them happy to win their trust and get good impression, again, doesn't mean you can get promotion but for some reason you would think that you need to do that.
-A lot of tools you need to learn and use every day, otherwise you will get stuck. most of the time the tools are not user-friendly and take you long time to get what you want. Some data integrity issue and at the end you will be ended up in getting just garbage data.
-Too many different process you need to be familiar with and people make changes to the process very frequently especially after the re-organization which is happening every
-Very competitive in terms of Politics which you want to make sure you play the games right and smart on your role, otherwise you are "screwed". Others can back stab you or give you hard time right on your face.
-No career advancement opportunity (only for those chosen candidates who are close to their management)
-20 years old coffee maker inside the breakroom you can get in this so called worldclass network & communication company

Pros:
* Good work life balance
* Treated with respect
* Good exposure to different technologies
* Good brand name in industry
Cons:
* SJ based companies. Growth in other locations limited
* Lots of growth in late 90s and early 2000s - but not much in last few years. As a result, there are well compensated middle/senior managers, who don't want to move, and ill-compensated junior people with not much potential to grow
* Too much process

Pros: There is a lot of collaboration between different teams, there is good internal networking, although perhaps not as good as Microsoft. There is good communication with top level leadership and they are really trying to make career growth a priority for people.
Cons: It depends on the group, but some groups are better than others at communication, and those on the main campus (in Cali) are more respected and given more important roles than similarly qualified individuals offsite.

Pros: Access to great technology, a chance to meet with the best in the industry (Customers that is). You can work from home depending on your manager. There are still some managers that beleive you must be inthe office. News flash eat what you make, webex, umi, telepresence..shall I go on? The medical is great however company has started to re-look at this.
Cons: Company has taking virtualization to the highest, have removed all  human interaction from training to mentorship etc. There are some fundamental things that just cannot be virtualized, thus a degradation in personal development.  Salaries are not up to par with the industry. Take it or leave it attitude this is Cisco!  Attitude is very pompous of middle management, here is a news flash, those whom were responsible for building CSCO are gone (Retired with $$ or heading up your competition). You will have to pave your own way the brand is not what it used to be.  Cisco has no identity internally, no company culture. This is a result of the plethora of acquisition that has created a melting point of everyone wanting to build their own empire as this was the cohesive Cisco of the 90s.

Pros: Good benefits, Silicon Valley HQ, base of operations.
Cons: If you're not growing, you're dying! Cisco is now focused on short-term deliverables of cost savings, at the expense of medium, long-term planning. This is a survival strategy, not a growth strategy. The stock price will never recover until Cisco shows where the revenue growth will come from. They need a top-line revenue plan, as well as a cost containment plan to be successful.

Pros:
Very competent workforce. Benefits are ok, salaries are low, but when bonus is added, then it is
close to the industry average. 
Work life balances is preached about, but seldom practised. But depends on the BU/team you are
a part of.
You can anonymously interview with other teams when you are ready to move. But never trust any
of the internal career websites, since clicking buttons can rock the boat by a tip off to the present
reporting chain.
There is $30 billion cash, but they cut employee amneties like free soda etc.
Good employees are continuing to leave.
Cons:
Benefits are ok, salaries are low, but when bonus is added, then it is
close to industry average. Absolutely ZERO career progression opportunity if you are located outside of San Jose. Cisco does a good job of lipservice about promoting other sites, but the executives are total snobs. They want all their reports to be local in SJ, regardless of costs and attrition rates. Poor performing execs get promoted and moved up. When your run rate is over $1B, why rock the boat with new R&D and increasing your bottom line? Status quo is great. Brown nosing works well. Many a managers and Directors are jerks and should not have been put in leadership roles to begin with.  Now the senior execs are flattening the organization, meaning absolutely no career path if one plans to move from say engineering to management.

Pros: Some of the best people in the industry, good products most of the time and large scale allows to to get the job done.
Cons: R&D getting too focused on there KPIs not what the market wants, slow decisions and much more politics - making us miss markets and opportunities. Start to loose the wrong people.

Pros: Good products which are well known by IT professionals.
Cons: I worked for a contract employer, and my program was cut by 80% staffing (including me) when the company laid off 10K staff.  My immediate supervisor was excellent.  Technically, we both had bosseses working in different divisions.  Somewhat confusing re: varying compensation incentives and conflicting goals.  It would be better if the lines of reporting were linear.

Pros:
It used to be a good place to work. Experience looks good on a resume. ESSP was a great deal.
Severance is good, when they offshore you.
Cons: In Cali, India or China it is probably an ok job. In RTP, you can be in sales or support and possibly have a future. If you are a Sr. developer in RTP, your future is limited. When you start teaching offshore replacements, be worried. Don't be surprised if you work night and weekends, have great performance reviews, and then are thrown out like old socks.

Pros: Great benefits, nice people, support of work/life balance, competitve salary, good review and reward system, ability to stretch and take on projects not in my job description and be recognized for the above and beyond work.
Cons: Corporate structure is too big to make quick decisions. Management doesn't empower their employees to make decisions to run the part of the business they are responsible for. Processes are slow. Too many past acquisitions thus losing focus on core competencies.

Pros:
Strong financials make it a relatively stable place to work.
Decent pay and benefits.
Opportunities for movement between jobs are available, at least sometimes.
Cons:
Painful 'transformation' of the company is long overdue, and may be too little, too late.
Finance more or less rules - often penny wise and pound foolish decisions that favor short-term gain over long-term success.
Some parts of Engineering have really poor middle-managers that are better at playing politics than leading technology and engineering.
Many products hampered by 30-year-old software technology and a fragile architecture, making software development a painful experience.

Pros: Flexible schedule, collaborative people, friendly culture, invests in employee training and development
Cons: Need new young blood, some folks like status quo and are not willing to change, key strategic decisions which should be clarified and made by SVP/EVP are avoided which leads to confusion and actions that are not ideal by lower ranking folks responsible for execution

Pros:
- Decent salary and benefits. 
- You can cruise along without doing much in some business units
Cons:
- You can cruise along without doing much in some business units - low performers rarely fired
- No emphasis on innovation - you will pretty much be adding some incremental little features on  existing systems or maintaining legacy systems.
- Not a place for young superstars. Even if you rank in the top performance bracket, you might not get a promotion because there are 15 other older folks in the promotion pipeline.

Pros:
#Stable job, candidate doesn't get fired if he does his job, can learn different technology if we move to different group, RSUs given - though it is very limited in no.
#Easy to grow from entry to senior level easily.
#Rooms to grow by taking side steps rather staying in the same course.
#ccie attempts are free, complete them and move out of cisco if you want to earn more.
Cons:
#No matter what you do, you can't grow beyond certain level. Because there is no mentoring or the stuff mentioned on the book doesn't work even if we achieve them. 
#The growth/promotion guidelines are displaced with different info on 3 different places with different rules. It takes many many years to follow/complete them, not sure how people are getting promoted.
#Cisco expects to do an team work but your performance is judged against them using a method called cpc.
#Bonus is very small for the top most performer. it doesn't worth the time.
#Company recognizes the hard work but not to the great extend.
#Cisco doesn't identify the talent and assign the work to them accordingly rather always look for sr. member to do that job irrespective of he is capable or not which produces little to no output.
#Need to give way for young generation rather going behind the person who work for that team for 10/20 years who doesn't do well with today's pace and technology change.
#Job assignment is based on how many years the person worked at cisco rather checking the person's knowledge on that work or his prior work history.

Pros: For me, the salary was good and the working hours were good.  As a technical writer I did not have to work crazy long hours.
Cons: Lots of restructuring. Every other week they changed the organizational structure.  Plus, they are outsourcing a lot of the jobs to India.  There is also a lot of bureacracy that seems to come with a big company.  Some of the tools used were out of date, but with a big company, you had to follow their rules and use what they gave you.

Pros:
Culture promotes an environment where you don't have to feel awkward reaching out to more experienced people or seeking input on problems. 

There is great camaraderie at all levels, people are friendly and helpful.

Compensation and benefits are great but more importantly, Cisco recognize the importance employee satisfaction. Interactions with Cisco feel human and personal.

Mobility is a reality here, the workforce and teams are global but work seamlessly.

The company values are very simple - to put it briefly, they focus on integrity and respect.

Highly recommended!
Cons: I can't think of any.

Pros: Job Security is above average. Befits are good, Choices for Health Life, Dental and Vision. Stock options are not offered anymore. Employee stock purchase program is good. Training and education are Very good. Diverse culture. Employee's are encouraged to expand and move out of their box into other areas to get ahead. Salary is average or just above average. Cisco is a VERY very large company so experiences and situations will vary depending on location. In The United States, East Coast RTP TAC has some of the  most intelligent people on earth. They are good at what they do and they enjoy doing it.
Cons: Compensation is lacking. Once you branch out of the lower levels such as support you start to run into road blocks. The company is VERY political internally.
