Management is great , above average at talk on ideas and planning but lacks the ability to create a complete strategy and execute on it. The company as of 2014 is facing its greatest challenge. Share holders want to see double digit returns on the core business, Routing and Switching. These are based on bare metal products. Bare metal is going away. Amazon and Google have already eroded some of this. Cisco does have a cloud strategy however its late unproven, and complex and full of issues. Cisco will fall behind in 2014 so do not expect a great deal of hiring. Bonus Compensation is based on performance and for FY13 this was sub par. Looking into FY14 this trend is expected to continue, companies own words. Same CEO has been had the helm since day 1. CEO and top tier base strategy on acquisitions. This is has stopped working. Simply buying a product or company does not make the grade anymore you have to be able to align and execute. Cisco is in a free-fall in this respect.  From a Services perspective Cisco is missing the boat. The company has yet to figure out how to deliver on this. Then again so has its competitors.

Pros:
Company is better than most large corporation - focuses on employee benefits, their customers and the market
Mostly great and intelligent people
Work location flexibility (very supportive of telecommuting and working from wherever you want)
Great work/life balance
Experienced leaders
Competitive salary but not in the top 10% for silicon valley
Cons:
Huge company and sometimes difficult even as a top performer to break the glass for promotions or recognition
Excessive management layers
Contractor to employee ratio extremely high (some organizations 70/30 - contractor to employee)
Seems face paced...but moves slowly at all levels

Pros:
Flexibility - no shortage of virtual/collaboration tools
Culture - people care about one another, its a friendly and collaborative environment
Talent - lots of smart and capable people
Cons:
Strategy is not clear - too many "shiny balls" in the air
Low accountability to factors that drive productivity and impact
No unified leadership to drive top down change that is needed
Many roles sliced too thin - low oppt to drive impact

Pros: Services / Customer Advocacy -> Good compensation, great work life balance, managers trust employees, interesting and varied work.
Cons: Lots of "doom and gloom" talk from employees and management. We are behind the curve in new product offerings, code reliability is poor, operational features for customers is poor. Macro outlook not great, stock price flatlined, we have a few challenging years ahead of us.

Pros: you can gain valuable experience working in an international organization; great pay and benefits
Cons: you will work hard for your great pay and benefits, but the experience and feeling of accomplishment is rewarding

Pros:
- Flexible work schedule and location - easy to work from home or Starbucks
- Fun to work with smart people
- Good mission - to change the world
Cons:
- Frequent layoffs get tiresome and demotivating
- Management is good overall, but there are some bad apples
- Frequent stack ranking and firing the bottom percentage demotivates half the population
- HR not on the employees' side; they are there to defend the company
- A bit too much bureaucratic BS

Pros: Great benefits, VERY smart people to work with, can be very creative at times. Cisco is very interested in keeping market share for hardware, and now  getting into software, so it's shifting a lot of internal views on what's profitable, which is a good thing. Cisco is willing to try, several times if need be, to get something right.
Cons: Sales is still silo ed, some business units don't take impute from sales and what customers needs are going to be. Long hours at times, very revenue focused.

Pros: Salary and benefits are decent, lots of great people.
Cons:
The CEO claims to care about people but has turned the company into a splurge and purge, now managing by laying off people.  They used to at least go through the motions of trying to see if people's skill set would match any of the areas being actively invested in but the receiving VP's would almost always find something not up to par and go for a new hire instead.  In the last couple years they haven't even bothered with that, now they give people a few weeks to find something internally but usually cancel 98+% of the open reqs just before that to ensure they move most out of the company.  One of the reasons for this is that the management that matters is not allowed to do their job of actually managing their workforce.  They are always encouraged to manage out the bottom but more often than not they are not allowed to backfill those they manage out, which as you would expect, causes them to only manage out those that are a net negative to the team and not just a low performer.

We are trying to make innovation into a process, while continually adding more mandatory process that stifles innovation and all the while continually cutting budgets.

If you are not based in the SJ area or India the opportunity for advancement in the management hierarchy quickly declines as you rise in the ranks.

We claim to be have great success acquiring and integrating companies, and for as many as we've done you'd think that would be the case but don't believe the hype.  The only way it works if we are hands off.

Pros: Good compensation and yearly bonus payout. Company provides flexible work hours and pays respect to employee's work-life balance. There are many talented employees across different functional and geographical areas. It could be a great place to work if you happen to work in a group with growing business.
Cons: Cisco used to like a startup company where engineers were empowered to make design and architecture decisions. Things has changed over the years and now management is under a lot of pressure to grow the tech giant by making "market driven" engineering decisions and cutting large number of head counts in declining business units.

Pros:
Lots of opportunity to find additional positions of interest within the company
* Stable workforce so long as you are not involved in a 'fringe' technology team being phased out
* Generous opportunity to find other positions if restructuring requires, and generous package in lieu of another position if you so choose
Cons:
Slow to move into some newer technologies, though rapidly changing that attitude this past year
Yearly lay-offs are draining morale. Engineering is viewed as a cost center, so engineering is being marginalized by getting less of the bonus pot of money than some other areas in the corporation. We're not sure where this will lead Cisco in the future as it has traditionally been based on technology advancement. It might end up in very dark places for an engineer based in the USA.

The best benefits (restricted stock options, for example) are reserved for only the top 5 or 10% of employees. This is stratifying the environment, and a culture of severe envy is building. As an engineer, obtaining the top 5% can be counter intuitive. Technical excellence helps, but political connections are most important. This is anathema to a typical engineer.

As an engineer, the advancements of salary and title are now extremely limited. The upside to this is most of the engineers achieve excellent work-life balance since there is little benefit to working too hard.

All of the above started changing sharply in 2008. Before that, it was a very different story. Many engineers are mourning the loss of a once great Cisco.

Pros: Still has good hardware, and they are trying to change the culture.       Individually, some nice people with sharp skills but the company is like a large slug that can't move fast enough to get out its own tracks let alone the bullet train that is coming with software, cloud, and newer consumption models.
Cons:
This company recently laid off thousands of people with more than half of the impacted employees over 50.    They shamelessly offer an extra 3 months of severance if the senior employee signs a non-disclosure and waiver of any rights for age bias.       The impacted employee is supposed to have the right to look within the company for an open req but that is window dressing.    No rehiring of the impacted people is allowed.     

Very few company perks  -- they aren't Google no matter how many interns they hire.      Not even bottled water is offered -- well for $1 a bottle.      

This company is headed for disaster unless their values and priorities don't change.      Their business processes and systems are archaic and even small business progressions like supporting the SP market with utilization billing is beyond their automation capabilities.

Pros: Cisco takes care of it's employees; this is the most important requirement for me as an employee.  I hope this point helps someone who is considering the company.
Cons: Too much bureaucracy.  Too many silos and small companies within the company.   First level management will not help direct reports' careers.  First level management does not do a great job managing teams.  There are too many employees and not enough work; Cisco needs to get rid of the slackers.

Pros: Good location, Good good salary, well-known, good management, friendly people, good benefit, flexible works, good cultures, requiring often customer site support.
Cons: very limited or late to promotion, For example, it takes more than 5 years to get higher position.  it is pretty big company, so it moves slowly. There are many political issues rather than technical issues.  The management is very conservative and there is nothing much to change or contribute in personal.

Pros:
Outstanding people
Good products
Great benefits
Not going to fail any time soon; expect many more years of network product dominance.
Good at driving technology changes in the market.
I had 18 years of above average and outstanding yearly reviews -- probably 14-15 of those years I would say the company still felt "great" (and yes my last three reviews were also above average)
Huge opportunity for "diverse" people to have a strong career track.
Cons:
Senior leadership that is focused on political consensus and not able to make good, practical decisions.
Leadership that puts their own individual careers ahead of their people and the company's success.  Managing up seems to be more important than doing the right thing, and what is sad is the people above the "manage up" folks can't seem to figure out that is what is happening; or they don't care.  It was pretty obvious to me when one of my direct report leaders was a manage up person that didn't take care of their team, and I had no place for that in my organization.
Cisco used to be mostly "A" players, and "B" players crept in.  "A" players as leaders hire more  "A" players and don't worry about the risk that the person they hired can supersede them.  "B" players hire "C" players so they can't be challenged.... and Cisco is well down that path now... even  worse are the many politically motivated  "C" players who have made their way into executive decision making roles.
Lost the early "get things done, do the right thing, have fun" Cisco culture as the company got big.
In early Cisco anybody could go see anybody with any title and have a conversation that often led to results.  Now you can't get on any executive calendar if they don't have a hidden agenda that involves you.
Diversity at Cisco means almost anything except older white males.  Unfortunately because the %s are so far off in the networking industry at large, good people are being sacrifice to the god of "diversity"
Middle-aged white males have no future at Cisco, don't bother going there regardless of your experience, brilliance, leadership skill or innovation level.  If you are in that category and still there... change is good, look around.

Pros: Work-life balance here is amazing. The opportunity to shift in projects or roles is always okay to discuss in open. I feel that Cisco the company as an entire unit has treated me well financially over the years. I've been able to make a good living and pay the bills with savings.
Cons: Consultants are renewed every QTR, they can rid you at any time and then your left jobless and shocked. Depending on the manager and team you're interviewing for, some will allow you to work from home all the time, even a few days a week OR some will want you in the office everyday for standard business hours. Some managers have even told me red badges had to come in everyday but the blue badges couldnt. I very often felt and heard the division of consultants (red badges) and full time employees (blue badges). I've been a long time consultant 6.5 years. There would be times when I was in meetings they would excuse red badges out of the room (how awkward to get up and walk out or hang up). Team lunches, email mailers, all hands meetings ect. all red badges were left out. I've even been invited to some and then told I couldn't come in and attend the all hands at the door. Sometimes I felt like I was peeling potatoes with the poor people on the titanic, very 3rd class.

Pros: Cisco is one of the best places to be if you enjoy learn new things and have chance to develop different types of skills, not only technological ones. Most part of the employees are very friendly and open to help you develop yourself.
Cons: Due its size and structure, Cisco is very slow when compared with some newer companies in the market. This can be dangerous in a market that is transitioning fast. However, we are faster than other companies with similar problems.

Pros: Great opportunity to learn, great people with whom to work, exciting products to sell, and the opportunity to travel.  Excellent pay and benefits.  The ability to work from home when not traveling or attending internal meetings.
Cons: "Cisco:  It's not a job, it's a way of life," is our unofficial motto. If 40 hours a week, 48 weeks a year, is your goal look elsewhere.  If you aren't willing to put in long hours on occasion--sometimes for a long stretch--you won't be happy here.

Pros:
1. Good management employee relationship.
2. Lenient Work Culture.
3. Great campus and the facilities.
4. If you want to spend your life peacefully without any tension and work pressure, you should join Cisco.
Cons:
1. Less learning.
2. People do not want to change the way things are.
3. More of bug fixing than developing real things.
4. No space for innovations and Ideas.

Pros: Great Company, good benefits, great people
Cons: Takes too long to get anything done.  Too many managers doing too few things.  Upper management has a tendency to not write anything down.  Expectation is to get consensus from bottom up all the time so that the management do not have to make any decision

Pros: Good salary, lots of perks, although many are available in San Jose only.  Depending on your interests, you can work on some new techmology
Cons: If you are not in the central core business, you are at risk for a layoff.  If you are not in San Jose, you will find your advancement opportunities limited.  Heavily political with regards to advancement, everywhere.

Pros:
Work from anywhere. 
Above average total benefits, and great place to interact with some of the best engineers in the industry, wide spectrum of products, technologies to learn from, and plenty of lateral options.
Cons:
Work from anywhere (so expectations in Asia, different cultures expecting 24 hours availability). 
Extremely complex organizational structure, Never updated internal information sources and lack of any formal structure/systems

Pros:
Work/life balance (working from home rocks!)
Decent benefits
Some good/talented folks in the trenches (but dwindling fast)
Cons:
No company vision
Lack of vision leads to lack of direction for mid-level management, which burns them out
Rampant nepotism
Political skills more important than technical skills
Stagnant salaries, very few promotions

Pros:
Being able to work from home
Equity scheme
Cons:
I came to Cisco via an acquisition.  Within a few years all the VPs and above from before the merger were fired or laid off, including virtually all the HR staff once the acquisition closed. Now almost all the Marketing people have been laid off. There is an annual cull of about 6,000 staff at the end of the FY and people are laid off each quarter which is damaging to morale. If you reach a senior position you are in danger of being seen as too expensive. 

When the layoffs happen you are just a number on an excel sheet, don’t have all illusions that management care about you or recognizes any of the hard work or your achievements in the last few years

Pros: Market leader and a lot of cash in the bank. Flexibility to work from home. Culture to care and help each other. There are many employee resources available. Global presence and connections.
Cons: It's like a joke but this is not uncommon a SVP reports to another SVP under another SVP. You can imagine this only creates slowness, politics, and duplication. "senior executives" care only about their promotions and compensations.

Pros:
+ Internships were enjoyable because I got to work on small but interesting projects in an easygoing environment. That said, compensation is very much below average compared to other tech companies in Silicon Valley.

+ Work/life balance is good. Rarely is anyone ever expected to work more than 40 hours per week. This might depend on your group though.

+ They are making a good effort to update their offices in San Jose from the old cubicle farms to the newer open-floor setups with free amenities (coffee/tea/espresso, snacks, etc.).

+ They do not skimp on developer machines and peripherals like monitors, headphones, etc.
Cons:
- Very bureaucratic, lots of reorgs and movement at the middle and upper levels (e.g. new directors, mid-level managers, upper-level managers).

- The pay is below average in comparison to other tech companies in the Bay Area. Promotions/raises seem to be few and far between. It will soon be my third year here, and all of my developer peers have also complained about slow growth within the company.

- Due to the bureaucratic nature of the company, communication among the many groups is slow and sporadic.

- It may be different for other groups, but there seems to be a general lack of expertise when it comes to software development best practices:
-- Everything is hacked together
-- Quantity of features and speed of development > quality and stability
-- There are no design/architecture discussions that include all of the developers ("design" of the product usually happens as informal conversations between mid-to-senior level developers, without including the newer/entry-level developers). These discussions are ad-hoc, informal, and often not even documented.
-- No standards followed for releases/deployment
-- Very little effort spent on documentation of anything
-- We are one of the many groups that tries to follow Agile/Scrum, but since we don't follow a lot technical practices that actual make Agile work (e.g. unit tests, code reviews, decent documentation, reasonably-sized & well-defined user stories, etc.), it isn't working as it should. The end result is shoddy code and constantly accumulating technical debt.

- People in non-technical roles (middle managers and product owners) push for features and user stories without really knowing what they want. User stories are often a terse title and an empty description (no behavioral/functional specifications, no summary, no consideration for inter-dependencies among other user stories).

- Projects often lack clear direction. This point applies to my group and our project, but I think it might apply to other groups as well. There are many technical leaders in our group, but for our project, we lack a TRUE lead technical architect who:

1) has a clear vision of what the product should be like
2) plans architecture & development tasks for the group
3) mentors less experienced developers
4) maintains standards on code quality and development processes

Bottom line: If you're looking for a place to hone your technical skills and grow as a developer, look elsewhere. Some of the other reviewers who mentioned a culture of complacency absolutely hit the nail on the head. I have observed first-hand many times where our group has accepted mediocre work or shortcuts without hesitation "if it gets the job done," creating more technical debt. When developers ask for time to address technical debt, we are rebuffed by managers who claim that it is "good enough" and that we should focus on pumping out more features. If you stay here too long, your skills as a software developer will only continue to rust.

Pros: Excellent company , fast paced,  industry leader, flexibility
Cons:
Still outnumbered. 30-1 . Most teams are 90% Men.  Especially Management Teams
Now that Cisco is trying to have more diverse interview panels, we are bombarded with every interview. No thank you or acknowledgement just so someone can make a metric

Pros:
Challenge environment to motivate your career development. 
Opportunity to work in a flexible environment and Remotely to facilitate to balance properly family and work.
In the last Women of Impact event, it was the first time I felt, women was sharing in a open way their responsibilities and needs to balance family and work, considering Cisco Company is impacting very positive in the way of thinking about their Human Resources.
Cons: The Environment of excellence produce high competition between Teams and Silos of knowledge.

Pros:
Cisco is far ahead of the industry in Customer Success.  Internal account managers, as well as customers, cannot believe that we are a free resource.

We are a newer team within Cisco that is growing rapidly.  We're able to help create best practices and pilot new offers.

Everyone has been great to work with and very willing to help when needed.
Cons: Since we are a newer team, there are some growing pains, but that also brings excitement and energy.

Pros:
One of the leading brands in IT field 
Pay us really good
Campus is great 
Very helpful HR team
Perks and facilities are great
Cons:
People in the team are not friendly at all

No help or guidance for freshers about the work ( maybe team specific as I have heard good opinion about their mentors and managers from my colleagues in other teams ) 

Work is not all that exciting when compared to the big brand value it has earned 

Work experience is entirely team specific and some team really lack the people and managers with required social skills

Pros:
Cisco helped me become the person I’ve always wanted to be, assisting my smooth transition of body & mind, in a safe environment, allowing for continued work productivity.
•	Cisco has been fully supportive with Global Benefits, HR, I&D and GLBT backing.
•	Provided help with transition timetable, notification and awareness training to co-workers and management, 
•	HR provided Life coach to help with Work/life balance through transition
•	Allowed me to present as myself in the office.
•	I&D support considered all aspects of work environment including restroom availability
•	Flexible working arrangements allowed for work from home through transition and beyond
Cons: None to feedback that I'm aware of

Pros: Love the benefits, love the way the company takes care of its people and the way the people take care of each other.   I feel encouraged to grow and develop and have been so lucky to have this as my first job out of college.  Cisco really focuses on its People Deal and its apparent that they live by their motto: Connect Everything, Innovate Everywhere and Benefit Everyone!
Cons: I do wish that the office was located in SF, but that's my only complaint!

Pros: Cisco is an amazing place to work.  Whether it's involving a customer, a teammate, a family member, or someone in need in the local community, people come together to make great things happen.  Without tremendous people from all walks of life, Cisco just wouldn't be Cisco.
Cons: We strive to make job rotations a reality, but often come up short.  It's unfortunate, as that kind of cross-pollination of people would be invaluable in helping people get different perspectives and experiences.

Pros:
I was part of the IT University hires for my role as an Engineer/Analyst.  This company has excellent benefits, knowledgeable coworkers, and truly sweet team members who care about your success. 

Large campus, great benefits, gym, good salaries, opportunities to work on different projects to expand your skillsets, work/life balance (depends on the team), and company lunches/dinners/outings really make this a great place to work. 

Cisco is truly a great place if you don't mind working for a large IT company in a small town (or in silicon valley). 

After leaving Cisco I've come to appreciate how truly great of a company they are and how much they care about improving the community and their employee's lives. There is something to be said about working for a multi-billion dollar company.
Cons:
The team you're on largely determines whether the work you do is exciting vs. mundane, whether you can work from home or if you have to be in the office every day for scrum.

In the end you are still working for an IT company that heavily values technical skills and abilities (design, marketing, HR, is always going to be secondary to software engineering, database, front end dev, etc.) Essentially you must have coding skills/abilities/understanding to succeed or work here.

Biggest con: the location. There are only two campuses you can work from (San Jose or RTP) and both locations are sprawling suburbs, heavily dependent on cars, and are a bit boring locale wise.

Pros: Our Engineers are some of the very best and their wealth of knowledge is first class.
Cons: The Sales teams try to  push away the important details that will fix the issue from the engineering side. Not enough pressure on our Partners to ensure they are selling the right solution, not just the most expensive one. Customers expect hand holding in solutions and sometimes do not put in the effort on their end and then blame the technology.

Pros: Work life balance. Some exciting projects but it’s rare.
Cons: Too stubborn workplace surrounded by people who don’t want changes. Those are usually have stayed at Cisco almost or over a decade. It’s difficult to live with too many obsolete products that showcase the worst case of UX and ugly design. Low RSU, Slow promo, Low or zero transparency on performance review. There’s no such formal performance review but managers still do that for their direct reports by their own fair hands.

Pros: relaxed work environment most of the time
Cons: you will be surprised how cheap cisco can be. make you buy your own equipment/tool, and say the money you spent is on your bonus check. if you fall in a team that supervised by someone who is nepotist, and bias, good luck, you may think cisco is a professional company but based on your team, it might be better to work for a slimy consulting company than cisco. i never could imagine cisco would be that cheap. they also recently laid off many people

Pros:
PROS:
-- Positive Work environment / Corporate Culture.

-- Constant Exposure to New Technology.

-- Endless opportunities to develop existing skills, learn new skills on the job, and change roles.

-- Leadership is dedicated to making the company feel like one large "team" or "family" where everyone is there to help everyone else (not always practiced of course).

-- An extremely well organized and streamlined company.

-- Company culture heavily promotes internal-innovation and is very open to hearing about (and trying out) ideas of employees if they are innovative, reasonable, doable, and the employee is willing to make them a reality.

-- Technical ability and breadth of technical knowledge are prized commodities company-wide, even among non-technical roles, and often go hand-in-hand with opportunities for personal development and advancement.

-- Positive attitudes are well rewarded and those with a consistently negative outlook often find themselves a victim of the Annual "limited restructuring" events.

-- The annual layoffs do not usually impact technical workers (and their supporting coworkers) that are focused on growing / profitable technologies and products. 
-- In contrast to media speculation and Lamentations following layoffs on web forums, these layoffs are almost entirely avoidable. With the deluge of resources to learn new technologies and skills within Cisco, workers who find themselves layed off when their area of focus is no longer relevant (profitable) almost always passed up many opportunities to reskill, move into growing tech, etc. And the writing is always on the wall well before the axe falls. 

NOTE: there ARE exceptions to this like when huge portions of staff at one of the Cisco sites is let go for heartless business reasons -- such as when jobs are moved overseas to save money (or when jobs are moved back because customers prefer to "speak to someone in "). 

-- Cisco gives you a choice of several nice notebook models to use (including the current year MacBook Pro 15") as well as quality monitors and computer peripherals for your daily use. This is a nice perk if you're a bit of a nerd, which many employees are.
Cons:
CONS:
-- The (very) regular restructuring / layoff events. There really MUST be a less heartless and less disheartening way of aligning human resources with ever-changing corporate goals and fluctuations in stock prices. The current method of mass purges every year can't really be called anything other than lazy and uninspired leadership with a near-sighted view of success. For a company that so prizes innovation this practice sticks out like a sore thumb.

-- Oftentimes employees are dramatically underpaid for their work. Sadly, since many of these workers started with the company fresh out of college as interns, after 10+ years they will often find themselves making half of what an employee at another company with identical skills and experience makes. Since Cisco does not really ever give employees more than a few percent pay increase per year, many of these seasoned workers are trapped in a low paying position with no real hope of receiving a fair wage without leaving the company, accepting a (much) higher position at another company, and reapplying at Cisco a year or so later, at which point Cisco will match (or offer a slightly higher) wage than the worker is currently being paid. Situations like this really show that at the end of the day, a giant corporation that genuinely cares about its workers well-being, is still a giant corporation.

-- The Annual layoffs

-- Even when an employee is paid something close to fair market value for a specific role, the pay is typically lower than what the vast majority of other organizations will pay, and the benefits (once amazing beyond compare!) are very middle of the road. 

-- The annual layoffs

-- Unless a candidate is truly an industry leader or posseses unique skills Cisco cannot find elsewhere, there is no real room for negotiating pay / an employment contract. If the candidate attempts to negotiate after an offer has been made and rejects the initial offer, that's the end of the ball game. The hiring manager will go on down the list of the fifty other perfectly qualified candidates and offer the job to one of them. This regular practice has cost many candidates a job when they were simply following normal, acceptable job-seeker etiquette. The unstated (but commonly understood) idea behind this behaviour is that working for a great company like Cisco is a highly valuable reward in itself, and the difference in pay is accounting for that "fact" -- I have never heard of anyone telling this to a candidate but I have heard managers on a number of occasion allude to this.

-- The annual layoffs

-- The company was founded in Californis and has always been based in California. For those who do not know, this region of the US known is known for its very strong progressive and left-leaning social and political beliefs. And while almost always a good thing, the imprint the area in which Cisco is located oftentimes makes leadership announcements, company initiatives, etc. a little bit preachy and "holier-than-thou" -- looking down on those who do not always agree with Cisco's political or social stances on certain topics.

-- The annual layoffs. I am taking to YOU, CHUCK ROBBINS, please fix this for the sake of your loyal employees, you're so much better than this.

Pros: Easy. Not very challenging.  Cisco is a place to join if you have 5 kids and you want minimal challenge.  Equal opportunity employer.  I get lovely emails from old executives who send out emails like “go team” and “let’s close the quarter strong” yet  I have no idea who these people are or what they do and I’m a manager!.  If I’m part of their team I would have loved to have met them! My sister is 54 with 3 kids and dreams of a job at Cisco so that says a lot.
Cons: Not very challenging. No real personal  growth potential...  Cisco worries more about what dividends they will give stock holders then how many shares they will give  talented employees.  I’m part of one of the large software companies that Cisco  acquired and the talent has fled like animals fleeing fire. I’ve personally stayed because of growth opportunities exist but hiring new talent under Cisco is almost impossible.  Because Cisco came from the hardware world they do not fully understand the software world.  the concept of retaining talent or talent acquisition is not really understood.  When COVID happened Cisco stopped all hiring for 4 or 5 months while every other smart company in the world gobbled up our talent.  If you look at Cisco’s leaders it’s like viewing a sad picture gallery of a high school reunion from 1950 ...  some will see this as a joke but it’s really a view into the slow death of what once was a champion.  Cisco can only find washed up 50 year olds for executives? I’m not against age but I know more people in their 30s who are better leaders then Cisco’s geriatric crowd.  I’ve been to many large marketing trade show events where large companies like google or other companies similar to cisco are there with huge flashy creative booths telling you a million ways how they will solve your problems.  Then you come to the Cisco booth and it says just “Cisco” ... as if someone in marketing thought that was enough to explain what they do ... very sad

Pros: Cisco cares for the employees
Cons: Struggling with transformation towards software and how to sell the value especially towards partner-led accounts, all accounts except the largest global enterprises.

Pros: Benefits are ok as compare to others, colleagues are great and helpful. You will learn a great experience there.
Cons:
Little work-life balance. Works are hectic. If you are not in the good book of your management, get ready to go. 

They will find fault in you even though the process might be set up before your time, you will be blamed. 

In front of you, will tell you if you need help look for them, they are here to make you successful. But at your back, say bad things about you.

Pros:
Cisco pays well, bonuses for performance, unless you really knock it out of the park, and makes an effort to manage its employees effectively.

Cisco is confronting a new and rapidly evolving business as they try to transform to a software driven business. Employees with those skills are going to find Cisco a great short term opportunity. Then the politics step in.
Cons:
Most of your managers will turn over in a year or two. It takes longer for the least competent to be replaced however.

The world is becoming software. Cisco is hugely dependent on Software, but their business models emphasize hardware. Consequently, their ability to execute to the rapid pace in the software world is challenged. This hurts your ability to fully maximize sales programs and leaves technical people in a support quagmire. 

Cisco is not a place for the long term. During my tenure my entire office of "Gray Lizards", people with decades of experience, customer relationships and technical knowledge of the quirks of older systems and how to keep them going, was riffed and we got a 42 page memo showing that in addition to those of us over 50, they had also removed several people who were 30 and thus no ageism existed in their decisions. While hard to accept, I do appreciate that times are changing for Cisco and they need to change with them.

Mid-Level "Faces" of the company change annually - indicating that priorities and investments are changing as well. Does not bode well for longer term employment stability after 2-3 years, especially if you are a project manager.

As with any company, politics is rife the higher you go. But at Cisco, the impact of politics is felt at operational levels in terms of investments, timelines rewards, and constraints. Duplicity is very common around projects that once held great promise, but now have new people with new priorities in place.

Pros:
Best for work life balance. Some teams have less than 2 or 3 hours of work a day. I myself had just about 6 hours of work a week for a good period of time after I automated a few of my tasks (not possible in TAC teams though).
Job security even during layoffs (India only)
You get a chance to learn new technologies, internal movement etc. Can grow skills during the downtime since work doesnt usually take up too much time. 
Company is very employee centric, you will get time off, benefits and support. Eg. Company went above and beyond during Covid crisis giving all employees in India 50k as a one time bonus irrespective of grade. They also helped with medical care and expenses in many cases. The Cisco India community is very kind and supportive (helped arrange beds and oxygen etc).
Feels amazing to be working at a place where you can learn a lot. The resources we have at our disposal to skill up is amazing - especially for those in networking domain. Just dont stay in boring roles like BCS and move to better teams.
Cons:
Use the free time wisely. A lot of people get stagnant and lose skills due to ample free time and not skilling up. Cisco does not have good growth in terms of pay. If you get stuck with boring work, change teams.
The pay disparity is huge. Over 50% pay difference in many cases between people in same roles with same skills. Pay seems to be more about experience than skills - something that resembles a government company (could be a good thing for many since there is job security). 
The TAC teams are especially bleeding talent due to terrible pay that has not kept up with industry. Freshers make more money than skilled, experienced folks who tend to leave to competitors. This has resulted in terrible support experience for customers. Most TAC cases globally are handled by folks with less product experience from Bangalore since the senior folks leave for better pay. 
Some teams are better placed in terms of decision making, benefits, product trainings etc than others. This disparity is often seen in different ways eg. Bangalore folks end up doing back office work and dont lead engagements or interact directly with customer.
Consulting roles which are NOT TAC are amazing for experienced folks looking for relaxation and retirement only and really atrophy the skills of freshers who want to grow and learn.
Do not stay if you want a pay bump. Internal growth is measly and the metrics used to evaluate performance are often gamed. Best to skill up and jump ship.

Pros: Great benefits, the people that work here are friendly and helpful, if you do your job right you can be rewarded with some healthy commission checks regularly
Cons: Sometimes your success depends on the territory that you're given and the team that you work with in each territory. Not all territories are created equal and not all teams are as good as others. A huge pain that the security sales team is currently experiencing is a complete lack of visibility and trust in the way that our commissions are paid out. I am hoping they fix that sooner than later.

Pros: Pays reasonably well...if you are not that bright, you can survive for ever in Cisco, place is full of dead weight so you'll fit right in.
Cons: Work is not interesting, people can be downright hostile, raises/rewards have no relation to the work you put in.

Pros: Good benefits, flexible hours, the facilities, compensation, two gyms on site, good employee discounts, smart people, everyone is issued a lap top (makes working much easier) brand recognition. If you can get into a good group that is not filled with territorial people that have been here for too long you will do just fine.
Cons: It's really a sales organization and not product oriented, review and bonus measurement metrics overly complicated and convoluted, management is too busy to help mentor your career path.

Pros: Very large, stable company with a lot of opportunity to move between divisions.  It is well known and has a good reputation in the industry.
Cons: Very ridged process that can be oppressive.  No work-life balance.  They are struggling to expand their business outside of the network and some of the new strategies are successful and some are definitly not.

Pros:
Flex policies regarding working hours. Good Gym and great colleagues. General exposure to technologies, and somewhat decent processes.
Opportunities to move around.
Cons: Unreasonable schedules and no work-life balance. The company mission statement  "To change the way the world works, lives, plays and learns" sounds orwellian. Almost meaningless pulse surveys.  Good at scapegoating engineers at the same time taking credit for success. No vision from senior management (director and above) in many BUs.

Pros: If you are curious and self-motivated, this is a great place to work. Learning is limited only by what you choose to do or not do.
Cons: 24-hour global schedule can be tiring at times. The work never stops. Hard to find the elusive "work-life balance" that is spoken of so often.

Pros: Stable company, job would be stable if you are a decent skilled employee. Good benefits and good paid time off.
Cons: Not much innovation going on, better to negotiate when you enter, don't expect much after you settle in there, promotions and recognition are hard to come by.

Pros: Awesome access to so many technologies. Opportunities to do whatever you want. if you don't like what you are doing, you have a world of choices at Cisco to make a career change.
Cons: Internal systems are fragile and often break. Goal setting is rarely ever realistic. Management is very top heavy. True training has been replaced with all web based content.

Pros: Good benefits - lots of meaningful work, very high quality engineers.
Cons: Becoming too large and high overhead - brings some of the usual slowness and some bonehead policies.   Rating system is really negative with forced placement of people into "bottom 5%" for example (the old discredited GE system).

Pros:
* Good work life balance. I thinks it's best place for woman.
* Smart employees and has decent learning experience.
* Good training sponsored by company
* Easy to move withing company
* Looks good on resume
* Good job security (yes, even after recent heavy layoffs, it's one of the safest company)
* Still best network company in world.
Cons:
*  Very hard to move vertical.
* Little bit slow moving company due to its size.
* Avg compensation.
* Has no gym or any ping pong table in any bldg.

Pros: Great people, collaborative culture, learned a lot, treats people with respect, highest integrity, global organization, video confernencing for remote teams, great bonus and plenty of Vacation time
Cons: Company lacks focus, message from leadership is fine but didn't traslated into company performance. Performance review process is ruthless. Very much a demotivator for people.

Pros: Cisco is an excellent employer that takes excellent care of it's employees and fosters a good work/life balance.  Cisco's support during a period of severe injury showed me that there are good companies that really do care about people.
Cons: Politics often get in the way of logical decision making.  Cisco's ventures into non-core businesses have been failures, yet the company has yet to address what their core is!

Pros: Large Corporation with good benefits.
Cons: Internal motivation is strongly lacking.  Majority of Directors and above are not real leaders, they are just looking to get their numbers boosted to make their quotas & collect commissions, even if customers are unhappy.  Too many processes which do not allow salespeople to do their job's effectively.

Pros: Great place to work. Employees are treated well if they actually perform.
Cons: It's a big company and can be hard to stand out.  Lots and lots of process.  Being overworked is common.  Cost cutting measures can appear ridiculous at times, especially considering how much money Cisco has in the bank.

Pros: Good culture and decent reputation for the company. Work and learning entirely depends on the individual. If you choose to grow you can.
Cons: Testing profiles are bit boring. You really dont need alot of learning. Recognition opportunities are less. Really cant do much out of the way. Cisco as a company will try to normalize everyone irrespective of their performance. So long term career may not have much advantage for people who aspire to grow really fast.

Pros: Telecommuting/working from home; some great people are still left. It's a good place to learn the technology if you're just getting into the industry, and you play your cards right.
Cons: Politics rules rather than technical innovation. In some specific cases, management covers up what should be firing offenses against "favorite sons" among the management team. Most managers are focused on building their empire, rather than building the company. Senior management doesn't understand the product they are actually building and selling, and doesn't know, within the company, who actually does.

Pros: Well paying company that pushes employees to work from home. Flexible work atmosphere. Cisco grades by quality of work done, rather than hours spent at a desk.
Cons: Rising in Cisco is challenging. Everyone is extremely talented, bright and motivated. Rising from an entry level position to a high level is somewhat rare it seems like.

Pros:
Great company, great technology, great people.

Huge opportunity to get exposure to some of the most innovative and fast paced technology in the industry.
Cons:
Not the startup or growth technology company that it once was.
Culture has changed over the years.
Career and pay advancement is tough.  As is with most large companies, there is too much red tape and not enough common sense.

Pros: Very flexible.  Some very smart people.  Lots too learn if you're motivated.
Cons: Too many re-orgs.  Every 12 months different vision/strategy.  Focus on moving workforce to less-expensive locations is taking it's toll.  Yes, you can save 30% by moving your employees from location A to location B.  But if it reduces your quality by 50% does it make sense?  Increased price pressure from low-cost competitors like Huawei is going to result in a hit to the high quality of Cisco products.

Pros: It is great to work for a respected market leader with a big market share.  They have mature and solid processes in place that regulates every aspect of their business
Cons: Often it feels likes working for the government.  There are some many different groups and teams with each of them their own goals and agenda's.  It makes it hard to move fast and getting buyin from all stakeholders becomes a full time job

Pros:
* Highly technical development work
* The opportunity to be recognized for your work through bonus and awards
* The company focuses on a lot of areas, so I had opportunities to work on many projects
* Great training available
Cons:
* Salary on the lower end and doesn't move much
* Managers are entirely hit or miss in their management abilities
* Things can move slowly if you don't have a motivated team
* Too many processes and layers

Pros: Cisco provides each employee with ample resources to perform her/his job onsite or remotely. They care about work-life balance.
Cons: Perks declined over the past few years and no longer compete with LinkedIn, Goggle, and others in the area. Promotions and significant pay increases are rare. They don't recognize the people who perform behind the scenes, primarily those who are loud and showy.

Pros:
- Work/life balance.
- Compensation and benefits.
- Work environment.
- Work force made up of smart, friendly people.
- Interesting industry.
- Sales is a strength of the company.
Cons:
- Innovation is a weakness of the company.
- Obstacles to growth into new positions and/or groups.
- Stack ranking of employees.
- Large scale workforce reductions (mass layoffs) are too frequent.

Pros:
Flexible working hours
Good place to check-out and retire
Decent benefits but getting worse
Decent compensation for top-performers
Cons:
Rampant nepotism 
A lot of talk, no walk
Little or no accountability 
Extremely top-heavy management structure
MO: If unable to innovate, steal someone else's idea and take their credit

Pros:
Smart, Motivated People
Decent Salary, at least in sales
Work, life balance is good and better than most companies
Company values are strong and they enjoy giving back
Cons:
The work ethic and level of engagement has fallen off in some areas
People are less motivated, possibly because of stock, and many don't go extra mile
The speed of change and red tape is cumbersome and frustrating
The ability to influence and change process is hard, long and challenging, if it happens at all

Pros: Supportive infrastructure and services to employees. Good salary package. Strong leadership. Market leader. Sense of pride.
Cons: Some bad apples. Lots of senior execs on cruise control. Very difficult to build a strong team when you cannot back-fill. So, you keep your low performing folks because they're better than nothing and to fill your span of control goal. This really needs to change.

Pros:
Have completed a lot of interesting projects, and where more are on the road map.
Excellent training is readily available.
The people are friendly and smart!
Organizations are nimble.
Opportunities are available to change groups.
Cons:
Priorities change frequently causing many projects to be either shelved or derailed.
An increasing dependency on offshore contractors as local workforce is shrinking due to attrition.
Working on projects across time zones is becoming increasingly difficult.
Changes are not communicated well, or sometimes not-at-all.
Difficult to promote.

Pros: Employees are empowered to do make decisions best for the company. Great place to learn various skills. Have freedom to move around to work different products and functions.
Cons: Given the size of the company growth is limited. No start-up culture anymore. Has turned into true big company. No talent recognition. Mediocre people are rising up the ladder and good talent are leaving for other smaller companies and startups.

Pros: Benefits in kind are good enough and are important to be considered, work-life balance is also key as you can always work remotely from your home. Job performance is evaluated based on competencies and never taking into consideration the number of hours you spend in front of your laptop.
Cons: Company culture is focused on stock so since the last four year there is an important lay off each year in which aprox 8 to 10% of the workforce is impacted.

Pros: Flexibility in work hours and location, with the clear expectation that work must be done on-time, and with quality results.
Cons: Very complex company, and will take a new employee a long time to ramp up and understand the company as a whole...Years to understand it holistically.  This is because there is not a traditional hierarchical org structure - rather think of it like many moving parts with virtual teams organized quickly and constant restructures.

Pros:
- Flexible hours
- Great team attitude
- Lots of great benefits (stock options, 401k, health insurance, etc)
- Team outings per quarter for team bonding
Cons:
Cisco's culture is vastly different from team to team. I have some coworkers in other teams that don't have nearly as many team events as we do. But for the most part, in comparison with other industries, they have you covered.

If you want to talk about first world problems, Cisco doesn't have free lunch and other random free stuff, but those companies do that so you end up living there.

Pros: Competitive pay and benefits. Getting to work on products that build the worlds network infrastructure.  There are tons of training classes that you can take at no cost.
Cons: Cisco has become so large that it can't effectively innovate anymore.  It seems like all the new and best tech coming from Cisco is a product of recent acquisitions.

Pros: Stayed at the company because telecommuting is a great perk. But at some point, you wonder if that is enough to offset the kind of poor management and unhealthy team dynamic. Note this is dependent on the team you're on. Company culture as a whole is not bad.
Cons: Lots of strong individual contributors get promoted but I've seen too many of those promoted to people managers who make terrible bosses. The worst part is they were able to get promoted because of political savvy so even the type of bullying, micromanagement, and all sorts of management nightmares go undetected by most with their subtle harassment.

Pros: the place sucks, nothing but empty words and they work you without any consideration. If  you have a good boss it can be ok but if you have a crappy boss...good luck
Cons: if they are worried about meeting their wall st numbers be prepared to be furloughed without much notice. During the X-mas break be prepared to be furloughed for a longer period than the full time employees. They talk about how integral contractors are to the success of the company but it is simply empty words. They don't put their money where their mouth is. I would love to see how this place would collapse if all the contractors went out on strike for an extended period.

Pros: Great benefits, good work. The company is a market leader in its line of business. The networking industry is under pressure due to SDN and white box. Cisco is trying to keep up with the new technologies. So there is a lot of good work and learning opportunities.
Cons: Due to the race to build new technologies there is a lot of work that needs to be done in short time. Consequently work life balance is impacted.

Pros: Access to great minds. If you network, you have a lot of access to people that can help and help you advance positions. You can get a position that requires travel to stay in your preferred area. Training is always available for free for Cisco products, but I always had training for other company products as a choice.
Cons: It's harder to advance if you are in the technical side and not in a major city where Cisco has a presence.  Big company politics (just like any other). Lots of organizational changes. Sales organization is favored over other divisions.

Pros: Ability to work on some of the most cutting edge technology out there;  great scale;  thrilling.  Massive stage to play on.
Cons: Bureaucratic;  can be stuck in the past;  hard to get stuff done.  Anyone can say no but no one can say yes.

Pros: Cisco is a giant and a brand people trust.  For good reason they make some of the best network related products on the market.  Customers pick up the phone when they hear your from Cisco.
Cons: Cisco has lost its way in terms of their sales efforts.  They have become so effective at marketing to themselves they've lost perspective on the world around them.  They're so focused on selling for the now they frustrate customers of the long term relationship.

Pros:
Flexibility, great benefits
Always connected via technology
Cons:
political if someone decides they don't want you in the department, they will find a way to move you out or move you out of the company. 

Just as being connected can be a flexibility people are always working a lot of hours because of the east of being connected. 

Hoops to promote as an administrative assistant to an EA. A lot of it is who you know and who will vouch for you vs actual proven performance

No increase in pay for years

Pros: You are surrounded by very high IQ and EQ people who are amongst the best in the business. Everyone seems to be on the same program, be it the sales process, or the engagement with channel partners. For a big organisation it is very flat and management is accessible, though busy. Salary is great; accelerators, benefits etc, also first class.
Cons: It is 24/7. If you don't like working evenings, Cisco probably isn't for you. Also, with regular re-structures, you never feel like you have a job for life.

Pros: Great people who are smart, knowledgeable and very collaborative.  The company lives its vision to change the world and they are developing some fantastic products that will positively impact people and the world.  They treat their employees very well, with respect and always want to do the right thing. Great benefits and rewards.
Cons: Not as transparent as they think they are.  Not really open to change. Marketing is not cutting edge and hard to make an impact.  Strategies change daily.

Pros: No need to sell as you simply need to rely on the partner community to do all the work. Cisco management simply sits around all day and scrutinizes salesforce.com.  Meetings everyday over your forecast so they can push the number up to the top.  Sell without regard to the partner or customer.
Cons: Nothing matters but your forecast which will be analyzed hourly.  But even if you hit your hourly, weekly, monthly and quarterly number chances are that another 5,000 to 6,000 empolyees will be terminated without regard on August 1st.

Pros: Company offers above average benefit with great people working together, engineering team is frugal and strikes to deliver innovative solution is a fast pace environment with Agile transformation in mind.
Cons: Lately I see increasing pressure to deliver more with less people with yearly restructuring .  Managing performance becomes the norm with fear of being managing out.

Pros: Good salary, excellent benefits, bonus. Work from home friendly but that is going away. Most people friendly but such a big org mileage may very.
Cons: Constant threat of layoffs, managers usually remote unengaged with staff, pretty cold about layoffs. Lots of offshore work taking USA jobs. Difficult to understand or communicate with co-workers because they do not know English very well. Required to work all nighters or face layoff. A very politically correct company.

Pros:
Home Working
Good remuneration 
Global teams
Constant change
On route to a better place
Powerful heritage
You will never get fired
A culture of get it done we don't care how or when (not 9 - 5 office based)
Cons:
Change not focussed
Too political at higher levels 
No clear direction
In transition to new model but in painful stage currently
Will get worst before it gets better (night is darkest before the dawn)
You will be made redundant 
You will never see your team
Absent managers
Expectation to always be online at all hours

Pros: Very good work life balance. Good for Network skill sets.
Cons: Too many restructurings, affects visas, job stability. Don't be surprised to get stabbed even if you are a good worker.

Pros: Good compensation, nice ergonomic working atmosphere, ample number of benefits, however, least time to try them out in the vicinity. If you're in the right team, you get to work on good challenging technology, good showcasing work, visibility, etc. Work from home,  casual working/dressing environment, etc.
Cons: Bad work-life balance, micromanagement, work from home after a while becomes like you get it only if you're favoured by manager, team policies sometimes really become bad, favouritism is  pretty much evident, etc.

Pros: its a workplace that does not differentiate capabilities between men and women,  yet provides the flexibility that women need in times when they have to care for progeny
Cons: there are pockets which still need to work on work-life balance, as well as recognition of smart work ( apart from hard work)

Pros: Managers are understanding, the work can be demanding, people are naturally creative.
Cons: The work can take up SO. MUCH. TIME. because there's many people involved, sometimes there can be egos / too much reliance on tin cupping budgets, and there are definitely differently layers of opacity that lead to people acting like horses with blinders on.

Pros: Honestly, one of the most authentic companies I have worked for. Really, has a vision of growing and really understanding the needs of the customer. The motto around here is do good and see good. I recently attended our annual conference in Vegas, and the networking and understanding of the Company was tremendous. You can literally walk up to the CEO of a 70,000 employee company and he will greet you with a smile and be happy that you came up to him. Great atmosphere!
Cons: None that I can see

Pros: Cisco has a really established name in the industry. So the place of work is great with a nice airy office. The people I worked with were really good and I cherish my time at Cisco because of the great friendships I have formed over time. The benefits are good.
Cons: There is a lot of hierarchy and corporate bureaucracy.  Things don't move fast because the approval processes can be long and lengthy.  Salaries are not competitive at all.

Pros: Amazingly smart and dedicated people work at Cisco.  Many work very hard and demonstrate excellence and passion.  You can learn a LOT if you take initiative and get involved.  Lots of career growth opportunities possible.
Cons: Technology shifts in industry, moves to Saas and open source are tricky waterrs to navigate.  Cisco has some huge advantages but getting alignment across the entire company can be difficult for any company of our size.

Pros:
With the right team and boss this can be a rewarding place to work.
Decent work/life balance.
Cons:
Lay off central at Cisco these past few years -- and it's ain't over.  In fact, it's the new normal.
They're bringing in the young and kicking out the old...  45 years-old or more and a grade 12 or above and you're a target!
100% financially driven.  Not customer-centric at all.
Highly political.

Pros: Global, flexibility of work location, and seems profitable. Very receptive to younger generation employees and tries to make fun, and not just work!
Cons: Lack of diversity, especially in leadership or managers.  Lots of employees from Inida who do not understand US culture. Can make meetings and IT support very difficult and getting work done unproductive.  Understanding how things work as a new employee is not very good; confusing.

Pros:
1. Good work life balance
2. Decent pay
3. Good domain
4. Free safari account/Internet bill reimbursement
Cons:
1. One will feel stagnant and stuck in the role, even after years.  
2. Bit of favouritism for the people manager/director likes and not for the people who work hard
3. No promotion
4. You might get exploited for low-performers in the team

Chennai site is not Cisco, the managers have the attitude of Scientific Atlanta.

Pros: Pay, Benefits are good.  Cisco has its hands in a lot of different technologies which make it good for being able to move around to a technology that is best for you.
Cons: Cisco  no longer innovates, but waits to buy up its competition.  Poor Product  reliability.  Pretty sure there is no QA, unless you count the customer as being your test monkey.

Pros: Changes to the company strategy is paying off with increased sales and market share which means the company is doing better financially.  The company has a good culture which is friendly, informal and committed to Diversity and Inclusion of its workforce.
Cons: Promotions are very difficult to get.  Managers change positions frequently which means it takes 2 or 3 years to prove your value to a new manager in order for them to recommend salary increases or promotions.  About the time you can prove your value, the manager changes again and you start over again.

Pros: Wide range of technologies to learn and work with.
Cons: Little to no opportunities for advancement.  No regular pay raises or compensation given for top performers.  Bloated management structure with not enough workers to continue to pyramid scheme that gets the executives paid absorbant salaries.   Yearly layoffs ensure you team members are always leaving or looking for work.  Below industry average employee benfits.

Pros: Corporate commitment to work-life balance, well compensated, company name instantly enables you to get a meeting
Cons: Product portfolio seems to be a step behind smaller more agile companies.  Migration to cloud is taking longer than anticipated.

Pros: Good market focus. Build only what sells today or at max in 1 year .
Cons: Little to no risk-taking or innovation appetite for building Next-gen cutting edge technology  something that you would expect from a market leader.

Pros: This role allows one to run their own book of business. Though the technology is complex in nature, but there are many learning resources. My team is super helpful. There is a lot of positive attrition at Cisco, so there is a culture of helping the people succeed, no matter what level you are currently in. It is honestly my dream job. The salary is above average for the industry. Theoretically one could work anywhere, though being in the office is encouraged.
Cons: If you want to be successful, you will find yourself working some on the weekends and evenings.

Pros:
Lots of travel opportunities. You could use all your passport pages.
Projects are sometimes good, sometimes not so much.
Good brand value. People look upto you when you introduce yourself to any client.
Cons:
Working remotely, specially when your manager is in a different city is a  major downside. The people who work closely in the same office often get better projects which have more visibility.
Salary is below average. Only few people get good salary if they have good ties with the manager. Rest have a below average hike.

Pros: Work-Life Balance! Benefits! Internal Growth opportunities.
Cons: Political Env. Top heavy management structure. Decision making is slow.

Pros:
Great culture although it depends on the location you're working from.

Always had the opportunity to work on the latest technologies in several fields of networking

Cisco always encourages expanding your technical knowledge, I rarely got a training request rejected. Even if the content was not directly related to my field of work
Cons:
Political environment, moving up the ladder doesn't always depends on your performance.
Vague KPIs for network engineers
Limited visibility if you are not based in a central hub location

Pros: The best company you could work for, as they truly care about their employees. During the pandemic, they were truly supportive and understanding of employee's well-being. Cisco is always at the fore-front of innovation, and truly understand what it means to have a healthy and excellent company culture!
Cons:
Forecasting can be stressful, but thats everywhere!
Might encounter some politics in some regions/teams.
It's very tough to become a manager quickly as a junior, as employees are much more senior and have an extensive expeirence.

Pros: Excellent work life balance culture. Lots of opportunity to move up and move to other teams. Base pay is a little low but the benefits are great. They also value mental health a great deal and give us plenty of "me" days to recharge/rest.
Cons: Sometimes it can lack consistency as far as workload, a lot of down time or very busy times but that just might be the nature of the job. No RSUs.

Pros:
Great work life balance. But pandemic made wlb worse.
Good supportive management in ucs BU.
Decent pay.
Very good culture.
Cons:
Market correction of salaries does not happen. Very bad increments or hikes with work done.
Bangalore teams always need to fight and showcase for getting right work.
Internal job switch is not easy or looked upon.

Pros: 1. Excellent infrastructure and facilities including transport 2. Good health insurance policy including parents and dental insurance 3. Brand name
Cons: 1. As a software developer most of the work is about fixing defects in badly written, poorly documented legacy code and unit testing them on overcomplicated test setups.. Don't get swayed by fancy job descriptions. 2. Managers have limited themselves only to asking status and rarely talk with the team members to understand their problems. 3. Regular layoffs has created a culture of withholding knowledge and there isn't much camaraderie in the team. 4. Annual increments are minimal and even zero.

Pros: They pay well, every two weeks. The medical, dental, and vision package is better than average. The cafeterias are very nice, and they have an excellent gym in building 6. Overall, the benefits package is great. Top management seemed mostly honest, and middle management is less venal than other companies I have worked at. Cisco is very driven by their "VSE" documents (Vision, Strategy, Execution) and takes them very seriously - I found it refreshing to find a company that actually does take Vision and Strategy seriously. They actually measure things, and sometimes make decisions based on those measurements - an idea from an underling with good data can overturn the intent of a VP with an opinion, sometimes.
Cons: They will try to work you to death. Some parts of the company are a lot sharper than others - I was part of a group that was closely aligned to another group, and I was always amazed at how much more organized the other group seemed; we just couldn't seem to make decisions and stick to them. Middle managers (directors) seem so busy with all kinds of activities that they don't seem to have any time to manage. All managers are expected to have "individual contributor" duties, which diminish their effectiveness as managers. Cisco loves routine, procedure, and process; it is very difficult to do anything new there.

Pros: Cisco does a lot of good for the community.  They take pride in giving back and are taking large steps to becoming more green.  John Chambers is a solid guy and does a lot for the employees and the community.  Cisco provides excellent benefits and compensation is competitive.  The company is so large that there are limitless opportunities if you are positioned well to take advantage of them.  Being global offers limitless opportunity for travel and international exposure. Cisco is also a very flexible company to work for.  They have onsite day care and allow most people to work remote.
Cons: Cisco is extremely political.  As with any large company it depends on the group but I have seen very dark/bad behavior from executives at the SVP level on down.  The lengths people will go to at Cisco to remain in power are drastic and ugly.  There is definately a good old boys network and mostly the unsavory survive.  I left because I could not trust senior management.  There are not many leaders there that truly care about there people.  Most are very savvy at managing up and leave a lot to be desired about managing down.  I would not reccomend Cisco, despite all of their good qualities because I felt like it was a cultural cess pool.

Pros: Cisco is a great place to balance work and everyday life or your side interests. Working from home is accepted, you can take a long lunch break and disappear for a few hours, nobody will notice. There is plenty of vacation and salary is decent compared to the work you are required to do. It's a big name in the networking business and if you are smart enough you can learn a lot. There are plenty of opportunities to learn with online and real classes.
Cons:
The level and quality of engineering is overall pretty low, lower than many other companies: many people still use the same tools as they used  30 years ago. Other are jealous of what they know and try not to share it with anybody (job security?!?). Process is very very long and frustrating: with 60k employees, it sometimes takes a week to do a 1 hour job. It all explain why many products are coming from acquisitions and are not developed internally. 
There is no diversity at all in engineering: I would guess 90% is from India (maybe more).
Also, from the level of director going up, many are "retired": they are just interested in getting their bonus and consider sending random emails at random hours (with their blackberry and similar) a valid proof that they are working around the clock.

There are not many chances to improve your career once you get on board in term of salary or promotion: i.e., negotiate well before signing or you might just get stuck with something that you really do not like. Also, watch out on where you end up going: you might be forced to just do fire fighting and bug fixing and no development (almost at all): that's not good in your resume and it's not good for your mind.

Pros:
Work life balance, good benefits
On paper, provides a wide range of career opportunities (across different functions and markets). I haven't been around for that long to know how well this works in practice.
Cons:
Typical cons associated with a large company. 
Difficult to get recognized. Will need to work with the system and it will take a few years to find your groove.
Quite slow to react to opportunities.

Pros: Smart & fun people most of the time. I working in marketing and really enjoyed the CMO organization which I think is now called "business marketing." and the US channels organization.
Cons: I would stay away from any type of internal communications marketing role. Internal communications at Cisco leave alot to be desired. It is a organization with no home, really. Poorly thought out organization, very difficult to work in & get cooperations from other groups. Mainly because they do not want the interaction, it is just another layer of red tape.

Pros: I only worked there for a summer internship but it was a great experience!  Great pay rate for a software engineering intern, free drinks, basketball courts with plenty people to play with, great work play balance, very laid back.
Cons: I didn't feel like I accomplished as much work there because of how laid back it was.  My manager was very distant and the only time we met was when I arranged a meeting.

Pros: Depending on your role- you can pick and choose when you come into the office.  Depending on the manager you are not micro-managed.
Cons:
* Endless conference calls that are a waste of time
* Now employees have to pay for their own internet connection and mobile phone at home
* No pay rises since 2000 (unless you hand in your notice then expect an incredible £5k counter offer)
* Few stock options
* Lower bonuses
* Lack of personal development- poor training opportunities
* rediculous workload (despite people saying you should balance your work: life)
* Crazy performance review process (coast the year or work yourself into the ground you will end up with the same ranking!)
* Lacks a competitive package when compared to the rest of the industry (but management will try to tell you otherwise)
* Despite employee surveys (Pulse) showing management what needs to be done- nothing will be done

Pros: Relaxed environment, people are great and it is enjoyable. Cisco make great use of the technology they have (WebEx, telepresence etc) which makes working with global colleagues a breeze.
Cons: Big company to work for and you feel like just another statistic, just someone on the payroll. Training is encouraged, but only if it directly helps your department, not so much about you its about making the department money.

Pros:
Great opportunites to learn and wide access to information.
Use of technology in the company 
Ability and flexibility to use the products/technology
Some very technical and smart individuals
Cons:
Losing focus and flexibility
Culture of constant work/response expecation and escalation 
Too many layers of process and infrastructure
Tools/infrastructure harder to use
Poor work/life balance
Outsourcing jobs and outsourcing talent/core competencies
Ineffeciences due to virtualization/time-zone and discussion/solutions through email/process (and the need for more processes and metrics)

Pros:
home office is a great idea
great usage of technology: IP Phones, VPN, Webex, Telepresence
relaxed environment
bright people
pride of working for a big company
Cons:
mobility is limited
feel like my career is stalled
those who are vocal get the promotion
hate time cards
you can be lost in the company especially if you are working remotely

Pros: Strong networking technology to support the complany wide communication any where any time.  This company has a great open door evnironment and employee can go to any cisco building and get the access to the basice area freely.  Great education opportunity, many internal courses that employee can sign up.  Overall administration supports are pretty good.  Some locations, the departments had the freedom to design the office layout and worked very nice.  Work from home or remote are supported by some managements, not all, and the company has great technology to make that fairly easy to do.  Used to be, cisco provided all kinds of drinks to employee.  But that had been removed in recent years to save the cost.
Cons: Cisco moves a lot jobs from US to off-shore, ie. India and China.  It is very common that on one day, the company cut hundreds of jobs from US, and the next day it opens hundreds of job in Inida.  The upper management only believe the short term profit and does not value the employee's experiences and quality.  They only look the numbers and thinking more number of engineers is sufficient to cover the lost of experienced people.  The quality of the products get worse and worse.  Many people got frustrated and decided to leave the co.  The first line management has poor skills to manage engineers.  Many promotions are just the result of networking.  Cisco also hiring a lot contractors from India with working visa for US positions.  That was the results of influences from contract houses running by India owners.  I didn't know how much under the table deals they had with Cisco management.  But, I knew some contractors had very bad performance and got kicked out from one department, and return to the other department in the following week.

Pros:
- Decent starting pay
- Good bonuses with 401k matching
- Excellent Benefits - good health insurance, and we still have an onsite gym
- Ability to work from anywhere
- ESPP is a good deal
- Decent direct managers if you have one in the US
- Payment for oncall time worked
- For the most part, no micromanagement - you can do your job how you see fit, as long as you stay within the processes set by other departments.
Cons:
- Company is losing full time employees rather quickly. The good employees are leaving to take better offers, and the bad ones are sticking around. Most people I know who left were offered 20% more to work elsewhere.
