- Lost positions are typically not being backfilled. My manager is in India while I am in the US because my former US manager took a better offer. I have no visibility with my current manager because of this, which will greatly stunt my career growth. There are no plans to have a US manager.
- Most positions that are actually being backfilled are contractor positions. Contractors don't care about the company and it shows in their work. By the time they're ramped up and useful, they leave for a better offer. 
- Poor work-life balance. Even though they try to promote it, the ridiculous processes that require tons of weekend work prevent it in practice. This company is run on silly processes and meetings run by PMs who like to feel important. 
- Company is taking our cubicles away and putting us into bullpens (CCW). No personal workspace, it's very noisy and just a very terrible working environment. We had no choice in the matter, it was forced upon us. Management tried to make it seem positive by saying that everyone loves it. Nobody likes it except for the implementers. 
- Recognition is very poor outside of what your manager recognizes you for in front of your team. Your director and above probably has no idea who you are, nor do they seem to care. Promotions  in the form of raises are very rare, so after you've worked here for a few years, you're making less than when you started due to inflation. Most people move laterally instead. 
- Budget cuts are bordering ridiculous. No training budget makes personal and technical development nearly impossible. No travel makes it so you spend hours working with people you've never met and can't attend conferences. 
- Cisco is not innovating. They acquire garbage that other companies have already beat us to. The number of business processes stifles product development, so that we're almost the last ones to release a product. Customers have found us difficult to work with as a result of these processes.

Pros: Great pay with awesome benefits. Tons of highly motivated and highly qualified technical teams. Get to design the most expensive, most complicated systems imaginable and actually see them deployed.
Cons: Management is hostile towards technology. The less technical you are the higher you can rise in the ranks. Engineers and technical individual contributors are second class citizens whose recommendations are largely ignored, then are cut when management's revisions fall flat. Zero accountability of any kind for decision makers.

Pros: Work environment is very good. Flexible work practice is also a plus
Cons:
These comments are about current CRBU(core routing) which is headed by managers who were previously in optical BU
Very heavy workload- will be forced to work on weekends(wil have to work from office) without any travel arrangements provided by company
Untolerable politics- there will not be any recognition based on performance. They will make us work like donkeys and in the end will give a feedback that work is not satisfactory.
They will offer high CTCs when you join; but it will be a constant for 3-4 years and the work keeps on increasing day by day
Most of the managers are technical guys who dont know how to manage people

Pros: Lots of smart people solving hard problems. Good leadership in place, though John Chambers should probably look to retire soon
Cons: The company is getting bigger and slower. Fewer young and up-and-coming aggressive types in the company these days. The company is facing increasing threats of commoditization by Chinese competitors and architectures like SDN.

Pros:
- Benefits Package
- Brand awareness is a door opener
- With only a few exceptions, very solid product line
- Great people, sales reps and upper management
Cons:
- Low base pay, not in line with industry standards.
- Too many levels of management, product specialists and useless positions... people are working constantly to justify their positions.  
- No employee loyalty... the only concern is the bottom line.  Direct management will stalk you for hour to hour business updates offering to do anything they can do to help, ultimately doing nothing but adding unnecessary stress and day to day headache with endless spreadsheets and busy work, greatly limiting time to sell.
- Amazing number of managers with no direct reports dreaming up activities to justify their own existence.
- Internal processes are painful to navigate.
- Forecasting is a complete farce... reps are highly encouraged to commit business that does not exist in order to forecast to team quota and when you don't meet those numbers the same managers will set you up internally as delivering consistently bad forecasting and use it as ammunition against you.
- Accounts and quotas assigned by favoritism and if you're new, prepare for a well picked over list.  
- Highly political environment... unless you're in with the political clicks and completely inhaling their Kool-Aid, you should always be concerned for your job status.    
- Lots of great people, sales reps and upper management but...
- Middle management (RM) regional sales management need to be reigned in, sweat shop mentality and the ability to make your life hell to the point of complete harassment and use of bullying tactics.  Ego trips way beyond anything I've ever seen.  Obviously not true for all RM's but...
- Significant pressure to work with only specific partners (regardless of talent), makes you wonder what's in it for your manager pushing those partners.  
- Upper management is generally very good but they're turning a blind eye to what's really going on below them and losing talented people.

Pros: Remote working capability allows for a flexible work life balance. The sales force is very driven and willing to help especially with deals. The company does push for a collaborative environment. Great company to have on your resume to move within the Technical industry. Also they have a employee stock program. Certifications are available to all employees and they hold weight in the industry. Overall it is a decent place to work given the
Cons: Salesforce team gets burnt out fast and the company has cut back things like simple sales force gatherings. If you do not negotiate your pay and title once you get into the company that will be you pay ranking for a while 3 to 5 years. Middle management really has no purpose and they delegate a lot of meaningless items to their reports. if you think you will retired from cisco that will not happen you most likely there will be a layoff and you will be effected. Cisco is ranked 90 out of 100 best companies to work for and us to be ranked 17th. They are a good company but the culture has changed to the point were if you lucky to get in make sure you take advantage and do alot of stuff to build your resume and move on. Also the company is not diverse and doesn't demonstrate diversity. Our executive do mention this a lot but middle mgmt doesn't not recruite diversity. Instead they higher and promote people they know, family members, and those that look like them. The company is filled with alot of old republican males. And the young people at time clash because of the value systems.

Pros: Excellent culture of freedom and empowerment, great people, great work. One man being at the helm has obviously helped largely retain focus on the company's goals. As an employer, Cisco provides so many opportunities to learn and challenge oneself! Truly satisfying if you are looking for stability and growth too .
Cons: Not the best paymaster. Cisco has grown in size and a result slowed down over the years and there's more "governance" now than before, some of it which seems like red tape

Pros: Good compensation package.  Financially stable.  Wide range of products and many internal opportunities.  Engineering has talented people and can still generate a new product or enhance existing product quickly.  Money not a problem (available) when needed to fix customer issues or accelerate engineering to achieve a market window.
Cons: Benefits have been trimmed continuously (for years) on a regular basis.  Bureaucracy increasing.  Too much infrastructure has been outsourced (i.e. benefits, payroll, HR). Visibility (top down and bottom up) into the "business" (specifically from Engineering) decreasing.  Business Units have too much control to design/market product or acquire companies with "non core-value".  Specifically, consumer products with no profit margin (linksys, video cameras).  Commodity (i.e. data storage, tablets) with huge established players (NetApp, EMC, Apple - more).

Pros:
- SUPER flexible in terms of hours and location (work from home? No big deal! Got a doctor's appointment? Don't worry about it!) 
- People are genuinely nice, well-meaning and fun to work with
- You learn a LOT of invaluable Big Corporation skills - how to manage up, how to play corporate politics, how to deal with really difficult personalities, how to create pretty PPTs  
- "Do first, ask permission later" culture means you can really drive what you're passionate about
- If you are smart, work hard and carry yourself well, you can take on a lot of responsibility regardless of your age. People generally don't discriminate. 
- Lots of different orgs to move around in, good for lateral moves  
- The Cisco name goes a long way in high tech circles
Cons:
- Constant re-orgs has caused a lot of ambiguity, mistrust, and a highly political environment that has gotten worse in the last 18 months. 
- Everything moves very slowly because there is no ownership or accountability. A lot of people can skate by doing little work as a result. 
- Despite the flex time/location, the company works you hard. You feel pressured to work late into the evenings because everyone else is too. 
- Upward mobility is all about who you know, not how good you actually are. It's also a very slow process. 
- If you're an undergrad, you will be expected to do the work of people who are much older than you for half the pay.  
- People get rewarded for doing things, not getting results. You see a lot of projects being funded that don't make sense if you stop and think about what it accomplishes.

Pros: still a lot of great minds at work, and in some organizations - innovations are still being encouraged.  still the #1 in networking in most market segments
Cons: politics are getting in the way.  people are too busy protecting themselves and are too concerned about who is going to get the credit.  risk taking is no longer the norm but the exception.

Pros:
-If you are a Sr. Mgr (grade 12) and above, your total compensation is pretty lucrative
-Remote working policy is good for those that are not at SJ headquarters or have children to attend to at home
-Still carries a pretty decent brand name on a resume (although no longer the top of the heap in the tech sector, such as Apple, Google and Facebook)
Cons:
-If you are under Sr. Mgr level, salaries and total comp are no longer competitive in the marketplace
-Old, stodgy culture.  Lots of fat cats that do nothing but are collecting huge paychecks and preventing you from advancing
-Very political.  More important who you know and how fancy you can make a PowerPoint than your skillset
-Constant fear of layoffs.  Especially if you are in a high cost location, such as San Jose
-More and more work offshored to India.  Sr. Mgmt doesn't care about getting the best talent, but getting "adequate talent" at the cheapest price
-Not a fun culture.  You go into the office and its completely empty.  Absolutely no sense of camaraderie.
-Dismal outlook.  Earnings are forecast to dwindle as are margins.  Additional layoffs expected.  Very little in terms of raises/promotions
-Too many kool aid drinkers.  You'll see it on this board about it being a great place to work.  Don't believe the hype.  These are people that probably haven't experienced anything else and have already advanced above their skillsets (cannot find comparable pay elsewhere).
-Corporate strategy not in line with industry trends.  Chambers used to be an innovator.  Now he's risk averse and is just milking it until retirement, as the company continues to bleed.

Pros: The flexible benefits package is good, salary and bonus is above average. The technology is interesting. The coffee machines are good.
Cons: It is very hard to get things done inside Cisco. The company feels like it has lost its way. The CEO announces strategies to change the culture of the company, but nothing changes, probably because it is like getting a super tanker to change direction.

Pros: Work life balance is encouraged, leaders are experienced. Lots of options for a recent grad with many different programs and communities that may interest you.
Cons: Very rigid career path, limited job roles; every performance review is more about red tape than it is about helping you. A significant percentage of management are people who are paper pushers and have been career employees at Cisco (think 15-20 years+) who are more concerned about keeping their job than advancing a vision or program.

Pros: been able to develop new markets, new technologies, invent new technologies.
Cons: became large and not agile, slow moving decision making, the field does not have much authority to make business decisions. As an employee you have to manage your own career and HR is unfortunately just an administrative department. This is unfortunate because Cisco has many talents.

Pros: Work with smart, engaged people in a collaborative environment.  The company has the power to shape markets, and has clout when working with customers and partners.
Cons: Always working...no downtime.  It is expected that you are available/accessible at all times, including nights and weekends.  Downsizing has only increased the pressure on those that remain.  There is still too much bureaucracy.

Pros: Above average salaries, great benefits, fun place to work at, very international, very flexible, great in work-life balance, great in "giving back" to the community, encourages volunteering on a regular basis.
Cons: Way too many reorganizations and lay-offs lately in the past 2-3 years, demoralizes employees, works bad on motivation and turns into negative work atmosphere, decreased productivity etc.

Pros: Global scale and reach, philanthropic, relationships with governments of developing countries, democratizing access to information, total compensation (when paying bonuses).
Cons: No clear line of site to revenue growth, so layoffs will continue until 2015 or 2016, and it will be difficult to move within the company.  Poor decisions since 2005 to acquire, and then gut, new business models costing $3B+ per company (Scientific Atlanta, Cerent, Webex, Tandem) and smaller at ~$500M each (Flip, Linksys).  Very slow migration to monetizing SaaS and software in general. Still a very HW-centric mindset.

Pros: Brilliant people, challenging work, supportive work-life balance. Strong commitment to "doing the right thing" - both for the customer & the employees. There is a cachet to being part of such a well-known company.
Cons: office politics: up to about grade 10/11 it's about as strict a meritocracy as you can find. Above that it's politics, politics, politics. There's also a well-supported meme that the best way to advance is to leave, get a title at a competitor, then return.

Pros:
Work from home is possible.
Work quality/opportunities is varying. It has been very good for me.
No. 1 company for networking. Has many teams where you can switch your role easily
Bangalore Campus has excellent facilities like gym, outdoor/indoor sports.
Cons:
Not ideal for freshers as good opportunities are not given in the beginning.
Very frugal in budget. Pay hike and bonus is not consistent. 
The growth cycle is almost fixed and does not give much exceptions to excellent performers.
Work can reduce drastically over some weeks as projects gets cancelled frequently due to high level management issues.

Pros:
Interesting work
Smart people who actually do the work
Flexibility to work from home when needed
Good work/life balance (with the right manager)
Good benefits
Good bonus opportunities
Cons:
Annual layoffs kills morale and productivity every year like clockwork
Promotions based more on politics than capabilities and proven results
Default philosophy seems to be to hire senior talent from outside than promoting from within (even if external hires are clueless)
Salary stagnation
Frequent reorgs tend to just shuffle existing management around rather than solving real problems
Lack of clarity around what is expected and required for promotion
Managers do not invest in their people to develop leadership skills
No career path or advancement opportunities once you reach management position
Executive management is totally out of touch with employees and markets
Executive management seems to believe that reorgs + layoffs = "reinventing the company" year after year
John Chambers' "we are a family" theme may sound nice from the outside but is considered a joke on the inside
Ethics and truthfulness of exec management are questionable at best given annual layoffs, exec raises, and consistently false statements made to press & media about company strategies
Cisco has lost its tarnish and is no longer seen as a cool or innovative place to work
Execs constantly push for innovation acceleration but are unwilling to take any risks required to enable this
Lots of talk by exec management to change things within the company, but such changes usually end up being tactical shuffling of resources
Execs invest in annual Pulse Survey to get employee input but this is just an information gathering exercise that is typically not acted upon

Pros: Company cares about the environment and promotes a fun work place.  There is somewhat a flexible schedule and they promote rotation.
Cons: There is no stability , for the past 4 years the company has laid off many employees and then they open new jobs and does not give the opportunity to these employees to find a job in the area of growth.  Individual contributors do not feel like they can be heard, and when they are, they are usually the ones that are let go.  Company promotes rotation, but it makes it very hard for an employee to rotate .  They have no clear paths to promotion.  There is no life work balance as the hours are long and hectic, although some departments allow employees to work remotely.  The company advertises that there is tuition reimbursement for a career that aligns with the company as a whole, but they fail to let the employee know that if you are rotating to a new department, that department does not have to honor your tuition reimbursement leaving employees with the financial burden or an incomplete degree.   Accounting and Finance culture reminds me of a high school clique , and not everyone is accepted in the circle.

Pros: Some great people with a passion to succeed
Cons: Extremely poor leadership, lack of focus and clear objectives creates an atmosphere of internal competition and jockeying for position. Leftover culture that operates out of fear leads to many talented people either leaving or just putting their head down and doing bare minimum.

Pros:
1. Good work life balance.
2. Many recreational activities.
3. Managers(only to few) are friendly.
Cons:
1. No learning, if you are fresher/mid-level exp, please reconsider.
2. Alot of YOUR salary part depends on company's , teams performance added with Managers favoritism.
3. Management  is filled with ppl stuck there for ages, loads of discrimination.
4. Very unstable, no job security.
5. Lack of training and cooperation.

Pros: Good pay and benefits. HQ buildings and facilities are decent. Networking technology progresses fast, so you're never bored.
Cons: Many projects were underfunded and understaffed, creating significant stress. Lots of bureaucracy and red tape slows progress significantly. The old-timers rub your nose in how great the company used to be (as they coast into early retirement while you do all the work).

Pros: Exciting engaging work with solid peers and managers.   May opportunities to do something different in either bleeding edge or solid workhorse technology.  Solid compensation package.
Cons:
Too addicted to using layoffs to stay competitive instead of investing more in training and developing a learning culture like GE. 

Lost it's fun factor.  Most of the fun elements once standard at Cisco, and common in many Bay Area companies are all gone.

Pros: Some very smart engineers, lot of learning opportunities, some great internal employee groups
Cons: Extremely political environment, cronyism, management lacks leadership, promotion is not necessarily merit based and uneven distribution of workload and type of work

Pros:
Cisco is a reasonably best place to work. Lot of attention to employee needs.  
Generally good atmosphere
Cons: You need to identify your own way of building relationships and cutting through the hierarchy to get visibility

Pros: best place for those who look for the life and balance.   you can always remote access even if you are not at local. plenty of time that you can manage your personal life.
Cons:
lack of young and talented engineers and it looks like a safe place for those who look for safe and easy going environment.
as usual for big company, strong politics and difficult to get promotion unless you are one of their favorate.

Pros:
- Good salaries
- Autonomous working 
- Good working set-up (IT support, smartphone, quick expenses re-imbursement)
- Great training
- Excellent involvement of everyone at all levels in company matters (e.g. at quarterly company meetings)
Cons:
- All flights are in economy, even to Australia
- Too many changes of managers
- Managers not trained well enough
- Masses of jargon, guff and stuff about we're the best when actually Cisco is pretty much like any other tech company out there nowadays

Pros: Cisco benefits and business ethics are great. They are technology leaders and have a lot of interesting work to do. They treat employees well and with respect.
Cons: Doing software in a hardware company always has the big question of whether the software is there to sell the hardware or if the software is a product in itself. This can lead to a tiring tug of war on this topic and recurring reorganizations.

Pros: Good environment to learn different processes, technology and how to work and survive in enterprise environment which runs in different paces depending on which group and project you are on, nice people who are mostly willing to help, teach and collaborate.
Cons: Just like any large companies, sometimes there are too much red tapes and processes that impede the project execution.  Other that, overall good company to work for.

Pros: Average government salaries are competitive with the private and nonprofit sectors. Pay can also increase fairly quickly for top candidates with strong education and experience. Federal benefits, including health insurance, retirement and vacation, are extremely competitive with, if not superior to, other sectors.
Cons: Where do you want to work and live? Whatever the answer, chances are you can find federal government work there. Most people think that federal government jobs are all in Washington, D.C., but in fact 84 percent of federal government jobs are outside of the D.C. area. More than 50,000 federal government employees work abroad.

Pros:
Strong technology leaders
Get to work on latest and greatest in networking
Huge breadth of talent and experience and active projects locally
Opportunities to move internally
Plenty of customer engagement
Cons:
Some antiquated processes
Some antiquated tools
Projects are not globally filtered and ordered so determining which project to work on and when can be chaotic.
Lack of a deep support team means many customer issues make it back to the designers - this could be a Pro but not usually

Pros: Cisco is an established company who knows what they're doing.  They are serious about their image as a family oriented company.  It really feels like you are part of a community, although I'm sure that view changes wildly based on your team.
Cons: They are a large corporation, with a large and strange bureaucracy at times.  Everything moves slowly and requires quite a bit of fighting to get pushed through.

Pros: There are no PROS for this company!
Cons:
They lay people off, then they hire more than they laid off only to squeeze blood from you until there is no more blood to give and then poof your on the unemployment line. 
Management in this place is a joke, they all lie to cover for each other, HR is the worst I have ever seen. They are supposed to investigate claims by employers, they go directly to the manager tell them that there is a compliant against them and then come back and tell you that they found no bass for your claim. JOKE !!! Stay away from these people, you don't need that negativity in your life.

Pros:
Flexible work option. The employees who work on the business side (program managers, business analysts, ops mgrs, etc) are very intelligent and committed to getting the job done and doing what is best for Cisco, not themselves.Lots of great personal perks, i.e. on site health center, doctors, gym, personal heath coaching. HR is trying to make Cisco "fun" again and they are making good progress. 
The new CEO Chuck Robbins is really nice as he looks and he will be a good leader for Cisco. He is focused and committed to making Cisco great again.
Cons:
If you are 30+, I suggest you look for another company because Cisco is interested in a younger employee base (even tho all the Sr. Mgmt except 1) is over 40-50. There are little career advancement for people in this age range.  If you are under 30, expect a lower pay base because of your "lack of experience." They like your new ideas but will not pay you for them. Over the past 5 years I have seen Cisco lay off thousands of "old timers," people who have been there for 10+ years  and who are in the 30s/40s. Focus has been on the new blood, the newly graduated. Avoid IT because their culture is focused on looking good to their management and ignoring what customer and internal tech/users requirement are, very dog eat dog organization.
In San Jose the cafeteria food is expensive and you can get a better meal off site for the same price with better quality.

Pros: Access to some of the smartest people in the world, great salary, remote work culture, and great customers
Cons: Too much internal focus and time spent on "beauty pageants" where SEs are asked to present back to management. It's really a way to prove you're good at your job, but in my opinion a good manager should know without burning valuable time that should be spent focusing on customers.

Pros: Opportunity to work and contribute directly with industry idea / product leaders. Strong in place processes and methods for product management. Opportunity to affect very large scale sales base with exceptionally talented field sales/support teammates. A wide variety of offerings may provide some lateral opportunities.  Decent to better total compensation.  Executive management espouses and somewhat really means the high culture and values.
Cons: Many visions and agendas that can openly conflict are not only tolerated but appear to be accepted by management. While in the past this could lead to good idea competition that could result in multiple winners, it's now become much more one side "We are the only smart, capable team, you are not us, so don't ever think you can" and other side "We must keep going and understand that other investments must be made...oh and ignore that you are often reminded that you are less-thans and treated that way".   Unfortunately this has significantly dropped the professionalism of the organization.  Last, the culture has also shifted strongly to a  high reward for the top few, low reward for the remainder, and removal of any who are not in synch at that time.  This is at odds with the culture and values espoused. The result has been a significant tide of mid-to-high experience staff turn over (8-15+ year staff) for which so many reasons management stated, but first hand knowledge from those staff says they just didn't want to deal with this any longer.

Pros: Great colleagues and many people who are collaborative and willing to work with you. The remote work policy is great with some flexibility. Used to be a great place to work for many years.  Company as a whole is actually pretty pleasant, certain organizations are not.
Cons:
Most unprofessional managers in the last 6-12 mos who feel entitled to threaten and bully employees. Managers asks employees to do work even after having approved PTO days.  

Open space feels like a fish bowl.

Pros:
1. Flexible timings.
2. People in general are helpful. 
3. Food at the cafeteria is great. 
4. There are lot of campus activities like fitness program 'walkathon'
5. Does really good job in CSR activities . Makes on feel good.
Cons:
1. Recognition is one of the low points in the work culture here. People usually doesn't bother to appreciate if some one is doing a good job. 

2. One of the thing which was pretty visible is the managers trying to get noticed to their seniors by simply pushing innovation apps which of not much value add. And who ever is working on major release doesn't get noticed for their effort since its a regular job  and what ever significant value add is considered plain normal expectation.

3. Learning curve for a fresher isn't great. Once you hit a plateau there are very few opportunity to expand your skill set. The consequence you cannot market your skills well outside Cisco and you are eventually locked down at Cisco IT. 

4. Especially senior developers feel unrecognized at times. This makes them feel them they are not that relevant to team and as a result they usually fear when they'll get fired. 

5. Salary hike on an average happens 1-2%  or no hike at all even if your performance is strong for 4 to 5 quarters. 

6. Too many All-hands meeting with the same content..

Pros: Good benefits, decent pay, work/life balance - depends what group you're in but my experience is good.  Many highly educated intelligent people.
Cons: Difficult to get promoted- constant excuses. The people that get promoted are the same people always getting promoted. Many Reorgs. Very political. No longer a stable place to work - constant worry about the next layoff.

Pros: All area of networking are covered Enterprise/Service Provider/Data Center and all industries Medical/Banking/Education/Government/ etc you can therefore find an intersection between your networking interest and its applications. Most products are Linux based and the. Adapted to fit networking purposes with hardware assistance to deliver the most demanding needs.
Cons: The company has a very large existing code base so depending in where you lend it will be more bleeding edge or more core business (more sustaining)

Pros:
Good benefits
Still see vestiges of what was once a great company
Stable in that it has lots of cash in the bank
Cons:
Core business is in transition
Constant layoffs which have little to do with performance but rather how old you are, how much you are paid, or the business unit you are in.
Little opportunity to move within the company.  Movement just tees you up to get pushed out during the next layoff.

Pros: Stock purchase plan, and stock options if your manager saves some for you.  Medical benefits.
Cons: You have to get senior management on your side, or your time is limited.  Very little movement in Senior Management, and the culture is one of always wondering if or when you will get a call telling you your time is up.  No matter how good you have been for the company.

Pros:
Great benefits for employees outside Silicon Valley. Respectable benefits for Silicon Valley Companies.
Generally higher than average local salaries than other companies in RTP.
Many opportunities to learn and grow professionally, so long as you drive your growth.
Top-notch people to work with in US.
Complex technology.
Cisco culture. Have a serious family emergency, or even minor, most groups understand and always say take care of your family. wonderful examples of employees out for 5 months with medical issues, Cisco and individual team took care of them and family.  Child out with serious illness, again most groups really pitch in to help out.
Long term, short term disability outside California is not as good as CA, but better than most companies in RTP. Parental leave meets local laws, but not equel throughout company.
IC's allowed to make deisions
PTO at 4 wks starting can't be beat.
Cons:
Cisco is very risk adverse for long term projects. Some are ahead of their time, but company not willing to develop market or save product for when market is available.
New products only seem to build on existing. Market share loss to cloud vendors, etc. New Security services along with Advanced Sere vices pulling in most of money
Work loads can vary by groups.  Yearly layoffs becoming a thing.  Seems that it's quicker and less expensive to lay off top technical people and hire new ones with some new expertise, rather that really invest in and develop current dedicated staff.
Mobile worker cubes and open work environments not conducive to burying your head into work.
I'm sure there are far worse places to work in North Carolina

Pros: A good Life/ work balance.  Work hard, play hard, rinse and repeat.
Cons: Company is in the midst of re- inventing itself.  As such, many great people have been laid off, and other great people have left on their own accord for much greener pastures.   Morale is very low.  A once great culture has been lost.

Pros:
Still be number one in many areas that inspiring employee to work in Cisco.
Nice relationship among colleagues
Flexibility work style is the key to retain key talents
Cons:
Chinese is difficult to play key business role due to culture and communication challenge.
Cisco China is shrinking, getting old but refreshment of talent is slowing and inefficient. 
Lack of exciting for Cisco China

Pros: The benefits are pretty good. Most teams are set up as smaller businesses inside of Cisco, giving some flexibility with how those business units run. The people including immediate upper management are great.
Cons: Unfortunately, it is still a large corporation and there is always the threat of limited restructuring (layoffs) that are based on how the unit does on a whole. I was recruited out of college and started working on a project that was shut down 3 months after I started due to upper management politics.

Pros:
Good work life balance.
work from home
cabs (you have to pay)
Good initial salary
Good campus.
You can get work on latest tech. It will depend on your BU.
Lots of young people in last few yrs. 
If you are interested in NW tech. This is the place to be.
Cons:
I saw 3 layoff. Doesn't feel good.
Being a giant moves very slowly.
Major work is done in US. Your work will be affected by BU you choose.
All major work is done in master-slave mode. US guys asks report from Indian folks.
Lots of advanced training in US. You don't see them happening in India.

Pros: Flexibility in working hours, locations, great people - team oriented, level of expertise and professionalism, cultural diversity, company culture
Cons: Too many changes too often, virtual working environment is great but it limits the personal contact with co-workers, internally lack of clarity on career path. HR became more of HR operations support rather than HR.

Pros: Good benefits, flexible hours, pockets of good management. Can be a good jumping off point for early in career/fresh out of college folks. Capitalize on the opportunities, training , networking and you should have a pretty risk free start to your career.
Cons:
Layoff culture,  lots of politics and empire builders. Most challenges with the work aren't technical, they're political.  All the red tape and bureaucracy makes delivery slow. 

Like any large company, shareholder value dominates how the "leadership" makes decisions. Culture is more often lip service than it is not.

Pros: Flexible work schedule and many  free managers.
Cons: Sub Par line Managers. People who spent 10 years are sitting in manager roles and want to encourage their personal companies to be benefited. Raising with HR does not call for any changes. Passive upper management entertaining Vendor companies. Individual contributors are forced to hire contractors from the managers  friend's companies so that the line managers could get a cut.

Pros:
>> If you love a multicultural environment, you will love Cisco Krakow.  
>> If you really love challenges (and not as a cliche), you will enjoy Cisco Krakow.
>> Benefits beyond salary could be nice. (Additional cards for spending in cultural/wellness activities and maybe more).
>> Ergonomic offices.
>> When leaving Cisco, companies really value the experience from someone who worked at Cisco. In my opinion more when this person comes from TAC in case of technical roles.
>> You will  literally find "global talented people", super smart and willing to share and teach. So, definitively a place to learn.
Cons:
>> If you do not set a limit or some boundaries to Cisco in your life,  the office (some Cisco guy that you do not know in some part of the world) WILL "swallow you".  It is not a thing of being good, efficient or bad at your position. You have to remember that you are dealing with global customers and their demandings can come at whatever time.  So, if you are considering Cisco, SET BOUNDARIES with your manager and whatever Cisco employee talking outside your working hours with the excuse that you or the customer are in a different timezone.
>> Be careful when management uses expressions like "customer satisfaction", "global visibility" to demand something from you. It is good to help sometimes but again, remember about boundaries.
>> Depending on the department where you are working on, the chances to get promoted can be really hard to achieve.  My advice  ? Be clear with your direct manager and if he/she does not say more than "limited budget", "not a good year", then you should consider to move asap and without hesitating. 
>> If you did not arrive at Cisco with  minimum a grade 8, ohhh God, you are going to be really "squeezed" to get a promotion grade at what you are doing.
>> Offices like Mexico, Belgium and US offer higher grades and promotions a lot easier than in Krakow.  
>> Salary is good for a single person. If your wife/girlfriend/mom/dad/dog/cat cannot work and you are economically supporting them, then I would say you have a lot more interesting offers in Krakow. (In terms of money).
>> Although there are many extracurricular activities and trainings to attend at Cisco, if your department or team is overloaded, then you are not going to be able to take advantage of them.

Pros: At the level of policies(leave, compensation, benefits, bonus) this is one of the best companies to work for.
Cons:
Engineers in India are treated as second class citizens by some managers. If the manager doesn't feel comfortable with you(for some reason that he alone knows) and would like to exclude you he will play with your weaknesses rather than with your strengths. 
This is how its done. Its bit tricky but neatly done. Have patience to read.
'Certain people' will be allowed to work on technologies they already know of (at least to certain extent). Those 'certain people' will be given a good edge on the product knowledge, exposure to other teams, technical discussions, requirements etc., 'Other guys'(the second class citizens) will be given tasks on the technologies that they do not know.  The timeline will also be short and the requirements will not be detailed enough.  The 'Other guys' will need to go behind the 'Certain people' for the details. This will be like you're in mid of a dark forest.
No one will ask whether you know the technology or not.  Nobody will care whether you're interested to work on that or not. You'll simply be forced to do that. In a nutshell you'll be given work in a technology that you do not know, requirements that are not detailed enough and in a short timeline. If you're unable to do this that will be considered as a weakness and will be taken as a good reason for not giving you opportunity to work on technologies that you already know of, interested in and in which you've already proved your skills. The funny part is that the manager himself will not know the technology but he will stamp others who do not know the technology as weak guys and exclude them.
Even when you express your areas of interest that will not be considered as 'Certain people' are already working on that. This double standard is so worse that if nobody in 'Certain people' available to do a work in a technology known to 'Other guys', it will be done even by some other team but never be given to 'Other guys' who belong to the same team. 
Ultimately, what manager wants out of you is the demotivation and he'll get that eventually. The 'Other guys' must work on the spill over work of the 'Certain people'. Thats what ultimately needed.
I certainly don't understand why they recruit engineers in India and try so much hard to exclude them and deliver a crystal clear message that you are not here to do a job that you like to do. Your passion and interests doesn't matter. 
Moreover, false promises on opportunities will be given by the manager on some holiday trip which he forgets as soon as he leaves the city. So, do not trust the promises. The faith will go in vain for sure.
In a nutshell, do better research on the team you're joining. Otherwise, you may regret it and leave soon.

Pros: Excellent salary, best benifits in the industry, my team is amazing.  So much talent, support and Team work happening here.  Onboarding was flawless.  This is where I hope to retire, Cisco has been my  destination for years.   Cisco gives back to the community and World!  I love my job and am so thankful that I am blessed to be part of this amazing company!
Cons: Interview process is fast and you will have 6+ intetviews.

Pros:
International environment, amazing lecturers and a save environment where you can learn from everybody. The mix of technical and sales background it's really accurate and will help you develop high demanded skills nowadays.
After finishing your degree/master, this is an amazing opportunity to start working for a unbelievable company surrounded by young, active people. Definetly a experience to remember for years.
Cons: Selection process is quite intense, you will compete with the best of the best in your country. Being such a big company, sometimes you are overwhelmed by the amount of info, tools, processes and solutions available

Pros:
The technology we have, all the benefits as employee, learning and training possibilities for people who are interested in building an IT Career,
work and sporty culture where you feel included from day 1, that’s just some of them….
Cons:
Could still be better sync between RND/engineering, supply chain and sales, sometimes you can feel that we are two different companies.
Although this is much better now than how it was 3-4 years ago, but when it comes to our common summer and christmas party we definitely 
sync quicker and better.

Pros: Cisco is a great company to work for. Throughout lockdown they have really looked after the staff. We had 2 paid days off. The first a "Day for you" and "A day to reflect" when the BLM movement happened. There are alot of great people and the culture is great! I really recommend it as a place to work
Cons: As its so big you don't often get to know other people in other parts of the organisation that do the same role as you. A forum of POs would be great as a place to learn and share what works well.

Pros: Great people to work with , Cisco culture makes getting along with colleagues you just met feel very natural and it's easy to make life long friends and connections.
Cons:
Company direction has changed , not the same place it used to be. It's moving further and further away from an engineering company to being a sales company. 
Most people are focused on personal growth and what benefits their progression rather than actually doing whats right . 

Advancement is not really based on merit and hard work but rather on who you know and who is willing to sing your praises upwards.

Pros:
There are alot of talented people.
 Some of the initiatives and causes that the company undertakes that really makes it stand out in the corporate world. 

I think the pay is fair if you have the WFH flexibility(which has been in the culture, but depending on org and director/manager ). But now that all other tech are giving flexibility long term what is Cisco selling point.

There is a certain amount of security and stability knowing that your the big gorilla in the in the playground and the company can weather the storm
Cons:
Neoptism, too much given to people who dont contribute vs those that have been there. The established people do the work while the early and late in career get a pass. 

No RSU when you ask it is said that there are none. C'mon senior leaders you think the" middle class" dont talk amongst themselves and hear about who gets it. Since there answer is there aren't RSU's maybe you should give us credit that we can see the stock awards to our leaders who cut 10K people then get 35K shares really you can't take 25K shares and kick 10K down to us. Or how about stop laying people off and buying a 3 Billion dollar company the next week say maybe just once...lets start small dont acquire < 1 Billion company and maybe keep some good people around.

Pros: There are many good reasons to work for Cisco Systems.  In my opinion, the best reason to work for Cisco Systems is the technology you get to work with as an employee.  The breadth and impact the technologies Cisco Systems has to offer to the communities and socienties Cisco serves is enormous.  To have a direct hand in the hardware, software, and business processes that Cisco provides for its customers, knowing the impact you're having, is extremely satisfying.  Other great reasons to work for Cisco is the location.  Cisco's campus is right in the heart of Silicon Valley, where business and technology expands at the speed of human involvement and communication.  To opportunities are great for those who are ready for them.
Cons: There are very few downsides of working at Cisco Systems.  One particular downside is the very large scale of Cisco's business.  Communication between different business units, and venturing through Cisco's intranet can sometimes be challenging.  However, with increased knowledge of the different services available on the intranet, as well as constructing a vast network of colleges within Cisco will make navigating the intranet as well as navigating the Org charts much more manageable.  One further downside to Cisco, particularly in San Jose, is the immense cost of living.  Once you get over the initial price tag shock, you'll be just fine.  Plus Cisco helps to compensate for the cost of living with your salary.

Pros: I love Cisco.  My role in sales is very fast paced and rewarding, both personally and financially.    The Cisco family is unstoppable when it wants to be.  Senior leaders are energized about the company and communicate our vision and strategy with clarity.
Cons: Cisco is a large company with a complex set of corporate initiatives and solutions.  You will need your thinking cap to be successful.

Pros: I worked there as an intern, and thought it was a great place to spend an internship. Cisco has a really laid back, west coast culture, especially the IT group. My manager always listened to our concerns and was understanding about time off and working from home. Overall, a good experience.
Cons: Larger Organization means it's harder to maneuver within the group. I've not experienced this yet, but thats what i've heard. Also, the HR is super disorganized. There was no proper on-boarding process, and i felt like i just fell into my cubicle one day.

Pros: Flexible, good work/life balance, interesting work. The benefits at Cisco were great, plenty of paid vacation, and even had a very nice gym right on the campus. The managers allowed you to work independently as well.
Cons: There weren't too many cons about working there. The company is huge, so it felt like it was difficult to work your way up to higher management, but I wasn't there for very long so maybe it would have been.

Pros: Cisco is a very good in providing training to employees. You will surround yourself with many intelligent people, but there is always politic involved.
Cons: Job advancement is unclear and junior people will most likely not get a promotion for 4 years. Management is very vague abou what it takes to advance and there is no clear description of each level.

Pros:
Can leverage experience into other areas and move around
Work and life balance
Cons:
Inconsistencies across orgs on how training and development budgets are spent; its only as good as the senior vps allot (some changes are in the works, I hear with more classes available that do not hit the budgets as hard)
Political plays get in the way of productivity

Pros: Products are good and challenging for development. Company has good Intellectual Property. Feels good to develop a product which will be quickly deployed by customers.
Cons: Company is very big. No one has any time to talk to colleagues.  Not much fun. Its hard to build any friendships with colleagues.

Pros: Good management, nice people, flexibility to work, work life balance. Good wok content, but you need to be patient as you need to prove yourself internally.
Cons: salary has stagnated. You join the organisation at high salary levels, but the it tends to stagnate. If you have good negotiation skill you end up with good hikes as they can pay the moon, but it end there.

Pros: Great company to work for. Very conscious in supporting minorities. Payment is good. Flexible in working from home.
Cons: internal positions are often filled before jobs are announced. Coming from an acquisition company makes a career in higher management close to impossible. Very American focused on Sahre price of the company instead of the best business plan.

Pros: Cisco invests in its people and gives a lot back to the community. They are a smart and ethical company. They are very good at predicting where the market is going and making sure we have viable products ready for the "next big thing".
Cons: Cisco is very large. You have to take a hand in guiding your own future. They are working on cutting bureaucracy to help simplify and empower employees, but it's a constant battle in any large company.

Pros: Company has amazing reach and allows for massive changes to be done, when looking to get a product out to the field it is a very impressive machine
Cons: Company has outgrown itself, and not only is it no longer nimble, it discourages any fast pace movement in the organization, innovation is to be bought instead of done in house whenever possible

Pros: Competitive salary and great benefits.  Large reputable company.  Depending on what product you work on, you will have all the tools and resources needed to perform well in your job.  Will send you to training if it helps.
Cons: A little unorganized.  Management doesn't seem to be working that hard to retain talent.  Some buildings are outdated.  Company culture needs to work on becoming more helpful.

Pros: Great people, excellent teamwork and collaboration.  Very good benefits abd good compensation, though Sales team compensation expense is "managed" by the setting of unreasonably high goals.
Cons: Has moved to much more "inward" focus.  Increasingly, decisions are politically motivated.   "Limited restructuring" (layoffs) are now part of the culture.

Pros: Use to be great and pretty good layoff packages
Cons: Use to be great.  Now nothing but layoffs and promises of more layoffs.  Moral has crashed and the work environment has turned super negative

Pros:
Good environment. Big company. You get to see a wide range of customers and deal with a lot of people from different paths in the company. Great pay, good bonuses and promotions if you're better than average and the company is doing well.
TAC gets a shift allowance and weekend pay (overtime).
Bangalore employees get cab/van/bus pickup and drop at convenient times.
Cons: Stack ranking. Politics. Stagnant big company feel.

Pros:
Training options are top notch, depending on the year
Remote work is an option, with less than 5% travel
The people working there are some of the best in the world
Cons:
Job security is non-existent
Organizational silos make changing positions infeasible
Upper management is cut-throat whilst the experts have a supportive culture

Pros: Real good benefit, training opportunity, work life balance
Cons: Personal growth is very limited hence promotion is just a dream. upper management make wrong decisions and it impacts regular people. Leadership team make their money with their stock options so they never understand how every layoff impact ordinary people.

Pros: Easy to move between organizations, work-life balance is good, flexibility in working from home is great
Cons: Been a contractor for 6 years. Job stability has never been an issue for me, but the division between red badges (contractors) and blue badges (perm) is frustrating. Red badges don't receive the same training, communications, or opportunities, except that we have the same exact job role as blue badges.

Pros:
- Excellent people to work with. Very fun and friendly atmosphere. There's pretty good "social" perks, like quarterly outings with the team, free donuts and bagels, and even beer on Thursdays. Management even listens to suggestions, and recently starting giving people their birthday off, company-wide!
-There's some pretty neat projects to work on. It's always good working with relevant technologies and picking up skills that are valuable even on other projects and at other companies. I'd argue this is one of the most important aspects of a tech job.
-Cisco is pretty good about recognizing achievements. If you do a really good job, Cisco will recognize you with some award, almost always accompanied by some cash and a goofy but appreciated certificate or plaque or trophy.
-Pretty decent opportunities to move up and get raises. I've only been here a short while, but they do give modest annual raises, and I know people who get promotions every so often.
Cons:
-A lot of the tooling is out of the stone age. It's extremely frustrating when you're trying to build the hot new thing, and you're constrained by tools and systems that have been obsolete for over a decade. In some areas we're using the hottest new things (docker, Jenkins, artifactory, VMware, etc.), and in other areas we're using systems from the 90s (CVS, SVN, a homemade bug tracking system, decade-plus old poorly written perl scripts, etc.)
-Like any company this size, your experience will largely vary on who your manager is and what project you're on. I've personally had a great experience, but I know a few managers (definitely in the minority, but they do exist) who I would have a terrible time working for.

Pros:
* Great Technology.
* Training opportunities.
* Most groups allow flexibility with Working from Home one or two days a week.
* Annual Bonus based on company & individual performance.
Cons:
* Layoffs (Restructuring) occurs on an annual basis.   These restructuring are usually not just for individuals, might be a entire group with the decision made from management so your individual performance is not taken into account.  Not a good environment to feel secure in your job.
* Large company red tap and politics.
* If you do not working at the mother ship location(San Jose) then you're considered a second class citizen.

Pros: Cisco is capturing the transition of the changing work place and workforce.  Never in my career have I been a part of a company that has been able to capture the market transition with a view and ability to translate the change and impact on everyday work for employees.  The concept of digitization and automation is real.  I am watching groups like Supply Chain and HR open the gates to their employees to rethink how work is done.  They are not asking people managers or senior leaders to do this - they are asking employees.  The are looking at full day experiences to break old processes and use new tools to re-invent work. We are telling Cisco how to work differently, using the tools and best practices that we see.  We will learn together.  We get to take simplification and speed to another level.  Every demographic in the workplace can join in to reboot work.  In this digital world the walls must come down, employees must work together to solve problems, motivate each other and bring in the talent to continue the wave.  It is real - Cisco is doing it!  We are connecting everything, benefiting everyone and innovating everywhere!  The culture at Cisco is evolving...Human Resources is standing up in a bold way to be a driving force in how the company evolves.  We all have to step into the conversation and be a part of this change.  Relationships still matter but you also have to think differently - real time.  Nothing remains the same....this is fantastic.
Cons: In order to be a part of the transition, you have to have time to think and solve the problems in a new way.  We work hard and smart.  In this time of change - you must do more.  Work life integration is getting harder.  So remember wherever you are,  you must take time to reflect and rest,  or you will not be able to see the changes you must make.

Pros:
I was always afraid of joining a behemoth of a company: afraid to lose my creativity and individuality. Of course, you're a small fish in a large ocean at Cisco, but I've come to realize/understand that everything (your enjoyment, focus, motivation, loyalty, and on and on) hinges directly on the business unit (BU) and managing chain you're brought into. I was extremely fortunate to have landed in an up-and-coming BU that is constantly heralded as a "do not fail" BU which really keeps you positive. If anything, do your homework and talk to multiple people that work directly in or with your team under the same direct chain of management and pray you'll not be working under an old-school type that refuses to learn new technologies and practices. Some of those guys refuse to accept that it's 2016 and the world has moved on :) Below are some things I find great about working here (keeping in mind both my manager and director are wicked smart and easy-going if you're a hard worker and can prove you're a solid engineer):

* a fantastic work from home policy - I refuse to uproot my family and slog it out in CA where home prices are 4-5x more, so I get an income that basically no other local company can match in overall compensation without moving more into the senior manager/VP positions
* benefits are great - my family uses the high deductible plan which works well for us if you can build up enough buffer in your HSA and take advantage of the hundreds of dollars of HSA  incentives; paid life insurance; paid short- and long-term disability
* structured bonus plan - the bonus is nothing to laugh at and is extremely welcome; it's tied to both your performance (kind of derived by your manager) and the companies metrics (customer service quality, shareholders, revenue, etc) but if both do well your percentage goes up
* 4.5% match, immediately vested, 401k-roth option, brokerage option, bonus matching, bonus stock (4-year vesting)
* BU-dependent, but budget for training, conferences, books, classes, etc are all very good if you choose to use them
* perks galore - I guess I didn't realize that with thousands of employees comes greater purchasing power, so various discounts on anything from Whirlpool appliances and movie tickets, to reduced cell phone bills and (I kid you not) solar panel installs. You may not use all of what's available or even care, but to even provide so many different ways to save you cash on things you're going to buy will lead to more compensation
* the career path and income increases in all former jobs has been engineer, senior engineer, (maybe principal), manager, glass ceiling...then what? More management? At Cisco they have two paths: management and engineering. The roles and responsibilities increase as you go up levels in either of those paths, as well as the pay and perks, however, they understand that good engineers may want to remain engineers, and they reward their great ones accordingly. I think this is in my top 3.
Cons:
* Kind of an ongoing reorganization (aka, forced layoffs) discussion that seems to have been a strong theme the last few years, but nothing really negative as happened yet. I believe there's a severance package if this does happen to you?
* Like many places, your peers could be complete duds, which forces you to pick up their slack or else the entire team including yourself look terrible...but, without any "real" guidelines in place to let these people go they kind of hang around and leach off the company and their peers
* I've been here over a year and through various conversations with my peers I've discovered that I should probably be a level above where I'm at now, however it is not really clear at all how you move up

Pros: Flexible work schedule, can work remotely as needed in most groups
Cons: low pay raises or none at all even when company performs well, lots of bad managers, discriminatory work environment tolerated and managers who are leading such groups and who are also practicing such type of behavior continue to have senior leadership roles even when complaints come and people leave.

Pros:
Flexibility, great benefits, competitive salary, positive work environment
Have worked at another company since leaving and realized how well Cisco takes care of their employees. Current employees should be very thankful because the grass is definitely not greener on the other side.
Cons: The area the company needs to focus on is laying off the employees who are not performing or are on performance improvement plans. I saw a lot of very talented and intelligent employees with proven track records get impacted by the layoffs and noticed the under performing employees are still there.

Pros: Probably one of the few very good places to work. truely innovative and flexible, great plans, strategy, people and modern.
Cons: for some poeple who come from other companies cisco might be difficult to find Your way in, as it is basically all self Service and you have to proof Your self - but that is ecactly why its good

Pros: Lots of spare time, you can pretty much do your own business. Good gym. Free dinner (at least my BU has free dinner), free snacks and fruit. Cisco daycare is the best in Bay Area (but expensive too).
Cons: Slow promotion, miniature RSU, lack of innovation, politics, low pay compare to Google Facebook Apple Amazon same position, internal IT support sucks, no training no room to learn.

Pros:
Work life balance is huuuuge with Cisco. Most non-engineering employees are completely free to work remotely. Cisco practices what it preaches by allowing employees to use webex and work from ANYWHERE. 

The pay. In general, Cisco pays in the 80th percentile so if you work their, it's difficult to leave for financial reasons
Cons: Remote work has real downsides. If you're not in San Jose, exposure and career growth can be difficult. Engagement can be an issue when your only encounters with real life people come at starbucks

Pros: You have flexibility to work from home or a remote Cisco location. They have best immigration lawyers if you're on a visa. The employee benefits are awesome! The culture is pro-employees. Management really takes care that employee are not working on weekends. And if you do, then you get compensation offs. They have great trainings for employees and a set budget assigned to each. You can switch comfortably within the company which grows every year with a new acquisition.
Cons: Just filling up the 5 word minimum. I have absolutely no cons to say.

Pros: Great adoption of technology, great collaboration tools for working with colleagues (eat their own dog food).   Great people.
Cons: Very big.  San Jose is the center of the world.  Having to make technology pivots where older products are slowing down, therefore quite a lot of restructuring.  They used to treat employees like "family"...I don't think this is the case today.

Pros: There are lots of resources and if you're willing to put in the work, you can find opportunities to learn and grown. The company is a tech giant, and is also focused on innovation and community engagement. There is a focus on developing women in leadership roles and connecting women within the organization
Cons: Can be bureaucratic and hard to navigate. Duplication of effort is not abnormal because there are so many people working towards the same or similar goals. Not all managers are created equal.

Pros: Great benefits, awesome culture, ability to work with intelligent peers and managers who are willing to help when you need it. My position is also highly flexible, which is one of the greatest benefits.
Cons: Cisco can operate as a large company and sometimes this impedes the ability to get things processed quickly. In addition, the diversity at Cisco can be improved. Cisco is great about hiring women but can hire professional of different ethnicities to improve overall diversity. Overall, awesome place to work!

Pros: Cisco has historically been a one of a kind culture where employees love network technology and enjoy the fast pace.
Cons: Burn out among top performers pushes them out and Cisco struggles to replace them. Quota's increase, and new employees more frequently come from other sales specialties and consequently know very little about network technologies. Politics are getting worse with each year...

Pros: Forward looking culture.  Great work schedule flexibility, pay, and benefits.  Tremendous collaborative culture.  Worked with some of the smartest professionals I've encountered during my career.  Empowerment to drive innovation and personal brand.
Cons: Because even a single team can span the globe, the non-traditional work schedule that is so wonderful can also intrude upon "non-working" hours.  The flexible location / virtual collaboration philosophy that Cisco markets is limited and doesn't always apply to positions that can effectively be managed remotely; there remains core belief that synergy is more effectively driven physically.

Pros:
This is a great sales training rotational program for people with sales experience who want to first learn about and understand the Customer Success role. Cisco in general is an amazing company to work for and our leaders are just that; intelligent, committed, individuals who strive to ensure our success.

Customer Success is the new era of sales and I would highly reccomend this position. This role is unique in how it exposes you to the new way of not just selling products, but selling business outcomes. It's also exciting for those who like to innovate, value relationship-building with the customer, and pioneer new processes and ideas. I really enjoy being able to have direct impact at a company this big and being a member of the Customer Success Team here at Cisco gives you that unique opportunity. 

I can't emphasize enough the responsiveness of our executives and leaders; I'm honestly amazed at how Cisco has given new employees the ability to have exposure with our senior management and how willing and compasionate they are about our sales team.

I would reccomend Cisco, Customer Success, and Sales to anyone, hands down.
Cons:
Working at a fortune 100 company as large as Cisco, especially as we migrate our revenue model and product offerings, means there will be holes. I think this is natural at any large company but the mindset of adapting to ever-changing processes, acquisitions, etc. is crucial in order to thrive. Not necessarily a con if you like a challenge and put in a lot of effort. 

No "work from home" but not necessarily a con either; I personally prefer to come in the office but just something to keep in mind as people have different views on this.

Pros:
I started working at Cisco immediately after graduating college. I was placed in operations and was able to learn some valuable generic business skills. Although the role wasn't necessarily a good long term fit for me, I was able to find a new job within Cisco IT after about 2 weeks of looking for something new. This new role has been amazing! I have a manager who is flexible with my work hours, coworkers who are fun and hard-working, and work that makes me feel fulfilled. Every time I talk to my family about my job and work/life balance, they are amazed and advise I stay at Cisco for as long as I can. I believe I am paid well for my status of early in career and I am learning a lot of skills that will be beneficial in whichever line of work I do. Management is great and I feel that out of the three managers I've had, each one of them were attentive to my personal and career growth. 

I have not had any experience at other corporate workplaces, but I know that I have fallen in love with the culture of Cisco. I feel as if this is a safe place with no judgments, people who care about you, and provides an open work environment. Definitely a great place to work and I highly recommend!
Cons:
Cisco is a large company and therefore, it can sometimes take a while to get things done due to red tape. I personally have not encountered this problem yet but have heard stories. 

Even though I am lucky to be on a team with an average age of about 26, many people who work at Cisco are a little older (or wiser). As an early and career worker, it can sometimes be difficult to relate to those who are 20+ years older than I am but that doesn't mean they are any less nice.

Pros:
Joining as a graduate and having been part of other graduate roles with other companies that I won't name, Cisco really devotes a lot of time to training and developing their employees. The interview process did not accurately reflect the culture that lies within Cisco, one that truely cares and provides meaningful work.

As someone who struggled with the quarter life crisis, wondering if a terrible 9-5 job for the rest of my life in 'mundane corporate' doing pretty much nothing but pretending to look busy whilst shuffling numbers on spreadsheets or doing meaningless presentations no one cares about, Cisco definitely changed my perspective on corporate life.

The work is meaningful, it gives me purpose, and whilst it is challenging, you are adequately rewarded and then some. The people are excellent and if you are passionate about technology, this is the place to be. A moral and ethical company, I strongly feel that Cisco is a great place to work. I highly recommend to anyone who were overachievers in high school and university who feel like their talent is wasted at other companies to apply to Cisco as they will push you to your best.
Cons: There is some cons to mention however. Again and again, I keep seeing people who are toxic to the organisation promoted. Positive encouragement and a flexible culture should be fostered and those that promote this culture of pushing boundaries, thinking outside the box, creativity, and making decisions with a bit of gut should be moved forward. Those who hold a traditional view of the office, making every i is dotted and every t is crossed, with their archaic ways and no value add to the company should be kept in positions where they have no influence over the culture or better, removed.
